name: La Présidente. –
text: Dear colleagues, our debates are very late, so I am going to have to stop accepting blue cards and I am going to ask you once again to respect your speaking times.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President! After the Brexit shock, the citizens of Europe gave the institutions a new leap of faith, the polls say. Whether we justify this leap of faith and thus politically strengthen the foundations on which this project stands depends - I fully agree with Mr Reul - on whether we deliver very pragmatically. It's not about continuing to promise, it's about delivering. And I always get scared when I hear from the Council earlier: “The Youth Guarantee will be continued.” This language clearly promises: nothing new is coming! Something new could be the European Solidarity Corps that you spoke about, President Juncker. I think that would be worth a lot of social initiative. But we don't just need the reallocation of funds to do this, we also need the determination to do a lot more. And if you say: “The young people react positively”, then let us give a clear signal that we are daring a new start. I believe, Mr President Juncker, that a major weakness in the agenda of what we have to deliver is the weakness that Europe is currently less ambitious in industrial policy than it was in the Barroso II era. You have to change that!

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - We are constantly talking about migration and security, but action on these issues is completely inadequate, even for our languages.We do not have the global security strategy that the Council is about to talk about.There is only the interest of the individual larger countries of the European Union in that security and defense strategy.We do not have a migration strategy.The second issue will be discussed again by the Council.There will probably also be discussions in the speeches about Turkey's progress or agreements with African countries.Don't expect concrete solutions?I am just fascinated by your naivety.Gentlemen, let us stop talking about side things and start discussing the essentials that are important to ordinary Europeans who want only one thing: to live in their own country, to work, to earn money, to build their lives in their homeland, where no newcomers would dictate their rules.I hope that European leaders will be able to understand that.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that this debate is surreal, it confirms that those who govern this Europe, the European Commission, are few strong powers and few dangerous subjects. Not a word on Islamic extremism, not ISIS, we have discovered that the enemy of Europe and the world is Russia, Putin, the ongoing clandestine invasion must continue to be financed, Turkey can safely continue to dialogue with Europe and with the billions that Italians and Europeans are giving it. I remind President Juncker that, while he is chatting, in recent years more than eight hundred citizens have committed suicide for economic reasons in Italy, then to the ramblings of the right and left who are looking for populists, extremists and fascists everywhere and who believe that Putin is in charge of having blood on my hands I reply with the words of Pope Francis' vicar, Monsignor Khazen, who says that, speaking of Syria and Aleppo, this Christmas will have another scent for the liberation of the city, people have joy, optimism and hope. So get your feet back on the ground, not least because you have little left to govern this European Union that has become a madhouse.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Madam President, this is the third Christmas I have celebrated here as an MEP. Whilst I watch Members of this House enjoy lavish drinks receptions and parties, I think of the millions of European families who will have a different Christmas caused by the EU’s failed policies, thinking, and the euro; one of unemployment, one of poverty, one of austerity.  And whilst I supported Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, I will also be thinking of Charles Dickens’s three ghosts in his book A Christmas Carol. The ghost of Christmas Past was the British people’s yearning for a lost freedom and self-determination. I see the ghost of Christmas Present as Brexit, a messenger of hope, and I glimpse the ghost of Christmas Future, where Britain’s prosperity will be engaging with other countries across the world. I quote from Dickens: ‘I will honour Christmas in my heart, and try to keep it here all year’. I only wish the European Union would do the same for its people, but nonetheless, Merry Christmas to you all.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: - The summit closes the year 2016, which was dominated by bad news from both the European Union and the European Union's environment. The consolation prize may be news from the labor market, which is actually more lively than ever before. After 2013, the Union created eight million new jobs. The unexpected result of the British referendum in the form of increased trust in European institutions may also be a consolation. The agenda of the next summit includes migration, security and youth opportunities. It is indeed a decisive battlefield against populism and nationalism, which was the cause of the greatest misfortunes of our continent. Also in 2016, it dictated not only the work program, but also the tone of public debate, as well as the fears and moods of European citizens. I know that it is not easy to put emotions into rational programs and hit our message to the young generation, which did not experience the consequences of the nationalisms and selfishness that destroyed our continent. New, thrilling visions of reinventing Europe are not a prescription. We already have the appropriate programs, the passwords also sound nice - Valletta Action Plan, Internal Security Strategy, Defense Union - but you still have to convince yourself that it works. The Union must convince the average citizen with its usefulness, and this is what I wish it to do in 2017.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - The time to end the massacre in Aleppo is long gone. Collectively, we failed and we failed to provide security for the people. I therefore call on the summit to do its utmost to alleviate the situation. Colleagues, we still do not have working measures to address the challenges of security and migration. Mr Juncker, you mentioned the ambition to return to Schengen. By what arguments does neighboring Austria still have border controls? I'm from Slovenia. Does the Commission allow this? Why? There are no reasons. It is an unnecessary obstacle to the travel of our citizens and has created a great deal of resentment. Moreover, it created an atmosphere in my country so that when the refugees arrived again, a third of Slovenes would completely close their borders. She created such an atmosphere. Distrust of European solutions. And this mistrust, which is growing not only in Slovenia, worries me greatly. We need a functioning and humane European migration policy. I am sorry, but the proposal to overhaul the Dublin reform is also not a proposal that would revive solidarity and shared responsibility. On the contrary, countries with an external border will still suffer the greatest burdens. Not to mention the inability and lack of courage to open up legal and safe routes for migrants to Europe. Colleagues, tackling the situation of migrants must go hand in hand with strengthening Europe's economy and jobs. And in a situation where it is boiling around us, we need a strong Europe and the trust of Europeans.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: - 4,733: So many people drowned in the Mediterranean in 2016, families, mothers, fathers, children.That is a living shame.4733!We must ask ourselves whether the European Union is really doing everything it can to stop that.Yes, we now come with the new Coast and Border Guards.Yes, there are new plans from the European Commission to improve the situation in Africa so that fewer people leave.But let's be honest, that won't reduce drowning.For that we need an ambitious anti-drowning plan for the entire Mediterranean, with pushbacks, with maximum limits, with ambitious readmission agreements for various countries in the Maghreb.That's what it takes.That must be our priority.But let's not kid ourselves.Winter is upon us.Spring will be there very soon.If we don't act now, if we don't act now, the Mediterranean will remain a mass grave and that is unforgivable.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin. Caithfidh mé a rá go bhfuil EFSI agus an tionscnamh, ‘Ógfhostaíocht’ go bunúsach thar a bheith lochtach. Seasann dífhostaíocht ár n-óige in Éirinn, mar shampla, os cionn 15% leis na céadta mílte dár n-aos óg ar imirce cheana féin. Labhraimid mar gheall ar ár ndaoine óga mar dhream éigin atá sa todhchaí agus ní thugann an Chomhairle aon tosaíocht dóibh inniu, ach b’fhéidir sa todhchaí. “Mair, a chapaill agus gheobhair féir” is é an dearcadh gan aon infheistíocht láithreach a chur ar fáil chun fostaíocht a chruthú chun deis a thabhairt dár bpobal óg saol a chruthú dóibh féin. Teip mhór eile, gan dabht, is ea EFSI nó plean Juncker. Fós, gan aon torthaí suntasacha le feiscint, níl sé trédhearcach, níl sé ag freastal orthu siúd atá i gcruachás i dtaobh rochtain ar airgead chun infheistiú in SMEnna; níl aon rud simplí faoi agus, cinnte, níl sé ag freastal ar na comharchumainn ná ar an bhfiontar sóisialta mar a bhí geallta. Táim ag glaoch anois ar réiteach a fháil air seo, leis an gcruinniú seo atá ag teacht aníos; agus achmhainní fónta a chur ar fáil seachas bheith ag teip ar an bpobal arís agus arís eile agus ag sodar i ndiaidh na mbodairí móra!

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: - Madam President!Thanks for the word.It is astonishing to hear you say that the EU is delivering.That the EU has control over migration flows.I wonder - what naive world do you really live in?The truth is the complete opposite.You are in the trap of blackmail with the Turkey agreement, where the EU chooses to be blackmailed by a country where democracy, human rights, freedom of the press and freedom of expression are completely ignored.The EU is in a situation where President Erdoğan is saying 'jump' and you have no choice but to jump.The truth is, Mr Juncker, that what you call "team Juncker" is a sign of failure and failure.But of course you do not have to worry about that in your privileged life.With the salary and the benefits you receive, you can sit back in the armchair and enjoy your brandy and let the taxpayers take the slap.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! We are talking about Syria, and Putin has blood on his hands, that has been heard several times today. Let me remind you that the first genocide in Syria took place against Alevis during the civil war, and blood is on the hands of those who welcomed the Arab Spring back then and, above all, gave it military support. The European Commission's answer to this is to partner with Turkey. May I remind you that five hundred thousand refugees, Turkish refugees within Turkey, are currently on the run from Mr Erdoğan - your partner! What is interesting, however - and this can be seen from today's debate - is the state of the European Union. Mr. Weber from the CSU defines the progressive forces based on the standards of a communist. Mr Verhofstadt is afraid that we will actually put forward arguments. Where is Mr. Verhofstadt's self-confidence that he normally carries in front of him like a mantra?

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the European Union offers solutions, but the information does not always reach our citizens. Europe still lacks too much visibility, and too many unanswered concerns. The recent elections unfortunately prove me right. The migratory pressure is thus the first concern of our fellow citizens. Europe's ability to respond to them will be decisive for its future. This is why I welcome the first reintegration agreement, which was thus signed with Mali and which makes it possible to address the problem at the root. That said, border control really remains the major issue. The instability of the world is another source of anguish and what is happening in Aleppo is a tragic example on our doorstep. The Europeans must hold a place which will be difficult, between the Russia of Vladimir Putin and the United States of Donald Trump, and we will have to recreate this "European leadership" and the community method must find its place again. The situation in Syria, the various attacks in France, Belgium, Germany, the fate of Eastern Christians must also guide us towards a strong and independent common defense policy to ensure our protection, but they also oblige us to strengthen our development policy on the African continent. The Brexit negotiations are finally an opportunity to assert our authority and our firmness, to show those who elect us that their leaders keep their word. To successfully exit the UK before the 2019 European elections, we need to speak clearly. Ambiguity only serves the interests of Eurosceptics and demagogues.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Europe is at a crossroads; we have citizens calling for stronger solutions when it comes to economic, social and security fronts, and we have not only populist movements but nationalistic movements arguing that the best way to protect citizens is just to go back to national borders. This is a total mistake and a total illusion. We need to have much better European solutions, and this is the responsibility of the next meeting of the European Council.  We approve the idea of moving forward European defence capacity and bringing about a real European border; but we also must deliver on a real asylum system with relocation and resettlement of refugees. Otherwise, this is a total shame. We agree that we need to have a new phase of the European Fund for Strategic Investment and we need to have new life for the Youth Guarantee, but let me tell you: this is not enough to address the problem of jobs we have in Europe.  We need to have an industrial policy in Europe, we need to have an agenda to complete the economic and monetary union. Otherwise, this is not a real solution; and more than that, just jobs is not enough. We need to have decent jobs. That is why the European pillar of social rights is a basis which is coming up in the European Parliament, and the Council should build on that, so we are waiting for better solutions on the social front also.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: –This Parliament wants to freeze accession negotiations with Turkey.Stopping in the end would be much better, but we have certainly taken a good step forward.The prisons in Turkey are full of opposition parliamentarians, journalists, students and various minorities.With every criticism from Europe on his person or on his country, Erdogan threatens to reopen the flow of refugees.Erdogan blackmails the European Union with the refugee deal.But we know that Turkey is not a safe country.Turkey is violating the rights of refugees in the southeastern part of the country.And it is completely unclear in whose pockets the billions of EU money for refugee reception disappear.Europe itself must resolve the issue of asylum and migration.Deals with third countries can help, but not this blackmail deal with Erdogan.Tomorrow, let the Council stop or, if necessary, freeze Turkey's accession.And finally, a question for you: where has Mr Juncker gone?

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President! Thanks so much! Colleagues! Commission! The advice! There is starting to be an unbearable gap between words and deeds. What the EU claims to stand for and what it is actually doing. Peace means armaments and militarization and a rapprochement with NATO. It's a dangerous road to walk. That's the way to go. EU development aid should no longer go to poverty reduction, but should fund migration control, as it is called, in third countries. It even cooperates with oppressive regimes. All to stop people on the run. It's time to stop sitting on Erdoğan's lap. It is time to end the agreement, and the only way to do that is to organize a dignified reception for more people seeking protection in Europe. Colleagues! Words and deeds must go together. We must show real respect for human rights and the rule of law, and we must show real solidarity with people on the run. Redistribution of refugees from Greece, more legal routes to Europe and a dignified reception here.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Madam President, tomorrow you should reflect on what a great year it has been for democracy: Brexit, the election of Mr Trump, and the great work done by our Austrian friends in their presidential elections. Let us not forget the Ukraine referendum in the Netherlands and the ‘no’ vote against Renzi in the Italian referendum.   And the best is yet to come. In the UK and in the USA, the people are taking back control. You hate referendums and would rather have them banned here. Fortunately, we have an exciting year coming up, full of general elections. In March, we have the Dutch elections where Geert Wilders is likely to become Prime Minister; in April, we have elections where Marine Le Pen is likely to become President; and in September, the Alternative für Deutschland will continue its rise in Germany. The people are rejecting your asylum and migration policies. They don’t want EU trade schemes; they don’t want EU armies, nor your obsession with gender and windmills. None of your plans will survive the coming years, because the peoples of Europe have had enough. Democracy will prevail. You condemn the populists, but you’re happy to consort with communists and extremists on the left. However, I wish you all a Happy Christmas and a very good New Year.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: - Madam President! We continue to say that we have many critical problems in the European Union, although we also confirm that it is better than a year ago, in 2015 in December. I would also like to thank the Slovak Presidency for this six-month operation at a difficult moment. Migration, security - both internal and external, energy security, economy and employment are de facto key problems at present. Many of these problems connect us in the European Union because we have many problems that divide us. And I would like to say here that the difficult relationship, in terms of migration, with Turkey is also a serious challenge to security and stability. Turkey is an important economic and military partner - after all, it is one of the main partners in NATO. At the same time, the joint statement of the EU and Turkey played a key role in the practical limitation of the influx of migrants to Europe, the so-called along the Balkan route. Regardless of all critical assessments in this regard, the recent attempted attack in Turkey, but also the internal reaction of the government in Ankara, put this cooperation to a great test. The problem of immigration is not only a problem of the EU. It is also a global problem, and we must constantly emphasize this as to the sources of an effective response, and here the internationalization of this problem is needed. Undoubtedly, we must also count on the implementation of the Valletta plans, including the acceleration of work related to external investments, which can be very helpful.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Better with Europe than without Europe: That was the simple conclusion of the presidential elections in Austria. But now, please, action, please act at the European Council, because the citizens want to see results too. Yes, the Youth Guarantee is a wonderful, good and correct European invention. The Council, the Commission and, above all, the European Parliament have done the right thing. Unemployment in Europe has fallen on average among young people, but of course it is still unbearably high: 18.4% of young people in Europe are unemployed on average. If we now look at what it looks like with those young people who are not in training, who enjoy no education and are not employed at all, then it is sad. There are 13.2 million so-called needs. Much more is necessary here than what has happened so far. So, I know that the Youth Guarantee will be increased by EUR 2 billion by 2020, but of course that is a drop in the ocean. It is the right measure, but far too little is invested in young people. That is why the subject of investments is so extremely important, namely that more happens here. So tomorrow don't just evaluate the EFSI, i.e. the Juncker Fund, which is named after the Commission President himself, but think about how it can be used more efficiently and effectively so that new funds are ultimately used to really finance projects, that appeal to the citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the European Council will discuss youth unemployment, a problem that plagues my homeland Croatia. Since becoming an MEP, I have been emphasizing that insisting on mobility may lead to a beautification of statistics at EU level, but it opens up a whole range of other major problems. Today, young people from Croatia easily go to work in other members of the Union. Wealthier members get skilled workers, and Croatia records a sharp drop in unemployment. Politicians on both sides are rubbing their hands contentedly. One because they import good workers who integrate quickly and easily into society, and the other because they can boast of nice statistics. However, only a few seem to understand that Croatia and other members who are in a similar situation will very soon get into terrible economic and social problems that will have to be remedied by more developed members. Youth unemployment should be addressed at the level of each Member State separately, and not by the migration of peoples from less developed to richer Member States.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Council. A plethora of ideas, plans, speeches, decisions ... Now another council meeting follows, with another line of speech. I can only hope that this council meeting will be fruitful, much more productive than it has been so far. However, I would like to congratulate the Slovak Presidency, which has done a particularly good job this semester and tried to address all the issues that are our priorities properly. Yet we are talking about migration now. Two years after this huge migratory pressure began. Two years after some Commission officials even talked about not even migratory pressure. We now have an agreement that is full of doubts. An agreement that is actually outsourcing a job. We have left the problem here as we try to find a solution outside. And this agreement is very difficult to maintain. It's full of worries. His non-compliance, on the other hand, could lead to the Greek situation, the Greek refugee situation, getting worse and worse. These people cannot be sent back to Turkey, asylum agencies say Turkey is not safe. We want to entrust the solution to a country that is not secure. Here is .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: - Madam President!Control external borders!Everyone agrees that it will be the same tomorrow in the Council.But is it really about control or is it more about closing down?Just don't let any more refugees in.Indeed: hardly any movement in legal routes to Europe, only slow distribution of refugees in all member states, insistence on the Dublin system.And on top of that the fearful adherence to a deal with Turkey, a country in which judges, journalists and teachers are fired or imprisoned en masse, as well as repatriations to countries like Afghanistan.Doubtful, also because Parliament's right to have a say in returns and international agreements is cleverly undermined.But only together and based on democracy and the rule of law can we shape major challenges sustainably.Tomorrow the Council could think about it - but I don't dare to wish a Merry Christmas just yet.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the last Council of 2016 is necessarily that of the balance sheet of the year and, possibly, that of the mid-term, in my opinion, positive. But it is even more that of the projections for the next year. On migration, remarkable work has been done. The foundations for a new holistic approach and partnerships have been laid. So, it seems to me that the priority for 2017 must also be the external investment plan for the neighborhood and Africa, to really tackle the roots of irregular and uncontrolled migratory flows. Two remarks in this context: It is crucial that the economic environment is improved for the plan to work. Our partners must carry out the necessary reforms, as Tunisia is currently doing. Secondly, on the new partnership framework - it must be remembered - we can only succeed with countries that show a willingness to work with us, including with readmission agreements, and if the Member States actually use the value added Union. On security, notable progress has been made: the Border and Coast Guard Agency and an agreement on the Anti-Terrorism Directive. But in the face of today's threats, the internal and external dimensions merge. We need a Europe of defense. The Commission has made proposals, the ball is in the court of the Member States to transform the repeatedly repeated wishes into action. Finally, a remark about Ukraine. You're going to talk about the Association Agreement, but let's talk about visas. It is high time that the Union delivered visas for Ukrainians today. The criteria are met.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, it is not enough to mourn the dead in Aleppo, it is necessary to arm the negotiating arm of the European Union. For this, obviously, a defense is lacking. I welcome the fact that this European Council is tackling the issue of defense head on. You have to be consistent. There will be no defense without more spending. Member States will have to take their responsibilities. We must do it all the more so than in the United States, the victory of Mr. Trump indicates the disengagement that this state will bring to the security of Europeans. We will face our responsibility. But, during this European Council, the Commission must act to ensure that the Heads of State and Government, while they are still awaiting Article 50 from the United Kingdom, do not stand idly by, so that they must think about the future of the citizens of the European Union. For that, we need President Juncker to resume his pilgrim staff to bring the report of the five presidents to life and finally achieve a sustainable economic and monetary union.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the tragic events in Aleppo were described by many of my colleagues, but I want to say that they illustrate the very serious problem that we are facing. This is the problem of the inability to act even in such a dreadful situation. President Juncker has mentioned that we are working, and some of our work is delivering results, and I see some improvement in the area of economy and others. Initiatives such as EFSI or the European Solidarity Corps are very good ideas that will make life in our part of the world better, and we should we should keep going in this direction, but at the same time I firmly believe that the priority for the year to come is in other areas. This is the area of security and defence in a broader and more strategic sense. These are areas in which we need to act together as Europeans and also as responsible members of NATO. It’s not enough to have a good security system, good weapons and dedicated soldiers: we must know what we really want and have the courage to take the necessary actions. That is why I am calling for the representatives of the Member States in the Council to have more courage to formulate our foreign policy and to take responsibility to act. Otherwise, the dreadful events in Aleppo – the tragic stories we were hearing about yesterday – will simply not come to an end.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Turkey was hit again by an awful terrorist attack last weekend. This time it was in Istanbul. I would hereby like to express solidarity with the Turkish citizens, and especially with the families and friends of the victims. To fight against terrorism is our joint duty, and Turkey can count on our support.  The topic on the plate of the EU leaders is how to react to the internal developments in Turkey. When it comes to the European Parliament’s call to temporarily freeze the accession talks, I am glad to see that, for the first time, there seems to be a clear majority of Member States willing to give a political signal. The signal is that under the current circumstances, the EU’s approach can no longer be ‘business as usual’. Member States seem to be united along the position that no new chapter should be opened in the negotiation process. Although that doesn’t go as far as our call, it does indicate that EU leaders are finally taking the clear position of Parliament – the position of our citizens – seriously.  It is important that we send a joint signal from the European Union that Turkey must return to the path of democratic reform and respect for the rule of law. I hope that the 28 EU leaders will manage to come up with a unanimous statement. Talks on accession are now not credible, but that doesn’t mean that we should stop our dialogue with Turkey. This dialogue, however, cannot be limited solely to cooperation on migration. It cannot be limited only to the implementation of the EU-Turkey deal.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would essentially like to start by pointing out that next year will be a very unstable and uncertain year for the European Union. Therefore, it is essential that the Council and the Commission, but in particular the Council, are able to maintain some stable policies that were already designed. The first had to do with the external borders and the Coast and External Guard, and here we need to give a huge boost, because it is evident that we are going to have a bigger refugee crisis, and here I accompany my colleague Mariya Gabriel in all politics prevention measures that we have to do in North Africa and, in particular, also in the Middle East. This is a point. A second point that I consider to be fundamental has to do with the Union's economic, financial and banking issue. I think that it is now essential to complete the banking union and, even before that, it is essential that the members of the Council and the Commission, even within the scope of their powers, even if only as, say, leading political actors, they contribute to the financial and banking stabilization of the entire Union. who are much more distressing from a humanitarian and Union values ​​point of view, will be at risk. I therefore ask for all the urgency for this issue.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Aleppo lies massacred, Putin and Assad exult. Unable to act, what remains of credibility for the European Council? The European Union fails because it is missing. In Ukraine, attacked and occupied by Russia, and in Syria, in Iraq, in Yemen, in Libya, in Palestine, where Member States not only do not coordinate, but compete to sell arms and other sordid deals with regimes that make wars for power of attorney, instrumentalizing terrorist groups such as the Saudi, the Catari, the Turkish - I am not exhaustive. No wonder Putin, Erdogan, soon to be Trump, are fond of blackmailing a Europe in anti-integration intergovernmental setback, in tow of a German government, without strategy, which may want to appease, but in fact feeds xenophobic populisms. From the incomplete euro, which sows divergence and inequality, to non-harmonized taxation, which distorts the internal market and takes advantage of corruption and organized crime, through Fortaleza Europa, which delivers migrants and refugees to traffickers' networks and radicalises their own young people, giving recruits to the terrorist hydra: this is not the European Union of peace, human rights, solidarity and progress. This intergovernmental Europe does not protect or defend us: it is destroyed, jeopardizing our security and global security.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! On this issue of the issues to be dealt with tomorrow, too, we were not lacking in resolutions or proposals. We just lack political will! Nationalisms, populisms and the politics of isolation are still blocking the implementation of the agreements. And unanimity still blocks the necessary European unity. So I say very clearly: agree on what has been proposed and do what has been decided. The fight against unemployment is not just a question of money, but has mainly structural causes. These are a question of education and training, of investing in sustainable growth and new jobs, of tax and budget policy. Here, too, it is important to learn from one another and to act with one another, to develop the European Union from a monetary union to an economic, social and investment union. The same is true of defense policy. I welcome the action plan that we are working together on research, procurement and financing. But we have a blatant implementation deficit. In all countries we have too few staff, too little money, too little efficiency, and the lack of cooperation costs us between twenty-five and one hundred billion euros a year. Let's tackle these problems. We know how to do it and what to do. Let's do it!

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Mr Juncker proposed to us the possibility that we build Europe with little stories of the future.Stories of tomorrow, he said in his speech.Let's put two stories for the next few years.The first is the possibility of the European Union communicating to citizens that a minimum wage is established, for example, around 60% of the average wage in the countries of the European Union.That would be news that would really build Europe.I have the feeling that Europe has to reconnect with citizens with positive signals.Let's say we do this, let's say we establish an agreement on the possibility of an unemployment guarantee fund for those who have been unemployed for more than two years.I believe that Europe urgently needs signs of those stories, signs of tomorrow's stories.But he does not need what I would call speeches from the past, but projects for the future.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE).
text: - Madam President, one can only be satisfied that defense is on the agenda of tomorrow's Council. However, allow me to temper the declaratory enthusiasm of the last few days and this very morning, with three very specific points that must be taken into consideration. Firstly, defense was already on the Council's program in December 2013. We are in December 2016. Three lost years, because the conclusions of December 2013 resemble word for word those that will be adopted tomorrow and we cannot say that 'we have made a lot of progress. Second, we hear a lot about cooperation and complementarity with NATO. This is obvious, NATO has a key role to play, but I remind you all the same that from January, at the NATO decision-making table, there will be Mr. Trump and Mr. Erdoğan, and I am not sure that Europe should make its defense depend on these individuals. Third, the industry. I welcome the Commission’s commitment to finding funding avenues for the defense industry. I would remind you, however, that it is the States and exclusively the States which make the defense market work, because they are the only customers, and that, therefore, European States should already, when European equipment exist, buy European . The other powers, including more liberal ones than us, buy the productions of their own country.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the Foreign Ministers did not adopt joint conclusions for the first time yesterday. There is no consensus on the relationship between the European Union and Turkey. It is not even among the member states regarding the redistribution of the initial 60,000 refugees. In the meantime, we are witnessing humanitarian catastrophes from Aleppo to Mosul, which will force hundreds of thousands of new people to find a new home. The question is whether future relations between the European Union and Turkey will be based solely on security arrangements or respect for democratic standards. The European Union should not compromise its standards, but must take more care of its own security mechanisms. We need a serious integration of security and defense policy. The Union's inability to provide security for its citizens can permanently distance them from common ground and focus exclusively on national solutions. It is good that youth employment and the revision of the Strategic Investment Fund are on the agenda, especially after the increase for the Youth Guarantee in the next budget, but the fund will be a successful project only if it respects more even geographical distribution and general economic conditions in countries.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Madam President, it is good that tomorrow the Council's agenda also includes migration and security and economic growth and youth unemployment and social Europe. However, it is true that the European Union is absent at this time. The international community failed the exam in Syria. Hundreds of thousands of civilians, women, children are going through hell at the moment. We need to be aware of that, and there is a Council meeting tomorrow. Yes, we must ensure that humanitarian aid reaches those who need it on the ground. We must make it clear that the situation in Aleppo is caused by the Russian bombing of women and children. So, I agree with our Manfred Weber, Russia needs to extend the sanctions. This is a policy of solidarity with the victims in Istanbul. When we talk about Turkish politics, then it is something else. Then we do not support the regime that Erdoğan is trying to impose in Turkey. And when it comes to the European Union, I want to make it clear that it is good that our two big blocs are cooperating. This ensured that there were no intra-party or party contests. It is very important to keep the mainstream here, it is important not to give space to either populists or extremists, and I think that is our basic task here in the European Parliament.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not feel like sharing the optimism of the President of the Council and of the Commission on the outcome of the next European Council, much less congratulate me on the results achieved on the redistribution of migrants on European soil, nor on how the EU-Turkey agreement has been implemented. I remember that the meager results achieved so far on migration issues have been possible thanks to the role of co-legislator of the European Parliament, a role that we will defend in the face of any attempt at an under-the-table agreement. The voice of Parliament cannot go unheard, the resolution of this House on the holistic approach to the phenomenon of migration must be the basis for discussion for a sustainable management of the phenomenon of migration. Solidarity is a cardinal principle of our legal system and not a mechanism to be triggered when a member state is overwhelmed. Solidarity can never be flexible. Finally, Aleppo. Enough proclamations, we expect unanimous condemnation, which must be followed by a definitive political solution to the ongoing massacres and a reconstruction strategy.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is important for this Parliament to give a clear message to the Heads of State and Government. Citizens are asking us for concrete answers immediately. I would like to focus on the topic of investments, in particular on the EFSI which will be discussed tomorrow. For too many years Europe has been waiting for a recovery worthy of the name and it is precisely the lack of investment that is one of the main obstacles to its realization. The Juncker Plan implicitly admits that in a global world in which all the major players support their economies, the European Union must also do so, even if the figures in the field are not sufficient to guarantee the flow of investments necessary to make it strong and competitive. the European Union. The EFSI has been an excellent investment which has brought some benefits to the territories. It is necessary to insist, increase the funds available and go to correct those aspects that have not worked. Two fundamental points: the geographical coverage, which must be extended, the synergy and coordination with the structural funds.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: - (FI) Mr President, the European Union summit is now the place for a serious debate. Just as has been pointed out here, all too often, from month to month, the same things revolve around the agenda, but decent solutions cannot be achieved, and once decisions have been made, they must also be implemented. This will now erode the credibility of the European Union as a whole, unless the decisions already taken are implemented more effectively. By this I am referring in particular to the immigration crisis. Another important topic of discussion is the values ​​of the European Union in general. We must dare to defend the values ​​of the European Union - freedom of expression, human rights, the rule of law - both inside and outside the EU. I am referring in particular to the EU membership negotiations with Turkey, which in this situation should now be suspended until Turkey chooses the path it intends to take. However, the most urgent matter this week is, of course, the situation in Syria and Aleppo, which is truly catastrophic. Here, joint action by the European Union is urgently needed.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of migration remains at the heart of the European Council's discussion. European leaders should carefully reassess the implementation of the EU-Turkey agreement which, it seems to me, has failed as a preventive measure, given the number of deaths in the Mediterranean which has once again become the main channel to reach Europe. I think it is also necessary to evaluate the progress made on the pacts signed with the African countries. The issue of strengthening EU cooperation in the field of external security and defense must be addressed. It is essential to accelerate the creation of a European Defense Fund and the implementation of the European Defense Action Plan. Leaders need to tackle the urgent problem of youth unemployment by putting in place measures to improve the implementation of the Youth Guarantee and develop youth mobility. Finally, I hope that the European Union will bluntly condemn the indiscriminate bombings of Aleppo. Impunity for such crimes can no longer be tolerated and European leaders must act promptly.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). - Madam President, Mr Juncker and Mr Korčok at the beginning of the debate expressed satisfaction with the refugee situation in relation to Greece. So they seem to have no idea what is going on, because at least 16,500 refugees and illegal immigrants are currently trapped on the islands. There are only 7,500 accommodation places, and Mr. Avramopoulos knows this very well. Due to this situation there are conflicts between refugees. Burn the hot spots. At the same time, the inhabitants of Chios, Lesvos and Samos can no longer stand it. Their social peace has been disturbed, tourism has disintegrated, their lives have been disrupted. This situation cannot continue. There must be immediate relocations from Greece. Secondly, Mr. Avramopoulos, the return of those who have left and gone to the countries of the hard core cannot begin with Dublin III. Finally, there must be an end to accession negotiations with Turkey.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). - Madam President, the European Council will meet again tomorrow to discuss the same issues again. But will any decisions be taken that will promote the resolution of the serious problems facing the European Union? Will it be decided, for example, to suspend the accession negotiations with Turkey, so that Mr. Erdogan stops threatening and blackmailing Europe with illegal immigrants, violating human rights in his country and refusing to recognize the Republic of Cyprus? Will a decision be made to tackle youth unemployment, which in Greece has reached an astronomical rate of 67%? Young people do not just want training and education; they want work so that they can show their skills and abilities. European leaders will again discuss tomorrow the unnecessary need to increase the European Union's military capabilities and economic issues, but there I do not know whether they will discuss reducing the illegal and abusive debt they have imposed on Greece or say big words of solidarity and cooperation . (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr Secretary of State, Commissioner, I personally view the Slovak Presidency positively. I welcome the concept of effective solidarity in resolving the migration crisis. I also agree with the dual regime for posted workers, which was proposed during the negotiations on the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive. However, I think we should be more self-critical when it comes to the overall results of the European Union. Neither the European Commission, nor the European Parliament, nor its Presidents have done enough to convince British voters to remain in the European Union. I see this as our failure, which must lead to greater humility and reflection on real priorities, and these should be discussed by the European Council. However, I do not see a clear response in her program to ending the bombing of Aleppo and the suffering of the civilian population. In what interest are Russian bombers bombing Aleppo? How do we end the suffering of civilians? The European Council should respond to this.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S & amp; D). Madam President, this draft Council Statement, paragraph 23, highlights the Commission's interest in preparing for the enhancement of trade relations through the customs union between the European Union and Turkey. I read it twice: "upgrading trade relations". It is incredible! Every citizen in the European Union evaluates the Erdogan regime as an authoritarian regime - as it is - except the leadership of the European Union, which is silent. And then we wonder how Euroscepticism is growing! I continue with paragraph 25, where it mentions that the measures taken in 2016 are sufficient for Turkey. I end with two questions: How will a solution be found to the Cyprus problem based on the principles of the European Union, when there are occupying troops, when will the regime guarantee a solution ... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, while it is understandable that much of the debate today was taken up with the unfortunate situation in Aleppo, and also the unacceptable developments in Turkey, at the same time it is important that we focus on what  citizens in Europe want at this particular time in relation to their own lives, and that is jobs and growth. I welcome especially the success thus far of EFSI. I had the privilege of hosting a conference in Dublin last Friday, where Mr Cassoni from the Commission and the EIB Vice-President also came and spoke, and they are setting up an office in Dublin. This will help SMEs to benefit from financing, which will help them to grow and create jobs. We need that right across the European Union, because the European Union will stand or fall on the basis of what citizens think and how it affects their own lives.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, indeed, the situation in Turkey is extremely worrying, and the European Parliament, by its resolution, made, it seems to me, the right proposal to suspend the accession process. The complete breakdown of the negotiations would throw this strategic state towards other Eastern partners, which would further complicate the situation in the Middle East. This resolution, you know, provoked the fury of President Erdoğan, who threatened to break the agreement on migrants, proof that we have touched to the heart, by the way. The Union must not give in to this type of threat and must move forward on issues of welcoming migrants without having to give in to Mr. Erdoğan's injunctions. Now it is up to the Commission to speak loudly, but also to the Council, with the support of the European Parliament, and to demand that individual freedoms in Turkey be protected and that the massacres of the Kurdish people cease. Earlier, I received high school students, who are wondering about the situation in Turkey and who are wondering what the European Union's capacity for action is. This is a question that I must relay here to Parliament.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). - Madam President, tomorrow the leaders are discussing the extension of the Juncker investment plan, Commissioner Avramopoulos, which is indeed having spectacular results in numbers. But in countries like our common homeland, Greece, this success is not reflected in the real economy. Of the 154 billion leveraged by the FC, 1.9 are leveraged in Greece and more than 1 billion correspond to small and medium-sized enterprises. But small and medium-sized enterprises do not have the ability to finance, a financing that can no longer seem to be done through banks and it is urgently needed to encourage financial platforms, even outside the existing banking system. Behind every number, as President Juncker said a moment ago, is a man. 46.5% of young Greeks are unemployed. It is time to act. To use the Juncker investment plan, so that it has a return to the daily life of Greeks.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission has been working on a very clear strategy since the beginning. This strategy was not just theory, but had focused on specific delivery. For this strategy to succeed, all actors need to play their part, in particular the Member States. The support of this House has been more than helpful. When everyone takes up their responsibilities, we have tangible results. One example, which has been mentioned on many occasions, is the European Border and Coast Guard. Tomorrow, the European Council will give further meaning to and guidance on the European Defence Action Plan.  The European Council will also address two foreign policy issues. First, it must ensure that the EU—Ukraine Association Agreement is concluded. This is a matter of geopolitical responsibility. It is time to complete the work of this Chamber and the Ukraine’s Rada when they simultaneously ratified the agreement. I would also like to congratulate the Parliament for having completed negotiations on the visa suspension mechanism. Visa-free status must now be granted to Ukrainian and Georgian citizens as quickly as possible. This is of major importance for the citizens of these countries and will be mutually beneficial for Europe and the region.  The European Council will also discuss the war in Syria. As has been said here, the situation in Aleppo is grave. There are reports of slaughter and children trapped under collapsed buildings. I call on the warring parties to see through the fog of war at least for a moment – at least long enough to recall their humanity – and to allow civilians, women and children to leave that great city in safety.  One of our next goals is to finalise the reform of the asylum package. I will come back to some of these issues later this afternoon, but I would like to say some words about Turkey. We shall come back to Turkey later. However, I want to express in this Chamber our condolences for the terrible and horrendous terrorist attacks. This again shows that we have common challenges and proves that dialogue needs to continue in all fields for the benefit of both the European Union and Turkey. The EU-Turkey statement is working and giving tangible results. We are committed to continue implementing it. On Dublin II, I must be very clear, because I think there has been a misinterpretation. The Commission did not decide to send refugees or migrants back to Greece. What we recommended to Member States was a gradual return to the application of the rules with the necessary safeguards for the best interests of these people, but also for Greece, which is under exceptional pressure. Greece’s progress, despite the exceptional situation, has been recognised by the fact that we have proposed a gradual resumption as of mid—March 2017. This means only migrants who enter Europe through Greece after that date and might try to move irregularly towards other Member States. But even then it will concern certain categories and will presuppose individual guarantees for the transfer of each migrant, which Greece should be in position to provide. It goes without saying that the Commission will constantly monitor the situation and update its recommendation if necessary. Ideally, if everyone plays their role, the implementation of the EU—Turkey segment should be accelerated, the relocation should be stabilised in larger numbers, and no migrant – or very few – should move irregularly on his own. Yes, the revision of the Dublin rules, based on a fair distribution mechanism, is the priority of this Commission, as it is for you in Parliament.  I have listened to everything you have said. What is important is that right now, at a time of crisis and divisions, this House leads the way towards more unity and common European responses to common challenges. Our responsibility is huge: not to allow populism and nationalism to destroy what we have built – not only for the sake of our past, our history, but for the sake of our future, our common future.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, actually I do not know whether it makes sense to share with you the concluding remarks on behalf of the Council, because if I look around, the Members are obviously engaged in other activities; but I will be very short. First on Brexit and the role of the EU institutions in negotiations once the United Kingdom has invoked Article 50. President Schulz will have an opportunity to raise this issue tomorrow when he meets with the members of the European Council. I am hopeful – let me stress this; this is extraordinary – that the European Parliament will want to ensure its involvement in this matter in negotiations which fully correspond with the Treaty provisions. I have three additional points of substance that I would like to make on behalf of our Presidency on the issues that have been mentioned.  (The President interrupted the speaker) Okay, I will try once more. Firstly, TDI was mentioned and one of the honourable Members has referred to a blockade which allegedly exists in the Council on TDI. We are working hard until the end of our Presidency, and tomorrow morning – after many years of problems reaching an agreement on it – the Council has agreed on TDIs. Now we are ready to start negotiations with the Parliament. This is important. Secondly, EFSI was also mentioned. On this, the Council agreed a general approach on 6 December and is ready to start negotiations and trilogues with the European Parliament, while we take note that the Parliament has postponed this until May 2017.  Lastly, the Youth Employment Initiative is an extremely important area and the subject of deliberations tomorrow in the European Council. I would like to recall that the Slovak Presidency was dealing with this issue within negotiations on the revision of Multi-annual Financial Framework. I would like to recall that the Council is proposing to allocate an additional EUR 1.2 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative until the end of 2020. This, by the way, is 20% more than the original proposal of the Commission. Those were the points of substance, and I would like to thank you for your attention.  (Applause)

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - The agenda for the European Council meeting on 15 and 16 December includes a number of issues of great importance that need to be addressed as soon as possible. One such issue is immigration, which is more urgent to deal with day by day, as tens of thousands of immigrants come to Europe every week in the hope of a better life. It is not responsible to say that we are helping all immigrants when unemployment is high among EU citizens and a significant proportion of people are struggling with livelihoods. Above all, the causes of emigration must be prevented, and this requires a stronger partnership with third countries, especially in African countries. People’s basic needs must be met and they must be offered a perspective on their future in their homeland. At the same time, it is crucial to strengthen the Union's external borders, the need for which has been demonstrated by the control shortcomings identified in connection with the tragic terrorist attacks of recent months. EU citizens have a legitimate expectation of security, and this requires stepping up the fight against illegal immigration and terrorism. In tackling the migration crisis, the Union must not lose sight of the protection of its own citizens and the development of its own Member States. Cohesion and agricultural resources must not be reduced when determining resources for tackling the migration crisis.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The very precarious and degrading conditions of detention of refugees and migrants in the European Union are worsening, where thousands of human beings are left at the mercy of the harsh winter and bad weather. It is the Fundamental Rights Agency itself to point out the gross violations of human rights on European soil. These are consequences of the criminal EU-Turkey agreement and the policy of externalizing borders. This year alone, there are 4715 deaths in the Mediterranean, the highest number ever. At the same time, a review of EU legislation is underway that will further deepen the racist, xenophobic and security nature of its migration policies, harmonizing and lowering the standards of the response, restricting access, periods and asylum rights. They intend to integrate into law the criminal measures of that agreement, in contradiction with international law. In practice, they want to end the right to asylum in the EU. All of this, while the security and militaristic escalation deepens. The increase in Member States' defense budgets of up to 2% of GDP, the increase in funding from military industry and research, the affirmation of the EU as the European military pillar of NATO and the intentions to create the so-called European Army just a few examples. The EU is inhuman and dangerous.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written.- I ask the Council to commit to an upward revision of the multiannual financial framework for next year.I also demand that progress be made towards European unemployment insurance, increased minimum wages and the protection of posted workers.Furthermore, if we need investment, we cannot accept the brake that the Eurogroup has given to the proposal for an additional 50 billion.Let's be consistent between the diagnosis and the therapies we apply to problems.As for the situation in Syria, I am not forgetting Aleppo.Humanitarian access to food and medicine must be achieved as well as working politically to resolve a conflict with the presence of the Union.And not just in Aleppo.Also in Greece.The situation of the refugees there is inhumane.We need to move refugees to safe places, guaranteeing their dignity and rights.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: in writing. - In the context of the upcoming Council meeting, I would like to highlight three issues: the European Fund for Strategic Investments, youth initiatives and the situation in Syria. Regarding the extension of the duration of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, I fully agree that this instrument is important in terms of boosting economic growth in the Union and competitiveness. Nevertheless, one of its main goals - ie supporting high-quality education necessary to stimulate economic growth - has not been achieved. Supporting education is the best investment for employment and economic growth. Therefore, we absolutely need projects aimed at improving the quality of education and ensuring access to it for all social groups. In the field of youth initiatives, I call for more financial support for Erasmus +, the EU's flagship mobility program, to ensure its continued success and added value. Finally, the situation in Syria - the increasing death toll in Aleppo is appalling. Therefore, I call on ministers to urgently take action to provide the necessary humanitarian aid to the Syrians and to step up efforts to end this cruel war, which has already claimed at least thousands of lives.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! Launched in 2014, the EU Investment Fund, known as the Juncker Plan, has proved to be a huge success in much of Europe. In most Member States, the investment plan has mobilized billions, leading to safer and more efficient energy supply, faster internet, fewer potholes on the road, and better lives for European citizens. The Juncker Plan received the most money from the states that were able to convince the European investment bank, which is allocating resources, of their country’s competitiveness. Member States competed for investment, but unfortunately not all Member States were able to come up with competitive ideas worth EU billions. In Hungary and Cyprus, for example, little has been invested in the plan. While only EUR 17 million was mobilized in Hungary and EUR 160 billion in the other 27 Member States for risky projects with EU guarantees. Unfortunately, this shows well where Hungary stands in the competitiveness ranking of the EU nations. If governments make an effort, make good proposals, the Juncker Plan will turn into projects that will improve the lives of their citizens. This, of course, requires the governments of the Member States to represent the interests of their own citizens, not to be preoccupied with themselves.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - The agenda of the European Council summit covers all relevant topics: the situation in Syria, including Russia's involvement, an agreement with Turkey, a common migration policy, and initiatives to increase employment among young Europeans. I would like to emphasize the importance of two of these topics. A set of specific proposals implementing the provisions of the joint EU-NATO declaration signed during the Warsaw summit, which include joint actions to combat hybrid threats, the transfer of critical information between NATO and EU institutions, and the integration of procedures to combat cyber threats, deserve support. Cooperation with NATO, which continues to be the backbone of our defense, is key to ensuring security, and I hope we will eventually see tangible results. The second - key from a security point of view - element under discussion will be the European Defense Action Plan proposed by the European Commission. It foresees three actions: the creation of a European Defense Fund to support in particular research and development of defense technologies, facilitating investment in the defense sector and strengthening the defense single market. These are good proposals because, in the medium to long term, they will help us use funds more efficiently, which at present do not sufficiently increase our security. Time for concrete action.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Dear ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, dear Members of Parliament! Today is the last working session that I will chair as President of the European Parliament. (Applause from the right) The attacks on your part are the pride of every European democrat. That, ladies and gentlemen, is a moving moment for me, a moving moment, without a doubt. And so I thank you for having the opportunity to speak to you again from here. Five years ago, when I was elected President, I said that my aim was to make the European Parliament more visible, more audible and more influential. Five years later I can say that we succeeded together. Parliament is more visible today, it is more audible and it is more influential than ever. (Applause) Over the past few years we have jointly succeeded in making the European Parliament the place of European democracy. Here, here in this room, the important debates take place, the decisions are made that make people's lives better and safer. With the Spitzenkandidaten process, the European Parliament has succeeded in making the EU more democratic and in strengthening the influence of the citizens on the politics of the European Union. As a result, ladies and gentlemen, we have strengthened our transnational democracy. But it is precisely this transnational democracy that is in great danger today. All over this continent the splitters and the ultra-nationalists are spreading again - those who turn people against each other and those who want to unwind the liberal, social and ecological model of society. In doing so, they are endangering one of the greatest civilizing achievements that our continent has ever seen. In any case, I will continue to oppose this hatred with all my might in the future, regardless of where I am from. (Applause) Because it is our duty to defend ourselves against these destructive tendencies - no matter in what capacity. Ladies and Gentlemen! The European Parliament, with its 751 members from 28 sovereign states representing 508 million citizens, is a unique institution. It has been an extraordinary honor for me to be President of this institution. I am very grateful for that. I was certainly not a comfortable President of this House, nor was I an easy one. But I have endeavored to fight for the cause of Europe to the best of my knowledge and belief, so that people and peoples can overcome rifts and so that together we can make a contribution to a peaceful world. I wish my successor and all of us the best of luck and the strength and confidence to turn things around for the better. We must not let up in our striving to make this Europe a better place, one that also radiates outwardly and gives hope again to the hopeless. Yesterday's awarding of the Sakharov Prize was an emphatic reminder of this. It is up to us, ladies and gentlemen, to hand over Europe to our children and grandchildren as a place that represents this hope. I humbly thank you for your work together over these five years. Many Thanks! (Members of Parliament stand up and give the President sustained applause.)

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate you on your five-year term. I also rise under Rule 11(2). Mr Verhofstadt, according to the financial report, has three jobs that pay him EUR 1 000 to 5 000 per month and a further job that pays him EUR 10 000 per month. So for Mr Verhofstadt, it is Christmas every day. Now we all know that Mr Verhofstadt is a master of the universe, a Superman, but how can he do all these jobs and be the European Parliament’s Brexit negotiator? This does not respect the dignity of Parliament and is incompatible with the dignity of Parliament, as per Rule 11(2). I must ask for a ruling on this.  (Applause from the right)

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, on behalf of my Group and according to Rule 190 of our Rules of Procedure, which calls for adjournment of a debate and vote, I would like to ask for a postponement of this vote. The reason for this is that the reports on the cotton harvest and on forced labour in Uzbekistan during the cotton harvest, which has just ended recently, have not been finalised yet. The International Labour Organization will finalise its reports in January 2017, and we have reports from several civil society independent monitors which are also saying that, despite some improvements, forced labour is still being done, with the authorities demanding that people fulfil quotas in those harvests. So I think it would be due process for us to wait for our vote on the consent on the textile protocol until those reports are out from the International Labour Organization’s independent monitors and to postpone it. I hope Members will follow me and my Group on this.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all I wish to thank Parliament, its rapporteur Mr Fleckenstein, as well as the shadow rapporteurs in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, for the important work that they have accomplished. With their logistic and industrial activities, maritime ports provide employment to three million Europeans. They are also critical for development of short-sea shipping as an alternative to road transport as part of our strategy to decarbonise transport. This is why maritime ports are extremely valuable assets ...

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Further regulation will ensure greater transparency for the use of public funds in ports. Many receive considerable financial support from both national and European Union budgets. Transparency will contribute to a genuine level playing field between European ports. It will also help make public funding more efficient. The Court of Auditors stressed the necessity to address this issue in a recent report.  Second, the regulation creates a common framework for the provision of port services. This framework brings legal stability for the tendering of port services. It will end today’s unclear situation where ports policy is not decided by EU legislation, but rather by judgment of the European Court of Justice on a case by case basis.  Third, it will ensure better training of port workers in line with the work undertaken by the social partners. Finally, the regulation will contribute to our decarbonisation strategy. We need to green the shipping industry and promote short-sea shipping. This requires investment and the right type of investment in ports.  Many of you attach great importance to clear and simple state aid rules. The Commission shares its attachment. We have been working a lot on the issue of state aid in ports over the last months. My colleague Commissioner Vestager and I are making sure that the views of European ports are adequately taken into account. Replying last week to a preliminary question from Mr Fleckenstein, the Commission clarified the framework for state aid in ports, including the general block exemption regulation. The situation is as follows: a new set of infrastructure analytical grids was published on 2 December. With this document, the Commission explains which infrastructures are considered to be non-economic and therefore should not fall under state aid rules. These infrastructures include defence infrastructure, such as docks, and access infrastructure to ports, such as a river flowing through a port that can be used by anyone. Last week, the Commission also completed its second public consultation on the general block exemption regulation. Its objective is to identify which public investments in port infrastructure are considered state aid but are unproblematic and therefore do not need to be notified. We are now analysing the replies to improve the text further and adopt the regulation in 2017.  The result of the analytical grids and the revised general block exemption regulation will be more legal certainty and more clarity, but there will be no change in the decision-making practice of the Commission. With this work, we are doing exactly what you have been calling for under Recital 45 of the Port Services Regulation. However, for institutional reasons and to recall the better law—making principles agreed between the Commission and the co—legislators, we will record a statement from the Commission to be inserted regarding this recital. The text is balanced. It is the result of three years of discussions with all stakeholders. All major organisations representing the European port sector stand behind it – the trade unions, port authorities, port terminal operators and port services providers. It received strong support in the Transport Committee and was accepted unanimously by Member States. It is now time to conclude the legislative procedure at first reading. All the circumstances allow it. (Loud applause and cheers from certain quarters)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for the explanations.My impression was that it was probably intended more for the debate.If the Commission should have detailed declarations in further votes, I recommend that we add them to the minutes.That does not change the fact that what Mr Andriukaitis has just said is a very, very far-reaching process and decision that we have taken here.But parliamentary work is secondary to you.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission, in writing. –  Commission statement on recital 45 of the compromise agreement reached by the co-legislators on the Proposal for a Regulation establishing a framework on market access to port services and financial transparency of ports The Commission considers that recital 45 should not have been included for the following reasons. First, the recital does not relate to any of the enacting terms of the regulation and hence does not comply with the principles of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. In that agreement, the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission confirmed that they remain fully committed to the Interinstitutional agreement on common guidelines for the quality of drafting of Community legislation, which provides that the purpose of recitals is to set out concise reasons for the chief provisions of the enacting terms, without reproducing or paraphrasing them, and that recitals should not contain normative provisions or political exhortations. Second, the Commission recalls that the notion of State aid within the meaning of Article 107(1) TFEU is an objective one, enshrined in the Treaty and not at the disposal of the Union legislator. It can only be applied as such by the Commission or national courts in specific cases, subject to the control of the Union courts. Third, the wording of the recital may create confusion. Having regard to the Treaty notion of State aid, it cannot be claimed that public funding of all access and defence infrastructure accessible to all users on equal and non-discriminatory terms always falls outside the scope of the State aid rules. The Commission’s decisional practice shows, for instance, that public funding of certain access infrastructure located within the area of a port may constitute State aid.

name: Bart Staes
text: Reporter.- I will not take up much of your time.I would like to point out that this is the ninth time this year that we have appointed a new Member of the Court of Auditors.At the beginning of 2016, there were still 5 women in 28 members of the Court of Auditors.With the appointment of this Estonian member, we drop to the level of 3 women out of 28. This is an impermissibly low number.Action is needed.We successfully put pressure on Commissioner Juncker in 2014 to ensure that his Commission had no fewer female members than the Barroso Commission.So let us act together now to ensure that the Member States also propose women as candidates for membership of the Court of Auditors.Women have their place in the Court of Auditors.Let's fight for that together.

text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report because it is a technical transposition of a modification in the annex to the regulation concerned.A legislative modification in the Polish insolvency law implies the change of the aforementioned annexes and with said change the extension of the exceptions that the United Kingdom and Ireland have with respect to said regulation must be specified.Due to the strictly technical nature of the content of this report, I have decided to vote in its favor.

Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings will apply from 2017. June 26 The Annexes to this Regulation contain lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners relevant to its application. Annex A to the Regulation lists insolvency proceedings and Annex B lists insolvency practitioners. 2015 December. Poland has notified the Commission of a substantially revised national restructuring law, which was due to enter into force in 2016. 1 January 2006 and requested that the lists in Annexes A and B to the Regulation be amended accordingly. Poland has reformed its lawinternal restructuring and, on this occasion, requested that the regulations be amended accordingly.The Commission has presented a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council with the aim of ensuring that the scope of the said Regulation will correspond to the reformed legal framework of Polish law.This Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature and does not provide for any substantive modification of the regulation, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as the European Union should have no right to dictate to Member States what the criteria for insolvency proceedings should be or how insolvency practitioners should operate.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal to amend the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners in Annexes A and B to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings.The Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings entered into force in 2015.June 26The regulation will apply from 2017.June 26The Annexes to this Regulation contain lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners relevant to its application.However, Poland notified the Commission of a substantially revised national restructuring law, which was due to enter into force in 2016.1 January 2006 and requested that the lists in Annexes A and B to the Regulation be amended accordingly.The Commission has examined whether Poland's request complies with the requirements of the Regulation.As the Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature and does not contain any substantive changes to the Regulation, Parliament supports the amendment.

text: in writing.- Poland reformed its internal restructuring law and on this occasion requested that the regulation be amended accordingly.The Commission has presented a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council with the aim of ensuring that the scope of the said Regulation will correspond to the reformed legal framework of Polish law.The Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature and does not provide for any substantive modification of the regulation.I abstained on this vote.
