text: in writing.- I approved this report, which aims to replace the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners appearing in annexes A and B of regulation 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings following a substantial reform of the lawinternal Polish restructuring.

text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the Zwiefka report on insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners.It is a text of a technical nature that does not involve any substantial changes;it follows the request made by Poland to amend the lists in Annexes A and B of Regulation (EU) 2015/848, to adapt them to the changes in its national law as a consequence of a substantial restructuring reform.The text approved today contains only three minor changes, also of a technical nature, to the proposal presented by the Commission.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a substantial reform of its national legislation on restructuring, which would enter into force on January 1, 2016, and requested an amendment to the lists in Annexes A and B of the Regulation. According to Article 1 (1), point 4 of Article 2 and recital 9 of the Regulation, national proceedings can only be considered 'insolvency proceedings' in the context of the Regulation if they are listed in Annex A to the Regulation. The annexes to the Regulation can only be amended by a regulation that is adopted in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure of the legal basis on which the original Regulation was adopted. The Commission examined whether Poland's application met the requirements of the Regulation and submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council in order to ensure that the scope of the recast Regulation was aligned with the current legal framework of Polish insolvency law in the time of application. In this context, the Commission proposal is purely technical. It does not contain any substantive modification of the Regulations. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this Report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I have supported this report on insolvency proceedings and insolvency administrators.We agree with the purpose of the Agreement and its content, but we consider that the three amendments of a technical nature should be approved, reflecting the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland in relation to the Commission proposal in accordance with Protocol n.21 on the area of freedom, security and justice of these two Member States.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- I preferred to abstain from this report, which concerns a modification of a purely technical nature on insolvency proceedings governed by Regulation (EU) No 2015/848.These changes come as a result of a reform by Poland of its internal restructuring law.The regulation therefore had to be amended accordingly, so that it corresponded to the reformed legal framework.If this modification is purely formal, that does not prevent me from being in disagreement with the substance of the regulation, hence my abstention.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The report being voted on has some unclear passages which I do not fully agree with.I therefore decided to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report which modifies the Regulation of insolvency proceedings and bankruptcy administrators.This Regulation includes in its annexes procedures that are important and necessary to be able to apply the rules correctly.The modification is given by the reform of the insolvency legislation of Poland and the request of said country to modify the lists established in the annexes, which stipulate that national procedures may only be considered "insolvency proceedings" if they are inthe list in annex A, and it is only possible to modify said annexes through the ordinary legislative procedure.The Commission examined whether Poland's request met the statutory requirements, thus forwarding a proposal of a technical nature to the Council and Parliament, without substantive changes to the Rules of Procedure.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report on insolvency cases and insolvency professionals. The annexes to the Insolvency Regulation contain lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners relevant to its application. 2015 December. Poland has notified the Commission of a substantially revised national restructuring law, which was due to enter into force in 2016. 1 January 2006 and requested that the lists in the Annexes to the Regulation be amended accordingly. The annexes to the Regulation can only be amended by a regulation adopted in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, on the basis of the legal basis applicable to the original regulation, i.e. y. Article 81 TFEU. name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Insolvency Proceedings and Trustees Report which contains annexes relevant to their application.The rapporteur agreed with the aim of the proposal and its content on the general conditions.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- Poland reformed its internal restructuring law and on this occasion requested that the regulation be amended accordingly.The proposed text aims to ensure that the scope of the said regulation will correspond to the reformed legal framework of Polish law;it is purely technical.I abstained.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report. It is a purely technical file making a minor amendment to the regulation on the request of Poland after it changed its national laws on insolvency (Poland should now be inserted into a formal list in annexes of the regulation). The original regulation in 2013 improved the previous insolvency regulation but it did not go far enough in protecting workers’ entitlements in these situations. But this vote was unrelated to the content of the regulation and due to its purely technical nature – just adding Poland to the list of who is covered in the regulation, basically – we voted in favour.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - Insolvency Proceedings Regulation (EU) 2015/848, includes annexes that contain lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners. In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a substantial reform of its national restructuring law and requested to amend the lists in Annexes A and B of the Regulation. National procedures fall within the definition of "insolvency procedures" only if listed in Annex A. The annexes can only be amended by a regulation to be adopted in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure. The Commission examined whether the application submitted by Poland complied with the requirements of the regulation and submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council to ensure that the scope of the recast regulation is adapted to the current legal framework of Polish legislation on the subject of 'insolvency. The Commission proposal is purely technical in nature and does not entail any substantial changes to the regulation. However, it is considered that it requires three amendments of a technical nature. The first two amendments reflect the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland in relation to the area of ​​freedom, security and justice. The third amendment aligns the date of entry into force of Regulation (EU) 2015/848.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing.- Regulation 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2015 on insolvency proceedings entered into force on 26 June 2015 and will apply in the Member States from 26 June 2017. Poland hasreformed its restructuring legislation and called for the said regulation to be amended at the same time.This proposed amendment to the regulation aims to ensure that its scope remains in line with the Polish legal framework.Insofar as this modification of the regulation, proposed by the European Commission, does not foresee any major modification, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The European Parliament's draft legislative resolution concerns a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council replacing the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners in Annexes A and B to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings. text: in writing. – UKIP have voted against this because it is not for the EU to tell the UK or any other Member State what the criteria would be for insolvency procedures and practitioners.

name: David Casa (PPE)

text: in writing.- The report by my colleague Zwiefka is not critical since it is a mere recasting procedure which, however, requires the ordinary legislative procedure by virtue of the legal basis on which the original regulation was adopted, namely art.81 of the TEU.The amendment will apply to Annexes A and B of the Insolvency Proceedings Regulation voted in 2015 and which will apply from June 26, 2017. name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report, as we agree with the purpose of the proposal and its content in general.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted on the report on the replacement of insolvency proceedings lists and insolvency administrators in Annexes A and B to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings.This is a purely technical issue aimed at improving and modernizing the operating structures of the European edifice.That is why I voted in favor.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention for this report which does not make any substantial changes to the regulation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - This is a technical provision that will not make substantial changes to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 relating to insolvency proceedings, therefore I can only guarantee you my consent. name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report because it is a technical transposition of a modification in the annex to the regulation concerned.A legislative modification in the Polish insolvency law implies the change of the aforementioned annexes and with said change the extension of the exceptions that the United Kingdom and Ireland have with respect to said regulation must be specified.Due to the strictly technical nature of the content of this report, I have decided to vote in its favor.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. - This regulation mainly includes two annexes for insolvency proceedings and for bankruptcy trustees. In addition to purely technical issues, the issue of Poland is particular, which has requested an amendment to the lists in Annexes A and B to the regulation given a substantial reform of its national restructuring law. Under the regulation, a national proceeding qualifies as an "insolvency proceeding" in the context of the regulation only if it is listed in Annex A to the regulation. Therefore, the Commission examined whether the request from Poland regarding compliance with the requirements of the regulation and presented a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council in order to ensure that the scope of the revised regulation is adequate to the current legal framework. of Polish bankruptcy law. I am voting in favor of this text, as the work carried out by the European institutions has shown itself to be attentive to the European and national instances regarding insolvency procedures, and therefore, a step forward towards greater harmonization.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the application for insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners, as this application directly concerns Poland's affairs and the protection of its economic interests. In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a major reform of its national restructuring law with effect from 1 January 2016 and requested changes to the lists in the annexes to the regulation. The Commission proposal and the proposed changes are purely technical. They do not contain any substantive amendments to the regulation. Therefore, the proposed proposal merely constitutes an official codification of the legislative text. It is important for the Polish side that urgent measures are taken to address this issue, as it is obvious that the failure to rapidly incorporate new types of proceedings may have far-reaching negative financial consequences for cross-border creditors and debtors in Polish restructuring and bankruptcy proceedings.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Companies and individuals in the EU Member States are increasingly establishing business activities or economic interests in EU countries. For these reasons a regulation which lists insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners is required. name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support the technical modifications to the proposed regulation, which makes changes to the lists of insolvency proceedings and practitioners in the legislation, and which underlines that the UK has chosen to opt in.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This legislative report proposes to improve the efficiency of insolvency proceedings, that is to say, on the one hand, the rules which define a natural or legal personality as non-solvent and, on the other hand,rules which concern those responsible for collection.Considering that the harmonization of insolvency proceedings at Union level will ensure equal treatment between European citizens and facilitate the action of insolvency practitioners throughout the territory, I voted in favor ofthis report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this because it is not for the EU to tell the UK or any other Member State what the criteria would be for insolvency procedures and practitioners.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- To ensure the proper functioning of the internal market, it is important that effective insolvency proceedings are guaranteed in all Member States.To this end, the European Union has compiled a list of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners in the Member States.These lists must be kept up to date because only the procedures and the actors who are registered there are recognized at European level.While respecting European principles on insolvency, Poland has recently revised its legislation in this area.The lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners should therefore be amended to take account of the Polish changes.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of 20 May 2015 on insolvency proceedings entered into force on 26 June 2015. It shall apply from 26 June 2017, with the exception of the part on the system for the interconnection of national insolvency registers, which shall apply from 26 June 2019. The annexes to the regulation contain insolvency proceedings (Annex A) and experts (Annex B) relating to its application. In December 2015, Poland informed the Commission that it had implemented a major reform of its national restructuring law, which entered into force on 1 January 2016, and requested that the list in Annexes A and B to the Regulation be amended accordingly. The Commission has examined whether Poland's request complies with the requirements of the Regulation and has submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council to adapt the scope of the recast Regulation to the current Polish legal framework before its application. The proposal is of a technical nature and does not involve any substantive changes. The aim and content of the proposal are appropriate, but three more technical amendments are needed. The first two amendments reflect the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland on the Commission's proposal under Protocol 21 on the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland in the area of ​​freedom, security and justice. The third amendment seeks to align the date of entry into force of the amending Regulation with Regulation (EU) 2015/848. In view of the above, I am voting in favor of amending the proposal.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)

The Commission has examined whether Poland's request complies with the requirements of the Regulation and has submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council to amend the two Annexes accordingly. The Committee on Legal Affairs states in its report that the Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature, does not contain a substantive amendment to the Regulation, and therefore proposes that it be adopted by Parliament at first reading with three amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2015 on insolvency proceedings entered into force on 26 June 2015 and will apply from 26 June 2017. Poland has reformedits internal restructuring law and requested, on this occasion, that the regulations be amended accordingly.The Commission has presented a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council with the aim of ensuring that the scope of the said Regulation corresponds to the reformed legal framework of Polish law.The Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature and does not provide for any substantive modification of the regulation.Abstention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- EU Regulation 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 20, 2015 on insolvency proceedings entered into force on June 26, 2015 and will apply from June 26, 2017. name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report with a view to ensuring that the scope of the recast regulation will be adjusted to the current legal framework of the Polish insolvency legislation by the time of its application.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council replacing the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners.The purely technical text takes into account the recently adopted insolvency reform in Poland and amends European law accordingly.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Across the EU companies and individuals are increasingly establishing business or economic interests in EU countries other than where they conduct their core activities. In case they become insolvent, there may be direct implications for the good functioning of the internal market. I have voted for this report that will replace the list of insolvency proceeding and insolvency practitioners.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because this report sets out the European Parliament's position at first reading for a purely technical change.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.This is an amendment to the Regulation resulting from the application of the revised Polish insolvency legal framework.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Regulation 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2015 on insolvency proceedings entered into force on 26 June 2015. In December 2015, Poland informed the Commission of a substantial reform of its domestic law concerning the restructuring, which entered into force on 1 January 2016, and requested that the lists in Annexes A and B to the Regulation be amended accordingly. The Commission examined whether the application from Poland complied with the requirements of the Regulation and submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council in order to ensure that the scope of the Regulation would be adapted to the current legal framework of Polish insolvency legislation from now on. of its implementation. For the effective management of cross-border insolvency proceedings of debtors centered in a Member State, the scope of the recast regulation must reflect the actual state of national insolvency law. The purpose of this proposal is to ensure that the scope of the recast regulation is adapted to the insolvency legal framework of the Member States in force at the time the regulation is implemented.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of my colleague's proposal on replacing the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners (Annexes A and B to EU Regulation 2015/848) and the amendments of a technical nature that this replacement implied as I take note of the modification of the law on restructuring that affected Poland in 2015 and I understand the need for the Polish State to have its national procedures included in the list of "insolvency procedures", provided for by the aforementioned regulation. On the basis of current legislation, the amendment of the annexes to the regulation must be carried out through the adoption of a regulation to be adopted according to the ordinary procedure; in this case it is not a question of modifying the previous content of the regulation but only of making additions following the supervening change in Polish legislation; this entails variations of a technical and non-substantial nature which I consider appropriate to ratify. Therefore, I voted in favor

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I supported the resolution on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the replacement of the list of insolvency proceedings and the insolvency administrator in Annexes A and B to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings adopting the Commission's position at first reading. These are legal and technical amendments to the Insolvency Procedure Regulation, which entered into force on 26 June 2015 and will apply on 26 June 2017, except in the part relating to the system of interconnection of national insolvency registers, which will will apply from 26 June 2019. In view of Poland's request to reform its national law on restructuring, which is in line with the acquis and related to the application of Annexes A and B to Regulation 2015/848, the amendment of European legislation may be implemented by a regulation. on the basis of the legal basis applicable to the original Regulation, which is adopted in the ordinary legislative procedure. The two technical amendments take into account the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland with regard to the Commission proposal in line with the Protocol on the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland with regard to the area of ​​freedom, security and justice. The third amendment concerns the harmonization of the application of the Regulation in question amending the basic act, ie Regulation (EU) 2015/848.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council, which contains lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency administrators relevant to its application, entered into force on 26 June 2015 and will enter into force on 26 June 2017, except for the part relating to the system of interconnection of national insolvency registers, which will come into force on 26 June 2019. In order to effectively deal with cross-border insolvency proceedings against debtors whose main interests are in a Member State, the scope of the modified Regulations must reflect the actual state of national insolvency laws. This proposal seeks to ensure that the scope of the amended Regulation is aligned with the actual legal framework of insolvency Member States until its application. In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a radical reform of its national restructuring law and requested an amendment to the list in Annexes A and B to the Regulation, and the Commission examined the compliance of the application with the conditions of this Regulation. Requests have been submitted to the European Parliament and the Council to ensure alignment with the existing legal framework of Polish legislation before the entry into force of the revised Regulation.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report aims to introduce minor technical changes to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings. The amendments are intended to take into account a reform that Poland has undertaken in terms of restructuring, and Poland has requested to amend accordingly the lists contained in Annexes A and B to this Regulation. The annexes to the regulation can only be amended by a regulation adopted in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure. As such, the Commission presented a proposal to the European Parliament to ensure the scope of the recast regulation, taking into account, as such, the legal framework of Polish insolvency legislation at the time of its application. The proposal coming from the Commission and the three amendments tabled are of a purely technical nature and do not substantially change the Regulation. Regarding the content of the regulation, we expressed in due time our concerns regarding negative elements, such as the issue related to workers' credits, as they are not recognized as having credit privileges.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. - In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a major reform of its national restructuring law with effect from 1 January 2016 and requested changes to the lists in Annexes A and B to the Regulation. The Commission examined the compliance of Poland's request with the requirements of the Regulation and presented the relevant proposal to the European Parliament and the Council. The annexes to the regulation can only be amended by a regulation which has to be adopted under the ordinary legislative procedure, in line with the legal basis used for the original regulation (Article 81 TFEU). The purpose of the proposal is to ensure that the scope of the recast Regulation is aligned with the actual legal framework. It is important for Poland that urgent action is taken on this issue, as it is clear that the failure to quickly include new types of proceedings in the Annexes to Bankruptcy Regulation No 1346/2000 could have far-reaching negative financial consequences for cross-border creditors and debtors under the Polish restructuring and bankruptcy proceedings. I hereby support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Regulation on Insolvency Proceedings has been recast and will enter into force in 2017. At the same time, Poland has amended some provisions in its legislation in this area.She subsequently called on the Commission to amend the regulation on insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners.I voted in favor of this report which therefore relates to the Commission's proposal for a regulation in this sense.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this because it is not for the EU to tell the UK or any other Member State what the criteria would be for insolvency procedures and practitioners.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Commission's proposal is purely technical.It does not contain a substantial amendment to the regulation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report which modifies the Regulation of insolvency proceedings and bankruptcy administrators.This Regulation includes in its annexes procedures that are important and necessary to be able to apply the standard correctly.The modification is given by the reform of the bankruptcy law of Poland, and the request of said country to modify the lists established in the Annexes, which stipulate that national procedures could only be considered "insolvency procedures" ifin the list in Annex A, and it is only possible to modify said Annexes through the ordinary legislative procedure.The Commission examined whether Poland's request met the statutory requirements, thus forwarding a proposal of a technical nature to the Council and Parliament, without substantive changes to the Rules of Procedure.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported this legislative resolution of the European Parliament of 14 December 2016 which replaces the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners appearing in Annexes A and B of Regulation (EU) No 2015/848 oninsolvency proceedings.Annexes A and B of Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council list the names given, in the national law of the Member States, to the insolvency proceedings and to the insolvency practitioners to whom the said regulationapplies.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- I supported Mr Zwiefka's report.It was a non-controversial report on technical changes.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of this proposal, which has a purely technical content, insofar as it intends to adapt the reform of national legislation carried out in Poland to the regulatory framework regarding insolvency proceedings.In legal terms, the process of legislative change in Poland is only qualified as an “insolvency procedure” if it is framed in the respective annex A of the regulation in question, and the respective annexes can only be changed by a regulation, according to the ordinary legislative procedure andthe legal basis on which the original regulation was adopted.In view of this circumstance, Poland's request was examined in the light of legal and regulatory requirements, with the aim of ensuring that the scope of the recast regulation is adapted to the legal framework of Polish insolvency law, with no substantial change to theregulation.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report because it is a technical transposition of a modification in the annex to the regulation concerned.A legislative modification in the Polish insolvency law implies the change of the aforementioned annexes and with said change the extension of the exceptions that the United Kingdom and Ireland have with respect to said regulation must be specified.Due to the strictly technical nature of the content of this report, I have decided to vote in its favor.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP have voted against this because it is not for the EU to tell the UK or any other Member State what the criteria would be for insolvency procedures and practitioners.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report. In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission about a substantial reform of its domestic law on restructuring, which would take effect as of 1 January 2016. This involved a request for a modification of the lists set out in Annexes A and B to the Regulation as – according to Article 1(1), to point (4) of Article 2 and to recital (9) – national proceedings qualify as ‘insolvency proceedings’ in the context of the Regulation only if they are listed in Annex A thereto. The Annexes to the Regulation can be amended only by a regulation to be adopted following the ordinary legislative procedure under the legal base on which the original regulation was adopted. The Commission examined whether the request from Poland complied with the requirements of the Regulation and submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and to the Council with a view to ensuring that the scope of the recast regulation will be adjusted to the actual legal framework of the Polish insolvency legislation by the time of its application. The Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature and contains no substantive change to the Regulation.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution.In view of the fundamental reform of national law on restructuring in Poland, which entered into force on 1 January 2016, the Commission was requested to amend the lists of insolvency proceedings and administrators relevant to the application of Regulation (EU) and Council Regulation (EU) accordingly.2015/848 of 20 May 2015 on insolvency proceedings.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and success.actions.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - The recast of the Insolvency Regulation has required major reforms of restructuring law that have recently taken place in Poland. I supported the technical adjustments requested by the Commission, as they do not involve any substantial changes to the regulation itself. As for the changes made, they are mainly of a technical nature. As Poland carried out a major reform of its national law in December 2015, it asked the Commission to amend the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency administrators accordingly. The intention was to adapt the recast version of the Regulation to the current legal framework of the Polish insolvency law. In addition, the rapporteur has proposed three non-problematic adjustments, which both reflect the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland and at the same time align the date of application of the Regulation with other legislation. I have no reservations about the adoption of this regulation, as it is, in principle, a technical change to the legislative text.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- We have adopted changes in the legislation on insolvency proceedings at the request of the Republic of Poland, which has adopted a fundamental change in its legislation in this area and the European Parliament has adapted certain parts of the relevant regulation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings entered into force on 26 June 2015. The Regulation will apply from 26 June 2017. The annexes to that Regulation contain lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency administrators relevant to its application. In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a radical reform of its national restructuring law and requested an amendment to the list in the annexes accordingly. The annexes to the Regulation can only be amended by a regulation adopted in the ordinary legislative procedure. The Commission examined whether Poland's application complied with the requirements of this Regulation and submitted a request to the European Parliament and the Council to ensure that its scope is aligned with the existing legal framework for Polish insolvency law before the amended Regulation enters into force. The report agrees with the purpose of the proposal and its content, but considers that three changes of a technical nature need to be included. The first two amendments reflect the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland in the area of ​​freedom, security and justice. The third amendment aligns the entry into force of this amending Regulation with that of the Regulation. I support this Report as there is no significant change to the Regulation.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council replacing the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency administrators in Annexes A and B to the Insolvency Procedure Regulation.This is only a technical and not a substantive change to the regulation, after Poland informed the European Commission at the end of 2015 that the reform of domestic restructuring legislation would enter into force on 1 January 2016.Precisely because of these changes in legislation, we need changes to both annexes to the Regulation.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings entered into force on 26 June 2015 and will enter into force on 26 June 2017. In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a substantial reform of its national restructuring legislation and requested that the lists in Annexes A and B to the Regulation be amended. On the basis of this request, the Commission submitted the relevant proposal to the European Parliament and the Council, therefore the issue is of a purely technical nature as it does not contain any substantive changes to the substance of the regulation, which is why we voted in favor of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- The Commission examined whether Poland 's request complied with the requirements of the Regulation and submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council, in order to ensure that the scope of the recast Regulation would be adapted to the actual legal framework of Polish legislation oninsolvency until its entry into force.In this context, the Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature.It does not contain any changes to the substance of the regulation.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. - Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of 20 May 2015 on insolvency proceedings entered into force on 26 June 2015. It shall apply from 26 June 2017, with the exception of the part on the system for the interconnection of national insolvency registers, which shall apply from 26 June 2019. The annexes to the regulation contain insolvency proceedings (Annex A) and experts (Annex B) relating to its application. In December 2015, Poland informed the Commission that it had implemented a major reform of its national restructuring law, which entered into force on 1 January 2016, and requested that the list in Annexes A and B to the Regulation be amended accordingly. The Commission has examined whether Poland's request complies with the requirements of the Regulation and has submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council to adapt the scope of the recast Regulation to the current Polish legal framework before its application. The proposal is of a technical nature and does not involve any substantive changes. The aim and content of the proposal are appropriate, but three more technical amendments are needed. The first two amendments reflect the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland on the Commission's proposal under Protocol 21 on the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland in the area of ​​freedom, security and justice. The third amendment seeks to align the date of entry into force of the amending Regulation with Regulation (EU) 2015/848. In view of the above, I am voting in favor of amending the proposal.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report, which adopts an amendment to the Insolvency Regulation.After examining the request for amendment submitted by Poland due to a significant reform of national restructuring law, the Commission confirmed that it was of a purely technical nature and did not involve a substantive change to the Regulation.In addition, the report complements the proposal with two amendments, which are also of a technical nature, which also do not prevent the full and proper application of the regulation, so they are all eligible.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In December 2015, Poland notified the European Commission on a substantial reform of its domestic law on restructuring, which was to take effect as of 1 January 2016, and requested a modification of the lists set out in the Annex lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners. The Annexes to the Regulation can be amended only by a regulation to be adopted following the ordinary legislative procedure. After examining the request from Poland, the Commission submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and to the Council to ensure that the scope of the recast regulation will be adjusted to the actual legal framework of the Polish insolvency legislation by the time of its application. I support this report, as the Commission’s proposal was of a purely technical nature.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I support the objective of the proposal and its content in general terms.I also voted in favor of the technical amendments.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2015, Poland passed a new insolvency law to make existing legal instruments more effective and to help business entities survive financial stress or distress. As a result, the current Annexes to the EU Insolvency Regulation require an update to harmonise with the new reform of Polish domestic law. I voted in favour of the Regulation under the ordinary legislative procedure, which will facilitate legislation that will be business-friendly and encourage growth for business entities conducting business in Poland.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written.- Tadeusz Zwiefka, A8-0324⁄2016 I support the motion for a resolution to replace the list of insolvency proceedings and the insolvency administrator in Annexes A and B to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings as a technical matter.an amendment that contributes to legal certainty and not a substantial amendment to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council.This proposal streamlines the objective preparatory period for entry into force, allows Member States to harmonize and provides an open possibility for the adoption of a new regulation.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a radical reform of its national restructuring law and requested that the list in Annexes A and B to the Regulation be amended accordingly. The Commission examined whether Poland's application complied with the requirements of this Regulation and submitted a request to the European Parliament and the Council to ensure that its scope is aligned with the existing legal framework for Polish insolvency law before the amended Regulation enters into force. I agree with the purpose of this proposal and its content in general. However, like the rapporteur, I believe that three changes of a technical nature need to be included. The first two reflect the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland with regard to the Commission's proposal on the position of those countries with regard to the area of ​​freedom, security and justice. The third amendment aligns the application of this amending Regulation with that of Regulation (EU) 2015/848. It is very important for Poland to take urgent measures in this regard, as it is obvious that the lack of rapid inclusion of new types of procedures in the annexes could have far-reaching detrimental financial consequences for cross-border creditors and debtors in Polish restructuring and bankruptcy proceedings. Accordingly, I supported this report and voted in favor.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council replacing the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency administrators in Annexes A and B to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings.It calls on the committee to refer the matter to Parliament again if it intends to amend its proposal substantially or replace it with another text.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing.- Poland reformed its internal restructuring law and requested, on this occasion, that the regulation be amended accordingly.The Commission has presented a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council with the aim of ensuring that the scope of the said Regulation will correspond to the reformed legal framework of Polish law.The Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature and does not provide for any substantive modification of the regulation.I chose abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a major reform of its national restructuring law with effect from 1 January 2016 and requested changes to the lists in Annexes A and B to the Regulation.The Commission examined the compliance of Poland's request with the requirements of the Regulation and presented the relevant proposal to the European Parliament and the Council.The whole thing is purely technical, so I voted positively.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on insolvency proceedings shall apply from 26 June 2017, with the exception of the scattering part of the system for the interconnection of national insolvency registers, which shall apply from 26 June 2019.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - In December 2015, Poland notified the Commission of a substantial reform of its national legislation on restructuring, which would enter into force on January 1, 2016, and requested an amendment to the lists in Annexes A and B of the Regulation. According to Article 1 (1), point 4 of Article 2 and recital 9 of the Regulation, national proceedings can only be considered 'insolvency proceedings' in the context of the Regulation if they are listed in Annex A to the Regulation. The annexes to the Regulation can only be amended by a regulation that is adopted in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure of the legal basis on which the original Regulation was adopted. The Commission examined whether Poland's application met the requirements of the Regulation and submitted a proposal to the European Parliament and the Council in order to ensure that the scope of the recast Regulation was aligned with the current legal framework of Polish insolvency law in the time of application. In this context, the Commission proposal is purely technical. It does not contain any substantive modification of the Regulations. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this Report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour as it was a technical amendment on the regulation concerning the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)

I voted in favour because I believe that, in this context, the Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report because it is a technical transposition of a modification in the annex to the regulation concerned.A legislative modification in the Polish insolvency law implies the change of the aforementioned annexes and with said change the extension of the exceptions that the United Kingdom and Ireland have with respect to said regulation must be specified.Due to the strictly technical nature of the content of this report, I have decided to vote in its favor.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor because Poland notified the Commission in December 2015 of a significant reform of its national legislation on restructuring, with entry into force on 1 January 2016.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This report aims to introduce minor technical changes to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2015 on insolvency proceedings.The amendments are intended to take into account a reform that Poland has undertaken in terms of restructuring, and therefore Poland has requested to amend accordingly the lists contained in Annexes A and B to this Regulation.The proposal that comes from the Commission and the remaining three proposals are of a purely technical nature and do not substantially change the Regulation.Regarding the content of the regulation, we expressed our concerns regarding negative elements, such as the issue related to workers' credits, basically because they are not recognized as having credit privileges.As the Regulation is not at issue in this vote, we voted in favor.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- Since this report is only a purely technical change, the European Parliament only takes a position on it and changes the Commission proposal only slightly, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on insolvency proceedings and insolvency practitioners.I agree with the objective of the proposal and its content, in general terms.I believe that it requires the three amendments of a technical nature.The first two amendments reflect the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland on the Commission proposal under Protocol (No 21) on the position of the United Kingdom and Ireland in relation to the area of freedom, security and justice.The third amendment aligns the date of entry into force of the amending regulation with that of Regulation (EU) 2015/848.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation replacing the lists of insolvency proceedings and insolvency administrators in the annexes to the Insolvency Regulation.The need for this change arose after Poland notified the Commission in December last year of a planned change in its national restructuring law.Poland's proposal was thoroughly analyzed and a proposal was subsequently made to amend the Annexes to the Regulation accordingly.I think that the whole process of changing the regulation went according to the prescribed rules.The Member State, in this case Poland, has duly notified the planned change, and I therefore think that the proposal to amend the regulation, resp.amendment of its annexes defining individual concepts in the field of insolvency law was here.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the replacement of the lists of insolvency proceedings and trustees in Annexes A and B to Regulation (EU) 2015/848 on insolvency proceedings.I support the Commission's proposal, made at Poland's request, to amend the lists in Annexes A and B to the Regulation accordingly in order to ensure that the scope of the recast Regulation is aligned with the actual legal framework of Polish insolvency law until it enters into force.Thus, the Commission proposal is of a purely technical nature and does not contain any substantive changes to the Regulation.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Uzbekistan, a loyal friend of Russia, has had a new president for a few weeks, after 27 years of being led with an iron fist by President Karimov.We know that the new president was the right hand of former President Karimov.It seems that power is moving in Uzbekistan from hand to hand - also with an iron hand.We want to encourage trade with Uzbekistan through this report, but we must condition this trade with the democratization of the country.Steps have been taken, for example, by banning child labor (exploitation of children through labor), but this is not enough.I repeat, trade together with democratization and human rights.All those who oppose the regime must be free to do so, through expression, through demonstrations, through everything that means democracy, civil and political rights.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan regarding textiles is a dossier opened a long time ago, but it remained blocked for a long time due to the widespread child labor in Uzbekistan.I believe that the fact that children and adults were mobilized en masse during the cotton harvesting season is an inhumane practice.It must be said in this sense that, although the Uzbek authorities were unwilling to discuss the problem, the EU has worked hard over the years to combat this phenomenon and in fact in recent years the situation has greatly improved, the country has in fact decided to open upand to collaborate with international institutions.The fact that the situation has improved a lot and that cooperation and dialogue has been established between Uzbekistan and the European institutions are the reasons why I voted in favor.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this proposal to accept an Agreement that seeks to deepen imports into the Union of textile products from Uzbekistan.The Union with this Agreement once again ignores human rights and legitimizes as an economic partner a country where there is slavery, forced labor in cotton fields and child labor.With this Agreement, the Union once again ignores human rights to act, once again, as a mere ambassador for the interests of the textile transnationals and their multimillion-dollar profits obtained at the cost of perpetuating labor exploitation and dumping.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the draft European Parliament resolution on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textile products between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part. 2011 December. The European Parliament adopted a preliminary report stating that it would approve the agreement if the human rights situation in Uzbekistan improved, in particular by abandoning child and forced labor in the cotton harvest. Following the adoption of the report, a dialogue has been established with Uzbekistan, with annual hearings involving representatives of civil society, the Uzbek authorities, the EU and other international bodies. Close cooperation has also been established between Uzbekistan and the International Labor Organization (ILO) to assess the steps taken to eliminate child and any other forced labor in the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan. 2013, 2014 and 2015 ILO representatives went to observe the cotton harvest. A recent report by an ILO monitoring mission shows that child labor is virtually non-existent in the cotton harvest. The ILO has confirmed that child labor has become a solitary and socially unacceptable phenomenon. I therefore take the view that, in the light of the ongoing dialogue and fruitful cooperation, the European Parliament should support the efforts made by Uzbekistan in this area by endorsing the protocol to the agreement with Uzbekistan on textiles.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, to amend the extend the provisions of the agreement on bilateral trade in textiles, given the expiration of the bilateral agreement on textiles, as Uzbekistan has demonstrated in recent years its willingness to continue cooperating with the EU.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - This recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the partnership and cooperation agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan , on the other hand, amending the said agreement in order to extend its provisions to bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the expiry of the bilateral agreement on textiles. The EU had previously postponed approval of the textile deal with Uzbekistan because of child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields. The ILO was able to monitor the cotton harvest: child labor has become rare and occasional and socially acceptable. NGOs say for their part that forced labor continues despite everything. In principle, the Front National votes against free trade treaties including on textiles, but since this agreement will have very little impact for France and allows this poor and landlocked country to find some outlets for its cotton, I chose to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I followed the whips’ recommendation to vote in favour of this motion, having insufficient personal knowledge of the situation to be able to consider doing otherwise. I note that Uzbekistan has made genuine steps towards improving workers’ rights in recent years and that further trade deals will help to build a safer working environment in that country.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this recommendation in order to extend the provisions of the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan to include the textile trade.The report of the last mission of the International Labor Organization, which took place from September 14 to October 31, 2015, indicates that public authorities have put in place various measures to eliminate child labor.In view of the respect of this condition, I therefore considered that the agreement could be extended.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles.2011The European Parliament adopted a preliminary report stating that it would approve the agreement if the human rights situation in Uzbekistan improved, in particular as regards child labor and forced labor each year during the cotton harvest.The latest International Labor Organization (ILO) monitoring mission has seen the efforts of the Uzbek authorities to abolish forced labor.In the light of the ongoing dialogue and cooperation, I welcome the agreement with Uzbekistan on textiles.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained because, although I usually vote against all the free trade agreements that the Union multiplies in all directions, this one only concerns textiles, with a minimal impact for France, and will allow this landlocked countryto find outlets for its cotton.Even more like its neighbors in Central Asia, Uzbekistan is called upon to play an increasingly important geopolitical role.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation by my colleague Maria Arena who proposes, via a protocol, to extend the cooperation agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and Uzbekistan, on the other hand, to bilateral trade in textiles given the expiration of the bilateral agreement on textiles. This would include, among other things, the granting of reciprocal most-favored-nation status, trade free of quantitative restrictions, a safeguard clause and the principle of transit. The negotiations with a view to the implementation of this protocol were notably facilitated by the fact that child labor during the cotton harvest had been practically completely eradicated according to the last monitoring mission carried out by the ILO in 2015 in Uzbekistan. Unfortunately, this is not the case with the situation of forced labor. Therefore, the report specifies that the Parliament will adopt appropriate measures if the Uzbek authorities were to suspend the implementation of their commitment to abolish forced labor.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I strongly supported the Arena report which approves the extension, as regards the dimension of trade in textiles, of the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan. This is an important vote, which I followed previously in the Foreign Affairs Committee, and which marks a crucial stage in the path that since 2013 has seen Parliament and the International Labor Organization monitor the cotton harvest, with the authorization of the Uzbek authorities. The systematic use of child and forced labor was for a long time the condition that prevented extending the validity of the agreement in this sector, but the joint work has made it possible to note, since October 2015, a substantial elimination of child labor and the presence of some progress, although not yet sufficient, on the forced labor front. This is undoubtedly a success of European trade policy, an instrument that has been able to strengthen human rights in the republic of Central Asia and to generate concrete progress in the agricultural labor market. However, it will be necessary to remain vigilant, carefully verifying that the direction that the new president will give to the country proves to be in continuity with the path started.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against granting consent to the signing of the protocol that would extend the provisions of the EU-Uzbekistan Cooperation and Partnership Agreement to the textile sector. We appreciate that since Parliament postponed taking a decision on the GPA in 2011, there have been significant improvements on the ground: not only have ILO missions to Uzbekistan been allowed, but they have also shown a very favorable evolution, especially in the eradication of child labor. However, the situation of the textile sector in Uzbekistan is far from reaching a minimum of labor and social guarantees that we consider essential to approve this agreement. Both the ILO and other observers warn of the systematic use of forced labor in the sector. This is reason enough for us to be against the Union granting advantages to this sector, since these advantages would only serve as an incentive to increase production and thus these practices.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I want to thank the rapporteur, Ms Arena, for her work on this report on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and Uzbekistan and bilateral trade in textile products.We fully support the work carried out by the ILO to definitively eliminate forced labor in the country and also that, should the Uzbek authorities suspend compliance with their commitment to abolish forced labor, Parliament reserves the right to request theEuropean Commission and the Council the activation of articles 2 and 95 of the ACC to adopt general or specific measures for violation of human rights.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report concerning the EC-Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement. Let us recall that the EU had previously postponed the approval of the agreement on textiles, in particular because of the problems of child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields. Despite the progress noted on the ground by the International Labor Organization, the NGOs present there affirm that forced labor continues. In addition, I am in general opposed to free trade agreements between the European Union and third countries, on the one hand, because the EU should not have this competence, and, on the other hand, because that these agreements are often harmful for employment in France. However, in this specific case, the textile agreements with Uzbekistan will have little impact on the French industry and will also allow this developing country to find some outlets for its cotton reserves. Realism and prudence therefore called for abstention.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The report on the EU-Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement on bilateral trade in textile products is well structured and can be shared, which is why I intended to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation, which deals with the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles. The European Parliament is requested to approve the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement to extend bilateral trade in textile products. With the ratification of the Protocol on Textiles, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) between Uzbekistan and the EU, concluded in 1999, would include textiles. Therefore, the provisions of the above-mentioned chapter of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement on trade in goods would also apply to textiles. The provisions of this Chapter provide for the reciprocal granting of most-favored-nation status, trade without quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices, a safeguard clause and the prohibition or restriction of imports, exports or goods in transit on grounds of public morality or public interest. and public security. Following the adoption of the report, a dialogue has been established with Uzbekistan and annual hearings involving various actors, including civil society, the Uzbek authorities, European and international institutions. Close cooperation has also been established between Uzbekistan and the International Labor Organization (ILO) to assess the steps taken to eliminate child labor and forced labor in the annual cotton harvest in Uzbekistan.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - Economic aid in exchange for democratic reforms and civil progress is one of the tools most used by the EU in its relations of neighborhood and partnership with third countries. A way of relating that has often produced positive results for citizens on both sides and has increased the range of influence of the soft power of the European Union. The Republic of Uzbekistan is a country that has embarked on the path that can lead it in the future to a democratic form of a modern type, which looks to the West and to the development of the rule of law despite the still serious structural deficiencies, its own problems. internal social networks, the difficult relationship with some countries of the Asian area. Overall, Europe can look to the Republic of Uzbekistan as a potentially friendly country, which we must support by allowing it to develop under appropriate conditions, gradually, and to gradually enter the area of ​​free trade and common collaboration, in a manner consistent with what is foreseen. by international agreements whose main purpose remains the reduction and ultimately the elimination of poverty.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report deals with the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan in order to extend the provisions to bilateral trade in textiles. The European Union had recently postponed approval of the agreement due to multiple cases of forced labor and child labor on some farms. Since this postponement, the International Labor Organization (ILO) as well as NGOs have been able to confirm a clear decline in these unacceptable practices. Of course, we always oppose in principle any free trade agreement, especially when it concerns textiles, in order to protect French companies from unfair international competition. But this agreement will have a low impact on the French economy and does not pose a threat to our businesses. This is the reason why I abstained on this report which will help to increase the opportunities for Uzbek farms in a country sufficiently marginalized from trade relations.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report over concern about human rights. There is an existing EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement in place since 1999, but it excludes the textile industry. In 2011 the European Parliament refused to give consent to a Commission proposal to include the textile industry in the PCA due to evidence of the systematic use of child labour in cotton harvesting related to the textile industry. The Commission says this is no longer a problem but human rights NGOs believe it is still a problem.  We voted in favour of a request from the Greens to postpone the vote until after an ILO report next year, which should shed further clarity on the ongoing extent of child labour, but it was defeated.  Due to the allegations of ongoing child labour by credible human rights and labour rights NGOs, we are strongly opposed to this agreement.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The Protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, envisages extending the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. Thus, this protocol implies the inclusion of textile products in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement concluded between Uzbekistan and the European Union. Trade in goods will also apply to textile products, which involve trade without quantitative restrictions, respect for the principle of free movement, trade at market prices, a safeguard clause and prohibitions or restrictions on imports and exports for reasons of public interest, or public security. The human rights situation has seen a visible improvement in the use of child labor and forced labor in the annual cotton harvest in Uzbekistan. According to the International Labor Organization's 2015 report, child labor in cotton harvesting has been abolished, and a number of advances have been made in forced labor among adults and appropriate measures have been taken to eradicate it. which I spoke in favor of this project.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the recommendation in question which approves the extension of the economic partnership agreement (already in place) with Uzbekistan to the textile sector, rewarding the remarkable progress made in recent years by the country of the former Soviet Union on the issue of child labor. The inclusion of another economic sector in the agreement constitutes a further incentive for the Uzbek authorities to engage in an awareness campaign that affects the entire nation and completely eradicates child labor. In this sense, the Uzbek government has shown openness in allowing the International Labor Organization to monitor the cotton harvest and in working towards the implementation of a national program for decent work. However, I am of the opinion that EU assistance to Uzbekistan should set itself more ambitious objectives, also aiming to free the country from cotton monoculture and reduce its dependence on exports, diversifying its economy.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report which attempted to include the Uzbekistan’s textile industry in a pre-existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the EU. In 2011, the European Parliament refused to give its consent to the Commission’s proposal to include it due to evidence of systematic use of child labour in cotton harvesting related to the industry.  Despite widespread reporting that child labour is still a problem in the industry by leading human rights NGOs, such as Human Rights Watch, the Commission thought it appropriate to include it.  I fundamentally disagreed so voted against.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving my consent to the textiles protocol and of the accompanying resolution, extending the provisions of that Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles.  In December 2011, Parliament adopted an interim report postponing its decision on consent pending an improvement in the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, particularly in relation to the use of child labour and forced labour in the annual cotton harvest.  The ILO confirmed that the use of child labour was only sporadic and that the practice had now become socially unacceptable. The same conclusions could not, however, be drawn as regards forced labour.  I fully support the work done by the ILO to abolish forced labour in Uzbekistan definitively and the efforts of the Uzbek authorities.  However, if the Uzbek authorities fail to follow through on their commitment to abolish forced labour, I agree that Articles 2 and 95 of the PCA should be activated, allowing general or specific measures to be taken in the event of a failure to respect human rights.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Until a few years ago, the "mass mobilization" of children and adults during the cotton harvesting season, a fundamental asset for the country's exports, was a sad reality that the Uzbek authorities were reluctant to discuss.In recent years, however, the country has decided to open up, to collaborate with international institutions and has begun a strong policy of deterring the use of forced labor, especially child labor.The situation in Uzbekistan has significantly improved, forced labor is now sporadic while child labor can be considered uprooted.My vote was positive.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution as I believe that we should intensify our trade relations with Uzbekistan. We know from ILO reports and other observations that there are still some concerns regarding labour conditions. Having said that, the Uzbek Government has made good progress in addressing these concerns, especially on forced and child labour. In this context, I am in favour of enhancing our cooperation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report and emphasize that we fully support the work of the International Labor Organization with a view to the definitive elimination of forced labor in Uzbekistan.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favor of the recommendation on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Uzbekistan, in order to extend the provisions of the agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, given the expiry of the bilateral agreement on these products . The development of cooperation between the two parties is positive and legitimate. However, as there are specific objections to the situation at work and the working conditions of the citizens of Uzbekistan, I decided to vote against the report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - While welcoming the conclusion of a PCA protocol with the Republic of Uzbekistan, I agree with what has emerged and highlighted in the report. I have all my esteem for Uzbekistan, in which there is an aura of great trust on the part of the whole Union, precisely by virtue of this it is necessary to resolve as soon as possible the gaps presented by it regarding working through cooperation to achieve more dignified situations. Thanks to the decisive contribution of the World Labor Organization, starting from 2013 striking leaps have been made regarding the elimination of child labor, which has strongly characterized the cotton sector. The results achieved give hope for an almost complete elimination of this abuse within a few years, however the need to eradicate forced labor remains despite encouraging efforts being made in this direction. Consistently with what has been noted, the future Uzbek President is invited to found a new paradigm of human rights, in parallel the Commission and the European delegations in Tashkent are required to cooperate in carrying out structural reforms such as increasing the minimum wage and greater transparency in financial statements of the textile sector, which today is the one most considered by our companies.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
