text: in writing. ‒ I supported the recommendation on EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left-wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I gave my positive opinion on an amendment to the Partnership Agreement which aims to include certain tariff guarantees for the European textile industry.In the approved text, Uzbekistan undertakes not to increase customs tariffs.It should also be noted that today the country's working conditions have improved, even if not yet optimally, as confirmed by the International Labor Organization.The resolution therefore also recognizes the efforts by the Uzbek government in pursuing the elimination of forced child labor and hopes that this will be a positive sign of encouragement for further improvement actions and for strengthening cooperation with the EU.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this proposal to accept an Agreement that seeks to deepen imports into the Union of textile products from Uzbekistan.The Union with this Agreement once again ignores human rights and legitimizes as an economic partner a country where there is slavery, forced labor in cotton fields and child labor.With this Agreement, the Union once again ignores human rights to act, once again, as a mere ambassador for the interests of the textile transnationals and their multimillion-dollar profits obtained at the cost of perpetuating labor exploitation and dumping.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- Ratification of the Textile Protocol entails amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, extending the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement tobilateral trade in textiles.I would like to remind you that the European Parliament has approved an interim report, making its approval conditional on the improvement of the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, particularly in relation to child labor and forced labor in the annual cotton harvest.Therefore, welcoming the inclusion of textiles in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) concluded between the country and the EU in 1999, I hope that the Uzbek authorities will continue their commitment to guaranteeing human rights in the workplace..

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up.- The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, on the extension of the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement on bilateral trade in textiles will bring economic benefits to both parties..This agreement also provides for trade without quantitative restrictions, the principle of free movement, but also trade at market prices.Results were recorded in order to completely eradicate child labor in cotton harvesting.I voted for the implementation of these beneficial exchanges for both parties, but also for the road to a healthier labor market, without the use of children or forced labor.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and Bilateral Trade in Textiles. I believe that expanding cooperation in trade based on partnership relations will bring benefits for the economy and create new development prospects. Consideration should be given to the significant progress made in Uzbekistan since 2013, including the adoption of a law banning the use of child labor, which has led to an almost complete elimination of child labor. Such actions to eliminate the use of children as cheap labor prove the willingness to develop cooperation and the adoption of European standards. It also increases the protection of children's rights. Continued talks with the government of Uzbekistan on the part of the EU are important to ensure the effective implementation of the agreement. The Commission and Council are also called upon to initiate the Art. 2 and 95 of the PCA, to take all necessary general and specific measures in the event of failure to comply with the commitment to eliminate child labor and forced labor.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as, in the context of the ongoing dialogue and cooperation, it is appropriate for Parliament to give its consent to the textile protocol with Uzbekistan while also encouraging further improvements. I agree that, if the Uzbek authorities fail to follow through on their commitment to abolish forced labour, Parliament reserves the right to ask the Commission and the Council to allow general or specific measures to be taken in the event of a failure to respect human rights.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that giving consent for an agreement on bilateral trade in textiles with Uzbekistan will constitute a positive sign of encouragement to the Uzbek government to pursue much stronger efforts on the full eradication of child labour and all other forms of forced labour, as well as to further strengthen cooperation with the EU.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This consultation report proposes the positive opinion of the European Parliament to the Commission's proposal to include trade provisions for textile products in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) concluded between the European Union and theUzbekistan.Uzbek authorities have adopted a series of measures to eliminate child labor, such as the provision of after-school care, fines for violators or accountability of parents, teachers and farmers..In view of these positive developments and being in favor of closer ties between the Union and Uzbekistan in the framework of deep cooperation, I voted in favor of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left-wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of concluding a protocol to the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan to include bilateral trade in textiles.In 2011, in view of the human rights situation and the exploitation of children during the cotton harvest, the European Union refused to include bilateral trade in textiles in this agreement with Uzbekistan.Faced with this European pressure, Uzbekistan worked with the International Labor Organization and eradicated child labor in this sector.In view of these efforts and the improvement in the situation of children, we can now open our market to the Uzbek textile industry.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union must make full use of the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities are committed to strengthening the rule of law and democratic reforms.Significant progress has been made on this path with the adoption of legislation banning child labor, but further government action is needed as more indirect and sophisticated forms of forced labor can still be found.The release of prisoners imprisoned for political reasons is essential, and arrests and convictions that violate human rights must be stopped.The European Union will continue to monitor the measures and, if necessary, call on the European Commission and the Council to give effect to Articles 2 and 95 of the Agreement.In line with the above, I vote in favor of the motion.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing.- The inclusion of textiles in the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan is important as it promotes trade and competitiveness.It also strengthens the control of international institutions over the exploitation of forced labor in Uzbekistan.Following ILO monitoring, the Uzbek government made several commitments to abolish forced labor.However, I urge the EU not to let its guard down because forced labor is an unacceptable practice and contrary to European values of democracy and civil rights.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - For three years, in cooperation with the International Labor Organization (ILO), the Uzbek authorities have worked to end forced labor and child labor in the country. Important progress has been made. The most significant concerns child labor, which, according to the latest ILO reports, is now virtually eradicated. It is in light of this progress and the awareness by the Uzbek authorities of the importance of respecting international labor standards and human rights - as well as the implementation of a strategy in this meaning - that the European Parliament has given its approval to the inclusion of textiles in the areas of commercial cooperation covered by the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Uzbekistan. It remains essential to follow developments in the situation with the greatest vigilance. Recall that cases of forced labor are still observed in Uzbekistan. We therefore expect the authorities to continue to intensify their efforts to end it. Thus, any deterioration in the human rights and labor law situation will necessarily lead to an immediate suspension of the preferences granted under these agreements.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.This is a draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Memorandum of Understanding on partnership and cooperation between the European Union and Uzbekistan in the textiles sector.Approval of the textile deal with Uzbekistan had been delayed due to concerns over the persistence of child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields.In fact, the debate on this question has not known a definitive answer: according to the International Labor Organization, child labor has become occasional and socially acceptable, but some NGOs point to its persistence.We are in principle opposed to free trade agreements.This will, however, have little impact on EU Member States.This landlocked state would find some outlets for its cotton there.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - I welcome the report and the recommendation. I am glad that Uzbekistan has implemented measures to eliminate child labor when picking cotton. In the 21st century, the use of child labor is unacceptable and cannot be tolerated in any country in the world. I therefore congratulate the International Labor Organization and the Uzbek Government on achieving these results. There are, of course, a few more steps that need to be taken to eradicate forced labor in cotton collection. I am particularly worried that everything achieved so far could fail dizzyingly due to the death of President Islam Kerimov. That is why we, as the EU, and the rest of the world must closely monitor the development of political life in this republic.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought to promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against consent for an EC-Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement and bilateral trade in textiles, according to the wishes of students from Wales who wanted to show solidarity with Uzbek students. Thousands of university students were forcibly mobilised by the government to pick cotton and threatened with expulsion from college if they refused. I oppose all forms of modern slavery.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- The report approves the conclusion of the protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other, in order to extend the provisions of that agreementbilateral trade in textile products.The report of the latest ILO follow-up mission noted that child labor had been almost completely eradicated during the cotton harvest.Public authorities have taken different measures to eliminate child labor.The same conclusion was not reached with regard to forced labor.Efforts by the Uzbek authorities should also be encouraged.I agree with the conclusion of the protocol on textile products with Uzbekistan.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention: we are voting against free trade treaties including on textiles, but this agreement will have very little impact on France and will allow this poor and landlocked country to find outlets for its cotton.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation aims to conclude a “Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other”. The nature of this agreement and its objectives do not differ substantially from the free trade matrix that habitually characterizes agreements of this type. Perhaps it is worth mentioning that the European Parliament itself, which endorses the agreement, recognizes the existence of cases of forced labor in the country with which it is signing the agreement. It matters little. The constraints that result from the reduced diversification of Uzbekistan's economy, from the high dependence, for example, on “cotton monoculture” are recognized. It matters little. Free trade will accentuate this trend, with the intensification of the export nature of production and a disregard for the domestic market. Putting further pressure on European countries that still have a textile industry, such as Portugal. Nothing new: large importers from central Europe benefit, producers from the periphery are harmed. We obviously voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this recommendation because as a result of considerable efforts by the Uzbek government, the scourge of child labor has largely been healed.It therefore appears desirable to encourage the efforts of the Uzbek authorities by approving the textile protocol with Uzbekistan.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted no because I disagree.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- In 2011, the European Parliament refused to give its consent to the agreement, which had major economic as well as political consequences for Uzbekistan.President Karimov died in 2016, a major milestone for the country, as President Karimov ruled the country for an authoritarian and extremely long period.New elections will take place soon and everything shows the willingness of local authorities to cooperate with the European Union.However, we must continue to closely monitor compliance with fundamental human rights, as well as labor rights, including the right to certain guarantees for employees.However, the country has finally managed to move away from child labor and forced labor.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles.Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought to promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The death of President Karimov earlier this year marks another turning point in the country’s history. New elections will soon take place but all signs point to a new willingness to cooperate constructively with the EU. However, as outlined in the accompanying resolution to the consent we call for the EEAS to continue to monitor developments ensuring that respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law are upheld and that more space for independent civil society is ensured.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - The purpose of this proposal is to approve the Protocol extending to bilateral trade in textiles the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part. This would provide for the reciprocal granting of most-favored-nation status; trade free of quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices. The proposal also contains a safeguard clause and prohibitions or restrictions on imports, exports or goods in transit justified on grounds of public morality, public policy or public security. Given the current state of cooperation, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to give its consent to the signing of a protocol on the textile sector, but if the Uzbek authorities suspend their commitments, Parliament will maintain the entry into force of Articles 2 and 95 of the Partnership Agreement. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing.- I thank Mrs Marie Arena for her excellent mediation work in following up on the trade negotiation with Uzbekistan.The final text can certainly be seen with satisfaction by the S & amp; D group: I want to emphasize in particular the inclusion of the requirements of mandatory respect for certain fundamental and labor rights, as in the case of children.Following the recent presidential elections in the country, this agreement can lay the foundations for a stronger role for the EU in calling for a significant opening in Uzbekistan on the rule of law and the involvement of civil society;as Parliament we will be vigilant that this partner, which is so important to the EU, keeps its commitments.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- The agreement stands for the continuous improvement of working conditions in the cotton fields in Uzbekistan.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ After intense research I decided to vote for this recommendation. I note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which gives consent to the textile protocol with Uzbekistan. However, if the Uzbek authorities fail to follow through on their commitment to abolish forced labour, Parliament reserves the right to ask the Commission and the Council to activate Articles 2 and 95 of the PCA, allowing general or specific measures to be taken in the event of a failure to respect human rights.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing.- The agreement is extremely delicate and I find the debate we can have today extremely useful.The EU is certainly ready and able to face the opening of the partnership also to the textile sector.However, let us not forget that as a Union we have made a commitment to first and foremost support political reforms in compliance with each other's decisions and choices, just as we have repeatedly supported socio-economic and educational improvements in Uzbekistan.I will be voting in favor of the report because it rightly takes this complexity into account and commits the European Parliament to ask for a suspension of the application of the agreement if the criteria we have commonly established on labor rights are not respected.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against granting consent to the signing of the protocol that would extend the provisions of the EU-Uzbekistan Cooperation and Partnership Agreement to the textile sector. We appreciate that since Parliament postponed taking a decision on the GPA in 2011, there have been significant improvements on the ground: not only have ILO missions to Uzbekistan been allowed, but they have also shown a very favorable evolution, especially in the eradication of child labor. However, the situation of the textile sector in Uzbekistan is far from reaching a minimum of labor and social guarantees that we consider essential to approve this agreement. Both the ILO and other observers warn of the systematic use of forced labor in the sector. This is reason enough for us to be against the Union granting advantages to this sector, since these advantages would only serve as an incentive to increase production and thus these practices.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I have voted to support this resolution. Uzbekistan has slowly but surely cooperated with not only the EU, but the ILO – allowing an unhindered inspection of the cotton harvest to take place for the last three years. They have also broadened ILO cooperation in a number of other areas. The ILO has reported significant progress, and although concerns remain about the use of adult labour, most monitoring reports state that Uzbekistan has been cooperative in trying to do away with this.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted against the report, because we cannot ignore the allegations of child labor in this country.By accepting the protocol, we are giving the wrong message to the country's authorities to improve this situation.Also, the promotion of textiles in the European Union by Uzbekistan will discourage the country from the urgent need for changes in the agricultural sector.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Uzbekistan has achieved substantial progress with the reform of their labour market, especially concerning child labour, since 2013. We need to commend the Uzbek authorities for their close collaboration and engagement with the ILO. The progress made by the Uzbek authorities allows us to move forward and include textiles in our partnership agreement. However, we will remain extremely vigilant. We want the Uzbek government to continue full cooperation with ILO to eradicate child and forced labour and for this reason I was happy with the agreement.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. - The purpose of this proposal is to approve the Protocol extending to bilateral trade in textiles the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part. This would provide for the reciprocal granting of most-favored-nation status; trade free of quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices. The proposal also contains a safeguard clause and prohibitions or restrictions on imports, exports or goods in transit justified on grounds of public morality, public policy or public security. Given the current state of cooperation, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to give its consent to the signing of a protocol on the textile sector, but if the Uzbek authorities suspend their commitments, Parliament will maintain the entry into force of Articles 2 and 95 of the Partnership Agreement. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. We have seen fundamental changes in Uzbekistan and the beginning of a new period of openness and cooperation. The EAS should continue to monitor developments ensuring that fundamental rights and the rule of law are upheld.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, and amending the Agreement. provisions on bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the expiry of the bilateral agreement on textiles (16384/1/2010 - C7-0097 / 2011 - 2010/0323 (NLE)). Namely, in 2011 the European Parliament adopted an interim report in which it conditioned its consent on the improvement of the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, especially the issue of child and forced labor during the annual cotton harvest. According to the latest observation mission, it showed that child labor in cotton picking was almost completely eradicated, which, however, cannot be confirmed in terms of forced labor. The Uzbek authorities have taken a number of measures to phase out forced adult labor, and efforts should be supported in this regard. With regard to the continuation of dialogue and existing cooperation, the European Parliament is of the opinion that consent should be given to the textile protocol with Uzbekistan. If the Uzbek authorities stop working to end forced labor, this decision should be changed.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am usually opposed to free trade agreements but it is clear that this partnership will have little impact on the French economy and that it will allow Uzbekistan to find outlets for its industrycotton.I therefore abstained.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported this report on the partnership between the European Communities and the Republic of Uzbekistan, because I believe that the EU's support for Uzbekistan in recent years is producing tangible results.The report emphasizes the continuation of deepened cooperation with a focus on the rule of law and the judiciary, efforts to kick-start reforms, streamline the work of the Uzbek parliament and monitor the ongoing process of improving working conditions in the cotton fields in Uzbekistan.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Maria Arena on the partnership and cooperation agreement with Uzbekistan. The textile industry is an important part of the Uzbek bursar which constitutes a trading partner for European companies. To this end, the European Union has worked closely with the government and the World Labor Organization to end child labor and forced labor. The report welcomes the efforts undertaken over the past five years by the country to remedy the situation and calls for additional measures to be put in place. This agreement is not a blank check given to Uzbekistan since in the event of a serious violation of human rights, the Union retains its hand to suspend the agreement completely. It is by maintaining healthy trade relations with our neighbors that the EU will gain in competitiveness and growth, which is why I welcome the adoption of this report.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report by Mrs Arena, which called on the European Parliament to approve the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, which extends the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to Bilateral Trade in Textiles. Ratification of the Protocol on Textiles would entail the inclusion of textiles in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) concluded between that country and the EU in 1999. Therefore, the provisions of the heading "Commodity Exchanges" of the these PCAs would also apply to textiles.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I have the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Community and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the agreement in order to extend the provisions of the agreement to theagreed to bilateral trade in textiles in view of the expiry of the bilateral textile agreement.Uzbekistan has joined the ILO and has achieved good results in the fight against child and forced labor in a short period of time, which should be taken into account.I therefore support the conclusion of a textile trade agreement with Uzbekistan.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which gives consent to the textile protocol with Uzbekistan. However, if commitments to abolish forced labour are not followed through, Parliament reserves the right to ask the Commission and the Council to activate Articles 2 and 95 of the PCA, allowing general or specific measures to be taken in the event of a failure to respect human rights.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing.- Uzbekistan is a dominant, constantly developing state in the Central Asian region with significant agriculture and manufacturing.The agreement in question is essentially a renewal of an earlier document that is now expiring, which experience has shown has served the interests of both the Union and Uzbekistan.Nowadays, it is particularly important that we can also help maintain the stability of a given region, and at the same time Europe can create some economic counterbalance in a remote area.I note that the inauguration of the new President took place just a few days ago, following an election procedure which, according to the unanimous opinion of many foreign observers, was impeccably conducted.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I supported the recommendation for a partnership and cooperation agreement between the EC and Uzbekistan on bilateral trade in textiles. The main precondition for concluding the agreement was the condition set in an interim report of the European Parliament to achieve an improvement in the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, in particular with regard to child labor and forced labor in the annual cotton harvest. According to reports from the International Labor Organization, child labor has been virtually eliminated during the cotton harvest, and government agencies have taken on permanent prevention.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing.- With this agreement the European Parliament gives its consent to the amendment of the Partnership Agreement which aims to incorporate tariff guarantees for European industry.Specifically, Uzbekistan undertakes not to increase customs tariffs.Originally the agreement was blocked due to some shortcomings in terms of labor law, and in this case minors, but in 2016, following a monitoring mission aimed at supervising forced labor by the ILO, it emerged thatwith regard to cotton harvesting, child labor has been completely eliminated.The authorities intervened through various measures, including after-school activities, fines for offenders, and increased responsibility for parents, teachers and farmers

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The current restrictions on Uzbek cotton are justified by the practice of forced labor for the cotton harvest. During the harvest period, locals and even children are requisitioned, as well as people "hired" by force by the local authorities to harvest cotton and thus reach production quotas. The current authorities are trying to change this assessment, but not necessarily the practices. Of course, an ILO evaluation mission was authorized, as well as some local NGOs. The latter conclude that there has been an improvement, especially in the government's speech announcing measures against these practices. But in reality, we are still a long way off: the monitoring missions have been remote-controlled by the Uzbek authorities and serious doubts persist about the independence of local NGOs. In fact, other NGOs have presented us with conflicting information about forced labor. In the end, we are still a long way off and better access to the European market will strengthen an industrial and very large-scale cotton cultivation in Uzbekistan when it is already responsible for the drying up of the Aral Sea. That’s why I opposed this deal.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on the EC / Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement and bilateral trade in textiles.The European Union previously postponed approval of the textile deal with Uzbekistan because of child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields.The ILO was able to monitor the cotton harvest: child labor has become rare and occasional.NGOs say for their part that forced labor continues despite everything.I normally vote against free trade treaties, including on textiles, but this agreement will have very little impact on France and will allow this poor landlocked country to find some outlets for its cotton.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing.- The European Union had previously postponed the approval of the textile agreement with Uzbekistan because of child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields.According to the latest observations from the International Labor Organization, child labor has become rare, very occasional and socially acceptable.As for forced labor, NGOs report that it unfortunately still exists.In addition, I am, especially given the current economic climate, opposed to free trade agreements.However, this agreement will have very little impact on France and will allow this poor and landlocked country to find some outlets for its cotton.I thus abstained on this text.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against this report, whose vote I asked to be postponed, because I believe that there are not enough guarantees that the minimum social standards (including ILO standards) necessary to address a bilateral trade agreement in textiles are applied.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor.I am in favor of removing tariffs and barriers to trade in textiles between the EU and Uzbekistan.I consider free trade to be beneficial for both parties.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - In order to include textiles in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement signed by the European Union and Uzbekistan in 1999, ratification of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Union and its Member States with Uzbekistan is required. The European Parliament had already adopted an interim report at the end of 2011, but the European Parliament's consent was conditional on the improvement of human rights in Uzbekistan, especially when it comes to child and forced labor during the annual cotton harvest. Uzbekistan has also cooperated with the International Labor Organization (ILO), which is tasked with evaluating measures taken to eradicate child and forced labor during the annual cotton harvest. The report of the ILO's latest observation mission showed that child labor in cotton picking was almost eradicated, which cannot be confirmed for forced labor as indicators related to the exploitation of workers at work and during the recruitment process are visible. I supported this recommendation as the Uzbek authorities made efforts and made progress towards the final eradication of forced labor.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. – European parliament recalled that ratifying the textiles protocol would mean including textiles in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement concluded between Uzbekistan and the EU in 1999. That title foresees: trade free of quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market-related prices, a safeguard clause, prohibitions or restrictions on imports, exports or goods in transit justified on grounds of public morality, public policy or public security. I fully support developing of cooperation between EU and Uzbekistan.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- The agreement extends the original 1999 agreement on reciprocal trade in textile products.Such trade will be covered by the most-favored-nation clause, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices, a safeguard clause and a reasoned prohibition or restriction on the import, export or transit of goods on grounds of public morality, public policy or public security.The European Parliament has reserved the right to call on the Commission and the Council to take effective action in the event of a finding of human rights violations by Uzbekistan, in particular with regard to child and forced labor.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, to amend the Agreement to extendprovisions of the agreement on bilateral trade in textiles, given the expiration of the bilateral agreement on textiles, because it is not complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the EP decided to withhold consent for this protocol in 2011, the Uzbek Government has slowly but surely cooperated with the EU and the ILO. The ILO has reported significant progress, including the abolition of forced child labour. There is still progress to be made, but the Uzbek government has made important strides in the right direction. I therefore voted to give consent to this protocol.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.The cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan in the field of textiles poses several problems.First, this country is known to use forced labor in the cotton fields.In addition, it is common for children to be forced to work in this sector.These are the reasons why the EU had previously postponed approval of this agreement.Nevertheless, the International Labor Organization carried out checks in the textiles sector and was able to monitor the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan.According to the results of the checks, child labor has become rare and occasional.On the other hand, many NGOs observe that forced labor continues.Taking into account the efforts made by the State to improve working conditions, but retaining reservations following the NGO reports, we abstain on this text.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: in writing. - In 2011, the Commission proposed to extend the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan to the textile trade. The inclusion of the "textile protocol" in this partnership agreement - above all symbolic, given the volumes involved - does not represent an important economic stake for the European Union. At the time, however, the European Parliament had (and rightly so) decided to reserve its consent to a clear improvement in the human rights and labor situation in Uzbekistan. At the time, child labor in the cotton fields was widespread, as was forced labor. The Uzbek government has since partnered with the International Labor Organization (ILO), allowing it to send several observation missions to the field. Five years later, according to the ILO, the situation has improved: child labor has almost disappeared, and forced labor has significantly declined. This is why my colleague Marie Arena, supported by my political group, proposed to finally give the green light to the conclusion of the "textile protocol", while reserving the right to request its suspension if the fundamental rights situation were to arise. degrade. I voted for.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- This report is a legislative proposal in favor of the conclusion of a textile agreement with Uzbekistan.The government of Uzbekistan has made significant progress in improving working conditions in the textile sector in a short period of time, which I believe should be rewarded.That is why I approved this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- Parliament proposes to accept this Council agreement on the extension of import facilities to the European Union of textile products from Uzbekistan.However, this country is not only one of the world's leading cotton producers but also one of the last to still practice slavery!So yes, there is "notable progress" in the eradication of child labor but in addition, there is also, with each harvest, "forced labor" for adults in the fields.If this Parliament really wanted to "promote human rights in the world", it would start concretely by rejecting this kind of agreement.I am voting against cotton harvested with chains!

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- This free trade agreement between the European Communities and their Member States on the one hand and Uzbekistan concerns the textile industry.The European Union initially postponed its acceptance as forced labor was found and children were working in the cotton fields.As the ILO has concluded that child labor has become rarer and more socially acceptable, the EU is therefore submitting this agreement.However, NGOs say that forced labor continues despite everything.In view of these elements, I abstained on this free trade agreement.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: written. - Cotton production is the most important economic sector in the trade relations between the EU and Uzbekistan. This separate resolution evaluates the cooperation between the Uzbek government and the International Labor Organization. Thanks to this collaboration, the steps taken by the Uzbek government to end child labor and forced employment during cotton harvesting in Uzbekistan can be assessed. I am pleased that this collaboration has ensured that child labor is now rare and is no longer tolerated socially. But despite measurable progress in child labor, this is not yet true of forced labor in the cotton industry. It is therefore appropriate and necessary to encourage the Uzbek government to conduct national awareness-raising campaigns and to carry out intensive checks to improve working conditions in its country. Therefore, the cooperation agreement should be read not only as the logical final piece of the efforts made to eradicate child labor, but also as a permanent tool of the European Union to evaluate the commitments to better working conditions to which the Uzbek government is committed.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which shows fundamental changes in Uzbekistan, doing away with child and forced labour and ushering in a new period of openness and cooperation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Council drew up a draft decision on the conclusion of a protocol extending the provisions of the agreement to the partnership and cooperation agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part.In order to adopt the decision, the Council must obtain the consent of Parliament.In its report, the Committee on International Trade proposes that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement.I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- The EU had previously postponed approval of the textile deal with Uzbekistan over child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields.The ILO was able to monitor the cotton harvest: child labor has become rare and occasional and socially acceptable.NGOs say for their part that forced labor continues despite everything.We vote against free trade treaties including on textiles, but this agreement will have very little impact for France and allows this poor landlocked country to find some outlets for its cotton.Abstention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- The EU had previously postponed approval of the textile deal with Uzbekistan over child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields.The ILO was able to monitor the cotton harvest: child labor has become rare and occasional and socially acceptable.NGOs say for their part that forced labor continues despite everything.I am opposed to free trade treaties, including on textiles, but this agreement will have very little impact for France and allows this poor and landlocked country to find some outlets for its cotton.I therefore abstain on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as with the recent passing away of Uzbekistan’s authoritarian leader Islam Karimov, the current period is seen as a valuable opportunity to develop deeper relations between the EU and Uzbekistan and is part of its broader strategy in Central Asia.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text which approves the agreement on trade in textiles with Uzbekistan.This agreement follows the progress made and commitments made by Uzbekistan in the fight against forced labor and child labor.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation that will extend provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Uzbekistan regarding the inclusion of bilateral trade in textiles.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the EP's agreement to extend the scope of the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which has been negotiated since 2011, because, in my opinion, the reasons why the EU has suspended the agreement have passed.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because Uzbekistan has achieved good results in the fight against child and forced labor in a short period of time.I believe this should also be supported.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.Given that Uzbekistan has taken positive steps to eliminate the use of child labor in Uzbek cotton farms, the conclusion of the agreement could further motivate them for further reforms in this area.At the same time, according to several observers, child labor has been replaced by forced labor.This is not acceptable and the EU must monitor the situation very closely and, if necessary, take steps to put an end to such practices.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: written. - The approval of the Protocol amending the Cooperation and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan aims to extend the provisions of the Agreement to trade in textile products, which entails the inclusion of the textile sector within the scope of the 1999 Collaboration and Cooperation (ACC). In 2011, the European Parliament ruled to link the conclusion of an agreement to an improvement of the human rights situation and working conditions in Uzbekistan. Since then, the International Labor Organization has meticulously monitored conditions in the country. It concludes that child labor has been eradicated although doubts persist about forced labor in the textile sector. I have voted in favor of the conclusion of this Protocol in case it favors the improvement of working conditions. In the event that the country suspends compliance with its commitment to abolish forced labor, we will undoubtedly have to activate suspension measures.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - In December 2011, the European Parliament adopted an interim report on the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and the bilateral trade in textiles, subject to its consent to the improvement of the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, in particular with regard to child labor. and forced labor in the context of the annual cotton harvest. A dialogue with Uzbekistan has been launched, through which annual hearings have been held with the participation of various civil society actors, the Uzbek authorities, as well as European and international institutions. There has also been close co-operation between Uzbekistan and the International Labor Organization (ILO) to evaluate actions taken to eliminate child labor and forced labor in the context of the annual cotton harvest in Uzbekistan. The report of the latest ILO inspection mission showed that child labor has been almost completely eliminated during the cotton harvest. However, the same assurances could not be given on the issue of forced labor. It is important, as the report points out, that cotton wholesalers and retailers stop supplying cotton produced by forced child labor in Uzbekistan and inform both consumers and all their suppliers of their position.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleague's draft resolution concerning the draft Council decision on the extension to the provisions relating to bilateral trade in textiles under the partnership agreement between the EU and the Republic of Uzbekistan as I believe that the efforts demonstratedby the Uzbek authorities regarding the abolition of forced labor in Uzbekistan may be considered relevant and sufficient to legitimize the conclusion of the agreement.Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Uzbekistan, of the other part, and the amendment of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to extend its scope to bilateral trade in textiles. Ratification of the Textile Protocol would lead to the inclusion of textiles in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. It provides for the granting of most-favored-nation status in a reciprocal manner, trade without quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices, a safeguard clause and prohibitions or restrictions on imports, exports or transit of goods justified on grounds of public morality, interest or security. In December 2011, the European Parliament adopted an interim report in which it made its agreement conditional on the improvement of human rights in Uzbekistan, especially with regard to child and forced labor during the cotton harvest. A report from the ILO’s most recent observation mission, which ran from September 14 to October 31, 2015, showed that child labor in cotton picking was almost completely eradicated. Public authorities have implemented various measures to eradicate child labor, such as organizing extended school stays, penalties for offenders, and encouraging the accountability of parents, teachers, and farmers. Due to the efforts and progress in this area, I support the modification of the agreement.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The scope of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, concluded in 1999, which establishes a partnership between the European Union and its Member States and Uzbekistan, would be extended to bilateral trade in textiles by adopting the Protocol and amending the Agreement. More precisely, the provisions of the title "Trade in goods" which provide for the granting of the status of the most privileged nation in a reciprocal manner, trade without quantitative restrictions and at market prices and the principle of free transit, would also apply to textiles. At the end of 2011, the European Parliament adopted an interim report in which it conditioned its agreement on improving the human rights situation and launched a dialogue with Uzbekistan, during which annual hearings were held with representatives of civil society, Uzbek authorities and European and international institutions. The latest report on the ILO observation mission, which lasted from 14 September to 31 October 2015, showed that child labor in cotton picking was almost completely eradicated and became a socially unacceptable phenomenon. However, the same cannot be confirmed with regard to forced labor, although the Uzbek authorities have taken several measures to phase it out. The work of the ILO and the efforts of the Uzbek authorities are to be commended and supported, and I call for agreement on the textile protocol. The EU should continue to be an important partner for Uzbekistan in implementing important reforms.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation aims to conclude a “Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other”. The nature of this agreement and its objectives do not differ substantially from the free trade matrix that habitually characterizes agreements of this type. Perhaps it is worth mentioning that the European Parliament itself, which endorses the agreement, recognizes the existence of cases of forced labor in the country with which it is signing the agreement. It matters little. The constraints that result from the reduced diversification of Uzbekistan's economy, from the high dependence, for example, on “cotton monoculture” are recognized. It matters little. Free trade will accentuate this trend, with the intensification of the export nature of production and a disregard for the domestic market. Putting further pressure on European countries that still have a textile industry, such as Portugal. Nothing new: large importers from central Europe benefit, producers from the periphery are harmed. We obviously voted against it.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. - Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR), in writing. - Taking into account the significant progress made in Uzbekistan since 2013, including the adoption of a law banning the use of child labor which has led to the almost complete elimination of child labor, it is recommended to authorize the conclusion of the EU-Uzbekistan Protocol on textiles. The consent will be a positive sign of encouragement for the government of Uzbekistan to continue its efforts to completely eliminate child labor and all other forms of forced labor, and to further strengthen cooperation with the EU. A combination of dialogue and cooperation as well as continued pressure on the Uzbek government from the EU, ILO and World Bank will still be needed to achieve this goal, and reserves the right to call on the Commission and the Council to initiate the Art. 2 and 95 of the PCA, to take all necessary general and specific measures in the event of failure to comply with the commitment to eliminate child labor and forced labor. I hereby support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this recommendation, which aims to extend the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan to bilateral trade in textiles.According to the International Labor Organization, child labor has now virtually disappeared in Uzbekistan, so I encourage the conclusion of this agreement and the total eradication of all forms of forced labor during cotton harvesting work.I remind you that if the country does not continue its efforts in this area, we will ask to suspend the agreement.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - This Recommendation aims to approve the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other, in order to extend the provisions of the referred to the bilateral trade in textile products. The ratification of the protocol on textile products resulted in the inclusion of these products in the partnership and cooperation agreement concluded between Uzbekistan and the European Union in 1999. The provisions of the title "Trade in goods" of that agreement are therefore also applicable to products textiles. One of Parliament's concerns about this agreement was with respect for human rights in Uzbekistan, in particular in relation to child labor and forced labor in the context of the annual cotton harvest. I approve of this report and praise the cooperation established between Uzbekistan and the International Labor Organization, in order to assess and conclude that the measures taken to eradicate child labor in the context of the annual cotton harvest in Uzbekistan have had results.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left-wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - Textile products are now included in the partnership and cooperation agreement concluded between Uzbekistan and the Union in 1999. In December 2011, an interim report had already been approved, making the approval of the agreement conditional on the improvement of the rights situation. particularly in relation to child labor and forced labor in the context of the cotton harvest. Following the approval of this report, a dialogue was established with Uzbekistan, in the framework of which annual hearings were held, with the participation of various stakeholders, namely civil society, Uzbek authorities and European and international institutions. Close cooperation was also established between Uzbekistan and the International Labor Organization. Parliament believes that, in the current context of dialogue and cooperation, efforts by the Uzbek authorities should be encouraged. However, if the Uzbek authorities suspend the application of measures to abolish forced labor, Parliament reserves the possibility to ask the European Commission and the Council to activate Articles 2 and 95 of the partnership agreement. and cooperation, which allow the adoption of general or specific measures for non-respect for human rights.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - In December 2011, the Parliament had already adopted an interim report on the issue which made the consent of the hemicycle conditional on an improvement in the human rights situation in Uzbekistan. Since then, the International Labor Organization has conducted three observation missions which have found, among other things, the virtual eradication of child labor. It was on this basis that, among other things, Parliament agreed to include textiles in the 1999 EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. A decision at the time aimed at encouraging the government of the country to continue to eradicate all forms of forced labor and to strengthen its cooperation with the European Union. In the text of the non-legislative resolution voted on this afternoon, Parliament welcomed the fact that Uzbekistan had started to cooperate with the International Labor Organization, but nevertheless urged the Uzbek authorities to accelerate the deployment of national campaigns of awareness that will eradicate this practice completely. Parliament will therefore continue to monitor the matter and could always, as a last resort, ask the European Commission and the Council to suspend the agreement if the authorities do not keep their commitments in terms of the abolition of forced labor.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Textiles are an important part of Uzbekistan's foreign trade.Foreign trade is, as we know, an important instrument of the EU's external relations.By opening up its market, the EU can encourage partner countries to make progress on human rights and political freedoms.Unfortunately, in the case of Uzbekistan, there is nothing to promote yet.Even after the death of a long-time dictator, the situation in the country is not improving.I myself sincerely wish the people of Uzbekistan to start building a state for themselves, not for a handful of the elect, and I am ready to campaign for all possible help.However, as we can see from the current trends, the time has not yet come for this - it is too early to talk about progress in Uzbekistan.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - We are dealing with a report that concerns a proposal to amend the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the Republic of Uzbekistan signed in 1999, in order to cover the area alluding to bilateral trade in textile products. This inclusion of textile products in the “commodity trade” chapter provides, inter alia, for the reciprocal granting of the most favored nation status, freedom of transit and restrictions on imports, exports and goods in transit for reasons related to morality, order and public safety. For this amendment to the agreement to enter into force, the European Parliament placed the condition for an improvement in the human rights situation in this country, namely in terms of child labor and forced labor. According to a recent report by the International Labor Organization (ILO), there have been clear improvements in this area, especially in terms of child labor, despite the fact that there are still failures in forced labor. Bearing in mind that this worrying situation continues to be closely monitored by the ILO and that Uzbekistan has made a lot of efforts to comply with and enforce labor standards and respect for human rights, I was in favor of approving this report, in the sense that approve the conclusion of the protocol on textile products with this country.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which gives the consent of the European Parliament to establish the textile protocol between the EU and Uzbekistan.Since 2011 and the refusal by the European Parliament to approve this protocol, Uzbekistan has done important work and taken actions to eradicate child labor as well as forced labor.In view of the efforts made and given the publication of the latest ILO monitoring report, Parliament gave its approval to the protocol.However, actions to eradicate forced labor and child labor must continue and if the situation worsens, Parliament reserves the right to request the suspension of this protocol at any time.The trade policy of the European Union is based on values which must be respected.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I have agreed to extend the provisions of the Agreement between the EC and Uzbekistan (PCA) to bilateral trade in textiles.Support is given by the fact that the situation in Uzbekistan with regard to child and forced labor has improved significantly over the past few years.The country has taken appropriate measures to eliminate child and forced labor from the annual cotton harvest.In addition, Uzbekistan has committed itself to applying and expanding the measures in the future.There is therefore nothing to be said against placing trade in textiles under the same conditions as trade in other goods.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this proposal to accept an Agreement that seeks to deepen imports into the Union of textile products from Uzbekistan.The Union with this Agreement once again ignores human rights and legitimizes as an economic partner a country where there is slavery, forced labor in cotton fields and child labor.With this Agreement, the Union once again ignores human rights to act, once again, as a mere ambassador for the interests of the textile transnationals and their multimillion-dollar profits obtained at the cost of perpetuating labor exploitation and dumping.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I have voted in favour of this draft recommendation for consent as we have seen fundamental changes in Uzbekistan, doing away with child and forced labour and ushering in a new period of openness and cooperation. It is important to build on this in order to strengthen civil society.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing.- The purpose of this resolution is to approve the inclusion of bilateral trade in textiles in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and its Member States and the Republic of Uzbekistan.The Republic of Uzbekistan has recently made great progress in eliminating child labor during the annual collection of cotton, which has been almost completely eliminated.I voted in favor.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I have chosen to abstain from this Report, and this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of Members of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia.representative action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Cotton is one of the most important crops grown for textile fiber production, which also plays a significant role in the economic development of Uzbekistan, which has traditionally been one of the largest producers and exporters in the world. Unfortunately, this production also has many negative social and environmental consequences that need to be phased out. I supported the draft non-legislative resolution, as the agreement on the textiles of the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol could be a positive signal to encourage the Uzbek Government to continue its efforts to eliminate child labor and all other forms of forced labor altogether, while further strengthening cooperation with the EU. . I am very positive about the changes in the field of textile trade that have taken place as a result of the dialogue and cooperation between the EU and Uzbekistan. I am pleased that, thanks to concrete reforms, Uzbekistan has achieved major positive results towards the real elimination of forced labor and child labor at national, regional and local levels. As this whole process is not yet complete in Uzbekistan, I consider it necessary to develop further support from the EU and the international community, including the participation of civil society organizations active in the field of human and labor rights.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union's trade agreements with the countries of Central Asia are not only an instrument for economic and political stabilization and the gradual democratization of the region, but are also a way of extending European standards, especially in the field of copyright protection.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The European Parliament is requested to agree to the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Uzbekistan, of the other part, and to amend the Agreement to apply its provisions. expanded to bilateral textile trade. The European Parliament adopted an interim report in December 2011, in which it made its agreement conditional on the improvement of human rights in Uzbekistan, with particular emphasis on the issue of child and forced labor. Following the adoption, a dialogue was launched with Uzbekistan during which annual hearings were held. Public authorities have implemented various measures to eradicate child labor. The European Parliament supports the work done by the ILO to finally eradicate forced labor in Uzbekistan. Efforts by the Uzbek authorities should also be supported. I therefore support this Report because I consider the exploitation of workers and child labor to be an unacceptable social phenomenon. The European Parliament should give its consent to the textile protocol with Uzbekistan. However, in the event that the Uzbek authorities cease to act in order to abolish forced labor, Parliament reserves the right to ask the European Commission and the Council for general and specific measures against human rights violations.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the EU and the Republic of Uzbekistan amending the Agreement to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral textile trade..I support the Protocol on Textiles, which amends the EU-Uzbekistan Partnership Agreement, provided, of course, that the authorities in the Republic of Uzbekistan do not suspend their commitment to abolish forced labor.We must give all support to the International Labor Organization in its work on the elimination of child labor and forced labor in Uzbekistan.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union must make full use of the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities are committed to strengthening the rule of law and democratic reforms.Significant progress has been made on this path with the adoption of legislation banning child labor, but further government action is needed as more indirect and sophisticated forms of forced labor can still be found.The release of prisoners imprisoned for political reasons is essential, and arrests and convictions that violate human rights must be stopped.The European Union will continue to monitor the measures and, if necessary, call on the European Commission and the Council to give effect to Articles 2 and 95 of the Agreement.In line with the above, I vote in favor of the motion.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The European Union has consistently encouraged dialogue with Central Asian countries in recent years. Uzbekistan is one of the main states in the region, both in terms of population and economic development. The EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement was concluded in 1999, which was an important moment in the development of bilateral relations. In 2011, following the request for approval of a Protocol amending the Agreement to facilitate bilateral trade in textiles, the European Parliament adopted an interim approval report, subject to improving the human rights situation, in particular as regards the use of child labor and forced labor in cotton harvesting. The dialogue initiated with Uzbekistan following this report included, in addition to national authorities, civil society, European and international institutions (the International Labor Organization). Currently, according to the latest monitoring reports, child labor in cotton harvesting has been completely eradicated, and the use of child labor has become an isolated phenomenon in other areas. With regard to forced labor, however, significant efforts remain to be made to change the situation on the ground, with a view to implementing international conventions in the field. The Uzbek authorities have pledged to step up the fight against this practice. In these circumstances, I support the adoption of the recommendation.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I followed rapporteur Maria Arena on the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the partnership and cooperation agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States,on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other hand, amending the said agreement in order to extend its provisions to bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the expiration of the bilateral agreement on textiles.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In an effort to strengthen its ties with Uzbekistan, the EU is seeking to add bilateral trade in textiles to the existing EU-Uzbekistan PCA (1999). The trade agreement, more specifically, seeks to forge a closer collaboration between the central Asian country, the EU and the International Labour Organisation to tackle forced and child labour in Uzbekistan, a problem that is prevalent in the country’s cotton industry. I voted in favour of including textiles in our partnership agreement, as the agreement will encourage the Uzbek Government to continue to implement reforms that will allow the country to respect their international commitments regarding human and labour rights, and eventually eradicate forced and child labour.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the "Motion for a Resolution on the EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and Bilateral Textile Trade" with regard to the expiry of the bilateral textile agreement. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan was concluded in 1999 and regulates the general cooperation between the Union and Uzbekistan. This resolution enables the implementation of bilateral trade in textiles in the chapter "Trade in goods" of the above-mentioned partnership agreement with the implication of the validity of all provisions of that chapter on trade in textiles. This would allow trade without restrictions, at market prices and a safeguard clause that would prevent the import or export of goods that are not in the public interest. With this resolution, Parliament supports the work of the ILO, which seeks to eradicate forced labor and child labor in the cotton industry. The ILO report confirmed that the practice of using child labor was almost eradicated, in which the Uzbek government itself participated by introducing various measures and fulfilling the recommendations from the 2011 interim report of the Parliament. The European Parliament should give praise, encouragement and consent as an incentive for such action.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of Mr Arena's report because I believe that the Council's approval of the agreement on cooperation and partnership with Uzbekistan would be beneficial to both parties.It will also have a positive effect on reciprocal trade in fiber products.This decision by the Council and Parliament is awaiting a European clothing factory because the cheap raw material from Uzbekistan will improve the competitive position of European products in the textile industry.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I supported the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the Member States and the Republic of Uzbekistan, and amending the Agreement to extend its application to bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the expiration of the bilateral agreement.textiles.Namely, the government of the Republic of Uzbekistan has made significant progress since 2013 in the fight against child labor by adopting a law banning the exploitation of child labor.I believe that the adoption of this Recommendation would be an incentive for the Uzbek government to make further efforts to completely eradicate child labor and all other forms of forced labor.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part with textiles, given the expiry of the bilateral textile agreement, I supported. The European Parliament has been asked to approve a protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Uzbekistan, of the other part, to extend the provisions of this Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. The country would receive benefits such as trade without quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices, and so on. Uzbekistan has so far completely eliminated child labor in picking cotton, but there is still too much forced labor with exploitative working conditions.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Economic partnership between the EU and Uzbekistan should be promoted.Cooperation may bring tangible benefits not only to Uzbekistan but also to EU Member States.The cultural exchange, which is very widespread in our countries, should also be extended to economic exchange.I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- The European Parliament is requested to approve the Protocol extending the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles annexed to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against granting consent to the signing of the protocol that would extend the provisions of the EU-Uzbekistan Cooperation and Partnership Agreement to the textile sector. We appreciate that since Parliament postponed taking a decision on the GPA in 2011, there have been significant improvements on the ground: not only have ILO missions to Uzbekistan been allowed, but they have also shown a very favorable evolution, especially in the eradication of child labor. However, the situation of the textile sector in Uzbekistan is far from reaching a minimum of labor and social guarantees that we consider essential to approve this agreement. Both the ILO and other observers warn of the systematic use of forced labor in the sector. This is reason enough for us to be against the Union granting advantages to this sector, since these advantages would only serve as an incentive to increase production and thus these practices.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against, because this consent procedure should have been initiated after December, when the ILO report on the 2016 cotton harvest will be available. One of the conditions included in the interim report that the European Parliament adopted in 2011 included the need to eradicate child labour and other forms of forced labour. Even though there has been considerable progress in the eradication of child labour, the same result is likely to not have been achieved regarding forced labour.
