This is why the independent ILO assessment is a key tool to evaluate the possibility of giving our consent to this Protocol.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing.- The European Parliament is requested to approve the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement to extend bilateral trade in textile products.With the ratification of the Protocol on Textiles, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) between Uzbekistan and the EU, concluded in 1999, would include textiles.Therefore, the provisions of the above-mentioned chapter of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement on trade in goods would also apply to textiles.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, taking account of the expiry of the bilateral textiles Agreement. Parliament is asked to give its consent to the Protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and the Republic of Uzbekistan extending the provisions of that Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. Ratifying the textiles protocol would mean including textiles in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) concluded between Uzbekistan and the EU in 1999. The report on the ILO’s last monitoring mission revealed that the practice of using child labour in cotton harvesting had been virtually eradicated. I voted in favour because I fully support the work done by the ILO to abolish forced labour in Uzbekistan definitively.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written. - This proposal aims to include the textile sector of Uzbekistan within the scope of the 1999 Cooperation and Partnership Agreement, since according to its article 16 the textile sector was excluded from the obligations of most-favored-nation treatment and the prohibition of quantitative restrictions, yes applicable to other sectors. This proposal can fill the gap that supposes that Uzbekistan is not a member of the World Trade Organization, since as long as it does not join that body, it will not be bound by the most-favored-nation clause and the multilateral rules that are established. all its members apply. This report comes after several years of efforts by the authorities to eradicate - based on the guidelines provided by the Union - child labor, backed by a 2015 investigation that reveals the virtual elimination of this practice and applauds the measures taken To achieve this (after-school care, fines for those who promote it and higher levels of responsibility for parents, teachers and farmers…), having managed to make using child labor considered a socially unacceptable practice. For all these reasons, I have considered it appropriate to vote in favor of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this proposal to accept an Agreement that seeks to deepen imports into the Union of textile products from Uzbekistan.The Union with this Agreement once again ignores human rights and legitimizes as an economic partner a country where there is slavery, forced labor in cotton fields and child labor.With this Agreement, the Union once again ignores human rights to act, once again, as a mere ambassador for the interests of the textile transnationals and their multimillion-dollar profits obtained at the cost of perpetuating labor exploitation and dumping.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor because the European Parliament adopted an interim report in December 2011, in which it makes its approval conditional on improving the human rights situation in Uzbekistan with an emphasis on child and forced labor in the annual cotton harvest.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The report accompanying the recommendation, which proposes the conclusion of the Agreement, contains, under the pretext of the supposed aid, unacceptable and unequivocal considerations of the instruments that the European Union uses to ingest sovereign states, seeking to condition its social and economic policies, withthe superb vanity of those who think they can teach lessons.We voted against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- This report is a legislative proposal in favor of the conclusion of a textile agreement with Uzbekistan.The government of Uzbekistan has made significant progress in improving working conditions in the textile sector in a short period of time, which I believe should be rewarded.That is why I approved this report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With the recent passing away of Uzbekistan’s authoritarian leader Islam Karimov, the current period is seen as a valuable opportunity to develop deeper relations between the EU and Uzbekistan and is part of its broader strategy in Central Asia. Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report as we believe that, in the context of the ongoing dialogue and cooperation, it is appropriate for Parliament to give its consent to the textile protocol with Uzbekistan. However, if the Uzbek authorities fail to follow through on their commitment to abolish forced labour, Parliament reserves the right to ask the Commission and the Council to activate Articles 2 and 95 of the PCA, allowing general or specific measures to be taken in the event of a failure to respect human rights.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the recommendation on the conclusion of a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Community and the Republic of Uzbekistan, amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and extending it to trade in textiles.Although a partnership and cooperation agreement was concluded with Uzbekistan as early as 1999, the textile sector was excluded due to the widespread use of child and forced labor to harvest cotton.In 2011, the European Parliament refused to abolish this derogation as the problem persisted in Uzbekistan.However, much has changed since then, with Uzbekistan passing new laws to eliminate child labor, and its almost complete disappearance confirmed by independent observers.That is why I think that these changes in Uzbekistan need to be appreciated, and I believe that the extension of the agreement on trade in textile products will encourage Uzbekistan to adopt further positive reforms.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part. textiles, subject to the expiry of the bilateral textile agreement. According to the report of the last ILO observation mission, the competent authorities in Uzbekistan have successfully implemented measures to eliminate child labor and made several further commitments to phase out forced adult labor, including the establishment of a feedback mechanism to respond to population complaints. awareness-raising campaigns and the establishment of a program to evaluate the implementation of international conventions in this field. I therefore support the approval of a protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Uzbekistan, of the other part, to extend the provisions of this agreement to bilateral trade in textiles.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan regarding textiles is a dossier opened a long time ago, but it remained blocked for a long time due to the widespread child labor in Uzbekistan.I believe that the fact that children and adults were mobilized en masse during the cotton harvesting season is an inhumane practice.It must be said in this sense that, although the Uzbek authorities were unwilling to discuss the problem, the EU has worked hard over the years to combat this phenomenon and in fact in recent years the situation has greatly improved, the country has in fact decided to open upand to collaborate with international institutions.The fact that the situation has improved a lot and that cooperation and dialogue has been established between Uzbekistan and the European institutions are the reasons why I voted in favor.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this Resolution that accompanies the Agreement with Uzbekistan since it legitimizes an Agreement that rejects and washes its hands regarding human rights by focusing on the existence of a clause that allows its freezing in the event of violation of these.In other words, an Agreement with a country with flagrant violations of human rights, such as forced labor or child exploitation, is justified, justifying that it will be frozen if human rights are violated.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles. The textile sector, especially cotton production, is a key area of ​​trade between the EU and Uzbekistan. I support the provision in the resolution which states that in Uzbekistan, from 2013 onwards, Significant progress has been made, including the adoption of laws banning the use of child labor and the almost complete abolition of child labor. The resolution encourages the Uzbek authorities to continue the nationwide campaign to raise awareness for the complete elimination of child labor. It is to be welcomed that the Government of Uzbekistan, in cooperation with the International Labor Organization (ILO), is also working to eliminate forced labor, and that progress has been made, but it must be emphasized that there are still hidden, unpublished cases of involuntary work. The situation calls for employment policy reforms. I am of the opinion that, as a result of these efforts by the Uzbek Government, Parliament should give its consent to the EU-Uzbekistan Protocol on Textiles, as an incentive for the Uzbek Government to continue its efforts to abolish child labor and all other forms of forced labor and to further strengthen cooperation. with the EU.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, to amend the Agreement to extend the provisions of the agreement on bilateral trade in textiles, given the expiration of the bilateral agreement on textiles, because Uzbekistan has demonstrated in recent years its willingness to continue cooperating with the EU.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report contains a non-legislative proposal and is complementary to the draft recommendation on the EU-Uzbekistan textile protocol for which I propose to vote abstention. The European Union previously postponed approval of the textile deal with Uzbekistan because of child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields. The ILO was able to monitor the cotton harvest: child labor has become rare and occasional. NGOs say forced labor continues, but the European Parliament welcomes Uzbekistan’s efforts. The latter calls for continued efforts and asks the European Commission for a traceability mechanism in the garment sector, respect for ILO standards by Uzbekistan, an end to forced child labor, respect for democratic rights and NGOs. He also recommends voting for the text on the textile protocol. Since certain elements of the report constitute interference in the policy of a sovereign state, I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I followed the whips’ recommendation to vote in favour of this motion, having insufficient personal knowledge of the situation to be able to consider doing otherwise. I note that Uzbekistan has made genuine steps towards improving workers’ rights in recent years and that further trade deals will help build a safer working environment in that country.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this recommendation in order to extend the provisions of the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan to include the textile trade.The report of the last mission of the International Labor Organization which took place from September 14 to October 31, 2015 notes that the public authorities have put in place various measures to eliminate child labor.In view of the respect of this condition, I therefore considered that the agreement could be extended.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Council decision on the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textile products.2011The European Parliament adopted a preliminary report stating that it would approve the agreement if the human rights situation in Uzbekistan improved, in particular as regards child labor and forced labor each year during the cotton harvest.The latest International Labor Organization (ICO) monitoring mission shows the efforts of the Uzbek authorities to abolish forced labor.In the light of the ongoing dialogue and cooperation, I welcome the agreement with Uzbekistan on a textile agreement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report calls for compliance in Uzbekistan with the standards of the International Labor Organization.Although this intention is laudable, the report is extremely intrusive since it includes this part: "Endorses the idea of extending the country program for the promotion of decent work beyond 2016 and deepening it in order to encompassmodernization of the Uzbek economy, employment policy, occupational health and safety and labor inspection, while taking into account gender equality."Being resolutely against the interference, I chose to abstain.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report by my colleague Marie Arena which proposes, via a protocol, to extend the cooperation agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and Uzbekistan, on the other hand, to bilateral trade in textiles given the expiration of the bilateral agreement on textiles. This would include, among other things, the granting of reciprocal most-favored-nation status, trade free of quantitative restrictions, a safeguard clause and the principle of transit. The negotiations with a view to the implementation of this protocol were notably facilitated by the fact that child labor during the cotton harvest had been practically completely eradicated according to the last monitoring mission carried out by the ILO in 2015 in Uzbekistan. Unfortunately, this is not the case with the situation of forced labor. Therefore, the report specifies that Parliament will adopt appropriate measures if the Uzbek authorities were to suspend the implementation of their commitment to abolish forced labor.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the non-legislative motion for a resolution on the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan and bilateral trade in textiles. The text underlines the importance of the action taken in recent years by the Uzbek government to authorize the ILO to monitor the cotton harvest, and welcomes the country's commitment to defining the national program for decent work. Parliament's vote in favor of the Protocol to the Partnership Agreement is a direct consequence of these assessments. However, the Central Asian republic presents numerous problems linked in particular to subtle forms of non-voluntary work, which would require profound changes in employment policies to be definitively eradicated. Also in the textile sector, strong action should be taken to ensure an increase in the wages of cotton pickers, mechanization and greater budgetary transparency as regards the revenue from the harvest. These are revolutionary measures that the European Union should promote by contributing, thanks to political dialogue and assistance programs, to the realization of those structural reforms necessary for Uzbekistan,

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against the accompanying resolution because, although I agree with most of its points, the rapporteur takes, based on that diagnosis that I share, the opposite conclusion: that the European Parliament should grant consent to the signing of the protocol that would extend the provisions of the EU-Uzbekistan cooperation and partnership agreement to the textile sector. Indeed, the report expresses concern that forced labor remains a common practice in the textile sector in Uzbekistan today. I share with the rapporteur the opinion on the progress that has been made in the country; and I subscribe to the request made in the resolution for the Commission to present as soon as possible the Union's flagship initiative on responsible management of the supply chain in the textile sector. However, I do not share with this resolution its main purpose: to support a consent procedure with which I do not agree.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I have supported this Resolution on the Agreement for collaboration and cooperation between the European Communities and Uzbekistan and bilateral trade in textile products.Following today's vote in favor of the Agreement, this Resolution underlines the importance of the measures taken by the Government of Uzbekistan to authorize the ILO to supervise the cotton harvest and cooperate with this organization within the framework of a work programdecent by country.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- I wanted to abstain from this report on the EC-Uzbekistan cooperation partnership agreement on bilateral trade in the textile sector.Complementing the previous draft recommendation on the subject, I reiterate my doubts about the “progress” made by Uzbekistan on forced labor, in particular child labor.Furthermore, I deny that the European Commission has the power to impose a traceability mechanism in the clothing sector.As usual, the EU uses the means of intervention to blackmail and threaten countries on their political, economic and social models.Therefore, I suggest to be careful, without sanctioning Uzbekistan, it is also not to encourage the European Union to dictate its laws in terms of international agreements.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- I wanted to support with my vote the resolution of the Committee on International Trade (INTA) which accompanies the approval of the protocol on textiles between the EU and Uzbekistan, given that this agreement does not present problems for our territories.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, in which the European Parliament takes the view that, as a result of the Uzbek Government's efforts, Parliament should give its consent to the EU-Uzbekistan Protocol on textiles. Such support would be a positive sign for the Government of Uzbekistan to continue its efforts to eliminate child labor and all other forms of forced labor, as well as to further strengthen cooperation with the European Union. Parliament welcomes the significant progress made since 2013. In Uzbekistan, including the adoption of laws banning the use of child labor and the almost complete abolition of child labor. He encourages the authorities to continue the nationwide campaign to raise awareness for the complete elimination of child labor. It also welcomes the fact that the Government of Uzbekistan, in cooperation with the International Labor Organization, is also working to eliminate forced labor and that progress has been made, but stresses that there are still subtle forms of involuntary work that are complex and require, among other things, employment policy reforms.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Today's vote on the partnership and cooperation agreement is an important step in relations between the European Union and Uzbekistan.In recent years, thanks also to the support of international organizations such as the ILO, important progress has been made in the field of combating and eradicating the scourge of forced labor, especially child labor.These developments in the country must necessarily continue until the complete end of this hateful practice: for my part, I will continue to closely monitor the evolution of the situation in the INTA committee.By voting in favor of this dossier, we hope to give a concrete message of confidence to Uzbekistan, hoping that soon we will be able to speak only in the past about the scourge of forced labor in this country.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Report, which is also a success of S & D's trade policy.Thanks to the requirements set by our group, we have seen fundamental changes in Uzbekistan, stopping the forced labor of children and announcing a new era for openness and cooperation.Therefore, we all need to continue working together to strengthen civil society.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report over concern about human rights. There is an existing EU—Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement in place since 1999, but it excludes the textile industry. In 2011 the European Parliament refused to give consent to a Commission proposal to include the textile industry in the PCA due to evidence of the systematic use of child labour in cotton harvesting related to the textile industry. The Commission says this is no longer a problem but human rights NGOs believe it is still a problem.  We voted in favour of a Greens request to postpone the vote until after an ILO report next year, which should shed further clarity on the ongoing extent of child labour, but it was defeated. Due to the allegations of ongoing child labour by credible human rights and labour rights NGOs, we are strongly opposed to this agreement.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing.- The updating and renewal of the agreement stipulated with the Republic of Uzbekistan is a necessary formal act, which sanctions its full implementation and which is hoped for a positive development for both contracting parties in the long term.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - This resolution deals with the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan in order to extend the provisions to bilateral trade in textiles. The European Union had recently postponed approval of the agreement due to multiple cases of forced labor and child labor on some farms. Since this postponement, the International Labor Organization (ILO) as well as NGOs have been able to confirm a clear decline in these unacceptable practices. Of course, we always oppose in principle any free trade agreement, especially when it concerns textiles in order to protect French companies from unfair international competition. But this agreement will have a low impact on the French economy and does not pose a threat to our businesses. This is the reason why I abstained on this report which will help to increase the outlets for Uzbek farms, in a country sufficiently marginalized from trade relations.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The Protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, envisages extending the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. Thus, this protocol implies the inclusion of textile products in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement concluded between Uzbekistan and the European Union. The human rights situation has seen a visible improvement in the use of child labor and forced labor in the annual cotton harvest in Uzbekistan. According to the International Labor Organization's 2015 report, child labor in cotton harvesting has been abolished, and a number of advances have been made in forced labor among adults and appropriate measures have been taken to eradicate it. I welcome the efforts made to respect human rights and the abolition of child labor and forced labor. The textile sector is the main area of ​​trade between the Union and Uzbekistan, and I therefore consider this resolution to be an opportunity to expand and strengthen relations between the two partners, which is why I have spoken in favor of this motion for a resolution.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this accompanying report to the economic partnership agreement with Uzbekistan (extended to the textile sector) because it offers valid ideas to the Commission to improve the economic and social situation of the country of the former Soviet Union. Cooperation between the International Labor Organization (ILO) and the Uzbek government gradually expanded, and in 2014 Uzbekistan became the first Central Asian country to agree on a national decent work program with the ILO. Awareness of forced labor in Uzbekistan is still at an early stage, but ILO surveys indicate that workers are mostly voluntary in harvesting cotton and have the option to refuse to do so. The report calls on the Commission and the European External Action Service to monitor the political transition in Uzbekistan, regularly informing Parliament, and encourages the Uzbek government to work towards the ratification and effective implementation of all 27 key international conventions of the GSP + commercial incentive system, in order to be able to request the application of GSP + generalized tariff preferences.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which attempted to include Uzbekistan’s textile industry in a pre-existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with the EU. In 2011, the European Parliament refused to give its consent to the Commission’s proposal to include it due to evidence of systematic use of child labour in cotton harvesting related to the industry. Despite widespread reporting that child labour is still a problem in the industry by leading human rights NGOs, such as Human Rights Watch, the Commission thought it appropriate to include it. I fundamentally disagreed so voted against.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution amending the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. Following reports of the use of child and forced labour during the cotton harvest, the Government of Uzbekistan authorised the ILO to monitor the cotton harvest and to engage in broad cooperation with ILO through a Decent Work Country Programme. I welcome the substantial progress made in Uzbekistan, including the adoption of laws which prohibit the use of child labour, achieving the almost total eradication of child labour. The Government of Uzbekistan is also pursuing the eradication of forced labour in cooperation with the ILO and that progress has been made, but problems still exist that require, among other things, a reform of employment policies. I agree that in view of the efforts being made by the Government of Uzbekistan, Parliament should give consent to the EU-Uzbekistan Textiles Protocol as it will constitute a positive sign of encouragement to the Uzbek Government to further pursue its efforts to fully eradicate child labour and all other forms of forced labour, as well as to further strengthen cooperation with the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Until a few years ago, the "mass mobilization" of children and adults during the cotton harvesting season, a fundamental asset for the country's exports, was a sad reality that the Uzbek authorities were reluctant to discuss.In recent years, however, the country has decided to open up, to collaborate with international institutions and has begun a strong policy of deterring the use of forced labor, especially child labor.The situation in Uzbekistan has significantly improved, forced labor is now sporadic while child labor can be considered uprooted.My vote was positive.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. - Cotton production is an important trade sector between the Union and Uzbekistan. In this area, the European institutions have initiated political dialogue on sensitive issues such as human rights. The protocol represents the consolidation of a long process that began in 2011, when Parliament made its approval of the protocol conditional on the improvement of the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, especially with regard to child labor and forced labor in the cotton harvest. Thanks to the successful cooperation between the Uzbek authorities, the EU and the International Labor Organization (ILO), the country has made great progress in eradicating child labor, through concrete reforms and the national decent work program. The direction taken is the right one, but the road is still long. Continued forced labor in cotton harvesting requires urgent reform of employment policies and continued commitment by the new government. In conclusion, I believe that this protocol confirms the EU's support for the democratic path taken by the country. I hope that the new government of the Uzbek republic can start from this important result to continue the fight against forced labor. For these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report and emphasize that we fully support the work of the International Labor Organization with a view to the definitive elimination of forced labor in Uzbekistan.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favor of the report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Uzbekistan, with a view to extending the provisions of the agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. bilateral agreement on these products. The development of cooperation between the two parties is positive and legitimate. However, as there are specific objections to the situation in the workplace and the working conditions of the citizens of Uzbekistan, I decided to vote against the proposal.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - I applaud the decision to consolidate our trade relations with Uzbekistan in an ever more decisive manner given the considerable potential it enjoys. In detail, this is the extension of bilateral trade provisions for textiles that would be included in the partnership and cooperation agreement concluded in 1999. Therefore, trade will be made free from quantitative restrictions, free transit of goods with prices market with a safeguard clause, prohibition or restriction on imports, exports and transit if justified on grounds of public morality, order or security. Uzbekistan has centuries-old traditions in cotton processing and is among the main producers and exporters of this raw material, therefore European textile machinery companies will find new business opportunities in a textile market of sure interest in the long term. Furthermore, the Uzbek market could offer interesting opportunities to foreign companies that produce highly technological equipment and machinery in the agri-food, metalworking, car components, agricultural, steel and railway machinery sectors. Furthermore, urban planning, environmental remediation, the marketing of biodegradable and environmentally friendly consumer goods should not be underestimated. At present, although it has considerable potential, the Uzbek market sees a sporadic national presence at the level of foreign direct investments which, in any case, will see significant growth.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the EC—Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution accompanying the assent on the same subject.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this Resolution that accompanies the Agreement with Uzbekistan since it legitimizes an Agreement that rejects and washes its hands regarding human rights by focusing on the existence of a clause that allows its freezing in the event of violation of these.In other words, an agreement with a country with flagrant violations of human rights, such as forced labor or child exploitation, is justified, justifying that it will be frozen if human rights are violated.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles. I believe that expanding cooperation in trade based on partnership relations will bring benefits for the economy and create new development prospects. Consideration should be given to the significant progress made in Uzbekistan since 2013, including the adoption of legislation banning the use of child labor, which has led to an almost complete elimination of child labor. This kind of activities reducing the use of children as cheap labor prove the willingness to develop cooperation and the adoption of European standards. It also increases the protection of children's rights. Continued discussions with the government of Uzbekistan on the part of the EU are important to ensure that the provisions are effectively implemented. The Commission and Council are also called upon to initiate the Art. 2 and 95 of the PCA, to take all necessary general and specific measures in the event of failure to comply with the commitment to eliminate child labor and forced labor.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Uzbekistan has cooperated with both the European Union and the International Labour Organisation while also abolishing forced child labour. We need to make sure that Uzbekistan lives up to its commitment. I am in favour of an EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles which further builds on the improvements observed to strengthen civil society. I voted in favour of extending the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. - European trade policy has a double value: the first is purely economic, that is, aimed at increasing opportunities for European companies; the second is purely social, ie tending to the promotion and protection of human rights in third countries. The agreement with Uzbekistan is a clear example of this. In light of the dramatic phenomenon of rampant child labor in Uzbekistan, in 2011 the European Parliament - at the urging of our group - denied the consent on the protocol on cotton within the cooperation agreement with the country. This denial was a strong political signal for Uzbekistan, with significant economic consequences - since cotton is one of the largest export products for this country. Following this decision, Uzbekistan has begun to cooperate with the EU and the International Labor Organization (ILO). Although respect for human rights in Uzbekistan still needs to be strengthened, the ILO has made significant progress in recent years, primarily by recording the definitive abolition of child labor. Thanks to the priorities established by our group, therefore, the European Union has achieved an extraordinary double result: the opening of a new commercial channel and, above all, respect for human rights.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This consultation report proposes the positive opinion of the European Parliament to the Commission's proposal to include trade provisions for textile products in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) concluded between the European Union and theUzbekistan.The Uzbek authorities have adopted a series of measures to eliminate child labor, such as the provision of after-school care, fines for violators, or the accountability of parents, teachers and operators.agricultural.Considering this positive progress and being in favor of a rapprochement of the Union with Uzbekistan in the framework of deep cooperation, I voted in favor of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text setting out recommendations on the EU / Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement and bilateral trade in textiles.While the efforts led by the Uzbek authorities to eradicate child labor legitimize the introduction of the textile trade into EU-Uzbekistan relations, European encouragement must, however, be coupled with careful monitoring of respect for human rights.'man.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union must make full use of the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities are committed to strengthening the rule of law and democratic reforms.Significant progress has been made on this path with the adoption of legislation banning child labor, but further government action is needed as more indirect and sophisticated forms of forced labor can still be found.The release of prisoners imprisoned for political reasons is essential, and arrests and convictions that violate human rights must be stopped.The European Union will continue to monitor the measures and, if necessary, call on the European Commission and the Council to give effect to Articles 2 and 95 of the Agreement.In line with the above, I vote in favor of the motion.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - For three years, in cooperation with the International Labor Organization (ILO), the Uzbek authorities have worked to end forced labor and child labor in the country. Important progress has been made. The most significant concerns child labor which, according to the latest ILO reports, is now virtually eradicated. It is in light of this progress and the awareness by the Uzbek authorities of the importance of respecting international labor standards and human rights - as well as the implementation of a strategy in this meaning - that the European Parliament has given its approval to the inclusion of textiles in the areas of commercial cooperation covered by the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Uzbekistan. It remains essential to follow developments in the situation with the greatest vigilance. Recall that cases of forced labor are still observed in Uzbekistan. We therefore expect the authorities to continue to intensify their efforts to end it. Thus, any deterioration in the human rights and labor law situation will necessarily lead to an immediate suspension of the preferences granted under these agreements.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.This is a motion for a non-legislative resolution complementary to the draft recommendation on the EU-Uzbekistan textile protocol.The aim is to demand traceability efforts in the garment sector.This text also demands from Uzbekistan: - an end to forced labor and child labor;- respect for fundamental rights and the principles of democracy;- more freedom of action for NGOs.These demands, which certainly relate to fundamental rights, amount to interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state.Note, however, that the text advocates the ratification of the agreement on trade in textiles.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - I welcome the report and the recommendation. I am glad that Uzbekistan has implemented measures to eliminate child labor when picking cotton. In the 21st century, the use of child labor is unacceptable and cannot be tolerated in any country in the world. I therefore congratulate the International Labor Organization and the Uzbek Government on achieving these results. There are, of course, a few more steps that need to be taken to eradicate forced labor in cotton collection. I am particularly worried that everything achieved so far could fail dizzyingly due to the death of President Islam Kerimov. That is why we, as the EU, and the rest of the world must closely monitor the development of political life in this republic.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- Agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought to promote the development of the Member States of the European Union without prejudice to their national and economic interests.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution on EC-Uzbekistan partnership and cooperation agreement and bilateral trade in textiles, according to the wishes of students from Wales who wanted to show solidarity with Uzbek students. Thousands of university students were forcibly mobilised by the government to pick cotton and threatened with expulsion from college if they refused. I oppose all forms of modern slavery.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Uzbek government has authorized the ILO to control the cotton harvest, with the ILO carrying out a number of controls, initially focusing on child labor and subsequently extended to forced labor and recruitment conditions.The latest oversight campaign carried out by the ILO during the 2015 cotton harvest shows that the use of child labor for the cotton harvest has become rare, sporadic and socially unacceptable, but that it is necessary to keep a constant watch.The Uzbek Government has been committed to eradicating forced labor in collaboration with the ILO, of which there is some progress.Therefore, the EU should take full advantage of the enlargement of the PCA to ensure that the Uzbek authorities are engaged in a transition process leading to better governance, strengthening the rule of law, democratic reforms and improvementthe human rights situation.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention: we are voting against free trade treaties including on textiles, but this agreement will have very little impact on France and allows this poor and landlocked country to find outlets for its cotton.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report accompanies the recommendation that endorses the conclusion of a “Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other” . The report supports the conclusion of the Agreement, which does not differ substantially from the free trade matrix that characterizes such agreements. The report acknowledges the existence of cases of forced labor in Uzbekistan. For the majority of this parliament, it matters little. The constraints that result from the reduced diversification of Uzbekistan's economy, from the high dependence, for example, on “cotton monoculture” are recognized. It matters little. Free trade will accentuate this trend, with the intensification of the export nature of production and a disregard for the domestic market. Putting further pressure on European countries that still have a textile industry, such as Portugal. Nothing new: large importers from central Europe benefit, producers from the periphery are harmed. The report beckons with propaganda measures that, he hopes, serve to obscure its real effects. In addition, it unravels a usual rosary of interference and considerations about the way the State is organized in this country. We voted against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because as a result of considerable efforts by the Uzbek government, the scourge of child labor has largely been healed.It therefore appears desirable to encourage the efforts of the Uzbek authorities by approving the textile protocol with Uzbekistan.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted no because I disagree.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor as with this agreement the European Parliament has demanded a lot from Uzbekistan in terms of respect for human rights.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of extending the provisions of the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles (resolution), as agreements between the EU and third countries should be sought to promote the development of the Member States of the European Union, withouttheir national and economic interests are affected.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We expect immediate action to forbid the use of systematic forced child labour. Following this, Uzbekistan has slowly but surely cooperated with not only the EU, but the ILO – allowing an unhindered inspection of the cotton harvest to take place for the last three years. This is a success for our trade policy. Thanks to demands laid down by our Group, we have seen fundamental changes in Uzbekistan, doing away with child and forced labour and ushering in a new period of openness and cooperation. We want to build on this to strengthen civil society.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union must make full use of the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities are committed to strengthening the rule of law and democratic reforms.Significant progress has been made in this direction with the adoption of legislation banning child labor, but further government action is needed as more indirect and sophisticated forms of forced labor can still be found.The release of prisoners imprisoned for political reasons is essential, and arrests and convictions that violate human rights must be stopped.The European Union will continue to monitor the measures and, if necessary, call on the European Commission and the Council to give effect to Articles 2 and 95 of the Agreement.In line with the above, I vote in favor of the motion.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution presented to the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan , on the other, amending the agreement to extend its provisions to bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the expiry of the bilateral agreement on textiles because, five years after the postponement of the decision on the approval of the protocol, finally the Uzbek government has shown that it has adopted action plans to change the recruitment for cotton harvesting and has promoted important awareness-raising operations against child exploitation in cotton harvesting. I am very pleased with the measures taken by Uzbekistan to try to ensure access to unforced labor and the significant support that the EU and the international labor organization have shown for a government that is now ready to resolve this age-old issue. I am convinced that from today it will be possible to talk about new conditions for opening up new scenarios of close collaboration with Uzbekistan and that we will work together with the aim of building a civil society based on full respect for fundamental human rights.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- The agreement stands for the continuous improvement of working conditions in the cotton fields in Uzbekistan.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ After intense research I decided to vote for this recommendation. I note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which accompanies the report granting consent to the EU—Uzbekistan Textiles Protocol. This resolution crucially allows us to highlight areas where we expect further improvement, increased monitoring and effective implementation. Amongst others, these include: – the possibility to suspend the Protocol if the commitment to the abolition of forced labour is not lived up to; – monitoring of developments in Uzbekistan and decision to organise a regular dialogue with the ILO, the Commission, the EEAS and other stakeholders aimed at the total eradication of forced labour in Uzbekistan; – measures to encourages Uzbekistan to work towards the ratification and effectively implementation of all 27 GSP+ core international conventions, in order to be able to apply for GSP+ tariff preferences; – a call on the Commission to submit to Parliament a legislative proposal for an effective traceability mechanism in the garment sector.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution but, as repeatedly stressed in the provision, I remain of the opinion that this assent is to be linked to constant monitoring of the effective eradication of the scourge of child labor and efforts to combat forced labor. It is not enough to say that the textile sector, and in particular cotton production, is the main area of ​​trade between the EU and Uzbekistan. We must remain vigilant and not endorse practices that undermine the rights of workers. Only in this way will we be able to support with conviction what for now remains an agreement aimed at expressing our will to support and encourage the steps already taken in this direction. An encouragement that is all the more appropriate if we think that it comes after celebrating the 22nd anniversary of the creation of diplomatic relations between Uzbekistan and the European Union which took place on November 16, 1994. However, so that relations can continue in the sign of constant political and social improvement, as well as an increase in trade, collaboration with the ILO remains essential for respecting the objectives of the EU's common commercial policy and respecting European values.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against the accompanying resolution because, although I agree with most of its points, the rapporteur takes, based on that diagnosis that I share, the opposite conclusion: that the European Parliament should grant consent to the signing of the protocol that would extend the provisions of the EU-Uzbekistan cooperation and partnership agreement to the textile sector. Indeed, the report expresses concern that forced labor remains a common practice in the textile sector in Uzbekistan today. I share with the rapporteur the opinion on the progress that has been made in the country; and I subscribe to the request made in the resolution for the Commission to present as soon as possible the Union's flagship initiative on responsible management of the supply chain in the textile sector. However, I do not share with this resolution its main purpose: to support a consent procedure with which I do not agree.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I have voted to support this resolution. Uzbekistan has slowly but surely cooperated with not only the EU, but the ILO – allowing an unhindered inspection of the cotton harvest to take place for the last three years. They have also broadened ILO cooperation in a number of other areas. The ILO has reported significant progress, and although concerns remain about the use of adult labour, most monitoring reports state that Uzbekistan has been cooperative in trying to do away with this.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of extending the EU-Uzbekistan Association Agreement to bilateral textile trade, after having verified that our rejection of it, 5 years ago, has had the desired impact. In 2011, at the initiative of the Socialists, the European Parliament rejected the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, until this country demonstrated progress in human rights and labor standards. Today, the European Union (EU) and the International Labor Organization (ILO) have reported a clear evolution in the required direction. Among other measures, the Uzbek government has taken the steps required to eradicate child exploitation - previously used systematically in the cotton fields and now almost non-existent - and in favor of trade union dialogue, it cooperates with the ILO within the framework of the Decent Work Program and has authorized international supervision of cotton crops; further proof that the Union's trade policy, accompanied by an adequate external dialogue, is a key tool for promoting human rights and labor standards in the world. Furthermore, we Socialists have called on the Commission to develop accompanying measures and an effective traceability mechanism for the textile sector.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted against the report because we cannot ignore the allegations of child labor in this country.By accepting the protocol, we are giving the wrong message to the country's authorities to improve this situation.Also, the promotion of textiles in the European Union by Uzbekistan will discourage the country from the urgent need for changes in the agricultural sector.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union must make full use of the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities are committed to strengthening the rule of law and democratic reforms.Significant progress has been made in this direction with the adoption of legislation banning child labor, but further government action is needed as more indirect and sophisticated forms of forced labor can still be found.The release of prisoners imprisoned for political reasons is essential, and arrests and convictions that violate human rights must be stopped.The European Union will continue to monitor the measures and, if necessary, call on the European Commission and the Council to give effect to Articles 2 and 95 of the Agreement.In line with the above, I vote in favor of the motion.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report containing the draft non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part. application of its provisions to bilateral trade in textiles taking into account the expiry of the bilateral agreement on textiles (16384/1/2010 - C7-0097 / 2011 - 2010/0323 (NLE) - 2016/2226 (INI)) progress including the enactment of laws banning the use of child labor thus almost completely eradicating it. Furthermore, the Uzbek government is working to eradicate forced labor and significant progress has been made, although subtle forms of involuntary labor still exist. The Commission should continue to report to the European Parliament, as it is anticipated that it will be necessary to continue the dialogue, cooperation and continuous pressure. EU assistance to Uzbekistan should be aimed at abandoning the country's cotton monoculture and reducing its dependence on cotton exports by diversifying its economy. The EU should use this agreement to guarantee democratic reforms.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- Welcoming Uzbekistan's efforts that still need improvement on the issue of forced labor against children, the European Union is once again interfering in the internal politics of a third country by promoting the modernization ofeconomy, gender equality and labor inspection according to standards imported from the ILO.The defense of rights and freedoms is certainly laudable, but must not be accompanied by too deep intrusion into the affairs of a country.I chose to abstain.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I have approved the present non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the partnership and cooperation agreement establishing a partnership between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other.Uzbekistan has joined the ILO and has achieved good results in the fight against child and forced labor in a short period of time, which should be taken into account.I therefore support the conclusion of a textile trade agreement with Uzbekistan.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this resolution. In recent years Uzbekistan has broadened ILO cooperation in a number of areas. In addition, this resolution allows us to highlight areas where we expect further improvement, increased monitoring and effective implementation.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The fact that Uzbekistan has started to cooperate with the International Labour Organisation ILO, reaching positive results in eradicating child labour, is showing that Uzbekistan is setting the right indicators. Nevertheless, NGOs are reporting that the Country still practice massive forced mobilisation of employees during the cotton harvest, as well as the interrogation and persecution of people who speak out about the working condition. I voted against this report since forced labour is still an issue in Uzbekistan.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: In written form. - I supported the report on the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement on bilateral trade in textiles. The main precondition for concluding the agreement was the condition set in an interim report of the European Parliament on the improvement of the human rights situation in Uzbekistan, in particular with regard to child labor and forced labor in the annual cotton harvest. According to reports from the International Labor Organization, child labor has been virtually eliminated during the cotton harvest, and government agencies have taken on permanent prevention. I believe that the EU must continue to develop its relations with Uzbekistan, while at the same time demanding and monitoring the observance and improvement of human rights, the rule of law and good and democratic governance.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the EU-Uzbekistan Textiles Protocol because such a consent will constitute a positive sign of encouragement to the Uzbek Government to further pursue its efforts to fully eradicate child labour and all other forms of forced labour, as well as to further strengthen cooperation with the EU. Nevertheless, I call on the Uzbek authorities to undertake democratic reforms, to create more space for independent civil society, to eradicate child labour and all other forms of forced labour, to meet Uzbekistan’s commitments under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention against Torture. On the other hand, I call on the EU to make full use of the extension of the Protocol to urge the Uzbek Government to respect human rights and rule of law. Last but not least, I call on both the EU and Uzbek authorities to work together on diversification of Uzbek economy, which could gradually alleviate the disastrous environmental situation with regard, in particular, to what is left of the Aral Sea and its tributaries.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The current restrictions on Uzbek cotton are justified by the practice of forced labor for the cotton harvest. During the harvest period, locals and even children are requisitioned, as well as people "hired" by force by the local authorities to harvest cotton and thus reach production quotas. The current authorities are trying to change this assessment, but not necessarily the practices. Of course, an ILO evaluation mission was authorized, as well as some local NGOs. The latter conclude that there has been an improvement, especially in the government's speech announcing measures against these practices. But in reality, we are still a long way off: the monitoring missions have been remote-controlled by the Uzbek authorities and serious doubts persist about the independence of local NGOs. In fact, other NGOs have presented us with conflicting information about forced labor. In the end, we are still a long way off and better access to the European market will strengthen an industrial and very large-scale cotton cultivation in Uzbekistan when it is already responsible for the drying up of the Aral Sea. That’s why I opposed this deal.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on the resolution concerning the EC-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and bilateral trade in textiles.This report rightly calls for respect for ILO standards by Uzbekistan, an end to forced labor and child labor, and respect for democratic rights.At the same time, the report is very intrusive: “Endorses the idea of extending the Decent Work Country Program beyond 2016 and deepening it in order to encompass the modernization of the Uzbek economy, theemployment policy, health and safety at work and labor inspection, while taking into account gender equality ”.The European Union is therefore trying to interfere strongly in Uzbekistan’s domestic politics.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing.- The European Union had previously postponed the approval of the textile agreement with Uzbekistan because of child labor and forced labor in the cotton fields.According to the latest observations from the International Labor Organization, child labor has become rare, very occasional and socially acceptable.As for forced labor, NGOs report that it unfortunately still exists.Moreover, this motion for a resolution intrudes abnormally in the internal affairs of Uzbekistan.For the sake of balance and taking all these elements into account, I chose to abstain.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted against this report, whose vote I asked to be postponed, because I believe that there are not enough guarantees that the minimum social standards (including ILO standards) necessary to address a bilateral trade agreement in textiles are applied.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I stayed.It was a vote on the accompanying resolution to the EU-Uzbekistan agreement on trade barriers to textile imports and exports.I voted in another vote in favor of trade liberalization.I abstained from this accompanying resolution because the authors of the resolution did not forgive the unnecessary call for changes to Uzbekistan's labor legislation on child labor and the remuneration of agricultural workers.The EP is supposed to leave this legislation to Uzbekistan, and free trade will best help free trade, not an EP resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written.- The textile sector, and in particular cotton production, is a major area of trade between the EU and Uzbekistan.Therefore, the EU should make full use of the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities engage in a transition process following the sudden death of the President, which should lead to better governance, strengthening the rule of law and democratic reforms.Uzbekistan should focus on abandoning the cotton monoculture and reducing its dependence on cotton exports by diversifying its economy, which could gradually alleviate the catastrophic state of the environment.I therefore supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- In 2011, the EP made its agreement to the EU-Uzbekistan protocol conditional on unrestricted monitoring in the country, focusing on forced and child labor on cotton plantations.The Government of Uzbekistan is actively cooperating with the International Labor Organization and has gradually adopted recruitment action plans and measures to eliminate forced and child labor, as evidenced by monitoring reports.However, this phenomenon was not completely eliminated.I supported the EP resolution calling on the Government of Uzbekistan to take a more active approach to fulfilling international commitments, promoting democracy and respecting human rights in that country, despite progress in this area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement on Partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part , to amend the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the date of expiry of the bilateral Agreement on Textiles, as it is incomplete and substantiated.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This accompanying resolution envisages suspending the textiles protocol if commitments on forced labour are not lived up to, calls for continued monitoring of the situation, encourages Uzbekistan to ratify and implement all 27 GSP+ conventions, as well as calling on the Commission to propose legislation for an effective traceability mechanism in the garment sector. It is an important safeguard for labour rights in Uzbekistan. I therefore supported this resolution accompanying the consent procedure to the textiles protocol.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.This report contains a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the EU-Uzbekistan textile protocol, on which I abstained.In its resolution, the European Parliament calls on Uzbekistan to continue its efforts in the fight against child labor and forced labor.In addition, he asks the European Commission to create a traceability mechanism in the clothing sector.These are the positive aspects of this resolution.However, it remains very intrusive in the internal politics of Uzbekistan and that is the reason why I abstained on this text.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: in writing. - In 2011, the Commission proposed to extend the partnership and cooperation agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan to the textile trade. The inclusion of the "textile protocol" in this partnership agreement - above all symbolic, given the volumes involved - does not represent an important economic stake for the European Union. At the time, however, the European Parliament (and rightly so) decided to make its consent conditional on a clear improvement in the human rights and labor situation in Uzbekistan. At the time, child labor in the cotton fields was widespread, as was forced labor. The Uzbek government has since partnered with the International Labor Organization (ILO), allowing it to send several observation missions to the field. Five years later, according to the ILO, the situation has improved: child labor has almost disappeared and forced labor has significantly declined. This is why my colleague Marie Arena, supported by my political group, proposed to finally give the green light to the conclusion of the "textile protocol", while reserving the right to request its suspension if the fundamental rights situation were to arise. degrade. I voted for.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I support the adoption of the Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, extending the provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to Bilateral Trade textiles. The Uzbek authorities have also made numerous commitments to the progressive elimination of forced labor in adults, including the establishment of a feedback mechanism to address public grievances, the organization of awareness-raising campaigns and the implementation of implementation evaluation programs. on the subject. The European Parliament fully supports the work of the ILO with a view to the elimination of forced labor in Uzbekistan.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- In December 2011 the European Parliament decided to postpone approval of a protocol on trade in textiles with Uzbekistan until an interim report has been drawn up.In particular, the allegation of child and forced labor should be investigated.According to the most recent observation by the ILO (2015), child labor is rarely found in the cotton harvest, and forced labor is no longer a problem.After the government of Uzbekistan made significant progress in a short period of time in improving working conditions in the textile sector, I voted for this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that acknowledges the steps made by the Uzbek Government to combat child labour and also their failure to abolish it.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution accompanies the approval vote on the textile agreement with Uzbekistan. The socialist rapporteur did not want to hear anything. We asked at least to wait for the new report from the International Labor Organization for the year 2016 reporting the evolutions of forced labor in the cotton fields. It was a matter of a few weeks. Well no, she preferred to respond to the sirens of the Commission, which sees in the death of the former Uzbek leader a means of strengthening its hold over Central Asia. I denounce the argument that assumes that these free trade agreements have "human rights clauses" that will allow them to be suspended if serious human rights violations are committed. If from the outset possible conditions of slavery are not considered "serious", how, once the agreement is passed, can we get its suspension? Especially since these clauses have never been invoked in practice, even under the Ben Ali regime in Tunisia. We thus end up promoting inexpensive cotton in competition with production that respects human rights. I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- This non-legislative report, in conjunction with the previous one, contains recommendations for compliance with ILO standards by Uzbekistan but is very intrusive in the affairs of this sovereign state.I therefore abstained, considering that the European Union is not intended to interfere in the internal affairs of Uzbekistan.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: written. - In this report, the EP advocates organizing textile trade between the EU and Uzbekistan by adding a protocol to the existing cooperation agreement that both partners have concluded since 1999. This change of agreement is necessary because the textile trade, and in particular cotton production, is the most important sector in the trade relations between the EU and Uzbekistan. This extension recognizes the progress that has been made to curb child labor during the cotton harvest. The report urges the next Uzbek president to continue in the same direction and to put an immediate end to any form of forced employment during the cotton harvest. Parliament rightly calls for Uzbekistan to initiate a transition in order to achieve better working conditions, better governance and democratic reforms. Regarding the need for full transparency in the textile sector, I support the call to the Commission to take action to help improve working conditions, health and safety in the ready-to-wear sector of third countries.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution, which calls on the EAS to continue to monitor developments ensuring that respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law are upheld and that more space for independent civil society is ensured.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Committee on International Trade has attached a motion for a resolution to its proposal as indicated in point 2. The 1999 Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between Uzbekistan and the EU does not cover bilateral textile trade. In its report adopted in December 2011, the European Parliament linked the contribution to the extension to the improvement of the situation in Uzbekistan with regard to child labor and forced labor in the context of the annual cotton harvest. In its 2015 report on the control of the cotton harvest in Uzbekistan, the ILO found that child labor had been virtually eliminated during the cotton harvest, but could not make a similar statement about forced labor. In its draft resolution, the Committee on International Trade welcomes the progress made and acknowledges the measures taken by the Uzbek Government to abolish forced labor, expressing the view that Parliament should give its consent to the bilateral textile trade agreement in recognition of the Uzbek government's efforts in this area. to extend. At the same time, it makes suggestions and expectations to the Uzbek authorities to further normalize the situation and calls on EU bodies to monitor the process and to assist structural reforms in Uzbekistan. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report calls for respect for ILO standards by Uzbekistan, an end to forced labor and child labor, and respect for democratic rights.He also recommends voting for the text on the textile protocol.At the same time, the report is very intrusive and gives the impression that the European Union is interfering strongly in the domestic politics of Uzbekistan.Abstention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
