text: in writing.- This report calls for respect for ILO standards by Uzbekistan, an end to forced child labor, respect for democratic rights and NGOs.He also recommends voting for the text on the textile protocol.At the same time, this report is very intrusive in the internal politics of Uzbekistan.I therefore abstain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as with the recent passing away of Uzbekistan’s authoritarian leader, Islam Karimov, the current period is seen as a valuable opportunity to develop deeper relations between the EU and Uzbekistan and is part of its broader strategy in Central Asia.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which accompanies the approval of the textile trade agreement with Uzbekistan.The text points out that Uzbekistan has started to cooperate with the International Labor Organization (ILO) and virtually eradicated child labor in the past three years.It calls on the Uzbek authorities to step up the deployment of national awareness campaigns that will make it possible to eradicate this practice completely.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will extend provisions of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Uzbekistan regarding the inclusion of bilateral trade in textiles.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing.- In line with the approved report, I welcome the significant progress that has been made in Uzbekistan since 2013, including the adoption of legislation banning child labor and the achievement of almost complete eradication of child labor.Significant progress has also been made in eliminating forced labor, where Uzbekistan is actively cooperating with the ILO.At the same time, I believe that the EU should use the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to put pressure on the Uzbek authorities to ensure that a process of political transformation begins after the sudden death of the President, leading to the rule of law, democratic reforms and a substantial improvement in the situation.human rights.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I also spoke in favor of this report, because Uzbekistan has achieved good results in the fight against child and forced labor in a short period of time.I believe this should also be supported.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.Given that Uzbekistan has taken positive steps to eliminate the use of child labor in Uzbek cotton farms, the conclusion of the agreement could further motivate them for further reforms in this area.At the same time, according to several observers, child labor has been replaced by forced labor.This is not acceptable and the EU must monitor the situation very closely and, if necessary, take steps to put an end to such practices.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: written. - The approval of the Protocol amending the Cooperation and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan aims to extend the provisions of the Agreement to trade in textile products, which entails the inclusion of the textile sector within the scope of the 1999 Collaboration and Cooperation (ACC). In 2011, the European Parliament ruled to link the conclusion of an agreement to an improvement of the human rights situation and working conditions in Uzbekistan. Since then, the International Labor Organization has meticulously monitored conditions in the country. It concludes that child labor has been eradicated although doubts persist about forced labor in the textile sector. I have voted in favor of the conclusion of this report in case it favors the improvement of working conditions. In the event that the country suspends compliance with its commitment to abolish forced labor, we will undoubtedly have to activate suspension measures.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of my colleague's non-legislative motion for a resolution as I note the collaboration between Uzbekistan and the International Labor Organization (ILO), launched in 2013 on monitoring the cotton harvesting sector in order to prevent the exploitation of child labor and to prevent the continuation of forced labor; this cooperation was supported in 2014 by the agreement reached by the ILO and the Uzbek government on a national decent work program and the gradual adoption by Uzbekistan of work plans to change the recruitment rules for cotton harvesting. The policies implemented to date make it possible to affirm that the aim of the eradication of child labor has been achieved and that considerable progress has been made in the prohibition of forced labor. I welcome the idea that the EU should maintain a high level of human rights monitoring in the country; I share the rapporteur's opinion on the need for Uzbekistan to free itself from the monoculture of cotton and to reduce its dependence on imports with a diversification of domestic production thanks also to the support of the European Union Therefore, I voted in favor

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this decision because it acknowledges the efforts by the Uzbek government in pursuing the eradication of forced and child labour and recommends giving consent as a positive sign of encouragement for further actions and strengthening of the cooperation with the EU. However, if the Uzbek authorities fail to follow through on their commitment to abolish forced labour, Parliament reserves the right to ask the Commission and the Council to activate Articles 2 and 95 of the PCA. The resolution also takes account of the recent political developments and notes that the sudden death of President Islam Karimov should not have any impact on the continuity of the ongoing process of improving labour conditions in the cotton fields in Uzbekistan.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I emphasize that the textile sector, especially cotton production, is the main area of ​​trade between the EU and Uzbekistan. In this regard, I emphasize that the EU should make full use of the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities engage in a transition process following the sudden death of the President, which should lead to better governance, strengthening the rule of law, democratic reforms and significant improvement. human rights. I welcome the progress made since 2013 on the issue of child labor in Uzbekistan, including the adoption of laws banning the use of child labor, and urge the authorities to further engage in awareness-raising campaigns across the country to eradicate child labor. I emphasize the role of EU diplomatic efforts in this process, and in particular Parliament's 2011 resolution which suspended the adoption of the agreement and which led to the active involvement of the International Labor Organization (ILO) and the World Bank. I urge the Uzbek authorities to step up efforts to further modernize and diversify the country's agricultural sector, with continued support from the EU, the World Bank and other international donors.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - In 2011, the European Parliament decided to postpone the decision on the consent to the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol, and an interim report on the alleged use of child and forced labor in the cotton harvest was adopted, clarifying that Parliament would consider giving consent only if the Uzbek authorities allow International Labor Organization observers to establish unhindered monitoring to confirm the implementation of concrete reforms in order to make real progress in eradicating these forms of work at all levels. The Uzbek government has adopted action plans to change the way cotton workers are employed, and has promoted awareness-raising and developed a monitoring mechanism to prevent forced and child labor. The latest ILO report showed that the use of child labor to harvest cotton has become almost eradicated and socially unacceptable. The textile sector is a major area of ​​trade between the EU and Uzbekistan, and the EU should use the extension of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to ensure that the Uzbek authorities engage in a transition process leading to better governance, strengthening the rule of law, democratic reforms and substantial improving the human rights situation. Therefore, on this occasion, I also call on the Uzbek authorities to release from prison individuals imprisoned on the basis of politically motivated charges and to end the cycle of repression, arrest and sentencing.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report accompanies the recommendation that endorses the conclusion of a “Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other” . The report supports the conclusion of the Agreement, which does not differ substantially from the free trade matrix that characterizes such agreements. The report acknowledges the existence of cases of forced labor in Uzbekistan. For the majority of this parliament, it matters little. The constraints that result from the reduced diversification of Uzbekistan's economy, from the high dependence, for example, on “cotton monoculture” are recognized. It matters little. Free trade will accentuate this trend, with the intensification of the export nature of production and a disregard for the domestic market. Putting further pressure on European countries that still have a textile industry, such as Portugal. Nothing new: large importers from central Europe benefit, producers from the periphery are harmed. The report beckons with propaganda measures that, he hopes, serve to obscure its real effects. In addition, it unravels a usual rosary of interference and considerations about the way the State is organized in this country. We voted against.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. - Taking into account the significant progress made in Uzbekistan since 2013, including the adoption of a law banning the use of child labor which has led to the almost complete elimination of child labor, it is recommended to authorize the conclusion of the EU-Uzbekistan Protocol on textiles. The consent will be a positive sign of encouragement for the government of Uzbekistan to continue its efforts to completely eliminate child labor and all other forms of forced labor, and to further strengthen cooperation with the EU. A combination of dialogue and cooperation as well as continued pressure on the Uzbek government from the EU, ILO and World Bank will still be needed to achieve this goal, and reserves the right to call on the Commission and the Council to initiate the Art. 2 and 95 of the PCA, to take all necessary general and specific measures in the event of failure to comply with the commitment to eliminate child labor and forced labor. I hereby support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I support the extension of the partnership and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Uzbekistan to include bilateral trade in textiles and therefore vote in favor of this resolution.According to the International Labor Organization, child labor has now virtually disappeared in Uzbekistan, so I encourage the conclusion of this agreement and the total eradication of all forms of forced labor during cotton harvesting work.I remind you that if the country does not continue its efforts in this matter, we will request the suspension of the agreement.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ After a vigorous debate, some UKIP MEPs voted in favour whilst some abstained. We note Uzbekistan’s significant improvement in the areas of concern, as evidenced by its ratification of multiple ILO conventions. We feel left wing NGOs were calling for a rejection as a spiteful ideological response, rather than due to any meaningful attempt to help. Some MEPs, whilst accepting Uzbekistan’s improvement, abstained due to the principle that the EU should not conduct any law, anywhere, ever.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - Textile products are now included in the partnership and cooperation agreement concluded between Uzbekistan and the Union in 1999. In December 2011, a provisional report had already been approved, making the approval of the agreement conditional on the improvement of the rights situation. particularly in relation to child labor and forced labor in the context of the cotton harvest. Following the approval of this report, a dialogue was established with Uzbekistan, in the framework of which annual hearings were held, with the participation of various stakeholders, namely civil society, Uzbek authorities and European and international institutions. Close cooperation was also established between Uzbekistan and the International Labor Organization. Parliament believes that, in the current context of dialogue and cooperation, efforts by the Uzbek authorities should be encouraged. However, if the Uzbek authorities suspend the application of measures to abolish forced labor, Parliament reserves the possibility to ask the European Commission and the Council to activate Articles 2 and 95 of the partnership agreement. and cooperation, which allow the adoption of general or specific measures for non-respect for human rights.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - In December 2011, the Parliament had already adopted an interim report on the issue which made the consent of the hemicycle conditional on an improvement in the human rights situation in Uzbekistan. Since then, the International Labor Organization has conducted three observation missions which have found, among other things, the virtual eradication of child labor. It was on this basis that, among other things, Parliament agreed to include textiles in the 1999 EU-Uzbekistan Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. A decision at the time aimed at encouraging the government of the country to continue to eradicate all forms of forced labor and to strengthen its cooperation with the European Union. In the text of the non-legislative resolution voted on this afternoon, Parliament welcomed the fact that Uzbekistan had started to cooperate with the International Labor Organization, but nevertheless urged the Uzbek authorities to accelerate the deployment of national campaigns of awareness that will eradicate this practice completely. Parliament will therefore continue to monitor the matter and could always, as a last resort, ask the European Commission and the Council to suspend the agreement if the authorities do not keep their commitments in terms of the abolition of forced labor.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Textiles are an important part of Uzbekistan's foreign trade.Foreign trade is, as we know, an important instrument of the EU's external relations.By opening up its market, the EU can encourage partner countries to make progress on human rights and political freedoms.Unfortunately, in the case of Uzbekistan, there is nothing to promote yet.Even after the death of a long-time dictator, the situation in the country is not improving.I myself sincerely wish the people of Uzbekistan to start building a state for themselves, not for a handful of the elect, and I am ready to campaign for all possible help.However, as we can see from the current trends, the time has not yet come for this - it is too early to talk about progress in Uzbekistan.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - As with the proposed amendment to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Uzbekistan, I also voted in favor of this proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the same subject, since it formulates a set of proposals parallel to the approval of the Agreement, underlining, by a On the one hand, the importance for the European Union of respect for human rights and compliance with the rule of law, working conditions in accordance with the standards of the International Labor Organization (ILO) and respect for the environment and, on the other hand, lists the reforms that the government of this country has carried out to improve labor standards and respect for human rights, which constitute a “conditio sine qua non” for the establishment of trade agreements with the European Union. I highlight, among others, the progress made at the legislative level, with the adoption of laws that prohibit the use of child labor, adherence to the International Trade Union Confederation and the establishment of structural reforms, aimed at improving the working conditions of cotton pickers and to introduce greater mechanization and budget transparency in terms of revenue from the cotton harvest. In view of the above, I voted in favor of this Report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution which accompanies the consent of the European Parliament to establish the textile protocol between the EU and Uzbekistan. Since 2011 and the refusal by the European Parliament of this protocol, Uzbekistan has provided important work and carried out actions to eradicate child labor as well as forced labor. In view of the efforts made and given the publication of the latest ILO monitoring report, Parliament gave its approval to the protocol. Nonetheless, the text calls for continued action to eradicate forced and child labor and stresses that if the situation deteriorates, Parliament reserves the right to request the suspension of the protocol at any time. At the same time, concerning the textile sector, the resolution asks the European Commission to present the “EU garment initiative” as soon as possible and encourages it to continue its initiatives and actions in favor of improving working conditions and health. and safety in the garment sector.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this Resolution that accompanies the Agreement with Uzbekistan since it legitimizes an Agreement that rejects and washes its hands regarding human rights by focusing on the existence of a clause that allows its freezing in the event of violation of these.In other words, an agreement with a country with flagrant violations of human rights, such as forced labor or child exploitation, is justified, justifying that it will be frozen if human rights are violated.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I have voted to support this resolution. Uzbekistan has slowly but surely cooperated with not only the EU, but the ILO – allowing an unhindered inspection of the cotton harvest to take place for the last three years. They have also broadened ILO cooperation in a number of other areas. The ILO has reported significant progress, and although concerns remain about the use of adult labour, most monitoring reports state that Uzbekistan has been cooperative in trying to do away with this.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing.- The purpose of this resolution is to approve the inclusion of bilateral trade in textiles in the existing Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and its Member States and the Republic of Uzbekistan.The Republic of Uzbekistan has made great progress in eliminating child labor during the annual harvest of cotton, which has been almost completely eliminated.I voted in favor.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I have chosen to abstain from this Report, and this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of Members of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia.representative action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Although there are still cases of human rights violations in Uzbekistan, I supported the legislative resolution approving the Protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the EU and the Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, on the other. , in order to extend the provisions of this Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. I am pleased that dialogue and cooperation between the EU and Uzbekistan have improved in recent years, and the ILO monitoring report from the last mission was able to state that, thanks to the measures taken, Uzbekistan has almost completely eliminated child labor during the annual cotton harvest. This fact is all the more gratifying as child labor has become socially unacceptable. Despite the fact that Uzbekistan has not yet been able to deal with the issue of forced labor, I appreciate the efforts of the ILO, which is interested in permanently eliminating forced labor in Uzbekistan. Although solving the problem of forced labor is not an easy task at all, I also appreciate the Uzbek authorities, which have made a number of commitments to phase out adult labor.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union's trade agreements with the countries of Central Asia are not only an instrument for economic and political stabilization and the gradual democratization of the region, but are also a way of extending European standards, especially in the field of copyright protection.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - In 2011, the European Parliament postponed a decision on the consent to the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Protocol and adopted an interim report addressing the alleged use of child and forced labor in the cotton harvest. In that report, he concluded that he would consider giving consent only if the Uzbek authorities allow International Labor Organization observers to conduct detailed monitoring and if observers confirm that significant results have been achieved. In 2013, the Uzbek government allowed the ILO to oversee the cotton harvest. A recent ILO report found that the use of child labor to harvest cotton has become rare and socially unacceptable although continued monitoring is still needed. The eradication of forced and child labor is an endeavor that requires additional support from the EU and the international community. I support this Report because I believe that, due to the efforts of the Uzbek government, Parliament should give its consent to the Textile Protocol between the EU and Uzbekistan. This will encourage the Uzbek government to continue its efforts to completely eradicate child labor and all other forms of forced labor, as human rights violations continue to be reported in the country.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the non-legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the EU and the Republic of Uzbekistan, amending the Agreement to extend bilateral trade to textiles,textile agreement.We must give all support to the International Labor Organization in its work on monitoring cotton harvesting and its cooperation with the Government of Uzbekistan through the national decent work program.Thanks to the efforts of Uzbekistan, which is working to end forced labor, I support the EU-Uzbekistan Textile Trade Protocol.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the reform of the textile agreement, as it is primarily intended to show support for the progress made by Uzbekistan.In practice, the agreement has very little economic impact, but as a political signal, it is an important encouragement to Uzbekistan to continue working to improve human and labor rights.Further work is needed to improve labor rights and regular monitoring in this area needs to be continued.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- I followed the opinion of my rapporteur colleague Maria Arena on the report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing apartnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the said Agreement in order to extend its provisions to bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the expiry of thebilateral agreement on textiles.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In an effort to strengthen its ties with Uzbekistan, the EU is seeking to add bilateral trade in textiles to the existing EU-Uzbekistan PCA (1999). The trade agreement, more specifically, seeks to forge a closer collaboration between the central Asian country, the EU and the International Labour Organisation to tackle forced and child labour in Uzbekistan, a problem that is prevalent in the country’s cotton industry. I voted in favour of including textiles in our partnership agreement, as the agreement will encourage the Uzbek Government to continue to implement reforms that will allow the country to respect their international commitments regarding human and labour rights, and eventually eradicate forced and child labour.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I supported the resolution extending the agreement on bilateral trade in textiles of the EU member states and the Republic of Uzbekistan, given that the Uzbek government has made significant progress in combating child labor by introducing a law banning child labor.I believe that the adoption of this law is a positive step in achieving the goal of complete eradication of child labor, and this agreement is a sign of dialogue and cooperation between the European Union and Uzbekistan.However, there is also the problem of forced labor for adults in Uzbekistan, and this resolution makes it possible to take general or special measures in case of failure to respect human rights.Nevertheless, I believe that Uzbekistan will fulfill its obligation to abolish forced labor for adults and organize awareness-raising campaigns and introduce an assessment of the implementation of international agreements in this area.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Motion for a non-legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part trade in textiles, given the expiry of the bilateral textile agreement. The European Parliament has been asked to approve a protocol amending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Uzbekistan, of the other part, to extend the provisions of this Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles. The country would receive benefits such as trade without quantitative restrictions, the principle of free transit, trade at market prices, and so on. Uzbekistan has so far completely eliminated child labor in picking cotton but there is still too much forced labor with exploitative working conditions.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Economic partnership between the EU and Uzbekistan should be promoted.Cooperation may bring tangible benefits not only to Uzbekistan but also to EU Member States.The cultural exchange, which is very widespread in our countries, should also be extended to economic exchange.I voted in favor of the agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- In December 2011, the European Parliament decided to postpone its decision on the agreement between the EU and Uzbekistan on a textile protocol and to adopt an interim report to investigate allegations of child labor and forced labor in Uzbekistan's cotton plantations.In this interim report, Parliament stated that it would only give its consent if the Uzbek authorities allowed ILO observers to carry out a thorough and unhindered inspection, confirming that reforms had taken place with concrete and significant results, leading to:the effective abolition of forced labor and the practice of child labor at national, provincial and local levels is under way.I supported the resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against the accompanying resolution because, although I agree with most of its points, the rapporteur takes, based on that diagnosis that I compare, the opposite conclusion: that the European Parliament should grant consent to the signing of the protocol that would extend the provisions of the EU-Uzbekistan cooperation and partnership agreement to the textile sector. Indeed, the report expresses concern that forced labor remains a common practice in the textile sector in Uzbekistan today. I share with the rapporteur the opinion on the progress that has been made in the country; and I subscribe to the request made in the resolution for the Commission to present as soon as possible the Union's flagship initiative on responsible supply chain management in the textile sector. However, I do not share with this resolution its main purpose: to support a consent procedure with which I do not agree.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against because this consent procedure should have been initiated after December, when the ILO report on the 2016 cotton harvest will be available. One of the conditions included in the interim report that the European Parliament adopted in 2011 included the need to eradicate child labour and other forms of forced labour. Even though there has been considerable progress in the eradication of child labour, the same result is likely to not have been achieved regarding forced labour, this is why the independent ILO assessment is a key tool to evaluate the possibility of giving our consent to this Protocol.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part, amending the Agreement in order to extend the provisions of the Agreement to bilateral trade in textiles, taking account of the expiry of the bilateral textiles Agreement. In December 2011 the European Parliament decided to postpone its decision on consent to the EU-Uzbekistan Textiles Protocol. The report stresses the importance of the action taken by the Government of Uzbekistan to authorise the ILO to monitor the cotton harvest and to engage in broad cooperation with ILO through a Decent Work Country Programme. Moreover, it welcomes the substantial progress that has been made in Uzbekistan since 2013, including the adoption of laws which prohibit the use of child labour. I voted in favour because I believe that only concrete evidence of substantial and measurable progress of Uzbekistan allows Parliament to give its consent.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written. - This proposal aims to include the textile sector of Uzbekistan within the scope of the 1999 Cooperation and Partnership Agreement, since according to its article 16, the textile sector was excluded from the obligations of most-favored-nation treatment and the prohibition of quantitative restrictions, yes applicable to other sectors. This proposal can fill the gap that supposes that Uzbekistan is not a member of the World Trade Organization, since as long as it does not join that body, it will not be bound by the most-favored-nation clause and the multilateral rules that are established. all its members apply. This report comes after several years of efforts by the authorities to eradicate - based on the guidelines provided by the Union - child labor, backed by a 2015 investigation that reveals the virtual elimination of this practice and applauds the measures taken To achieve this (after-school care, fines for those who promote it and higher levels of responsibility for parents, teachers and farmers…), having managed to make using child labor considered a socially unacceptable practice. For all these reasons, I have considered it appropriate to vote in favor of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have rejected this Resolution that accompanies the Agreement with Uzbekistan since it legitimizes an Agreement that rejects and washes its hands regarding human rights by focusing on the existence of a clause that allows its freezing in the event of violation of these.In other words, an agreement with a country with flagrant violations of human rights, such as forced labor or child exploitation, is justified, justifying that it will be frozen if human rights are violated.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor because the European Parliament welcomes the significant progress that Uzbekistan has made since 2013, including the adoption of laws banning the use of child labor, which have ensured that the country has virtually eliminated child labor.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The report accompanying the recommendation, which proposes the conclusion of the Agreement, contains, under the pretext of the alleged aid, unacceptable and unequivocal considerations of the instruments that the European Union uses to ingest over Sovereign States, seeking to condition its social and economic policies, withthe superb vanity of those who think they can teach lessons.We voted against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- In December 2011 the European Parliament decided to postpone approval of a protocol on trade in textiles with Uzbekistan until an interim report has been drawn up.In particular, the allegation of child and forced labor should be investigated.According to the most recent observation by the ILO (2015), child labor is rarely found in the cotton harvest, and forced labor is no longer a problem.After the government of Uzbekistan made significant progress in a short period of time in improving working conditions in the textile sector, I voted for this report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With the recent passing away of Uzbekistan’s authoritarian leader Islam Karimov, the current period is seen as a valuable opportunity to develop deeper relations between the EU and Uzbekistan and is part of its broader strategy in Central Asia. Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report as we believe that, in the context of the ongoing dialogue and cooperation, it is appropriate for Parliament to give its consent to the textile protocol with Uzbekistan. However, if the Uzbek authorities fail to follow through on their commitment to abolish forced labour, Parliament reserves the right to ask the Commission and the Council to activate Articles 2 and 95 of the PCA, allowing general or specific measures to be taken in the event of a failure to respect human rights.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the non-legislative resolution on the conclusion of a protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Community and the Republic of Uzbekistan.This protocol concerned the extension of the original Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to trade in textiles.Originally, at the time of the conclusion of this agreement between the European Community and Uzbekistan, the textile sector was excluded from trade.The reason was the use of child and forced labor to collect cotton in Uzbekistan.However, much has changed since then, Uzbekistan has taken steps to eliminate child labor and, overall, significant progress has been made.That is why I think that this effort to improve conditions needs to be supported, and I believe that extending the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to this particular sector will motivate Uzbekistan to pursue further positive reforms.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I supported the report containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part. its provisions on bilateral trade in textiles, taking into account the expiration of the bilateral agreement on textiles. The purpose of this proposal is to approve, on behalf of the European Union, the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other part. The interim resolution of the parliament states that the Union is one of the main importers of cotton from Uzbekistan, and it is estimated that imports into the Union range from 6% to 23% of Uzbek cotton in the last 10 years. Therefore, I believe that it is important to extend the provisions to bilateral trade in textiles. I also strongly condemn forced labor and child labor and support the European Parliament's reforms to eradicate these two problems.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report with a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement establishing a partnership between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Uzbekistan, of the other partAgreement on bilateral trade in textiles, subject to the expiry of the bilateral agreement on textiles.I support the deepening of the partnership and cooperation with Uzbekistan, as the Uzbek authorities are actively cooperating with the World Labor Organization in eliminating forced labor and child labor, and working to promote human rights and the rule of law in structural reforms.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I have asked for the floor to explain the vote in favor of the Agreement with Ecuador because I think it is very important that the European Parliament has approved this Agreement for Ecuador to join the Agreement with Colombia and Peru.We do a great favor to Ecuador and its people with this Agreement.I do not understand that there is any reason to oppose free trade with a country that can export a lot to Europe, and we can greatly benefit the people of Ecuador.Ecuador is doing a very modern transformation of its country, and these exports of its products are key for them.We have worked very intensively with them, we have ensured that banana exports do not harm other countries, specifically Spain and the Canary Islands, and we have ensured that the relationship between Europe and Latin America through this new Agreement is intensified and improved, something that I think is very important for Europe too.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - Madam President, as Vice-Chair of the Committee on International Trade, I was very pleased to support Ecuador's accession to our existing relationship with Colombia and Peru.The world is not in a good situation for free trade at the moment.We see the various obstacles that arise in concluding a transatlantic agreement, we see that the United States is likely to withdraw from some of the agreements that have already been concluded in the future, which is why it is important for the European Union to promote free trade, because our economies can only benefit.We have some free trade agreements in Asia, of course Latin America is also important.That is why it is very good that we have succeeded in voting for Ecuador's accession to this free trade agreement.I only welcome it and, of course, I supported it.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru is an important step in bilateral relations with Ecuador.Trade will be opened by both sides and this is a benefit for the European agricultural sector.The timing of the signing of this agreement is crucial, as Ecuador is facing a difficult economic situation.The price of oil fell by more than 60%, oil exports fell by 50%, and the April earthquake cost the government $ 3 billion.Moreover, at the end of the year, Ecuador loses its GSP status.It is essential that Parliament supports this agreement, so that Ecuador's economy is not severely affected.Ecuador is a very important regional partner for the Union and that is why we stick to this agreement and we voted for it.I also call for regular monitoring of existing agreements.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The agreement referred to in the report was signed in 2012 by Colombia and Peru.The agreement includes an article that allows other member countries of the Andean community to enter.In fact, in 2014 the negotiations for the accession of Ecuador were concluded.As I find it important to include Ecuador in the agreement as it is experiencing a very difficult economic situation, I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - I have supported the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement of the European Union with Colombia and Peru, with which the Union will give continuity to the tariff preferences that it has granted up to now and that, by rising to a middle-income country, would have lost in January weighing down the exports of which many people live in this country. We Socialists celebrate that this Agreement includes ambitious, unprecedented commitments between the Union and Ecuador, on sustainable development, human, labor and environmental rights, which should serve to promote fairer bilateral trade. In this sense, Ecuador has already been undertaking some good reforms, which under the Agreement must continue. We have also worked very intensively with Ecuador, to ensure that its export capacity in the banana sector does not harm European regions that, like the Canary Islands, are highly dependent on this crop. An Agreement that, without a doubt, will help to intensify and improve the relationship between Europe and Latin America, as we Spanish socialists defend. We will closely monitor compliance with the commitments and support Ecuador in its reforms, with all the Instruments available to the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have voted against the Adhesion of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia / Peru Multiparty Trade Agreement, understanding that there are no substantial changes in an Agreement that continues to be based on the logic of free trade, deregulation, privatization or the exploitation of resources natural. I opposed the EU-Colombia / Peru Agreement and I continue to reject it. Our model of relations are not Free Trade Agreements that do not take into account economic asymmetries and that only seek to open new markets and benefits to multinational companies, but agreements that are based on complementarity, cooperation, sustainable and sustainable development and whose main objective is to end inequalities. We reject the blackmail to which the Union subjects third countries through its current tariff policies and the conditioning of development cooperation funds, linked to the signing of Trade Agreements like this one. We support the Government of Ecuador in the policies it has carried out for the development of the "good living" model based on greater control by the State of strategic sectors of the economy, but we consider that social achievements would not have been possible under the logic that establishes this Agreement.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- Ecuador, together with Bolivia, has long worked for a new type of trade agreement that promotes sustainable development, redistribution and indigenous peoples' rights.This agreement means a return to an unfair and unsustainable trade where Ecuador becomes stuck in a dependence on raw material exports.The popular movements in Ecuador are critical.Therefore, we can not vote in favor of the agreement.At the same time, we want to respect an elected government in the South and do not choose to vote no either.We are voting blank this time.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the EU-Colombia and Peru trade agreement (accession of Ecuador). 2012 December 11 The European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution approving the conclusion of such an agreement. Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility of accession to the Agreement by other Member States of the Andean Community. 2015 November 20 The European Parliament adopted a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement, which welcomed the conclusion of the negotiations with Ecuador and called for a swift full entry into force and implementation of the agreement, believing that it would help Ecuador to continue in a new direction. y. to promote the country's economically and socially sustainable development policy in a complex regional and international context. I am of the view that Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, its gradual and flexible implementation, subject to periodic evaluations and consultations with the Ecuadorian government and civil society in both countries, should be a step towards an EU alliance of important economic growth. countries in this region of the world.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and of Colombia and Peru, of the other part, tothe accession of Ecuador should be taken into account, because I believe that the approval process needs to be accelerated so that Ecuador can benefit from the free trade agreement as soon as possible.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report calls for the approval of Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru dating from 2012. However, Ecuador having become a middle-income country, it cannot no longer be part of the GSP + agreement (status of countries with a “special incentive regime”). High tariffs are abolished, service markets liberalized, public procurement open, with environmental and social standards imposed ... Ecuadorian fishing will no longer have tariffs. Ecuador, according to the European Union, "will benefit from significant new access to the European Union's banana markets". In 17 years, 90% of customs duties in the agricultural sector will be eliminated. This will be very unfavorable to producers in overseas regions for whom bananas are an important source of income. For all these reasons, I opposed this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was simply a technical update on the progress of the agreement, and it is standard practice for UKIP MEPs to abstain on such motions.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I chose to vote for this text because Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru and the gradual and flexible implementation of the latter, with a foreshadowing approach by the Commission,taking into account the periodic assessments after consultation with the Ecuadorian government and civil society on both sides, should constitute an important step forward in the alliance with important countries, growing and of the same sensitivity, in a region increasingly oriented towardsAsia and the Pacific.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Ecuador.Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Colombia and Peru is an important step forward in the development of relations between the EU and Ecuador, which has become an important partner in the region with similar interests.However, I agree that the Commission must ensure the full implementation of the provisions on sustainable development and closely monitor the political and fundamental rights situation in the country.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report asks to accept Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru, dating from 2012. High tariffs would be removed, markets for services liberalized, marketsopen audiences.Ecuador, according to the EU, "will benefit from significant new access to EU banana markets".90% of customs duties in the agricultural sector would be eliminated in 17 years.This would be very unfavorable to producers in our overseas regions for whom this fruit represents an important source of income.I therefore opposed this membership.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I approved this report relating to the conclusion of the protocol of accession to the trade agreement between the Union, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other hand, in order to take account of theaccession by Ecuador.The report stresses that Ecuador's accession will give it the opportunity to pursue its policy of sustainable economic and social development in a difficult regional and international context.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report, which is consistent with my position regarding Ecuador's accession to the EU Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru.I believe that in the current global context, the Union must strengthen its relations with Latin America, being a preferential and reliable partner that contributes to the economic and social progress of the region.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the Scholz report approving the protocol to the trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru, to take account of the accession of Ecuador. The original agreement, signed in 2012, provides for the possibility for other member countries of the Andean Community to join in order to fully exploit the economic advantages deriving from it. This is an opportunity of primary importance, especially for a country like Ecuador which is facing a complex situation, with a 60% drop in oil prices, a revaluation of the dollar and the simultaneous devaluation of the currencies of other countries of the 'area, such as Colombia. The general collapse of exports, which saw a decrease of 6.1%, caused a substantial drop in revenues, which risks compromising the financial stability of the state itself. The accession to the trade agreement will allow the Latin American country to strengthen its economy, favoring the adoption of more progressive social and environmental policies, and at the same time will allow the EU to recover positions in a region that is seeing the influence of states increase. Asiatics and the Pacific.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- It is undeniable that the drop in the price of oil and the rise in the dollar makes the economic and political situation in Ecuador difficult.In this context, the loss of tariff preferences threatens Ecuador's economy in the short term and also the electoral victory of the emancipatory project in February.However, although I understand the short-term interest of the Ecuadorian Government in obtaining the oxygen balloon that supposes the non-increase in tariffs on its exports, the Agreement contains harmful elements in the long term as it could lay the foundations for an unequal commercial relationship.Furthermore, with this agreement, the Union is promoting, once again, a system in which the foundations are laid for a trade for the benefit of the usual, which I will not defend under any circumstances.That is why I have voted against it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I opposed this report on Ecuador's accession to the free trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. It is true that, since Ecuador has become a so-called "middle-income" country, it can no longer benefit from the generalized preference system of the European Union, which grants facilities for developing countries. I take this opportunity to affirm that the very existence of this system discredits ultra-liberal ideology since it recognizes the need, in favor of economic development, for customs duties, protected PGIs, social and environmental standards, in short, intelligent protectionism. I therefore consider that integrating Ecuador into this trade agreement will not only be negative for this country, but also for our producers, since it will lead to Ecuador benefiting from "considerable new access to the European Union markets. for the banana ”. However, this would be a disaster for our producers in overseas regions for whom bananas are an important source of income.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- I do not agree with the proposed enlargement to Ecuador of the existing agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru, because this could damage our production system, already severely tested by the economic crisis and the crazy policies of the European Union,which should instead do much more for the protection of our businesses.For these reasons, I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation on the trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru (accession of Ecuador). This agreement was signed in 2012. June 26 In Brussels. Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, its gradual and flexible implementation, with an initial phase by the Commission in the light of periodic evaluations and in consultation with the Ecuadorian government and civil society on both sides, should be a step towards an alliance with important, growing countries in a region seeking ever closer ties with Asia and the Pacific. Ecuador responded to the European Parliament's request and in 2016 June 21 It presented a document to the European Parliament entitled "Overview of Ecuador's policies, achievements and actions for good living conditions". In this context, Parliament welcomes the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru. However, it wishes to point out that the monitoring, evaluation and follow-up of existing agreements must be a key priority of the common commercial policy and that the Commission must keep Parliament informed of its implementation, monitoring and follow-up, in particular with a view to sustainable development. development obligations as defined in the 2015 November 20 European Parliament resolution.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Report on the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement (accession of Ecuador).

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- This agreement will be very unfavorable to producers in overseas regions for whom bananas are an important source of income.I therefore voted against.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report. There are certain progressive aspects to the proposed accession of Ecuador, led by the progressive government of Rafael Correa, but we have previously opposed the EU-Colombia/Peru FTA based on both the liberalisation agenda and human rights abuses in Colombia. In 2014 due to Correa’s anti-poverty measures, Ecuador moved to being a middle-income country, meaning it was excluded from the Generalised System of Preferences, under which it had been able to export to the EU without tariffs but maintain tariffs on imports. However, this FTA contains the usual adverse impacts on ordinary people – lack of respect for democracy, social rights, transparency, and the environment. We believe this FTA will lead to increased land-grabbing by multinationals in Ecuador, and a deterioration in the rights of indigenous people, workers and trade unions. For these reasons we voted against.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report recommends the approval of Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement concluded in 2012 between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. This agreement includes a drastic reduction in customs duties as well as the liberalization of the services market, in return for more stringent environmental and social standards. Ecuadorian fishing will, in fact, be exempt from customs duties; As for agricultural products, the agreement provides for the elimination of 90% of tariffs within 17 years. We have obviously opposed this trade agreement which will threaten the viability of our farms, especially in overseas regions where banana exports are an important source of income. Consequently, the multiplication of tariff concessions granted by the European Union risks dealing the final blow to our agricultural sector, which is already facing falling commodity prices as well as the Russian embargo. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012, with the possibility of accession to that agreement and other Member States. of the Andean Community. As a result, the European Union and Ecuador have concluded negotiations for such accession. This agreement would allow Ecuador to strengthen its new guidelines on encouraging economic and social sustainable development policies. Thus, the implementation of the trade agreement will have a positive impact in terms of Ecuador's development and its alignment with European standards. I am in favor of this report because I believe that this instrument will promote the strengthening of bilateral relations and political dialogue based on respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - I have supported the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement of the European Union with Colombia and Peru, with which the Union will give continuity to the tariff preferences that it has granted up to now and that, by rising to a middle-income country, would have lost in January weighing down the exports of which many people live in this country. We Socialists celebrate that this Agreement includes ambitious, unprecedented commitments between the Union and Ecuador, on sustainable development, human, labor and environmental rights, which should serve to promote fairer bilateral trade. In this sense, Ecuador has already been undertaking some good reforms, which under the Agreement must continue. We have also worked very intensively with Ecuador, to ensure that its export capacity in the banana sector does not harm European regions that, like the Canary Islands, are highly dependent on this crop. An Agreement that, without a doubt, will help to intensify and improve the relationship between Europe and Latin America, as we Spanish socialists defend. We will closely monitor compliance with the commitments and support Ecuador in its reforms, with all the Instruments available to the Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the report in question which extends the trade agreement concluded in 2012 with Colombia and Peru to Ecuador. The aim is to integrate the Andean Community into the global trading system by increasing trade and investment with the European Union. Economically, Ecuador is facing a difficult situation. Ecuadorian exports suffered a 29% decline in 2015, mainly due to the collapse of oil exports, which was accompanied by a decline in other exports, resulting in insufficient revenues to cover the government's financial needs. The agreement will allow Ecuador to pursue the new guidelines for promoting policies for the country's economic and social development in a complex regional and international context. The obligation for the Commission to inform the Parliament about its activities related to the implementation and monitoring of this agreement, in particular as regards sustainable development obligations, will contribute to the monitoring, evaluation and follow-up of the policy European commercial.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs abstained on this, as it was a simple technical update to the fact that Ecuador is now party to certain parts of this agreement. We did not feel a strong need to vote against this tidying—up exercise.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru. The global picture of the country, as reported in this resolution of November 2015, confirms the progress made by Ecuador in many areas, although some outstanding issues remain, such as a complete press freedom. Ecuador is still benefiting until the end of the year from preferential access to the EU market for its goods what has anticipated for the country the full benefits of the accession. Furthermore, the accession of Ecuador should bring benefits to the integration of the Andean region.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru was concluded in June 2012 and its article 329 provides for the possibility for other member countries of the Andean Community to access it. The European Union and Ecuador concluded their accession negotiations on 17 July 2014. Economically, Ecuador is facing a difficult situation and Ecuadorian exports suffered a sharp decline in 2015. Still, on April 16 an earthquake of magnitude 7.8 shook the country, causing at least 673 victims and 27 732 injured. According to estimates by the Ecuadorian government, the costs of reconstruction will be around 3 billion US dollars, equal to about 3.0% of GDP. A scenario where Ecuador does not enjoy the benefits of the trade agreement could have a highly negative impact on the country's economy. Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru with a gradual and flexible implementation of the agreement, supported by a preparatory approach by the Commission is therefore positive.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. - Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru represents a further step forward in relations between the Union and the member countries of the Andean Community. Ecuador is facing a difficult situation in the face of the collapse of oil prices, the devaluation of the currencies of the Andean countries and, not least, the tragic earthquake that hit the country in April 2016. I believe that the rapid and complete entry into the vigor and implementation of this agreement will allow Ecuador to restart its economy and carry out the new guidelines for promoting policies for sustainable economic and social development. Furthermore, I believe that Ecuador's accession to the agreement can give a new impetus to political and economic integration in the Andean region, and more generally strengthen political dialogue with the EU. In particular, I hope that this dialogue can also extend to more sensitive issues, such as freedom of expression and freedom of the press, which have been severely restricted following the adoption of the communication law in June 2013. For these reasons I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report, as we consider that Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru and its progressive and flexible implementation by the Commission on the basis of a pre-accession approach, taking into account periodic evaluations after consultation with the Ecuadorian government and civil society on both sides would be a step forward in the alliance with important and rapidly developing countries embracing the same ideas in a region increasingly oriented towards Asia and the Pacific.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The recommendation on the conclusion of a Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take into account the accession of Ecuador, is an attempt to further develop cooperation withthird countries, which can benefit the citizens of both parties, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing.- Ecuador's accession represents not only a step towards closer bilateral relations through greater political and economic integration, but a further opening for the Union to strengthen ties with further countries in the Andean region.In the beginning there was the agreement concluded between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and by Colombia and Peru, on the other, signed on June 26, 2012, which specifies in article 326 the provision of accession forother South American states.Therefore, the negotiations concluded with Ecuador do not generate astonishment, but encourage the promotion of policies for sustainable economic and social development along the same lines as the plans adopted by Colombia and Peru regarding structural reforms.I hope, with my favorable vote, a much brighter future for everyone.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the EU-Colombia and Peru Trade Agreement (accession of Ecuador)

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs abstained on this, as it was a simple technical update to reflect the fact that Ecuador is now party to certain parts of this agreement. We did not feel a strong need to vote against this tidying up exercise.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of Ecuador's entry into the pre-existing trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru as the measure is very important for the Ecuadorian economy whose products will be placed on the European market under a regime ofparity with those from Colombia and Peru.Furthermore, the agreement widens the regional dimension among the Andean countries with undeniable positive effects on their economies.For the European Union, Ecuador's entry also solidifies the presence of the European Union in Latin America with evident economic and political advantages.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have voted against the Adhesion of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia / Peru Multiparty Trade Agreement, understanding that there are no substantial changes in an Agreement that continues to be based on the logic of free trade, deregulation, privatization or the exploitation of resources natural. We opposed this EU-Colombia / Peru Agreement and we continue to reject it. Our model of relations are not Free Trade Agreements that do not take into account economic asymmetries and that only seek to open new markets and benefits to multinational companies, but agreements that are based on complementarity, cooperation, sustainable and sustainable development and whose central objective is to end inequalities. We reject the blackmail to which the Union subjects third countries through its current tariff policies and the conditioning of development cooperation funds, linked to the signing of Trade Agreements like this one. We support the Government of Ecuador in the policies it has carried out for the development of the "good living" model based on greater control by the State of strategic sectors of the economy, but we consider that social achievements would not have been possible under the logic that establishes this Agreement.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- The rapid and complete entry into force and implementation of this agreement will allow Ecuador to carry forward the new guidelines for promoting policies for the sustainable economic and social development of the country in a complex regional and international context.I therefore welcomed the conclusion of the negotiations with Ecuador and I hope that the monitoring, evaluation and follow-up of existing agreements will be a key priority of the common commercial policy.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. The European Parliament encouraged the entry into force and implementation of this agreement without delay and in full, considering that this would allow Ecuador to continue its new guidelines aimed at stimulating the country's economic and social sustainable development policies in a complicated regional and international context. From an economic point of view, Ecuador is currently in a difficult situation due to the fall in oil prices by more than 60% (2015). In 2015, Ecuador's total exports fell by 29%, mainly due to the decline in oil exports by 50%, while other exports also fell by 6.1%, with the remaining revenues insufficient to cover the needs government financial resources. I voted in favor of Ecuador's accession to this trade agreement, an agreement that would help the sustainable development of all parties involved, in a region that is increasingly oriented towards Asia and the Pacific region.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - A trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, was signed in 2012, which also provides an opportunity for other Andean Community countries to join the agreement. Accordingly, the European Union and Ecuador concluded accession negotiations on 17 July 2014. Ecuador will lose its GSP + status on 31 December 2016 following a change in the relevant EU legislation. A situation in which Ecuador would not enjoy either GSP + status or the benefits of a trade agreement would negatively affect the Ecuadorian economy. With the fall in oil prices of more than 60% (2015) and the appreciation of the US dollar and other currencies (Colombia), Ecuador is currently in a difficult economic situation. In addition, on April 16, a magnitude 7.8 earthquake shook Ecuador. The Ecuadorian government estimates that reconstruction costs will kick in at about $ 3 billion, or about 3% of GDP. Ecuador’s accession to the trade agreement, along with Colombia and Peru, would be a step forward in an existing alliance with major, like-minded and fast-growing countries in a region that is increasingly turning to Asia and the Pacific. The European Parliament today gave its consent to the conclusion of the protocol.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- Due to the completed negotiations between the EU and Ecuador, I voted in favor of Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru.In accordance with the content of the trade agreement, other member states of the Andean Community may accede to the agreement.In the case of Ecuador, I believe that effective and swift action is necessary, as Ecuador will lose its GSP + status as of December 31, 2016.Loss of this status by Ecuador would disturb trade and be harmful to the Ecuadorian economy.I am in favor of implementing this agreement as soon as possible, which will positively contribute to accelerating the development of partnerships with important, like-minded and fast-developing countries in a region that is increasingly turning to Asia and the Pacific.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of taking account of the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement and that the monitoring, evaluation and follow-up of existing agreements must be a key priority of the Common Commercial Policy. Economically Ecuador is in a difficult situation and thus a trade agreement would help this country develop. This agreement should be a step forward in the alliance with important, like-minded and fast-growing countries.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ My party and I have always encouraged the quick and complete entry into force and implementation of this agreement. It will provide welcome new market access opportunities to UK firms in fast growing markets, as well as helping to cement deeper economic ties and strengthen the rules-based global trading system.

name: Jakop Dalunde (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- Ecuador, together with Bolivia, has long worked for a new type of trade agreement that promotes sustainable development, redistribution and indigenous peoples' rights.This agreement means a return to an unfair and unsustainable trade where Ecuador becomes stuck in a dependence on raw material exports.The popular movements in Ecuador are critical.Therefore, we can not vote in favor of the agreement.At the same time, we want to respect an elected government in the south and do not choose to vote no either.We are voting blank this time.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. - I strongly voted in favor of the recommendation on the conclusion of Ecuador's accession protocol to the trade agreement between the European Union-Colombia and Peru. The assent of the Parliament will allow, in fact, the provisional application of the agreement as early as January 1, 2017, pending ratification by the national parliaments of each EU member state as well as Ecuador, Colombia and Peru. An asymmetrical agreement, which provides for the liberalization of 60% of tariff lines by Ecuador and 95% by Europe, with a gradual reduction of duties over a period of 17 years and which has the merit of aligning the situation of the Ecuador to that of Colombia and Peru also with regard to the preferences granted by the EU to the latter for banana exports, obviating the competitive disadvantage that existed up to now in this sector. The conclusion of the protocol, an instrument that will also remain available to Bolivia if it wishes to join the agreement in the future, represents an important step towards the consolidation of the regional integration of the countries of the Andean Community as well as a fundamental step forward in the broader framework of the strengthening of trade and non-trade links between the EU and Latin America.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This report offers the European Parliament's positive opinion on the approval of Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia and Peru trade agreement.Until the end of the year, Ecuador continues to benefit from privileged access for its goods to the European Union market, which has enabled the country to benefit, in advance, of all the advantages ofadherence to the trade agreement.The conclusion of the process at Union level, with the provisional entry into force of the Protocol, will establish a more stable economic relationship.The French EPP delegation worked extensively in favor of the establishment of an internal protection mechanism for the banana market, allowing better protection for European producers, and French producers in particular.Considering these elements, I voted in favor.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs abstained on this, as it was a simple technical update to reflect the fact that Ecuador is now party to certain parts of this agreement. We did not feel a strong need to vote against this tidying up exercise.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. The inclusion of Ecuador in this agreement will help remove tariff barriers and all parties will benefit from positive trade spillovers. Facilitating market access for exporters, Europeans and Ecuadorians, on the basis of a pre-existing agreement with countries neighboring Ecuador is a reasoned approach which allows the interests of each party to be properly taken into account and leads to on profits for all. This trade agreement with an additional member of the Andean Community must also be able to serve as a foundation for ever more developed relations between the Andean Community and the European Union. In order to protect European producers from Ecuador - the world's largest banana producer - however, we have ensured that a stabilization mechanism for bananas will accompany this agreement when a certain annual import volume is reached.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which approves the ratification by the European Parliament of the trade agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru.Consensus has been found in this international agreement to guarantee operational protection of European banana production.This condition was essential for us to be able to accept the agreement, as the opening up of markets should not be detrimental to our operations.The negotiated mechanism brings more transparency, better monitoring and the promise of appropriate measures that will support the future of European production in the event of market disruption leading to a crisis in the sector.These changes were ultimately necessary before considering the ratification of this agreement with Ecuador.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 and certain provisions of the Agreement were signed between the European Union and Peru on 1 March 2013 and between the European Union and Colombia since 1 August 2013. Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility for other members of the ANDEAN Community to accede to the Agreement. The European Union and Ecuador concluded accession negotiations on 17 July 2014. On 20 November 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement (2015/2656 (RSP)), urging the Ecuadorian Government to take similar measures on the basis of the action plans submitted by Colombia and Peru. Following the resolution, the rapporteur visited Ecuador in March 2016. In view of the above, it is appropriate for Parliament to give its consent, but it is important to note that monitoring and evaluating existing agreements is a key priority of the common commercial policy. The Commission is therefore obliged to inform Parliament about the implementation and monitoring of this agreement. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported Ecuador's agreement to join the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru. The deal is crucial for the economy of Ecuador, a country that has been hit hard by falling oil prices and exports, and the high costs of reconstruction after this year's earthquake. It can pave the way for progressive social and environmental policies. The EU also has a lot to gain from this, as once the agreement enters into force, Ecuador will remove tariffs on 60% of its imports from the European Union. Ecuador will also benefit from optimized access to the EU for its main exports, such as fish, cut flowers, coffee, cocoa, fruits and nuts. Some products will also benefit from a preferential rate, but a stabilization mechanism, put in place through other legislation, will ensure that the interests of European producers are protected.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - Three years after the ratification of the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru, Ecuador joins the list of signatories.
