The Ecuadorian economy, hit by the drop in exports and by the violent earthquake that struck this summer, will be able to take full advantage of the preferences offered by the agreement to begin its recovery. As for the EU, it has a lot to gain from closer economic ties with the countries of Central America and the Andean countries. The provisions of this agreement must not, however, threaten fragile sectors of the European economy. The banana industry is particularly sensitive in this regard; it risks suffering from competition from Ecuador, the world's leading export producer. That is why, before giving our assent to the inclusion of Ecuador in this partnership, we felt it necessary to strengthen the mechanisms to protect European production. The agreement reached the day before ratification between the Commission, Parliament and the Council on safeguard clauses will, on the one hand, allow better forecasting of the development of imports into the Union and, on the other hand, to react more effectively against an increase in banana arrivals from these countries, which would be likely to destabilize the European market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This concerns the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement between the EU, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other hand, dating from 2012. This text implies, in particular, theelimination of 90% of customs duties in the agricultural sector within 17 years, liberalization of the services market and the imposition of environmental and labor standards.This text will notably promote Ecuadorian fishing and banana production, which will be extremely detrimental to French overseas producers.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- Once again, the EU intervenes in the interior of a third country in exchange for / promising the conclusion of a trade agreement.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against giving consent to the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia/Peru Trade Agreement because the accession agreement is not strong enough. It is important to my constituents that agreements with countries around the world are based on shared standards and firm commitments for improvement.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- Ecuador is currently in a difficult situation due to the sharp drop in oil prices of more than 60%.In 2015, Ecuador's total exports decreased by 29%, essentially due to a 50% decline in oil exports, while exports of non-oil products also decreased by 6.1%, which leaves no revenuesufficient to cover the Government's financial needs.On April 16, the country was hit by an earthquake measuring 7.8 magnitude, resulting in at least 673 deaths and 27 732 injuries.According to the Ecuadorian government, reconstruction costs are expected to amount to US $ 3000 million, which is equivalent to about 3.0% of GDP.I agree with Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, because it will help Peru to rebuild at a particularly difficult time.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Against: unfavorable to producers in overseas regions for whom bananas are an important source of income.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation report proposes to extend to Ecuador the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru. The initial objective was to establish an agreement with the countries of the Andean Community. In this phase, negotiations ended up being restricted to Colombia and Peru, since Ecuador and Bolivia resisted it and ended up abandoning it, denouncing the EU's intentions to conclude a free trade agreement, which oppose a trade vision for the development. Under enormous and growing pressure and interference in the region, this free trade agreement, contrary to the economic and social policies that the Ecuadorian government has carried out, serves as a blackmail weapon that aims, in particular, to destabilize the founding countries of Mercosur. The “free trade agreements”, of a neocolonial nature, aim at the privatization and exploitation of natural resources, the deregulation of the world of work and the conditioning of the economic and social policies of those countries. With this agreement, the major European economic groups in industry and services will win. The export sectors for machinery, automobiles (and other transport equipment) and chemicals. With service groups - telecommunications, construction, distribution and financial services - on the lookout for the opportunity to colonize yet another market. We voted against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the following proposal as I believe it necessary to facilitate the rapid accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other.I share the aim of the agreement which would allow Ecuador to maintain preferential access to the European Union market and would allow the two parties to forge even closer bilateral relations, giving further impetus to political and economic integration in the Andean region and strengthening dialoguepolitical based on respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- The European Union and Ecuador concluded mutual negotiations on accession to the agreement in July 2014. However, due to trade-related problems between Ecuador and Colombia and Peru, the Accession Protocol was not approved by the Trade Commission until 8.2.2016.This means that the approval procedure must be significantly accelerated in order for Ecuador to start benefiting from the trade agreement as of 1 January 2017. This proposal establishes all the necessary modifications associated with Ecuador's accession.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I vote against, extending the agreement to Ecuador could increase exports to Europe of agricultural products and textiles that could penalize our production system.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- Once again, the EU intervenes in the interior of a third country in exchange for / promising a trade agreement, which is why I am voting against the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement (accession of Ecuador).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, as it will open up markets and increase the stability and predictability of the trading environment. The accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru is another decisive step forward in the alliance with important, like-minded and fast-growing countries and regions. The Agreement will provide improved access to the Ecuadorian market for many key EU exports, for example in the automotive sector or for alcoholic beverages. However, the Agreement will not only secure access to markets; more importantly, it will also create a stable and predictable environment that will help boost and diversify trade and investment on both sides.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 and certain provisions of the Agreement were signed between the European Union and Peru on 1 March 2013 and between the European Union and Colombia since 1 August 2013. Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility for other members of the ANDEAN Community to accede to the Agreement. The European Union and Ecuador concluded accession negotiations on 17 July 2014. On 20 November 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement (2015/2656 (RSP)), urging the Ecuadorian Government to take similar measures on the basis of the action plans submitted by Colombia and Peru. Following the resolution, the rapporteur visited Ecuador in March 2016. In view of the above, it is appropriate for Parliament to give its consent, but it is important to note that monitoring and evaluating existing agreements is a key priority of the common commercial policy. The Commission is therefore obliged to inform Parliament about the implementation and monitoring of this agreement. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Accession Protocol to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other hand, to take into account the accession of Ecuador, because it is a legal act necessary to allow the South American country to benefit from important commercial advantages, such as a progressive opening of the markets for goods, services, public procurement, abolition of most tariffs, a chapter on trade and sustainable development with ambitious provisions on labor and environmental protection. This is a dutiful support to a country that is suffering from a major crisis and which has also recently experienced a terrible earthquake, which has claimed more than 600 victims. I am convinced that this agreement will allow the two parties to develop even closer relations, facilitating the social and economic development of the country, but also the political dialogue between the EU and Ecuador on important issues, first of all the protection of individual freedoms. and social. I am therefore proud of the important contribution made by Parliament, with its official visit to Ecuador, to speeding up negotiations between the parties.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- The agreement offers the opportunity to intensify the political dialogue between the EU and Ecuador on the basis of respect for democratic principles and respect for fundamental rights.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this recommendation as it was a simple technical update to reflect the fact that Ecuador is now party to certain parts of this agreement. I did not feel a strong need to vote against this tidying-up exercise.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report. The Protocol establishes the necessary modifications to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru to take account of the accession of Ecuador. The Trade Agreement establishes the conditions for EU economic operators to take full advantage of the opportunities and the emerging complementarities between our respective economies.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: in writing. - A trade agreement was signed between the EU, Colombia and Peru in 2012. The Council proposes to the European Parliament to integrate Ecuador. Fishery and agricultural products would thus be exported to the Union with greatly reduced customs duties. Dependent on sharply falling oil exports and the victim of a serious earthquake that killed thousands of people, Ecuador is in a difficult economic situation. The earthquake is expected to result in reconstruction costs of around 3% of GDP. Of course, this reconstruction offers possibilities to the European construction giants. Remember, however, that the country is no longer sovereign over its currency, since the US dollar is legal tender there. Because of the dollar's extraterritoriality, the conquered markets will therefore be subject to American laws, which are regularly used to weaken our industrial leaders. The extension of the trade agreement to Ecuador will also pose a threat to our overseas departments, whose banana exports to the EU will face stiff competition. Moreover, this agreement risks placing local economic players in a very delicate situation (competition from more competitive European players), even though the country must rebuild itself after this natural disaster. So I voted against this proposal.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- It is undeniable that the drop in the price of oil and the rise in the dollar makes the economic and political situation in Ecuador difficult.In this context, the loss of tariff preferences threatens Ecuador's economy in the short term and also the electoral victory of the emancipatory project in February.However, although I understand the short-term interest of the Ecuadorian Government in obtaining the oxygen balloon that supposes the non-increase in tariffs on its exports, the Agreement contains harmful elements in the long term as it could lay the foundations for an unequal commercial relationship.Furthermore, with this agreement, the Union is promoting, once again, a system in which the foundations are laid for a trade for the benefit of the usual, which I will not defend under any circumstances.That is why I have abstained.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Protocol. This proposal establishes the necessary modifications to the Trade Agreement to take account of the accession of Ecuador.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written. - I have supported the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement of the European Union with Colombia and Peru, with which the Union will give continuity to the tariff preferences that it has granted up to now and that, by rising to a middle-income country, would have lost in January weighing down the exports of which many people live in this country. We Socialists celebrate that this Agreement includes ambitious, unprecedented commitments between the Union and Ecuador, on sustainable development, human, labor and environmental rights, which should serve to promote fairer bilateral trade. In this sense, Ecuador has already been undertaking some good reforms, which under the Agreement must continue. We have also worked very intensively with Ecuador, to ensure that its export capacity in the banana sector does not harm European regions that, like the Canary Islands, are highly dependent on this crop. An Agreement that, without a doubt, will help to intensify and improve the relationship between Europe and Latin America, as we Spanish socialists defend. We will closely monitor compliance with the commitments and support Ecuador in its reforms, with all the Instruments available to the Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted against Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement as we did with the original agreement.Such trade agreements are not in the public interest, and the implementation of this agreement in Colombia and Peru has shown this to us.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the EU and Peru and Columbia and encourage the quick and complete entry into force and implementation of this agreement. This agreement, therefore, will allow Ecuador the opportunity to continue stimulating policies on economic and social sustainable development.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 and certain provisions of the Agreement were signed between the European Union and Peru on 1 March 2013 and between the European Union and Colombia since 1 August 2013. Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility for other members of the ANDEAN Community to accede to the Agreement. The European Union and Ecuador concluded accession negotiations on 17 July 2014. On 20 November 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement (2015/2656 (RSP)), urging the Ecuadorian Government to take similar measures on the basis of the action plans submitted by Colombia and Peru. Following the resolution, the rapporteur visited Ecuador in March 2016. In view of the above, it is appropriate for Parliament to give its consent, but it is important to note that monitoring and evaluating existing agreements is a key priority of the common commercial policy. The Commission is therefore obliged to inform Parliament about the implementation and monitoring of this agreement. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of concluding the protocol setting out the necessary amendments to the EU Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru to take account of Ecuador's accession.The EU and Ecuador concluded accession negotiations on 17 July 2014, but due to trade issues between Ecuador and Colombia / Peru, the accession protocol was only approved by the Trade Policy Council on 8 February 2016.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other partconsidered the accession of Ecuador as it gives its consent to the accession of Ecuador to the Agreement.Ecuador is in a difficult regional and international and economic situation due to reduced exports, falling oil prices and the earthquake that hit this country.I believe that the Agreement will enable the continuation of incentive policies for economically and socially sustainable development.Certainly, this is of mutual benefit and I therefore support this Recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am opposed to this plan to join one of the world's leading banana exporters, which will harm producers in our overseas regions for whom its trade represents an important source of income.I voted against.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: written. - I have supported the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement of the European Union with Colombia and Peru, with which the Union will give continuity to the tariff preferences that until now it has granted and that, by rising to a middle-income country, would have lost January weighing down the exports that many people live in this country. We Socialists celebrate that this Agreement includes ambitious, unprecedented commitments between the Union and Ecuador, on sustainable development, human, labor and environmental rights, which should serve to promote fairer bilateral trade. In this sense, Ecuador has already been undertaking some good reforms, which under the Agreement must continue. We have also worked very intensively with Ecuador, to ensure that its export capacity in the banana sector does not harm European regions that, like the Canary Islands, are highly dependent on this crop. An Agreement that, without a doubt, will help to intensify and improve the relationship between Europe and Latin America, as we Spanish socialists defend. We will closely monitor compliance with the commitments and support Ecuador in its reforms, with all the Instruments available to the Union.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported this recommendation regarding the accession of Ecuador to the agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru, because I am in favor of deepening the EU's relations with the countries concerned.Ecuador is in a complicated regional and international context, and I believe that closer cooperation will stimulate its sustainable economic and social development.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Helmut Scholz on the trade agreement integrating Ecuador into the EU-Colombia and Peru trade agreement.The agreement creates the right conditions to benefit all signatories.It provides for the lifting of several tariff barriers opening up new outlets for European companies, in particular through a rationalization of standards in terms of intellectual property, phytosanitary rules and competition.I am also delighted that an agreement was obtained upstream on the implementation of the safeguard clause and the stabilization mechanism for bananas, so as not to endanger production in the French Antilles, which is at the end of the line.origin of many jobs.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I approved this report.The trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru was signed in 2012 and has been in place with both countries since August and March 2013, respectively.Ecuador is now keen to join this agreement as well.This is all the more important now that the persistent weak oil price, which makes up over 60% of the country's exports, is affecting economic and government revenues.In addition, Ecuador will lose its GSP + standard in December 2016 and will therefore be significantly restricted in its opportunities to trade with the EU.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Protocol. This proposal implements the necessary modifications to the Trade Agreement to take account of the accession of Ecuador.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this trade agreement in the spirit of my consistent opposition to unfair trade deals. It is not going to contribute to the creation to the new jobs and overall prosperity of Ecuador.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing.- Many of the warm fruits, spices and fruits found in European shops come from Central American countries, so the importance of economic ties should not be underestimated.Under the previous trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, its extension to Ecuador should be clearly supported.Here, too, Europe has a balancing effect, which is undoubtedly a positive thing for all the outermost regions.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia and Peru Trade Agreement. In fact, the accession of Ecuador to the agreement is crucial for the EU and Ecuador, because it will allow both parties to develop even closer bilateral relations and will be an impetus for further economic and political integration in the Andean region. It is important to note that the agreement contains a Trade and Sustainable Development Charter, which includes ambitious provisions on labour and environmental protection and aims to ensure predictable and stable environmental conditions for investors on both sides. Last but not least, the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia and Peru Trade Agreement will provide an opportunity to enhance the EU’s political dialogue with the country in regards to respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights. In a long-term perspective, the enhanced political dialogue should be used by the EU to urge Ecuador to tackle sensitive issues such as freedom of expression, labour rights and protection of indigenous people.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - The report on the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru expresses the European Parliament's favorable opinion on the entry of Ecuador. This step represents an important turning point for Ecuador's economy, which will see its products placed on the European market, together with products from Colombia and Peru. It also aims at a progressive opening of the markets for goods, services, public procurement, investments, and above all the abolition of most tariffs. Trade and sustainable development are also foreseen in the agreement, which include ambitious frameworks for the protection of labor and the environment. The same will allow the two sides to be able to develop closer bilateral relations, giving an impetus to political and economic integration in the region, and will offer the possibility of strengthening the political dialogue between the EU and Ecuador. In light of the economic, political and social benefits of Ecuador's accession to the free trade agreement, I am voting in favor of the report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the EU-Colombia and Peru trade agreement on Ecuador's membership.This report asks to say yes to the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru dating from 2012. Customs duties will be abolished, services markets liberalized, PGI protected,open public procurement, with environmental and labor standards imposed.Ecuadorian fisheries will no longer have tariffs.Ecuador, according to the EU, "will benefit from significant new access to the European Union's banana markets".90% of customs duties in the agricultural sector will be eliminated in 17 years.This will be very unfavorable to producers in overseas regions, for whom bananas are an important source of income.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report defends Ecuador's adherence to the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru, dating from 2012. This agreement risks severely penalizing the production of bananas, essential in our overseas regions.Wed.Indeed, thanks to this membership, Ecuador will benefit from considerable new access to the European Union markets for this fruit.I want to protect our fruit production against competition from foreign countries, and therefore voted against this membership.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- Ecuador's entry into this free trade agreement is proof of how Europe uses trade agreements to force developing countries to integrate peripherally into world trade.By signing a trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, an agreement that has had very negative effects in terms of labor rights, land grabbing and productive dismantling of these countries, exports were diverted from Ecuador, which in this way was forced to signthis agreement to avoid a balance of payments crisis.However, the effects of this agreement will be very negative in the long term also for Ecuador and for this reason I have voted against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written. - By virtue of this text, the Parliament approves the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru, concluded in 2012. At the present time, Ecuador is in a difficult situation, derived from the sharp drop in Oil prices, the appreciation of the US dollar, the depreciation of other currencies and the tragic 7.8 magnitude earthquake that occurred in April of this year. That is why adhesion to this Trade Agreement could be very beneficial for a faster recovery of the country. Throughout the process of the accession negotiations, the will to include Ecuador has become clear. Thus, in November 2015, Parliament approved a Resolution in which it welcomed the establishment of negotiations with Ecuador and encouraged a rapid entry into force of accession. I give my favorable vote because I believe that the Agreement will allow Ecuador to continue in the line it is following of stimulus policies in terms of sustainable economic and social development.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor.This agreement means accepting Ecuador's accession to the EU-South America Trade Liberalization Agreement.I support the EU and Ecuador being able to trade in goods and services duty-free.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written.- The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Colombia and Peru was signed in Brussels in 2012, and in the same year the European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution approving the conclusion of the Agreement.Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility of accession of other member states of the Andean Community to the Agreement, and the EU and Ecuador concluded negotiations on such accession in 2014.By the end of this year, Ecuador should lose its GSP + status (general benefit system), which could have negative consequences for its economy.Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, its progressive and flexible implementation will be a step forward towards concluding alliances with important countries that are recording rapid growth in the region.I therefore supported this recommendation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Committee on International Trade adopted the on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Ecuador. The European Parliament give its consent to the conclusion of the Protocol and I support this position.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- With this resolution, the EP gives its consent to the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part.Ecuador has significant economic problems related to the fall in oil prices, and is also affected by the effects of this year's earthquake.This agreement will help the Ecuadorian economy, but at the same time the Commission must closely monitor the implementation of this agreement and inform Parliament in good time of the findings and measures that affect the agreement and mutual trade.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I vote in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and of Colombia and Peru, of the other part, totake into account the accession of Ecuador, because it is sufficiently documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This free trade agreement will not only boost trade between the EU and Ecuador, but will also contribute to improving labour rights and environmental standards in the country through the provisions of the trade and sustainable development chapter. I therefore voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this report.This report aims to give the European Parliament's approval for Ecuador's accession to the 2012 trade agreement between the European Union and two Latin American countries, namely Colombia and Peru.As a result of this membership Ecuador will gain significant new access to EU markets in the banana sector.Thus, we consider it unfavorable to producers in overseas regions for whom bananas are an important source of income.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on EU-Colombia and Peru Trade Agreement (accession of Ecuador). Such agreement is crucial in strengthening the EU’s relations with strategic South American partners such as Colombia, Peru and Ecuador. At the same time, the agreement proves beneficial to all people and countries involved, as it opens up to a progressive market of goods, services, government investment and abolition of most tariffs. Most importantly, the agreement will further allow economic and political integration in the Andean region, as well as enhancing cooperation in terms of democratic principles and fundamental rights. Hence, the report is worth supporting, as all the actors involved will benefit from the agreement.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: in writing. - Unlike the various EU-Africa "Partnership Agreements" which I have consistently opposed, Ecuador's Protocol of Accession to the Colombia-Peru Agreement is a pro-development agreement. Resolutely asymmetric - at a maturity of 17 years, the Ecuadorian market will be 60% open, against 95% for the European market - it takes Ecuador’s needs into account. Thus, it should make it possible to support the social efforts of the Correa government, and result in a GDP increase of 0.5%, on the Ecuadorian side. At the same time, the agreement will allow European industries and producers to gain a foothold in the Ecuadorian market: access to public markets is broadened, customs duties clearly reduced in the automotive sector, around a hundred names of European controlled origin are recognized. However, by implementing a high tariff dismantling (the entry price on the European market for Ecuadorian bananas will be set at 75 euros / tonne), the agreement could pose a risk to the West Indian banana sector, whose good health is decisive for the prosperity of these territories. While it is true that the stabilization mechanism specifically dedicated to bananas will soon be strengthened, there is reason to doubt its applicability. I therefore abstained.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I am in favor of the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and of Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of Ecuador, because I believe that Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru and its progressive and flexible implementation by the Commission on the basis of a pre-accession approach, taking into account periodic evaluations in consultation with the Ecuadorian It would be a step forward in the alliance with important and rapidly developing countries embracing the same ideas in a region increasingly oriented towards Asia and the Pacific. Traditionally, fishermen do not fish in specific waters: they catch specific stocks or species and fish in waters where those stocks or species are found and also follow migratory species. This tradition preceded the creation of states and the recognition of territorial waters and - much later - exclusive economic zones.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written. - The trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru was signed in 2012 and has been in place with both countries since August and March 2013, respectively. Ecuador is now keen to accede to this agreement. This is all the more important now that the ongoing weak oil price, which represents a good 60% of the country's exports, and the appreciation of the US dollar, which is used to conduct business with the main export partners, are affecting the economy and government revenues. In addition, Ecuador will lose its GSP + standard in December 2016 and will therefore be significantly restricted in its ability to trade with the EU. The country exports goods worth around 12 billion US dollars, more than half of them to the USA; other main trading partners are South American countries. Since the economic consequences for the EU are negligible and the agreement actually has a symbolic value, I supported this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which creates stronger trade links with the Andean countries.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have been explaining the dangers of these free trade agreements with Latin America for several years. Already with the agreement with Colombia and Peru, the first step to break the Andean alliance. I was opposed during the conclusion of the negotiations with Ecuador, which I believe were obtained with a lot of pressure and blackmail from Brussels and its lobbies on the government of Rafael Correa. This agreement recites all the liberal mantras: "liberalize the markets for services", "the dismantling of several important non-tariff barriers" (social and environmental standards), "will completely free European exporters of industrial products and goods from the payment of customs duties. fishery products destined for Ecuador ”. We can clearly see the interest in European multinationals, the mining and agribusiness sectors. On the other hand, Ecuadorian small farmers are directly threatened. But also our small banana producers facing the giant Chiquita which practices environmental dumping and land grabbing. In short, years of promoting cooperation and the whole Ecuadorian social model of Buen Vivir are called into question. I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- This agreement seeks to accept Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement, dating from 2012, between the EU, Colombia and Peru.It provides for abolished customs duties, the liberalization of service markets, the opening of public contracts.In addition, Ecuadorian fishing will no longer be subject to customs duties and Ecuador will be able to benefit from significant access to the European Union markets for bananas, this having a very heavy impact on the French overseas regions.I therefore opposed this agreement.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report setting out the necessary changes to the EU / Colombia and Peru trade agreement to take into account the accession of Ecuador. This agreement, which will enter into force on January 1, 2017, is essential for Ecuador. It will stimulate trade and investment between the two sides, thereby contributing to economic growth and job creation. It will allow Ecuador to integrate into the regional and world economy. This asymmetric agreement, designed to contribute to Ecuador’s development, provides, as in the EPAs, for progressive tariff liberalization over a period of 17 years. Ecuador will benefit from better access to the European market for fishery products, cut flowers, coffee, cocoa, fruits and nuts. Bananas will be granted a preferential rate that will be accompanied by a stabilization mechanism as is the case with other countries party to the agreement. With this agreement, Ecuador will be able to take better advantage of the opportunities offered by international trade.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU and Ecuador concluded the negotiations for the accession on 17 July 2014, but due to trade-related problems between Ecuador and Colombia/Peru, the Protocol of Accession was only approved by the Trade Policy Council on 8 February 2016. This means that the adoption procedure had to be accelerated, so that Ecuador could start benefiting from the FTA as of 1 January 2017, after its temporary trade preferences granted by the EU expire. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this proposal to establish the necessary modifications to the Trade Agreement to take account of the accession of Ecuador, which is essential.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- Article 329 of the Trade Agreement concluded on 11 December 2012 between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, provides for the possibility of accession to the Agreement by other Member States of the Andean Community.The European Union and Ecuador concluded accession negotiations on 17 July 2014.The Council has drawn up a draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of a protocol taking into account the accession of Ecuador, subject to the consent of Parliament.In its report, the Committee on International Trade proposes that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the protocol.I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report asks to say yes to Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru dating from 2012. High tariffs are abolished, markets for services liberalized, PGIsprotected, open public procurement, with environmental and labor standards imposed.Ecuadorian fisheries will no longer have tariffs.Ecuador, according to the EU, "will benefit from significant new access to the European Union's banana markets".90% of customs duties in the agricultural sector according to eliminated in 17 years.This will be very unfavorable to producers in overseas regions for whom bananas are an important source of income.Vote against.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report asks to say yes to Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru dating from 2012. Ecuador having become a middle-income country, it can no longer dopart of the SPG + agreement.High tariffs are abolished, service markets liberalized, PGIs protected, public procurement opened, with environmental and labor standards imposed.Ecuadorian fisheries will no longer have tariffs.Ecuador, according to the EU, "will benefit from significant new access to EU banana markets".90% of customs duties in the agricultural sector will be abolished in 17 years.This will be very unfavorable to producers in overseas regions for whom bananas are an important source of income.I therefore vote against.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it introduces several amendments to the Commission proposals, in particular with respect to increased transparency, making the triggering of the stabilisation mechanism automatic beyond a certain threshold, and it also called on the Commission and Council in a draft joint declaration annex to the resolution to maintain the stabilisation mechanism beyond 2019 if ‘a serious deterioration in the state of the market or the situation of European producers is found to have occurred or is in danger of occurring’.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text which approves the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement between the EU, Colombia and Peru.EU exporters will thus save more than 100 million euros in customs duties each year.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 26 June 2012, the Trade Agreement between the EU, on the one side, and Colombia and Peru on the other, was signed. I have voted for this recommendation to take into consideration the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I support the present agreement because, firstly, there are no significant effects to be feared on the European Union and Ecuador is not being deprived of its economic development potential.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The agreement provides for the gradual opening of the market for goods, services, procurement and investment, including the abolition of most tariffs. This will allow Ecuador to maintain preferential access to the EU market in a situation where Ecuador becomes ineligible due to the World Bank's classification as a higher-income country. At the same time, the economic situation in the country is quite complicated. In addition, the agreement includes a chapter on trade and sustainable development, which contains ambitious provisions in the field of employment and environmental protection, and which aims to ensure predictable and stable environmental conditions for investors and businesses on both sides. The agreement provides an opportunity for both sides to forge closer bilateral relations and give impetus to further economic and political integration in the Andean region. It also provides an opportunity to enhance the political dialogue between the EU and Ecuador, based on respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: written.- The Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru was signed on June 26, 2012. Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility of other member countries of the Andean Community joining the Agreement.That is why the Union and Ecuador finalized the negotiations for such accession on July 17, 2014. Ecuador is currently going through a very complicated economic situation to which is added the terrible earthquake that it recently suffered and that at the end of the year will lose its preferential statusSPG +.It is urgent that the Trade Agreement enters into force as soon as possible.The economic, collaborative and friendly relations between Ecuador and Spain have always been fruitful and my support for this recommendation is part of my wish that its effects extend to the Union.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012, and the European Parliament adopted a legislative resolution approving its conclusion. this agreement. On 20 November 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the agreement, welcoming the conclusion of the negotiations and encouraging the rapid and full entry into force and implementation of the agreement, considering that this would allow Ecuador to continue its new orientations regarding the stimulation of policies of sustainable economic and social development of the country, in a context of complex regional and international conditions. That is why the European Parliament, in its resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement, urged the Ecuadorian government to take into account the action plans submitted by Colombia and Peru and to take appropriate measures before the vote in the European Parliament on the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement. I therefore voted in favor of this report, which highlights the necessary amendments to the trade agreement to take account of Ecuador 's accession.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that the entry into force of the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia, Peru and Ecuador, on the other, will bring great economic benefits.Indeed, Ecuador is facing a difficult situation due both to the collapse of oil prices, by more than 60%, and to the appreciation of the dollar and the devaluation of the currency of other countries.In addition, the Ecuadorian people were severely damaged by an earthquake with a magnitude of 7.8% which caused 673 victims and 27 732 injured.All the more reason, as a politician, I believe that, in the light of the facts mentioned above, the entry into force of this trade agreement is very important for Ecuador.I therefore voted in favor

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this agreement because it provides for a better and more stringent system of information. This system will be based on reliable statistics on the trends of imports of bananas from the three countries to the EU. In particular, when the volume of these imports reaches 80% of the threshold, the Commission must inform the EP and the Council, giving them an analysis of the impact of these imports.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, is a major step forward in the EU's relations with Ecuador, which has become an important EU regional partner shares similar views. The agreement provides for the gradual opening of markets for goods, services, public procurement and investment, including the abolition of most customs duties. It therefore allows Ecuador to maintain preferential access to the EU market, despite not qualifying for the GSP + system since the World Bank ranked it among the higher middle-income countries. In addition, the agreement contains a chapter on trade and sustainable development, which includes ambitious provisions on the protection of workers and the environment, and seeks to ensure predictable and stable environmental conditions for investors and entities on both sides. The agreement will allow both parties to develop even closer bilateral relations and serve as a stimulus for further economic and political integration in the Andean region. It will also provide an opportunity to improve the EU's political dialogue with Ecuador based on respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights. I support this proposal because it contributes to better relations between the EU Member States and Ecuador.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Colombia and Peru provides for the accession of other Member States of the Andean Community, and in November 2015 the European Parliament adopted a Resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Agreement welcoming the conclusion of earlier negotiations strength that would encourage reform policies for economically and socially sustainable development. Ecuador is currently in a difficult economic situation and government revenues are insufficient for its financial needs. Amid falling oil prices and rising US dollars, Ecuador's total exports fell by 29% during 2015. In addition, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake hit the country this year, with reconstruction costs estimated at about $ 3 billion. Accession to the Agreement brings a number of necessary economic and political benefits and guarantees a commitment to respect and implement international treaties and agreements in the field of labor rights and environmental protection. I call on the relevant institutions to closely monitor the political situation and the state of fundamental rights in that country, as well as to report regularly to the European Parliament on the implementation of the agreement. The agreement will allow both parties to develop even closer bilateral relations and will also serve as an incentive for further integration in the Andean region.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation report proposes to extend to Ecuador the Trade Agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru. The initial objective was to establish an agreement with the countries of the Andean Community. In this phase, negotiations ended up being restricted to Colombia and Peru, since Ecuador and Bolivia resisted it and ended up abandoning it, denouncing the EU's intentions to conclude a free trade agreement, which oppose a trade vision for the development. Under enormous and growing pressure and interference in the region, this free trade agreement, contrary to the economic and social policies that the Ecuadorian government has carried out, serves as a blackmail weapon that aims, in particular, to destabilize the founding countries of Mercosur. The “free trade agreements”, of a neocolonial nature, aim at the privatization and exploitation of natural resources, the deregulation of the world of work and the conditioning of the economic and social policies of those countries. With this agreement, the major European economic groups in industry and services will win. The export sectors for machinery, automobiles (and other transport equipment) and chemicals. With service groups - telecommunications, construction, distribution and financial services - on the lookout for the opportunity to colonize yet another market.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the agreement on Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement that the European Union concluded in 2012 with two other Andean countries, Colombia and Peru. I consider this agreement to be an important step in deepening EU-Ecuador relations, which will facilitate the conditions for trade on both sides. This agreement will eliminate tariffs on all industrial and fishery products, increase market access for agricultural products, and improve access to public procurement and services. I firmly believe that Europe will benefit from this agreement, which will open up space for investment. In November 2015, the European Parliament welcomed the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador, supported the swift and full entry into force of the agreement, but called on Ecuador to step up its efforts to secure access to education, combat child labor and comprehensively respect women's rights. Whereas Ecuador has presented this year an action plan entitled "Overview of Ecuador's policies, achievements and actions to ensure well-being". I am pleased that Ecuador has made visible progress in fulfilling its commitments on labor law and human rights.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru was signed in Brussels on June 26, 2012 and some of its provisions are applied on the basis of Art. 330 of this agreement between the European Union and Peru from 1 March 2013 and between the European Union and Colombia from 1 August 2013. In Art. The 329 Trade Agreement foresees the possibility of accession to the Agreement of other Andean Community member states. On 17 July 2014, the European Union and Ecuador finalized their accession negotiations with the agreement. On December 31, 2016, Ecuador will lose its GSP + status. A situation where Ecuador could not benefit from GSP + status or the benefits of the trade agreement would disturb trade and be detrimental to the Ecuadorian economy. The agreement should be a step forward in an alliance with important, like-minded and fast-growing countries in a region that is increasingly looking towards Asia and the Pacific. I hereby support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the inclusion of Ecuador in the agreement already established with Colombia and Peru. But this vote almost did not take place. Indeed, with my colleagues Tokia Saïfi and Maurice Ponga, we fought until the last moment to obtain absolutely an agreement on the safeguard mechanisms for the banana sector. Ecuador is in fact the world's largest producer of bananas and we will give them preferential access to the European market. In this, our producers in the Antilles in particular need to be protected. Some wanted the deal at all costs, without waiting for what needs to be protected. It is not in my principles. As with any agreement, as long as I am sure that anything that needs to be protected is, I ratify it. There is no exception. But to get there, we had to mobilize the EPP, the only group to have fought so hard for the protection of this sector! France's voice has been heard and I now call for the vigilance of the banana sector.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012. It is an open agreement, in themeaning that Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility of accession by other member countries of the Andean Community.Ecuador's adherence to the Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru and its progressive and flexible application should constitute significant progress in the alliance with these countries, in full growth and with the same market sensitivity.This Protocol will allow the EU to increase and improve its relations with the countries of South America. In fact, with the inclusion of Ecuador in the said trade agreement, an environment favorable to the strengthening of ties is created, not onlyEcuador, but also among those Andean countries.Therefore, my vote is in favor.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs abstained on this, as it was a simple technical update to reflect the fact that Ecuador is now party to certain parts of this agreement. We did not feel a strong need to vote against this tidying up exercise

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing.- On 20 November 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement, in which it welcomes the conclusion of negotiations with Ecuador and encourages the swift entry into force and full implementation of this agreement, consideringthat it will allow Ecuador to pursue policies aimed at stimulating sustainable economic and social development in a difficult regional and international context.I remember that, economically, Ecuador is going through a difficult situation due to the sharp drop in oil prices of more than 60% (2015).In 2015, Ecuador's total exports fell by 29%, essentially due to a 50% decline in oil exports.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - I have supported the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement of the European Union with Colombia and Peru, with which the Union will give continuity to the tariff preferences that it has granted up to now and that, by rising to a middle-income country, would have lost in January weighing down the exports of which many people live in this country. We Socialists celebrate that this Agreement includes ambitious, unprecedented commitments between the Union and Ecuador, on sustainable development, human, labor and environmental rights, which should serve to promote fairer bilateral trade. In this sense, Ecuador has already been undertaking some good reforms, which under the Agreement must continue. We have also worked very intensively with Ecuador, to ensure that its export capacity in the banana sector does not harm European regions that, like the Canary Islands, are highly dependent on this crop. An Agreement that, without a doubt, will help to intensify and improve the relationship between Europe and Latin America, as we Spanish socialists defend. We will closely monitor compliance with the commitments and support Ecuador in its reforms, with all the Instruments available to the Union.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- Trade negotiations between the European Union and Colombia, Ecuador and Peru had started in January 2009. Negotiations with Ecuador were concluded on July 17, 2014. By joining this agreement, Ecuadorwill retain its preferential access to the European Union market, which it would have lost following a reform of the European system of preferences.I voted in favor of this recommendation which carries a vital agreement for the country's economy, which has been strongly affected by the fall in oil prices and exports and by the high costs associated with reconstruction after the earthquakethis year (as a reminder: a disaster that caused the death of 673 people and injured tens of thousands of others).

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Ecuador's accession to the tripartite EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement is a very welcome decision.This will undoubtedly help European producers to enter the South American market.At the same time, I would like to point out that the report under discussion also includes the necessary safeguards for European bananas.I am even a little jealous that other European agricultural sectors, such as potato growers, are not receiving as much attention from some right-wing groups.The only question is whether the translator should focus on bananas in the negotiations on the profits of a few remote island farms, especially if much more time and intellectual effort could be invested in improving the overall content of the treaty and linking its provisions more closely to human rights and freedoms in Ecuador.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this consent procedure, which aims to take into account Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other. Given the fact that the provisions of the trade agreement allow the accession of other member countries of the Andean Community (Ecuador and Bolivia), it is now intended that, with the completion of this process, Ecuador will be able to continue with its policies to stimulate growth and economic, social, labor and environmental development in a sustainable way. Ecuador is the largest exporter of bananas in the world, so its accession to the Agreement will have a relevant impact on Community producers, namely in the outermost regions, such as the Autonomous Region of Madeira, in Portugal. It is precisely for these reasons that I was very satisfied with the conclusion of the trilogue that same day and following the proposals presented by this Parliament, (amendment of regulations 19 and 20/2013), in order to ensure compensatory mechanisms / stabilization of the banana market more effective and that avoid unnecessary disruption risks in the European market, thus safeguarding the (relatively) precarious position of European producers in the outermost regions of Portugal, Spain and France.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text, which represents the ratification by the European Parliament of the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other hand, in order to take into account the accession of Ecuador. The deal will remove tariffs on many products and once fully implemented, it is estimated that EU exporters will save at least 106 million euros per year in tariffs. It should also be noted that around a hundred geographical indications from the EU will be protected in the Ecuadorian market. Nonetheless, we were concerned about the repercussions of this agreement on our European banana producers as Ecuador is the world's largest producer of bananas. Thus, we have ensured, by holding a trialogue the day before the agreement is ratified, that it will be accompanied by a safeguard clause and a stabilization mechanism for bananas. These arrangements will allow us to obtain better information and provide support to our producers in the event of market disruptions.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I have approved the accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement between the EU and its member states on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other.The accession of Ecuador helps the country in its development, as a large number of initiatives have been taken in the course of the accession negotiations to remove barriers to market access.Accession will also help to stabilize the economic relations based on the agreement and to deepen the integration of the Andean region.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have voted against the Adhesion of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia / Peru Multiparty Trade Agreement, understanding that there are no substantial changes in an Agreement that continues to be based on the logic of free trade, deregulation, privatization or the exploitation of resources natural. We opposed this EU-Colombia / Peru Agreement and we continue to reject it. Our model of relations are not Free Trade Agreements that do not take into account economic asymmetries and that only seek to open new markets and benefits to multinational companies, but agreements that are based on complementarity, cooperation, sustainable and sustainable development and whose central objective is to end inequalities. We reject the blackmail to which the Union subjects third countries through its current tariff policies and the conditioning of development cooperation funds, linked to the signing of Trade Agreements like this one. We support the Government of Ecuador in the policies it has carried out for the development of the "good living" model based on greater control by the State of strategic sectors of the economy, but we consider that social achievements would not have been possible under the logic that establishes this Agreement.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing.- Ecuador is currently facing a very difficult economic situation due to many factors, including the devaluation of the currencies of other neighboring countries, the collapse of oil prices, the appreciation of the dollar and the costs of reconstruction of approximately3.0% of GDP following the earthquake which in April caused at least 673 victims and nearly 28,000 injured.The accession of Ecuador to the trade agreement between the European Union with Colombia and Peru will allow this country to carry out new reforms in order to integrate into the world economy, consolidate growth, increase wellbeing and improveconsequently the living conditions of its citizens.I have therefore decided to vote in favor of the agreement.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, as I do not wish to see the EU manage our trade deals.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Protocol. This proposal establishes the necessary modifications to the Trade Agreement to take account of the accession of Ecuador.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I have chosen to abstain from this Report, and this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of Members of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia.representative action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - A trade agreement between the EU on the one hand and Colombia and Peru on the other has been in force since 2012. The agreement provides for the possibility of accession to other Member States of the Andean Community. I am pleased that the Union has succeeded in concluding negotiations on its accession to the agreement, because Ecuador is now in a complicated regional and international context. Economically, the country found itself in a difficult situation due to a large drop in oil prices, which fell by as much as 60% in 2015. The Ecuadorian economy is also negatively affected by the strengthening of the US dollar and the weakening of other currencies, such as the Colombian. Ecuador's total exports fell by 29% in 2015, due to insufficient revenue to cover the government's financial needs. In addition to economic problems, a devastating earthquake measuring 7.8 on the Richter scale hit the country this year. 673 people were killed, thousands injured and the Ecuadorian government estimates the cost of reconstruction at about $ 3 billion. That is why I supported Ecuador's accession to this trade agreement, as I believe that it could be a step forward for the country. However, in order to fulfill the commitments of the agreement in accordance with the principles of sustainable growth, it will be necessary to continuously monitor its fulfillment.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of the accession of Ecuador on behalf of the Union. The conclusion of this trade agreement would lead to the gradual opening of the market for goods, services, public procurement and investment between the EU and Ecuador and the abolition of all customs duties. I see the agreement, which will improve Ecuador's access to the EU market, as a tool to contribute to raising living standards in Ecuador, especially in view of the situation in Ecuador after the April 2016 earthquake, falling exports due to falling oil prices and the US dollar. I see Ecuador's commitments to the protection of employees and the protection of the environment associated with Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement as a positive contribution to the trade agreement. I also welcome the opening of dialogue for future economic and political integration, especially in view of the possible improvement in freedom of expression and the press in Ecuador, which was severely curtailed in 2013 following the adoption of the controversial media law.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - In 2012, the European Union and the 28 Member States concluded a trade agreement with Colombia and Peru. Ecuador now also wants to join this. The Ecuadorian government is feeling internal pressure from actors willing to join because of perceived economic benefits. The Greens are voting against, as we did when concluding an agreement with Colombia and Peru. It is absolutely no argument for us that the far-left rapporteur wants to support the left-wing government in Ecuador from an ideological point of view. What matters to us is that the civil society in Ecuador is against it. There is a broad front, ranging from environmental organizations to farmers' organizations, that expressly speaks out against this state of affairs. Environmental NGOs fear that accession will take a step backwards and go back to the exhaustion model, which will mainly affect indigenous people and smaller farmers. I certainly do not support such an economic model. So I voted against with conviction.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The European Union's trade with other countries not only brings new jobs and profits to our companies, but also helps to promote European standards.However, in the case of countries such as Ecuador, European trade diplomacy should go hand in hand with demands for democratic reforms and respect for human rights.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written.- The accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, represents a major step forward in the EU's relations with Ecuador.The agreement envisions opening markets for goods, services, government procurement and investment.In addition, the agreement contains a chapter on trade and sustainable development, which includes ambitious labor and environmental provisions, and aims to ensure predictable and stable conditions for investors.I support this agreement because it will increase the EU's presence in South America and complete the regional dimension of the Andean countries that are now linked to the Union.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of Ecuador's accession.I support Ecuador's accession to the EU-Colombia-Peru trade agreement, which will deepen relations between the two signatories and enable Ecuador to develop policies for sustainable economic and social development.Assuming regular assessments, of course, after consulting the Ecuadorian government and civil society.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- Once again, the EU intervenes in the interior of a third country in exchange for / promising the conclusion of a trade agreement.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012 and certain provisions of the Agreement were signed between the European Union and Peru on 1 March 2013 and between the European Union and Colombia since 1 August 2013. Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility for other members of the ANDEAN Community to accede to the Agreement. The European Union and Ecuador concluded accession negotiations on 17 July 2014. On 20 November 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement (2015/2656 (RSP)), urging the Ecuadorian Government to take similar measures on the basis of the action plans submitted by Colombia and Peru. The rapporteur visited Ecuador in March 2016. In view of the above, Parliament's assent is justified, but it is important to note that the monitoring and evaluation of existing agreements is a key priority of the common commercial policy. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament agreeing, on a proposal from the Council, to the signing of a protocol to the bilateral trade agreement between the EU and its Member States and Colombia and Peru, which will include Ecuador in Andean cooperation. I have considered the fact that this could provide indispensable support to the Ecuadorian economy, which is currently struggling with falling oil prices, which could also contribute to the stability of the precarious political situation in the country and the region as a whole. It is also a fact that due to changes in EU regulations, Ecuador will lose GSP preferences from the end of 2016, and without this bilateral agreement, the country’s trade would be in a difficult position while the country’s government is still struggling with the economic and financial consequences of this spring’s severe earthquake. From a political point of view, the agreement can also help to strengthen the bilateral dialogue and resolve the remaining problems from a European perspective, in particular the shortcomings of press freedom in Ecuador.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The accession of Ecuador to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other hand, is an important step in the development of relations between the EU and Ecuador, which has become an important like-minded regional partner. The agreement provides for a gradual opening of the market for goods, services, public procurement and investment, including the elimination of most tariffs. It therefore allows Ecuador to maintain preferential access to the EU market, although the country is no longer eligible for GSP + due to the fact that the World Bank has reclassified it as a higher-middle income country. In addition, the agreement includes a chapter on trade and sustainable development with ambitious labor and environmental protection provisions aimed at ensuring a predictable and stable environmental condition for investors and actors on both sides. The agreement will allow both sides to develop even closer bilateral relations and will be a source of impetus for further economic and political integration in the Andean region. It will also provide an opportunity to strengthen the political dialogue between the EU and Ecuador based on respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The European Union is one of the main proponents of free trade worldwide. In this context, the EU has in recent years concluded a number of free trade agreements with certain countries of the world with which it has common economic interests. Colombia and Peru are two of these states, with which the Commission signed those agreements in 2012, documents approved by the European Parliament. Also in November 2015, Parliament adopted a resolution on Ecuador's accession to this trade agreement, which would allow the Andean country to manage a complicated regional and international context, including lower oil prices, the appreciation of the US dollar, a 29% drop in total exports and revenues. of the Quito government. Moreover, on April 16, 2016, an earthquake with a magnitude of 7.8 affected Ecuador, resulting in 673 dead and 27,732 injured. After 31 December 2016, following the amendment of the EU regulation, Ecuador will lose its GSP + status. Under these conditions, it is necessary for the country's accession to the EU's Free Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru, which would reduce Ecuador's economic problems and help increase trade with this important region of the world. I believe that the recommendation should be adopted.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing.- We have approved Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other.We insist, however, that the monitoring, evaluation and follow-up of existing agreements must be a top priority of the common commercial policy and that the Commission has an obligation to inform Parliament of its activities regarding the implementation., monitoring and follow-up of this agreement, especially with regard to the obligations of sustainable development as underlined in the European Parliament resolution of 20 November 2015.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Negotiations for an EU trade agreement with the Andean countries started in 2009, and Colombia and Peru are the latest additions to the Agreement. The trade agreement allow all parties involved to develop closer bilateral relations and will serve as an impetus for further EU economic and political integration in the Andean region. The Agreement is also a way of enhancing the EU’s political dialogue with Ecuador and Colombia, based on the respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights. I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe both the EU and the Andean community will benefit from closer collaborative ties.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. - Unlike many trade agreements, this protocol for Ecuador's accession takes into account the country's specific development needs. Thus, he predicts that the Ecuadorian market will be open to 60% within 17 years, against 95% for the European market. This is an important step forward in the conception of the European Union's trade policy: to ensure fair trade that does not destroy the partner's economy. But this progress must not come at the expense of fragile European productions. By deepening the tariff dismantling of the banana trade, this agreement represents a risk of destabilization for the economy of the outermost regions of the EU (such as the French overseas departments). I am particularly attached to the defense of the economy of these territories, subject to unique social, environmental and regional factors. We must be vigilant about the repercussions that trade agreements can have on these territories. However, the safeguard clause to protect banana productions from falling prices, provided for in this type of agreement, is not automatic and far too long to put in place. Consequently, I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a Resolution on the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement (Accession of Ecuador"), given that the EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement was signed on 26 June 2012 and is in force.is from March 2013.Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility of accession by other states, and the EU and Ecuador conclude such negotiations on 17 July 2014.This agreement enables the European Union to benefit from its presence in South America, and the accession of Ecuador should create greater integration among existing partners.In this way, the European Union would take adequate action to prevent the negative trend of South American countries turning to Asia and the Pacific.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I supported the proposal to conclude a Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru, taking into account the accession of Ecuador, as I believe that the conclusion of this Protocol is progress in relations with very important countries in the Latin American region.The rapid and full entry into force of this agreement will enable Ecuador to continue the country's economic and socially sustainable development.In addition to developing closer bilateral relations and political dialogue, the agreement envisions the gradual opening of markets for goods, services, public procurement and investment, including the abolition of most tariffs.Due to the fall in oil prices and other economic circumstances and the earthquake in April, Ecuador is currently in a difficult economic situation.I believe that the implementation of this agreement will be of great benefit in the recovery and progress of its economy.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
