text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru, on the other hand, in order to take account of Ecuador's accession. The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed on 26 June 2012 in Brussels. Ecuador is currently in a very poor economic situation due to a sharp drop in oil prices of more than 60% and the overvaluation of the US dollar and the undervaluation of other currencies (Colombia). In April this year, Ecuador was shaken by a strong earthquake in which 672 people lost their lives and about 27,000 were injured. The cost of the renovation will cost them 3 billion, which will be an additional burden. At the end of the year, it will lose its status for the benefits of the trade agreement with the EU, which will have a negative impact on the economy. It would be advisable for Parliament to approve Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, as this is an important step forward in relations with Ecuador, which has become an important and like-minded regional partner.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- The Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru was signed in Brussels on June 26, 2012. The agreement should be a step forward in an alliance with important, world-class and fast-developing countries in a region that is increasingly turning to Asiaand the Pacific.The business relationship will bring a positive effect to each side, so I voted in favor of joining the agreement.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012.Article 329 of the Trade Agreement provides for the possibility for other Member States of the Andean Community to accede to the Agreement.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- It is undeniable that the drop in the price of oil and the rise in the dollar makes the economic and political situation in Ecuador difficult.In this context, the loss of tariff preferences threatens Ecuador's economy in the short term and also the electoral victory of the emancipatory project in February.However, although I understand the short-term interest of the Ecuadorian Government in obtaining the oxygen balloon that supposes the non-increase in tariffs on its exports, the Agreement contains harmful elements in the long term as it could lay the foundations for an unequal commercial relationship.Furthermore, with this agreement, the Union is promoting, once again, a system in which the foundations are laid for a trade for the benefit of the usual, which I will not defend under any circumstances.That is why I have voted against it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against the Ecuador accession for the main reasons my political group voted against the trade agreement in 2012, as the text has not changed. In addition, those sectors in the Ecuadorian Government which were responsible for the Ecuadoran ‘Buen Vivir’ model, as well as environmental NGOs, opposed this accession until today. With the FTA accession, indigenous people, small farmers, environmentalists and grassroots activists fear a return to the previous resource depletion model, while the ‘Buen Vivir’ model had guaranteed them better redistribution of wealth, access to schools and health systems and a strong decrease of poverty rates. These factors were highly praised by CEPAL (UN Economic Commission for Latin America). National researchers and activists saw the Ecuadorian model as a path to follow, which would lead away from dependence on mono-cultural exploitation. If they had voted in favour of the accession, it would have meant abandoning their support for the attempt to create a different economic model in a peripheral country. An additional strong argument against accession is that the agreement is fundamentally unchanged and is still open to tax dodging and money laundering. In the short run, export companies will win, of course. However, globally, labour rights in this sector are not said to be the best.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing.- Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, its gradual and flexible implementation, with the Commission at an early stage, in the light of periodic evaluations and in consultation with the Ecuadorian government and civil society on both sides, should be a step towards an alliance with important,fast-growing countries in a region seeking ever closer ties with Asia and the Pacific.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written.- We are talking about an agreement that has been voted in parallel to the safeguard clause and the stabilization mechanism for bananas.In this way, the commercial agreement will not only bring advantages in the economic sphere for the parties involved, but will also help prevent the threshold set for the agreement in relation to this product from being exceeded without measures being taken in this regard, sinceThe new mechanism will include an early warning system that will oblige the European Commission to formally alert Parliament and the Council in writing when the volume of banana imports reaches 80% of the planned import thresholds.For all these reasons, I think it appropriate to vote in their favor.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- Ecuador, together with Bolivia, has long worked for a new type of trade agreement that promotes sustainable development, redistribution and indigenous peoples' rights.This agreement means a return to an unfair and unsustainable trade where Ecuador becomes stuck in a dependence on raw material exports.The popular movements in Ecuador are critical.Therefore, we can not vote in favor of the agreement.At the same time, we want to respect an elected government in the south and do not choose to vote no either.We are voting blank this time.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I have voted against the Adhesion of Ecuador to the EU-Colombia / Peru Multiparty Trade Agreement, understanding that there are no substantial changes in an Agreement that continues to be based on the logic of free trade, deregulation, privatization or the exploitation of resources natural. We opposed this EU-Colombia / Peru Agreement and we continue to reject it. Our model of relations are not Free Trade Agreements that do not take into account economic asymmetries and that only seek to open new markets and benefits to multinational companies, but agreements that are based on complementarity, cooperation, sustainable and sustainable development and whose central objective is to end inequalities. We reject the blackmail to which the Union subjects third countries through its current tariff policies and the conditioning of development cooperation funds, linked to the signing of Trade Agreements like this one. We support the Government of Ecuador in the policies it has carried out for the development of the "good living" model based on greater control by the State of strategic sectors of the economy, but we consider that social achievements would not have been possible under the logic that establishes this Agreement.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor because Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other, is a significant step forward in relations with Ecuador, which has become an important, like-minded regional partner.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Ecuador will no longer benefit from the SPG + system as of December 31, 2016. In order not to lose the benefit of this customs preference, Ecuador had to resume negotiations on the free trade agreement that the EU has already passed to other countries of the Andean Community of Nations by putting them in competition while claiming the opposite. Ecuador had good reasons to leave the negotiating table in 2010. The country's ambition was to move from an economy based on the export of raw materials to a high value-added economy based on innovation and renewable energies. Not having its own currency, the country also had to retain substantial fiscal leeway. Blackmail and pressure, coupled with significant drops in oil prices, have overcome Ecuador’s resistance. I am fundamentally opposed to free trade agreements, I have serious doubts about the benefits Ecuadorians will derive from them in the long term. It is for these reasons that I have chosen to abstain as I have had the opportunity to do for similar situations.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The initial objective of this process was to establish an agreement with the countries of the Andean Community. In this phase, negotiations ended up being restricted to Colombia and Peru, since Ecuador and Bolivia resisted it and ended up abandoning it, denouncing the EU's intentions to conclude a free trade agreement, which oppose a trade vision for the development. This recommendation report proposes to extend to Ecuador and to approve the conclusion of the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other. Under enormous pressure and interference in the region, this free trade agreement, contrary to the economic and social policies that the Ecuadorian government has carried out, serves as a blackmail weapon that aims, in particular, to destabilize the founding countries of Mercosur. The “free trade agreements”, of a neocolonial nature, aim at the privatization and exploitation of natural resources, the deregulation of the world of work and the conditioning of the economic and social policies of those countries. We voted against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written. - The trade agreement between the EU and Colombia and Peru was signed in 2012 and has been in place with both countries since August and March 2013, respectively. Ecuador is now keen to accede to this agreement. This is all the more important now that the persistent weak oil price, which represents a good 60% of the country's exports, as well as the appreciation of the US dollar, which is used for business with the main export partners, are affecting the economy and government revenues. In addition, Ecuador will lose its GSP + standard in December 2016 and will therefore be significantly restricted in its ability to trade with the EU. The country exports goods worth around 12 billion US dollars, more than half of them to the USA; other main trading partners are South American countries. Since the economic consequences for the EU are negligible and the agreement actually has a symbolic value, I supported this report.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the report on the EU Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru (accession of Ecuador). The EU-Colombia-Peru Trade Agreement was signed in Brussels on 26 June 2012, and a number of provisions in the agreement have been applied. This trade agreement provides for the accession of other Member States of the Andean Community. On 17 July 2014, the European Union and Ecuador concluded negotiations for such accession. The rapporteur recommended that Parliament approve Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part. The report emphasizes that monitoring, evaluation and the measures taken following the agreements in force must be a key priority of the common commercial policy and that the Commission has an obligation to inform Parliament of its activities related to the implementation, monitoring and measures adopted in following this agreement, in particular as regards sustainable development obligations, as set out in the European Parliament resolution of 20 November 2015.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the recommendation on the conclusion of a Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru to take account of the accession of Ecuador.The possibility of the Andean Community acceding to this agreement has been possible and welcomed since its conclusion in 2012.Ecuador has expressed its willingness to accede to this agreement, and I consider this to be a very good step.The situation in Ecuador is not ideal after the fall in oil prices and the earthquake that struck it in April this year.In addition, at the end of 2016, Ecuador's preferential position under the GSP + Generalized System of Preferences will end.That is why I think that its accession to the Trade Agreement will be very helpful in such a situation, and I believe that it will help Ecuador to overcome the difficult economic period and motivate it to implement a new political direction towards sustainable economic and social development.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the Scholz report which provides for Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Colombia and Peru, on the other.I emphasize that the agreement will allow the parties to develop increasingly close bilateral relations and will stimulate the deepening of economic and political integration in the Andean region.The agreement provides for a gradual opening of the market in trade in goods, services, public procurement and investment, including the abolition of most customs duties.In addition, the agreement contains a chapter on trade and sustainable development, which includes ambitious labor and environmental protection provisions and aims to ensure a predictable and stable environment for investors and operators in the regions concerned.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support Helmut Scholz's recommendation that Ecuador be taken into account with regard to the Trade Agreement between the European Union, Colombia and Peru. This protocol was signed about a month ago in Brussels. The consent of the European Union on this case was still pending. Ecuador, as one socialist state, nevertheless had to adapt to Colombia and Peru, so that it eventually accepted most of the provisions adopted with the other two partners during the negotiations. Ecuador needed certain reforms to accede to this Agreement. I welcome Ecuador's efforts to be, along with Colombia and Peru, a member of this Agreement. Certainly this is another example of how a lot can be gained with effort and positive reforms. Therefore, Ecuador took the initiative and made progress, which the EU recognized. The global picture of this country shows that progress has been made in many areas, although some omissions, which is to be expected, still exist. Accession to Ecuador will bring great benefits to the integration of the countries of the Andean region.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Protocol of Accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Colombia and Peru, of the other part, to take account of Ecuador's accession.I support Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement with Colombia and Peru, as I believe that this will allow Ecuador to continue its new direction, namely to promote sustainable economic and social development policies.On the other hand, the EU will bring an alliance with a new trading partner with a promising fast-growing economy.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The agreement which is the subject of the following report allows access to the fishing areas in the Skagerrak for both Swedish and Danish and Norwegian vessels.As it represents a very important agreement that can almost be described as a historic event, I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report which emphasizes that access to the internal market of any third country must be based on reciprocity, and this in the case of Norway's customs duties on food products, including fish products, from theUnion must be in accordance with the Agreement of the European Economic Area.The report draws the attention of the Commission to forward to the European Parliament the minutes and the conclusions of the consultations, as well as a full report before opening the renewal of the negotiations.It also calls on both the Commission and the Council to keep the European Parliament fully informed immediately at all stages of the procedures related to the agreement and its renewal, as established in Article 13, paragraph 2 of the Treaty on European Union andArticle 218, paragraph 10 of the Treaty on the functioning of the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it implies consenting to a shared management agreement for the fishery resources located in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat.These two straits are what separate the waters of the Baltic from the waters of the North Sea, it is a fishing area where fishermen traditionally follow the schools of fish regardless of the border line of the countries involved.As it is a shared fishing area with Norway, the Union is responsible for the development of this type of agreement with third countries.As it is an agreement to allow traditional fishing methods and to respect principles of reciprocity and sustainability in these areas, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the EU-Norway reciprocal fishing opportunity in the Skagerrak. In the Kattegat and the Skagerrak, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together for the same stocks since the Middle Ages. The fact that two countries have become members of the EU has not changed the principle that fishermen from these three countries should enjoy historic fishing rights in the Skagerrak and Kattegat. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) provides a framework for managing fish stocks in the waters covered by that policy. Under this policy, the historic rights of fishermen are supported. This new agreement gives Danish, Norwegian and Swedish vessels the exclusive right to fish in their waters four nautical miles from the baselines. It ensures reciprocal access for the two EU Member States and Norway to the relevant waters of the other Contracting Parties in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat, while ensuring sound conservation and management measures in the area. It also allows for control measures to be applied to fishing in the North Sea in accordance with the principles of normal coastal State jurisdiction. I supported this agreement because it contributes to support for historic fishing rights in the area and will also be useful for the implementation of the improved CFP in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of an Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden, as it ensures that fishing vesselsvessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden operating in the area comply with the relevant laws and regulations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - On December 19, 1966, Denmark, Norway and Sweden signed an agreement concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat up to four nautical miles from their respective baselines. This agreement coexisted with the 1980 fisheries agreement between the EU and Norway. Following developments in fisheries law (1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and 1995 United Nations Fish Stocks Agreement), Norway denounced this agreement on July 29, 2009. Norway and the United Nations The EU signed a new agreement in 2015 on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas. The new agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring the implementation of measures of conservation and management of fisheries in this area. It also allows for the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State. So I voted for it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is legislative and talks heavily about the Common Fisheries Policy, which I oppose as I believe Member States should be in control of their own fishing waters. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text to give my approval to this new agreement between the European Union and Norway concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.Signed on January 15, 2015, it complies with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea as well as related provisions of other agreements concluded subsequently.Following the expiration of the previous existing agreement in 2012, it was necessary to introduce a new text to allow reciprocal agreement on fishing activities for Norway, Sweden and Denmark.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the recommendation on an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Under this agreement, the three countries had reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat up to four nautical miles from their respective baselines. The agreement was originally valid for 35 years, i. y. until 2002 and was subsequently extended for two five-year periods until 2012. However, Norway has terminated the agreement in the light of recent developments in international fisheries law. Norway recently entered into formal negotiations with the Commission, negotiating on behalf of the European Union, with a view to concluding an agreement on reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat, which would replace the previous agreement. As the new agreement is in line with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and subsequent related provisions of other agreements, I support this agreement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- Following the denunciation of the previous agreement, Norway and the European Union signed a new agreement on January 15, 2015 concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas.The new agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned - Denmark and Sweden - and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring theimplementing measures for the conservation and management of fisheries in this area.It also allows for the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State.Since it is only a matter of approving this deal on behalf of the Union, I voted for it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I approved this recommendation which proposes to renew the old agreements concerning reciprocal access to the fishing activities of Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the area of Skagerrak while ensuring the implementation of conservation measures andadequate management of fisheries in this area.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- The Skagerrak maritime zone has traditionally been a shared fishing area between Norway, Denmark and Sweden.I have voted in favor of continuing reciprocal access for these countries.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Many maritime areas of Europe retain a tradition prior to the creation of states and the recognition of territorial waters and EEZs for which fishermen carry out their activity in the waters where certain stocks and fish species are found, and follow them during migrations. The Kattegat and the Skagerrak are a typical example of this condition; realities that have seen Swedes, Danes and Norwegians fishing together in the same waters for centuries. On 15 January 2015, a new agreement was signed between the EU and Norway which replaces a previous 1966 international treaty between Denmark, Sweden and Norway on access to the fishing grounds of the Skagerrak. It is of the utmost importance that these historic fishing rights are respected; for this reason I have decided to vote in favor of the recommendation presented in Parliament today. Indeed, the agreement guarantees the support of historical fishing rights in this area, complies with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and related provisions, and represents above all a useful tool for the implementation of the reformed CFP in the Kattegat and in the Skagerrak.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the report to the extent that for centuries Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together in these waters and species.Accession to the Union must not affect your historical fishing rights in your historical fishing grounds.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I supported this report on the EU Agreement with Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak, in which I was the shadow rapporteur for my group.The Agreement contributes to supporting the historic fishing rights in this area and will also be beneficial for the implementation of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as it accredits the agreement that EU Member States and Norway will have reciprocal access to each party's respective waters in the Skagerrak area.The agreement also provides for conservation and management measures for sustainable fishing in this area.This agreement is also in line with that of December 19, 1966 between Denmark, Sweden and Norway.This new agreement is only a bringing into conformity, following the accession of Denmark and Sweden to the EU but above all to the new standards of international law in the matter, in particular concerning the rights of the sea and stocks.of fish.Finally, the new agreement will allow for the adoption of control measures consistent with the principles of normal coastal state jurisdiction.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The Skagerrak and the Kattegat are two natural channels that connect the North Sea with the Baltic Sea.In these two sea areas Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together since the Middle Ages.I believe it is important that these historic fishing rights are respected, despite Norway being not an EU Member State.That is why I have come out in favor of the report.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Recommendation for the conclusion of the Agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for Danish, Norwegian or Swedish vessels.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation on the EU-Norway agreement on reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak. Denmark, Norway and Sweden in 1966 The Agreement on reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat entered into force in 1967. Under that agreement, concluded in 1980. complemented by a bilateral fisheries agreement between the European Union and Norway, the three countries had reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat up to four nautical miles from their respective baselines. In addition, the agreement provides that the area is to be considered as international waters for the purposes of such fishing. The agreement thus regulated relations between flag states and coastal states. In the light of recent developments in international fisheries law and, in particular, since the entry into force of the 1982 Act, UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and 1995 UN Fish Stocks Agreement, Norway has ruled that the current agreement does not comply with current provisions of the law of the sea. Norway was most concerned about the control provisions. In addition, in its view, the agreement did not comply with the principles of normal coastal State jurisdiction under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and the current principles of conservation and management. The new agreement gives Danish, Norwegian and Swedish vessels the exclusive right to fish in their waters four nautical miles from the baselines.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Report on the EU-Norway Agreement to ensure the continuation of reciprocal access to fishing by vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden for the conservation and sustainable use of the living resources in the Skagerrak.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. This new Agreement was signed on 15 January 2015 and conforms with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea as well as subsequent related provisions in other agreements.  It continues the exclusive reciprocal access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, whilst at the same time ensuring conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. For centuries, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have together fished in these waters for the same stocks. Their historical right to fish in the areas concerned should be respected.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing.- I fully support this agreement, which is in accordance with the 1980 bilateral fisheries agreement, the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the objectives of the CFP.Indeed, the agreement ensures that fishing vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden comply with the laws, regulations and control and enforcement measures for the conservation and sustainable use of biological resources in the Skagerrak.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing.- In December 1966, Denmark, Norway and Sweden signed an agreement allowing reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat up to four nautical miles from their baselines.Agreement which was necessary in view of the confluence of national laws as well as for practical reasons.Following the accession of Denmark and Sweden to the European Union in 1973 and 1995, the management of this agreement on behalf of the two Member States fell to the Commission.The new agreement in question aims to take into account changes in international law as well as to guarantee reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and Norway to the respective waters of the other parties.This new agreement will also help to protect fishery resources in this area.That’s why I voted in favor of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The 1966 Agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak and Kattegat and the 1980 bilateral agreement on fishing between the European Union and Norway provide for reciprocal access between the three countries to fish up to 4 nautical miles from fishing lines. their base in the Skagerrak and Kattegat. The existing agreement was considered inconsistent with current provisions of the law of the sea, given the more recent developments in international fisheries law and, in particular, with the introduction of the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. As a result, Norway has expressed concern about the control provisions, but also about the principles of conservation and management, which no longer correspond to current needs. Thus, this project aims to support the historical fishing rights in this area and, at the same time, to ensure an efficient and sustainable fish stock management system, which is why I have spoken out in favor of this initiative.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report which emphasizes that access to the internal market of any third country must be based on reciprocity, and this in the case of Norway's customs duties on food products, including fish products, from theUnion must be in accordance with the Agreement of the European Economic Area.The report draws the attention of the Commission to forward to the European Parliament the minutes and the conclusions of the consultations, as well as a full report before opening the renewal of the negotiations.It also calls on both the Commission and the Council to keep the European Parliament fully informed immediately at all stages of the procedures related to the agreement and its renewal, as established in Article 13, paragraph 2 of the Treaty on European Union andArticle 218, paragraph 10 of the Treaty on the functioning of the Union.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access for vessels flying the flags of Denmark, Norway and Sweden to fishing activities in the Skagerrak. In view of developments in international fisheries law, the 1966 agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden, completed in 1980 by an EU-Norway agreement, was brought into conformity with the United Nations conventions on the law of the sea. A new agreement was therefore signed on January 15, 2015. This new agreement maintains the exclusive access enjoyed by vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to the respective waters of these States beyond four nautical miles from the lines of based. It guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the area of ​​Skagerrak and Kattegat, while ensuring the implementation of measures for the conservation and management of fisheries. in this area.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the recommendation approving the renewal of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fishing grounds in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the Danish, Norwegian and Swedish flags. In fact, an agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to fishing areas in the Skagerrak and Kattegat has already been in place since 1967. However, this agreement, in the face of the most recent developments in international fisheries law and, in particular, following the adoption of the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Stocks, it no longer complies with the current provisions of the law of the sea, and therefore a new understanding was necessary. The new arrangement will continue to grant ships from Denmark, Norway and Sweden exclusive access to their respective waters beyond 4 nautical miles from the baselines.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This new Agreement was signed on 15 January 2015 and conforms with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea as well as subsequent related provisions in other agreements.  It continues the exclusive reciprocal access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, whilst at the same time ensuring conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. For centuries, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have together fished in these waters for the same stocks. Their historical right to fish in the areas concerned should be respected.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose legislation which extends the discredited, unreformable common fisheries policy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. It maintains the exclusive access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles from the baselines; ensures continued reciprocal access for the two Member States and Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, whilst at the same time, ensuring sound conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area; and allows for control measures in harmony with the principles of normal coastal state jurisdiction, as it is already the case for fisheries in the North Sea.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- With the accession of Denmark (1973) and Sweden (1995) to the EU, the European Commission became responsible for managing the agreement on behalf of these two Member States.This is a truly historic fishing agreement: Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished the same fish stocks together in these waters at least since the Middle Ages.Norway has held formal negotiations with the European Commission.I therefore voted in favor of the agreement.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. - The agreement, which guarantees Sweden, Denmark and Norway the continuity of reciprocal access to their respective waters in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, has the merit of regulating fisheries in the area by means of certain conservation measures and effective instruments of joint management. In addition, the agreement will make it possible to have control measures that comply with the principles of the normal jurisdiction of coastal states, as is already the case for fishing in the North Sea. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together in these waters since at least the Middle Ages. The fact that two of the countries have become EU Member States has not changed the principle that their fishermen should enjoy historical fishing rights in the waters of the Skagerrak and the Kattegat. I believe it is important that these historic fishing rights are respected: our internal market is based on the principle of reciprocity and fair competition. I therefore believe that the agreement under consideration is in line with these principles and useful for the implementation of the EU's common fisheries policy. For these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the agreement, which supports historic fishing rights in this area and will be beneficial for the implementation of the revised CFP in the Kattegat and Skagerrak area.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of an Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden is a reasonable and legitimate effort to findcommonly accepted solutions in the field of fisheries and trade, with the aim of cooperating all parties involved for the benefit of the citizens, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the agreement concluded between the European Union and Norway to define as clearly as possible mutual access to the fishing areas in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat. In fact, these are areas in which the waters of the North Sea mix with the less saline ones of the Baltic Sea, thus producing a favorable habitat for numerous marine species and making it a very fishy area. Therefore, it is essential to ensure exclusive access for Danish, Swedish and Norwegian vessels to their respective waters beyond 4 nautical miles from the baselines. Together with this, the continuity of mutual access to the respective waters of the other parts in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat must in any case be affirmed and respected in full compliance with the historical fishing rights in the aforementioned areas 1966 and included only three articles, the first of which defined the area in question, while the second defined access rights and the will to harmonize technical regulations).

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the EU-Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose legislation which extends the discredited, unreformable common fisheries policy.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the agreement defining mutual access to fishing areas in the Skagerrak and Kattegat as it contributes to jointly regulating this important sector in the territorial waters of Denmark, Sweden and Norway.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it involves consenting to a shared management agreement for the fishery resources located in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat.These two straits are what separate the waters of the Baltic from the waters of the North Sea, it is a fishing area where fishermen traditionally follow the schools of fish regardless of the border line of the countries involved.As it is a shared fishing area with Norway, the Union is responsible for the development of this type of agreement with third countries.As it is an agreement to allow traditional fishing methods and to respect principles of reciprocity and sustainability in these areas, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up.- There has been an agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden since 1966 on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak and Kattegat.In view of the latest developments in international fisheries law, Norway has considered that the existing agreement is not in line with current provisions of the law of the sea.It is particularly concerned about the control provisions.This new agreement maintains exclusive reciprocal access to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden, while ensuring effective conservation and management measures in the fisheries sector.I voted in favor of respecting the historic right to fish in these waters, even though only two of these countries have become EU Member States.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fisheries in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I believe that the update of the agreement is necessary to reflect the situation in the field of international fisheries law.The agreement provides for the promotion of conservation and management measures for the fishery resources in the area and for the possibility to apply control measures in line with the normal jurisdiction of the coastal state.The report on this agreement aims to promote a political declaration reminding Norway that any customs duties on food products, including fishery products, with the EU must be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this agreement, which builds on the historical fishing rights of fishermen from Norway, Denmark and Sweden without prejudices to the rights of fishermen in other states. I support the implementation of a reformed system for fisheries management in the EU in line with the common fisheries policy.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this report which aims to promote a political statement reminding Norway that any customs duties on food products (including fisheries products) from the EU must conform to the EEA Agreement.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This non-legislative report concerns reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak, a strait between southern Norway, south-eastern Sweden and north-western Denmark.Norway, a non-member of the European Union, has entered into formal negotiations with the European Commission with a view to obtaining reciprocal access to this highly prized fishing area, also exploited by Sweden and Denmark, members of theUnion.The agreement includes provisions for the sustainable management of fisheries in this area and control measures in harmony with the principles of coastal State jurisdiction.Considering that this agreement ensures the reasoned exploitation and sustainable management of fish stocks in this international fishing zone and that it will offer new opportunities to European fishermen, I voted in favor of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose legislation which extends the discredited, unreformable common fisheries policy.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.Denmark, Sweden and Norway share a maritime space in which they can develop their fishing activities.On the occasion of the renewed discussions concerning the sharing of these areas (Skagerrak and Kattegat), Norway and the European Union have decided to modernize their cooperation with this new agreement applying only in the Skagerrak.This maintains the provisions for sharing access to these areas enshrined in previous agreements, but also allows the adoption of more modern and effective control measures.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.On December 19, 1966, Denmark, Norway and Sweden signed an agreement concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat up to 4 nautical miles from their respective baselines.Extended from 2002, the agreement was denounced by Norway on July 29, 2009, because it had become unsuitable, in particular with regard to the adoption of the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the United Nations.1995 United Nations agreement on fish stocks.A new European agreement was therefore signed on January 15, 2015. This new agreement is balanced and guarantees reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties.It also makes it possible to adopt coastal control measures.We are therefore in favor of it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form.- I supported Mr Dorman's report on the resolution on the EU-Norway agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak, as he emphasized that Norway must comply with and not impose food duties (includingfishery products) from the EU which do not comply with the Agreement on the European Economic Area.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We are voting against the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fisheries in Skagerrak for Danish, Norwegian and Swedish-flagged vessels, as the report emphasizes that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that in the case of Norway any customs duties on foodstuffs, including fishery products, from the EU must comply with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. However, the Agreement on the European Economic Area adopts provisions in the areas of free movement of persons, goods, services and capital. The EU and two of its EEA partners - Norway and Iceland - are also linked to a number of "northern policies" and through forums focusing on the rapidly evolving northern regions of Europe and the Arctic region as a whole. Bilateral relations have been severely tested since the anti-immigration initiative of February 2014, the outcome of which called into question the principles of free movement and the single market on which these relations are based.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the EU-Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak. The agreement retains the exclusive access to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles from the baselines. It is important to my constituents in Wales that the fisheries of the European Union are managed effectively.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- This new agreement maintains the exclusive access granted reciprocally to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to the waters of each of the three countries located outside the limit of four nautical miles measured from the baselines.Traditionally, fishermen do not exercise their activity in certain waters.Kattegat and Skagerrak are typical examples of this.Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together for the same fish populations in these waters since at least the Middle Ages.The fact that two of these countries have become Member States does not alter the principle that fishermen in these three countries should enjoy the historic rights to fish in Skagerrak and Kattegat.The EU's common fisheries policy establishes a system for the management of fish stocks in the waters it covers and thus supports the historic rights of fishermen.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote for: the agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring theimplementation of conservation and fisheries management measures in this area.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation aims to update the agreement on reciprocal access to fishing activities in Skagerrak and Kattegat, between Denmark, Norway and Sweden. This agreement is dated 1966, before Denmark and Sweden became members of the EU. The update, proposed by Norway, aims to bring the old agreement into line with the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Populations, namely in terms of control, or maritime conservation and management issues. This agreement, with the respective updates, contributes to reinforce the historical rights of fishermen in the region, regardless of their nationality, considering that the fishing springs do not know administrative jurisdictions and that fishing activity depends on access to resources. Involving two EU Member States and a third country, this agreement would not have to be the subject of any decision by the EU (European Parliament and Council), should it not be the case that, under the institutional framework given by the Lisbon Treaty, management of living marine resources has become an exclusive competence of the EU. We voted in favor. We reiterate, however, our disagreement with the aforementioned institutional framework.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this recommendation as I believe that the new agreement grants ships from Denmark, Norway and Sweden exclusive access to their respective waters beyond 4 nautical miles from the baselines.It also ensures that the two Member States and Norway have continuity of mutual access to the respective waters of the other parts in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat, while allowing fisheries in the area to be regulated by means of certain conservation and management measures.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- It is very important that European vessels continue to be given access to the Skagerrak, thus continuing the agreement that the European Union and Norway have had for decades.The new agreement provides exclusive access to the areas for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden.The agreement in question benefits all parties and is in line with agreements that have been in force for more than 35 years.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor, it is important that some historical fishing rights are respected.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for Danish, Norwegian and Swedish-flagged vessels, as the report emphasizes that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that in the case of Norway any customs duties on foodstuffs, including fishery products, from the EU must comply with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. However, the Agreement on the European Economic Area adopts provisions in the areas of free movement of persons, goods, services and capital. The EU and two of its EEA partners - Norway and Iceland - are also linked to a number of "northern policies" and through forums focusing on the rapidly evolving northern regions of Europe and the Arctic region as a whole. Bilateral relations have been severely tested since the anti-immigration initiative of February 2014, the outcome of which called into question the principles of free movement and the single market on which these relations are based.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The new Agreement maintains the exclusive access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles from the baselines. It ensures continued reciprocal access for the two Member States and Norway to the respective waters of the other Parties in the Skagerrak area, whilst at the same time ensuring sound conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. Furthermore, it allows for control measures in harmony with the principles of normal Coastal State jurisdiction, as is already the case for fisheries in the North Sea. I fully support this Agreement, which is in conformity with the 1980 bilateral fisheries agreement, with UNCLOS and with the objectives of the CFP. It ensures that fishing vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden operating in the area comply with the relevant laws, regulations and control and enforcement measures for the conservation and sustainable use of the living resources in the Skagerrak.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fishing areas in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the Danish, Norwegian and Swedish flags, becauseit is a vote that allows us to continue a centuries-old practice of fisheries cooperation in force in the Scandinavian countries well before the creation of the European Community.It is a technical vote that allows to adapt the previous agreements in force to the new developments of the international law of the sea and the rules on fishing, modernizing the previous texts as desired by Norway but at the same time safeguarding the traditions present in the two territories of the Skagerrak andof the Kattegat.I therefore wholeheartedly support the position expressed unanimously by the Committee on Fisheries and Maritime Affairs.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- With the new agreement, ships from Denmark, Norway and Sweden have exclusive access to the other waters outside the four-mile zone from the baselines.It continues to ensure mutual access between the two EU Member States and Norway to the respective waters of the other contracting parties in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas, while at the same time ensuring appropriate conservation and management measures for the fisheries in the area.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose legislation which extends the discredited, impossible to reform common fisheries policy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I supported this proposal, which is replacing a previous agreement that is not in conformity with international laws (Law of the Sea and UN Fish Stock Regulation). It is based on historical rights and will grant Member State access to Norwegian waters and reciprocal access for Norway for Danish and Swedish waters, up to four nautical miles from baselines in Skagerrak.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the new agreement on fishing activities in the Skagerrak, a fishing area between the North Sea and the Baltic Sea. This agreement concerns two Member States, Denmark and Sweden, and a third State, Norway. It extends a 1966 convention, made necessary for practical reasons because this very limited area is at the confluence of the maritime areas of these States. Norway denounced this old convention in order to sign a new agreement better adapted to developments in fisheries law. Indeed, the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Stocks have changed the situation. The new agreement guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and Norway to their respective waters in the Skagerrak area. It also allows the implementation of conservation and fisheries management measures in this area. Finally, it makes it possible to adopt control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the report to the extent that for centuries Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together in these waters and species.Accession to the Union must not affect your historical fishing rights in your historical fishing grounds.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report which emphasizes that access to the internal market of any third country must be based on reciprocity, and this in the case of Norway's customs duties on food products, including fish products, from theUnion must be in accordance with the Agreement of the European Economic Area.The report draws the attention of the Commission to forward to the European Parliament the minutes and the conclusions of the consultations, as well as a full report before opening the renewal of the negotiations.It also calls on both the Commission and the Council to keep the European Parliament fully informed immediately at all stages of the procedures related to the agreement and its renewal, as established in Article 13, paragraph 2 of the Treaty on European Union andArticle 218, paragraph 10 of the Treaty on the functioning of the Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Traditionally, fishermen do not fish in specific waters: they catch specific stocks or species and fish in waters to which those stocks or species are found and also follow migratory species. This tradition preceded the creation of states and the recognition of territorial waters and - much later - exclusive economic zones. The Kattegat and Skagerrak area is a prime example. At least since medieval times, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been active in these waters together, aiming for the same stocks. The fact that two of these countries became Member States has not affected the principle that fishermen in the three countries have the historic right to fish in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas. Respect for this historic right is of the utmost importance. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy provides for a system of managing fish stocks in waters covered by it and in its own way supports the historical rights of fishermen. The agreement also supports historic fishing rights in the area and will be beneficial for the implementation of the revised CFP in the Kattegat and Skagerrak areas. We therefore voted in favor of the report so that the agreement can be approved.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Agreement adds to the support of the historical fishing rights in this area and will also be beneficial for the implementation of the reformed CFP in the Kattegat and Skagerrak. Therefore I supported this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report with a view to ensuring reciprocal access to the Skagerrak for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden for the conservation and sustainable use of living resources.The report emphasizes that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that, in the case of Norway, any customs duties on food, including EU fishery products, must be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Sweden and Norway.The Agreement is in line with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and supports historical fishing rights in the area.Also, mutual access to waters in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas and clear conservation and management measures for fishing are guaranteed, and I therefore support this Recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- This new agreement is more suitable in terms of international law as well as in a more practical sense, guaranteeing reciprocal access of the three States to the maritime areas of Skagerrak and Kattegat and ensuring the proper conduct of conservation measures.and management of fishing activities.Finally, the agreement respects the jurisdiction of each coastal state and their control measures.I voted for.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Jorn Dohrmann on the agreement on fishing activities in the Skagerrak.This agreement guarantees access for the Member States for fishing activities in the area.It replaces the agreement signed by Norway and the European Union in 1980. The Skagerrak is a very important maritime area that links the North Sea and the Baltic Sea.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this proposal, which is replacing a previous agreement not in conformity with international laws (Law of the Sea and UN Fish Stock Regulation). It is based on historical rights and will grant Member State access to Norwegian waters and reciprocal access for Norway for Danish and Swedish waters up to four nautical miles from baselines in Skagerrak.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing.- Legislation on fishing activities is a success story between both EU and UN regulations.Indeed, decades of evidence have shown that it has succeeded in ensuring the conservation of marine fish stocks in a sustainable way, while at the same time supplying the EU internal market with sufficient and good quality fish products.This report, which is clearly to be supported, will help to maintain balanced fisheries management in the future in relation to Scandinavia.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing.- The emerging agreement between the EU and Norway aims to define mutual access to the fishing areas in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat.The agreement guarantees the vessels of Denmark, Norway and Sweden to have access exclusively to waters beyond 4 nautical miles, also guaranteeing the two Member States and Norway the continuity of mutual access to their respective waters, always respecting historical rights.fishing in this area.Usually, fishermen do not fish in these waters, but they fish certain fish stocks or certain species, in the waters in which these stocks or species are found.This is a tradition prior to the creation of states and the recognition of territorial waters and exclusive economic zones.In light of the above, I believe that this report should be supported.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted for the report on the agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak. On December 19, 1966, Denmark, Norway and Sweden signed an agreement concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat up to four nautical miles from their respective baselines. Following developments in fisheries law, particularly after the adoption of the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Stocks, Norway denounced this agreement. on July 29, 2009. It therefore expired on August 7, 2012. The new agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring the implementation of conservation and fisheries management measures in this area. It also allows for the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I consider it to be an environmentally sustainable and fair deal for Scandinavian fishing vessels operating in the Skagerrak.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written.- The new Agreement on Reciprocal Access to Fishing in the Skagerrak and Kattegat replaces the 1966 Agreement, which had been extended until 2012. The previous Agreement, according to Norway, did not comply with the current provisions of the Law of the Sea, nor with theprinciples of the normal jurisdiction of the coastal State, nor to modern principles of conservation and management.All this was taken into account in the negotiations between the Commission and Norway, which concluded in this Agreement that, in addition to complying with the aforementioned provisions and principles, it maintains exclusive access to Danish, Norwegian and Swedish vessels to the mostbeyond four nautical miles from the baselines, respecting the historical fishing rights in this area.I support the Agreement because it will benefit the Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I stayed.This agreement concerns the access of fishing vessels of Norway, Denmark and Sweden to the Skagerrak and Kattegat.I consider it a matter for Denmark and Sweden, so I refrained.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written.- Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area between Denmark, Norway and Sweden entered into force in 1967. This agreement, supplemented by a bilateral fisheries agreement between the European Union and Norway in 1980, provided reciprocal access to fisheries for the three countries.within an area of up to four nautical miles from their starting lines in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area.This agreement further supports the historical fishing rights in the area and will be useful for the implementation of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy in the Kattegat and Skagerrak area.Having regard to the recommendation of the Committee on Fisheries, Parliament agreed to conclude this Agreement.I therefore supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Norway agreement on the Skagerrak, allowing fishing vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to fish in each other’s waters, has been updated. The new agreement, aimed at bringing fisheries management in the Skagerrak into line with international principles of coastal state jurisdiction, was signed in January 2015 and has been applied provisionally pending its entry into force. Parliament gave consent for the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- I support the consent to the conclusion of this agreement, which replaces the original 1980 EU-Norway agreement. The agreement is in line with the current international maritime law.It ensures the continuation of the historically reciprocal approach to fisheries of the two Member States of the European Union, Denmark and Sweden, with Norway in the Skagerrak and Kattegat, with regard to the protection, management and control of fisheries in those areas.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of an Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden, as it is incomplete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.This report concerns the approval of the agreement between Norway and the European Union on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat.The agreement signed by the European Commission and Norway is an update of previously existing fisheries agreements between Norway and the European Community and between Norway and other Scandinavian countries.This new agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of the reciprocal access of Sweden, Denmark and Norway to water, in the area of Skagerrak and Kattegat.It also ensures the implementation of conservation and fisheries management measures in this area.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted positively on the report on the EU—Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak. On one hand, the report further enhances the relationship between Flag and Coastal States. At the same time, supporting the agreement represents ensuring reciprocal access by the Scandinavian countries while procuring fishery conservation and efficient management. From the early years, fishermen have been able to enjoy fishing in Kattegat and Skagerrak. Therefore, supporting the agreement represents respect for the historical rights to fish that fishermen have been enjoying since medieval times.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: written.- I support the agreement and agree with the position of the rapporteur Jørn Dohrmann, because the agreement contributes to supporting the historical fishing rights in this area and will also be beneficial for the implementation of the reformed common fisheries policy in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I am in favor of the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden, because since the Middle Ages, Swedes, Danes and Norwegian fishermen jointly operate in these waters with a view to the same stocks. The fact that two of these countries became Member States has not affected the principle that fishermen in the three countries have the historic right to fish in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas. Respect for this historic right is of the utmost importance. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy provides for a system of managing fish stocks in waters covered by it and in its own way supports the historical rights of fishermen. The agreement also supports historic fishing rights in the area and will be beneficial for the implementation of the revised CFP in the Kattegat and Skagerrak areas.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This resolution approves the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway concerning the reciprocal access of vessels flying the flags of Denmark, Norway and Sweden to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.It emphasizes in particular the better taking into account of the objectives of sustainable management of fisheries with the introduction of "the obligation to land and the maintenance of stocks above the levels which allow the maximum sustainable yield to be achieved".I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. - On December 19, 1966, Denmark, Norway and Sweden signed an agreement concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat. This 35-year agreement was extended for two five-year periods until 2012 and could be terminated by either party with three years' notice before the expiration date of one of the two periods. five years. Following the denunciation of the agreement by Norway, a new agreement was signed on January 15, 2015 with the European Union. This agreement, adapted to changes in international law, guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring the conservation and management measures of fishing in this area and also allows the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State. So I voted for this agreement.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I welcome the approval given by the European Parliament to the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and Norway on historic access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.This is a fishing area in which both Norwegian, Danish and Swedish fishermen are active.This agreement replaces an earlier agreement on reciprocal access to fishing activities in this area and respects historic fishing rights in these waters.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this agreement, which calls to continue a reciprocal access of vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden for the conservation and sustainable use of the living resources in the Skagerrak. The report also emphasises that access to the internal market for any third country must build on reciprocity, and that in the case of Norway any customs duties on food products, including fisheries products, from the EU must be in conformity with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. Furthermore, it stresses that the task of the Commission is to ensure that customs duties on food and fisheries products from the EU are not set in a way contrary to the principles of free trade in the area of food products, including fisheries products.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to the Skagerrak and Kattegat, which entered into force on 7 August 1967, recognized that fishing rights in this area have traditionally been granted to fishermen from these three countries. Denmark joined the EU in 1973 and Sweden in 1995, making the Commission responsible for administering the agreement in respect of these two Member States. In the light of recent developments in international fisheries law, in particular the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Fish Stocks Agreement, Norway has considered that the existing agreement does not comply with the provisions of the Convention on the Law of the Sea. with effect from 7 August, but entered into formal negotiations with the Commission with a view to drawing up a new agreement. The new agreement was signed on 15 January 2015. The Council has drawn up a draft decision on the ratification of the agreement, the adoption of which requires the consent of Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Fisheries proposes that Parliament agree to the conclusion of the agreement. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- Following the denunciation of the previous agreement, Norway and the European Union signed a new agreement on January 15, 2015 concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas.It is simply a matter of approving this deal on behalf of the Union.The new agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring the implementation of measures ofconservation and management of fisheries in this area.It also allows for the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State.Favorable vote.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- This new agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring the implementation of measuresconservation and management of fisheries in this area.It also allows for the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State.I therefore vote in favor.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which is is based on historical rights and will grant Member State access to Norwegian waters and reciprocal access for Norway for Danish and Swedish waters up to four nautical miles from baselines in Skagerrak.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text which approves the fishing agreement with Norway on access to the waters of the Skagerrak.The agreement maintains the exclusive access enjoyed by vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to the respective waters of those states beyond 4 nautical miles from the baselines.It guarantees the maintenance of the reciprocal access of these States to the waters of the other parties in the area of Skagerrak and Kattegat, while ensuring the implementation of sound conservation and management measures.Finally, it allows the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal state, as in the case of the North Sea fisheries.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 7 August 1967, an agreement on reciprocal fishing access in the Skagerrak area between Denmark, Norway and Sweden entered into force. Following Denmark’s and Sweden’s accession to the EU, the Commission became responsible for the management of this Agreement on behalf of these two Member States. I have voted for this recommendation regarding the renewal of this agreement.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.The EU's Common Fisheries Policy has established a system for managing the fish stocks in the waters within its scope, thereby supporting fishermen's historic rights.The agreement further supports the historical fishing rights in the region and will also benefit from the implementation of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. Traditionally, fishermen do not fish in specific waters: they catch specific stocks or species and fish in waters to which those stocks or species are found and also follow migratory species.
