This tradition preceded the creation of states and the recognition of territorial waters and - much later - exclusive economic zones. The Kattegat and Skagerrak area is a prime example. At least since medieval times, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been active in these waters together, aiming for the same stocks. The fact that two of these countries became Member States has not affected the principle that fishermen in the three countries have the historic right to fish in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas. Respect for this historic right is of the utmost importance. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy provides for a system of managing fish stocks in waters covered by it and in its own way supports the historical rights of fishermen. The agreement also supports historic fishing rights in the Kattegat and Skagerrak areas. For the above reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that the Replacement Agreement on Mutual Access to Fisheries Areas in the Skagerrak and Kattegat, signed on 15 January 2015, is in accordance with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and subsequent related provisions contained in other agreements. In addition, this agreement, however, will continue to ensure access to their respective waters beyond 4 nautical miles from baselines for ships from Denmark, Norway and Sweden. The approval of this agreement allows, on the one hand, reciprocal access in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat to Denmark, Sweden and Norway and, on the other hand, allows for the regulation of fishing in the areas concerned by applying certain conservation measures and management. In conclusion, this agreement between the EU and Norway allows for the adoption of control measures that comply with those principles of jurisdiction of coastal states, as is already applied for fishing in the North Sea. I therefore voted in favor

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - The EU's Common Fisheries Policy provides for a system for managing fish stocks in the waters, supporting the historical rights of fishermen. The Commission has therefore opened formal negotiations on behalf of the EU with Norway with a view to establishing an alternative agreement on reciprocal access to fisheries in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area between Denmark, Norway and Sweden. The new agreement is in line with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 UN Agreement on Fish Stocks and subsequent related provisions of other agreements. It guarantees vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden and continues to have exclusive reciprocal access to waters more than four nautical miles from their departure lines and provides the two Member States and Norway with further reciprocal access to the waters of the other countries in the Skagerrak and Kattegat. At the same time, it shall ensure prudent measures for the conservation of fisheries and the management of fisheries in the area. The tradition of fishing is older than the formation of states and the recognition of territorial waters, as well as the much later created exclusive economic zones. Respect for historical fishing rights is extremely important, so I supported this resolution approving the Council's decision on an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Fishermen traditionally do not fish in certain waters, but catch certain species in waters where those species can be found. The Kattegat and Skagerrak are typical examples of this tradition older than the recognition of territorial waters and the principle that fishermen from Denmark, Sweden and Norway should enjoy the historical right to fish in the area should be protected. The previously valid 1966 agreement between the three countries, supplemented by a bilateral fisheries agreement between the European Union and Norway in 1980, allowed those countries reciprocal access to fishing within four nautical miles of their starting lines in the Skagerrak and Kattegat. In the light of recent developments in international law, Norway considered the existing agreement to be incompatible with the provisions of the law of the sea and in July 2009 formally announced its wish to terminate the agreement - which expired on 7 August 2012. negotiations with the Commission thereafter with a view to establishing a replacement agreement in line with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, which was subsequently signed on 15 January 2015. conservation and management for fishing in the area.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation aims to update the reciprocal access agreement for fishing activities in Skagerrak and Kattegat, between Denmark, Norway and Sweden. This agreement is dated 1966, before Denmark and Sweden became members of the EU. The update, proposed by Norway, aims to bring the old agreement into line with the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Populations, namely in terms of control, or maritime conservation and management issues. This agreement, with the respective updates, contributes to reinforce the historical rights of fishermen in the region, regardless of their nationality, considering that the fishing springs do not know administrative jurisdictions and that fishing activity depends on access to resources. Involving two EU Member States and a third country, this agreement would not have to be the subject of any decision by the EU (European Parliament and Council) if, under the institutional framework given by the Treaty of Lisbon, the management of living marine resources has become an exclusive competence of the EU. We voted in favor. We reiterate, however, our disagreement with the aforementioned institutional framework.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing.- I fully support the EU-Norway agreement on reciprocal access to fisheries in the Skagerrak.This Agreement shall maintain exclusive access for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to their waters located more than 4 nautical miles from the baselines.This agreement respects the laws, regulations and administrative provisions for the conservation and sustainable use of living resources in the Skagerrak.As the agreement is in line with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, the objectives and rules of the Common Fisheries Policy and the 1980 Bilateral Fisheries Agreement between the European Union and Norway, I see no reason to prolong negotiations and postpone decisions.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. - The agreement on mutual access to fisheries in the Skagerrak and Kattegat between Denmark, Norway and Sweden has been in force since August 1967. This agreement allows the three countries to access fish stocks outside 4 nautical miles from the national baselines. Denmark joined the EU in 1973 and Sweden in 1995, so the Commission became responsible for managing the agreement on behalf of these two Member States. This agreement is currently being updated to reflect developments in international fisheries law. The agreement provides for: the preservation of the exclusive access granted to Danish, Norwegian and Swedish vessels to each party's waters beyond 4 nautical miles from the baselines; supporting conservation and management measures for the fishery resources in the area; allowing control measures to be applied in line with the normal jurisdiction of the coastal state (this is already the case for North Sea fisheries). I hereby support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this recommendation on a fisheries agreement with Norway to maintain the exclusive access enjoyed by vessels from Denmark and Sweden in their respective waters and in those of Norway beyond fournautical miles from baselines.In addition, this agreement will ensure the maintenance of reciprocal access of these same States to the respective waters of the other parties in the area of Skagerrak and Kattegat.In these areas, fishing rights are historic and pre-date the creation of states, so it is important that EU law respects these traditions.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - The agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to fishing activities in Skagerrak and Kattegat came into force on 7 August 1967. This agreement allowed the three countries to have reciprocal access to fishing activities for up to four nautical miles calculated from their base lines in Skagerrak and Kattegat. The 1966 agreement remained in force for an initial period of 35 years, until 2002, and was subsequently extended for two periods of five years, until 2012. In view of the evolution of international fisheries law, Norway considered that the current agreement it did not comply with the current provisions of the law of the sea and called into question the control mechanism. After Norway entered into formal negotiations with the Commission, an agreement was reached in 2013 with the aim of establishing a substitution agreement on reciprocal access to fishing activities in those areas. I voted in favor of this report, because the new agreement defends the historic fishing rights of fishermen in Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the Kattegat and Skagerrak, without prejudice to the rights of fishermen in other States, while guaranteeing the adoption appropriate measures for fisheries management and conservation in those waters.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose legislation which extends the discredited, unreformable common fisheries policy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - This new agreement maintains the exclusive access granted reciprocally to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to the waters of each of the three countries located outside the limit of four nautical miles measured from the baselines. It guarantees the two Member States and Norway the continuity of reciprocal access to the waters of each of them in Skagerrak and Kattegat, while at the same time ensuring adequate measures for the conservation and management of fisheries in this area. In addition, it allows for control measures in line with the normal jurisdictional principles of a coastal state, as is already the case for fishing in the North Sea. Fishing in these waters is a practice prior to the creation of States and the recognition of territorial waters and, subsequently, the exclusive economic zone. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together for the same fish populations in these waters since at least the Middle Ages. The fact that two of these countries have become Member States does not alter the principle that fishermen in these three countries should enjoy the historic rights to fish in Skagerrak and Kattegat.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written.- I have given my vote in favor of the recommendation for the conclusion of the agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for Danish, Norwegian or Swedish vessels.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.Together with Parliament, I give my consent to the conclusion of this agreement.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Fishing in the Skagerrak is a small but important issue for the functioning of the European Economic Area.Although the issue is largely technical in nature and does not raise major political contradictions, its rapid settlement demonstrates the effectiveness of the functioning of the EEA.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which concerns the conclusion of a new agreement on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, which replaces the old agreement that existed between Denmark, Norway and Sweden in this matter. The new agreement maintains, like the previous one, exclusive access granted reciprocally to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to the waters of each of the three countries, beyond the limit of four nautical miles. It also ensures the continuity of reciprocal access to the waters of the three countries and adequate measures for the conservation and management of fisheries in this area, also allowing for control measures in line with the principles of normal jurisdiction of a coastal state, as is already the case with fishing in the North Sea. It is fundamentally a matter of common sense and balance, since the fishermen of these three countries fish in certain waters for certain fish populations, in what is a procedure prior to the creation of States, the recognition of territorial waters and the exclusive economic zone . The fact that two of them subsequently became Member States should not alter this tradition or the underlying historical principle.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I approved the agreement between the EU and Norway on mutual access to fishing in the Skagerrak.The agreement includes mutual access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.In this context, it ensures mutual easier access for the contracting parties to the waters in the Skagerrak and, at the same time, ensures the management of the fishery in this area.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it involves consenting to a shared management agreement for the fishery resources located in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat.These two straits are what separate the waters of the Baltic from the waters of the North Sea, it is a fishing area where fishermen traditionally follow the schools of fish regardless of the border line of the countries involved.As it is a shared fishing area with Norway, the Union is responsible for the development of this type of agreement with third countries.As it is an agreement to allow traditional fishing methods and to respect principles of reciprocity and sustainability in these areas, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I have decided to cast my vote in favor of the EU-Norway agreement on mutual access to fishing grounds in the Skagerrak.The new agreement not only continues to ensure that Sweden, Denmark and Norway can carry out fishing activities together up to a distance of 4 nautical miles from their respective baselines, but also promotes conservation and fisheries management measures in the area.and allows for control measures in accordance with the principles of the normal jurisdiction of coastal states.This is a necessary agreement following the entry of Denmark and Sweden into the European Union, in order to reflect new developments in international fisheries law.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not agree with the CFP.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to support this recommendation. The agreement ensures continued reciprocal access for the two Member States and Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, whilst at the same time ensuring sound conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. Furthermore, it allows for control measures in harmony with the principles of normal coastal state jurisdiction, as is already the case for fisheries in the North Sea.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and success.actions.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Fishing is not traditionally governed by national borders. The Skagerrak and Kattegat are typical examples of areas where fishermen have been fishing since the Middle Ages and have been guided by the migration of different species. Therefore, as early as 1966, Denmark, Norway and Sweden concluded an agreement on reciprocal access to fisheries in these areas. It recognized the geographical specificities and historical rights of fishermen from the three countries. The agreement itself was very simple and contained only three articles. With some minor adjustments, mainly due to the accession of Denmark and Sweden to the European Union, this agreement was in force until 2012. The accession of these countries to the EU transferred the competences for the administration of this agreement to the European Commission. In 2009, Norway decided to terminate the original agreement, mainly due to recent developments in international fisheries law. The Norwegian authorities are convinced that the agreement is obsolete and that its provision will need to be brought into line with current fisheries control methods. I approved the new form of the agreement mainly because it takes into account the Union's common fisheries policy. And this supports not only the original rights of fishermen, but also modern trends in controlling the use of fishery resources.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The Agreement on Reciprocal Access to Fishing in the Skagerrak and Kattegat between Denmark, Norway and Sweden guarantees these countries exclusive reciprocal access to waters more than four nautical miles from their baselines, while ensuring prudent conservation and management measures for fishing in that area. area. Fishermen traditionally do not fish in certain waters: they hunt certain stocks or species and fishermen in waters where those stocks or species can be found. This tradition is older than the formation of states and the recognition of territorial waters, and the Kattegat and Skagerrak are typical examples of this. The fact that two of these countries are EU Member States has not changed the principle that fishermen from all three countries should enjoy the historic right to fish in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area. It is extremely important that these historical fishing rights are respected. I therefore support this Report because this agreement further supports the historical fishing rights in the area and will be useful for the implementation of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy in the Kattegat and Skagerrak area.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the new EU-Norway agreement, which replaces the old agreement that Norway withdrew.With the new agreement, Denmark, Norway and Sweden will continue to have exclusive access to the waters of all three countries, as well as reciprocal access by all Member States to the waters of the other Contracting Parties in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report in line with the ALDE recommendation.It is important that cooperation between the EU and Norway continues in a constructive manner.It is fair that the centuries-long use of the Skagerrak for fishing will continue to be open to Norway, Denmark and Sweden.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: signed up. - The European Union institutions have taken over the role of regulating fisheries areas on behalf of the Member States following the application of the provisions of the Common Fisheries Policy. One such area is the Skagerrak and Kattegat Straits between the North Sea and the Baltic Sea. There is a historical tradition of fishing together between Danish, Swedish and Norwegian fishermen in this area, which led to the adoption of the 1966 Agreement between the three countries on reciprocal access to fishing up to 4 nautical miles from the baselines, according to the principle of the high seas. . The denunciation of this agreement by Norway in 2012, on the basis of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and the UN Fish Stocks Agreement, led to the launch of formal negotiations between the Commission and the Norwegian State for the establishment of a replacement agreement. The new agreement was initialed in October 2013 and signed in January 2015 and provides for reciprocal access by vessels from the three countries in the Skagerrak area, ensuring effective conservation and management measures in the field of fisheries, as well as control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction. coastal states. I support the adoption of Parliament's current recommendation, which lays the groundwork for normalizing the fishing situation in that area.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted for the text. Traditionally, fishermen do not fish in certain waters: they fish for specific fish stocks or species in the waters where these stocks and species are found, and they follow migratory species. This tradition predates the establishment of states and the recognition of territorial waters and exclusive economic zones, which emerged much later. The Skagerrak and Kattegat area is a typical example of this situation. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together in these waters and for the same stocks at least since the Middle Ages. The fact that two of these three countries have become Member States does not change the principle that fishermen from these three countries should be able to enjoy historic fishing rights in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area. Respect for these historic fishing rights is of the utmost importance.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak, a strait running between the southeast coast of Norway and the southwest coast of Sweden, allows for reciprocal access between the EU, Sweden and Norway to fish up to four nautical miles from their respective baselines in the Skagerrak. I voted in favour of the report because it supports the historical fishing rights shared in the area, one that predates the creation of states and the recognition of territorial waters and, as well as exclusive economic zones.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - The Agreement on Reciprocal Access to Fishing in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area regulates the rules for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden and has been in force since 1967. Following the accession of Denmark and Sweden to the European Union, it has been supplemented by a bilateral fisheries agreement between the European Union and Norway, but now needs to be aligned with the principles of customary coastal state jurisdiction under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. . As in the previous agreement, vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden are guaranteed exclusive reciprocal access to waters more than four nautical miles from their bases and prudent conservation and management measures are provided for fishing in the area. In addition, the agreement provides for control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State. As I believe that this supports the historical fishing rights of these countries in the Kattegat and Skagerrak area, I have supported this agreement.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together in these waters for at least the Middle Ages. The tradition of fishing is older than the creation of countries, and it is important that historical fishing rights are respected. The Agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat entered into force on 7 August 1967 and was extended until 2002 until 2012. The new agreement continues to allow Danish, Norwegian and Swedish vessels exclusive access to the waters of all three countries. longer than four nautical miles from the baselines. It shall ensure the continued reciprocal access of the two Member States and Norway to the waters of the other Contracting Parties concerned in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, as well as prudent measures for the conservation and management of fisheries in that area. In addition, it provides for control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of coastal states, which already apply to fishing in the North Sea.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This recommendation is proof that agreements can be reached between individuals from different European countries or with Norway, even if it is not a Member State. I support this proposal, which respects the historic agreements and will favour the fishing sector of these countries to continue working on the basis of the rules of the Union.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing.- Following the denunciation of the previous agreement, Norway and the European Union signed a new agreement on January 15, 2015 concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas.It is simply a matter of approving this deal on behalf of the Union.The new agreement is adapted to changes in international law and guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, while ensuring the implementation of measures ofconservation and management of fisheries in this area.It also allows for the adoption of control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of the coastal State.I voted for this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- This agreement allows the three countries to access fish stocks beyond 4 nautical miles from the national baselines.Following the accession of the countries to the EU, the Commission became responsible for managing the agreement on behalf of these two Member States.This agreement is currently being updated to reflect developments in international fisheries law, and I therefore voted positively.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the report to the extent that for centuries Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together in these waters and species.Accession to the Union must not affect your historical fishing rights in your historical fishing grounds.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of an Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.The Skagerrak is traditionally a fishing area for vessels flying the flag of these three countries.The original reciprocal fishing agreement, which allowed fishing within 4 nautical miles of the coastal waters of Denmark, Norway and Sweden, has expired.I therefore think that the historical right of the fishermen of Denmark, Norway and Sweden needs to be supported and enshrined in the treaty.At the same time, the agreement contained measures to ensure sustainable fishing and the conservation of fish stocks in the area.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support Jorn Dohrmman's report on the EU-Norway agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. The new agreement contains the exclusive right of access to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden with their own waters outside the 4 nautical miles from the baselines, thus ensuring continuous reciprocal access for the two Member States (Denmark and Sweden) and the non-member country (Norway) to the respective waters. parties in the Skagerrak area, while at the same time ensuring fisheries protection and management measures in the area. This agreement managed to correct and regulate the relations between these countries related to fisheries in the area. For these purposes, the area is considered an open sea. Thus, vessels from Sweden, Denmark and Norway, which sail under these flags, have mutual access to the waters that belong to them. At the same time, conservation measures for fishing in these areas and management are provided.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the new agreement, as it continues to give Danish, Norwegian and Swedish vessels exclusive access to the waters of all three countries beyond four nautical miles from the baselines, while setting out prudent measures for the conservation and management of fisheries in the area.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The agreement which is the subject of the following report allows access to the fishing areas in the Skagerrak for both Swedish and Danish and Norwegian vessels.As it represents a very important agreement that can almost be described as a historic event, I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which refers to the recommendation for the conclusion of the agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for Danish, Norwegian or Swedish vessels.This point is closely linked to the initiative report that contains the non-legislative resolution linked to the recommendation and for consistency the votes are linked.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it is the political resolution that supports the agreement of shared management of the fishery resources located in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat.These two straits are what separate the waters of the Baltic from the waters of the North Sea, it is a fishing area where fishermen traditionally follow the schools of fish regardless of the border line of the countries involved.As it is a shared fishing area with Norway, the Union is responsible for developing this type of agreement with third countries.As it is an agreement to allow traditional fishing methods and to respect principles of reciprocity and sustainability in these areas, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP resolution on the EU-Norway agreement on reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak. Fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden have traditionally always fished together in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak. Under this agreement, it is proposed to continue to guarantee the historic fishing rights of Danish, Norwegian and Swedish fishermen in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak, without prejudice to the fishing rights of other countries, while ensuring that appropriate fisheries management and conservation measures are taken in these waters. The agreement also contributes to the implementation of the reformed EU fisheries management system, in line with the objectives and guiding principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP). This applies in particular to the application of mandatory measures to maintain stock levels that ensure sustainable fishing. In addition to these principles, I also agree with the need to emphasize that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity. In addition, in the case of Norway, EU tariffs on food, including fishery products, would be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. The Commission must ensure that EU tariffs on food and fishery products are set in a way that does not run counter to the principles of free trade in food, including fishery products.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden,because it ensures that fishing vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden operating in the area comply with the relevant laws and regulations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - This draft resolution asks the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council "at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal". He also expressed certain reservations of the European Parliament with regard to this agreement with Norway: he thus recalled that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity. In the case of Norway, the Commission is asked to put pressure on this country so that the customs duties on agriculture, food products and fisheries that it imposes on the European Union do not go to against the principles of free trade. It is this aspect that poses a problem, because Norway cannot be blamed for protecting its internal market in order to preserve its economy and its jobs. However, I did not vote against the draft resolution because this Norwegian protectionism is being done to the detriment of the Member States of the Union. I chose to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am opposed to the Common Fisheries Policy, this report highlights the importance of free trade, which is a vital component of a prosperous country. I therefore chose to support the whips’ position of abstention on the textual account of the resolution, whilst voting against the legislative report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text to give my approval to this new agreement between the European Union and Norway concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.Signed on January 15, 2015, it complies with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea as well as related provisions of other agreements concluded subsequently.Following the expiration of the previous existing agreement in 2012, it was necessary to introduce a new text to allow reciprocal agreement to fishing activities for Norway, Sweden and Denmark.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Under this agreement, the three countries had reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat up to four nautical miles from their respective baselines. The agreement was originally valid for 35 years, i. y. until 2002 and was subsequently extended for two five-year periods until 2012. However, Norway has terminated the agreement in the light of recent developments in international fisheries law. Norway recently entered into formal negotiations with the Commission, negotiating on behalf of the European Union, with a view to concluding an agreement on reciprocal fishing opportunities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat, which would replace the previous agreement. As the new agreement is in line with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and subsequent related provisions of other agreements, I support this agreement.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- The draft resolution asks the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council "at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal".He also expresses some reservations of the European Parliament with regard to this agreement with Norway: he thus recalls that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity.In this case, the Commission is being asked to put pressure on Norway so that the tariffs on agriculture, food products and fisheries that it imposes on the European Union do not go to the EU.against the principles of free trade.As a sovereignist, I cannot blame Norway for wanting to protect its internal market in order to support its economy and its jobs, but I believe that we could achieve better agreements without the European Union.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I approved this report which proposes to renew the old agreements concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities of Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the Skagerrak area while ensuring the implementation of conservation measures andadequate management of fisheries in this area.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: written.- The Skagerrak maritime zone has traditionally been a shared fishing area between Norway, Denmark and Sweden.I have voted in favor of continuing reciprocal access for these countries.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the Dohrmann report, a text closely linked to Parliament's recommendation on the approval of the EU-Norway agreement on mutual access to fisheries areas in the Skagerrak.The resolution reiterates the positive view on the agreement, which mutually guarantees continuity of access to the fishing areas of the Skagerrak for vessels from Denmark, Sweden and Norway, while allowing the conservation and sustainable use of biological resources.The text invites the Commission to submit a full report on the implementation of the agreement to Parliament and the Council and requests that Parliament be kept informed at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the report to the extent that for centuries Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together in these waters and species.Accession to the Union must not affect your historical fishing rights in your historical fishing grounds.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I supported this report on the EU Agreement with Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak, in which I was the shadow rapporteur for my group.The Agreement contributes to supporting the historic fishing rights in this area and will also be beneficial for the implementation of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak.It further emphasizes that any country's access to the internal market must be based on reciprocity and that, in the case of Norway, all tariffs on food products, including fishery products, from the EU must be in accordance withthe EEA Agreement.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I preferred to abstain from this resolution on the agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak. On the one hand, it is normal that, as a sovereign nation, Norway is empowered to protect its fishing industry, therefore its economy and its jobs, by measures that I call for France as customs duties on fishing in its trade with third countries, in a logic of intelligent protectionism. As such, I find it scandalous that the European Union, through the Commission, wishes to put pressure on Norway so that this country submits to the diktat of savage free trade. However, I recognize that, assuming that there is and will be agreement, on the basis of access for Norway to the internal market, it would be normal for there to be reciprocity, at the risk, otherwise, that this agreement is greatly unfavorable to the Member States, and in particular to France.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- The resolution on the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fisheries areas in the Skagerrak consistently underlines the "reciprocity" nature of customs duties vis-à-vis Norway.I am in favor of granting Norway the historic right to fish in the Baltic waters, where Swedish and Danish vessels also fish.That is why I voted in favor of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - This initiative report contains a non-legislative Resolution on the Recommendation for the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for Danish, Norwegian or Swedish vessels. The attention of the Commission is called to forward to the European Parliament the minutes and the conclusions of the consultations, as well as a full report before opening the renewal of the negotiations. Likewise, both the Commission and the Council are asked to keep Parliament informed of all stages of the procedures related to the Agreement and its renewal, as established in Article 13 (2) of the TEU and Article 218 (10) , of the TFEU. Finally, the task of the Commission in ensuring that EU customs duties on fishery products are not established contrary to the principles of free trade in the area, in accordance with the Agreement on the European Economic Area and the principle of reciprocity. For these reasons, I have voted in favor of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission to submit a detailed report to Parliament and the Council on the implementation of the agreement during the final year of its application and before negotiations on its renewal begin. It also calls on the Commission and the Council, within the limits of their respective powers, to keep Parliament immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal, as laid down in the Treaty on European Union. Furthermore, Parliament emphasizes that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that, in the case of Norway, customs duties on foodstuffs, including fishery products, from the EU must be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. The EP also emphasizes that the Commission must ensure that customs duties on food and fishery products from the EU are not imposed in a way that is contrary to the principles of free trade in food, including fishery products. The agreement also contributes to the implementation of the reformed EU fisheries management system established by the objectives and guiding principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), in particular the landing obligation and binding measures to maintain stocks in excess of sustainable fishing, compliance.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. This new Agreement was signed on 15 January 2015 and conforms with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea as well as subsequent related provisions in other agreements.  It continues the exclusive reciprocal access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, whilst at the same time ensuring conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. For centuries, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have together fished in these waters for the same stocks. Their historical rights to fish in the areas concerned should be respected.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing.- We welcome this agreement which guarantees mutual access of boats from Denmark, Norway and Sweden for the conservation and sustainable use of biological resources in the Skagerrak.The resolution supports requests for full reporting and emphasizes the obligation of the Commission and the Council to keep the European Parliament immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal, as required by theTreaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - This draft resolution asks the European Commission to keep Parliament and the Council informed of all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak. This text expresses certain reservations about this agreement and recalls that Norway’s access to the internal market must be based on reciprocity. In addition, the Commission is asked to put pressure on the Norwegian government so that the customs duties on agricultural and food products that it imposes on the Member States of the Union do not go against the principles of free exchange. Of course, Norwegian protectionism harms the economic interests of the Member States. However, we believe that the authorities of this Scandinavian country are ardently defending their internal market in order to protect their businesses and their jobs. It is therefore high time that we regain our national sovereignty to act in the same direction! I abstained on this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The 1966 Agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak and Kattegat and the 1980 bilateral agreement on fishing between the European Union and Norway provide for reciprocal access between the three countries to fish up to 4 nautical miles from fishing lines. their base in the Skagerrak and Kattegat. The existing agreement was considered inconsistent with current provisions of the law of the sea, given the more recent developments in international fisheries law and, in particular, with the introduction of the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. As a result, Norway has expressed concern about control provisions, but also about conservation and management principles that no longer meet current needs. Thus, this project aims to support the historical fishing rights in this area and, at the same time, to ensure an efficient and sustainable fish stock management system, which is why I have spoken out in favor of this initiative.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which refers to the recommendation for the conclusion of the agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for Danish, Norwegian or Swedish vessels.This point is closely linked to the initiative report that contains the non-legislative resolution linked to the recommendation and for consistency the votes are linked.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of this accompanying report to the Council decision for a new agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fishing areas in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the Danish, Norwegian and Swedish flags.This report asks the Commission to present to Parliament and the Council a full report on the implementation of the agreement in force before the opening of negotiations for its renewal.It also invites the Commission to keep Parliament immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal, recalling that its task is to ensure that customs duties on food and fishery products originating from theEU are not set up in a way that contravenes the principles of free trade in the food sector, including fishery products.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Resolution on reciprocal access to fishing in Skagerrak. This new Agreement was signed on 15 January 2015 and conforms with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea, as well as subsequent related provisions in other agreements.  It continues the exclusive reciprocal access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, whilst at the same time ensuring conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. For centuries, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have together fished in these waters for the same stocks. Their historical rights to fish in the areas concerned should be respected.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained as this is non-legislative and Norway has chosen to agree it.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Resolution on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- With the accession of Denmark (1973) and Sweden (1995) to the EU, the European Commission became responsible for managing the agreement on behalf of these two Member States.This is a truly historic fishing agreement: Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished the same fish stocks together in these waters at least since the Middle Ages.Norway has held formal negotiations with the European Commission.I therefore voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the agreement, which supports historic fishing rights in this area and will be beneficial for the implementation of the revised CFP in the Kattegat and Skagerrak area.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The resolution on the report containing a proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden helps to find common groundsolutions in the field of fisheries and trade, with the aim of cooperating all parties involved for the benefit of the citizens, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing.- I agree with the findings of the non-legislative motion for a resolution, given that fishermen from Denmark, Sweden and Norway have been practicing their activities jointly in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat for centuries.I am also firmly convinced that the agreement in question not only effectively acknowledges it by guaranteeing the aforementioned historical fishing rights, but is also concerned with ensuring the adoption of adequate measures for the management of the activity in question.I therefore urge the Commission to provide as soon as possible relevant information and data on the implementation of the agreement, especially in light of the difficulties encountered due to the customs duties applied by the Kingdom of Norway on food products from the EU.In fact, they must comply as much as possible with the agreement on the European Economic Area and certainly not in contrast with the principles of the free market.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We abstained as this is non—legislative and Norway has chosen to agree it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the non-legislative resolution (INI) accompanying the report on the subject adopted in the PECH Commission.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it is the political resolution that supports the shared management agreement for the fishery resources located in the Skagerrak and Kattegat.These two straits are what separate the waters of the Baltic from the waters of the North Sea, it is a fishing area where fishermen traditionally follow the schools of fish regardless of the border line of the countries involved.As it is a shared fishing area with Norway, the Union is responsible for developing this type of agreement with third countries.As it is an agreement to allow traditional fishing methods and to respect principles of reciprocity and sustainability in these areas, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- The EU's common fisheries policy provides for a system for the management of fish stocks in the waters it covers and thus supports the historic rights of fishermen.I believe that the fact that two of the signatories to the agreement have become Member States has not changed the principle that fishermen from the three countries, namely Sweden, Denmark and Norway, should enjoy historical fishing rights in the Skagerrak and Kattegat.It is of the utmost importance that these historic fishing rights are respected.I therefore welcomed this resolution which guarantees the three states the continuity of reciprocal access to the respective waters of the other parts in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat and at the same time allows for the regulation of fisheries in the area through certain conservation and management measures.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fisheries in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I believe that the update of the agreement is necessary to reflect the situation in the field of international fisheries law.The agreement provides for the promotion of conservation and management measures for the fishery resources in the area and for the possibility to apply control measures in line with the normal jurisdiction of the coastal state.The report on this agreement aims to promote a political declaration reminding Norway that any customs duties on food products, including fishery products, with the EU must be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement ensures continued reciprocal access of vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden for the conservation and sustainable use of the living resources in Skagerrak. I voted in favour of this report as it requests full reporting while emphasising on the obligation of the Commission and the Council to keep the EP immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This non-legislative report concerns reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak, a strait between southern Norway, south-eastern Sweden and north-western Denmark.Norway, a non-member of the European Union, has entered into formal negotiations with the European Commission with a view to obtaining reciprocal access to this highly prized fishing area, also exploited by Sweden and Denmark, members of theUnion.The agreement includes provisions for the sustainable management of fisheries in this area and control measures in harmony with the principles of coastal State jurisdiction.Considering that this agreement ensures the reasoned exploitation and sustainable management of fish stocks in this international fishing zone and that it will offer new opportunities to European fishermen, I voted in favor of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained as this is non-legislative and Norway has chosen to agree it.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report making recommendations for the proper follow-up of the agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.Without calling into question the adoption of this fisheries agreement between the Union and one of its closest neighbors, it is imperative, for this agreement to be effective, that the European Parliament be kept informed of the progress of the procedure.implementation of the agreement.We also want the Commission to ensure that the customs duties, set by Norway, on food products, are effectively in line with the provisions of the agreement on the European Economic Area.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.The draft resolution calls on the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council "at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal".The text thus recalls that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity: yet Norway imposes numerous customs duties on the Member States of the European Union.We are in favor of Norwegian protectionism in principle.In this case, since it is done to the detriment of certain European states, including France, we preferred to abstain.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on the EU-Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak, which was de facto concluded between Denmark, Sweden and Norway as early as 1967. With the accession of Denmark and Sweden to the EU, the European Commission became responsible for managing fishing in those countries, and therefore this Agreement, on behalf of both Member States. This is the main reason why Iceland does not want to join the EU. This Agreement updates the previous one to reflect new trends in international fisheries law, such as the promotion of fisheries conservation and management measures in the region.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We are voting against the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fisheries in Skagerrak for Danish, Norwegian and Swedish-flagged vessels, as the report emphasizes that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that in the case of Norway any customs duties on foodstuffs, including fishery products, from the EU must comply with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. However, the Agreement on the European Economic Area adopts provisions in the areas of free movement of persons, goods, services and capital. The EU and two of its EEA partners - Norway and Iceland - are also linked to a number of "northern policies" and through forums focusing on the rapidly evolving northern regions of Europe and the Arctic region as a whole. Bilateral relations have been severely tested since the anti-immigration initiative of February 2014, the outcome of which called into question the principles of free movement and the single market on which these relations are based.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the EU-Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak. The agreement retains the exclusive access to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles from the baselines. It is important to my constituents in Wales that the fisheries of the European Union are managed effectively.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- Fishermen in Denmark, Norway and Sweden have always fished together in Kattegat and Skagerrak.The agreement defends the historic fishing rights of fishermen in Denmark, Norway and Sweden in Kattegat and Skagerrak, without prejudice to the rights of fishermen in other States, while ensuring that appropriate measures are taken in fisheries management.and conservation in those waters.The Commission must submit to the Parliament and the Council, during the last year of the agreement's validity, and before the opening of negotiations with a view to its renewal, a complete report on its implementation.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Abstention: the draft resolution calls on the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution accompanies the recommendation to update the agreement on reciprocal access to fishing activities in Skagerrak and Kattegat, between Denmark, Norway and Sweden. This agreement is dated 1966, before Denmark and Sweden became members of the EU. The update, proposed by Norway, aims to bring the old agreement into line with the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Populations, namely in terms of control, or maritime conservation and management issues. This agreement, with the respective updates, contributes to reinforce the historical rights of fishermen in the region, regardless of their nationality, considering that the fishing springs do not know administrative jurisdictions and that fishing activity depends on access to resources. Involving two EU Member States and a third country, this agreement would not have to be the subject of any decision by the EU (European Parliament and Council), should it not be the case that, under the institutional framework given by the Lisbon Treaty, management of living marine resources has become an exclusive competence of the EU. We voted in favor. However, we reiterate our disagreement with the aforementioned institutional framework.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as I believe that the new agreement grants ships from Denmark, Norway and Sweden exclusive access to their respective waters beyond 4 nautical miles from the baselines.It also ensures that the two Member States and Norway have continuity of mutual access to the respective waters of the other parts in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat, while allowing fisheries in the area to be regulated by means of certain conservation and management measures.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the resolution to guarantee historic fishing rights and confirm the "reciprocity" nature of customs duties vis-à-vis Norway.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for Danish, Norwegian and Swedish-flagged vessels, as the report emphasizes that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that in the case of Norway any customs duties on foodstuffs, including fishery products, from the EU must comply with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. However, the Agreement on the European Economic Area adopts provisions in the areas of free movement of persons, goods, services and capital. The EU and two of its EEA partners - Norway and Iceland - are also linked to a number of "northern policies" and through forums focusing on the rapidly evolving northern regions of Europe and the Arctic region as a whole. Bilateral relations have been severely tested since the anti-immigration initiative of February 2014, the outcome of which called into question the principles of free movement and the single market on which these relations are based.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The new Agreement maintains the exclusive access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles from the baselines. It ensures continued reciprocal access for the two Member States and Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak area, whilst at the same time ensuring sound conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. Furthermore, it allows for control measures in harmony with the principles of normal Coastal State jurisdiction, as is already the case for fisheries in the North Sea. I fully support this Agreement, which is in conformity with the 1980 bilateral fisheries agreement, with UNCLOS and with the objectives of the CFP. It ensures that fishing vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden operating in the area comply with the relevant laws, regulations and control and enforcement measures for the conservation and sustainable use of the living resources in the Skagerrak.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution which refers to the recommendation for the conclusion of the agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for Danish, Norwegian or Swedish vessels.This point is closely linked to the initiative report that contains the non-legislative resolution linked to the recommendation and for consistency the votes are linked.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of this proposal for a non-legislative resolution, as it is in line with the position we took in voting on the same rapporteur's report (A8-0321 / 2016) on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union andKingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this agreement which is in line with the 1980 bilateral fisheries agreement, UNCLOS and the objectives of the CFP.This agreement ensures that fishing vessels in Denmark, Norway and Sweden operating in the area comply with the laws, regulations and control and enforcement measures for the conservation and sustainable use of living resources in the Skagerrak.The new agreement maintains the exclusive access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to the waters of the other Party beyond 4 nautical miles from the baselines.It shall ensure continued reciprocal access for the two Member States and Norway to the respective waters of the other Parties in the Skagerrak, thus ensuring sound conservation and management measures for the fisheries in the area.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the proposal for a non-legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.Sweden and Norway and the rights of fishermen in other countries are not called into question.In addition, I support the implementation of the reformed fisheries management system in the EU and the measures aimed at effective fisheries management and water conservation, and I therefore support this Report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- This resolution's call to put pressure on Norway so as not to hamper the principles of free trade goes against the conception of the economy that I would like to apply at home.However, this protectionism put in place by Norway comes at the expense of the Member States of the European Union.I therefore abstained.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this proposal, which is replacing a previous agreement that is not in conformity with international laws (Law of the Sea and UN Fish Stock Regulation). It is based on historical rights and will grant Member State access to Norwegian waters and reciprocal access for Norway for Danish and Swedish waters, up to four nautical miles from baselines in Skagerrak.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on the resolution concerning the agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak. The text expresses certain reservations of the European Parliament with regard to this agreement with Norway. It thus recalls that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity. In the case of Norway, the Commission is asked to put pressure on this country so that the customs duties on agriculture, food products and fisheries that it imposes on the European Union do not go to against the principles of free trade. It is this aspect that is problematic, because Norway cannot be blamed for protecting its internal market in order to preserve its economy and its jobs. However, I did not vote against the draft resolution because this Norwegian protectionism is being done to the detriment of the Member States of the Union ...

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I consider it to be an environmentally sustainable and fair deal for Scandinavian fishing vessels operating in the Skagerrak.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written.- In this motion for a non-legislative resolution of the European Parliament, the latter takes a position on the Agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for Danish, Swedish and Norwegian vessels and, taking into account the objectives soughtby the aforementioned Agreement, namely the defense of the historical rights of the fishermen of these three countries in the Strait and the adoption of appropriate measures for the management and conservation of fisheries in those areas, Parliament calls on the Commission andthe Council to be kept informed about the application of the Agreement before its eventual renewal.I give my favorable vote since it is important to be aware of the application of this Agreement, which applies the basic objectives and principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I stayed.This is a resolution on an agreement on the access of fishing vessels of Norway, Denmark and Sweden to the Skagerrak.The resolution asks the Commission to report on the application of the agreement before its renewal.I consider this agreement to be a matter for Denmark and Sweden, which is why I abstained.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The report highlights the fact that fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden traditionally fish together in the Kattegat and Skagerrak area. The agreement respects the historical rights of fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to fish in the Kattegat and Skagerrak areas without prejudice to the rights of fishermen from other countries, while guaranteeing that appropriate measures are taken to manage and conserve fisheries in those waters. It also supports the implementation of a reformed fisheries management system in the EU in line with the objectives and basic principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy, in particular the introduction of landing obligations and mandatory measures to keep stocks above levels that achieve the highest sustainable yield. It is essential that for all third countries, access to the internal market is based on reciprocity and that, in the case of Norway, all customs duties on EU food products, including fishery products, must comply with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. It is therefore the Commission's task to ensure that customs duties on food and fishery products from the EU are not set in a way that is contrary to the principles of free trade. I supported this report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- With this resolution, the EP calls on the Commission to submit a full report on the implementation of this agreement to Parliament and the Council during the last year of application of the EU-Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fisheries in the Skagerrak and before negotiations on its renewal begin.At the same time, the Commission is obliged to inform Parliament at all stages during the renewal negotiations in accordance with the procedures under the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden,because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.This resolution aims to express certain reservations of the European Parliament with regard to the agreement between the European Union and Norway concerning fishing activities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat.The European Parliament criticizes Norway for certain restrictive measures imposed in order to protect its internal market.He makes these criticisms while, of course, glorifying the principle of free trade which we oppose.We cannot deprive Norway of its just right to preserve its economy and its jobs.However, we cannot vote against the draft resolution either, because Norwegian protectionism is obviously at the expense of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU—Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak (resolution). Voting positively means supporting the role of the Commission to ensure that custom duties on food and fisheries products from the EU do not contradict the principles of free trade in terms of food and fishery products. At the same time, the agreement will ensure that suitable measures are taken for the purpose of both fishery management and conservation of the waters in the region.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: written.- I am voting in favor of the agreement because it defends the historical fishing rights of Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak, without prejudice to the rights of fishermen from other states, while ensuring the adoption of adequate management measuresand the conservation of fisheries in these areas.Furthermore, it supports the implementation of the reformed fisheries management system in the Union, established in line with the basic objectives and principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), in particular the introduction of the landing obligation and the maintenance ofstocks above levels that can produce the maximum sustainable yield.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - An agreement signed in 1966 between Denmark, Norway and Sweden concerning reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat entered into force on August 7, 1967. With the accession of Denmark and Sweden to the European Union in 1973 and 1995 respectively, the management of this agreement on behalf of these two Member States fell to the Commission. In view of more recent developments in international fisheries law, Norway considered that the existing agreement no longer complied with the provisions of the law of the sea and with modern conservation and management principles. A new agreement was proposed in 2014: it guarantees the maintenance of reciprocal access of the two Member States concerned and of Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the area of ​​Skagerrak and Kattegat, while ensuring the implementation of judicious conservation and management measures in this area. The approval of the European Parliament is necessary for the conclusion of this agreement. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- Following on from the previous report, this draft resolution seeks to ask the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council of all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal.Certain reservations are expressed on this agreement with Norway, in particular as regards access to the internal market of this state for third countries.The Commission is called on to lobby that the tariffs on agriculture, food and fisheries imposed by Norway do not run counter to the principle of free trade.This reproach against Norway, which only wishes to protect its internal market, led me to abstain from this resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I welcome the motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.These waters, which lie between the Danish, Swedish and Norwegian territories, are the subject of fishing activities undertaken by fishermen from these three countries.I am delighted that the agreement in question here incorporates principles dear to the new common fisheries policy such as the landing obligation as well as the exploitation of stocks allowing the maximum sustainable yield.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for a non-legislative resolution, which is linked to the Recommendation on the conclusion of the Agreement between the EU and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. It calls on the Commission to forward to the EP the minutes and conclusions of any consultations as well as a full implementation report before the opening of renewal negotiations. It also calls on the Commission and the Council to keep the EP immediately and fully informed at all stages of the procedures related to the agreement and its renewal, pursuant to Article 13(2) of the Treaty on European Union and Article 218(10) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Committee on Fisheries has attached a draft resolution to its report referred to in point 5.The draft proposes that the Commission and the Council be kept informed of the implementation and renewal of the agreement by Parliament.It also emphasizes that Norwegian customs duties on food and fishery products originating in the Union must be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area and the principles of free trade in this area.I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. - The draft resolution asks the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council "at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal". He also expresses some reservations of the European Parliament with regard to this agreement with Norway: he thus recalls that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity. In the case of Norway, the Commission is asked to put pressure on this country so that the customs duties on agriculture, food products and fisheries that it imposes on the European Union do not go to against the principles of free trade. It is this aspect that poses a problem for us because we cannot blame Norway for protecting its internal market in order to preserve its economy and its jobs.
