We will not vote against the draft resolution, however, because this Norwegian protectionism is being carried out to the detriment of the Member States of the Union. Abstention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. - This draft resolution asks the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council "at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal". He also expressed certain reservations of the European Parliament with regard to this agreement with Norway: he thus recalled that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity. In the case of Norway, the Commission is asked to put pressure on this country so that the customs duties on agriculture, food products and fisheries that it imposes on the European Union do not go to against the principles of free trade. This is the aspect that I have a problem with, because Norway cannot be blamed for protecting its internal market in order to preserve its economy and its jobs. However, I am not voting against the draft resolution, as this Norwegian protectionism is being carried out to the detriment of the Member States of the Union. I rather abstain on this resolution.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which is based on historical rights and will grant Member State access to Norwegian waters and reciprocal access for Norway for Danish and Swedish waters up to four nautical miles from baselines in Skagerrak.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which accompanies the approval of the fisheries agreement with Norway on access to the waters of the Skagerrak.The text believes that the agreement respects the historic fishing rights of fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the Kattegat and Skagerrak without prejudice to the rights of fishermen in other states.It also guarantees the adoption of appropriate measures for the management and continuation of fishing in these areas.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ On 7 August 1967, an agreement on reciprocal fishing access in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas between Denmark, Norway and Sweden entered into force. Following Denmark’s and Sweden’s accession to the EU, the Commission became responsible for the management of this Agreement on behalf of these two Member States. I have voted for this report regarding the renewal of this agreement.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported.The EU's Common Fisheries Policy has established a system for managing the fish stocks in the waters within its scope, thereby supporting fishermen's historic rights.The agreement further supports the historical fishing rights in the region and will also benefit from the implementation of the reformed Common Fisheries Policy in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden have traditionally fished jointly in the Kattegat and Skagerrak areas. This agreement supports the historic fishing rights of fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden in Kattegat and Skagerrak, without prejudice to the rights of fishermen from other countries, while ensuring that appropriate fisheries management and conservation measures are taken in these areas. . The agreement also supports the implementation of the reformed fisheries management system in the EU, which was established in line with the objectives and basic principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), in particular the introduction of the landing obligation and mandatory stock conservation measures. above the levels that allow maximum sustainable performance. For the above reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway protects the historic fishing rights of Danish, Norwegian and Swedish fishermen in the waters in the Kattegat and Skagerrak,and makes it possible to apply adequate measures for the correct management of fishing activities and conservation in these waters.Another reason why I am voting in favor of this agreement is that it fully supports the implementation of the reformed system of fisheries management in the EU which has been developed in accordance with the basic principles of the new fisheries policy (CFP).In conclusion, as a Member, I invite the Commission and the Council to keep Parliament informed of the continuation of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I supported this non-legislative European Parliament Resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. The agreement is in line with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea and subsequent related provisions of other agreements. The fact that two of these countries have become EU Member States has not changed the principle that fishermen from all three countries should enjoy the historic right to fish in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area. It is extremely important that these historical fishing rights are respected. This tradition is older than the formation of states and the recognition of territorial waters, as well as the much later created exclusive economic zones. The Kattegat and Skagerrak are typical examples of this. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing the same stocks in these waters since the Middle Ages, and perhaps longer. This agreement shall ensure further reciprocal access to the waters of the other Parties in the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas and at the same time ensure prudent conservation and management measures for fisheries in that area.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Fishermen traditionally do not fish in certain waters, but catch certain species in waters where those species can be found. The Kattegat and Skagerrak are typical examples of this tradition older than the recognition of territorial waters and the principle that fishermen from Denmark, Sweden and Norway should enjoy the historical right to fish in the area should be protected. The previously valid agreement allowed these countries mutual access to fishing in the area up to four nautical miles from their starting lines in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area. In the light of recent developments in international law, Norway officially announced in 2009 its wish to terminate the agreement - it expired in 2012. Norway began formal negotiations with the Commission thereafter with a view to establishing a replacement agreement in line with the UN Convention on the Law it was subsequently signed on 15 January 2015. It provides those countries with further reciprocal access to the waters of the other Parties in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area and ensures prudent conservation and management measures for fishing in the area. Access to the internal market must be based on reciprocity for all third countries and, in the case of Norway, all customs duties on EU food products, including fishery products, must be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution accompanies the recommendation to update the agreement on reciprocal access to fishing activities in Skagerrak and Kattegat, between Denmark, Norway and Sweden. This agreement is dated 1966, before Denmark and Sweden became members of the EU. The update, proposed by Norway, aims to bring the old agreement into line with the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Populations, namely in terms of control, or maritime conservation and management issues. This agreement, with the respective updates, contributes to reinforce the historical rights of fishermen in the region, regardless of their nationality, considering that the fishing springs do not know administrative jurisdictions and that fishing activity depends on access to resources. Involving two EU Member States and a third country, this agreement would not have to be the subject of any decision by the EU (European Parliament and Council) if, under the institutional framework given by the Treaty of Lisbon, the management of living marine resources has become an exclusive competence of the EU. We voted in favor. We reiterate, however, our disagreement with the aforementioned institutional framework.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the EU-Norway agreement on reciprocal access to fisheries in the Skagerrak.This resolution calls on the Commission to forward to Parliament the minutes and conclusions of all consultations and the full evaluation report on the application of the agreement.Among other things, it calls on the Commission and the Council to inform Parliament immediately and fully in accordance with EU law at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing.- The report promotes a political declaration reminding Norway that any customs duties on food products (including fishery products) from the EU must be compatible with the EEA Agreement.I hereby support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the fisheries agreement between the European Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing activities in the Skagerrak, so I vote in favor of this resolution.This agreement will maintain the exclusive access enjoyed by ships from Denmark and Sweden to their respective waters and those of Norway beyond four nautical miles from the baselines.Moreover, it will guarantee the maintenance of the reciprocal access of these same States, to the respective waters of the other parties in the area of Skagerrak and Kattegat.In these areas fishing rights are historic and pre-date the creation of states, so it is important that EU law respects these traditions.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained as this is non-legislative and Norway has chosen to agree it.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - This new agreement maintains the exclusive access granted reciprocally to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to the waters of each of the three countries located outside the limit of four nautical miles measured from the baselines. It guarantees the two Member States and Norway the continuity of reciprocal access to the waters of each of them in Skagerrak and Kattegat, while at the same time ensuring adequate measures for the conservation and management of fisheries in this area. In addition, it allows for control measures in line with the normal jurisdictional principles of a coastal state, as is already the case for fishing in the North Sea. Fishing in these waters is a practice prior to the creation of States and the recognition of territorial waters and, subsequently, the exclusive economic zone. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together for the same fish populations in these waters since at least the Middle Ages. The fact that two of these countries have become Member States does not alter the principle that fishermen in these three countries should enjoy the historic rights to fish in Skagerrak and Kattegat.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: written. - This initiative report contains a non-legislative resolution linked to the recommendation for the conclusion of the agreement between the Union and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for Danish, Norwegian or Swedish vessels. The attention of the Commission is called to forward to the EP the minutes and the conclusions of the consultations, as well as a full report before opening the renewal of the negotiations. It also asks both the Commission and the Council to keep the EP informed of all stages of the procedures related to the agreement and its renewal, as established in Article 13 (2) of the TEU and Article 218 (10) of the TFEU. Lastly, the Commission's task is to ensure that the Union's customs duties on fishery products are not established against the principles of free trade in the area, in accordance with the Agreement on the European Economic Area and the principle of reciprocity. For these reasons, I have voted in favor of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the non-legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access for vessels flying the flag ofDenmark, Norway and Sweden to fishing activities in the Skagerrak.Thanks to this non-legislative resolution, the European Parliament gives its consent to this agreement providing that fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden can continue to fish together in the Kattegat and the Skagerrak as they always have done.Furthermore, Parliament calls on the Commission and the Council to be informed of the procedures related to this agreement and its renewal.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Fishing in the Skagerrak is a small but important issue for the functioning of the European Economic Area.Although the issue is largely technical in nature and does not raise major political contradictions, its rapid settlement demonstrates the effectiveness of the functioning of the EEA.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing.- As with the proposal for a recommendation on this matter, I also endorsed this proposal for a non-legislative resolution, as it presents a set of suggestions regarding the historical rights of fishermen in these three countries, which must be preserved, in order to be allowed to continuefishing together in the Kattegat and Skagerrak fishing areas.To this end, it is essential that adequate measures be taken in terms of fisheries management and conservation in these waters, keeping stocks above the levels that allow maximum sustainable yield to be achieved.I also endorse the importance of the presentation of an evaluation report on the implementation of the agreement, under the responsibility of the Commission, which should also have the task of ensuring that the setting of customs duties on food and fisheries products from the EU is not contrary to thefree trade.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it is the political resolution that supports the shared management agreement for the fishery resources located in the Skagerrak and Kattegat.These two straits are what separate the waters of the Baltic from the waters of the North Sea, it is a fishing area where fishermen traditionally follow the schools of fish regardless of the border line of the countries involved.As it is a shared fishing area with Norway, the Union is responsible for developing this type of agreement with third countries.As it is an agreement to allow traditional fishing methods and to respect principles of reciprocity and sustainability in these areas, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I have decided to vote in favor of the report on the conclusion of the agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on mutual access to fishing areas in the Skagerrak.The report correctly highlights the importance of respecting historical fishing rights.For centuries, Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together in this area.Finally, it stresses that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that, in the case of Norway, customs duties on food products from the EU, including fishery products, must comply with the agreement onEuropean Economic Area.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I do agree with free trade but not the EU organising it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report replacing a previous agreement which is not in conformity with international laws (Law of the Sea and UN Fish Stock Regulation). It ensures that fishing vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden operating in the area comply with the relevant laws, regulations and control and enforcement measures for the conservation and sustainable use of the living resources in the Skagerrak.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and success.actions.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The proposal for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden is without prejudice to the rights of fishermen from other countries. measures for fisheries management and conservation in those waters. It also supports the implementation of the reformed EU fisheries management system established in line with the objectives and basic principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy. The European Parliament emphasizes that for all third countries, access to the internal market must be based on reciprocity and that, in the case of Norway, all customs duties on EU food products, including fishery products, must comply with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. It also instructs its President to forward this resolution to the Council and Commission, and to the governments and parliaments of the Member States and of the Kingdom of Norway. The Commission's task is to ensure that customs duties on food and fishery products from the EU are not set in a way that is contrary to the principles of free trade in the food sector. I fully support this Report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the call on the Commission to provide Parliament with the minutes and conclusions of all consultations, as well as a comprehensive report on the implementation of the agreement in the last year of its entry into force and before negotiations for its renewal begin.The resolution also rightly emphasizes that the Commission must ensure that customs duties on EU food and fishery products are not set contrary to the principles of free trade in food, including fishery products.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - By adopting the recommendation, I agree with the draft reciprocal access agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway, which concerns vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the Skagerrak fisheries. The recommendation describes that the agreement maintains the historical fishing rights of Danish, Norwegian and Swedish fishermen in this area, without prejudice to the rights of fishermen from other states, while also ensuring that appropriate measures are taken in fisheries management and conservation in those waters. . I agree that the agreement will facilitate the implementation of a fisheries management system within the Union, reshaped in accordance with the principles of the new common fisheries policy, and the introduction of binding measures to keep stocks above maximum sustainable yield. I also agree that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity and that, in the case of Norway, customs duties on food products originating in the Union must be in line with the Agreement on the European Economic Area. This should be done in such a way that no customs duties are imposed on foodstuffs and fishery products originating in the Union which are contrary to the principles of free trade in foodstuffs, including fishery products.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report in line with the ALDE recommendation.It is important that cooperation between the EU and Norway continues in a constructive manner.It is fair that the centuries-long use of the Skagerrak for fishing will continue to be open to Norway, Denmark and Sweden.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted for this text too. Traditionally, fishermen do not fish in certain waters: they fish for specific fish stocks or species, in the waters where these stocks and species are found, and they follow migratory species. This tradition predates the establishment of states and the recognition of territorial waters and exclusive economic zones, which emerged much later. The Skagerrak and Kattegat area is a typical example of this situation. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together in these waters and for the same stocks at least since the Middle Ages. The fact that two of these three countries have become Member States does not change the principle that fishermen from these three countries should be able to enjoy historic fishing rights in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area. Respect for these historic fishing rights is of the utmost importance.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU-Norway Agreement on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak, a strait running between the southeast coast of Norway and the southwest coast of Sweden, allows for reciprocal access between the EU, Sweden and Norway, to fish up to four nautical miles from their respective baselines in the Skagerrak. I voted in favour of the report because it supports the historical fishing rights shared in the area, one that predates the creation of states and the recognition of territorial waters, as well as exclusive economic zones.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the "Motion for a resolution on an agreement between the EU and Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak", given the agreement signed on 15 January 2015. This agreement provides for authorized access to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden in mutual waters outside 4 nautical miles from the baselines. Although the primary agreement between these countries was signed in 1966 and then extended for two five-year periods, Norway considers that the existing agreement is not in line with current maritime law provisions, especially with regard to the introduction of the 1982 UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. and the 1995 UN Agreement on Fish Stocks. The new agreement continues to guarantee vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden access to the waters, but provides conservation and management measures for fishing. It is also worth noting the control measures introduced in accordance with the principles of the usual jurisdiction of the coastal state, which has already been established for fishing activities in the North Sea.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I supported the Report on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak area for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden as fishermen from these three countriesand it respects the historical rights of fishermen.I think it is very important that the agreement takes appropriate measures to manage fisheries and conserve those waters.An agreement on reciprocal access to fisheries in this area has been in force since 1967, but with the entry of Denmark and Sweden into the European Union and changes in international fisheries law, there has been a need to update this agreement.The amendments continue to guarantee Denmark, Norway and Sweden reciprocal access to the waters of the Skagerrak and Kattegat areas and promote the conservation and management of fisheries measures in the area.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have been fishing together in these waters for at least the Middle Ages. The tradition of fishing is older than the creation of countries, and it is important that historical fishing rights are respected. The Agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak and the Kattegat entered into force on 7 August 1967 and was extended until 2002 until 2012. The new agreement continues to allow Danish, Norwegian and Swedish vessels exclusive access to the waters of all three countries. longer than four nautical miles from the baselines. It shall ensure the continued reciprocal access of the two Member States and Norway to the waters of the other Contracting Parties concerned in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, as well as prudent measures for the conservation and management of fisheries in that area. In addition, it provides for control measures in accordance with the principles of normal jurisdiction of coastal states, which already apply to fishing in the North Sea.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution is proof that agreements can be reached between individuals from different European countries or with Norway, even if it is not a Member State. I support this proposal, which respects the historic agreements and will favour the fishing sector of these countries to continue working on the basis of the rules of the Union.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. - This draft resolution asks the European Commission to inform Parliament and the Council "at all stages of the procedures relating to the agreement and its renewal". He also expresses some reservations of the European Parliament with regard to this agreement with Norway: he thus recalls that access to the internal market for any third country must be based on reciprocity. In the case of Norway, the Commission is asked to put pressure on this country so that the customs duties on agriculture, food products and fisheries that it imposes on the European Union do not go to against the principles of free trade. It is this aspect that I have a problem with because Norway cannot be blamed for protecting its internal market in order to preserve its economy and its jobs. However, I will not vote against the draft resolution because this Norwegian protectionism is being done to the detriment of the Member States of the Union. I chose to abstain.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- This agreement allows the three countries to access fish stocks beyond 4 nautical miles from the national baselines.Following the accession of the countries to the EU, the Commission became responsible for managing the agreement on behalf of these two Member States.This agreement is currently being updated to reflect developments in international fisheries law, and I therefore voted positively.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Agreement between Denmark, Norway and Sweden on reciprocal access to the Skagerrak and Kattegat entered into force on 7 August 1967.This agreement, which complements the 1980 bilateral fisheries agreement between the European Union and Norway, allowed the three parties to fish in the Skagerrak and Kattegat beyond their own baselines, but up to 4 nautical miles away.I supported the relevant proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Draft Council Decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the report to the extent that for centuries Swedish, Danish and Norwegian fishermen have fished together in these waters and species.Accession to the Union must not affect your historical fishing rights in your historical fishing grounds.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution because the new Agreement maintains the exclusive access granted to vessels from Denmark, Norway and Sweden to each other’s waters outside four nautical miles from the baselines, ensures continued reciprocal access for the two Member States and Norway to the respective waters of the other parties in the Skagerrak and Kattegat area, whilst at the same time, ensuring sound conservation and management measures for fisheries in the area. Furthermore, it allows for control measures in harmony with the principles of normal Coastal State jurisdiction, as is already the case for fisheries in the North Sea.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it is the political resolution that supports the shared management agreement for the fishery resources located in the Skagerrak and Kattegat.These two straits are what separate the waters of the Baltic from the waters of the North Sea, it is a fishing area where fishermen traditionally follow the schools of fish regardless of the border line of the countries involved.As it is a shared fishing area with Norway, the Union is responsible for developing this type of agreement with third countries.As it is an agreement to allow traditional fishing methods and to respect principles of reciprocity and sustainability in these areas, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor because the agreement maintains the historical fishing rights of fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the Kattegat and Skagerrak, without prejudice to the rights of fishermen from other countries, while at the same time ensuring that appropriate measures are taken for fisheries management and conservation inthese waters.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The update, proposed by Norway, aims to bring the old agreement into line with the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 1995 United Nations Agreement on Fish Populations, namely in terms of control devices, or on maritime conservation and management issues.This agreement, with the respective updates, contributes to reinforce the historical rights of fishermen in the region, regardless of their nationality, considering that fish populations do not respect administrative jurisdictions and that fishing activity depends on access to resources.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing.- I supported the non-legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fisheries in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.Unlike the resolution on the direct conclusion of a new agreement between the EU and the Kingdom of Norway and the legal conditions for reciprocal fishing in the Skaggerak area, this report was drawn up on its own initiative by a political statement.With this statement, the European Parliament reminded Norway, which is not a Member State of the European Union, of its customs obligations in respect of food products.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report with a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway on reciprocal access to fishing in the Skagerrak for vessels flying the flag of Denmark, Norway and Sweden.I support the conclusion of the agreement, as it recognizes the historical fishing rights of fishermen from Denmark, Norway and Sweden in the Kattegat and Skagerrak areas, without prejudice to the rights of fishermen from other countries, and ensures that appropriate measures are taken to manage and conserve fisheries in these waters.The agreement also supports the implementation of a reformed EU fisheries management system set up in line with the objectives and basic principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy, in particular the introduction of landing obligations and mandatory measures to keep fish stocks above levels that maximize sustainable yields.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The report concerns possible strategic cooperation between Europol and Georgia, including on the exchange of personal data.It must be said that this year Parliament approved the new Europol regulation and also new regulations regarding the protection and exchange of personal data.When these regulations come into force in 2017, the Parliament will enjoy an enhanced role, being able to express an opinion and not just consensus as is currently the case.For this reason I have decided to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against this Agreement between Georgia and the European agency Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation. I am opposed, because it advocates the extension of Europol's operational scope, and my position is contrary to the existence of that Agency, as it does not act with the transparency and guarantees necessary for an institution of this type. Serious concerns have been expressed about the lack of political or judicial responsibility to which Europol is subjected. Furthermore, the lack of clarity on the subject of exchanging sensitive data, including personal data, of European citizens with third countries is something that is impossible to approve, since the protection of personal data and the rights of citizens are in doubt. On the other hand, from a geopolitical point of view, this agreement with Georgia is part of the Union's strategy of tightening relations with Russia, which I oppose, considering this neighbor as a strategic and necessary partner.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Georgia and Europol. This agreement provides for the exchange of information (including personal data), expertise, general situation reports, the results of strategic analyzes, crime prevention techniques and assistance in specific investigations into criminal offenses. Europol's Joint Supervisory Body, composed of national data protection authorities with law enforcement competence, taking into account the level of data protection in Georgia, has expressed its support for the conclusion of this cooperation agreement. Europol has a clear operational need for closer cooperation with Georgia. According to Europol, Georgia's role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime is growing, as it is a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a crucial partner in the fight against Georgian organized crime groups. I also voted in favor, given that the conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Georgia would help to strengthen and strengthen the fight against terrorism and organized crime, which is in itself international.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Georgia and Europol, as it is an important development in the field of security of European citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - In order to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, Europol has initiated the procedure for concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Georgia. The terms of cooperation governed by the operational and strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information which may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures and information. on methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. In addition, the agreement contains provisions relating to the exchange of personal data. In principle, with my colleagues from the National Front, we oppose the exchange of personal data of French citizens, so we are opposed to all the operational agreements that Europol wants to conclude with third countries. So I opposed this agreement.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am against Europol and its influence over Member States in the EU. This report aims to further promote Europol and build ties with a third country, which will further erode UK national sovereignty. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I spoke in favor of this report because I believe today that Europol needs to strengthen its operational collaboration with Georgia.This country now plays an important role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime as it is a transit country for foreign fighters.The conclusion of such an agreement would therefore facilitate and intensify the fight against these scourges.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol by the European Police Office (Europol).According to Europol, Georgia is playing an increasingly important role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, as it is a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a key partner in the fight against Georgian organized crime groups.In this context, I support the conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Georgia.This would help and strengthen the fight against terrorism and organized crime, which is in itself international.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- In order to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, Europol has initiated the procedure for concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Georgia.Cooperation would relate, among other things, to the exchange of information and in particular of personal information: I am opposed to this information concerning French citizens being shared.In the same way, I will speak out against all similar operational agreements that Europol would like to conclude with third countries.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because it will strengthen the exchange of information between Georgia and Europol.According to Europol, Georgia plays an important role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime as it is a transit country for foreign fighters.Therefore, a strengthening of the operational collaboration between Europol and Georgia is necessary.The information exchanged will include personal data (but with adequate control), specialist knowledge, general reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on prevention methods.of crime.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. - Georgia is a key partner of the European Union in the framework of the Eastern Partnership. The Moraes report, which I supported today, endorses the agreement on strategic cooperation between Europol and Georgia, further strengthening ties with the country and enhancing the common commitment to security and the fight against organized crime. In particular, the approved text will allow for a broader exchange of information on specialist knowledge, reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures and training activities. Collaboration on issues such as the fight against terrorism and organized crime will be strengthened, taking particular account of the fact that the former Soviet republic is now a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a key partner in the fight against organized criminal groups. . The agreement will also provide for the exchange of personal data.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The proposal refers to the approval of the conclusion of an Agreement between Georgia and Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation. As happened in the November session with the proposal for a similar Agreement with Ukraine (although in this case the chapter on the exchange of personal data is not included), Georgia, in addition to being a piece of the geopolitical game between the Union, the USA. The United States and Russia are still a country that is far from reaching the standards required by the Union's regulations regarding human rights; criterion that our group takes into account when approving any cooperation agreement. On the other hand, the European Parliament has voted a new Regulation for Europol that will enter into force next year, in which the Cooperation Agreements will be established through a much more transparent procedure than the current one. There are not enough reasons to hastily approve an agreement with a country for which we do not have sufficient democratic and legal guarantees. Therefore, I have voted against.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: written.- I want to thank the rapporteur for his work on the Agreement between Georgia and Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation.I have abstained in this report as we have been doing as a Group in all the country agreements with Europol, since the new Europol regulation is being negotiated and it would make more sense if it were to wait until then and that they all enter into the same review.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this report on the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol.My main point of opposition concerns in particular the exchange of personal data, a principle to which I am firmly opposed as it endangers the freedom of citizens, in particular their right to privacy.I also think that this measure is useless in terms of the fight against crime or terrorism: it leads to suspecting all citizens of offenses or crimes whose perpetrators are, in general, already known to the services.I would like to stress, however, that I am not against exchanges of information, in particular on criminal investigation procedures or on methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities, as well as the provision of advice andsupport in specific criminal investigations.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- I supported with my vote the proposed agreement on strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol, which concerns the exchange of operational information but excludes the exchange of personal data.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the draft Council Implementing Decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement between Georgia and Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation. According to Europol, there are clear operational needs for further operational cooperation with Georgia. Georgia's role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime has become increasingly important, in particular since the country has become a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a key partner in the fight against organized crime groups. This agreement provides for an exchange of information, including personal data. The information exchanged could include specialized knowledge, general situation reports, results of strategic analysis, among others.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report on the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol. Under the current Council Decision establishing Europol, the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third States or international organizations is approved by the Council after consulting the European Parliament. Such agreements may involve the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The operational cooperation agreement also covers the exchange of personal data. This proposal is linked to the proposal to approve an operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Georgia, which provides for the exchange of information, including personal data. This information could include expertise, general situation reports, the results of strategic analyzes, criminal investigation procedures, crime prevention methods and assistance with specific criminal investigations.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing.- The exchange of information with law enforcement authorities of third country partners is crucial for the successful fight against transnational organized crime.According to the European Police Office (Europol), Georgia is playing an increasingly important role in the fight against organized crime and more specific crimes related to drugs or the economy, as well as trafficking and smuggling of human beings and mobile (migrant) organized crime groups.The agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and Georgia will allow for the necessary exchange of information and the organization of crime prevention activities and training.Europol clearly needs to deepen its cooperation with Georgia, which is why I voted in favor of the initiative.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written.- I support this Report on the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Georgia and Europol.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- I do not accept the exchange of personal data of French citizens and therefore I am opposed to all operational agreements that Europol wants to conclude with third countries.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report over concern about human rights in Georgia. I have always opposed such arrangements between Europol and third countries when the human rights standards in the third country in question are poor.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing.- The operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Georgia and Europol is an act to be welcomed positively, useful for positively strengthening cooperation in a difficult moment in the history of the Republic of Georgia, within the framework of the best strategic and operational cooperation between the Member States of theEuropean Union and allied countries with a view to improving the efficiency of the fight against terrorism, mafias, smuggling and international crime.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. - Europol has initiated a procedure aimed at concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Georgia in order to increase efficiency in preventing and combating crime. The terms of this cooperation provide for the exchange of information including general reports, the results of strategic analyzes and information relating to criminal investigation procedures as well as to crime prevention methods. However, the agreement also includes exchanges of personal data which we strongly oppose. We consider that improving efficiency in the fight against organized crime depends rather on the ability of Member States to regain their territorial sovereignty without which governments cannot eradicate criminal and terrorist networks that use the porosity of national borders to proliferate. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - The agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol envisages the establishment of a cooperative relationship for the exchange of information, including personal data. The information may also be in the field of expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods and support in certain criminal investigations. Given the importance of Georgia in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, given that it is a country of transition for so-called foreign combatants and a key partner in the fight against organized crime groups in Georgia, it is necessary to deepen cooperation. operational with Georgia. I am in favor of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement between Georgia and Europol because I consider it to be an essential tool in the fight against terrorism and organized crime.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol. Georgia is of increasing importance in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, more specifically because it is a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a key partner in the fight against Georgian organized criminal groups. The conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Georgia will help and strengthen the fight against terrorism and organized crime. The terms of the cooperation include the exchange of information which may include specialist knowledge, general reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods as well as support for individual criminal investigations.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on the conclusion of an international agreement for the exchange of technical or classified information with Georgia.  Sinn Féin rejects cooperation agreements of Europol with certain third countries with poor human rights records. In all matters of judicial and law enforcement cooperation, we have always advocated that such cooperation can only happen when there are high human rights standards in place (fair trial rights, defence rights, judicial oversight, etc.), and this is not the case with Georgia.  In addition, the European Parliament has recently voted on a new Europol Regulation which should ensure that such agreements are concluded in a much more transparent way. The fact that the Council has chosen to rush this agreement through under the old regime raises questions.  For these reasons, I voted against.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP do no support Europol as an institution and do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as there seems to be clear operational need for Europol to deepen its operational cooperation with Georgia. According to Europol, Georgia is increasingly relevant in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, more specifically since it is a transit country of so-called foreign fighters and a vital partner in the fight against Georgian organised criminal groups. From that perspective, the conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Georgia would thus aid and reinforce the fight against terrorism and organised crime, which is international by definition.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The new regulation of the agency for the conclusion of international agreements of strategic cooperation between Europol and third countries, which will enter into force in 2017, provides for a new procedure in which the role of the Parliament is enhanced.Indeed, the new procedure requires Parliament to express an opinion and not give a simple consent as is the case at the moment.Being fully convinced of the importance of full Parliament involvement, we have decided to abstain.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing.- Europol has taken on a key role in fighting cross-border crime and terrorist organizations.It is therefore our duty to facilitate any strategic agreement that contributes to increasing its investigative effectiveness and operational capabilities.I believe that strategic cooperation with Georgia will be an essential resource for jointly addressing common security challenges in Europe - including that of terrorism - through the exchange of information, the creation of contact points and training programs.For these reasons, I decided to vote in favor of the report, albeit with the regret of not having seen the European Parliament have a stronger role in the negotiation of the agreement.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We support the report, as there are clear operational needs of Europol to deepen operational cooperation with Georgia.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of the report on the approval by Europol of the operational and strategic cooperation agreement with Georgia.Despite the obvious need for deeper cooperation with all countries in the wider perimeter of the European Union, with a view to consolidating security conditions, I believe that we must focus particularly on issues of personal data protection and respect for individual freedoms.As this is not achieved with this Report, I decided to vote against.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - On January 26, the existence of an Isis training camp in the Pankisi gorge, 160 km from Tbilisi, an area considered a hotbed of instability and a center for the recruitment of fighters for Daesh itself, was ascertained. In fact, at the dissolution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Pankisi, in particular, was overwhelmed by ungovernability, thus becoming a transit area for weapons and Chechen rebel groups adhering to a radical vision of Islam. In the face of situations of urgent gravity, I can only rejoice and fully share the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Georgia since it provides for the exchange of information regarding forms of know-how and best practices to be adopted for establish effective strategies in the fight against terrorism and organized crime. Indeed, the sharing of strategic analyzes, of information related to the procedures of criminal investigations, to methods of crime prevention is envisaged. All this is also accompanied by joint support in individual criminal investigations and the exchange of personal data.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Georgia and Europol.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing.- Within the scope of its mandate, Europol can conclude agreements with third countries and other organizations in order to establish avenues for cooperation, especially in the fight against organized crime and terrorism.In this context, it is up to Parliament - given the agreement reached - to consent to its signature by Europol.This is how you give your consent, demonstrating compliance with all legal requirements and ensuring all safeguards for European citizens.This agreement with Georgia is of particular importance in the context of combating terrorism, given that it is increasingly a transit country for so-called “Foreign fighters”.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP do no support Europol as an institution and do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the agreement as the measure in question provides for important aspects of operational cooperation between Georgia and the EU such as: the exchange of information that may include specialist knowledge, general reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods as well as support for individual criminal investigations.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted against this Agreement between Georgia and the European agency Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation. I am opposed, because it advocates the extension of Europol's operational scope, and my position is contrary to the existence of that Agency, as it does not act with the transparency and guarantees necessary for an institution of this type. Serious concerns have been expressed about the lack of political or judicial responsibility to which Europol is subjected. Furthermore, the lack of clarity on the subject of exchanging sensitive data, including personal data, of European citizens with third countries is something that is impossible to approve, since the protection of personal data and the rights of citizens are in doubt. On the other hand, from a geopolitical point of view, this agreement with Georgia is part of the Union's strategy of tightening relations with Russia, which I oppose, considering this neighbor as a strategic and necessary partner.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol is essential for preventing cross-border crime and supporting individual criminal investigations.Indeed, Georgia is of increasing importance in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, more specifically because it is a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a key partner in the fight against Georgian organized criminal groups.The terms of the cooperation include the exchange of information which may include specialist knowledge, general reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: signed up.- There is a clear operational need for Europol to deepen its operational cooperation with Georgia.According to Europol, Georgia is becoming increasingly relevant in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, being a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a key partner in the fight against organized crime groups in Georgia.I voted in favor of the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information between Europol and Georgia, for a more effective fight against organized crime, which has, by definition, an international character.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - Under the current Council Decision on Europol, the EP's proposal is that the Council, after consulting the EP, should approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third countries or international organizations. Europol has a clear operational need to deepen its operational cooperation with Georgia. According to Europol, Georgia is becoming increasingly important in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, precisely because of the so-called a transit country for foreign fighters and a vital partner in the fight against Georgian criminal organizations. In this respect, the conclusion of this strategic cooperation agreement with Georgia will help and strengthen the fight against terrorism and organized crime. The agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and Georgia, which I voted in favor of, concerns the exchange of information. This information may include the area of ​​expertise, general situation reports, the results of strategic analysis and information on criminal investigation procedures and methods, as well as the provision of support for specific criminal investigations.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing.- With regard to providing an effective means of exchanging information, including personal data, I voted in favor of the report on the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Georgia.The development of cooperation in the operational and strategic scope serves to increase the level of security and increases the effectiveness of activities in the fight against terrorism.Georgia is a key partner of the EU in the Eastern Partnership, and security and the fight against crime are the basic imperatives for the full achievement of the objectives of this cooperation.I strongly support the strengthening of operational cooperation with Georgia, and therefore also support the adoption of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, and there are clear operational needs for Europol to deepen its operational cooperation with Georgia. According to Europol, Georgia is increasingly relevant in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, more specifically since it is a transit country for foreign fighters and a vital partner in the fight against Georgian organised criminal groups. The conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Georgia would thus aid and reinforce the fight against terrorism and organised crime.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the adoption of the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Co-Operation between Georgia and Europol. I have long been supportive of Europol and its work. The fight against serious crime and terrorism goes beyond the borders of the EU, and that international cooperation is essential.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing.- This consultation report proposes the positive opinion of the European Parliament on the operational and strategic agreement between Europol and Georgia providing for the exchange of information, including personal data.This information may relate to expert knowledge, general status reports, or the results of strategic analyzes.Considering that this report aims to improve the effectiveness of the prevention of terrorist attacks and of public safety, I voted in favor.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this legislative report. UKIP do no support Europol as an institution and do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol, the European Police Office.While the Europol agency plays a fundamental role in the fight against terrorism at European level, we must step up its action through better cooperation with third countries.Better exchange of information with Georgia, which is not only an important partner in the fight against organized crime, but also a transit country for foreign fighters who have joined terrorist organizations, is essential to complete the European security arsenal..

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of Parliament's approval of the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol. The objective of this agreement is to support and strengthen the action of the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in the prevention of organized crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime. It provides for the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information. In order to be able to demonstrate greater effectiveness in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, and in particular taking into account the fact that Georgia is a close neighbor State of the Union, with which Georgia maintains many links and has many exchanges, it seemed to me opportune for our police agency to conclude such an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Georgia.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.In order to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, Europol has initiated the procedure for concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Georgia.The information concerned by these exchanges is, in particular, the following: expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in criminal investigation activities.training, as well as the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations.We oppose the exchange of personal information, which is provided for in particular under the agreement.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - This report is for an operational and strategic agreement between Europol and Georgia. It will provide a means for better exchange of information, including personal data. There is an operational need for Europol to deepen operational cooperation with Georgia, which is a key partner of the European Union in the Eastern Partnership. This agreement will help fight crime, which is one of the main tasks in order to fully achieve the goals of this partnership. I believe that Georgia can be our good ally in the fight for more security, and that is why I voted in favor of the report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The act demonstrates that commitments in the areas of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other. The agreement does not really strengthen the risk-based approach nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default, taking into account international practice but mainly the degree of protection of personal data by the Georgian authorities.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the agreement between Georgia and Europol. Europol assists EU Member States in combating organised crime in the European Union. As organised crime does not stop at national borders, it is essential to have cooperation with non—EU countries and international organisations. Better cooperation would have a positive impact on political, social economic integration in Georgia itself. This agreement is in the interests of my constituents in Wales.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- This report concerns the proposed approval of an operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Georgia, which provides for the exchange of information, including personal data.Such information may include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures, as well as methods of crime prevention, as well as support in certain criminal investigations.There also seems to be a clear need for Europol to deepen its cooperation with Georgia, as it plays an increasingly important role in the fight against organized crime, especially as it is a transit country for so-called foreign fighters and a partnerfundamental role in the fight against organized crime groups.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Europol is a European Union agency that fits into a federalist view of the European integration process, with the main objective of enforcing the law. A structure that, on the margins of the Member States, imposes itself and overlaps them, their sovereignty and the autonomy of their own security forces. This is in contrast to the natural and desirable cooperation between States and their police and judicial authorities. This report proposes the approval of an “Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Europol and Georgia”, which provides for the exchange of information, including personal data. Such information may include expertise, general situation reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures, as well as methods of crime prevention, as well as support in certain criminal investigations. In addition to more general objections regarding the role of Europol, in this case Georgia's geopolitical framework constitutes yet another front of confrontation and encirclement of the Russian Federation, in a context of destabilization and wars promoted by the USA and the EU in the Middle East, with emphasis on Syria today. We vote against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Georgia and Europol, as it helps and strengthens the fight against terrorism and organized crime.In fact, Georgia is of increasing importance in combating these phenomena, more specifically because it is a transit country for foreign fighters and is a key partner in the fight against Georgian organized criminal groups.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted no because I disagree.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- According to several available information, Georgia will play a very important role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime in the future, as it is a transit country and there are also a relatively large number of organized criminal groups.That is why it is already very important today for Europol to deepen and improve its strategic cooperation with Georgia, which the new agreement in question should help.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report because I believe an exchange of operational, strategic and technical information between countries is useful.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - The act demonstrates that commitments in the areas of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other. The agreement does not really strengthen the risk-based approach nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default, taking into account international practice but mainly the degree of protection of personal data by the Georgian authorities. For the above reasons, I am voting against the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Georgia and Europol.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: In written form. - I voted in favor of the adoption of this report, as Georgia has the potential to be a key EU partner in the fight against organized crime, including human trafficking, terrorism and corruption. In this context, the conclusion of the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Georgia and Europol is a decisive step that can make a significant contribution to a more effective fight against international organized crime. Enhanced security cooperation between the European Union, its Member States and Georgia is also of strategic importance in connection with the mobility of European and Georgian citizens and the finalization of the visa liberalization process for Georgian citizens. That is why I support the conclusion of the Strategic and Operational Cooperation Agreement with Georgia.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing.- The exchange of information with law enforcement authorities of third country partners is crucial for the successful fight against transnational organized crime.According to the European Police Office (Europol), Georgia is playing an increasingly important role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime, precisely because of the so-calleda transit country for foreign fighters and a vital partner in the fight against Georgian criminal organizations.An agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and Ukraine would help and strengthen the fight against terrorism and organized crime, which is essentially international in nature.Europol clearly needs to deepen its cooperation with Georgia, which is why, as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I voted in favor of the initiative.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP resolution on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol given the need to speed up police and judicial cooperation with this country, which plays a key role in the fight against organized crime inside and outside the EU. As Parliament, we have expressed our will to move forward with this vote, but we have given precise conditions to the Council and the Commission, given the procedure adopted for the signing of the agreement which limits parliamentary scrutiny to mere consultation. We therefore ask the European Commission to reassess the provisions of the agreement when the new legislation on Europol comes into force, and to present a complete assessment to the other institutions, allowing Parliament to exercise the new powers that will come into force on 1 May of 2017. Regardless of procedural issues, the fact remains that cooperation with Georgian police authorities, also with regard to the exchange of personal data and relevant information, is essential to ensure an effective fight against organized crime inside and outside the country. 'EU.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: written.- As a transit country for foreign fighters, Georgia plays a crucial role in the fight against terrorism and organized crime.The agreement is intended to intensify the strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this legislative report as I do not support Europol as an institution and do not support the EU concluding agreements with third countries.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal, which concerns the approval of an operational and strategic agreement between Europol and Georgia, providing for the exchange of information, including personal data. Georgia is increasingly relevant in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, more specifically since it is a transit country of so-called foreign fighters and a vital partner in the fight against Georgian organised criminal groups.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - The proposal refers to the approval of the conclusion of an Agreement between Georgia and Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation. As happened in the November session with the proposal for a similar Agreement with Ukraine (although in this case the chapter on the exchange of personal data is not included), Georgia, in addition to being a piece of the geopolitical game between the Union, the USA. The United States and Russia are still a country that is far from reaching the standards required by the Union's regulations regarding human rights; criterion that our group takes into account when approving any cooperation agreement. On the other hand, the European Parliament has voted a new Regulation for Europol that will enter into force next year, in which the Cooperation Agreements will be established through a much more transparent procedure than the current one. There are not enough reasons to hastily approve an agreement with a country for which we do not have sufficient democratic and legal guarantees. Therefore, I have voted against.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: in writing.- The Europol-Georgia cooperation agreement provides for the exchange of operational, strategic, technical, personal or classified information between the European Police Office and Georgia.This agreement is of particular importance given the growing role of Georgia in the fight against terrorism and organized crime.Since 2015, my parliamentary group has been of the opinion to wait for the entry into force of the new Europol regulation, scheduled for May 2017, before concluding new cooperation agreements.Sharing this opinion, I therefore decided to abstain from this vote just as I did with the previous operational and strategic cooperation agreements of Europol with China, the United Arab Emirates, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the United Arab Emirates.'Ukraine.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, as there are clear operational needs for Europol to deepen its cooperation with Georgia. This strategic cooperation agreement with Georgia would aid and reinforce the fight against organised crime and would contribute to enhancing international law enforcement co-operation.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Although the issue of the exchange of personal data did not arise in this report, we have always been critical of the Europol agreements. We fully support the fight against organized crime and trafficking in human beings. At the same time, however, we want to see police cooperation at the state level. This agreement is more political and is part of creating pressure on Russia and increasing EU policy in Georgia. For these reasons we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal concerns the proposed approval of an operational and strategic agreement between Europol and Georgia, providing for the exchange of information, including personal data. Such information could be in the field of specialist knowledge, general situation reports, results of strategic analysis, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime-prevention methods, and support in individual criminal investigations. I therefore support the conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Georgia would thus aid and reinforce the fight against terrorism and organized crime, which is international by definition.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: in writing.- I am pleased that the European Parliament has authorized the conclusion of a technical, strategic and operational cooperation agreement between Georgia and Europol.This cooperation is all the more important given that Georgia is at the gates of Turkey and Armenia, near a region in turmoil including Iran, Syria and Iraq, which places itat a strategic crossroads for criminal networks and terrorists.Also, this cooperation is fundamental insofar as the nuisance capacity of these criminal networks, traffickers and terrorists, including foreign fighters returning from Syria, goes far beyond European borders.Therefore, the fight against these scourges is a common struggle that can only be waged collectively through the exchange of information and the provision of material, human and operational support.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Georgia and Europol concerning the proposal for the approval of an operational and strategic agreement between the two.This report provides for the exchange of information, including the exchange of personal data.The conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Georgia would thus support and intensify the fight against terrorism and organized crime.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
