The reason for this is excessive taxes and bureaucracy and poor conditions due to which large producers do not decide to stay in the European Union. I believe that the European Union will not be able to recover the economy with the proposed policies of retraining workers, because these measures cannot help the recovery of the affected sectors, in this case the automotive sector. Considering that the proposed measures represent only a short-term solution for both redundant workers and the European Union economy, I voted against this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (role of Spain - EGF / 2016/004 EC / Comunidad Valenciana, automotive industry).The European Globalization Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.On 8 November 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF in favor of Spain to support the reintegration into the labor market of workers made redundant as a result of the bankruptcy and closure of Bosal S.A.This company operated from 1986 to 2015, when they were declared bankrupt.Its main activity was the production of parts and accessories for motor vehicles.The company got into trouble after production in the automotive industry fell.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. - Spain has submitted this request with a view to obtaining a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies in the automotive sector, involving a total of 29 companies. 250 redundant workers likely to benefit from a contribution from the Fund should participate in the measures in question here. Moreover, it should be noted that 50% of the dismissed employees concerned do not have a diploma, and that the economic context in the region is particularly catastrophic. The funds released will finance (globally up to 25%) actions such as information sessions, professional guidance, professional integration programs, entrepreneurship promotion campaigns, or allowances and incentives intended for dismissed workers. , contributions to their travel and moving expenses, hiring subsidies. I am obviously in favor of a state recovering the money it pays to the EU, in particular if this allows it to repair, even insufficiently, the immense damage caused by the total opening of borders. I voted for.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- The fund helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade patterns, for example when a large company closes a factory or is relocated outside the EU, or there is a global financial and economic crisis.All possibilities of helping the aggrieved workers should be supported, which is why I supported the proposal.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- The European Globalization Adjustment Fund has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.I voted in favor of the related proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report, which promotes funds intended to compensate and establish measures to promote job search in cases of relocation or company closures due to globalization. They will serve to address the situation of workers laid off in the Valencian Community (Bosal S.A.), in the already affected area of ​​Sagunto by industrial restructuring, with high levels of unemployment. These are measures that, if they did not exist, would leave the affected workers in a worse place. The vote in favor, however, does not hide our concern about the judicial process opened for alleged unfair administration of the company and that these funds are used to disguise processes of relocation of companies that are profitable. We consider, as we have stated in our amendments, that the funds for adaptation to globalization should be configured in accordance with reindustrialization strategies, applying measures to support workers affected by restructuring due to the non-viability of production, with a greater weight of public investments that make the productive sectors of the affected regions sustainable, helping to change the production model and guarantee the future of the productive sectors.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written.- The European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF) was introduced in 2007 as a flexible instrument through which the Union budget supports, under specific conditions, those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes inthe patterns of world trade, caused by globalization or by the economic and financial crisis spread globally.Through this report, the European Parliament supports the Commission's proposal to allocate € 856,800 from the European Globalization Adjustment Fund to 250 workers in the automotive sector.In the firm conviction that the Union's commitment to unemployed citizens must be translated into concrete actions, I voted in favor of this decision.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- This report refers to the contribution of the EGF fund in individual support measures for the reintegration of 250 workers laid off at the Bosal plant in Sagunto, of which 25% will be direct income support measures and the rest activitiestraining and job placement.These measures cannot in any case replace the need to develop an industrial policy that helps the region's economy, with unemployment above 25%, to recover from this closure.Nor do they exempt Bosal from its responsibility in this ERE, when instead of using the subsidies received and the benefits of its activity to invest in its plant, it decapitalized the company in a probably irregular way.But they suppose, at least, an aid to the unemployed workers and for that reason I voted in favor.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Spain to support the reintegration in the labour market of the workers made redundant after the bankruptcy and closure of Bosal S.A. The EGF (annual budget of max EUR 150 million) provides assistance in cases of more than 500 employees being made redundant (of 1 company or in 1 sector in a regional context) as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Types of assistance include job search, career advice, education, (re-)training, entrepreneurship, mobility etc., whereas co-financing of passive social protection measures is prohibited.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor because the European Parliament welcomes Spain's decision to offer training measures for obtaining certificates of competence, such as the passenger transport certificate, as well as for sectors or areas that offer or will offer opportunities, such as the food sector, therestaurant business, occupational risk prevention, quality control and environmental standards, heating, ventilation and air conditioning projects, and industrial equipment maintenance.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report approves the payment of a contribution of 856,800 euros to finance the professional reintegration of 250 workers made redundant by Bosal SA and its subcontractors in Sagunto (Valencian Community - Spain). However, the Public Prosecutor's Office of Valencia asked on November 24 that the multinational be found guilty of embezzlement, Bosal SA being suspected of having worsened its state of insolvency by legacy operations and the transmission of their assets (but no liabilities to group companies or related) in order to be able to declare bankruptcy and relocate production to Mexico without paying compensation due to employees. Bosal SA could be ordered to pay 15 million euros in compensation to employees. In this context and knowing that the multinational in question makes between 500 million and 1 billion euros in profits per year, I want to say that it is unacceptable that the European Union pays such a contribution which should be paid by Bosal SA. I have nevertheless decided to abstain, fearing that failing this, it will be the employees of Bosal SA who will once again pay the consequences of their employer's abuse, but I regret that the reimbursement of the sums paid in the event of a final conviction will not be not asked the company.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This application concerns 250 workers made redundant in 29 companies in the economic sectors. Spain has lost a significant market share in the last decade and one of the main factors behind this trend is the geographical transition of consumption associated with globalization, in particular the rapid growth of demand in the Asian market, which compromises EU manufacturers, which traditionally are not well positioned in these markets. In addition, European industry was also affected by the decline in domestic demand, due to the economic and financial crisis, with a lower number of vehicle registrations than those reached during the years before the crisis. Since 2008, due to the combined effect of these two factors on car manufacturing, many companies in Sagunto have closed or severely reduced their activity, resulting in redundancies or reductions in working time. We agree with the rapid mobilization of this aid, but we continue to affirm that only the break with the policies that are being followed by the EU will be able to stop this path of social and economic disaster

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- 856,000 EUR are to be made available here to reintegrate 250 workers from the former Borsal S.A., a supplier of auto parts in the Valencia region, into the labor market and to create new perspectives for the workers concerned.Since the EU is supposed to provide funding here to integrate these workers into the labor market, I have approved this report.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Spain submitted an application last June for the mobilization of the EGF in relation to redundancies in the Comunidad Valenciana region for the economic sector which refers to "Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers". The company affected is Bosal S.A., which is mainly active in the manufacture of parts and accessories for motor vehicles. It should be emphasized that this is the 23rd request for the mobilization of the EGF for the automotive manufacturing sector, demonstrating a clear contraction of the sector at European level. In fact, in 2015, the EU27 recorded a 0.5 million unit drop in motor vehicle production compared to 2006, while world production increased by 31.1% at the same time. In Spain, on the other hand, the decline in car production caused a reduction in both the number of companies and jobs, and in the Comunidad Valenciana in particular, out of a total of 187 companies in the sector, 62 went out of business in the period 2008-2014. I generally vote in favor of the requests regarding the EGF, although I am aware that it cannot be the solution to corporate crises. However, being the only option currently on the table, I believe it is fair to support it.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: written.- The PVV voted against the provision of funds from the Globalization Fund because the problems of the ES / Comunidad Valencia automotive sector cannot be directly attributed to globalization, which is a requirement.In addition, according to the European Commission, there is no longer an economic crisis in the EU, so that this crisis can no longer be a reason for allocating money from the Globalization Fund to ES / Comunidad.In addition, multinationals do not need to be rewarded with financing from a social plan if they cut jobs.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I did not support the draft decision, which recommended responding to Spain's request to mobilize the European Globalization Adjustment Fund, to provide EUR 856 000 from this fund. Spain has requested funding because, as a result of changes in world trade, Valencia's car industry is being forced to lay off 250 workers. I think that changes in world trade are indeed having a very negative effect on the number of employees, or even entire regions, where the number of employees is redundant as a result of the closure or reduction of production. I also think that it is necessary to help these dismissed employees as soon as possible. On the other hand, however, I do not think that the European Globalization Adjustment Fund is the right instrument for this. Even after the preparation of an extensive evaluation report, we did not find out how many redundant employees were able to find a new job thanks to this fund, and whether they were not re-employed only because of their skills and expertise. It is also a fact that re-employability varies greatly from country to country and depends more on the capabilities of the country or region than on assistance from the Fund. That is why I am of the opinion that, unless the data relating to this fund are sufficiently identified and evaluated, we should focus on other tools rather than helping these redundant workers.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written.- I support Esteban Gonzalez's report on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund, a request made by Spain.The very purpose of this fund was to help workers who became redundant after the bankruptcy and closure of Bosal SA, a company from Spain.In this regard, it was essential to help these people slowly reintegrate into the labor market.We are aware of today's crisis in economic flows.This often results in workers being fired.These workers need help.Therefore, the European Union offers assistance in various ways and through programs.That is why the European Globalization Adjustment Fund was created.Commission document COM (2016) 0708 proposed the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 856 800 to 250 workers declared redundant in the economic sector.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund (EGF).I agree that Spain is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 856 800 from the EGF, which will enable the re-integration into the labor market of 250 redundant workers who are more difficult to employ due to their age and low level of education.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, rail transport in Europe has changed, railway companies can provide services throughout the Union.The high-speed rail network has expanded very rapidly for the benefit of economies and, of course, for the benefit of citizens.50 years ago the alternative was between plane and train, today fortunately we can count on a variety of options in terms of rail transport.The 1969 Infrastructure Management Regulation has become incompatible with Union law.I therefore support a liberalized market in which all companies use and are required to apply the same rules, but in a competitive environment.It is also necessary to have fair competition between railway undertakings, precisely to facilitate the entry of new companies into the rail transport market.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The following report is part of the governance project of the fourth railway package and is mainly concerned with the normalization of the accounts of railway companies in Europe.In this sense, the report proposes to repeal the regulation in force until now, despite the fact that a transition period is granted for some types of compensation and exceptions are inserted.I believe that the need to reform the normalization mechanism for companies operating in the railway sector is clear, which is why I voted against the rejection amendment.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote on this report, as it is a second reading text from the Council.Had he been able to vote, he would not have done so in the affirmative, because despite its technical nature (obsolete regulations on aid to public railway companies are eliminated) its effect is to formally equalize public railway operators with private ones, in order to prepare for liberalizationand privatization of the sector in line with the rest of the fourth railway package.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted against the amendments rejecting the Council's position. I support the proposal to standardize the accounting of railway undertakings. The current Regulation no. Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 on the general rules for the accounting of railway undertakings, which the Commission proposes to repeal, allows Member States to compensate railway undertakings for payment obligations which they do not have to bear. Those obligations may relate, for example, to special payments in the event of accidents at work (the railway undertaking must pay them, but in the case of other modes of transport they are paid by the State). The regulation was adopted before the liberalization of the railway market, i.e. y. at a time when European rail transport was developing primarily in Member States with integrated companies that provided both rail services and infrastructure management. At the time, the regulation sought to ensure a level playing field between railway undertakings and other modes of transport in terms of social costs. For the original purposes of the Regulation, it contains a list of previously state-owned railway companies. This list has been adjusted several times to take account of the accession of new Member States and now includes 40 companies. However, the Commission notes that this Regulation no longer takes into account the current legal environment of non-discrimination against non-listed companies, as only 40 companies listed in the Annex to this Regulation are eligible for compensation. I therefore support the Commission's and the Council's proposals to repeal that regulation.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report is the least consistent of the three reports that constitute the Kyllönen report, since it deals only with the repeal of the current rules on the standardization of accounts of railway undertakings.The aim of the regulation is to allow the compensation by communities of railway undertakings for the significant charges they have to pay in particular because of their collective agreements.The committee noted that due to regulatory changes that have taken place over the past 10 years, the current regulation is inadequate since it is discriminatory: it allows compensation for designated companies but not for others.I voted against this report, which is part of the market part of the 4th railway package, which should be rejected as a whole.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal to reject the Council position because I do not believe further EU interference on railway use and the normalisation of transport systems is needed as each Member State should decide how best to operate its own railway infrastructure.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal on general accounting rules for railway undertakings.The purpose of the notification is to repeal Regulation (EC) NoRegulation (EEC) No 1192/69, which allows Member States to compensate railway undertakings for payment obligations which they do not have to bear.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing.- The regulation referred to in this report is intended to allow the compensation, by communities, of railway undertakings for the significant charges they have to pay, in particular by reason of their collective agreements.The Commission has found that due to regulatory changes that have taken place over the past 10 years, the current regulation is inadequate as it is discriminatory: it allows compensation for designated companies but not for others.I voted in favor of the amendment tabled by my Front National colleague Marie-Christine Arnautu to reject the Council's proposal.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - Three texts were on the table for the vote on the fourth railway package: one on the standardization of accounts, one on governance and the last on the public service obligation. We did not reject the first two. In the report on the governance directive, we obtained respect for our red line: private competition can be limited if it undermines public service obligations. On the other hand, we firmly opposed the last text which required a more advanced liberalization of the public rail passenger transport service. This liberalization will not only be harmful for rail users, but it is also done at the expense of workers, in particular because it does not establish the automatic and compulsory transfer of staff in the event of a change of operator. For socialist MEPs, such a strong social guarantee was essential in order to ensure that competition does not come at the expense of workers' rights and does not open the way to other forms of social dumping. We led the sling in Parliament but we lost the vote to reject this text for 15 votes out of 751, the right having supported it overwhelmingly.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report to phase out legislation that has become obsolete.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted against the three reports of the railway package.Aiming at opening up national passenger transport markets, the governance report (Sassoli) has the secondary objective of increasing the supply and quality of services, making the rail market more easily accessible to new businesses.Such a policy has led to a 20% drop in rail freight in France… Worse still, the "competition" report (Van de Camp) introduces an obligation to compete, including in public service cases, by leading a real hunt forall forms of subsidies… A policy that goes against national interests and economic protectionism.The Kyllonen report aims to allow the compensation, by communities, of railway companies for the significant charges they have to pay, in particular because of their collective agreements.He is unsuitable.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing.- I preferred to express myself with an abstention to the proposed rejection presented.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation on the standardization of accounting for railway undertakings. The regulation, which the Commission is proposing to repeal, allows Member States to compensate railway undertakings for payment obligations which they do not have to bear. Those obligations may relate, for example, to special payments in the event of accidents at work (which must be paid by the railway undertaking but are paid by the State in the case of other modes of transport), pensions to railway workers who normally retire earlier due to certain heavy work, or payments for crossing infrastructure costs. At the time, the regulation sought to ensure a level playing field between railway undertakings and other modes of transport in terms of passing on social costs and externalities. Moreover, at that time, the relationship between governments and mainly state-owned railway companies was not yet regulated by contracts and the two entities had much closer ownership ties. For the original purposes of the Regulation, it contains a list of previously state-owned railway companies. This list has been adjusted several times to take account of the accession of new Member States and now includes 40 companies. As the Commission states in its proposal, this regulation no longer takes into account the current legal environment. Parliament agrees that the current text of the regulation is discriminatory, as only 40 companies listed in the annex to this regulation are eligible for compensation, so maintaining this regulation is not an option unless the list of railway companies is constantly updated.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. - This regulation, which the Commission is now proposing to repeal, has allowed Member States to compensate railway undertakings for obligations relating to obligations which are not borne by undertakings in other modes of transport. As the Commission states in its proposal, the regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I share this opinion with the Commission. I also agree that the current wording of the regulation is discriminatory, as it makes the possibility of compensation available only to the 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation. Therefore, it is not possible to keep the regulation in force. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014. At the time, the European Parliament supported the repeal of the regulation, but called for the repealing provision to enter into force only two years later. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council. Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report, which calls into question the current rules for standardizing the accounts of railway undertakings which allow local authorities to compensate them for their charges linked to collective agreements, can only lead to more social dumping by placing companies practicing aadvanced social dialogue in a weak position.For this reason, I vote against.I vote for the reject amendment.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this file, which is part of the ‘market pillar’ of the so-called ‘Fourth Railway Package’, which is aimed at entrenching market liberalisation and competition in the European railway sector. This file concerns the repeal of a regulation which currently allows Member States to compensate railway companies for payments they are obliged to make – for example for accidents at work, pensions for early retirement of workers in arduous jobs, and for costs relating to level crossing facilities. While we support improvements and reform in the railway sector, Sinn Fein opposes the Fourth Railway Package due to its heavily neoliberal, pro-market bias. In particular, the ‘Market Pillar’ involves downgrading and repealing existing provisions, minimising Member State involvement in the sector and facilitating increased liberalisation and a more competitive market, rather than focusing on improving services. While some parts of the package are purely technical and potentially useful, others are clearly politically motivated, and explicitly promote the full liberalisation of the railway sector. I therefore voted against the repeal of this regulation.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. - Studies show that interoperability and rail safety are central elements of the sustainable development model for the Europe of the future. To improve them, the ERA (European Railway Agency) was established, based in Lille and Valenciennes (France), by means of Regulation (EC) No. 881/2004 of 29 April 2004. The Agency promotes the progressive approximation, registration and monitoring of technical specifications for interoperability (TSI) throughout the European railway system and the development of common safety objectives for European railways. Although the ERA has no autonomous decision-making powers, it contributes to draft decision proposals for the European Commission. Regulation (EC) No. 1335/2008 of 16 December 2008 assigned new tasks to ERA, which are linked to the changes made to the railway safety directives (2004 / railway (2008/57 / EC). Now, with the Adoption of the fourth railway package, ERA's investigative and audit powers will finally be strengthened in the areas of its competence. This will be useful to avoid having 28 different systems for the approval of trains: the Agency will act as a one-stop shop in charge of issuing authorizations for vehicles intended for cross-border activities and safety certificates to railway companies operating in the various states of the EU.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report is an integral part of the fourth railway package and deals with the repeal of the current rules on the standardization of accounts of railway undertakings.The text aims to promote compensation, by communities, of railway undertakings for the substantial charges they have to pay, in particular because of their collective agreements.The European Commission has, in fact, found that due to regulatory changes, the current regulation is unsuitable or even discriminatory since it allows compensation only for designated companies.Firmly opposed to the railway package, I voted against this text which does not make any substantial change to the regulations in force, and I voted in favor of the rejection proposal.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. - The trialogue agreement reached at second reading repeals Regulation (EEC) no. 1192/69 concerning common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway companies. This repeal is part of the liberalization measures of the rail transport market adopted with the fourth railway package. The regulation in question authorized Member States to compensate railway undertakings for costs arising from obligations that undertakings operating in other transport sectors do not have to bear, but was adopted before the liberalization of the railway market and when rail transport in Europe it developed mainly within national borders, with integrated companies managing both rail services and rail infrastructure. At the time, the aim of the regulation was to equalize railway undertakings and undertakings operating in other modes of transport as regards the costs incurred for social expenses or externalities. The repeal was necessary because the regulation no longer respects the current legal framework.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the one amendment tabled to this report, thereby rejecting the Council position on the text.  This file is part of the ‘Market Pillar’ of the Fourth Railway Package, which I oppose as it is aimed at entrenching full liberalisation of the European railway sector. This file concerns a Council recommendation for the repeal of Regulation 1192/69, which currently allows Member States to compensate railway companies for payments they are obliged to make but other transport modes are not. These obligations include special payments for accidents at work, pensions for early retirement of workers in arduous jobs, and for costs relating to level crossing facilities. The Regulation was adopted when rail services and infrastructure were integrated and were closely related to national governments. It contains a list of (now largely formerly) state-owned railway companies, who are entitled to receive the compensation mentioned, while any companies not listed are not entitled to compensation. The Commission considers this Regulation discriminatory, and rather than suggesting the list be updated, recommends its repeal. This is the same position as the Council. Since 2007 Ireland and 3 other countries have regularly made use of this Regulation.  Therefore I voted in favour of the amendment to reject the Council’s position.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted for the rejection amendment in order to ensure that this part of the Fourth Railway package would not proceed.  This report is part of three reports that constitute the Fourth Railway package and by voting to reject the Second Reading, we were trying to ensure that the Fourth Railway package did not go ahead and thus lead to governments of Member States having their hands tied through the mandatory competitive tendering initiative of the Commission.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on agreement to the conclusion of negotiations with Council. During negotiations and consultations with stakeholders, the Rapporteur found out that there is still need for a transitional period regarding the compensations paid for level crossing facilities (Class IV) due to the fact that some Member State(s) still use this Regulation as a basis for level crossing facilities compensations. In future, Member States may continue to pay compensation for the costs of those facilities on the basis of Article 8 of Directive 2012/34/EU. They may, nevertheless, need time to amend their national law and administrative provisions to take account of the repeal of Regulation 1192/69. Therefore, the Rapporteur’s recommendation is to follow the Commission’s proposal to repeal the Regulation, with the exception of these provisions which shall continue to apply until 31 December 2017. That would give time to Member States to adapt their national legislation concerning the compensations of costs relating to certain level crossing facilities.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal which is part of the "governance" pillar of the fourth railway package which provides for the normalization of the accounts of railway companies in Europe.The text provides for the repeal of regulation no.1192/69 concerning the common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway companies, which authorizes Member States to compensate railway companies for expenses deriving from obligations that companies operating in other transport sectors do not have to bear.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing.- We are voting against the report, as we disagree with key points.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of rejecting the recommendation to repeal Regulation (EEC) No 2454/93.Council Regulation (EC) No 1192/69 on common rules for the settlement of the accounts of railway undertakings.As I consider that there are no grounds for rejecting the recommendation, I voted against.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. - The repeal of Regulation (EEC) no. 1192/69 opens further tracks to the Single Railway Market and allows for the cessation of discrimination suffered by European companies operating in the railway segment by those acting within other transport sectors. By virtue of the obsolescence acquired by the aforementioned regulation, I am voting in favor of a provision representing the third pillar of the fourth railway package. A normalization of the accounts of railway companies is therefore envisaged to compensate for the payment of obligations that others, again in the transport sector, do not have to bear. These fall into 15 categories (classes) that define their specific scope and cost calculation criteria. Overall, reference is made to charges that mainly concern special payments in the event of accidents, pensions for railway workers who carry out a markedly strenuous activity, or are connected to expenses relating to level crossing systems. In any case, the historical moment in which regulation 1192/69 was developed must be taken into consideration, i.e. before the liberalization of the market and, therefore, when rail transport operated mainly within national borders, therefore proceeding with a demonization would be a somewhat ignorant mistake, today however it has been markedly rendered inadequate by progress.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support the proposal to reject the Council position on common rules for the normalisation of the accounts of railway undertakings.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted for the rejection amendment in order to ensure that this part of the Fourth Railway package would not proceed.  This report is part of three reports that constitute the Fourth Railway package, and by voting to reject the second reading we were trying to ensure that the Fourth Railway package did not go ahead and thus lead to governments of Member States having their hands tied through the mandatory competitive tendering initiative of the Commission.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the provision that proposes to repeal Council Regulation 1192/69 laying down common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway companies as I agree with the need to adapt the legislation by updating it and eliminating possible discrimination between companies in the sector in this matter.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote on this report, as it is a second reading text from the Council.Had he been able to vote, he would not have done so in the affirmative, because despite its technical nature (obsolete regulations on aid to public railway companies are eliminated) its effect is to formally equalize public railway operators with private ones, in order to prepare for liberalizationand privatization of the sector in line with the rest of the fourth railway package.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing.- Regulation no.1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of accounts of railway undertakings which authorizes Member States to compensate railway undertakings for costs deriving from obligations that undertakings operating in other transport sectors no longer have to bear no longer respects the current legal framework.I therefore welcomed the proposal to repeal the regulation, which also has discriminatory characteristics.However, I agree with the need to ensure a transitional period as regards compensation paid for level crossing facilities (category IV), due to the fact that some Member States continue to use this Regulation as a basis for these compensations.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. - Due to the fact that the provisions of the regulation became obsolete and did not apply, I voted against the ENF's request to reject the Council's position. I am in favor of the proposal which aims to repeal Council Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 on common rules for standardizing the accounts of railway undertakings. Arrangements for compensating railway undertakings' costs were necessary in the 1960s, when national railway undertakings acted on behalf of the state or other public authority. However, with the opening of the rail market and the separation of rail transport operations from infrastructure management, Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 became incompatible with Union law. The excessive number of regulations that are outdated should be reduced. Compensation issues, where still necessary and in line with Union law, should be incorporated in more relevant Union law.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal to reject the Council position and in favour of this recommendation, as it allows Member States to compensate railway activities for the payment of obligations which activities of other transport modes do not have to support. Obligations are of special payments in the case of accidents, pensions and other payments defined in the scope.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. - This legislative report mainly aims to repeal the common rules for the standardization of the accounts of railway undertakings. Indeed, Member States could compensate railway undertakings for the payment of obligations which undertakings of other modes of transport should not finance for various reasons. The Commission considers that the regulation no longer respects the current legal framework and discriminates between railway undertakings, and therefore those which are eligible for compensation and those which are excluded from the list. Thus, the European Parliament follows the European Commission and proposes to repeal this regulation. Considering that rail transport has long been favored by the Member States because of its fragility and its necessity for European transport, but that this situation must now be restored vis-à-vis other transport, I voted in favor of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for the rejection amendment in order to ensure that this part of the Fourth Railway package would not proceed.  This report is part of three reports that constitute the Fourth Railway package, and by voting to reject the second reading we were trying to ensure that the Fourth Railway package did not go ahead and thus lead to governments of Member States having their hands tied through the mandatory competitive tendering initiative of the Commission.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of repealing the regulation on common rules for the standardization of accounts of railway companies, in order to improve the quality of rail passenger transport services.This regulation, adopted before the liberalization of rail services, is now totally unsuited to the contemporary situation of the rail services market and, with the exception of a few measures, is no longer applied by the Member States.However, measures to offset the costs of level crossings are still useful for European rail services.Therefore, and in order to allow an effective transition, it is necessary to provide, for these measures only, a transitional period until 31 December 2017.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. - This regulation, which the Commission is now proposing to repeal, has allowed Member States to compensate railway undertakings for obligations relating to obligations which are not borne by undertakings in other modes of transport. As the Commission states in its proposal, the regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I share this opinion with the Commission. I also agree that the current wording of the regulation is discriminatory, as it makes the possibility of compensation available only to the 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation. Therefore, it is not possible to keep the regulation in force. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014. At the time, the European Parliament supported the repeal of the regulation, but called for the repealing provision to enter into force only two years later. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council. Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against these three reports falling under the railway package and, consequently, for the amendments requiring their withdrawal - notably those tabled by the ENF group, represented by Marie-Christine Arnautu. These reports relate to the following points: modification of the directive establishing a single European railway area; opening up of the market for national passenger transport services to competition; repeal of the regulation on common rules for standardizing the accounts of railway companies; opening up of national passenger transport markets. These reports confirm the separation between the activities of manager and operator, and extend the application of the principles of competitive tendering to services which were previously exempt. We are opposed to this new reform, which is in line with the previous rail packages: their consequences in France have been catastrophic (20% drop in freight in 5 years).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: In written form. - In view of the liberalization of the transport market and the fourth railway package already adopted, either the list of railway undertakings had to be supplemented or this regulation abolished altogether. It will take us a long time to complete this list every year and check if there are new railway undertakings and those that are not on the list. I agree with my colleagues who are proposing that this regulation be repealed because Member States can continue to use other regulations to pay compensation to railway undertakings.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing.- The amendment of this regulation does not include arrangements for the benefit of the employees concerning the operation of the railway undertakings and the work of the staff in them.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Normalisation of Accounts Regulation. No Member State in Europe now uses this system so the legislation is outdated. This applies to Wales, as elsewhere.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing.- I believe that the current text of the regulation is discriminatory, as it only offers the possibility of compensation to the 40 companies specified in the annexes to the regulation.Therefore, keeping the regulation in force is not an option, unless the list of railway companies is constantly updated.I also agree with the need for a transitional period with regard to compensation paid for level crossings due to the fact that some Member States still use that regulation as a basis for compensation for level crossings.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing.- Vote against the three reports of the railway package because they are unsuitable for the development of the sector.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This proposal is part of the EU's fourth railway package and aims to repeal Regulation (EC) No 1192/69. This regulation concerns common rules for the normalization of accounts of railway undertakings. It authorizes Member States to compensate railway undertakings for charges that undertakings in other modes of transport do not have to bear, such as special payments in the event of accidents at work. This Regulation was adopted before the processes of liberalization of the railway market and at a time when rail transport in Europe was developed within a national framework and integrated companies simultaneously guaranteed transport services and the management of railway infrastructure. The process of destruction, deregulation and privatization of companies was a disaster for the rail system. The goal: monopoly concentration on an EU scale, regardless of passengers and the development strategy of each state. We went against Regulation (EC) No. 1192/69. We even recognize that it may be out of context and that it currently allows public funds to be transferred to privatized companies that manage the rail system. But one thing is clear: the proposed repeal is not to stop liberalization, but to deepen it. We are against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing.- I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position as I believe that Regulation no.1192/69 is obsolete and incompatible with the current legislative compendium of the Union and should therefore be repealed.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted no because I disagree.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing.- Unfortunately, the current legislation in force presented by the regulation no longer corresponds to the current legal environment, as pointed out by the European Commission.The current regulation is not transparent and discriminatory, as it only allows compensation to 40 specific companies, which are clearly identified and defined in the annex to the regulation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing.- I am in favor of amending this regulation, as it does not include arrangements for the benefit of employees relating to the operation of railway undertakings and the work of staff on them.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly welcome the establishment of a single European railway area and the opening of the domestic rail passenger market to competition. It is clear that there is still need for a transitional period regarding the compensations paid for level crossing facilities due to the fact that some Member States still use this Regulation as a basis for level crossing facilities compensations. In future, Member States may continue to pay compensation for the costs of those facilities. They may, nevertheless, need time to amend their national law and administrative provisions to take account of the repeal of Regulation. Concerning the Domestic passenger transport services by rail (PSO) Regulation, I believe there is a need to strengthen the social protection in the new regulation, and that we must keep fighting for transport workers rights and jobs protection.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - This regulation, which the Commission is now proposing to repeal, has allowed Member States to compensate railway undertakings for obligations relating to obligations which are not borne by undertakings in other modes of transport. As the Commission states in its proposal, the regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I share this opinion with the Commission. I also agree that the current wording of the regulation is discriminatory, as it makes the possibility of compensation available only to the 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation. Therefore, it is not possible to keep the regulation in force. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014. At the time, the European Parliament supported the repeal of the regulation, but called for the repealing provision to enter into force only two years later. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council. Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. - The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger services. This would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail compared to other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. In order to achieve the general objective, the Commission proposes mandatory tendering for public service contracts in order to increase the competitive constraints on domestic rail markets. The aim is to increase the efficiency and improve the quality of rail passenger services. These measures shall be accompanied by provisions ensuring a favorable framework for competitive tendering procedures, including rules on access to railway vehicles. The Commission proposal is closely linked to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34 / EU establishing a single European railway area, which introduce open access rights for railway undertakings and strengthen the provisions for the management of infrastructure managers to enhance non-discriminatory access to railway infrastructure. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading on 26 February 2014, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Council Presidencies (with a view to reaching an early second reading agreement). Following six trialogues, Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation importantly allows Member States to compensate railway undertakings for any obligation that other transport modes do not have to support, this is very important as it allows for a much fairer market in the transportation sector. Our ultimate goal must be to create and ensure the best and most competitive transport market, where each method of travel or transportation is on a level playing field – this legislative proposal, alongside the other proposals of the market pillar in the Fourth Railway Package goes a long way to make this a reality. Given the substantial change in regulation, there is a clear need for a transitional period so that the Member States have time to adapt to the new rules regarding compensation. This transitional period is set until 31 December 2017 and I hope that this will give the Member States enough time to adapt their national legislation.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the government of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders. It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report to phase out legislation that has become obsolete.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of the recommendation for second reading, as the regulation is no longer compatible with the existing legal environment.In particular, the existing text of the regulation is discriminatory, as it provides the possibility of compensation to only 40 companies specified in the annexes to the regulation.Therefore, maintaining the current regulation is not an option unless the list of railway undertakings is constantly updated.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no legitimate reason to ask for a further prolongation and that Regulation 1192/69 should be repealed without transitional period. The first prolongation was asked to give time to Member States to transpose Directive 2012/34/EU. The deadline of transposition expired in June 2015 and only one Member State (namely Germany) has not been able to meet it. However, it is expected to do so by the end of this year (2016). I voted to reject the ENF amendment which would have rejected the Council position.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)

Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted AGAINST the amendments of the ENF Group to the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Parliament and Council Regulation repealing Council Regulation (EEC) No 2454/93.1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings, as they seek to reject the Council's position.I have followed the position of the ALDE Group and its shadow rapporteur in order to support the extension of this Regulation in a spirit of compromise.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: in writing.- This project suffers from its emptiness in that it only concerns the repeal of the current rules relating to the standardization of accounts of companies in the railway sector.I voted against.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Merja Kyllönen on the repeal of the rules for normalizing the accounts of railway companies.This text is part of the fourth railway package, which aims to create a European railway area.However, the regulation in question was no longer in line with the current legal environment, justifying its repeal.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written.- I approved this report.The regulation in question was issued before the planned liberalization of the rail market at a time when cross-border rail traffic was not yet an issue, as rail traffic was mainly carried out within national borders with integrated companies.The aim of the regulation was to create a level playing field between railway companies and companies operating in other modes of transport.The Commission believes that the possibility of compensating railway undertakings no longer takes into account today's realities in the railway sector.In addition, a non-discriminatory application can no longer be guaranteed.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. - This regulation, which the Commission is now proposing to repeal, has allowed Member States to compensate railway undertakings for obligations relating to obligations which are not borne by undertakings in other modes of transport. As the Commission states in its proposal, the regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I share this opinion with the Commission. I also agree that the current wording of the regulation is discriminatory, as it makes the possibility of compensation available only to the 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation. Therefore, it is not possible to keep the regulation in force. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014. At the time, the European Parliament supported the repeal of the regulation, but called for the repealing provision to enter into force only two years later. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council. Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. - Together with the fourth railway package, it is proposed to implement various legislative procedures concerning, among others, the repeal of regulation no. 69/1192 concerning the common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway companies, which provides the Member States with the possibility of being able to offset the payment of obligations incurred by companies operating in other sectors; proposes the amendment of directive no. 34/2012 EU, which creates a single European railway area, regarding the opening of the market for national passenger transport services by rail and the governance of the railway infrastructure; and finally analyzes the amendment of regulation no. 1370/2007 with reference to the opening of the market for national passenger transport services by rail. The report recommends following the Commission's proposal on the repeal of the Regulation, with the exception of the rules applying to the normalization of accounts for Category IV cases, following the Council position which appears to be in line with the agreement reached during the negotiations and to proceed to approval without changes.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. - The rail sector is a major issue, in Europe and more particularly in France, particularly economically and environmentally. Thus, I supported this report on the "normalization of the accounts of railway companies" which is part of the fourth railway package, because the latter carries a balanced and responsible vision. Without entering into frenzied liberalism, it promotes effective decisions, to give new opportunities to carriers. These new measures will open up the passenger transport market, providing sufficient guarantees so that this does not come at the expense of regional planning. Ultimately, users will see the offer improve and regions will have greater freedom of choice in their providers. Now is not the time for liberalization that would primarily benefit our international competitors and encourage social dumping. With this fourth railway package, we are enabling this sector to gain in competitiveness, while respecting social rights.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted for the amendment rejecting the report on the normalization of accounts of railway companies.Mrs Kyllönen’s report, which deals only with the repeal and replacement of the current rules on standardization of railway company accounts, is part of the fourth railway package, which I am opposed to.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote on this report, as it is a second reading text from the Council.Had he been able to vote, he would not have done so in the affirmative, because despite its technical nature (obsolete regulations on aid to public railway companies are eliminated) its effect is to formally equalize public railway operators with private ones, in order to prepare for liberalizationand privatization of the sector in line with the rest of the fourth railway package.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: written. - This proposal seeks to repeal Regulation (EEC) n. 1192/69 of the Council, relative to the common rules for the normalization of the accounts of the railway companies. This regulation authorizes the Member States to compensate railway companies for the expenses derived from the obligations that other transport companies do not have to assume. This is the case of compensation for occupational accidents in this area and that in the rest of the transport are paid by the State. However, this Regulation does not respect the current legal environment, as it was drawn up in a context in which there was a much more direct relationship between governments and railway companies and therefore the list of the Regulation contains a list of state ownership, which it has had to be expanded to include the new Member States. I vote in favor, since in addition to not being legally up-to-date, it discriminates between the companies that are included in that list and those that are not.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing.- I stayed.The regulation allows railway undertakings to pay sickness and similar expenses paid by governments to other companies.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Under Regulation 1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings, which the Commission proposes to repeal, Member States are allowed to reimburse those undertakings for the payment of obligations which do not apply to undertakings in other modes of transport. These obligations may relate to special payments in the event of accidents at work, pensions for railway workers or payment of the costs of railway-road facilities. The report also notes that the current text of the Regulation is discriminatory as it provides for the possibility of compensation only for the 40 companies listed in the annexes to the Regulation. The report proposes to follow the Commission's proposal to repeal the Regulation, with the exception of the provisions applicable to the normalization of accounts for Category IV cases, which will continue to apply until 31 December 2017. This will give Member States time to adapt their national legislation. in respect of compensation of costs associated with certain railway-road facilities. Given that the Council's position at first reading is in line with the agreement reached during the interinstitutional negotiations, I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing.- The regulation on the normalization of accounts was adopted before the liberalization of the railway market and currently no longer corresponds to the existing legal environment.However, until 31.12.2017, the provisions of the Regulation governing the payment of compensation for level crossings between Member States will remain in force.This leaves room for Member States to adapt their national rules in accordance with Directive 2012/34 / EU establishing a single European railway area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing.- I am voting against the amendment on the recommendation for second reading concerning the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Regulation (EEC) No 2454/93.Council Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 on common rules for the settlement of the accounts of railway undertakings, for the reasons set out in detail at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 12/12/2016.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing.- I voted for the rejection of the normalization of accounts, and therefore against this text.This text concerns, like the two other reports of the fourth railway package, the “market” aspect.This text aims to repeal the current rules on the standardization of accounts of railway undertakings.However, the current regulation is discriminatory in designating which companies are eligible for compensation, which we are opposed to.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- Today, we have discussed a report that is part of the so-called railway package and responds to the changes that have taken place in the field of rail transport since 1969, when the original regulation on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings was adopted.The amended legislation allows Member States to reimburse railway undertakings for payments related to obligations that other modes of transport do not have to fulfill.These are, for example, special payments in the event of accidents at work, pensions for railway workers who perform demanding work and thus retire earlier, or payments for the cost of level crossing equipment.I supported the report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: written.- The 4th railway package aims to liberalize the European railway sector in terms of market policy.The application of a general obligation to tender in the area of procurement is intended to save public money and reduce market access barriers for smaller competitors.In exceptional cases, however, the general obligation to tender may be waived and orders may be placed directly.In the future, infrastructure operators will have to be effectively independent in order to be able to guarantee equal access of railway companies to the infrastructure.Railway companies still have to comply with Union law, national law and collective agreements.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing.- I supported the Commission's proposal to repeal Regulation (EEC) NoRegulation (EEC) No 1192/69 on the general rules for the accounting of railway undertakings, since, following the adoption of many new instruments governing the railway sector, this Regulation no longer takes account of the current legal environment.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- This text is one of the three texts making up the "market" part of the fourth railway package.The aim here is to act on the abolition of a regulation which governed the financing of pensions and industrial accidents of railway workers.The objective is to put an end to the possibility for States to pay railway companies compensation linked to their social obligations.This text therefore attacks the possibility for states to finance an efficient social system and decent working conditions for employees, which is unacceptable.I vote against.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report concerns an amendment to the directive establishing a single European railway area, and more specifically on the governance of rail infrastructure.This is a technical and accounting report included in the fourth railway package, which we reject.Therefore, I objected.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The "market" part of the fourth railway package contains three legislative proposals. One of them is a Commission proposal to repeal Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69. The latter aims to allow states to award compensation to railway companies for expenditure related to obligations, while other companies using other modes of transport are not covered. There are 40 such companies formerly state-owned and receiving aid and are listed in the annex to the regulation. I voted in favor of this proposal in order to repeal Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69, because it seems to me that it no longer responds to the current situation. Indeed, in today's world, with the liberalization of the rail market, this regulation no longer responds to current challenges. The railway sector has undergone many changes and the regulation no longer conforms to the current legal environment and even amounts to discriminating against some companies not included in it. It is time to have legislation in line with reality and able to meet the challenges of our time.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council to repeal Council Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014, supporting the repeal of the Regulation, but calling for the repealing provision to enter into force only two years later. This was followed by inter-institutional negotiations, as a result of which Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016. The Council adopted its position at first reading in accordance with the agreement on 17 October 2016. In its report, the Committee on Transport and Tourism proposes that Parliament agree with the Council's position at first reading and declare that the legislative act has been adopted in accordance with the Council's position. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing.- The three reports which constitute the fourth part of the rail package are in line with the desired liberalization of rail in all its aspects.French freight has already paid the price for such measures, it is obviously unthinkable to endorse such texts.The EU still refuses to understand that people want efficient and affordable public services and the protection of their jobs.The time of permanent liberalism, which destroys the social fabric for the benefit of a few, must end.Against.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report deals only with the repeal of the current rules on the standardization of accounts of railway undertakings.The aim of the regulation is to allow the compensation by communities of railway undertakings for the significant charges they have to pay in particular because of their collective agreements.The Commission has found that due to regulatory changes that have taken place over the past 10 years, the current regulation is inadequate as it is discriminatory: it allows compensation for designated companies but not for others.I vote against this report, which is an integral part of the disastrous "railway package".

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal as it will compensate railway undertakings for the payment of obligations, which undertakings of other transport modes do not have to support.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text on the standardization of accounts of railway companies.The aim is to adopt a Council act as part of the implementation of the Fourth Railway Package, in order to make European railways more competitive and safer.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the recommendation on the normalisation of the accounts of railway undertakings.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: In written form. - Regulation (EEC) № 1192/69 allows Member States to compensate railway undertakings financially for the payment of obligations which are not normally borne by other types of transport undertakings. Such obligations are, for example, the payment of pensions to workers who retire early under conditions of hard manual labor, as well as the payment of overpass costs. However, with the change of the European legislation at present the financial compensation of railway enterprises is practiced rather seldom and that mainly by four member states, among which is not Bulgaria. To date, the regulation does not comply with the legal environment governing rail transport, which has been significantly transformed since the adoption of the fourth legislative package in this sector. In this context, I believe that the Council's proposal to repeal the regulation is justified, especially given the fact that countries wishing to indemnify their railway undertakings will be able to do so provisionally through Directive 2012/34 / EU.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: signed up.- I voted in favor today of this recommendation for the adoption of the regulation on the standardization of the accounts of railway undertakings and the repeal of the old one, as it had to be adapted to the new realities of the EU market.The provisions of the old regulation were in conflict with the new legislation adopted by the Fourth Railway Package, as it provided for the possibility for Member States to subsidize certain costs, specific to rail transport, for a number of 40 companies.In the absence of repealing these provisions, by allocating these subsidies, certain companies will be favored, and railway companies will have an advantage over other means of transport, which is contrary to EU law.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because I cannot support certain points in the report.For example, one point of criticism would be the unconditional ability of the transport authorities to provide transport services themselves.These should therefore also submit to the obligation to tender.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- Railway undertakings must have equal opportunities to claim compensation, and all undertakings involved in the sector must be entitled to claim benefits.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: written.- I voted in favor of repealing this Regulation on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings because it was completely out of date.However, a transition period is established for level crossing facilities, as some Member States continue to rely on this Regulation as regards compensation for certain obligations that other transport sectors do not have.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. - The KKE voted against the three regulations on the "Single European Railway Area", passenger rail transport and railway undertaking accounts, which constitute the so-called "4th package" for its single rail market and complete the complete privatization of railways. EU and Member States. The delivery of the railways, all relevant public infrastructure and networks and the transport project to the large business groups serves the further profitability of the business groups. It brings another serious blow to the working conditions and labor rights of railway workers. It drastically worsens the quality and safety of rail transport, raises ticket prices for the popular family. The interests of the capital are also served by the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government with the concession to individuals of TRAINOSE, within the framework of its overall anti-popular policy, of the 3rd and previous memoranda, which it draws up with the EU and the IMF and with the agreement of its other parties. urban management. In order to make railways and transport in general land, sea and air public property, in the service of the people's needs, the workers' struggle must focus on the very power of the monopolies, their imperialist union, the EU, for radical change. in power and the economy.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this report, as it will allow Member States to adapt their national legislation concerning the compensations of costs relating to certain level crossing facilities. In the framework of the Fourth Railway Package the Commission proposes to repeal regulation 1192/69 of the Council on common rules for the normalisation of the accounts of railway undertakings. We must support the railway sector as it is the environmental friendly means of transportation of passengers and cargo as well as being of strategic importance for the EU’s security.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - The normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings, which the Commission proposes to repeal, makes it possible for railway undertakings and the Member States to reimburse obligations which do not apply to undertakings in other modes of transport. These obligations may, for example, relate to special payments in the event of accidents at work which the railway undertaking is obliged to make and which in the case of other undertakings are paid by the State, pensions for railway workers who retire earlier due to certain difficult tasks or road facilities. The types of fees for such obligations are divided into 15 categories governing the specific scope and principles of accounting. At that time, the aim of the Regulation was to equalize railway undertakings and undertakings active in other modes of transport in terms of covering social costs or externalities. However, after several railway packages transforming the railway sector, the Regulation is no longer in line with the existing legal environment and discriminates between those railway undertakings included in the list and those that subsequently joined the list. This is intended to equalize all railway administrations.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Regulation 1192/69 is no longer in line with the existing legal environment, as it was adopted at a time when rail transport in Europe was developing mainly within national borders under the management of integrated undertakings. In the meantime, we have liberalized the railway market in Europe, and now the transformed railway sector is unfortunately exposed to discrimination. Namely, according to the Regulation on common rules for the normalization of railway undertakings' accounts, Member States are allowed to compensate railway undertakings for the payment of obligations which do not apply to undertakings in other modes of transport. However, the regulation contains a list of railway companies that were once state-owned and the possibility of compensation is provided exclusively for these 40 companies. Therefore, keeping the Regulation in force is only possible if the list of railway undertakings is regularly updated. However, a transitional period for the payment of charges for railway facilities is necessary, as some Member States still use the Regulation as a basis for charges and will need time to amend national legislation and administrative regulations. I call on all Member States to continue transposing the measures of Directive 2012/34 / EU, avoiding unnecessary delays.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This proposal is part of the EU's fourth railway package and aims to repeal Regulation (EC) No 1192/69. This regulation concerns common rules for the normalization of accounts of railway undertakings. It authorizes Member States to compensate railway undertakings for charges that undertakings in other modes of transport do not have to bear, such as special payments in the event of accidents at work. This Regulation was adopted before the processes of liberalization of the railway market and at a time when rail transport in Europe was developed within a national framework and integrated companies simultaneously guaranteed transport services and the management of railway infrastructure. The process of destruction, deregulation and privatization of companies was a disaster for the rail system. The goal: monopoly concentration on an EU scale, regardless of passengers and the development strategy of each state. We went against Regulation (EC) No. 1192/69.
