We even recognize that it may be out of context and that it currently allows public funds to be transferred to privatized companies that manage the rail system. But one thing is clear: the proposed repeal is not to stop liberalization, but to deepen it. We are against it.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing.- As regards the regulation on the normalization of the accounts, I support the repeal of this legal act, aimed at introducing greater transparency of the law applied in the area of railways.Compensation payments made on the basis of the regulation being repealed by the state to the infrastructure manager will be allowed on the basis of a different legal basis (Article 8 of Directive 2012/34 on the creation of a single European railway area).I hereby endorse the compromise that has been reached.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which concerns the Commission's decision to repeal the regulation on common rules for the standardization of accounts of railway companies.This allowed Member States to compensate railway companies for payments that companies in other modes of transport did not support.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for the rejection amendment in order to ensure that this part of the Fourth Railway package would not proceed.  This report is part of three reports that constitute the Fourth Railway package, and by voting to reject the second reading we were trying to ensure that the Fourth Railway package did not go ahead and thus lead to governments of Member States having their hands tied through the mandatory competitive tendering initiative of the Commission.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing.- Accounting standardization for railway undertakings is an important tool for ensuring the functioning of the Single Market and in the railway sector.Harmonizing the legislation of 28 Member States in a complex area such as railways is a really difficult task.Although it is a technical document, it has been the subject of lengthy negotiations, and I am glad that an agreement has finally been reached.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This report is part of a set of three legislative proposals for the fourth railway package. In this case, the intention is to repeal Regulation 1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of accounts of railway undertakings, the aim of which was to promote a greater balance between railway undertakings. railways and other companies in other modes of transport, with regard to the payment of social costs and externalities. After the liberalization of the railway market and after several railway packages, the regulation lost its original purpose, being in dissonance with the current legal context, it is to discriminate between railway companies on the list of companies owned by States and companies outside that list, which do not receive any compensation. After six rounds of trialogues, it was possible to reach an interinstitutional agreement, in which it is proposed to repeal the regulation, with the exception of the provisions on the normalization of accounts that refer to the compensation paid for level crossings, which require a longer until the Member States adapt their national legislation in this area. In view of the above, I voted in favor of this Report.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: written.- I voted for the normalization of the railway companies' accounts and therefore also for the repeal of Council Regulation 1192/69.The regulation allows the member states to compensate railway companies for the payment of obligations which companies of other modes of transport do not have to meet.When applying the regulation, however, it is problematic that the regulation does not cover individual railway companies.The companies are thus denied the opportunity to receive compensation payments from the member states.As a result, the relevant railway undertakings are discriminated against by the regulation.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing.- The compromise text negotiated between the European Parliament and the Council of the political pillar of the so-called 4th railway package is a compromise on a very sensitive subject.In recent years, we have heard many arguments for and against further market opening.Proponents of liberalization speak of pressure to be more efficient in a competitive environment, and opponents have argued that liberalization has not provided better and safer passenger services or more dignified employee conditions in the long run.On the contrary.The rules for opening up markets must therefore also be clear with regard to quality standards and the social standards of employees.Cheaper does not necessarily have to be better, and if market opening were to mean precariousness and worsening working conditions, it would be a loss for the whole railway sector.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote on this report, as it is a second reading text from the Council.Had he been able to vote, he would not have done so in the affirmative, because despite its technical nature (obsolete regulations on aid to public railway companies are eliminated) its effect is to formally equalize public railway operators with private ones, in order to prepare for liberalizationand privatization of the sector in line with the rest of the fourth railway package.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing.- With today's vote, an earlier regulation concerning state aid to railway undertakings is repealed.This regulation, adopted before the liberation of the railway market, no longer respects the current legal framework and discriminates between the railway companies listed therein and those excluded.I have therefore decided to vote in favor of its repeal.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this as I wish to put a ‘spanner in the works’ of the EU Fourth Railway Package.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written.- I did not support this report, but this reasoning of the vote is a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality and quantity of work.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Regulation No. Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 was adopted in the period before the liberalization of rail transport and aimed to create a level playing field for railway undertakings and undertakings operating in other transport sectors. As the current compensation regulation allows only 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation, it can be considered discriminatory. I voted in favor of the draft legislative resolution because I do not think that the regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment. I also agree with the Commission's view that, following several packages of rules that have changed the shape of the rail sector, this regulation is no longer relevant, as it divides railway undertakings into those on the list (which are eligible for compensation payments), and those not included in the list. I also agree with the rapporteur's recommendation that the regulation be repealed, with the exception of those provisions relating to the standardization of the accounts of Class IV cases, which are covered by Annex IV. These provisions should remain in force until 31 December 2017, giving Member States time to adapt their national legislation on the compensation of costs related to certain level crossings.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The European Commission has proposed repealing Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 laying down common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings, which allows Member States to pay compensation to railway undertakings for the payment of obligations which undertakings of other modes of transport are not required to cover. These obligations relate, for example, to special payments in the event of accidents at work which railway undertakings are required to pay while other modes of transport are paid by the State, to pensions for railway workers who perform heavy work and usually retire early, or on the payment of costs for devices at road-rail crossings. The regulation was adopted before the liberalization of the rail market, when rail transport in Europe developed mainly within national borders, with integrated undertakings providing rail services as well as managing railway infrastructure. The Regulation, after a number of railway packages that have changed the railway sector, is no longer in line with the current legal environment, as it distinguishes between listed railway undertakings (and thus eligible for compensation) and non-listed undertakings. I agree that the regulation is obsolete and its wording is discriminatory, as only 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation have the possibility to compensate, so I support the proposal.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing.- The adoption of the 4th railway package also includes the repeal of certain provisions of European legislation, which no longer correspond to developments, or their implementation is not effective.One of them is the Council Regulation (EEC) No.1192/69.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - Under Regulation 1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings, which the Commission proposes to repeal, Member States are allowed to reimburse railway undertakings for the payment of obligations which do not apply to undertakings in other modes of transport. This regulation was adopted before the liberalization of the railway market, and the aim was to equalize all carriers in terms of covering social costs. The Commission states that after several railway packages transforming the sector, the Regulation is no longer in line with the existing legal environment. The Regulation provides for the possibility of reimbursement of costs only for the 40 undertakings currently annexed to the Regulation, and its retention is only possible if the list of railway undertakings is regularly updated. Parliament's position at first reading was adopted on 26 February 2014. At that time, the European Parliament opted to repeal the Regulation, but requested a two-year postponement of the entry into force of that decision. After six rounds of trialogues, Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016. As the Council's position at first reading is in line with the agreement reached during the interinstitutional negotiations, I accept and vote for the legal act to enter into force.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing.- I voted against the amendment to reject the Council's position at first reading on common rules for the normalization of railway undertakings' accounts.The proposal to repeal the Regulation on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings is part of the market pillar of the fourth railway package.This will allow Member States to pay compensation to railway undertakings for the payment of obligations that companies of other modes of transport do not have to cover.The regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing.- The amendment of this regulation does not include arrangements for the benefit of the employees concerning the operation of the railway undertakings and the work of the staff in them.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - Regulation (EEC) No 1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings, which the Commission is now proposing to repeal, allows Member States to compensate railway undertakings for obligations relating to obligations which are not borne by undertakings in other modes of transport. These obligations may relate, inter alia, to special payments in the event of accidents at work, which railway undertakings are required to make but which are borne by the State in the case of other modes of transport, pensions of railway workers who normally retire from strenuous employment, or costs related to level crossing facilities. . The regulation was adopted before the liberalization of the railway market. At the time, the regulation was intended to ensure that railway undertakings and other modes of transport operate on a level playing field in terms of social costs and externalities. In the Commission's view, after a number of railway packages transforming the railway sector, the regulation no longer takes into account the current legal environment. I agree that the current wording of the regulation is discriminatory, as it makes the possibility of compensation available only to the 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation. For all these reasons, I voted in favor of the recommendation.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposal for the repeal of Regulation 1192/69 on common rules for the normalisation of the accounts of railway undertakings will allow Member States to compensate railway undertakings for the payment of obligations that undertakings of other transport modes do not have to support. This will take place gradually, which is necessary due the fact that some countries still use this regulation as a basis for level crossing facilities compensations. In the future, Member States may continue to pay compensation for the costs of those facilities and may need time to amend their national law and administrative provisions to take account of the repeal of Regulation 1192/69.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed the motion for rejection because I wished to support the agreement reached on the repeal of Regulation 1192/69 on the normalisation of accounts of railway undertakings. The regulation compensates railway undertakings for the payments of obligations which other modes of transport do not have to support. With the opening of the market, such measures are inconsistent with more recent EU legislation as railway undertakings continue to compete with other modes of transport but also between themselves. I therefore consider that such compensation should be managed according to the same principles applying to commercial companies. Directive 2012/34/EU establishes a different framework for such compensation and should have been transposed into national law already from 2015. I hope to see the repeal of Regulation 1192/69 as early as possible without a further transitional period, but in the spirit of finding a compromise, I agree to support another year of transition period.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, because I believe it is essential to ensure better market access for the rail sector in all Member States in order to increase competition, choice and quality of services for the benefit of passengers. Rail transport should also be relaunched in view of its contribution to sustainable mobility in our societies. The revision of the rules will make it easier for new entrants to enter the market and offer their efficient services to travelers. The results should materialize in greater choice, cheaper fares and improved quality for the benefit of passengers. Calls for tender will become the rule for public service contracts, while direct awarding will continue to be accepted where it improves service quality or cost efficiency. Furthermore, the inclusion in the contracts of efficiency and quality objectives, which include the punctuality and frequency of trains, was also positive. The reform will help strengthen railway companies to have equal access to tracks and stations.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written.- I supported the report which repeals the Regulation on common rules for the normalization of accounts of railway undertakings.By regulation, Member States may reimburse joint ventures for the payment of obligations not applicable to carriers in other modes of transport, which have been used by four Member States: Belgium, Germany, Ireland and Poland.As this Regulation provides for the possibility of compensation for only 40 companies listed in the annexes, this discriminates against other companies.I find it particularly useful that Member States are given the deadline of 31 December 2017 to be able to adapt their national legislation to the reimbursement of costs associated with certain railway undertakings in cases where the railway undertaking bears an unusually large share of the cost of construction and operation of facilities.for insurance used by railways and other modes of transport.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing.- Draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Regulation (EEC) No 2454/93I supported 1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings.As the Commission states in its proposal, the Regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment and has proposed its repeal.The report fully agrees with this.He also agrees that the current wording of the regulation is discriminatory, as only 40 companies listed in the annexes to the regulation have the possibility to compensate.Therefore, the validity of this Regulation cannot be maintained unless the list of railway undertakings is constantly updated.Negotiations have begun to resolve the problem.Member States should respect all previous acts and implement the measures provided for in the Directive without delay.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing.- This report is inconsistent since it deals only with the repeal of the current rules on the standardization of accounts of railway undertakings.The aim of the regulation is to allow the compensation by communities of railway undertakings for the significant charges they have to pay in particular because of their collective agreements.The commission noted that due to regulatory changes that have taken place over the past 10 years, the current regulation is inadequate as it is discriminatory: it allows compensation for designated companies, but not for others.I voted against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing.- Long term provisions should be introduced, not as in the proposed interim document.The proposed provisions are not very detailed and cause a number of legal doubts, the more so as the current solutions should be modern.Therefore, I did not support the project.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing.- The Regulation on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings, which the Commission is now proposing to repeal, allows Member States to compensate railway undertakings for obligations relating to obligations which are not borne by undertakings in other modes of transport.Following my vote, following the position of S&D, I did not support the ENF proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report to phase out legislation that has become obsolete.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because the proposal is intended to eliminate inconsistencies between payments of obligations by 36 railway companies (such as family allowances and pensions), predating the liberalisation of the railway market and today’s market reality. There is not a single Member State left that uses the regulation as legal basis for transfer payments. The TRAN agreed with a huge majority to delete the law as of January 2018.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: written.- This rule repeals the Regulation on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway companies, since it, which was adopted when the organizations that provide railway services were fulfilling certain responsibilities of the public sector, has become outdated.However, it is still used, in particular to offset costs related to level crossing facilities.This justifies a transition period for offsetting these costs, as well as for adjusting national legislation and administrative mechanisms under the new framework.All with a view to an effective implementation of the system that will be introduced, as this report defends.Trusting that this amendment will adapt the current system to the modern organization of the railway sector, I voted in favor of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote on this report, as it is a second reading text from the Council.Had he been able to vote, he would not have done so in the affirmative, because despite its technical nature (obsolete regulations on aid to public railway companies are eliminated) its effect is to formally equalize public railway operators with private ones, in order to prepare for liberalizationand privatization of the sector in line with the rest of the fourth railway package.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Regulation (EEC) No. 1192/69 was adopted before the liberalization of the rail market and at a time when rail transport in Europe was mainly developed within a national framework and integrated companies simultaneously guaranteed transport services and infrastructure management railway. The purpose of the regulation was then to put rail companies and companies in other modes of transport on an equal footing with regard to the payment of social costs or externalities. In addition, the relationship between governments and railway companies mainly owned by states was not yet regulated by contractual agreements and there was a much more direct ownership link between the two parties. Due to its initial purpose, the regulation contains a list that lists the railway companies previously owned by the States. This list has been adapted several times to take account of the accession of the new Member States, and currently contains 40 companies. The repeal of this regulation can only be interpreted as another way of liberalizing the sector and further reducing the capacity of public authorities to intervene in this sector, which is vital for the economy and for society.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: written.- The 4th railway package aims to liberalize the European railway sector in terms of market policy.The application of a general obligation to tender in the area of procurement is intended to save public money and reduce market access barriers for smaller competitors.In exceptional cases, however, the general obligation to tender may be waived and orders may be placed directly.In the future, infrastructure operators will have to be effectively independent in order to be able to guarantee equal access of railway companies to the infrastructure.Railway companies still have to comply with Union law, national law and collective agreements.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European railways are in need of urgent modernisation and more competition in order for them to become a genuine alternative to road transport. While the technical aspects of the railway reform were already voted on a few months ago, today the European Parliament voted on three reports addressing the political aspects. After three years of difficult negotiations between the Parliament and the Member States, Socialists and Democrats, including Labour MEPs, decided to reject the compromise reached with the Council on one of the reports, on the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services. During the negotiations, the Council completely dismissed the demand by the European Parliament to ensure the mandatory transfer of staff in cases of change of provider in the public sector. Labour MEPs back railway modernisation, but not at the expense of workers.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written.- Due to the discriminatory effect that Regulation 1192/69 has had so far on those companies that are not entitled to compensation, I support the report.I believe that it is not fair to allow cost reimbursement only to certain railway companies that are on the list of 40 companies, and its possible retention is possible only if that list is regularly updated to allow cost reimbursement to other companies.I see the shortcoming of the Regulation in the fact that it was adopted before the liberalization of the railway market and at a time when this form of transport was developing primarily within national borders.As it has also experienced several railway packages which have transformed the sector and the Regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment, I support the Commission's proposal to repeal it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing.- Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Regulation (EEC) No 2454/93I supported 1192/69 on common rules for the normalization of the accounts of railway undertakings.Regulation (EEC) NoRegulation (EEC) No 1192/69 is no longer in line with the current legal environment in the many railway packages which have changed the railway sector, as it discriminates between listed railway undertakings (and thus eligible for compensation) and non-listed undertakings.list.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, as I said, rail transport is no longer limited to the Member States, but ensures the connectivity of the Union. Regulation 1370/2007 refers to the award of public service contracts for railway transport. It is necessary to ensure effective Community rules for the award of these contracts and for public procurement procedures in the field of transport. Many times, we have all heard about rigged tenders, about contracts given to certain companies and these processes must stop. All railway operators must comply with the same quality and social standards imposed by national authorities. So Member States must strive to ensure transparency in public procurement, few rules, clear and transparent. Under these conditions, it is very difficult for corruption or fraud to intervene, and the costs of these contracts are much lower, for the benefit of the citizen.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I supported this proposal precisely because an agreement on the railway package has been sought here for a very long time. I believe that the proposed measures, such as the mandatory tendering of public service contracts, have the potential to improve the quality of rail passenger services. This is, I think, very important, and at the same time I feel that there is an increase in the competitive pressure that the measures are leading to. This is the right way to go, because I believe that passengers will especially appreciate the higher offer and competitiveness. Due to the greater efficiency of the new system, it is not only passengers but also taxpayers. I firmly hope that this will increase the attractiveness of rail transport compared to other modes of transport, which, for example, are less environmental, damaging our future. That is why I would support the promotion of rail transport.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- The following report is part of the governance project of the fourth railway package and is mainly concerned with fostering the opening of the market for rail transport.Although I understand the strong need to introduce rules to encourage greater opening of the railway market, I have decided to vote positively on the proposal to reject the Council's position because I believe it overlooks some aspects that are very relevant to me.One of them is the introduction of too many exceptions and exemptions for public service contracts, which play to the detriment of increased competition.Furthermore, in my opinion, very sensitive social issues such as the transfer of personnel are not adequately dealt with.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: written.- I have not been able to vote directly on this report, but I have supported an amendment rejecting the whole and others that sought to guarantee the rights of workers and the public service against the privatization of the railway.Unfortunately, the result of the votes has been favorable in importing the British railway model to the rest of the Union, so that domestic passenger transport will be progressively opened from 2020 to private operators with what it entails: priceshigher levels, less security, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of the conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precarious working conditions, with the recurrent intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will share the cake.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted against the amendments rejecting the Council's position. I support the proposal on inland rail passenger services in order to open up the internal market for rail passenger services and to improve the quality and efficiency of rail passenger services. This should increase the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railways vis-à-vis other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. To achieve these objectives, it is planned to launch mandatory competitive tendering for public service contracts, thus increasing the competitive pressure on the internal rail markets. This measure is accompanied by provisions to ensure favorable framework conditions for competitive tendering, including rules on access to rolling stock and a transparent and non-discriminatory public service procurement procedure. This proposal will also help to strengthen the provisions governing infrastructure management in order to strengthen non-discriminatory access to rail infrastructure.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing.- The “competition” report of the market section of the 4th railway package introduces an obligation to call for competition, including in the case of public services which must also be subject, with three minor exceptions, to the principle of competition and to the call for competition.'offer.It aims to ensure that the financial compensation granted is strictly proportionate (against disguised subsidies).At the request of groups, particularly on the left, the obligation to comply with state social rules and collective agreements was inserted into the regulations.Still happy that companies must respect the law!Putting such evidence on paper is proof that it is only intended for political display.The proliferation of service providers is in itself a source of increased fraud and social dumping, especially in the case of international journeys.I obviously voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the Council position, which was put forward by four political groups, as I do not believe that EU harmonisation of domestic passenger transport services is necessary. In particular, being a Member from the United Kingdom, I note that cross-border cooperation on such matters is extremely limited in scope and covers merely the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland (which is covered under the Good Friday Agreement) and the Channel Tunnel (which is covered by the Le Touquet Treaty). Therefore, this proposal is wholly unnecessary for the United Kingdom.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This explanation concerns amendment 10 that was tabled to this text. The VVD Delegation in the European Parliament wholeheartedly supports the rights of disabled people, and is in favour of improving access for disabled people to public transport and other facilities in general. However, the VVD Delegation chose not to support this specific amendment as its adoption would imply a rejection of a crucial part of the railway package in second reading. This would lead to a disproportionate delay in the legislative process, which the people of Europe do not deserve. Moreover, it is unlikely that a reopening of the negotiations would lead to an alternative outcome concerning this specific issue.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal for opening up the internal market for passenger rail transport services. The aim of the report is to improve the quality of rail passenger transport services and to ensure their more efficient delivery. The proposed measures should improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway towards other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: This report introduces an obligation to tender, including in public service cases, which must also be subject, with three minor exceptions, to the principle of competition and tendering. It aims to ensure that the financial compensation granted is strictly proportionate to combat disguised subsidies. The regulation added the obligation to comply with the social rules of states and collective agreements, as if previously companies did not have to comply with the law; the fact of laying such evidence on paper is proof that it is intended only to be a political display. The proliferation of service providers would in itself be a source of increased fraud and social dumping, especially in the case of international journeys, which is why I voted in favour of its rejection.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — Three texts were on the table for the vote on the fourth railway package: one on standardization of accounts, one on governance and the last on public service obligation. We did not reject the first two. In the report on the governance directive, we have achieved compliance with our red line: private competition can be limited if it infringes public service obligations. On the other hand, we strongly opposed the last text which required further liberalisation of public passenger rail service. This liberalisation will not only be detrimental to rail users, but also at the expense of workers, in particular because it does not introduce the automatic and compulsory transfer of personnel in the event of a change of operator. For the Socialist MEPs, such a strong social guarantee was essential in order to ensure that competition does not take place at the expense of workers' rights and does not open the way for other forms of social dumping. We led the sling in Parliament but we lost the vote rejecting this text by 15 votes out of 751, the right having supported it massively.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - Although the report was not entirely satisfactory for my group, I have decided to vote in favour of it.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We have tabled a rejection amendment and a number of amendments to the content against this amendment to the Regulation, which requires that the management of lines operated under public service contracts subsidized by public funds be put into competition. I understand that there was no reason to amend this text, which until today allowed each Member State, taking into account its own needs, to choose which contracts it wants to open for public tender and which contracts it grants directly to the national public operator. In addition, we have echoed the demands of trade unions across Europe for the serious lack of protection that workers will remain in cases of change of operator following a new contract. The only objective of this new text is the obligation to ensure open competition between all operators potentially present on the market, competition which is expected to take place at the expense of public coffers, essential elements of the public service and working conditions. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the three reports of the rail package. Aiming at opening up national passenger transport markets, the Governance Report (Sassoli) aims to increase the supply and quality of services, making the rail market more accessible to new companies. Such a policy has led to the fall of 20% of rail freight in France... Worse yet, the competition report (Van de Camp) introduces an obligation of competition, including in cases of public service, by leading a real hunt for all forms of subsidies... A policy that goes against national interests and economic protectionism. The purpose of the Kyllonen report is to allow for compensation by railway undertakings for the significant burdens they have to pay, in particular as a result of their collective agreements. He's unsuitable.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I wanted to support the proposal for rejection submitted by my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation on domestic passenger rail transport services. The overall objective of the Commission's proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality of rail passenger transport services and to ensure their more efficient provision. This should improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway towards other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. In order to achieve this general objective, the Commission proposed to launch compulsory competitive tenders for public service contracts in order to increase the competitive pressure on the internal rail markets. This is to ensure greater efficiency and better quality of rail passenger transport services. These measures shall be accompanied by provisions designed to ensure favourable basic conditions for competitive tenders, including rules on access to rolling stock. The Commission's proposal is closely linked to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a Single European Railway Area, which establish open access rights for railway undertakings and strengthen the provisions on the regulation of infrastructure management, with a view to reinforce non-discriminatory access to railway infrastructure.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger services. This would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway in relation to other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. In order to achieve the general objective, the Commission proposes to tender public service contracts based on compulsory tendering in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets. The aim is to increase the efficiency and quality of rail passenger transport services. Such measures shall be accompanied by provisions ensuring a framework conditions favourable to tendering procedures based on tendering, including rules on access to railway vehicles. The Commission proposal is closely related to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a single European railway area, which introduce open access rights for railway undertakings and reinforce the provisions on the management of infrastructure managers under the to enhance non-discriminatory access to railway infrastructure. Following the adoption of Parliament's first-reading position on 26 February 2014, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council (with a view to reaching an early second reading agreement). Following six trialogues, Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report, which proposes an obligation to compete for these railway undertakings, including in the context of public service missions, is intended to increase the number of players, including internationally, thus introducing a clear risk of social dumping. I am therefore voting against it. I am voting in favour of the rejection amendment tabled by my group.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this file, which is part of the ‘market pillar’ of the so-called ‘Fourth Railway Package’, which is aimed at entrenching market liberalisation and competition in the European railway sector. This file concerns amendments to Regulation 1370/2007 that would open up the domestic passenger market by rail to competitive tender, while restricting the power of authorities in Member States to allocate services by direct award. It deepens the liberalisation of the sector, while eroding public transport workers’ rights and conditions, and encouraging social dumping. While we support improvements and reform in the railway sector, Sinn Féin opposes the Fourth Railway Package due to its heavily neoliberal, pro-market bias. In particular, the ‘Market Pillar’ involves downgrading and repealing existing provisions, minimising Member State involvement in the sector and facilitating increased liberalisation and a more competitive market, rather than focusing on improving services. We therefore voted against the proposed amendments.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The adoption of the fourth rail package and the strengthening of the ERA's investigation and audit powers in the areas of its competence, it will help to comply with networks Trans-European transport and train. We will cease to have 28 different systems for the type-approval of trains: the Agency will act as a one-stop shop responsible for issuing authorisations for vehicles intended for cross-border activities and certificates of safety to railway undertakings operating in different EU states. The adoption of the regulation will also increase competitive pressure on the national transport agencies, with the hope that this will lead to an increase in the quality of service and to a optimization of costs.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report forms an integral part of the fourth rail package and introduces an obligation to compete for national rail passenger services. The text also aims to ensure that financial compensation is strictly proportionate in order to limit disguised subsidies. Although this report obliges companies to comply with the legislation of the Member States, which is evident, we consider that the increase in service providers is a source of social fraud and abuse of posted workers. That is why I voted against this text and in favour of the rejection proposal.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreement reached in trialogue at second reading amends Regulation No 1370/2007 on public passenger transport services by road and rail. This change concerns the opening of the market for national rail passenger transport services and aims to improve the quality of services offered and greater operational efficiency. This should increase the competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail compared to other modes of transport and further develop the single European rail area. The change introduces mandatory competitive tender procedures for public service contracts in order to intensify competitive pressure on national rail markets. These measures are accompanied by provisions to ensure favourable framework conditions for competitive tendering procedures, including rules on access to rolling stock.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This file is part of the ‘Market Pillar’ of the Fourth Railway Package, which I oppose as it is aimed at entrenching liberalisation, competition and the market in the European railway sector. Specifically, this vote concerns a Council recommendation to amend Regulation 1370/2007, opening up the domestic passenger market by rail to competitive tender, while restricting the power of authorities in Member States to allocate services by direct award. It deepens the liberalisation of the sector, while eroding public transport workers’ rights and conditions, and encouraging social dumping. Therefore I voted in favour of an amendment to reject the text.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the government of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders. It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report is part of the liberalisations of services in Europe, which unfortunately have not always resulted in the expected positive effects. Too often, in order to eliminate historical monopolies, wild liberalizations have been carried out which had the sole purpose of favouring industry at the expense of quality of services, social protection and public service obligations. For these reasons I voted against it.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We are voting against the report as we disagree with its main points.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the proposal to reject the recommendation amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 on the opening up of the domestic rail passenger transport market. I believe that solely targeting economic indicators and profits does not benefit European citizens, and that is why I voted in favour of rejecting the recommendation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In approving this measure, I believe that competition is pulsing to increase the quality, volume and efficiency of transport systems by preserving and granting a new affliction to the already excellent facilities. The main aim is to make three substantial innovations: firstly, the competent authorities will have to establish clearly the specifics of public service obligations in the provision of services and consistent with the stated political obligations. In addition, public service operators will be required to comply with the applicable obligations in the field of social and labour law. Finally, the award of public service contracts will be carried out through competitive tendering procedures, while providing exceptions with which to open to direct or simplified procedures. Thus, the efficiency and degree of attractiveness of the sector will increase, achieving an improvement in quality and, therefore, a heightened development of railways.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 concerning the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail. I did not support the proposal to reject the Council position on the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The objective of the Commission's proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality of rail passenger services and to increase their operational efficiency. The Commission proposal relates to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a Single European Railway Area. After six rounds of trialogues, Parliament reached agreement with the Presidency of the Council on 19 April 2016. Among other things, the agreement reached is that the competent authorities must define the specifications of public service obligations (PSOs) for public passenger transport; the fixing of compensation must be done at a level that guarantees the financial sustainability of the public passenger transport service; compliance by public service operators with the applicable obligations in the field of social and labour law as defined in Union law, national legislation or collective agreements in the exercise of PSOs; the obligation of public service operators and infrastructure managers to provide the competent authority with information that is essential for the award of future public service contracts (PSC). I therefore support this Recommendation.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the government of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders. It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it intends to increase competition in the rail transport sector by introducing specific improvements. Competition, however, is important that it is not an end in itself, but rather it represents an instrument to gradually increase the quality, volume and efficiency of passenger services. Efficient structures that already exist, therefore, should be preserved and should not lose in efficiency because of the new regulation. It is important that the European Union is increasingly committed to improving the quality and efficiency of passenger rail services.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I was not able to vote directly on this report, but I supported an amendment to reject the whole and others which sought to guarantee the rights of workers and the public service in the face of privatisation of railways. Unfortunately, the result of the votes has been favourable in importing the British railway model into the rest of the Union, and domestic passenger transport will therefore be progressively opened to private operators from 2020, with what it entails: higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of the conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of working conditions, with the recurrent intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will distribute the cake.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I think it is important to improve the quality of passenger transport services by rail and to promote their operational efficiency. This should increase the competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail compared to other modes of transport and further develop the single European rail area. Therefore, I welcomed the Commission's proposal to introduce compulsory competitive tender procedures for public service contracts in order to intensify competitive pressure on the national rail markets. However, I would like to point out that public service operators will have to comply with the obligations applicable in the field of social and labour law established by EU law, national law or by collective agreements.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Council's position at first reading was in line with the agreement reached in the interinstitutional negotiations on the amendment of the directive on domestic rail passenger transport services, and Parliament therefore proposed its adoption without amendments. The market pillar of the fourth railway package consists of three legislative proposals, one of which is the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards the opening up of the market for domestic rail passenger services. The Commission's proposal to amend that Regulation aims to improve the quality of rail passenger services and to increase operational efficiency. This would contribute to improving the competitiveness of the railway and the completion of the single European railway area. Provisions which provide favourable framework conditions for tendering procedures based on tendering, such as rules on access to railway vehicles, are essential. The main elements of the agreement include the definition of public service obligations and the improvement of social provisions. Competent authorities will be obliged to clearly define the public service obligations applicable to the public passenger transport service and their scope. They should also be consistent with Member States' public transport policy objectives.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. “I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position because I support the adoption of an agreement to open national rail markets for passenger services and to fix the award of public service contracts, the so-called fourth rail package. I believe that the railway industry is a very important field of the economy of the European Union, which benefits across borders, so it should be sought to support it. The agreement provides for the gradual opening of national rail markets for passenger services. This is the last segment of the rail transport market, which has not yet been liberalised in most Member States and is mainly based on the direct award of public service contracts. It should be emphasised that state authorities will continue to be able to directly award contracts for the provision of public rail services, provided that service providers meet objective objectives and effectiveness and performance criteria.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation, as it seeks to improve the efficiency of the rail passenger services operations. This should improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail vis-a-vis other modes of transport and develop further the single European railway area. The report aims to enhance the efficiency and to improve the quality of rail passenger services. These measures are accompanied by provisions to ensure favourable framework conditions for competitive tendering procedures, including rules on the access to rolling stock.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - The main objective of this package is to reform the rail sector by encouraging competition and innovation in the internal passenger transport markets, implementing a series of structural measures. I believe that the report encourages countries such as Romania to reform the rail system, whose competitiveness is affected.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This legislative report proposes to establish the principle of compulsory tendering for public contracts for passenger transport services. The aim of this proposal is to open up national rail markets to some degree of competition in order to improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail compared to other modes of transport and further develop the single European rail area. Considering that France's special interests, particularly with regard to high-speed lines, have been respected and that French rail services will have the opportunity to conquer new markets among our European neighbours, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the government of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders. It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. — The opening up of the markets for national rail services is one of the main objectives of the Fourth European Rail Package, aimed at improving the quality of rail services for European citizens. However, this objective can only be achieved if the different Member States comply with the same rules on the award of contracts. It was therefore crucial to harmonise the European railway area by making the use of tenders in the award of public service contracts for the carriage of passengers by rail. Aware of the characteristics of this market and the imperatives of public services, we have also foreseen situations of exemptions — with strictly defined characteristics — allowing direct award of the contract without resorting to a tender. I therefore voted in favour of this text, because it allows for the development of competition for rail services that benefit the European citizen.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Fourth Rail Package has been negotiating for years, and the European Parliament approved its first reading in February 2014 at the end of the previous parliamentary term. In view of the document adopted in the European Council, which was significantly different from the EP opinion, interinstitutional negotiations continued between October 2015 and April 2016 with a view to converging positions. The final agreement with the Council was reached on 19 April 2016 within the framework of the trilogues. The package of proposals adopted is a success for users and railway undertakings and is another step towards the Single European Railway Area. For users, the change will be more dynamic and user-friendly in the future, as well as a more qualitative and frequent service. The general objective of the proposals is to open up the market for domestic rail passenger services, improve the quality of services and improve their operational efficiency, which would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail in relation to other modes of transport. The maintenance of the current form of the Hungarian State Railways and the acceptance of the current form and operation of the integrated company Győr—Sopron—Ebenfurti Vasút Zrt. has been of paramount importance for Hungary from the outset. We have managed to reach an agreement on these issues that is acceptable to us and thus do not need to start unnecessary, costly and long-term restructuring. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the fourth rail package because this set of texts aims to improve the competitiveness and quality of rail services by reducing administrative costs, introducing increased competition in the passenger services sector and ensuring fair conditions for operators. At the national level, my country has always been in favour of a thoughtful opening up of the passenger transport market. Following the adoption of this fourth rail package, the Belgian authorities will still be able to award contracts directly to SNCB, without competition, but provided that the contracts resume stricter performance requirements. In this case, contracts will have to contain requirements for timeliness and regularity of service, quality of trains and sufficient capacity. I consider this to be a breakthrough that will benefit users.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against these three reports under the railway package and, accordingly, for the amendments demanding their withdrawal — in particular those tabled by the 'ENF' Group, represented by Marie-Christine Arnautu. These reports cover the following points: amendment of the Directive establishing a single European rail area; opening up to competition of the market in national passenger transport services; repeal of the Regulation on common rules for the standardisation of the accounts of railway companies; opening up national markets for railway companies passenger transport. These reports confirm the separation between the operations of manager and operator and extend the application of the competitive principles to services that were previously exempt from them. We are opposed to this new reform, which is in line with the previous rail packages: their consequences in France have been catastrophic (fall by 20% in freight in 5 years).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am worried that opening up the rail market for passenger transport will lead to the failure of “state-owned” carriers in small EU Member States. As we all know, rail transport carries out a social activity, i.e. it benefits the poorer part of our population to move from point A to point B. Unfortunately, the solidarity that the Union proclaims is not in people's income, and thus the railway will lose its social image and/or the state will have to bear the greater difference in the cost of the transport of the socially weak and non-working age.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - This proposal requires the competent authorities to ensure that the specifications of the public service obligations and the relative compensation of the net economic effect of the public service obligations meet the objectives of the public transport policy in a cost-effective manner. In addition, the amount of compensation should ensure the economic viability of the provision of public passenger transport, in accordance with the requirements laid down in the framework of public transport policy over time. This does not allow the Member States to decide on the provision of public goods even on economically disparate terms to their citizens in the context of their social policy.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against the report on PSO Regulation in the Fourth Railway Package. The tendering process is not good enough and this does not improve it. Many constituents in Wales contacted me on this issue, voicing their concerns.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The new legislation, already agreed with national governments, provides for public procurement to become the rule for the award of public service contracts, with some exceptions. Direct award will continue to be possible if it leads to a better quality of service or better cost-effectiveness. Performance requirements will include punctuality and frequency of trains. The reform in the railway sector will facilitate the entry of new entrants into the market and the provision of their services. Member States may, however, limit the right of access of a new entrant if the proposed service undermines the economic balance of an existing public service contract. Competent authorities will have to clearly define the specifications of public service obligations for public passenger transport and the scope of their application, including the geographical areas concerned.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: - This proposal is part of the EU's fourth rail package and focuses on amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007. This objective is to improve the quality of rail passenger services and increase their operational efficiency in order to improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport vis-à-vis other modes of transport and to develop the single European rail area. Well known palate. To achieve this objective, the Commission has proposed introducing a compulsory tender for public service contracts in order to intensify competitive pressure on national rail markets. In other words, in conjunction with the proposal of the European rail area, it opens up national rail systems, which are already completely deregulated, to international competition. Another step in the growing monopoly concentration in the sector. It is nonetheless paradoxical that there is talk of 'improving the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport vis-à-vis other modes of transport', using further liberalisation, while what statistics show is that liberalisation has only contributed to the loss of attractiveness. In this respect it should be noted that since 1988 Portugal has lost 43% passengers.km (pk); in the same period, Germany gained 24% and France 35%. We obviously voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of this proposal as it requires the competent authorities to ensure that the specifications of the public service obligations and the relative compensation of the net economic effect of the public service obligations meet the policy objectives public transport in a cost-effective manner. In addition, the amount of compensation should ensure the economic viability of the provision of public passenger transport, in accordance with the requirements laid down in the framework of public transport policy over time. This does not allow the Member States to decide on the provision of public goods even on economically disparate terms to their citizens in the context of their social policy.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly welcome the establishment of a single European railway area and the opening of the domestic rail passenger market to competition. It is clear that there is still need for a transitional period regarding the compensations paid for level crossing facilities due to the fact that some Member States still use this Regulation as a basis for level crossing facilities compensation. In future, Member States may continue to pay compensation for the costs of those facilities. They may, nevertheless, need time to amend their national law and administrative provisions to take account of the repeal of the regulation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Fourth Rail Package has been negotiating for years, and the European Parliament approved its first reading in February 2014 at the end of the previous parliamentary term. In view of the document adopted by the European Council which was significantly different from the EP opinion, interinstitutional negotiations continued between October 2015 and April 2016 in order to approximate positions. The final agreement with the Council was reached on 19 April 2016 within the framework of the trilogues. The adopted package of proposals is a success for users and railway undertakings and a further step towards the achievement of the Single European Railway Area. For users, the change will be more dynamic and user-friendly in the future, as well as a more qualitative and frequent service. The general objective of the proposals is to open up the market for domestic rail passenger services, improve the quality of services and improve their operational efficiency, which would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail in relation to other modes of transport. The maintenance of the current form of Hungarian State Railways and the acceptance of the current form and operation of the integrated company Győr-Sopron-Ebenfurti Vasút Zrt. has been of paramount importance for Hungary from the outset. We have managed to reach an agreement on these issues that is acceptable to us and thus do not need to start unnecessary, costly and long-term restructuring. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger services. This would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway in relation to other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. In order to achieve the general objective, the Commission proposes to tender public service contracts based on compulsory tendering in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets. The aim is to increase the efficiency and quality of rail passenger transport services. Such measures shall be accompanied by provisions ensuring a framework conditions favourable to tendering procedures based on tendering, including rules on access to railway vehicles. The Commission proposal is closely related to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a single European railway area, which introduce open access rights for railway undertakings and reinforce the provisions on the management of infrastructure managers under the to enhance non-discriminatory access to railway infrastructure. Following the adoption of Parliament's first-reading position on 26 February 2014, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council (with a view to reaching an early second reading agreement). Following six trialogues, Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This important proposal introduces mandatory competitive tendering for public service contracts in order to intensify the competitiveness of Member States’ railway markets. The aim is to increase efficiency and to improve the quality of rail passenger services. In more detail this proposal introduces extra obligations on PSOs in public passenger transport, that authorities ensure related compensation of net financial effects of public service, that all operators fulfil obligations in social and labour law. It is also important that the proposal includes that public service operators and infrastructure managers will be under obligation to provide information that is essential for the tendering process, including information on passenger demand, fares, costs and revenues. This proposal should provide for a more open, entry-free and competitive market, while ensuring the legitimate protection of confidential business information.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The EU rail governance reform package aims to bring higher safety standards, as well as a significant reduction in red tape and administrative burdens. Public procurement procedures for railway lines will be the same rule in the future, as will increased financial and organisational transparency of railway companies. Market access for new competitors will also be simplified. Increasing competition between railway companies ultimately benefits passengers in particular: the new package should improve the supply and service in the long term.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the government of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders. It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of rejecting the three reports that open national rail passenger services to competition. In all the activities that you have deregulated, today the same problems arise: lower quality of services, opacity of tariffs, dilution of responsibilities... The very way in which this “gradual” opening up to competition is organised is the guarantee of a skimming of the market: first high-speed and national lines, then profitable regional traffic... The rest will remain the responsibility of the community, as will the maintenance of the network. The royalties that new entrants will have to pay will not be enough to upgrade a French network undermining by thirty years of top priority to the TGV at the expense of everything else, since you reproduce the same scheme. Already, the state announced that it would put its hand in the pocket, or rather in the pocket of the French taxpayer. And I am not talking about the risks of social dumping. You have learned no lesson from the failure to liberalise rail freight, particularly in France, nor from the results of the liberalisation of passenger transport in Germany. This time, in addition, you play with passenger safety.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We have tabled a rejection amendment and a number of amendments to the content against this amendment to the Regulation, which requires that the management of lines operated under public service contracts subsidized by public funds be put into competition. I understand that there was no reason to amend this text, which until today allowed each Member State, taking into account its own needs, to choose which contracts it wants to open for public tender and which contracts it grants directly to the national public operator. In addition, we have echoed the demands of trade unions across Europe for the serious lack of protection that workers will remain in cases of change of operator following a new contract. The only objective of this new text is the obligation to ensure open competition between all operators potentially present on the market, competition which is expected to take place at the expense of public coffers, essential elements of the public service and working conditions. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the report.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted for the return of the text of Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail to the Council because the essential amendment on the protection of public sector workers was not contained. Adequate protection of public sector workers is particularly important. Public service operators must comply with the applicable obligations in the field of social and labour law established by Union law, national law or collective agreements. Directive 2001/23/EC on the transfer of undertakings applies to the change of public service operators where such a change constitutes a transfer of undertaking within the meaning of that Directive. In order to achieve the overall objective of the Commission's proposal to improve the quality of rail passenger services and boost their operational efficiency, the Commission proposed to introduce binding competitive public service contracts procedures for the purpose of to increase competitive pressure on national rail markets, but all these measures must comply with social protection rules.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against the compulsory opening-up of railway contracts across Europe to private sector operators, as the new laws do not provide protection for rail workers’ terms and conditions when services are contracted out and also do not ensure good staffing standards on privately-run services. The PSO Regulation is part of the ‘political pillar’ of the 4th Railway Package. The political pillar essentially seeks to update existing legislation in order to mandate further ‘opening’ of the European rail market and expose more elements to competition. The new regime would apply in principle from the end of 2019, subject to some transitional protection.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. — The opening up of the rail transport market will ensure that citizens receive quality services at the best price through the opening of public contracts to European competition, which will stimulate rail activity and economy. I therefore voted in favour of this proposal, because competition will make the railway more attractive compared to other more polluting means of transport.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The main goal of this proposal is the introduction of a mandatory competitive tendering procedure of Public Service Contracts (PSCs) as a general rule across the EU. Member States could continue to award contracts directly until 2019, taking into account that none of those contracts should extend beyond 2022. In this way, the quality of services, efficiency and attractiveness of the railway sector should be fostered. I voted in favour of the report. It has taken into account the need for a clarification and great reduction of direct award provisions in favour of competitive tendering while imposing an independent validation in case of direct award, and also a shorter transitional period, which now also includes a ‘progress review clause.’

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Mr van De Camp's report because I support the overall direction of change aimed at introducing a single rail market in Europe. Anyone who has had the opportunity to use trains in different countries in Europe recognises that there are still huge differences in both the quality and availability of services. This state of affairs remains in spite of the efforts of the Commission and the Member States and the partial progress that has already been made. However, it should be noted that this is happening for various reasons and the quality and availability of rail services for passengers is affected not only by the number of operators operating, but also by the type of management, state support, the level of implementation of reforms and many other factors. Therefore, I believe that there is still a need to work on the appropriate level of competition, but this process must take place while maintaining a balance and the highest level of service. When making changes, it is necessary to be guided primarily by the good of passengers and equally to try to improve the quality of rolling stock, handling and take care of the appropriate network of connections and to solicit a reduction in ticket prices, which are still too high in many cases and make collective road transport is more competitive.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. — The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger services. This would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway in relation to other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. In order to achieve the general objective, the Commission proposes to tender public service contracts based on compulsory tendering in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets. The aim is to increase the efficiency and quality of rail passenger transport services. Such measures shall be accompanied by provisions ensuring a framework conditions favourable to tendering procedures based on tendering, including rules on access to railway vehicles. The Commission proposal is closely related to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a single European railway area, which introduce open access rights for railway undertakings and reinforce the provisions on the management of infrastructure managers under the to enhance non-discriminatory access to railway infrastructure. Following the adoption of Parliament's first-reading position on 26 February 2014, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council (with a view to reaching an early second reading agreement). Following six trialogues, Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The VVD Delegation in the European Parliament wholeheartedly supports the rights of disabled people and is in favour of improving access for disabled people to public transport and other facilities in general. However, the VVD Eurodelegation chose not to support this specific amendment, as its adoption would imply a rejection of a crucial part of the railway package in second reading.
