This would lead to a disproportionate delay in the legislative process, which the people of Europe do not deserve. Moreover, it is unlikely that a reopening of the negotiations would lead to an alternative outcome concerning this specific issue.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted against this recommendation because the rights of transport workers and the protection of jobs with regard to rail passenger transport services in the internal market (PSO) are not respected. It is also not desirable to harmonise social protection at European level. At the moment, the Council is not willing to introduce more social protection for workers in the public transport sector, which is why this option remains in the hands of the Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I have voted against the amendment of individual groups of Members to the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards market opening for domestic rail services passengers, because they are asked, among other things, to reject the Council's position. I support improving the quality of rail passenger services and associated operational efficiency, and therefore support the ALDE Group's position supporting the agreement.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — The objectives of this report, such as being subject to the principle of competition and tendering or the obligation to comply with state social standards and collective agreements, reflect purely political interest. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Wim Van de Camp's report on the opening up of the market for passenger rail services. Under the fourth rail package, the aim of this legislative proposal is to improve the quality of passenger rail services and to strengthen the competitiveness of the railway compared to other modes of transport. Indeed, while we are experiencing a revolution in road (Uber, carpooling, etc.) and air (low-cost companies), the rail sector must be stimulated. However, this openness must, of course, be monitored and should not in any case result in liberalisation that would expose us dangerously to international competitors and promote social dumping. That is why we, together with my colleagues, have ensured that the rail package does not create unfair competition. We have also obtained sufficient guarantees to ensure that the opening does not take place at the expense of spatial planning.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. Regulation 1370/2007 lays down the conditions governing services of general interest, public, national and international passenger transport. The competent transport authority may impose public service obligations on the operator of transport services of general interest and may grant him compensation for this purpose. Taking into account an exclusively economic interest, operators would not otherwise take over this.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger services. This would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway in relation to other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. In order to achieve the general objective, the Commission proposes to tender public service contracts based on compulsory tendering in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets. The aim is to increase the efficiency and quality of rail passenger transport services. Such measures shall be accompanied by provisions ensuring a framework conditions favourable to tendering procedures based on tendering, including rules on access to railway vehicles. The Commission proposal is closely related to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a single European railway area, which introduce open access rights for railway undertakings and reinforce the provisions on the management of infrastructure managers under the to enhance non-discriminatory access to railway infrastructure. Following the adoption of Parliament's first-reading position on 26 February 2014, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council (with a view to reaching an early second reading agreement). Following six trialogues, Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing. — The otherwise somewhat controversial regulation on the opening up of the market for domestic rail passenger services has already been decided at first reading by Parliament. To put it mildly, the experience of liberalising the markets is mixed, and this is essentially about large, often public firms from developed EU countries having access to budget support from less developed countries. However, the vote in question is no longer about the material as a whole, but only about amendments, because the body of the material has unfortunately been accepted by Parliament. The amendments that are now on the table are, for the most part, dealing with workers' rights and are therefore eligible for support.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the interinstitutional agreement reached on the regulation on the opening of the market for domestic passenger services by rail. The aim of the regulation is to improve the quality of rail services and to increase their operational efficiency. This will improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport vis-à-vis other modes of transport and will help further develop the Single European Railway Area.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that easier access for all rail operators to domestic rail markets will give rail passengers more choice and better quality services. In fact, the liberalisation of domestic passenger transport services by rail will boost business, investment, innovation in the sector and most importantly will provide new passenger services in EU countries’ domestic markets. Therefore, I strongly support easier access to the market for rail operators. Nevertheless, I totally disagree with the notion that Member States could limit a new operator’s right of access if a new service would compromise the ‘economic equilibrium’ of an existing public services contract. I believe that Member States should not intervene or limit competition in a free market because thus they will put railway transport in an unsatisfactory position vis-à-vis other modes of transport.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — Parliament's report is in line with the Commission's proposal on improving competition in rail transport, a competition which aims to increase the quality and efficiency of passenger transport services. The new rules, in fact, are intended to optimise the quality of passenger transposition services for railways and operational efficiency, and increase competitiveness compared to other transposition services, enhancing the single European rail area. It is therefore proposed to introduce compulsory competitive tendering procedures for public service contracts in such a way as to ensure favourable framework conditions. In addition, this proposal is closely linked to the subsequent report on the establishment of a single European rail area, which discusses free access rights for businesses and improved provisions on infrastructure management. Taking into account both recommendations, which are aimed at the same result, I am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. — The railway sector is a major issue, in Europe and more particularly in France, particularly in economic and environmental terms. Thus, I supported this report on 'national rail passenger services', which is part of the fourth rail package, because the latter carries a balanced and responsible vision. Without entering into forced liberalism, it promotes effective decisions, to give new opportunities for carriers. These new measures make it possible to open up the passenger transport market, giving sufficient guarantees so that this does not happen to the detriment of spatial planning. In the end, users will see the supply improve and regions will have greater freedom of choice in their service providers. It is not time for liberalization that would primarily benefit our international competitors and promote social dumping. With this fourth rail package, we are enabling this sector to gain competitiveness, while respecting social rights.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This text opens up national rail markets to competition from 2020 onwards. From that date, the State, the regions, will issue tenders for public contracts for a maximum duration of 10 years for the different lines to be operated. Not only is it the monopoly, the know-how of SNCF and the whole public service organisation that is called into question, but it is to replace them with very short private concessions (10 years it is nothing for the railway) that will discourage the necessary long-term investments. For our users, as for railway workers, the consequences are colossal. The introduction of a profit logic and liberalization mark the end of the public service provided by a public company. They also mark the end of equalization systems that allow the least profitable lines to be financed by the most profitable lines and thus ensure territorial cohesion. This is the primacy of profit on service against the user and the working conditions of railway workers. Because I am defending a public rail service, I therefore voted against this text.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the amendments rejecting the report on national rail passenger services. I welcome the fact that not only the ENL Group but three other political groups have tabled a rejection amendment. The “competition” report of the fourth rail package introduces an obligation to tender, including in public service cases, which must also be subject, with three minor exceptions, to the principle of competition and tendering. At the request of certain groups the obligation to comply with the social rules of States and collective agreements was included in the regulation. Still glad that companies must abide by the law! The fact that such evidence on paper is proof that it is only a political display. The proliferation of service providers in itself is a source of increased fraud and social dumping, especially in the case of international journeys.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I was not able to vote directly on this report, but I supported an amendment to reject the whole and others which sought to guarantee the rights of workers and the public service in the face of privatisation of railways. Unfortunately, the result of the votes has been favourable in importing the British railway model into the rest of the Union, and domestic passenger transport will therefore be progressively opened to private operators from 2020, with what it entails: higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of the conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of working conditions, with the recurrent intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will distribute the cake.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This text, which is included in the rail package, concerns an amendment to the Regulation on the opening to the market of national passenger transport services by rail. In order to achieve the objective of improving the operational efficiency of the railway and, consequently, the competitiveness of the railway market, it adopts a number of effective and transparent measures, such as facilitation by public service operators and managers of the information infrastructure determinant to the the award of future public service contracts to the competent authority, a strict list of areas in which direct award may be carried out or carried out a simplified and transparent procedure if the competent authority receives a single tender. I agree with this amendment, which will result in a better quality and quantity of rail services for our citizens.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality of rail passenger services in order to improve its operational efficiency. This should improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail, in relation to other types of transport, and further development of the single European railway area. In order to achieve this objective, the Commission has proposed to launch a public tender for public contracts providing rail transport services in EU countries with a view to improving and developing new business services. The aim is to increase efficiency and improve the quality of passenger services in rail transport. These measures are accompanied by provisions to ensure favourable framework conditions for the implementation of tender procedures, including rules on access to rolling stock. Due to all of the above, I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The introduction of mandatory public procurement procedures will increase the pressure on the competitive environment in rail passenger transport while at the same time delivering a higher quality of the services provided for users of these services. Competition procedures will enter into force from 3.12.2019. At the same time, the Regulation takes into account certain specificities and requirements for the effectiveness of procedures and therefore provides for derogations from the invitation to tender for direct award and simplified procedures. For example, a power value of less than 7.5 million/year or 500 thousand km.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the amendment, which is a joint proposal by the Greens, the EFDD and the GUE, to the recommendation for second reading concerning the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 on the opening up of the market for domestic passenger rail transport, for the reasons I explained in detail at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/12/2016, and because with this amendment Parliament rejects the position of the Council at first reading.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This text, like the other two reports of the fourth railway package, concerns the market component. This text seems to introduce an obligation to compete but in fact has only a political communication purpose. Moreover, the proliferation of providers is one of the sources of increased fraud and social dumping, which we are fighting firmly against.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation is based on an idea of a single market in the rail sector, with the aim of increasing competition in the sector. However, this proposal does not take into account the social impacts that such liberalisation of the market may have, since it calls into question the protection of the public transport network and the fulfilment of the rights of its workers. I voted in favour of rejecting the Council proposal.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The 4th railway package aims to liberalise the European rail sector. The application of a general procurement obligation is intended to save public money and remove market access barriers for smaller competitors. However, in exceptional cases may not be subject to the general obligation to tender and contracts may be awarded directly. In the future, infrastructure managers must be effectively independent in order to ensure equal access to infrastructure by railway undertakings. Railway undertakings must continue to comply with Union law, national law and collective agreements.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against the PSO regulation which is part of the 4th Railway Package. As shown by our current rail crisis, too much emphasis on private operators running our railways is letting down train passengers. These new laws undermine fair terms and conditions for railway staff and staffing standards overall and will not benefit passengers. The regulations potentially conflict with Labour Party policy to bring rail franchises under public ownership. I am opposed to the mandatory competitive tendering of rail franchises which could prevent a future Labour government from providing the best train services to my constituents across the East of England.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this proposal and the new EU rules in the field of rail transport. I hope they will encourage Member States to open public tenders for the carriage of passengers by train, as well as to create a level playing field for all operators to use railway infrastructure. EU rules aim to strengthen rail passenger services, whose popularity is lagging behind other modes of transport, and consumer assessments are ambiguous. At the same time, it is proposed to oblige all EU countries to open public tenders for the carriage of passengers by train or to justify why such a tender is not appropriate.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: The purpose of this Directive is to deepen the opening up of national passenger transport markets. To this end, the Commission has proposed introducing an obligation to compete for public service contracts in order to increase competitive pressure on national rail markets. Barriers are put to the fulfillment of direct public service contracts. In particular, the obligation to present justification, and the possibility for other transport actors to issue opinions. Finally, the text allows the national authorities to be dispossessed of their latest possibilities for action in the field of rail and public transport policy. On the contrary, the public transport service must be put at the heart of an ecological transition policy. I am voting against this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: This is a proposal to amend the Regulation on the opening to competition of the market for national passenger rail services. This will be the blow of grace to the Public Rail Passenger Service, which is why I opposed it.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — In voting on such a report, which favours a thoughtful opening up of the passenger transport market, I am one of those who wish to improve the quality of rail supply and services to users, as well as increase the modal share of train in passenger travel. This opening, together with a number of new rules applicable to all market participants in the interests of fairness, preserves the maintenance of the principle of direct award of public service contracts, a transitional period and the guarantee of optimal protection for workers in the event of transfer of public service contracts to public service contracts. new contractors. Our advantage is to be able to continue to proceed directly to public service contracts if the characteristics of an infrastructure are not suitable for the transition to the tendering procedure. This is a considerable concession for many Member States, including Belgium. It goes without saying that this direct allocation will have to lead to an improvement in the quality of services and/or the efficiency of costs; whereas the proposal does not require anything in the event of a tendering procedure (no quality criteria, no performance monitoring).

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council the adoption of a directive amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards the opening up of the market for domestic rail passenger services. The aim was to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger transport services. The Commission proposed the tendering of public service contracts based on compulsory tendering in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014. At the same time, the Lithuanian Parliament, the Luxembourg House of Representatives, the Dutch Senate and House of Representatives, the Austrian Federal Council and the Swedish Parliament have submitted reasoned opinions that the draft legislative act is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. Subsequently, interinstitutional negotiations took place, which resulted in an agreement between the Parliament's negotiating team on 19 April 2016 with the Presidency of the Council. The Council adopted its position at first reading on 17 October 2016 in accordance with the Agreement. In its report, the Committee on Transport and Tourism proposes that Parliament should agree with the Council's position at first reading, thus concluding that the act will be adopted in accordance with the Council's position. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The three reports which constitute the fourth part of the rail package are in line with the desired liberalisation of rail in all its aspects. French freight has already paid the cost of such measures, it is obviously unthinkable to endorse such texts. The EU still refuses to understand that people want efficient and affordable public services and the protection of their jobs. The time of permanent liberalism, which destroys the social fabric for the benefit of some, must come to an end. Against.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report introduces an obligation to tender, including for public services which must also be subject, with three minor exceptions, to the principle of competition and tendering. It aims to ensure that the financial compensation awarded is strictly proportionate (against disguised subsidies). At the request of the groups, including left-wing groups, the obligation to comply with the social rules of States and collective agreements was included in the regulation. Still glad that companies must abide by the law! The fact that such evidence on paper is proof that it is only a political display. The proliferation of service providers is itself a source of increased fraud and social dumping, especially in the case of international journeys. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the light of Labour Party policy on public ownership of rail, and the lack of protection in the ‘Political Pillar’ measures for staff when services are contracted-out, I voted against this proposal as it provides for a framework for rights of ‘open access’ to rail lines for commercial train operators, as well as reinforcing a default position of mandatory tendering of passenger service contracts.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this legislative resolution on the opening up of the market for national rail passenger services, which is part of the fourth rail package, which aims to make Europe's rail more competitive and safer. The resolution endorses the Council's position and reminds Member States that they must fully comply with the Directive on the maintenance of workers' rights in the event of transfers of undertakings and that they can even go beyond the application of the Directive by taking additional measures to protect staff.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The 4th railway package will create a more competitive rail sector by encouraging competition and innovation in domestic passenger markets while meeting the targets to reduce emissions. I have voted for this recommendation regarding opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. The proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 contains many positive elements that would improve the quality and efficiency of rail services in Central and Eastern European countries. However, I did not support its amendment because, along with the positive components, it includes a clause which is against the interest of workers in railway undertakings. The modernization of rail transport has a huge added value for both citizens and businesses in the Bulgarian region, because it will make the movement faster, cheaper and more sustainable. However, this modernisation cannot be built on the backs of employees of undertakings which should be guaranteed normal working conditions and security. Supporting this regulation would mean de facto support a clause allowing the mass dismissal of workers by railway undertakings in the event of a change of ownership. It is for this reason that I did not stand by amending this regulation.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I support this recommendation to adopt the regulation on opening the market for domestic passenger rail services, as it aims to stimulate competition in the European market and improve services. This regulation forms part of the fourth railway package and I believe that the introduction, among other things, of binding competitive procedures for the award of service contracts will help achieve the overall objectives. I also think it is important to stress that, by adopting this package, rail passenger services will be alternatives to other types of passenger transport, less cost-effective and environmental impact.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — Having approved the technical part of the railway package in the earlier months of this year, I also supported its market part, which is undoubtedly a step forward, a step towards creating a real competition in the passenger rail market, from which passengers will benefit in particular. In this context, one can sigh slightly at the relatively long transition period, or the deferral of efficiency, when only from 2023 the competent authorities (Ministry of Transport of the Czech Republic and counties) the obligation to award contracts for public services in the field of rail transport through tenders open to all railway undertakings in the EU, i.e. including private carriers. Given that currently 98% of the long-haul market is covered by contracts concluded directly, i.e. without a tender process, significant changes will need to be made in order to bring about creating fair competitive conditions. Ultimately, it will depend on the Member States and the Commission's position as they proceed to the enacted possibility of granting derogations from the obligation to issue tenders for the provision of personal rail transport even after the end of the transitional period.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This explanation of vote concerns amendment 10 to this report. The VVD Delegation in the European Parliament wholeheartedly supports the rights of disabled people, and is in favour of improving access for disabled people to public transport and other facilities in general. However, the VVD Delegation chose not to support this specific amendment as its adoption would imply a rejection of a crucial part of the railway package in second reading. This would lead to a disproportionate delay in the legislative process, which the people of Europe do not deserve. Moreover, it is unlikely that a reopening of the negotiations would lead to an alternative outcome concerning this specific issue.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting because this is merely a repetition of the annex to the legislative resolution.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The purpose of the changes is to improve the quality and efficiency of rail passenger transport services. The changes will address transparency requirements, social provisions, information and monitoring processes and the specific features of the rail sector in internal procurement.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is inevitable legally to avoid the award of public service contracts by prior tendering. This negotiated solution therefore makes the system more effective from a European point of view, and that is why I supported the proposal. In any event, I would like to point out the fact that we are talking about one of the major strategic sectors and that we will therefore be vigilant so that there is no prejudice to workers' rights, the quality of services or safety in favour of the mere economy We must strike the balance between efficiency, quality and the social needs that are met. Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening of the market in national passenger transport services by rail and the governance of railway infrastructures

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Over the last decade, three 'railway packages' have been aimed at opening up national markets and making railways more competitive and interoperable at EU level. In order to complete the opening of the domestic rail passenger market to competition, the European Commission has proposed revising the current regulation 1370/2007 by removing the possibility of direct award of public service contracts. In its proposal, the European Commission has addressed a number of market challenges for new entrants that prevent them from competing with the incumbent (e.g. SNCF, SNCB, Deutsche Bahn), such as lack of access to information needed to facilitate successful participation in public procurement procedures or the unavailability of a market for rolling stock. A second entry barrier for new entrants is access to rolling stock. I voted in favour of this report, which underlines the importance of improving the quality of passenger rail transport and enhancing their operational efficiency, thereby improving the competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail sector transport towards other modes of transport and with the further development of the Single European Rail Area.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. — The Communist Party of Greece voted against the three regulations on the 'Single European Rail Area', passenger rail transport and railway companies' accounts, which constitute the so-called '4th package' for its single rail market' and complete the full privatization of rail transport in the EU and Member States. The delivery of railways, all relevant public infrastructure and networks and transport work to large business groups serves the further profitability of business groups. It brings another serious blow to the working conditions and the labour rights of railway workers. It drastically worsens the quality and safety of rail transport and skyrockets the prices of tickets for the popular family. The interests of the capital are served by the co-ordination SYRIZA-ANEL with the concession to individuals of TRAINOSE, within the framework of its overall anti-grassroots policy, the 3rd and previous memoranda, which it formulates together with the EU and the IMF and with the agreement of the other parties of civil management. In order to make the railways and transport as a whole land, sea and air popular property, at the service of popular needs, the workers' struggle must target the very power of the monopolies, their imperialist union, the EU, for radical changes in the power and the economy.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion to defeat the regulations respecting public passenger rail services. The Socialists and Democrats Group has made several progress on this text, in particular to enable local authorities to award public service contracts directly while the Commission wanted to make competition compulsory. It was a fundamental issue to allow the necessary room for manoeuvre for communities to decide how public services are organized in transport. However, I deeply regret that this text does not include strong social guarantees to ensure that competition does not take place to the detriment of workers. The Socialists and Democrats Group also retabled an amendment in plenary to reintroduce compulsory transfer. Unfortunately, the right has blocked this amendment, which, however, would have made it possible to protect workers in the event of market opening, so that competition does not feed the so-called social least.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I think it is a fundamental step for the development of European transport that the rail sector is now now equipped with a Community regulatory framework which can facilitate its competitiveness.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The general objective of the Commission proposal for an amendment of Regulation (EC) 1370/2007 is to improve the quality of rail passenger services and to enhance their operational efficiency. This should improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail vis-à-vis other modes of transport and develop further the single European railway area. I voted in favour of this report because the tabled recommendations will deliver a more resilient and flexible market for domestic passenger transport services by rail.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. — The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards market opening for domestic passenger rail services is to improve the quality of rail passenger services, in order to improve the operational efficiency of rail transport. This should improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport and further development of the Single European Rail Area. In order to achieve this objective, the Commission proposes to introduce competitive tender for public service contracts, which is accompanied by measures to ensure favourable framework conditions of tender procedures, including rules on access to rolling stock. The Commission proposal is closely linked to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU on the establishment of a single European railway area, which introduces open access rights for rail carriers and reinforcing provisions relating to infrastructure management in respect of strengthening non-discriminatory access to infrastructure of railway operators. This will make rail transport easier and more accessible to all citizens.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — Regulation on public service obligations provides a legislative framework for rail and road passenger transport services in the domestic market. The regulation aims to complete the opening of this market, removing the possibility of direct award of public service contracts. Many obstacles, such as the inability to access the necessary information or the inaccessibility of the market for railway vehicles, need to be removed. That is why I support the introduction of regularly updated so-called transport plans, where competent authorities will display all modes of transport relevant in the territory for which they are responsible. I welcome that public bidding will now become the rule and their transparency will be strengthened through simplified access to key data — more efficient public procurement procedures are key to the proper functioning of a competitive market. It is necessary to establish better protection of working conditions for workers in the sector and greater security of employment in competitive public bidding. This added value of the social dimension of revision of commitments is important to the S&D group and we will continue to work on that — harmonising social protection at European level is just another aspect of the fight for workers” rights, the S&D Group's most important goal.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) This proposal is part of the EU's fourth railway package and focuses on amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007. This objective is to improve the quality of rail passenger services and increase their operational efficiency in order to improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport vis-à-vis other modes of transport and to develop the single European rail area. Well known palate. To achieve this objective, the Commission has proposed introducing a compulsory tender for public service contracts in order to intensify competitive pressure on national rail markets. In other words, in conjunction with the proposal of the European rail area, it opens up national rail systems, which are already completely deregulated, to international competition. Another step in the growing monopoly concentration in the sector. It is nonetheless paradoxical that there is talk of 'improving the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport vis-à-vis other modes of transport', using further liberalisation, while what statistics show is that liberalisation has only contributed to the loss of attractiveness. In this respect it should be noted that since 1988 Portugal has lost 43% passengers.km (pk); in the same period, Germany gained 24% and France 35%. We obviously voted against it.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the compromise arrangements developed for political pillar IV of the Railway Package. In terms of regulation ws. PSO, I am pleased to maintain the possibility of direct procurement in exceptional cases, to maintain a favourable definition of “local authorities”, which will allow the allocation of PSO contracts directly by provincial governments to internal entities (the companies formed by themselves transport, such as Koleje Mazowieckie or Koleje Wielkopolskie) optional for providing access to rolling stock, ensuring the possibility of implementing already concluded long-term PSO contracts (for the time for which they have been concluded). I hereby supported the compromise worked out.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because there was a need to modernise access to the national market for railway operators. Travelers expect a more competitive offer (price/quality) and we are now able to deliver them. However, this openness to competition will have to be supervised in order to ensure the highest level of quality of services.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the government of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders. It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion to defeat the regulations respecting public passenger rail services. The Socialists and Democrats Group has made several progress on this text, in particular to enable local authorities to award public service contracts directly while the Commission wanted to make competition compulsory. It was a fundamental challenge for me to give the communities the necessary room for manoeuvre to decide how public services are organized in transport. However, I deeply regret that this text does not include strong social guarantees to ensure that competition does not take place to the detriment of workers. Throughout the negotiations, I have committed myself to incorporating the principle of compulsory transfer in the event of a change of operator. The Socialists and Democrats Group also retabled an amendment in plenary to reintroduce compulsory transfer. Unfortunately, the right has blocked this amendment, which, however, would have made it possible to protect workers in the event of market opening, so that competition does not feed the so-called social least.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: I supported the Van De Camp report amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards the opening up of the market for national passenger rail passenger services. The main elements of the agreement reached with the Council relate to the maintenance of public service missions, compensation for the net financial impact of public service obligations and social provisions, including rights and obligations relating to the transfer of staff. So many potentially explosive subjects but have been the subject of compromises skillfully weighed. Certain important priorities for my political group have been taken into account by this Trilogue agreement, which is good news. This is the sharp reduction in direct award clauses, apart from a genuine tendering procedure and the provision that provides for the traveller better access to rolling stock. Is it necessary to remember that while the average price of the train ticket increased by 42.6% between 2005 and 2015, the satisfaction index has, over the same period, declined overall among passengers? The latter often deserve the title of adventurers to ride.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — I supported this proposal. Although it rejects the Council's position, it also really creates much greater opportunities for opening up the EU rail market. It places an appropriate place on the social rights of workers, national railway development plans of Member States and other important aspects of market regulation.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: In writing. — The Socialists and Democrats Group won a number of crucial points in the course of legislative work. Firstly, competition for public service contracts will not be mandatory, so that public persons will be able to enter into such contracts directly without a tendering procedure being implemented. Furthermore, access by private operators to railway infrastructure may be limited if it jeopardizes the margins of an operator with a public service mission. These two advances guarantee the sustainability of public services, cohesion of territories and access to rail infrastructure for all. On the other hand, the Council's position is not acceptable from a social point of view. The latter does not provide for automatic and compulsory transfer of personnel in the event of a change of operator, and the majority group in Parliament has prevented the adoption of an amendment to this effect. Therefore, the protection of workers is not adequately ensured. That is why I voted in favour of the motion to reject the Council's position on the regulation on the opening of the market for national passenger rail services.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: This legislative proposal is also part of the fourth railway package and aims to amend Regulation 1370/2007 with the aim of improving the quality of rail passenger transport services and enhancing their operational efficiency. By achieving these objectives, it will be possible to achieve an increase in the competitiveness and attractiveness of this transport within the framework of what is the single European rail area. To this end, a number of regulatory changes should be made, inter alia, involving the introduction of tenders that promote fair competition and improve the quality of service provided to passengers. An agreement has been reached from the interinstitutional negotiations held in this respect, the content of which contains specific elements relating to public service obligations and their financial compensation, social and labour provisions, information provision and other elements which may be are characterised by transparency, simplification and non-discrimination of procedures. In view of the fact that these are substantive amendments which will bring benefits to the quality of rail transport services within the single European area that we share, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 on the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail. The Regulation provides for an invitation to tender for public service contracts. The aim of this invitation to tender is to increase competitive pressure on inland rail markets, thereby ensuring greater efficiency or quality of rail services.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. — The compromise text negotiated between the European Parliament and the Council of the Political Pillar of the so-called 4th Railway Package is a compromise on a very sensitive subject. Over the past years, we have heard arguments for and against further opening up markets many times. Proponents of liberalisation speak of a push for greater efficiency in a competitive environment, its opponents argue examples where liberalisation has not ensured in the long run or better; and safer services to passengers, nor more dignified conditions of employees. Rather the opposite. The rules for opening markets must therefore be clear even with regard to quality standards and social standards of employees. Cheaper isn't necessarily better, and if opening up markets were to mean precarization and worsening employee conditions, it would be a lose-lose for the entire rail sector.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I was not able to vote directly on this report, but I supported an amendment to reject the whole and others which sought to guarantee the rights of workers and the public service in the face of privatisation of railways. Unfortunately, the result of the votes has been favourable in importing the British railway model into the rest of the Union, and domestic passenger transport will therefore be progressively opened to private operators from 2020, with what it entails: higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of the conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of working conditions, with the recurrent intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will distribute the cake.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ The new regulation provides for the gradual opening of national rail markets for passenger transport: the competent authorities must henceforth assign service contracts public through tenders open to all railway undertakings. In this regard, clearer rules are laid down for the definition of public service obligations and their scope and provisions on the protection of workers in the event of change of the operator. Considering the expected positive effects on the competitiveness and sustainability of the rail sector and the consequent boost to economic growth, I decided to speak out in favour of this.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the government of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders. It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and hat implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against the compulsory opening-up of railway contracts across Europe to private sector operators, as the new laws do not provide protection for rail workers’ terms and conditions when services are contracted out and also do not ensure good staffing standards on privately-run services. The PSO Regulation is part of the ‘political pillar’ of the 4th Railway Package. The political pillar essentially seeks to update existing legislation in order to mandate further ‘opening’ of the European rail market and expose more elements to competition. The new regime would apply in principle from the end of 2019, subject to some transitional protection.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The amendment proposals aim to improve the quality of rail passenger transport services and increase their operational efficiency. This should mean greater competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail sector compared to other types of transport and a step forward in the development of a single European rail area. But unfortunately, the report contains too many flaws to support it himself. The proposal for new rules provides that public service contracts in railway transport must be concluded on the basis of tender procedures open to competition. However, the Regulation provides quite an exception to that principle and allows contracts to be concluded directly or under a simplified procedure in quite a few cases, which means that Member States will be able to maintain their national systems over time. It also seems problematic to me that the Regulation does not include a provision setting binding criteria in calls for public services when it comes to strengthening environmental and social aspects, as well as on the determination of the minimum quality of public services. We also wanted stronger wording on passenger rights, social and employment conditions and accessibility, which was not achieved. For all the reasons mentioned, I voted against.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As part of building a single European railway area, we are also focused on improving the services provided in national transport. Quality and price are closely related to competition. In this arrangement, we increase transparency in public procurement related to rail transport services.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The Commission proposal is to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 and improve the quality of rail passenger transport services and its efficiency. This should improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of railways in relation to other types of transport and enable the development of a single European railway area. The general objective is to introduce compulsory competitive public tender for the provision of public services in order to increase competition pressure on domestic rail carriers with a view to improving efficiency and quality of services. After the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading, interinstitutional negotiations began with the aim of reaching an early agreement in the second reading. Also, public rail service contracts must be awarded on the basis of a competitive bidding procedure. I accept and vote for the legal act to enter into force since the first reading of the Council is in agreement with the agreement reached during interinstitutional negotiations and should be accepted without amendments.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a second reading recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation concerning the opening of the market for internal passenger rail services. This amendment to the Regulation, which forms part of the market pillar of the Fourth Railway Package, will improve the quality of rail passenger transport services and increase their operational efficiency. I support increasing competitiveness in the rail sector compared to other types of transport. This will take an important step in the development of a single European railway area.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the proposal for the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards the opening of the market for national services in passenger transport by rail. In particular, this proposal aims to introduce common rules on the conclusion of public service contracts in the area of passenger rail transport. This is an important step to help complete the liberalisation of passenger rail services. The proposal will also help improve the environment, quality of service and cheapen prices for customers. Among other things, when opening up the market, Member States will take account of adequate social protection for employees.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - This proposal requires the competent authorities to ensure that the specifications of the public service obligations and the relative compensation of the net economic effect of the public service obligations meet the objectives of the public transport policy in a cost-effective manner. In addition, the amount of compensation should ensure the economic viability of the provision of public passenger transport, in accordance with the requirements laid down in the framework of public transport policy over time. This does not allow the Member States to decide on the provision of public goods even on economically disparate terms to their citizens in the context of their social policy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — By amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007, the European Commission aims to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger transport services. As one element, the Commission proposes the tendering of public service contracts on the basis of compulsory tendering. In addition, competent authorities would be obliged to clearly define the public service obligations applicable to public passenger transport services and their scope, such as services covering costs by the competent authorities combine with services that do not cover costs. This is essentially a compensation for the net financial impact of the operation of public service obligations in a cost-effective manner. The draft also includes social aspects, such as the need for public service providers to comply with the obligations laid down in legislation and collective agreements applicable in the field of social and labour law. Nevertheless, I believe that this second reading proposal has been too watered up, since liberalisation of the rail market makes sense if it is combined with open competition and social and labour protection for workers. They did not appear markedly in the present proposal, thanks to the EPP aspirations, so I did not consider this to be acceptable in this form.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - Domestic passenger rail transport is socially important, but also from the perspective of the environment, the mobility of individuals and the safety of passengers. Transforming domestic passenger rail into a modern EU industrial branch can be made possible through the cooperation of Member States in the realisation of the single European railway area, using railway models that have already demonstrated their effectiveness within the Community. At national level, obviously, the central role of the organisation of domestic passenger rail services lies with the competent authorities, which must fulfil their public passenger transport policy objectives in their territory. Multimodal public transport plans must be sustainable, coherent and efficient so as to ensure cost-effective quality and efficient rail transport services according to the criteria: punctuality, profitability, frequency of services, customer satisfaction, rolling stock quality and modal sharing of public transport. I agree that public service operators must comply with certain social standards, specifications and public service contracts, if so requested by the competent authorities, giving details of the contractual rights of staff, and the conditions under which employees are deemed to be related to those services.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - Overall, the regulation on public service operators lays the foundations for a dynamic and efficient rail system which, in the long term, will be able to ensure the competitiveness of this mode of transport compared to that of road. Most importantly, the introduction of an auction system based on efficiency and transparency criteria will encourage private sector investor participation, which ultimately will mean better passenger services. However, it is important, however, that efforts to reform the rail system do not erode the social rights of workers in this area. The social dimension of this regulation is indispensable for a functioning transport system, which obliges the European institutions to try to provide guarantees for workers' rights in situations where operator changes occur.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I opposed the motion for rejection as well as the amendments that were tabled in order to support the agreement the European Parliament reached with the Council and the Commission. The text will gradually make public tendering compulsory for the attribution of railway routes under public service obligations – such public tendering will increase the transparency of the procedure and should incentivise railway undertakings to provide ever better services to the passengers. Public tendering will also favour the emergence of new railway undertakings. Throughout the negotiations I aimed at setting up strict safeguards to allow public authorities to directly award the route to a specific operator, to set clear rules as concerns the accessibility of rolling stock and a shorter transitional period. In the end, I am satisfied with the deal that we managed to sign.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The market pillar of the Fourth Railway Package seeks to improve the competitiveness of the rail sector and the quality of rail services through the introduction of competitive public tender for railway service contracts, comprising three legislative proposals, including amendments to the Regulation on market opening for domestic rail passenger transport services. The proposed amendments set out clearer rules regarding the definitions of public service obligations and their scope of application and will effectively achieve the objectives of public transport policy, primarily the financial sustainability of the provision of public transport services. Provisions on social protection of employees in case of change of public service operators have been added and compliance with quality standards and social standards is achieved. As I believe that the proposed amendments will contribute to a simplified and transparent process of liberalisation of the rail sector, I supported this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the positions of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards the opening of the market for internal passenger rail services. The overall objective of the Commission proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality of rail passenger transport services and increase their operational efficiency. This should mean greater competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail sector compared to other types of transport and a step forward in the development of a single European rail area.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I will abstain on the Public service obligation report. The reason for this is that there is no real improvement of the situation compared to the Recast of the 1st railway package. The European regulator is still not in existence, the regulatory barriers to market access will remain present. There is no real opening of the market and tender will remain a fiction because Member States can appeal to the ‘economic equilibrium’ argument and many exceptions exist to tender and real opening of the market.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The “competition” report (Van de Camp) introduces an obligation to tender, including in public service cases, which must also be subject, with three minor exceptions, to the principle of competition and tendering. It aims to ensure that the financial compensation awarded is strictly proportionate (against disguised subsidies). The proliferation of service providers in itself is a source of increased fraud and social dumping, especially in the case of international journeys. I voted against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The project has a number of errors which, when cumulatively, give a negative picture of the changes. The fundamental mistake is that the railway is always a strategic state-owned company. As a result, each state should decide in its own right whether or not it wants to open up to private capital. That's why I didn't support the proposed changes.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. In order to achieve the general objective, the Commission proposes to tender public service contracts based on compulsory tendering in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets. The aim is to increase the efficiency and quality of rail passenger transport services. Such measures shall be accompanied by provisions ensuring a framework conditions favourable to tendering procedures based on tendering, including rules on access to railway vehicles. I followed S&D's position by Voksom.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We have tabled a rejection amendment and a number of amendments to the content against this amendment to the Regulation, which requires that the management of lines operated under public service contracts subsidized by public funds be put into competition. I understand that there was no reason to amend this text, which until today allowed each Member State, taking into account its own needs, to choose which contracts it wants to open for public tender and which contracts it grants directly to the national public operator. In addition, we have echoed the demands of trade unions across Europe for the serious lack of protection that workers will remain in cases of change of operator following a new contract. The only objective of this new text is the obligation to ensure open competition between all operators potentially present on the market, competition which is expected to take place at the expense of public coffers, essential elements of the public service and working conditions. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against because the tendering process is not delivering for passengers and this new package will not help matters. There are insufficient binding criteria to ensure environmental and social standards are met, and the minimum service quality criteria are not strong enough to ensure public services are of real benefit to users.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this agreement, public authorities maintain a scope for defining public service obligations in the area of rail, which must be consistent with strategic transport objectives. The text includes the principle of proportionality, which is already established in the acquis communautaire. From an economic point of view, the new rules contain a number of provisions that seek a balance between efficiency in the provision of the service and ensuring the long-term economic viability of responsible companies. For all these reasons, and with the ultimate objective of helping to increase the efficiency and competitiveness of rail transport services in the Union, I supported this agreement by voting a positive vote.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I was not able to vote directly on this report, but I supported an amendment to reject the whole and others which sought to guarantee the rights of workers and the public service in the face of privatisation of railways. Unfortunately, the result of the votes has been favourable in importing the British railway model into the rest of the Union, and domestic passenger transport will therefore be progressively opened to private operators from 2020, with what it entails: higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of the conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of working conditions, with the recurrent intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will distribute the cake.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted against because the competent authorities (CA) are required to clearly define the PSO specifications in public passenger transport, including the geographical areas concerned.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The Commission proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 aims at improving the quality of rail passenger services and increasing operational efficiency. This is supposed to strengthen the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport compared to other modes of transport and to further develop the Single European Railway Area. However, in practice, the Commission has proposed introducing a requirement of competition between public service contracts in order to intensify competitive pressure on national rail markets by putting pressure on low standards of safety, rights and quality of services.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The 4th railway package aims to liberalise the European rail sector. The application of a general procurement obligation is intended to save public money and remove market access barriers for smaller competitors. However, in exceptional cases may not be subject to the general obligation to tender and contracts may be awarded directly. In the future, infrastructure managers must be effectively independent in order to ensure equal access to infrastructure by railway undertakings. Railway undertakings must continue to comply with Union law, national law and collective agreements.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European railways are in need of urgent modernisation and more competition in order for them to become a genuine alternative to road transport. While the technical aspects of the railway reform were already voted on a few months ago, today the European Parliament voted on three reports addressing the political aspects. After three years of difficult negotiations between the Parliament and the Member States, Socialists and Democrats, including Labour MEPs, decided to reject the compromise reached with the Council on one of the reports, on the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services. During the negotiations, the Council completely dismissed the demand by the European Parliament to ensure the mandatory transfer of staff in cases of change of provider in the public sector. Labour MEPs back railway modernisation, but not at the expense of workers.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support this proposal, which relates to the Fourth Railway Package. In order to achieve better and better rail services at Europe-wide level, there is a need to create a single railway area based on an open and non-discriminatory access to rail infrastructure. This is the proposal presented dealing with the obligations of services for public transport of passengers, as well as the financial and social aspects of rail transport. I also consider it important that the proposal clearly and transparently describes how to tender for public services is to take place.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the recommendation on the Council's position for the adoption of a regulation amending the rules as regards the opening up of the market for national rail passenger services. Again, this is part of the fourth rail package. With proposals in the area of rail transport, the European Commission broadly monitors improving the quality of rail services and enhancing their operational efficiency. The changes introduced should, inter alia, improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of rail transport in relation to other modes of transport and ensure the further development of the single European railway area. The domestic rail passenger market is already the last sector that has not yet been liberalised. I think that the final agreed text is very balanced and, despite the fact that it still contains many exceptions or long periods for the application of this Regulation, given the complexity of the sector being modified, these small shortcomings cannot be reproached by the creators. However, I believe that, nevertheless, this amended regulation will meet its objective and bring many improvements and benefits to passengers.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. — In order to increase transparency, I support this report by my colleague Wim van de Camp and the proposal to introduce a compulsory public tender for the provision of public services for rail passenger transport. Improving the quality of rail passenger services and its efficiency is possible solely by increasing the pressure of competition on domestic carriers, but this system needs to be made transparent. In line with the objective of increasing transparency, I consider it acceptable for competent authorities at national levels to clearly establish specifications for public service obligations in public transport of passengers and their scope and ensure that the service is carried out in an economical manner. All these amendments to the Regulation in the report can and realistically expect to improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway and enable the development of a single European railway area.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a Recommendation for a second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 as regards the opening of the market for internal rail passenger transport services. I support the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007, as I believe that it includes concrete measures and solutions to improve the quality of rail passenger transport services and increase their operational efficiency. Measures taking a step forward in the development of a single European rail area will bring more competitiveness of the rail sector compared to other types of transport.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this regulation and I believe that the whole rail package is a big step forward towards European integration and for improving rights and services of European citizens. Mobility means competitiveness and liberalisation of rail services will allow our citizens to be more competitive and have a more efficient track transport system. Railway companies from other countries will thus be able to intervene and invest in those areas neglected by Italian companies, make agreements with local governments and hire staff on site. Finally the binaries won't have a monopoly on a company that neglects remote areas, in which it is not convenient for them to invest. I really hope that liberalisation, as well as industries, will also apply to the citizens, which frees them, precisely, from the constraint of ancient and inefficient rail services, in favour of services most modern and truly European transport.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I supported this proposal. I think this is exactly an example of the European Union showing that it makes sense. Because the liberalization of railways, the possibility of individual national carriers to implement their trade, their services and in other states, that is to use just the transport rail infrastructure in other countries of the European Union will lead to only that transport services will be more efficient and cheaper for the citizen. I have a liberal position on the matter. I am somewhat sorry that some of the steps in this package will not be until 2023, when individual carriers will be able to report to public tenders in individual Member States of the European Union. I think it could have been much sooner. Likewise, there are a number of exceptions in this package where, in short, the owner of the transport infrastructure will not be forced to embark on his infrastructure of a foreign carrier. So going forward, it's going to want to eliminate some of the problems and liberalize that space even more.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, I voted against the fourth railway package because it responds to the European Commission's repeated interests in dismantling the public rail system in Europe since the 1990s. In particular, the governance part lays down the obligation to open railway services to privatisation and to design an absolutely fragmented system. We are aware of the dire consequences of the liberalisation of the train because the United Kingdom experienced them in the 1990s. Free concurrence did not mean an improvement in service quality and competitive prices, but increased prices, abandonment of infrastructure, increased insecurity and accidents and economic bankruptcy, as well as deteriorating working conditions, to the extent that the State has had to be forced to renationalize and rescue some of the lines. We therefore clearly bet on a railway as a public service, as a mechanism for territorial backbone and social development and as a more efficient and more sustainable means of transport at the service of people.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, what Thatcher did not dare to do, this Parliament will do: completely privatize the rail sector. In case there were any doubts, the current European Union is on the right of the most radical neoliberalism. Promoting the railway requires aligning the territory with the conventional train, betting on affordable prices and ensuring coherent infrastructure planning. That is the only way to ensure that the train is an attractive option for people's mobility and for the transport of goods. Only a public train can ensure decent work for railwayers and a safe infrastructure for everyone. What the European Union will succeed, on the contrary, is to destroy the regional railway and eliminate all but the most profitable lines; for private operators to exploit workers and abuse passengers. That the train, in short, return to the 19th century.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - Madam President, this is the last report in today's rail transport package. Basically, in this last report we are talking about a single European area for rail transport and the privatisation of rail transport. Of course this means much more mobility for citizens and products, it means competition, it means compliance with the same rules and it means a beginning of rapprochement between Member States where rail transport, infrastructure and equipment are old and need to be reformed. This is what we rely on in several countries, including Romania, because in this single market we have to be at the same level as other states where the railway is of quality, are fast. This unique area we hope will also reach countries where the railway infrastructure is old and needs to be replaced and that it will bring benefits and funds.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted against the so-called 'fourth rail package' for the reasons which have just been quite illustrated by my colleagues in the group and because I agree in full the considerations expressed by the European Transport Workers' Federation. I believe that facilitating a process of liberalising the rail network without giving any guarantee to workers and workers means two things: facilitating social dumping, means decreasing safety in transporting travelers. In Italy we have clear disputes of what this means in the privatisation of rail transport. To defend the rights of workers, to defend the safety of passengers, I strongly reiterate my vote against the fourth rail package.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PP
text: E). — Madam President, I supported this report because I believe that the liberalisation of services in rail passenger transport, if it is actually conducted in order to protect competition, is fully in place. It increases competitiveness, delivers additional benefits for passengers and also for taxpayers. For that reason, I believe that increasing competitiveness in passenger rail services is fully in place, and I don't mind that liberalisation at all. I would also like to note that a similar increase in the quality of services has happened in freight transport. If there has been an increase in competitiveness, there is no reason to believe that this increase in the competitiveness of rail passenger transport will be avoided. I reiterate that this mode of mass public transport is undoubtedly very environmentally friendly and we should really support it.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The following report is part of the context of liberalisation of services in Europe, some steps to promote competition for international transport have already been done, now what is proposes to do is to apply the same rules for national markets. Although liberalisation of services is certainly a positive element, some considerations should not be left out. For example, experience teaches us how in many cases excessive liberalisation aimed at the elimination of monopolies has brought negative effects, Italy is a clear example of this. For these reasons, I decided to vote positively on the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — As with the van de Camp report, I supported the withdrawal of the text. In this case, regulations and control mechanisms are created to facilitate the liberalisation and privatisation of the railway sector, thus entailing higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of conditions labor, with the recurring intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will be distributed the cake.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted against the amendments proposing the rejection of the Council's position. I support the proposal for a Single European Railway Area and the measures it contains, which will make it easier for new entrants and service providers to enter the internal markets for rail passenger services. This reform should lead to investment in the rail sector, and increased competition would lead to a decrease in prices and a higher quality of services. Trains are an environmentally friendly vehicle, so promoting rail transport would also help reduce emissions across Europe.
