The reform aims to enable all EU railway companies to provide rail services across the EU, ensuring financial transparency and fair financing conditions. Equal access opportunities and a growing number of operators should ultimately lead to traffic. Increasing competition and specialisation of market participants should also have a positive impact on efficiency and efficiency and encourage an increase in investment in railway infrastructure. New market entrants are expected to be able to provide competing commercial services from 2020 and from 2023 competent authorities will have to conclude public rail service contracts by organising tenders in which everyone will be able to participate (with the exception of certain cases) EU railway companies.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The governance report of the market component of the fourth rail package aims to open up national passenger transport markets. The aim is to intensify competition to increase the supply and quality of services, to make the rail market equal to any company. The report points out that these provisions have enabled the success of rail freight: in France it is 20% in 5 years! Another objective is obviously the fight against global warming... This “governance” report aims to separate manager and operator activities by eliminating the dual operator-manager caps (which would promote conflicts of interest). The only positive point in this report is that companies already convicted of serious violation (what is the definition of “serious”?) binding collective agreements cannot obtain a licence to carry out passenger rail transport. Note that SNCF has been condemned several times for this reason... I obviously opposed this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the Council position, which was put forward by four political groups, as I do not believe that a single EU railway area is desirable for the United Kingdom. In particular, being a Member from the United Kingdom, I note that cross-border cooperation on such matters is extremely limited in scope and covers merely the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland (which is covered under the Good Friday Agreement) and the Channel Tunnel (which is covered by the Le Touquet Treaty). Therefore this proposal is wholly unnecessary for the United Kingdom.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As the European Union, we strive for a competitive and dynamic market that would incentivise stable growth in all Member States. A key factor in order to reach these goals is the fluidity of movement of goods which heavily relies on the railway system in Europe. From the times of the ‘Iron Curtain’ the railway system was a definitive difference between the two sides, the remnants of which stigmatise the ability of people and goods to move throughout the whole of Europe. A single European railway area would show the Europe is moving to true and full cooperation, allowing their citizens to travel freely around all of Europe and allowing their companies to benefit from the advantages of trade. For these reasons a single European railway area would benefit all Member States and would further strengthen the European Union as a whole.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal for a single European railway area. The aim of this report is to open up a market for domestic rail passenger services with a view to increasing competitive pressure on national rail markets in order to offer more better quality passenger services.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: The purpose of this report is to increase competition for, in theory, increase the supply and quality of services by making the rail market equally accessible to any company. It aims to separate the operations of manager and operator by eliminating the dual operator-manager caps, which would necessarily promote conflicts of interest. The rapporteur points out that these provisions have enabled rail freight to succeed; however, in France, the result of such a policy has been a 20% reduction in the number of intercities in five years. The only positive point would be that companies already convicted of serious violations of binding collective agreements would not be able to obtain a licence to carry out passenger rail transport. It may be noted, however, that SNCF has already been convicted several times on these grounds, without consequence. This report would therefore, for France, be either unnecessary or harmful, and I voted in favour of rejecting the text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — Three texts were on the table for the vote on the fourth railway package: one on standardization of accounts, one on governance and the last on public service obligation. We did not reject the first two. In the report on the governance directive, we have achieved compliance with our red line: private competition can be limited if it infringes public service obligations. On the other hand, we strongly opposed the last text, which required further liberalisation of public passenger rail service. This liberalisation will not only be detrimental to rail users, but also at the expense of workers, especially because it does not introduce the automatic and compulsory transfer of personnel in the event of a change of operator. For the Socialist MEPs in the European Parliament, such a strong social guarantee was essential in order to ensure that competition does not take place at the expense of workers' rights and does not open the way for other forms of social dumping. We led the sling in Parliament, but we lost the vote rejecting this text by 15 votes out of 751, the right having supported it massively.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We have tabled a rejection amendment and a number of content amendments against this amendment to the Directive which aims to make it mandatory to open passenger rail services to private operators, by means of a system in which any operator can provide rail services by renting tracks in a certain section and schedule. This reform combined with the amendment of the Public Service Regulation voted just before, is a lack of purpose both in terms of the coherence of the rail network as a whole (universal accessibility, promotion of social and territorial cohesion, etc.) and in terms of safety coordination and control. We are already aware of the consequences where this liberalisation has been implemented (UK, for example) and have been disastrous in terms of worsening the frequency and quality of service, rising prices and serious security failures. We will continue to oppose this market model and defend a public railway at the service of the needs of citizens in each territory. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the three reports of the rail package. Aiming at opening up national passenger transport markets, the Governance Report (Sassoli) aims to increase the supply and quality of services, making the rail market more accessible to new companies. Such a policy has led to the fall of 20% of rail freight in France... Worse yet, the competition report (Van de Camp) introduces an obligation of competition, including in cases of public service, by leading a genuine hunt for all forms of subsidies... A policy that goes against national interests and economic protectionism. The purpose of the Kyllonen report is to make it possible to compensate railway undertakings for the significant costs they have to pay, particularly as a result of their collective agreements. He's unsuitable.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this recommendation on the Single European Railway Area. These changes should increase competition, ensure financial transparency and fair financing conditions. Equal access opportunities and a growing number of operators should ultimately create new economic activities and encourage traffic. Increasing competition and specialisation of market participants should also have a positive impact on efficiency and efficiency and encourage an increase in investment in railway infrastructure. Combining open access and competing tenders for public service contracts should make the market even more open, as has already been the case in the freight and international passenger markets, as demonstrated by the more mature freight market, which allowed rail to occupy higher market share. Increased competition should increase the attractiveness of rail transport, which will make the sector more responsive to customer needs, making it easier for rail carriers to compete with other modes of transport. Further development of high-speed passenger services should also make rail transport more competitive, increasing its market share and all this will contribute to the achievement of climate change objectives. The expansion of railway transport activities should also increase demand for skilled railway workers and railway infrastructure facilities and demand for rolling stock, thereby creating more jobs in the railway manufacturing industry.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. − This Regulation, which is now proposed by the Commission to repeal, allowed Member States to compensate railway undertakings for payments relating to obligations which are not burdened by undertakings of other modes of transport. As the Commission states in its proposal, the regulation is no longer in line with the current legal environment. I share this opinion with the Commission as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation. I also agree that the current text of the regulation is discriminatory because it only makes the possibility of compensation available to the 40 companies indicated in the annexes to the regulation. Therefore, it is not possible to maintain the Regulation in force. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014. At the time, the European Parliament supported the repeal of the regulation, but requested that the repeal provision enter into force only two years later. Following the adoption of Parliament's position at first reading, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council. Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Presidency of the Council on 19 April 2016.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is to make the European rail market equal for any company, to the detriment of the strategic national choices of each Member State, by establishing a separation between the operations of manager and operator and the elimination of the dual operator-manager caps. He claims that this liberalisation will allow rail freight to succeed, whereas in France it has declined by 20% in five years. I am therefore voting against this report. I am voting in favour of the rejection amendment tabled by my group.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this file, which is part of the ‘market pillar’ of the so-called ‘Fourth Railway Package’, which is aimed at entrenching market liberalisation and competition in the European railway sector. This file concerns amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU that would open up the domestic passenger market to any rail operator, including newcomer operators, without consideration of the role and functioning of public ownership, large public infrastructure investments, and public funds and public service obligation contracts. In fact, the only policy criterion really considered in this is the promotion of competition for its own sake, with no consideration given to safety, accessibility, social and territorial cohesion or working conditions. While we support improvements and reform in the railway sector, Sinn Fein opposes the Fourth Railway Package due to its heavily neoliberal, pro-market bias. In particular, the ‘Market Pillar’ involves downgrading and repealing existing provisions, minimising Member State involvement in the sector and facilitating increased liberalisation and a more competitive market, rather than focusing on improving services. I therefore voted against the proposed amendments.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ In order to follow up on the commitment to create a single market for rail transport services, a common regulatory framework for rail safety must be established. Member States have developed safety standards and standards of essentially national scope, based on national technical and operational concepts, including the issuing of safety certifications of the national authorities. Instead, we need a single safety certificate for the European Union and a common safety policy also in the rail field. Strengthening the ERA, making it responsible for issuing safety certificates to railway undertakings operating in more than one Member State, would be a major advance for improvement in terms of safety culture and reporting of certain events of railway undertakings and network operators, as well as for the harmonisation and overall efficiency of the trans-European transport network. The safety and efficiency of European railways depend an important part of the possibilities for mobility of European citizens and sustainable development from an environmental and social point of view.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This report is an integral part of the fourth rail package and aims to open up national passenger transport markets. The objective is to increase competition in order to improve the quality of services offered while contributing to lower rates in the interest of customers. However, past experiences show us the opposite, as in the United Kingdom, where prices have steadily increased for equivalent quality, not to mention the obsolete and obsolescence of railway infrastructure. The liberalisation of rail transport which the European Union is trying to impose on Member States is intended only to serve the financial interests of large private groups, which see it as a source of profitability. Let us protect our public companies, working in public service missions, from the wild competition of private companies whose sole objective is to increase the remuneration of their shareholders. I therefore voted against this text and in favour of the rejection proposal.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The agreement reached in trilogue at second reading amends Directive 2012/34/EU on the single European rail area. This amendment aims, first, to open up the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail, with the aim of intensifying competitive pressure on national rail markets with the aim of increasing the quantity and improving the quality of passenger transport services; secondly, to improve the governance of the infrastructure manager, with the aim of ensuring equal access to infrastructure. In this regard, it provides for the elimination of conflicts of interest affecting the decisions of the infrastructure manager on market access and eliminating the possibility of subsidies cross between infrastructure managers and railway undertakings, existing in integrated structures. The changes made are also aimed at strengthening coordination between infrastructure managers and rail operators in order to improve the response to market needs, and to intensify the cross-border cooperation between infrastructure managers.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This file is part of the ‘Market Pillar’ of the Fourth Railway Package, which I oppose as it is aimed at entrenching liberalisation, competition and the market in the European railway sector. Specifically, this vote concerns a Council recommendation to amend Directive 2012/34/EU, opening up the domestic passenger market to any rail operator, including newcomer operators, without consideration of the role and functioning of public ownership, large public infrastructure investments, and public funds and public service obligation contracts. In fact, the only policy criterion really considered in this is the promotion of competition for its own sake, with no consideration given to safety, accessibility, social and territorial cohesion or working conditions. Therefore I voted in favour of an amendment to reject the text.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the governments of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders.  It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report is part of the liberalisations of services in Europe, which unfortunately have not always resulted in the expected positive effects. Too often, in order to eliminate historical monopolies, wild liberalizations have been carried out which had the sole purpose of favouring industry at the expense of quality of services, social protection and public service obligations. The M5S Europa supported in the trilogue meetings the maintenance of internal and external reciprocity clauses which were not included in the negotiated final text. I therefore decided to vote in favour of the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We are voting against the report as we disagree with its main points.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the proposal to reject the recommendation amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening up of the internal rail passenger services market and the governance of railway infrastructure. I believe that solely targeting economic indicators and profits does not benefit European citizens, and that is why I voted in favour of rejecting the recommendation.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Consistent with the vision of Europe which I have been yearning since I was a young boy, I vote favourably to the measure as decisive in achieving a fully integrated Union with regard to the rail transport. Moreover, it must represent an excellence in terms of efficiency in the provision of its services as well as an example in the positivity of its economic and financial indicators. In order for what is to take place, it is specifically proposed to open up the market by intensifying its competition in order to improve the efficiency of public financing and the quality of the whole sector, It is jointly aimed at implementing governance policies that conform the rights of passengers with the strengthening of social arrangements. In this regard, it is planned to introduce a comprehensive system for issuing tickets in order to enable more efficient transport of multimodal and cross-border passengers; it is essential, morally, provide clarification on the role of the European network formed by infrastructure managers by including mechanisms to ensure the assessment of their performance. The ambitiously proposed objective is further intended to ensure equal access to infrastructure with the most anticipated absence of conflicts of interest. This is, overall a significant step towards the single rail market in which Ferrovie dello Stato will be the protagonist.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail and the governance of the railway infrastructure. I did not support the proposal to reject the Council position on the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail and the governance of the railway infrastructure.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: - The Commission's proposal to amend Directive 2012/34/EU, also known as the 'Governance Directive', aims to ፦Opening up the market for national rail passenger transport services, with the aim of intensifying competitive pressure on national rail markets; - Strengthen the Governance of the infrastructure manager with the aim of ensuring equal access to infrastructure. These amendments are intended to contribute to increasing the level of competition, ensuring financial transparency and fair financing conditions. The role of the European Parliament has been key to achieving the overall agreement with the Council and succeeded in making the following improvements to the Commission proposal፦ Establishment of safeguards to ensure the impartiality and independence of infrastructure managers; - Establishment by Member States of a framework - Establishment of mandatory coordination mechanisms between infrastructure managers and railway undertakings; - Strengthening the powers of regulatory authorities. I therefore support this Recommendation.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because with the railway package we will make a decisive contribution to increasing competition in passenger transport. With equal market access and the increasing number of operators, we should enable more business activities and additional transport. Increased competition and specialisation of market participants should also have a positive impact on the productivity and efficiency of the European Railway Area and should lead to more investment in rail infrastructure.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the governments of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders.  It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure which has as a general objective to create a single European rail area. The main aspects I agree with the proposal are: market openness and public service contracts through a more balanced approach; better governance of the rail sector; greater protection of passengers' rights through the creation of a comprehensive ticket issuance system; strengthening social provisions and clarifying the role of the European network between operators of the European network infrastructure.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - As with the van de Camp report, I supported the withdrawal of the text. In this case, regulations and control mechanisms are created to facilitate the liberalisation and privatisation of the railway sector, thus entailing higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of conditions labor, with the recurring intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will be distributed the cake.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The governance directive aims at opening up the market for domestic passenger transport services by rail, with the aim of intensifying competitive pressure on the markets national railways in order to increase the quantity and improve the quality of passenger transport services. I believe that such an improvement in the governance of the infrastructure manager, with the aim of ensuring equal access, can realistically increase competition and ensure transparency financial and fair financial conditions. I therefore voted positively to this resolution because I believe that increased competition improves the attractiveness of the rail sector, making it more attentive to the needs of customers, and encourages the increased demand for skilled rail workers, thus creating new jobs.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — In view of the potential and untapped opportunities in the rail sector, I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position. I agree with the proposal to amend Directive 2012/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 November 2012 on the creation of a single European rail area with regard to the opening of the market for national rail passenger services and the management of rail infrastructure. I believe that the proposed changes will contribute to the development of the railway sector and improve the quality of services provided. The amendments to the Directive include a number of measures to increase the attractiveness, innovation and competitiveness of EU rail transport. It envisions the establishment of law giving European companies the ability to operate across the EU and the tightening of competition rules. The regulation introduces provisions to enable the standardisation of regulations in the railway sector and increases transparency of the actions taken.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which mainly aims to raise the level of competition, transparency and fair financial conditions in the single European railway area. The report also introduces safeguards to ensure independence and enforcing provisions on traffic management, maintenance and essential functions.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - I believe it is necessary to open the market for domestic passenger rail services, the main objective of which is to increase the competitive pressure on national rail markets, thereby increasing the quantity and improving the quality of transport services.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This legislative report aims to improve the governance of railway infrastructure managers in order to ensure equal access for operators and aims to strengthen coordination within a Member State, but also cross-border, between infrastructure managers and rail operators in order to improve the level of access for operators. meet the needs of the market. Considering these elements, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the governments of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders.  It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of amending the directive establishing a single European rail area, as regards the opening of national markets to European companies engaged in rail freight services and international passenger transport by rail. While rail transport has so far experienced a much lower pace of development than other modes of transport, increased competition in the national market will make it possible to make rail an alternative and accessible mode of transport. Increasing the quality and quantity of services is an opportunity for both the rail industry and European travellers. National rail operators will have to comply with new rules of transparency, impartiality and governance before 1 January 2019.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of these reforms on transport in Europe. They propose a balanced compromise between opening up shared transport markets and spatial planning, so as to make the railway industry competitive without losing sight of respect for development and local specificities, and respect for workers' social rights. It is important to adapt to international competition while protecting our industries and territories.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The general objective of the Commission proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 is to improve the quality and operational efficiency of rail passenger services. This would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the railway in relation to other modes of transport and further develop the Single European Railway Area. In order to achieve the general objective, the Commission proposes to tender public service contracts based on compulsory tendering in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets. The aim is to increase the efficiency and quality of rail passenger transport services. Such measures shall be accompanied by provisions ensuring a framework conditions favourable to tendering procedures based on tendering, including rules on access to railway vehicles. The Commission proposal is closely related to the proposed amendments to Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a single European railway area, which introduce open access rights for railway undertakings and reinforce the provisions on the management of infrastructure managers under the to enhance non-discriminatory access to railway infrastructure. Following the adoption of Parliament's first-reading position on 26 February 2014, interinstitutional negotiations took place during the Luxembourg and Dutch Presidencies of the Council (with a view to reaching an early second reading agreement). Following six trialogues, Parliament's negotiating team reached an agreement with the Council Presidency on 19 April 2016.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the establishment of a single European railway area is important because it promotes international transport, improves competitiveness and infrastructure management and ensures equal access and overcoming conflicts of interest. For these fundamental reasons for the future of rail transport, I voted in favour of the recommendation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the three reports under the railway package and, accordingly, for the amendments demanding their withdrawal, particularly those tabled by the 'ENF' Group, represented by Marie-Christine Arnautu. These reports cover the following points: — the amendment of the directive establishing a single European rail area; — the opening to competition of the market in national passenger transport services; — the repeal of the regulation on common rules for the standardisation of the accounts of railway companies; — the opening of markets national passenger transport. These reports confirm the separation between the operations of manager and operator and extend the application of the competitive principles to services that were previously exempt from them. We oppose this new reform, which is in line with the previous rail packages: their consequences in France have been catastrophic (a 20% drop in freight in five years).

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am worried that opening up the rail market for passenger transport will lead to the failure of “state-owned” carriers in small EU Member States. As we all know, rail transport carries out a social activity, i.e. it benefits the poorer part of our population to move from point A to point B. Unfortunately, the solidarity that the Union proclaims is not in people's income, and thus the railway will lose its social image and/or the state will have to bear the greater difference in the cost of the transport of the socially weak and non-working age.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - This proposal requires the competent authorities to ensure that the specifications of the public service obligations and the relative compensation of the net economic effect of the public service obligations meet the objectives of the public transport policy in a cost-effective manner. In addition, the amount of compensation should ensure the economic viability of the provision of public passenger transport, in accordance with the requirements laid down in the framework of public transport policy over time. This does not allow the Member States to decide on the provision of public goods even on economically disparate terms to their citizens in the context of their social policy.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against the report on the Governance Directive as part of the political pillar of the Fourth Railway Package. A key point is that it would allow EU rail companies to operate across the EU. Plaid Cymru – the Party of Wales believes railways must operate in the public interest and governments must be free to determine their ownership.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The fourth railway package aims to increase the quality and supply of rail services in Europe. According to European legislators, this should make train travel more attractive compared to other modes of transport with greater environmental impact. Based on the access rules, operators will be able to launch new 'commercial' services from December 2020. From 2023, the competent authorities should award public service contracts by means of tenders open to all EU railway undertakings except in specific cases. Public service contracts awarded by direct adjustment before the end of the transitional period may remain in force until December 2033.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This legislative proposal, also known as the 'Governance Directive', is part of the EU's fourth rail package and aims to: (a) opening up the market for national rail passenger services, with the aim of intensifying competitive pressure on markets national rail workers. Rail freight and international passenger transport services have been opened to competition since 2007 and 2010 respectively with the adoption of the previous railway packages. The result is known. The aim is to increase the efficiency of public financing of passenger transport services (tending towards private multinationals). (b) Strengthen the governance of the infrastructure manager with the aim of ensuring equal access to infrastructure. Read: in this way too, to favour the multinationals. The creation of the 'single European rail area' has two components: the internationalisation of the management of the railway operation; and the final axe of what remains of the relationship between operation and infrastructure, opening up new markets but reducing strategic integration. That is: more of the same. Consequences: degradation of services and infrastructure, the deregulation of the working world and, at the same time, the increase in the fortunes of the large European companies that already dominate the railroad in the European context - in the name of competition and transparency! We obviously voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against this proposal as it requires the competent authorities to ensure that the specifications of the public service obligations and the relative compensation of the net economic effect of the public service obligations meet the policy objectives public transport in a cost-effective manner. In addition, the amount of compensation should ensure the economic viability of the provision of public passenger transport, in accordance with the requirements laid down in the framework of public transport policy over time. This does not allow the Member States to decide on the provision of public goods even on economically disparate terms to their citizens in the context of their social policy.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly welcome the establishment of a single European railway area and the opening of the domestic rail passenger market to competition. It is clear that there is still need for a transitional period regarding the compensations paid for level crossing facilities, due to the fact that some Member States still use this Regulation as a basis for level crossing facility compensation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Fourth Rail Package has been negotiating for years, and the European Parliament approved its first reading in February 2014 at the end of the previous parliamentary term. In view of the document adopted by the European Council which was significantly different from the EP opinion, interinstitutional negotiations continued between October 2015 and April 2016 in order to approximate positions. The final agreement with the Council was reached on 19 April 2016 within the framework of the trilogues. The adopted package of proposals is a success for users and railway undertakings and a further step towards the achievement of the Single European Railway Area. For users, the change will be more dynamic and user-friendly in the future, as well as a more qualitative and frequent service. The general objective of the proposals is to open up the market for domestic rail passenger services, improve the quality of services and improve their operational efficiency, which would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail in relation to other modes of transport. The maintenance of the current form of Hungarian State Railways and the acceptance of the current form and operation of the integrated company Győr-Sopron-Ebenfurti Vasút Zrt. has been of paramount importance for Hungary from the outset. We have managed to reach an agreement on these issues that is acceptable to us and thus do not need to start unnecessary, costly and long-term restructuring. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this important proposal on opening up the market for domestic passenger rail services – this proposal has the very important objective of ensuring equal access to infrastructure, which will in turn serve to increase competitiveness and the efficiency of domestic rail services. I welcome the special rules set up to govern the access of high-speed passenger services to the EU rail infrastructure and the objective to developing the market for high-speed passenger services and promoting its competitiveness. I also welcome the strengthening of the role of the European Network of Infrastructure Managers and the including mechanisms to ensure the benchmarking of their performance. Another important aspect of this proposal is a cooperation mechanism for the coordination of international rail services or bi-national infrastructure being set up, as it should make cross-border cooperation and services more efficient and effective. Lastly, I support that the development of common information and through—ticketing systems was put forward as a priority. This is very important in order to facilitate more efficient cross-border passenger transport.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the governments of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders.  It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The fourth rail package we voted on Wednesday 14 December comes in the form of three texts relating to common rules for the standardisation of the accounts of railway undertakings, the opening of the market for national rail passenger services and the establishment of a railway area single European. Although I am in favour of harmonizing railway technical regulations, I am nonetheless opposed to establishing a governance of railway infrastructure which could limit the opening up of the market for national rail services and reinforcing the sustainability of national monopolies. That is why I decided to stand in favour of the two 'technical' texts of this package, but I voted in favour of rejecting the agreement reached on the text on the governance of the single European railway area.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against the compulsory opening-up of railway contracts across Europe to private sector operators, as the new laws do not provide protection for rail workers’ terms and conditions when services are contracted out and also do not ensure good staffing standards on privately-run services. The proposed Directive is a highly ideological and unjustified restriction of the prerogative of Member States to organise and run their railways. In addition, UK trade unions and the ETF have always rejected market opening for so-called commercial rail passenger services, arguing that open access competition invites cherry—picking and jeopardises a good overall network offer of rail passenger services.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text. The establishment of a European railway area is a real opportunity for market development in the passenger transport sector. European manufacturers were eagerly awaiting these texts, which will make it easier for them to sell their equipment in the European Union. Faced with the striking force of our competitors, especially Chinese, European companies now have a clear framework for selling their products in Europe. This agreement will also increase the quality and number of services offered and strengthen governance in infrastructure management.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. — Since 2001, Europe has been moving towards the creation of a single European railway area. In this context, the definition of the procedures for awarding public service contracts in passenger rail transport can have significant consequences for working conditions and social standards in force. However, by making tenders for public service contracts the general rule, with only a few exceptions, this report has as its sole objective competition for competition and not the quality of services. I therefore voted in favour of rejecting the latter because opening up to competition must not be done to the detriment of social rights and public services. Furthermore, I regret that the amendment by the Socialists and Democrats Group, which provided for the compulsory transfer of personnel in the event of a change of operator so that openness to competition does not penalise workers, was rejected by the right.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal of the Commission is amending Directive 2012/34/EU (‘Recast Directive’), which should have been implemented into national systems by June 2015. This proposal was closely linked to the Regulation on the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport (PSO Regulation), addressing the main obstacles to the creation of the Single European Railway Area. I believe this deal shows the fragmentation of the European rail market and only strengthens national monopolies where they exist. Accordingly, the creation of a large European Railway Area open and performance will be postponed indefinitely. Therefore I do not support the proposal.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Fourth Rail Package has been negotiating for years, and the European Parliament approved its first reading in February 2014 at the end of the previous parliamentary term. In view of the document adopted in the European Council, which was significantly different from the EP opinion, interinstitutional negotiations continued between October 2015 and April 2016 with a view to converging positions. The final agreement with the Council was reached on 19 April 2016 within the framework of the trilogues. The package of proposals adopted is a success for users and railway undertakings and is another step towards the Single European Railway Area. For users, the change will be more dynamic and user-friendly in the future, as well as a more qualitative and frequent service. The general objective of the proposals is to open up the market for domestic rail passenger services, improve the quality of services and improve their operational efficiency, which would improve the competitiveness and attractiveness of the rail in relation to other modes of transport. The maintenance of the current form of Hungarian State Railways and the acceptance of the current form and operation of the integrated company Győr-Sopron-Ebenfurti Vasút Zrt. has been of paramount importance for Hungary from the outset. We have managed to reach an agreement on these issues that is acceptable to us and thus do not need to start unnecessary, costly and long-term restructuring. Therefore, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted against this recommendation on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening of the market for domestic rail transport services passengers and the governance of railway infrastructure as competition should be increased, financial transparency and fair financing conditions should be guaranteed. Equal access to the market and the increasing number of operators should eventually generate new business activities and increased traffic. Increased competition and specialisation of market players should have a positive effect on productivity and efficiency, leading to increased investment in rail transport infrastructures.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of amendments by individual groups of Members to the Draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards market opening for domestic passenger rail services; and management of railway infrastructure, as this rejects the position of the Council. The deal reached points to fragmentation of the European rail market and empowers national monopolies. Therefore, I decided to vote to reject the Council's position and follow the ALDE line.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: This report, aimed at opening up national passenger markets, also proposes to increase competition and make the area of access rail equal to any company. These provisions have already proven themselves, resulting in a one-fifth reduction in French rail freight within five years. Finally, combating serious violations of binding collective agreements is not accompanied by effective convictions, as evidenced by the SNCF case. So I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague David Maria Sassoli's report on the single European railway area. The single railway area has been designed with a view to strengthening the safety and reliability of the European rail network. Rail liberalisation is a good thing provided that it aims to improve efficiency and competitiveness without creating free and wild competition. Our positions thus reflect the desire to strike a balance between improving competitiveness, consumer rights and preserving the social rights of staff. I also welcome the provision that opening cannot be made to the detriment of the least profitable lines, since the possibility of limiting access is retained in the event of questioning the economic balance of a public service.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this proposal to amend Directive 2012/34. In addition to the opening up of domestic rail passenger transport markets, stricter separation between infrastructure managers and railway undertakings should also be established in order to avoid conflicts of interest and cross-subsidisation. Equal access to infrastructure is also to be ensured.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I don’t support the opening of a single European railway area, which the European Commission aims to achieve with the Fourth Railway Package. Moreover, the report fails to provide the required level of social protection and the expected quality and performance standards. This is why I voted against this report.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ By establishing a single European railway area, the EU will manage to bring together in a single text the main principles governing railway transport, granting licences to railway undertakings and the levying of charges for the use of infrastructure. This move will raise the level of competition and guarantee financial transparency and fair financing conditions. Equal market access and the increasing number of operators should ultimately generate new business activity and additional traffic. Increasing competition and specialisation of the market players should also have a positive effect on productivity and efficiency and lead to increases in investment into rail transport infrastructure, making the sector more responsive to customers’ needs and allowing rail operators to compete with other modes of transport. Looking from this perspective, I supported the directive.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — I would like to thank Mr Sassoli for his long work on this important dossier, which envisages the creation of a single European rail area. This proposal aims to open up the market for domestic passenger transport services, intensifying competition in rail markets and increasing the quality and quantity of services for the transposing passengers and improving the efficiency of public financing of services. It also wants to optimize infrastructure management by removing conflicts of interest on market access, and to increase coordination between infrastructure managers and rail operators in such a way as to provide a more efficient response to market needs, and to strengthen cooperation between managers. As a result, a market opening will begin which will increase competition, ensure financial transparency and ensure that productivity and efficiency lead to increased investment in rail transpositation infrastructure. Finally, the system looks above all to the needs of customers and skilled workers, and to the achievement of climate change objectives. Always aiming for a more united and competitive European Union, I am voting in favour of the report, which is of strategic importance for this sector and for our citizens.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: The railway sector is a major issue in Europe and more particularly in France, particularly in economic and environmental terms. Thus, I supported this report on the 'Single European Railway Area', which is part of the fourth rail package, because it carries a balanced and responsible vision. Without entering into forced liberalism, this report promotes effective decisions to give new opportunities for carriers. These new measures make it possible to open up the passenger transport market, giving sufficient guarantees so that this does not happen to the detriment of spatial planning. In the end, users will see the supply improve, and regions will have greater freedom of choice in their service providers. It is not time for liberalization that would primarily benefit our international competitors and promote social dumping. With this fourth rail package, we are enabling this sector to gain competitiveness, while respecting social rights.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This text reflects the Commission's old dream: the separation of SNCF with its rail network. In the liberal logic, this separation should make it possible to facilitate the arrival of competitors on national networks. After the catastrophic attempts to establish this separation, States opposed it. From the outset, we saw catastrophic trends developing through this division of tasks: the railway network of France sought to cover its deficit inherited from SNCF without making the necessary investments and maintenance; SNCF thinks private, and favours investments in the most profitable sectors, the high-speed train, at the expense of the public service. This new text will create a real wall of China between the railway network of France and the SNCF: everything will be separated from decision-making to the staff. It is all the sharing of information and knowledge, these synergies that make the richness of the public service that are set aside for the sole benefit of competition. The example of the RER B shows us that it is not another logo that improves service: it is public investment in public infrastructure. That's why I voted against it.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the amendments rejecting the report on the single European railway area. Not only the ENL Group, but three other political groups tabled a rejection amendment. The official goal is to intensify competition to increase the supply and quality of services, make the rail market equal to any company. The report points out that these provisions have enabled rail freight to succeed: in France it is less 20% in five years! The rail package imposed by the EU is catastrophic.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. — This proposal seeks to establish a single European rail area as regards the opening up of the market for national passenger transport services by rail and the governance of railway infrastructures. One cannot doubt the success of the approval of the fourth railway package. Increased competition results in a greater attractiveness of railways over other means of transport. We can also take the opportunity to develop high-speed passenger transport, contributing to the achievement of climate change goals. I vote in favour because it will contribute to greater competitiveness of services, which will greatly benefit passengers, as they will enjoy more services with higher quality.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: in writing. — Innovation of rail transport in the European Union is a very important topic and needs to be approached with caution. IV rail package puts on reform and, in my estimation, this is a huge opportunity for the native railways of the Member States. With the aim of reducing travel costs, ensuring safety or opening new connections, it is also a response to the needs of consumers. The opening of rail transport to other countries could also lead to new railway companies to help Europe in an era of rising unemployment. Introducing open tender rules will give opportunities for any of the carriers to present their offer, which in my assessment is fair competition. The adoption of this package will also help to complete the process of creating a single rail area, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The Commission proposal to amend Directive 2012/34/EU aims primarily to open the domestic market for rail passenger transport services, with the aim of strengthening competitiveness, in order to increase the quantity and improve the quality of passenger services. This proposal goes towards the proposed amendment to Regulation 1370/2007 and aims to increase the effectiveness of public funding in this regard. The second goal is to improve infrastructure management and ensure equal access to all, and this can be achieved through the elimination of conflicts of interest affecting infrastructure manager decisions. Equal market access and an increasing number of entities should ultimately generate new business activity and additional turnover. Increasing competition and specialization of market participants should have a positive effect on productivity and efficiency and lead to increased investment in rail infrastructure. These changes should raise the level of competition, guarantee financial transparency and fair financing conditions, therefore I did not support the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The amended proposal for Directive 2012/34/EU establishing a single European railway area with regard to opening up the market for national rail passenger services and managing railway infrastructure increases competitive pressure on the rail market. At the same time, the position of the infrastructure manager is being strengthened and conditions are created to ensure equal access to railway infrastructure. Increasing transparency, competition together with tendering should strengthen cross-border cooperation and improve the quality of services and the attractiveness of rail passenger transport for residents, which will have positive impacts on quality of life in addition to economic and economic benefits environment, air and climate.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the amendment, which is a joint proposal by the Greens, the EFDD and the GUE, to the recommendation for second reading concerning the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Directive 2012/34/EU on the opening up of the internal rail passenger transport market and rail governance, for the reasons I explained in detail at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/12/2016, and because with this amendment the Parliament rejects the Council's position at first reading.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This text, like the other two reports of the fourth railway package, concerns the market component. Although it has a positive point in proposing not to renew the 'passenger transport licence' to companies convicted of serious breaches of binding collective agreements, which we agree, it contains too many negative points. Indeed, the aim of this text is to open up national passenger transport markets and to intensify competition and defends the idea that these provisions would have enabled rail freight to succeed, even though in the last five years it has fallen by 20%!

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This recommendation promotes the idea of full opening up of the rail market, which underpins increased competition in the EU rail sector. In fact, this proposal does not show any concern about the fulfilment of other objectives, which are essential for possible legislative change. First of all, throughout its text, there are no references to certain important objectives, such as social and territorial cohesion, accessibility, protection of working conditions and workers' rights. I voted in favour of rejecting the Council proposal.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The 4th railway package aims to liberalise the European rail sector. The application of a general procurement obligation is intended to save public money and remove market access barriers for smaller competitors. However, in exceptional cases may not be subject to the general obligation to tender and contracts may be awarded directly. In the future, infrastructure managers must be effectively independent in order to ensure equal access to infrastructure by railway undertakings. Railway undertakings must continue to comply with Union law, national law and collective agreements.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported the amendments to the directive. I hope that this will encourage competition in the rail sector and create a level playing field for all operators to access railway infrastructure.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report dramatically accentuates the logic of European competition for rail transport activities. It establishes the principle of total openness and separation between network management activities and passenger and freight transport activities. This logic has already shown its disastrous consequences for personnel, equipment and service. Moreover, States can limit private sector access to their networks only if their public service contract is “threatened”. No state, therefore, before the private sector has triggered a disaster. And it is up to the European Commission to lay down the rules on this point. I am voting against this total destruction of the French acquis in the field of public rail service.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report is a proposal to repeal the regulation on the standardization of the accounts of railway undertakings. This is the result of the fourth rail package, which is the result of the public rail passenger service. That's why I opposed it.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The market component of the fourth railway package contains three legislative proposals. One is a proposal from the Commission to amend Directive 2012/34/EU. For my part, I have decided to vote in favour of the proposal, as the objectives of the amendments are not only to open up the rail transport market, improve the governance of the infrastructure manager, but also to strengthen competition and financial transparency as well as fair financing conditions. All this will make rail transport more attractive to European citizens, create jobs and boost this sector of activity.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council the adoption of a directive amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening up of the market for domestic rail passenger services and the management of railway infrastructure. The aim of the proposal is to open the market for domestic rail passenger services in order to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets and to increase the volume and quality of passenger transport services and to improve the management of infrastructure managers to ensure equal access to infrastructure. Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014. However, the French Senate, the Lithuanian Parliament, the Luxembourg House of Representatives, the Netherlands Upper House, the Netherlands House of Commons and the Swedish Parliament have submitted reasoned opinions that the draft legislative act is incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. Subsequently, interinstitutional negotiations took place, which resulted in an agreement between the Parliament's negotiating team on 19 April 2016 with the Presidency of the Council. The Council adopted its position at first reading on 17 October 2016 in accordance with the Agreement. In its report, the Committee on Transport and Tourism proposes that Parliament should agree with the Council's position at first reading, thus concluding that the act will be adopted in accordance with the Council's position. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The three reports which constitute the fourth part of the rail package are in line with the desired liberalisation of rail in all its aspects. French freight has already paid the cost of such measures, it is obviously unthinkable to endorse such texts. The EU still refuses to understand that people want efficient and affordable public services and the protection of their jobs. The time of permanent liberalism, which destroys the social fabric for the benefit of some must come to an end. I voted against it.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to open up national passenger transport markets. The aim is to intensify competition to increase the supply and quality of services, to make the rail market equal to any company. The report points out that these provisions have enabled the success of rail freight: in France, it is 20% in 5 years! This “governance” report aims to separate manager and operator activities by eliminating the dual operator-manager caps (which would promote conflicts of interest). The only positive point in this report is that companies already convicted of serious violation (what is the definition of “serious”?) binding collective agreements cannot obtain a licence to carry out passenger rail transport. Note that SNCF has been condemned several times for this reason... I am voting against this report, part of the deadly railway package.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the light of Labour Party policy on public ownership of rail, and the lack of protection in the ‘Political Pillar’ measures for staff when services are contracted-out, I voted against this proposal as it provides for a framework for rights of ‘open access’ to rail lines for commercial train operators, as well as reinforcing a default position of mandatory tendering of passenger service contracts.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this legislative resolution on the opening up of the market for national rail passenger services and the governance of rail infrastructure, which is part of the fourth rail package, which aims to make Europe's rail more competitive and secure. The text approved the Council's position at first reading.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this recommendation regarding the single European railway area.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. In the past two decades, rail transport in Europe has seen a decline in its growth. Apart from the growth of personal car ownership among European citizens and the development of aviation transport, excessive regulation at national level can be highlighted as the main reason for the contraction of this sector. It represents a significant factor that deters the emergence of competition in this industry. This, in turn, has a negative impact on the quality of rail services, which mostly European passengers suffer. Unfortunately, Bulgaria is a telling example of this trend. Against this background, I have given my support to the amendment of Directive 2012/34/EU, which contains measures aimed at ensuring equal access to infrastructure and eliminating conflicts of interest when taking decisions on its use.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted today endorsed this recommendation to adopt the text of the directive on opening up the market for domestic rail transport services, as this represents a step forward for the European market. This directive aims to increase competition in Member States' rail transport markets, which will mean better services and lower prices. Another objective of this directive is to strengthen the governance of infrastructure managers, which will lead to better access to infrastructure for more transport companies and reduce non-competitive arrangements if the infrastructure manager and one of the carriers is in an integrated system.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this report because some points are not clearly defined in the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The aim is to open the market for rail passenger transport services and to promote infrastructure companies. These changes should raise the level of competition and ensure financial transparency and fair financing conditions.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - This legislative proposal, also known as the 'Governance Directive', aims to open up the domestic rail passenger transport market in order to increase competitive pressure on domestic rail markets in order to increase quantity and improve the quality of passenger transport and improve the governance of the infrastructure manager with a view to ensuring equal access to infrastructure. Increased competition should enhance the attractiveness of the railways and make the rail sector more sensitive to customer needs, allowing railway undertakings to compete with other modes of transport. The further development of high-speed passenger transport should also make the railways more competitive by increasing their market share and contributing to the achievement of climate change targets. The increase in railway activity is also expected to increase the demand for skilled workers and operators of railway service facilities, as well as the demand for rolling stock, thus leading to the creation of new jobs in construction railway industry. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. — The Communist Party of Greece voted against the three regulations on the 'Single European Rail Area', passenger rail transport and railway companies' accounts, which constitute the so-called '4th package' for its single rail market' and complete the full privatization of rail transport in the EU and Member States. The delivery of railways, all relevant public infrastructure and networks and transport work to large business groups serves the further profitability of business groups. It brings another serious blow to the working conditions and the labour rights of railway workers. It drastically worsens the quality and safety of rail transport and skyrockets the prices of tickets for the popular family. The interests of the capital are served by the co-ordination SYRIZA-ANEL with the concession to individuals of TRAINOSE, within the framework of its overall anti-grassroots policy, the 3rd and previous memoranda, which it formulates together with the EU and the IMF and with the agreement of the other parties of civil management. In order to make the railways and transport as a whole land, sea and air popular property, at the service of popular needs, the workers' struggle must target the very power of the monopolies, their imperialist union, the EU, for radical changes in the power and the economy.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the revision of the governance directive. After lengthy negotiations, I welcome the fact that the text integrates the position of the Socialists to ensure that private competition does not endanger a public service. Specifically, the text establishes that the regulator may limit the right of access to a private operator if the arrival of that operator jeopardizes the margins of the operator providing a public service. This was fundamental in order to prevent private operators from competing with public service operators on profitable lines that make it possible to finance less lucrative but essential connections for territorial cohesion. Finally, the text does not call into question the integrated company model, which brings together the historical manager and operator in the same group, as in France or Germany.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, as it put in place important safeguards aimed at ensuring the impartiality and independence of the infrastructure manager, by reinforcing the provisions on: double mandates, essential functions, traffic management and maintenance planning, outsourcing and sharing of the functions of the infrastructure manager and financial transparency. Furthermore, special rules governing the access of high-speed passenger services to the Union rail infrastructure have been established, with a view to developing the market for high—speed passenger services and promoting its competitiveness for the benefit of passengers. The market development of common information and through-ticketing systems was put forward as a priority in order to facilitate more efficient multimodal and cross-border passenger transport.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. — The main objectives of this proposal are to improve the quality and efficiency of domestic rail passenger transport services and remove the remaining legal barriers to completing the single European railway area, and to strengthen the management of infrastructure managers with a view to ensuring equal approaches. This will be achieved through the elimination of conflicts of interest affecting infrastructure manager decisions on market access and eliminating possible cross-subsidisation between infrastructure managers and railway carriers, existing in integrated structures. Finally, the proposal is aimed at strengthening coordination between infrastructure managers and rail operators in order to increase cross-border cooperation between infrastructure managers according to market needs. Increased competition should increase rail attractiveness, making the sector more sensitive to customer needs. The growth of rail activity also needs to increase demand for more qualified rail workers and rail service operators, but also demand for fleet, thus creating new jobs in the rail sector. I support the Council's position on this topic and because rail transport is the most environmentally friendly transport and it also safeguards our environment.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — International passenger transport and freight transport markets where open market access has already been reached provide a good example to the rail market as a roadmap towards further development and growth of market share. An open market for domestic rail transport will guarantee competitive competition and thus improved quality for passengers in Europe. It is primarily necessary to eliminate conflicts of interest and the possibility of unfair subsidisation — the decisions of the infrastructure manager must be transparent and impartial. That is why it decided to introduce safeguards that will ensure the independence of the infrastructure manager. I also call on Member States to establish national frameworks for assessing conflicts of interest where regulatory authorities would take into account all personal financial and professional interests which have the potential to unduly influence the decisions of administrators. New business activities and increased traffic which brings equal market access to an increased number of operators will drive productivity and efficiency growth and lead to increased employment and investment in rail transport infrastructure. Through bidding, the sector will develop a better approach to identifying customer needs and the attractiveness of railways will certainly increase. The development of information systems and systems for issuing single maps should be among the priorities in this sector. Finally, I would like to remind you that increasing the market share of this sector will also contribute to achieving climate change targets.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) This legislative proposal, also known as the 'Governance Directive', is part of the EU's fourth rail package and aims to: a) Opening up the market for national rail passenger services, with the aim of intensifying competitive pressure on markets national rail workers. Rail freight and international passenger transport services have been opened to competition since 2007 and 2010 respectively with the adoption of the previous railway packages. The result is known. The aim is to increase the efficiency of public financing of passenger transport services (tending towards private multinationals). (b) Strengthen the governance of the infrastructure manager with the aim of ensuring equal access to infrastructure. Read: in this way too, to favour the multinationals. The creation of the 'single European rail area' has two components: the internationalisation of the management of the railway operation; and the final axe of what remains of the relationship between operation and infrastructure, opening up new markets but reducing strategic integration. That is: more of the same. Consequences: degradation of services and infrastructure, the deregulation of the working world and, at the same time, the increase in the fortunes of the large European companies that already dominate the railroad in the European context - in the name of competition and transparency! We obviously voted against it.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — As regards the management directive, I am pleased by the lack of rules requiring radical, costly and time-consuming structural changes to the railway market in Poland, requiring a full chapter between the infrastructure manager and the undertakings railway and between the manager and maintenance companies, by favourable formulation of the definition of 'vertically integrated undertaking', excluding regional networks with a track gauge different from the dominant network of Member States in the EU (PKP LHS case) from the scope of application directive, that is, by the obligation to resolve infrastructure from the operation of rail services. I hereby supported the compromise worked out.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the amendment of the directive establishing a single European railway area. It is essential to open the passenger transport market in order to promote the growth of rail activity and create new jobs, while providing sufficient guarantees to ensure that such openness does not take place at the expense of quality of services and spatial planning.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the governments of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders.  It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the revision of the governance directive. After lengthy negotiations, I welcome the fact that the text integrates the position of the Socialists to ensure that private competition does not endanger a public service. Specifically, the text establishes that the regulator may limit the right of access to a private operator if the arrival of that operator jeopardizes the margins of the operator providing a public service. This was fundamental in order to prevent private operators from competing with public service operators on profitable lines that make it possible to finance less lucrative but essential connections for territorial cohesion. Finally, the text does not call into question the integrated company model, which brings together the historical manager and operator in the same group, as in France or Germany.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Creating a Single Railway Area is an important challenge for the EU. I am glad that we have come closer to this goal with today's vote. At the same time, it is important that some excess and unnecessary provisions on extremely high support for very fast lines have been removed from the resolution adopted. Instead of extremely fast and extremely expensive lines, we should focus on the development of sufficiently fast, high-quality, environmentally friendly and comfortable transport in all European countries, with due attention being paid to the new Member States.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
