text: in writing. - This is the third of three legislative proposals relating to the fourth railway package and concerns, in particular, the amendment of Directive 2012/34/EU, also known as the 'Governance Directive', on the opening of the national market for rail passenger services and governance of the railway infrastructure. The aim of this amendment is primarily the willingness to foster competition in national railway markets and strengthen governance of infrastructure managers. With these amendments, not only will there be gains in increasing competition, but it will also be possible to ensure greater financial transparency and better and fairer business financing conditions. After several trialogues and various interinstitutional contacts it was possible to reach a balanced agreement, largely because of the role of the European Parliament, which has proved essential, and for that reason I voted for this report in favour.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive amending Directive 2012/34/EU on the creation of a single European railway area. The main objective is to open up the inland rail market to other passenger services and to improve the quality of passenger services by providing more services.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. — The compromise text negotiated between the European Parliament and the Council of the Political Pillar of the so-called 4th Railway Package is a compromise on a very sensitive subject. Over the past years, we have heard arguments for and against further opening up markets many times. Proponents of liberalisation speak of a push for greater efficiency in a competitive environment, its opponents argue examples where liberalisation has not ensured in the long run or better; and safer services to passengers, nor more dignified conditions of employees. Rather the opposite. The rules for opening markets must therefore be clear even with regard to quality standards and social standards of employees. Cheaper isn't necessarily better, and if opening up markets were to mean precarization and worsening employee conditions, it would be a lose-lose for the entire rail sector.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - As with the van de Camp report, I supported the withdrawal of the text. In this case, regulations and control mechanisms are created to facilitate the liberalisation and privatisation of the railway sector, thus entailing higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of conditions labor, with the recurring intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will be distributed the cake.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ The overall objective of the fourth rail package is to improve the efficiency and quality of rail services by removing any legal, institutional and technical obstacles and promoting the competitiveness of the sector, in order to further develop the single European rail area. This new proposal includes a series of measures aimed at both making Europe's railways more attractive, innovative and competitive and to ensure greater transparency and fair financial conditions. I hope that the new rules will also help make the rail sector more attentive to customer needs and create new jobs through increased demand for skilled workers . I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted to reject the proposals at second reading on the Fourth Railway Package because this would inevitably lead to the UK Government and the governments of Member States having their hands tied with regards to the awarding of competitive tenders.  It is not for the EU to determine what may be constituted as competitive in a Member State without fully understanding the economic climate of that Member State and what implications any restriction or forced competitive process may have.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against the compulsory opening-up of railway contracts across Europe to private sector operators, as the new laws do not provide protection for rail workers’ terms and conditions when services are contracted out and also do not ensure good staffing standards on privately-run services. The proposed Directive is a highly-ideological and unjustified restriction of the prerogative of Member States to organise and run their railways. In addition, UK trade unions and the ETF have always rejected market opening for so-called commercial rail passenger services, arguing that open access competition invites cherry picking and jeopardises a good overall network offer of rail passenger services.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. — I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not actually reflect the actual the quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the representative activity.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that an agreement has been reached with the Council and, at second reading, we have approved the introduction of the fourth railway package in Parliament. Thanks to this legislative package, we are creating the conditions for the creation of a single European rail market. People travelling by trains will have greater choices in choosing national or international rail links. At the same time, we are giving an incentive to the entire rail sector, which should see job opportunities grow. In particular, the so-called Governance Directive establishing a Single European Railway Area aims to intensify competitive pressure on national transport markets and ensure equal access to infrastructure. In particular, the function of the infrastructure manager will be strengthened by requiring Member States to eliminate any possible conflict of interest, as well as cross-granting of subsidies by infrastructure managers and railway undertakings. The changes I have supported increase the level of competition and should guarantee financial transparency and fair financing conditions. In this way, a level playing field should be created on the rail market, which should increase the total number of operators. In particular, with these measures, we want to improve the capacity of the rail sector to respond to customers' needs. I believe that, in the end, train passengers will, in particular, feel the improvement of rail services and travel across Europe will become easier.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — By my vote, I supported the so-called Fourth Rail Package, which will, among other things, open up the markets of national passenger rail transport in the Member States. I see the opening of the rail market to competition as the right step to increase the quality of services provided to consumers, reduce the prices of rail services and improve efficiency public financing of this sector. Legislation brings also a very necessary separation of railway infrastructure managers from railway carriers, which occurred in the Czech Republic a few years ago. I also positively oppose provisions to ensure an adequate level of protection for employees in the sector, but which do not go beyond the edge of artificiality. On the contrary, I am looking at authorising the existence of existing holdings between rail carriers and infrastructure managers. Although the infrastructure manager must proceed independently when concluding contracts on the basis of a tender process, it will be difficult to avoid conflicts of interest or information advantage of entities that would form a holding with the infrastructure manager. Behind permitting the existence of railway holdings, I see the risk that there will be a denial of the idea of opening rail markets to free competition.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The so-called Management Directive aimed at opening up the internal passenger services market to increase competitive pressure on internal rail services markets with a view to increasing the volume and improving the quality of passenger services, and improving the quality of passenger services, management carried out by the infrastructure manager in order to ensure equal access to infrastructure. I am sorry of the view that the directive includes too many flaws to support it myself. A European Network of Infrastructure Managers is hereby established with a view to exchanging best practices, controlling implementation and tackling cross-border bottlenecks. Unfortunately, this is all that is left of our proposal to establish a European regulatory body that would have the power to address cross-border issues and issues that are not few. The Directive also provides for the development of common information and ticketing systems in order to enable more efficient multimodal and cross-border passenger transport, with the Commission to monitor developments and prepare a report for Parliament and the Council by 2022 and to it, where appropriate attach legislative proposals, for which no deadline is foreseen. In its first reading, the European Parliament called for such a system to be put in place by 2019, which would apply to all public rail passengers, unfortunately this is not taken into account here. There are so many shortcomings.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Rail transport is the most ecological and efficient form of transport of passengers and goods over long distances on land. We want to link existing systems in individual countries of the European Union to remove existing technical and legislative barriers and increase competition.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The aim of this Report is to establish a single European railway area to open up the domestic rail passenger transport market in order to increase competitive pressure, increase the scope and improve the quality of passenger transport services. These changes should increase competition, ensure financial transparency and fair financing conditions. Increasing competition and specialisation of market actors should also positively affect productivity and efficiency and lead to increased investment in rail transport infrastructure. Member States should establish a national framework for assessing conflicts of interest and regulatory authorities should take into account any personal financial, economic or professional interests which may have an unreasonable impact on impartiality. The Council's position at first reading is consistent with the agreement reached at interinstitutional negotiations. I accept and vote for the legal act to enter into force as coordination between infrastructure managers and railway operators should be strengthened to better meet market needs and improve cross-border cooperation among infrastructure managers.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a second reading recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Directive concerning the opening of the internal passenger services market and the management of railway infrastructure. I welcome the achievement of the European Parliament, which has achieved, in interinstitutional negotiations, inter alia, that safeguards have been put in place to ensure the impartiality and independence of infrastructure managers, while at the same time that Member States should establish a national framework for assessment of conflicts of interest.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the proposal for the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening of the market for national passenger transport services by rail and management and management of railway infrastructure. This proposal should open up the national market for rail services to international competition. Czech companies will be able to break into foreign markets with their services. This proposal also deals with the institutional separation of railway infrastructure management from the operation of transport services. The European Parliament places great emphasis on ensuring that, in the case of a 'holding' model, accounting and technical separation of infrastructure income and transport, ensuring fair competitive conditions.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - This proposal requires the competent authorities to ensure that the specifications of the public service obligations and the relative compensation of the net economic effect of the public service obligations meet the objectives of the public transport policy in a cost-effective manner. In addition, the amount of compensation should ensure the economic viability of the provision of public passenger transport, in accordance with the requirements laid down in the framework of public transport policy over time. This does not allow the Member States to decide on the provision of public goods even on economically disparate terms to their citizens in the context of their social policy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of its second-reading recommendation on the market pillar of the fourth railway package on its governance directive. The main objective of the legislative proposal is to increase the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets by opening up the market for domestic rail passenger services and to improve the quantity and quality of passenger transport services. Rail freight and international passenger transport services were opened to competition in 2007 and 2010, in order to increase the efficiency of public financing of passenger transport services. In addition, it was intended to strengthen the management of infrastructure managers by ensuring equal access to infrastructure. The current proposal aims to strengthen coordination between infrastructure managers and railway undertakings and to consolidate cross-border cooperation between infrastructure managers. The changes increase competition, ensure financial transparency and fair financing conditions. Increased competition is expected to increase rail attractiveness, which will respond more to consumers' needs and will also increase the need for skilled railway workers and service operators.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - The establishment of the single European railway area involves opening up the market for domestic passenger rail services and the governance of railway infrastructure, which contributes to increasing competitiveness, transparency (financial), competition, quality and efficiency of financing public rail services for passengers, of course, for the benefit of travelers. As a result of increased competition, the attractiveness of the railway sector should generate an increase in investment in this sector, including in the human resource, as well as in the diversification and quality of rail services for passengers, and the management of railway infrastructure and railway services by legally different entities, functionally and decision-making should at least ensure equal access to infrastructure, consistency in the management of the functions of infrastructure managers and coordination between infrastructure managers and railway operators, which is quite difficult to achieve. The governance of railway undertakings involves not only ensuring social standards and improving the quality of railway services, but, above all, taking social responsibility towards all those concerned. In this context, it is clear that the completion of the opening of the Union rail market does not transform rail transport into a credible and viable alternative, in terms of quality and price, to other modes of transport.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The overall aim of the directive is to build a railway single market area which would translate into more opportunities for passengers as well as an increase in the use of this transport mode in relations to others. To this end, the EP was instrumental in ensuring the impartiality and independence of the infrastructure managers. Safeguards have been put in place to ensure the impartiality and independence of the infrastructure manager, and Member States should put in place a national framework for the assessment of conflicts of interest.  The powers of the regulatory bodies were reinforced and a cooperation mechanism was established as regards the coordination of the decisions of two or more regulatory bodies concerning international rail services or bi-national infrastructure.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for rejection as I can’t support the agreement reached between the three institutions. The initial proposal aimed at addressing the obstacles to the creation of the Single European Railway Area, namely the closure of the national markets for domestic transport and the governance of the infrastructure manager. I am in favour of a broad opening of the market for passenger transport with certain limits to guarantee the economic equilibrium. In the same spirit, I support a full unbundling of the infrastructure manager and the railway undertaking as I consider that only such a separation can guarantee an equal access to the infrastructure, which is a basic requirement for fair competition.  Unfortunately, I consider that the provisions as such won’t be enough to ensure a minimum separation between the infrastructure manager and the railway undertaking and I therefore do not wish to support the text.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Railway infrastructure is the carrier of our transport system. The harmonisation of national laws, regulations and administrative rules have become increasingly important. Every legislative measure that aims at greater integration of the European rail system is, in my opinion, an advantage for our production system and our citizens. The package in question involves liberalising many train services, both long-distance and high-speed, also tackling social issues with the certification of cabin crew and compliance with the requirements on honourability for the maintenance of the railway licence.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the report on a single European rail transport area. This amendment to the directive is a proposal for six legislative acts which should revitalize the rail sector and provide better services. Following the changes, passengers will also have a greater choice of service providers in passenger transport. Improving service efficiency is a fair attempt to implement the changes proposed in the directive. This will ensure an increase in the competitiveness of EU rail transport and will support innovative solutions that will bring more benefits to the citizens of the Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - I supported this proposal, which goes towards revitalising the rail sector and providing better quality of services and greater choice for passengers. I believe that the targets set in the fourth rail package are truly universally acceptable - increasing the quality and efficiency of rail services through the removal of legal, institutional and technical barriers. Railways really need to keep pace with the times, and become more competitive to other transport sectors. The instruments to achieve this are also for all praise - financial transparency, avoidance of conflicts of interest, open access to high-speed rail, objectivity and impartiality of infrastructure management, etc.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - Draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening of the internal passenger services market and the management of railway infrastructure supported. The Commission's proposal aims to open the internal passenger services market to increase competitive pressure on internal rail services markets in order to increase volume and improve the quality of passenger services and improve the management carried out by the operator infrastructure in order to ensure equal access to infrastructure. The desire is to make rail passenger transport more attractive. Better rail activity increased demand for skilled rail workers and rail service facility operators and demand for rolling stock, thus creating new jobs in the rail manufacturing industry.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on Governance and will abstain on the Public service obligation report. The reason for this is that there is no real improvement of the situation compared to the Recast of the 1st railway package. The European regulator is still not existence, the regulatory barriers to market access will remain present. There is no real opening of the market and tender will remain a fiction because Member States can appeal to the ‘economic equilibrium’ argument and many exceptions exist to tender and real opening of the market.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: The purpose of this report is to increase competition to increase the supply and quality of services, to make the rail market equal to any company. The report points out that these provisions have enabled the success of rail freight: in France it is 20% in 5 years! Another objective is obviously the fight against global warming... This governance component of the rail package aims to separate the operations of manager and operator by eliminating the dual operator-manager caps (which would promote conflicts of interest). The only positive point in this report is that companies already convicted of serious violations of binding collective agreements cannot obtain a licence to carry out passenger rail transport. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The fourth rail package presented by the European Commission has a number of irregularities. The project introduces unnecessary bureaucracy and decision-making chaos. Importantly, it does not contain detailed records that could cause a reduction in the entrepreneurship of railway companies, which is why I voted against the project.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — One of the aims of the proposal is to open the market for domestic rail passenger services with a view to increasing the competitive pressure on domestic rail markets and increasing the volume and quality of passenger transport services. Rail freight and international passenger transport services were opened to competition in 2007 and 2010 by adopting previous railway legislative packages. The proposal should be interpreted in conjunction with the proposed amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1370/2007 and, in this context, aims to increase the efficiency of public financing for passenger transport services. I followed S&D's position by Voksom.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We have tabled a rejection amendment and a number of content amendments against this amendment to the Directive which aims to make it mandatory to open passenger rail services to private operators, by means of a system in which any operator can provide rail services by renting tracks in a certain section and schedule. This reform combined with the amendment of the Public Service Regulation voted just before, is a lack of purpose both in terms of the coherence of the rail network as a whole (universal accessibility, promotion of social and territorial cohesion, etc.) and in terms of safety coordination and control. We are already aware of the consequences where this liberalisation has been implemented (UK, for example) and have been disastrous in terms of worsening the frequency and quality of service, rising prices and serious security failures. We will continue to oppose this market model and defend a public railway at the service of the needs of citizens in each territory. That is why I voted in favour of the proposal to reject the report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against the single European railway area proposal because the door is left open to ruthless competition between the cheapest providers, with little regard for quality of service. An opportunity to level the playing field between different modes of transport has been missed. While Member States can introduce tolls on their roads if they see fit, Member States are obliged to charge a fee for every kilometre on every track they use.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Specific rules have been created governing the access of high-speed passenger services to the Union's rail infrastructure in order to develop the high-speed passenger transport market and promote its competitiveness, which is beneficial to passengers.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: in writing. — A major step is planned to open up the domestic rail passenger market by 2020, which will facilitate the provision of rail services in all Member States of the European Union (EU). Since 2005, the price increase for rail services has reached almost 50%, which is extremely high. The new rail rules will help EU Member States open up their rail transport markets and make them competitive, so all of us will benefit as travel by train becomes cheaper and more attractive. Railway plays a historically important role in Latvia. Its history is inextricably linked with the history of our country — the locomotive whistle, opening the first track, gave a signal to Latvia's progress towards rapid economic and industrial growth, accessibility of education and wider travel opportunities. Therefore, in support of the resolution on the creation of the European Area Railway, I consider the further development and integration of our railway infrastructure with other EU countries as a priority. Because we are currently quite limited in planning further journeys across Europe by rail. I believe that the new rules will lead to greater investment in the rail sector and improve the quality of service. Trains are an environmentally friendly mode of transport and will help reduce emissions across Europe by increasing the use of rail transport.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Directive constitutes another step in the opening of internal passenger transport services in order to increase quantity and improve their quality and efficiency. It addresses the governance of railway infrastructure management with the aim of ensuring equal access to the undertakings concerned, allowing the possibility of both separate and holding structures, and including reversibility of the chosen model. In this way, it regulates possible conflicts of interest that may arise before those who have to make management decisions and seeks to eliminate any possibility of cross-subsidy, strengthening the transparency of financial flows. It also introduces provisions on cross-border coordination of infrastructure management, emphasizing the role of regulators, who become guarantors of the application of rules on conflicts of interest and financial transparency. Finally, it includes information points and transport tickets that seek to mark the way to a multimodal passenger transport system. I therefore considered it appropriate to vote in favour of the text.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - As with the van de Camp report, I supported the withdrawal of the text. In this case, regulations and control mechanisms are created to facilitate the liberalisation and privatisation of the railway sector, thus entailing higher prices, lower safety, lack of planning, reduction of the weight of conventional train (especially in less populated regions) and precariousness of conditions labor, with the recurring intervention of public authorities to rescue the private companies that will be distributed the cake.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the amendment of Directive 2012/34/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 November 2012 establishing a single European railway area. The proposal conflicts with Labour Party policy to bring rail franchises into public ownership ‘as they expire’ and key demands to protect employment rights and social dialogue have not survived in the final versions of the text. In addition, it is not clear how this measure is compatible with Article 106(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which provides that the application of competition rules should not obstruct the performance of the tasks entrusted to them.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted for better governance of the infrastructure manager to ensure equal access to the infrastructure.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This is about the deepening of the ongoing liberalisation process in the rail sector. In fact this process has nothing to do with the market. It is rather a process of monopolistic concentration, an attack on national sovereignty, of degradation of public service and intensification of the operation of railway workers. It is scandalous that we should now call for greater centralisation and coordination of the system after completely or partially destroying the public rail system. It is a scandal that calls on the State to invest in infrastructure or guarantee systems that fuel private profit by socializing costs. Such social safeguards may serve to facilitate the collaboration of Social-Democracy in this process, but in practice they are of no use, as has been shown in other sectors.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The 4th railway package aims to liberalise the European rail sector. The application of a general procurement obligation is intended to save public money and remove market access barriers for smaller competitors. However, in exceptional cases may not be subject to the general obligation to tender and contracts may be awarded directly. In the future, infrastructure managers must be effectively independent in order to ensure equal access to infrastructure by railway undertakings. Railway undertakings must continue to comply with Union law, national law and collective agreements.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European railways are in need of urgent modernisation and more competition in order for them to become a genuine alternative to road transport. While the technical aspects of the railway reform were already voted on a few months ago, today the European Parliament voted on three reports addressing the political aspects. After three years of difficult negotiations between Parliament and the Member States, Socialists and Democrats, including Labour MEPs, decided to reject the compromise reached with the Council on one of the reports, on the opening of the market for domestic passenger transport services. During the negotiations, the Council completely dismissed the demand by the European Parliament to ensure the mandatory transfer of staff in cases of change of provider in the public sector. Labour MEPs back railway modernisation, but not at the expense of workers.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The rail package and the first debate on the Energy Union will directly affect the functioning of the railways and energy in Europe. The new rules, which are expected to come into force in 2020, will allow rail companies to bid for public passenger transport contracts across the EU. Although the possibility of direct award of such contracts will remain, the contracts will have to contain quality requirements such as the accuracy and number of connections, the quality of wagons and the number of persons transported. In addition, any transport company will have the right to offer commercial passenger services in any Member State. States will be able to limit this right for some lines, but only after an objective economic analysis has been carried out. The rail package is expected to deliver better services to passengers across the EU, while lower ticket prices. That is why I supported the report.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support, in my voice, this liberalisation rail package. I believe its adoption will enable better entry of competition into the pan-European market and improve the quality of services on the railways. For Czech companies, this will mean the possibility of penetrating foreign railways, but also introducing uniform and transparent rules. From the perspective of passengers, due to the increased competitive environment, services should be made cheaper and improved. At the same time, I am confident that the package will help improve the working conditions of railway employees and, as a matter of fact, increase their salaries.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading prepared by David Maria Sassle. I believe these recommendations create a pragmatic pillar for the rail package. After several years of discussions, it was rightly accepted that, in addition to common EU regulations, the specifics of individual countries must be taken into account. For Poland, this means, for example, agreeing to develop regional enterprises that deal with local traffic within individual provinces. It's very important for many passengers who, using local connections, get to work every day, schools or doctors. However, the consequence of this mindset should also be an increase in EU funding for local traffic development. EU investment, mainly in high-speed rail, will not solve other socially important needs. It's local, daily connections that are most relevant to many people.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the recommendation for the adoption of a directive amending the directive establishing a single European railway area. This amendment to the Directive concerns, in particular, the opening up of the market for national rail passenger services and the management of railway infrastructure. The proposal falls within the Commission's Fourth Railway Package, which aims to improve the quality of service and more opportunities for passengers, by removing legal, institutional and technical barriers. In particular, I have decided to support this proposal because a change in legislation in practice will bring benefits to passengers. In fact, within the single European railway area, they will have a wider choice of services, better services, but also more favourable prices. And these are all objectives that I hope will be considered useful and welcome by the citizens of the European Union.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I consider a positive increase in competition by opening the domestic rail market for passenger transport. Increasing competition as an end effect on domestic markets should have an increase in the quality of service, increase financial transparency, which is in the interest and for the benefit of all users of this form of transport. It would also lead to market specialization of providers of these services, a positive impact on efficiency and productivity, and greater investment in rail transport infrastructure. I support this report and the suggestion that it is necessary to establish at national level a framework for assessing conflicts of interest and regulatory bodies that would eliminate any potential impartiality threats and development of information and ticketing systems in order to make this form of transport as effective as possible.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/34/EU as regards the opening of the internal passenger services market and rail management Infrastructure. The proposed measures of the amended Directive 2012/34/EU will increase competition and ensure financial transparency and fair financing conditions. Increased competition and specialisation of market participants is also expected to have a positive impact on productivity and efficiency and lead to more investment in rail infrastructure.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this regulation because ports are effectively the routes of entry and transit of 96 percent of all goods in the European Union and it was really urgent that they should be regulated by standards that guarantee efficiency and transparency. They are also the workplace of nearly 500 000 people, numbers that could grow if there were more investment and more competitiveness. Maritime transport is already an alternative to road transport, but thanks to these rules it will be an area to be increased through investment also by private individuals. Maritime transport is absolutely central: putting ports at the centre of European policies means giving an opportunity for growth also and above all to the island regions, that of maritime transport live. Making ports more competitive means lowering the price of many goods. Port policies are decisively involved in achieving these territorial cohesion objectives, which in many regions of Europe are still far from achieving.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Madam President, I support the effective and fair application of European laws in terms of competition and increased transparency in financial relations between Member States, ports and port operators. The procedure for choosing port service providers must be open to all stakeholders and the content and outcome of these procedures must be made public — thus transparency and fairness in public procurement. Likewise, port service charges and port infrastructure charges shall be proportionate to the economic value of the services provided and not disproportionate and not discriminatory. And lastly, let us not forget that the big problem in many of the ports of the European Union is trafficking: drug trafficking, human trafficking and other forms of trafficking. This must be the number one priority, if we are talking about transport and access to port services.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, transparency in the management of services and application of funds in our European ports is a priority, which I am pleased to say is at the forefront of our agenda. Indeed the enhancement of existing procedures and regulations marks an essential step towards the development of more efficient competition rules within and between our Member States. The knock-on effects of the recommendations contained within this report would also prove central to marked improvements in the labour conditions within our ports. Also, of course, as we move to implementing COP 21 commitments, the maritime sector is going to play a huge role in that regard, and already there are moves afoot to make it more efficient from an energy point of view and, as the previous speaker mentioned, taking transport off the roads. In my constituency we have a great port, the finest port in the Shannon estuary, one of the deepest and most naturally deep ports in Europe, and it has huge potential but it needs to get on the corridor so that it can be beneficial for the region and for Europe.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, the United Kingdom did not request this inappropriate and unacceptable intrusion into the running of their ports, and I accordingly voted against the directive. After all, the UK is a maritime nation with a huge number of successful, efficient and effectively-run ports. It did not need another EU directive bringing about legislation, which will highlight why sovereign control of a major infrastructure project should stay with that government and that country and not be ceded to the European Union. There are over 500 companies in the United Kingdom – and indeed many of them are in the south—east region which I represent – which employ people in the port services. This legislation would do nothing to improve their lives and it would do nothing to improve the running of those ports. In fact, it would be very detrimental. When an EU decision actually hampers rather than enhances, the people who voted to leave the European Union feel vindicated. I do wish the European Union would take that on board because you complain all the time about driving people away from the European Union concept and yet legislation like this achieves precisely that aim.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The following report is concerned with establishing a common regulation, at Community level, with regard to port services. The most important points and which I agree mainly are the introduction of rules for the training of staff and concerning social rights and the exclusion of children, on which the application of charges bureaucratic and administrative could have very negative consequences. I also feel that it is essential to show transparently how public funds and state aid are used. That is why I have decided to vote for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Despite the Commission's intention to use this legislative initiative to liberalise and privatize the European port sector, the negotiations between Parliament and the Member States have enabled the text to become, on the contrary, a mechanism for preserving working conditions in the sector and strengthening its rights to collective bargaining or in the event of transfer of the operator service. However, some of its provisions could be used to fragment the public management of the port system by accounting separately those segments that could be open to private competition. Considering the text as a whole, I chose to abstain.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on access to the market for port services and the financial transparency of ports. This draft resolution aims to help ensure that the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) is more efficient, interconnected and more coherent, thus creating a system to improve the efficiency of all ports and to facilitate the adaptation of ports to transport and logistics changes in requirements. The main tasks of the project include the renewal of port services and activities and the creation of conditions that would encourage investment in ports. The aim is also to eliminate the conditions of weak competition and potential market abuse, thereby increasing the efficiency of the services provided by ports. This project is also in line with other important areas of EU policy, such as the White Paper on Transport, the Connecting Europe Facility and the Blue Strip initiative. It will apply to all seaports referred to in the TEN-T Guidelines and will help to remove the additional administrative burden faced by already well-functioning ports, while helping other ports cope with their structural challenges.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports because it refers to the need for the management entity's autonomy the port in order to act in accordance with its economic strategy, while respecting certain basic principles.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The social provisions governing the working arrangements in ports have been largely omitted from the regulation proposed by the Commission. Theoretical precautions have been added to combat precarious employment and improve training and safety at work. Compliance with national social standards has also been added, as well as the obligation of States to safeguard the rights of employees in the event of a transfer of enterprises. In principle, if the changes resulting from the first visit to the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the trilogue are positive (fewer activities concerned and less regulation in the activities concerned), this is still insufficient for FN-RBM MEPs to vote favourably, since once again the States are forced to do more liberalization. This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much broader liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, certainly not to port and maritime workers, and European employees and consumers as a whole. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because I do not believe the EU should have any say on how UK ports are operated. Many of the ports located in the UK are privately owned and operated and this differs greatly to most ports within the EU. Further ‘one size fits all’ legislation will have a damaging effect in the UK.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it is important to make TEN-T more efficient and interconnected. This requires creating a framework to improve port performance in order to attract investment and combat low competitive pressure as well as the risks of market abuse in the sector. For this purpose, provisions should be laid down in the areas of concession contracts or State aid.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the market for port services and financial transparency in ports. I support Parliament's proposal to introduce a transparent pricing system and to oblige ports to declare the funds they receive from the State in their financial statements. These rules target more than 300 EU ports, which employ almost half a million employees. They aim to encourage more efficient operation of ports in the hope that this will attract more investment. In turn, maritime transport is to become a competitive and sustainable alternative to overcrowded road transport.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. — As a matter of principle, if the amendments resulting from the first visit to the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the trialogue are positive, that is still insufficient and I voted against it, since once again the States would be forced to liberalise further. This proposal for a regulation would most likely only be the first step towards a much broader liberalisation which would benefit only multinationals, certainly not to port and maritime workers, and European employees and consumers as a whole.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on port services began with a liberalising proposal by the European Commission with which we are deeply against. However, during the negotiations, the proposal was reversed, the liberalization clauses were omitted and the rights of dockworkers were protected. This is a satisfactory result that we usually do not see in the reforms of European transport legislation. However, I have decided to abstain, because the final wording calls for the promotion of decentralized port management while, in an eminently maritime country such as ours, centralized management of the port network is one of the key elements of the system. Although in no case does this decentralisation take place compulsory, we wanted to be consistent with our position to defend the ability of each Member State to choose its own public management model, in accordance with its trajectory and its specificities.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Fleckenstein, for his work on this report, in which he is tabling a few amendments concerning port autonomy. I do not agree with the agreement reached on this point, but, in line with the rest of the text, I finally voted in favour of the agreement with the Council and, therefore, the report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the Commission's proposal which falsely claims to improve the competitiveness of the TEN-T EU ports compared to non-EU seaports, and fair competition between TEN-T ports. The whole is insufficient because States will still be forced to further liberalize. The European Union's policies on infrastructure are going back in the air of the times. In the United States, Donald Trump seems to want to pursue an ambitious policy for these strategic elements. Liberalization benefits only transnational corporations, not States and peoples.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this measure which provides for the liberalisation of sectors typical of port operations, according to principles similar to those contained in the Services Directive, the famous Bolkestein, which so much damage caused to our local bathing operators. I say no to measures taken down from above, such as this regulation, on the head of whole professional categories that would find themselves with their work at risk. I will always stand by our local operators, against to defend our territories against the advance of multinational corporations. For these reasons I did not support the text with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: I have voted yes. I have done so because the now adopted rules strike down the right of port workers to better training and better security, as well as their rights in transferring companies. Ports shall be able to limit the number of service providers in order to safeguard safety and environmental sustainability. Cargo handling and passenger services are also part of the new financial transparency rules. The organisation of the port services themselves remains the responsibility of the Member States. I would like to emphasise that I always opposed the policies of privatisation and market liberalisation of ports which the Commission had previously tried to implement, but stopped by the trade union movement and the majority of the European Parliament. It is important to stick to the principle position.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreement reached with the Council at first reading substantially changes the initial proposal submitted by the Commission, by ensuring that ports can limit the number of operators on a multitude of criteria (for public service obligations, safety or environmental matters, etc.). The agreement also requires greater transparency of financial flows between public authorities and ports in order to detect situations of unfair competition between ports and covert State aid. In addition, the text has been substantially improved with measures such as the exclusion from the Regulation of categories such as piloting, provisions relating to social dialogue and the strengthening of the obligations of subrogation of staff in the event of a change of port operator, while recognizing the possibility of fixing fees for the use of the port infrastructure by law, as is the case in Spain. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on access to the market for port services and the financial transparency of ports. The Commission's proposal aims to help ensure that the TEN-T network is more efficient, interconnected and more coherent by creating a system that improves the efficiency of all ports and makes it easier for ports to adapt to changes in transport and logistics requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include the renewal of port services and activities and the establishment of conditions which would encourage investment in ports. This Regulation aims at eliminating the conditions of weak competition and potential market abuse, thereby increasing the efficiency of the port services provided. Freight handling and passenger handling services have been excluded from Chapter II due to market access because they are often provided through concession contracts and are therefore covered by the Directive on the award of concession contracts. This Regulation should therefore apply in conjunction with Directive 2014/23/EU on the award of concession contracts. A clear framework for State aid rules is an important criterion for fair competition between ports on a level playing field. This regulation will apply to all seaports referred to in the TEN-T Guidelines and, according to the Commission, will help to remove the additional administrative burden faced by already well-functioning ports while at the same time helping other ports cope with their structural challenges.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: in writing. — If I cannot oppose the financial transparency of the ports, on the other hand, the introduction of competition within ports, even if it has been mitigated during its passage to the Committee on Transport and Tourism, will lead to a multiplication of private actors, which will undoubtedly be done to the detriment of employees and to the benefit of multinational companies, which I denounce. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This file deals with a regulation to establish an updated framework for the operation of European ports, replacing an older directive covering the same sector. Negotiations over this regulation have been a contentious and complicated, and have gone on for several years. The proposed new regulation transfers additional powers over ports to the EU, and the European Commission tried to make it a tool to gradually increase ‘market access’ and liberalisation in the port sector. Sinn Féin, along with trade unions and other organisations, are opposed to this recklessly pro-market agenda. Both during negotiations, and in a vote in the European Parliament in March, many of these negative elements of the regulation have been removed.  The new regulation is therefore more technical in nature, removing most of the liberalisation and ‘market access’ agenda whilst strengthening important social and labour protections – including the right to strike.  As a result of these significant improvements, and while the regulation is still far from perfect, I voted in favour of the new regulation.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ Modernising port services and facilities is a key element to contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of TEN-T, the trans-European transport networks , defining a framework to improve the efficiency of all ports and help them address changes in requirements in the logistics and transport sectors. An important condition for fair competition between ports on equal terms is a clear picture on state aid legislation. The Commission is currently engaged in reviewing the scope of the Block Exemption Regulation in order to include port infrastructure criteria by December 2018. It is important that the regulatory framework is fair, transparent and understandable so as not to increase the rift between ports in southern and northern Europe and to optimize their harmonisation and overall functioning.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission proposal seeks to improve the competitiveness of European Union ports classified in the TEN-T, a trans-European transport network through which 96% of goods and 93% of passengers transported. This proposal is also intended to improve the functioning and interconnection of seaports, in particular through the standardization of rules in the European Union. In addition, the text calls for competition within each port while excluding services related to the handling of goods which are subject to concession contracts. The liberalisation of the port services market which the European Union is trying to impose on Member States is intended only to serve the financial interests of large private groups, which see it as a source of profitability. I voted against this text in order to preserve our jobs and to protect our businesses from allegedly free and undistorted competition.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - This report aims to create a framework to improve port performance and make the transition to transport and logistics requirements needed to achieve a more efficient and sustainable TEN-T operation. To achieve these changes, it is necessary to modernise port services and operations, as well as to create framework conditions for attracting new investors. The main condition for fair competition between ports is to create a clear framework on State aid rules, but also on the White Charter on Transport, as well as the Connecting Europe Facility and the initiative known under the name of the Blue Belt. In conclusion, an autonomy of the managing body is necessary to act in accordance with its economic strategy, while also respecting certain key principles. I voted in favour of the report on access to the port services market and the financial transparency of ports because I encourage financial transparency but, at the same time, port autonomy in order to be able to manage the administration of each port effectively, an administration which brings economic added through the economic competition generated by the need for development, beneficial competition, both the EU and the Member States.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the regulation establishing a regulatory framework for access to the port services market and the financial transparency of ports. The aim of the Regulation is to contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of TEN-T by defining a framework to improve the efficiency of all ports and aid them to address changes in requirements in the logistics and transport sectors. For this reason, it also includes modernizing port services and operations and creating the framework conditions for attracting investment to ports. Since it covers only port services offered directly to users, dredging is excluded from the list of services, as it is not a service offered to individual users but a job Maintenance aimed at ensuring the accessibility of the port. The regulation will apply to all seaports identified in the TEN-T guidelines and avoid imposing additional burdens on ports that already work well, while creating the conditions to allow to the other ports of addressing their structural problems.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report came to a vote after a very long process of deliberation in the European Parliament. I am happy that the text that came before the Plenary this time no longer contains any mention of opening access to the market of port services, which was deleted thanks to pressure amendments co-signed by Sinn Féin. The report now is only concerned with organisation, the transparency of accounts, training and safety for workers.  Further amendments I supported the first time this came before plenary will result in strengthened social and labour protection and will prevent action being taken against collective industrial action (i.e. strikes) on the basis that they disrupt port services.  For these reasons I voted in favour of the report, which will now progress towards inter-institutional negotiations.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this because the ports within the UK operate completely differently to the ports on mainland Europe in that the majority of them are privately operated and it would be for the UK Government to decide on the operating terms expected. This regulation is a further adoption from the EU of a one—size—fits—all policy that will just not work.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The aim of this regulation is to increase transparency in the financial relationship between the state, ports and port service operators. This will contribute to better use of public funds and to the effective and fair application of EU competition rules in ports. The provision of port services, Chapter II of the Commission proposal (market access) as amended, now relates to the organisation of port services which may be subject to: (a) minimum requirements for the provision of port services; (b) limitations of the number of providers; (c) public service obligations; (d) restrictions related to internal operators.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This regulation aims to establish a common framework for regulating port services in Europe. Positive elements contained in the report are rules on staff training and social rights, financial transparency when there are public funds and state aid, the exclusion of small leads to the application of additional excessive bureaucratic and administrative burdens. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: ‒ The ports of the European Union play a fundamental role for the functioning of the internal market, facilitating trade between Member States as well as contributing to employment, investment and to GDP growth. However, not all ports on the trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) offer high-level services and a sufficiently attractive governance framework for investors. I believe that in order to make the port services market more efficient and competitive, it is necessary to reduce market access restrictions, impose minimum requirements on service providers and strengthen the transparency on the financing of ports. Furthermore, I believe it is essential for Member States and port authorities to ensure a tighter control of public financing to port infrastructure in order to avoid a unfair competition. I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation, because I believe it is essential to introduce a stable legal framework which can guarantee legal certainty and ensure development and development job creation while maintaining the heterogeneity of the organizations proper to the port sector.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report and ask the Commission to resubmit the proposal if it intends to make significant changes to it or replace it with a new text.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports will bring positive changes to the framework so far in force, as it aims to even more transparency. I think this is a good thing for the Member States of the European Union and for the citizens of Europe, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Our wonderful country with its 57 000 km of coastline possesses, by vocation, important port ports. I therefore welcome my vote because we will achieve significantly more satisfactory results in terms of efficiency, competitiveness and transparency. Long work has led to the drafting of the measure, in particular for the Italian delegation on the provisions concerning the compulsory of the social clause and amendments connected to piloting and mooring. Overall we can say satisfied with the final text as freedom to provide services is looming in the face of the minimum requirements required, such as professional qualifications and equipment, allowing thus greater development of the industry. It will also be possible to limit the number of service providers themselves and, jointly, Member States will be able to impose public service obligations under specific conditions. Thanks to these aspects, port services and operations will be modernized, opening attractive investment scenarios. All this is accompanied by measures aimed at the essential financial transparency of ports and related public funds, among them the establishment of consultation systems between all parties and supervisory bodies with control functions.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework on market access to port services and financial transparency of ports.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this because the ports within the UK operate completely differently to the ports on mainland Europe in that the majority of them are privately operated and it would be for the UK Government to decide on the operating terms expected. This regulation is a further adoption from the EU of a one—size—fits—all policy that will just not work.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure as it provides for an important reordering of the rules relating to the port sector, with measures for the freedom to provide services against minimum requirements required, the possibility of limitations on the number of port service providers, the possibility for Member States to impose public service obligations under certain conditions. The proposal also provides provisions on financial transparency aimed at demonstrating the use of public funds, the non-arbitrariness of prices fixed in the presence of monopolies and the transparency of infrastructure fees. Finally, it aims to establish a system for consultation of all interested parties, as well as independent supervisory bodies with control functions.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Despite the Commission's intention to use this legislative initiative to liberalise and privatize the European port sector, the negotiations between Parliament and the Member States have enabled the text to become, on the contrary, a mechanism for preserving working conditions in the sector and strengthening its rights to collective bargaining or in the event of transfer of the operator service. However, some of its provisions could be used to fragment the public management of the port system by accounting separately those segments that could be open to private competition. Considering the text as a whole, I chose to abstain.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Ports can contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industries on world markets, while ensuring added value and employment in all coastal regions of the Union. So I think it is necessary to address the current inefficiencies of the logistics chain and sustainable transport. I believe that the port management body should have the necessary autonomy to act in accordance with its economic strategy, while respecting certain fundamental principles. I welcomed the invitation to the Committee for Social Dialogue in the Port Sector to identify the guidelines for training requirements to prevent accidents and to ensure the maximum level of safety and health of port workers. In this way it will be possible to establish legal certainty for the ports and have a positive impact on the proper functioning of the TEN-T network.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report aims to contribute to the objective of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of the trans-European transport network by creating a framework that improves the performance of ports and helps them cope with changes in the requirements of transport and logistics. The main objectives are to modernise port services and operations and create framework conditions for attracting investments in ports without leaving fair competition between them. I voted for greater autonomy offered to port administrative bodies to enable them to act according to their economic strategy while respecting certain key principles.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a regulation on the creation of a legal framework for the access to the port services market and the financial transparency of ports. I believe that the final proposal for amendments, as a result of a fair consensus, leads to greater access for service providers to the port services market and to establish common rules on financial transparency and fees. In these regulations, it is of particular importance for me to introduce rules to ensure that Member States have the fullest possible competence. The amendments proposed by the ECR guarantee, inter alia, the removal of the records authorising the Commission to adopt delegated acts, the freedom to determine the most appropriate form of collecting environmental fees by ports, the possibility of Member States to the Commission on the issue of exclusion of private ports from the application of certain regulatory measures and adequate protection of smaller ports from the negative effects of strict regulations.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s approximately 1 200 seaports are fundamental to its economy, enabling the transit of some 74% of imports and exports of cargo and 37% of EU trade. In addition to being crucial both for the EU’s transport sector and for competitiveness, ports also employ more than 3 million people and have the potential to create further jobs and attract investors. This is why I am in favour of this regulation, as it will provide stability and legal certainty for the whole sector for the next decades.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ From the trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T), of which more than 300 Union ports are part, 96% of all goods, 93% of all ships' passenger transit annually, and more than 65% of all goods that are imported to our continent. The regulation that today has been approved by a large majority by the European Parliament proposes a total reorganization of the European regulatory framework of the sector of the ports. A review which was necessary and establishing precise provisions towards greater financial transparency, so that fair and effective competition in the management of services is ensured dockers. Rules that at the same time have the merit of ensuring good working conditions for the workers of the port services and above all provide for them a compulsory and constantly updated training on health and safety, so they can consistently respond to the challenge of technological innovation that has touched this industry. In this way, after 15 years of long negotiations, it was finally possible to take a step forward towards establishing a coordinated and more competitive European policy of the port services sector.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This legislative report aims to increase transparency in financial relations between Member States, ports and port service operators, thereby contributing to a better use of public funds. Although opening up a limited number of port services to some competition, French interests were preserved with the exclusion from the scheme of small ports or services such as pilotage. Considering that, despite the sensitive nature of the file, access to the port services market and the financial transparency of ports will improve the functioning and credibility of services. I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the ports within the UK operate completely differently to the ports on mainland Europe in that the majority of them are privately operated and it would be for the UK Government to decide on the operating terms expected. This regulation is a further adoption from the EU of a one size fits all policy that will just not work.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — With 1,200 ports, port activities contribute directly to job creation, foreign investment and GDP growth in European countries. In total, ports represent up to 3 million jobs, both direct and indirect, in the 22 Member States concerned. However, the sector is marked by low competitive pressure and risks of market abuse. In order to increase the efficiency of port services and to attract even more investment, the European Union must put in place an appropriate regulatory framework. I therefore voted in favour of the regulation establishing a framework for market access in port services and financial transparency of ports. By establishing a common framework on the organisation of port services, while preserving the principle of autonomous port management, this regulation achieves a fair balance, conducive to the development of port activities in Europe.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, connected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T by developing a framework that improves the operation of ports and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and operations and the establishment of framework conditions for investment in ports. In this Regulation, the Commission set itself the objective of offsetting low competitive pressure and potential market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services. An important requirement for fair competition between ports on a level playing field is a clear framework for state aid rules. This proposal is in line with other important EU policies and objectives, such as the White Paper on Transport, the Connecting Europe Facility and the Blue Belt Initiative. This Regulation will apply to all seaports identified in the TEN-T Guidelines and, according to the Commission, will not impose additional burdens on existing ports and will create conditions for other ports to face the structural challenges facing them it is necessary to solve it. Subject to this, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: Europe is one of the regions with the largest number of ports in the world. More than 1 200 commercial seaports operate on the Union's 70,000 kilometres of coastline and employ 470,000 people. 3 739 million tonnes of goods transported by sea were processed in these ports in 2012. The port sector is heterogeneous and is characterized by a wide variety of types and modes of organization. It is therefore necessary for the Union to establish a general framework which, while respecting this diversity, makes it possible to strengthen the competitiveness of ports, to develop maritime and port economy and employment, while ensuring that the high level of maritime security is maintained.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The Commission proposal seeks to contribute to improving the competitiveness of EU ports classified in the trans-European transport network compared to non-EU seaports. It also aims to improve the functioning and interconnection of seaports by introducing harmonised European operating rules. The report also aims to liberalise port management services: freight handling services and passenger services, which are covered by the concession contracts directive, are excluded. The requirement to respect applicable national social and environmental standards is included in this text, but for the most part we regret that more attention has been paid to the issue of the rights of workers in this sector.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the market for port services and financial transparency in ports, as I believe that the proposed amendments are fully in line with my positions. The proposed amendments underline the need for independence of the port's governing body in order to enable it to pursue its economic strategy, subject to certain key principles. Furthermore, the report stresses that the objective of avoiding administrative burdens in connection with the application of this Regulation is aimed at. In summary, this Regulation should lead to legal certainty for ports and have a positive impact on the successful functioning of the TEN-T network.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We firmly believe that port management is a matter of the highest national security and belongs exclusively to the states of Europe, which should discriminate and control their exploitation. For these reasons, we are voting against the report by the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on market access to port services because the report was too weak. I wanted stronger provisions for workers, for example. I also believe that in fact this would have no positive impact on Welsh ports.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The new rules cover more than 300 European seaports, including 13 Portuguese. The adopted legislation aims, among other things, to increase the transparency of charges for port services and the use of port infrastructure, as well as the use of public funding. These rules do not impose a specific model for the management of seaports and do not affect the competence of Member States to provide non-economic services of general interest. Different port management models are possible, provided that the system for the provision of port services and the common rules on financial transparency laid down in the Regulation are respected. Port services covered by the Regulation are fuel supply, mooring, towing and collecting ship-generated waste and cargo residues. Cargo handling, passenger services and pilotage shall be subject to financial transparency rules but exempt from the rules on the organisation of services.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Against: this proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much broader liberalisation which certainly will not benefit both port and maritime workers or European consumers as a whole.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The conversation is neither new nor the original arguments. Under the cover of a significant modernization of services and operations, the liberalization and privatization of another strategic sector of the economy is the port sector. The promises have already been seen in other sectors: to capture investment, greater efficiency, better quality. We know well what they mean, denying that they are, without appeal or harm, by reality. It is true that this proposal falls far short of what were the initial liberalising ambitions of the European Commission. Decreases the degree of liberalization. A retreat forced by the struggle, by the resistance of the workers, in the first place. But the truth is that, despite this, the proposal does not fail to point a way. That they will try to accomplish when they find themselves in the conditions to do so. A negative and urgent path that must be fought. The concern expressed about port users is amusing. It is funny that while in other sectors' users' become 'customers' — for example in public transport — here, where customers are big companies, then there is already talk of “users”.
