Very enlightening. It is very clear from the point of view expressed here: that of big business, large economic groups and large multinationals. We obviously voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the following proposal because I believe that it is necessary to promote a more efficient operation of the trans-European transport network. I consider, moreover, the objectives of the proposal to start a process of modernization of services and port operations and to contribute to the creation of new conditions suitable to attract investment in ports.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is very important that we work constantly to improve the competitiveness and transparency of European ports, and also not to forget the ports located on the absolute margins of the regions. Once new, legislation should focus more on setting a kind of minimum standards for the performance of services for individual ports or limiting the maximum number of service providers. The legislation in question also deals with financial transparency and the guarantee of fair competition, as well as the absolute restriction of price dumping.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting against the report because there is a real risk of creating very harmful effects on local incumbents who have been performing certain services for decades, if not in some cases for centuries, have been performing certain services in our ports.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - The control of the economic and commercial activities of ports which the European Union wants to impose creates more problems in terms of security, workers' rights and the development of its Member States. The ports are managed by the Member States of Europe and they alone should control their exploitation and information about their activity, thus ensuring their economy and national security. It is well known that neoliberal practices in the Member States in recent years have led to privatisation of ports, which have resulted in financial control, the restriction of the commercial activities of the Member States and the systematic undermining of workers' rights. I firmly believe that port management is a matter of the highest national security and belongs exclusively to the Member States of Europe, which should discriminate and control their exploitation. For these reasons, I am voting against the report by the Committee on Transport and Tourism on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it will damage British ports. It is a prime example of the ‘one-size—fits—all’ approach of the Commission that simply doesn’t work.  British Ports were privatised 30 years ago. This regulation will simply introduce a raft of regulations which will cost our ports money whilst adding nothing. Additionally, it does nothing to address the vast amount of state aid that publically owned ports receive elsewhere in the EU.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement sets a framework that should boost the efficiency and strengthen competitiveness of maritime ports of the trans-European transport network, taking into account the specific situation of ports located in outermost regions.  I believe it is fundamental to preserve the various organisation models in the Union, while allowing authorities or port managing bodies to set minimum requirements for performing port services or limiting the number of service providers. After two unsuccessful attempts to adopt a regulation on port services, the Parliament, thanks to our Rapporteur Knut Fleckenstein, is now on its way to success on its third attempt. This regulation will provide stability and legal certainty for the whole sector for the next decades, assuring growth and job creation.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, connected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T by developing a framework that improves the operation of ports and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and operations and the establishment of framework conditions for investment in ports. In this Regulation, the Commission set itself the objective of offsetting low competitive pressure and potential market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services. An important requirement for fair competition between ports on a level playing field is a clear framework for state aid rules. This proposal is in line with other important EU policies and objectives, such as the White Paper on Transport, the Connecting Europe Facility and the Blue Belt Initiative. This Regulation will apply to all seaports identified in the TEN-T Guidelines and, according to the Commission, will not impose additional burdens on existing ports and will create conditions for other ports to face the structural challenges facing them it is necessary to solve it. Subject to this, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, connected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T by developing a framework that improves the operation of ports and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and operations and the establishment of framework conditions for investment in ports. In this Regulation, the Commission set itself the objective of offsetting low competitive pressure and potential market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services. An important requirement for fair competition between ports on a level playing field is a clear framework for state aid rules. This Regulation will apply to all seaports identified in the TEN-T Guidelines and, according to the Commission, will not impose additional burdens on existing ports and will create conditions for other ports to face the structural challenges facing them it is necessary to solve it. Subject to this, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ports can contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industry on world markets, as can promote added value and create jobs in all coastal regions of the Union. In order to meet the challenges of maritime transport, some shortcomings in the sustainable transport and logistics chain need to be overwhelmed. This includes, for example, the simplification of the administrative procedure for customs clearance.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because the ports within the UK operate completely differently to the ports on mainland Europe in that the majority of them are privately operated and it would be for the UK Government to decide on the operating terms expected. This regulation is a further adoption from the EU of a one size fits all policy that will just not work.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s proposal for a new Port Services Regulation did not sufficiently recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. However, after negotiation and campaigning since 2013, the European Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements, including on respecting employment and trade union rights. The continuing success of the UK ports industry is vital to the country and there are major challenges ahead in the light of the Brexit vote. Labour MEPs will continue to work actively to support our ports and all who work in them.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on port services began with a liberalising proposal by the European Commission with which we are deeply against. However, during the negotiations, the proposal was reversed, the liberalization clauses were omitted and the rights of dockworkers were protected. This is a satisfactory result that we usually do not see in the reforms of European transport legislation. However, I have decided to abstain, because the final wording calls for the promotion of decentralized port management while, in an eminently maritime country such as ours, centralized management of the port network is one of the key elements of the system. Although in no case does this decentralisation take place compulsory, we wanted to be consistent with our position to defend the ability of each Member State to choose its own public management model, in accordance with its trajectory and its specificities.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report because, as a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I believe that the rapporteur has improved some aspects of the Commission proposal. The report stresses the need for the port management body to have autonomy in order to act on its economic strategy while respecting certain key principles. In addition, the rapporteur avoids an increase in the administrative burden associated with the application of this Regulation. In conclusion, this Regulation should create legal certainty for ports and have a positive impact on the functioning of the TEN-T network. Fair competition between ports in a fair competitive environment is essential. It is also important to modernise port services and operations and create framework conditions for attracting investment in ports.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to support this report. The Commission’s proposal for a new Port Services Regulation did not sufficiently recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. However, after negotiation and campaigning since 2013, the European Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements, including on respecting employment and trade union rights. The continuing success of the UK ports industry is vital to the country and there are major challenges ahead in the light of the Brexit vote. Labour MEPs will continue to work actively to support our ports and all who work in them.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this agreement, which aims to improve the quality and efficiency of port services for users, reduce costs and encourage investment. Indeed, this text introduces more transparency to ensure a better autonomy of our seaports and a better connection between maritime transport and rail. Thanks to these new measures, our ports in Europe will see their competitiveness stronger vis-à-vis their international competitors.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report deals with access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. Unfortunately, the aim of the report is to deregulate and liberalise port services. Many reforms are being promoted to reduce costs (with what this entails) and increase competitiveness to attract private investors. Many labour rights are endangered. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation (adopted in December 2016) aims at contributing to a more efficient functioning of the TEN-T by creating a framework which improves the performance of all ports and helps them to cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. Financial transparency lies at heart of this initiative, supported by the ALDE group, in order to provide clarity and promote fair competition between European ports –as many Member States still provide subsidies to their own ports. Moreover, this agreement offers a clear framework for the port services market. In future, all port authorities have to apply the same non-discriminatory rules when choosing their service providers.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, connected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T by developing a framework that improves the operation of ports and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and operations and the establishment of framework conditions for investment in ports.
