This Regulation will apply to all seaports identified in the TEN-T Guidelines and, according to the Commission, will not impose additional burdens on existing ports and will create conditions for other ports to face the structural challenges facing them it is necessary to solve it. Subject to this, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report that this Regulation should create legal certainty for ports and have a positive impact on the functioning of the TEN-T network. The main objectives of this report include modernising port services and operations and creating framework conditions for attracting investment in ports. This proposal is in line with important EU policies and objectives, such as the White Paper on Transport, the Connecting Europe Facility and the Blue Belt Initiative.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted for the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports (COM (2013) 0296 — C8-0144/2013 — 2013/0157 (COD)), since this Regulation achieves a more efficient and better connected functioning of TEN-T network by creating better conditions for the functioning of ports and adapting to changes in transport and logistical conditions. This Regulation aims to contribute to the modernisation of port services and port operations, to increase the efficiency of port services and create better conditions for attractiveness of investment in ports. It strengthens competition, better jobs and better working conditions for employees, legal certainty for both investors and employees, and better information for service users. This aims to achieve greater transparency in the use of public funds, control of state aid, clarity in public tenders, creating a level playing field for European ports. This Regulation will apply to all maritime ports set out in the TEN-T Guidelines, avoid additional burdens for those ports that are already functioning well, while other ports create conditions to cope with structural changes.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — Despite the positive aspects of the amendments resulting from the first visit to the Committee on Transport and the Trialogue, I oppose this permanent effort to further liberalisation, which this proposal for a regulation is only the foundation stone of a building that will benefit multinationals above all. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Knut Fleckenstein's report on access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. This report seeks to establish a clear framework for greater transparency while respecting port autonomy and respecting local specificities. The port professions are thus largely preserved as marine pilots and dockworkers are excluded from the reform and that tugs and manners can be protected by the national flag.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, more interconnected and sustainable operation of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T) by establishing a framework within which all ports can improve their performance and adapt to changing transport and logistics requirements. afford. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and port operations and the creation of an attractive framework for investment in ports. The Commission intends to use this Regulation to counteract weak competitive pressure and potential market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s proposal for a new Port Services Regulation did not sufficiently recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. However, after negotiation and campaigning since 2013, the European Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements, including on respecting employment and trade union rights. The continuing success of the UK ports industry is vital to the country and there are major challenges ahead in the light of the Brexit vote. I, along with Labour colleagues, will continue to work actively to support our ports and all who work in them.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, connected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T by developing a framework that improves the operation of ports and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and operations and the establishment of framework conditions for investment in ports. In this Regulation, the Commission set itself the objective of offsetting low competitive pressure and potential market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services. An important requirement for fair competition between ports on a level playing field is a clear framework for state aid rules. This proposal is in line with other important EU policies and objectives, such as the White Paper on Transport, the Connecting Europe Facility and the Blue Belt Initiative. This Regulation will apply to all seaports identified in the TEN-T Guidelines and, according to the Commission, will not impose additional burdens on existing ports and will create conditions for other ports to face the structural challenges facing them it is necessary to solve it. Subject to this, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party Delegation, I supported the report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the European Commission's proposal to establish a framework for access to the market for port services and financial transparency in ports, as its aim is to contribute to achieving the objective of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of trans-European transport networks by creating a framework to improve port activity and help them cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. The main priorities are to modernise port services and operations and the creation of framework conditions for attracting investment in ports. There is a drive to counter weak competitive pressure and possible market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services. An important condition for fair competition between ports on a level playing field is also the existence of a clear framework for State aid rules. The regulation will apply to seaports referred to in the TEN-T Guidelines and will avoid excess burdens on well-functioning ports, while creating the necessary conditions so that other ports can cope with the structural challenges facing them.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Europe is one of the densest port regions worldwide. At the same time, the port sector is very heterogeneous and characterised by a wide diversity in types and organisation. The EU is highly dependent on its ports for its trade with the rest of the world and for proper functioning of its own internal market. In this context, the Commission’s proposal on the trans-European transport network (TEN-T) seeks to contribute to the goal of more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of EU ports by creating a framework which improves the performance of ports and helps them to cope with changes in transport and logistics requirements. In general, the Commission’s proposal aims to counteract weak competitive pressure and possible market abuses, in order to increase the efficiency of port services and to promote financial transparency. Looking from this perspective, I voted in favour of it.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — I vote in favour of the report on access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports in order to create a political framework capable of increasing the effectiveness of ports, which allow adaptations in the case of changes in the logistics and transport sectors, with the aim of achieving a more efficient, sustainable and interconnected operation. The main purpose is to modernize the services of port operations, develop appropriate rules to encourage investment in ports and counter potential market abuses. The report calls for increasing transparency in the financial sector and in the relationship between Member States, ports and port services, using the funds available more efficiently. The proposed legislation will be implemented on all the seaports in the TEN-T guidelines, will make way to avoid the imposition of further burdens to the functioning ports and will give the possibility to other ports of deal with their structural problems.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to implement real port reform at European level. This creates greater transparency in the operation of ports, while respecting their autonomy, in the face of an increasingly strong international competitor. The port professions are largely preserved, since maritime pilots and dockworkers are excluded from the reform and tugs and manners can be protected by the national flag, which guarantees social rights. It is not time for liberalization, which would primarily benefit our international competitors and promote social dumping. With this port reform, we are enabling this sector to gain competitiveness, while respecting social rights.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on market access for port services and financial transparency of ports. The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to improving the competitiveness of EU ports relative to non-EU seaports, and fair competition between European ports. It also aims to improve the functioning and interconnection of seaports by creating uniform European operating rules. However, once again, States are forced to further liberalize. This proposal for a regulation is certainly one more step towards a much broader liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, certainly not to port and maritime workers, and European employees and consumers as a whole.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Despite the Commission's intention to use this legislative initiative to liberalise and privatize the European port sector, the negotiations between Parliament and the Member States have enabled the text to become, on the contrary, a mechanism for preserving working conditions in the sector and strengthening its rights to collective bargaining or in the event of transfer of the operator service. However, some of its provisions could be used to fragment the public management of the port system by accounting separately those segments that could be open to private competition. Considering the text as a whole, I chose to abstain.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission's proposal, which seeks to modernise port operations and services and attract investment in ports, seeking to increase competitiveness and combat market abuse, contributes by establishing a framework for the achievement of the more efficient trans-European transport network, interconnected and sustainable. I am voting in favour because this will result in an improvement of port services which will benefit many European citizens. We cannot ignore the opportunity of European industry's competitiveness by ports that work as efficiently as possible. It also gives us the opportunity to create new jobs in the coastal areas of the Union.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: in writing. — After 15 years of work, a balanced report on access to the port services market and the financial transparency of ports has been adopted. I am pleased that the work, especially during this term of the European Parliament, has been able to persuade the rapporteur to open up and accept the arguments of all parties to the dialogue. One of the more important proposals is to recognise the subjectivity and autonomy of port boards with a simultaneous emphasis on financial transparency especially in the area of public aid. It is important that one size fits all solutions have been waived, therefore, like most MPs, I supported the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted against. I don't agree with union regulation of port operations. This regulation will entail restrictions and additional costs for the Czech Republic with regard to the operation of its sovereign port in Hamburg.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The vast majority of the Union's maritime transport passes through the sea ports of the Trans-European transport network. This Regulation does not impose a specific model of port management on port management bodies. The proposal for a regulation seeks to increase transparency in financial relations between the state, ports and the port services market. This will contribute to a better use of public funds and the effective application of competition rules at ports across the Union, and I have therefore supported this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for market access to port services and financial transparency of ports, for the reasons I explained in detail in the plenary session of the European Parliament and of the Council. Parliament in Strasbourg on 12/12/2016, and also because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The aim of this text is to improve the competitiveness of EU ports classified in the TEN-T (319 largest ports) compared to non-EU seaports. It also wants to improve the functioning and interconnection of seaports or attract investment, which we support. On the other hand, it is forcing Member States to more liberalisation (which in addition to encroaching on our sovereignty, will only benefit multinationals). Moreover, the social provisions governing the labour regime in ports have been, for a large part, omitted from the regulation proposed by the Commission.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on market access to port services and financial transparency of ports. The proposal positively aims to implement a more efficient, interconnected, and sustainable functioning of the TEN-T through the improvement of performance of ports. In the long run, the agreement seems capable of modernising port services and operations as well as developing conditions able to attract potential investment in ports. Furthermore, supporting the proposal would result in increasing efficiency of port services by countering weak competitive pressure and market abuses. Without further ado, the proposal will have a positive impact on different sectors of society and the economy.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In the report concerning ports, today we discussed in particular the need for modernisation of port services and activities and the creation of framework conditions to attract investment. Emphasis is also placed on financial transparency of ports and port services. In the report we speak out against casual work and, on the contrary, call for better training and safety conditions. We also highlight the social provisions governing the port work regime, as well as the need to ensure the rights of employees in the event of a transfer of businesses or plants. I voted to accept this report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report provides for regulation of the port sector with regard to market access rules and the financial transparency of ports. The Regulation calls for the sovereignty of each Member State in respect of compliance with its national legislation and therefore disregards the idea of liberalization of this market sector. This legislative proposal advocates the mandatory initial and/or continuous training of dockers, the protection of their labour and social rights, the fight for non-precarious work, promoting greater safety and better working conditions in ports. I voted in favour of

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The aim of the Commission's proposal is to contribute to a more efficient, more interconnected and sustainable functioning of the trans-European transport network by establishing a framework within which all ports can improve their performance and adapt to the changing requirements in transport and logistics ( TEN-V). The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and port operations and the creation of an attractive framework for investment in ports. The Commission intends to use this Regulation to counteract weak competitive pressure and potential market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services. The social legislation on the labour regulations of ports has been substantially excluded from this Regulation and will be discussed by the Sectoral Social Dialogue Committee for Ports at EU level, which started its work on 19 June 2013. Nevertheless, the rapporteur considers it important to take a clear stand against irregular employment and for better training and better safety conditions. Compliance with national social standards has been added as a minimum criterion. In addition, Member States should ensure the rights of workers in the event of transfer of undertakings or establishments. For these reasons, I supported the report.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the Commission’s proposal for a new Port Services Regulation, Members of the European Parliament have managed to include improvements on employment, training and trade union rights, which is why I voted in favour of this report. I know that UK ports still have some concerns, and I will continue to listen carefully to the thoughtful contributions from major ports in the area including Felixstowe, London Gateway, Harwich, Tilbury, Ipswich, King’s Lynn and Lowestoft. I hope that with proper implementation, the rules on transparency can work positively.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The purpose of the proposal is to increase the efficiency of port services. To this end, it encourages the modernisation of port services and operations and the creation of framework conditions to attract investment in ports. In particular, it aims to increase the transparency of financial flows in order to avoid situations of unfair competition or dumping between Union ports. It is therefore a matter of allowing the liberalisation of port services. Of course, the emphasis is placed on the importance of training personnel in order to “protect the health and safety of port workers”. And the text states that no emergency measures can be taken by the port authority to deal with industrial class actions, that is, against strikers. Finally, if freight handling services (dockers), passenger services and pilotage are not currently affected by opening up to competition, this cannot be delayed. I am voting against this text

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. — This proposal by the European Commission aims to improve the competitiveness of European Union ports, but also the functioning and interconnection of them by creating new, uniform European rules. Proposals and amendments to this report are insufficient. Moreover, the Member States concerned are forced to increasingly liberalise and the proposal for a regulation is only the first step towards a much wider liberalisation of this sector, which will only benefit multinationals and not European employees and consumers. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The planning, development and operation of the trans-European transport network contribute to the achievement of important Union objectives, such as the smooth functioning of the internal market and the strengthening of economic and social cohesion. The maritime network is an integral part of it, since 319 ports — through which 96% of the goods and 93% of EU passengers pass — are affected by the guidelines on the trans-European transport network. Nevertheless, we must move towards more homogeneity in terms of the quality of services within the ports of the trans-European transport network and improve their governance in order to attract investors. With this resolution, we will contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of the trans-European transport network by creating a framework for ports to improve their performance and better cope with changing transport and logistics requirements.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this regulation, which calls to provide stability and legal certainty for the whole sector over the next few decades, assuring growth and job creation, which is essential.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission has proposed to Parliament and the Council the adoption of a regulation establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. In its report, the Committee on Transport and Tourism proposes that Parliament adopts the proposal at first reading with 136amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal seeks to contribute to improving the competitiveness of EU ports classified in the TEN-T (trans-European transport network, i.e. the main road, rail and maritime routes in Europe) compared to seaports outside the EU, and fair competition between TEN-T ports. It also aims to improve the functioning and interconnection of seaports by creating uniform European operating rules. The proposal also aims to attract investment in ports. Finally, by this regulation, the Commission intends to combat the lack of competition within each port and the alleged risks of abuse resulting from it. In principle, if the changes resulting from the first visit to the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) and the trilogue are positive (fewer activities concerned and less regulation in the activities concerned), this remains insufficient to support the report, since once again the States are forced to further liberalise. This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much broader liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, certainly not to port and maritime workers, and European employees and consumers as a whole. I voted against it.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. — As a matter of principle, if the changes resulting from the first visit to the Committee on Transport and the Trialogue are positive (fewer activities involved and less regulation in the activities concerned), this is still insufficient for me to vote favourably, since once again the States are forced to further liberalise. This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards a much broader liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, certainly not to port and maritime workers, and European employees and consumers as a whole. I am therefore voting against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s proposal for a new Port Services Regulation did not sufficiently recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. However, after negotiation and campaigning since 2013, the European Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements, including on respecting employment and trade union rights. The continuing success of the UK ports industry is vital to the country and there are major challenges ahead in the light of the Brexit vote. Labour MEPs will continue to work actively to support our ports and all who work in them.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text on the framework for market access for port services and financial transparency of ports. Parliament is thus amending a draft regulation which aims to strengthen the long-term competitiveness of our European ports, but also to simplify customs procedures.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Trans-European Transport Network supports the construction and upgrade of transport infrastructure across the European Union. I have voted for this report that will modernise port services and operations and create framework conditions that will attract investments in ports.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I believe that this report is making consistent improvements to the Commission's proposal for a regulation on access to the port services market and financial transparency. It is important that this regulation encourages competitiveness between ports, that fair competition between them is ensured, and that the services offered are constantly modernising and improving. In this respect, I believe that both the proposal of the committee, which meets these objectives and the present report, which improves the original text, will boost the ports of the European Union to become more efficient, competitive and innovative.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because I consider the proposals for improvement to be very positive. An important issue would be the improvement of working conditions on the basis of binding national, regional or local social standards to be granted.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. In order to ensure a more efficient operation of the trans-European transport network, port work will be enhanced and help them cope with changing transport and logistics requirements in the financial sphere.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal for a Regulation aims at modernising port services, improving investment and creating conditions for fair competition between ports on an equal footing. In addition, it aims to create a clearer framework for State investment and financial transparency. That is why I voted in favour of the compromise proposal reached with the Council.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The aim of the proposal is to contribute to efforts for a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of the trans-European transport network by creating a framework that will improve port efficiency and contribute to addressing changes in requirements transport and logistics. The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and operations and the creation of basic conditions for attracting investment in ports. Emphasis is also placed on good working conditions, which constitute an important part of the competitiveness of ports. The agreement also takes account of the specific situation of ports located in the outermost regions. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. — The Communist Party of Greece voted against the regulation on 'access to the market for port services', as agreed with the Council, because it leads to the full 'liberalisation of port services', i.e. their delivery along with the ports themselves and their infrastructure to the monopoly groups. Implementation of the regulation will also affect workers' rights, such as sectoral collective agreements, with worsening of working and pay conditions, intensification, etc. Their ports and services, either through various forms of direct delivery to capital or operated by the urban state, serve the profits of monopolies, to the detriment of workers, the people as a whole. Faithful to this direction, to the “acquis communautaire”, the Syriza-ANEL coalition delivers to the business groups ports, infrastructure and services, serving the strategic goal of the domestic bourgeoisie, to upgrade its geopolitical role in the region. That is why SYRIZA voted in favour of the regulation together with its partners in memoranda, ND, PASOK and Potamos, People's Party, Liberals and Social Democrats. The ports and infrastructure of the country can become popular property in the service of social needs, when the working people are relieved of the sovereignty of their monopolies and associations, taking power and economy into their own hands.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The regulation aims to increase transparency in the financial relationship between the state, ports and port service operators. This will contribute to better use of public funds and to the effective and fair application of EU competition rules in ports. As a member—substitute of the ECON Committee, I supported this agreement because I believe that financial transparency is crucial for building and maintaining trust.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. — The European Union implements a transport infrastructure policy linking the continent from east and west, to north and south. The aim of this policy is to bridge the unconnected parts of the transport network of Member States, remove bottlenecks that still threaten the smooth functioning of the internal market and overcome technical barriers. The policy promotes and strengthens transport links for passenger and freight transport, all keeping pace with the latest technology trends. Through this policy, 24.05 billion euros will be invested by 2020. In this collusion of activities aimed at improving infrastructure and operations in the transport sector, it is necessary to remove barriers in access to the port services market. The Commission's proposal is balanced and flexible to suit the needs of different port operators, as well as the specifics of each of the European ports in particular. The regulation aims to increase transparency in financial relations between state ports and services of operators operating at these ports. This will contribute to a better use of public funds and the effective and fair application of competition rules at EU ports. The application of this new regulation from the Union's set of legislative acts will increase the legal certainty of all stakeholders to whom ports life means. For all of the above, I supported the Resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — We have a duty to ensure the competitiveness of European industry globally tomorrow and by improving the operations of ports can contribute to this long-term objective — therefore it is necessary to respond to the challenges facing the maritime transport sector, which among other things affect competitiveness and social dimension. Therefore, Member States, together with the social partners, should take measures to preserve the competitiveness of the sector and prevent uncertain working conditions at ports. Working relations at ports have a great impact on the very functioning of ports and I call on the Sectoral Committee for Social Dialogue for Ports to provide EU social partners with a framework for the possible adoption of common results on social issues related to labour relations at EU level. The negotiations should respect the autonomy of the social partners and provide them with the opportunity to report on progress made. The inefficiency of the transport and logistics chain is a major challenge, and I call for simplification of administrative procedures for customs approvals, which will achieve a major economic advantage for ports in terms of competitiveness. It is necessary to avoid unfair competition from ports and reduce customs formalities that could seriously harm the Union's financial interests.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: The conversation is neither new nor the original arguments. Under the cover of a significant modernization of services and operations, the liberalization and privatization of another strategic sector of the economy is the port sector. The promises have already been seen in other sectors: to capture investment, greater efficiency, better quality. We know well what they mean, denying that they are, without appeal or harm, by reality. It is true that this proposal falls far short of what were the initial liberalising ambitions of the European Commission. Decreases the degree of liberalization. A retreat forced by the struggle, by the resistance of the workers, in the first place. But the truth is that, despite this, the proposal does not fail to point a way. That they will try to accomplish when they find themselves in the conditions to do so. A negative and urgent path that must be fought. The concern expressed about port users is amusing. It is funny that while in other sectors' users' become 'customers' — for example in public transport — here, where customers are big companies, then there is already talk of “users”. Very enlightening. It is very clear from the point of view expressed here: that of big business, large economic groups and large multinationals. We obviously voted against it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — This Agreement clarifies the scope and objective of the Regulation, creating a framework that should increase efficiency and strengthen the competitiveness of the maritime transport network. It also takes into account the special situation of ports located in the outermost regions. In connection with this, it aims to maintain the various organisational models in the Union while allowing authorities or port governing bodies to set minimum requirements for the implementation of port services or restrictions on the number of service providers. As a social democrat, I think it is necessary that there are similar regulations in the EU to guarantee that the European single market is fair to all its participants, so I have this agreement glad to upvoted.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — In the course of the work on the Regulation, solutions favourable to Poland's interests have been developed, such as the obligation to designate an independent authority to monitor and supervise the application of the Regulation; terminals for transhipment and passenger service have been excluded and piloting services from the main chapter of the proposed Regulation - on the rules for the provision of port services and transitional provisions requiring the adjustment of contracts governing port services to the new rules; significantly reduced the scope of application of the Regulation in with regard to dredging services; extended the deadline for the start of application of the Regulation to 24 months after its notice; the power to issue implementing acts and delegated by the EC; the preamble states that “the Regulation should not in any way infringe the rules regulating the system of property rights in the Member States applicable to seaports and should allow different port structures in the Member States. ' I hereby supported the compromise worked out.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report in order to improve port performance. We call for increased financial transparency on the fees and financing that EU ports receive, with the obligation to clearly show in their accounting systems the public funding received. This will facilitate the work of the European Commission to determine a coherent public aid scheme and encourage investment. We also encourage port service providers to ensure adequate employee training, including health and safety aspects, to meet the challenges of technological innovation and ensure quality services.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the ports within the UK operate completely differently to the ports on mainland Europe in that the majority of them are privately operated and it would be for the UK Government to decide on the operating terms expected. This regulation is a further adoption from the EU of a one size fits all policy that will just not work.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the regulation establishing a framework for the organization of port services. While the Commission had proposed a liberal text, I welcome the fact that the Council and the European Parliament have reached an agreement to arrive at a balanced text that deals no longer with the liberalisation of port services but on their organisation. Specifically, the text clearly establishes that port authorities are able to impose public service obligations, limit the number of providers and impose minimum requirements to be met by service providers (compliance with social legislation, good reputation of the port service provider). In this context, Member States may, in particular, impose the national flag obligation on service providers. This is a real step forward that I have always defended to protect workers against competition from flags of convenience, which are less protective of social rights (rest time, working hours, affiliation with a social security body...). Finally, on workers' rights, the text establishes that port authorities may impose the transfer of personnel in the event of a change of service provider. In this case, the staff will have to be resumed under the conditions prevailing under the former claimant.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has approved new rules on the provision of port services and financial transparency of ports covering six maritime infrastructures in mainland Portugal (Aveiro, Lisbon, Portimão, Porto/Leixões, Setúbal and Sines), with the responsibility of Lisbon to decide on the ports of the Azores and Wood. The legislation adopted today aims, among other objectives, to increase the transparency of port service charges and the use of port infrastructure, as well as the use of public funding. Port services covered by the Regulation are fuel supply, mooring, towing and collecting ship-generated waste and cargo residues. Cargo handling, passenger services and pilotage shall be subject to financial transparency rules but exempt from the rules on the organisation of services. The agreed text provides that social and labour rules are not affected by the regulation and that port workers receive adequate training on their working conditions. In addition, the report guarantees the right to strike. The Regulation also adopted provisions on financial transparency which ensure fair competition and prevent price abuse, in particular where services are not subject to effective competition.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — The agreement reached with the Council at first reading substantially changes the initial proposal submitted by the Commission by ensuring that ports can limit the number of operators on a multitude of criteria (such as public service obligations, safety or environmental matters etc.). The agreement also requires greater transparency of financial flows between public authorities and ports in order to detect situations of unfair competition between ports and covert state aid. In addition, the text has been substantially improved with measures such as the exclusion from the regulation of categories such as piloting, provisions relating to social dialogue and the strengthening of the obligations of subrogation of staff in the event of a change of port operator, while recognizing the possibility of fixing the fees for the use of the port infrastructure by law as is the case in Spain. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — After more than 15 years of debate on European port policy, the European Parliament finally reached an agreement this afternoon: the models for the management of existing ports can be maintained and, this is a novelty, the emphasis is finally placed on good working conditions, which represent an important part of competitiveness of ports and which, in my view, was a non-negotiable one. Until now, the lack of clear rules on public financing of port infrastructure and charges for their use hindered investment in ports. The new provisions adopted today aim, inter alia, to make ports more efficient and attractive to investors. These new rules will apply to more than 300 Union ports mentioned in the Guidelines for the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T). They include the obligation for ports to clearly show in their accounting systems the public funding received and to improve transparency, so that port services and infrastructure charges are fixed. In order to ensure quality services, new requirements are therefore also foreseen for port service providers to ensure adequate training of employees, with particular emphasis on health and safety aspects.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Although the proposed draft legislation has really good objectives: facilitating access to the port market, clarifying port services, it also has very many shortcomings. The shortcomings — from the limitation of workers' social rights such as the right to strike, the actual refusal to align the text with State aid rules to the ignoring of environmental objectives in the establishment of port charges — prevent me from supporting this proposal.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This report deals with a proposal for a regulation establishing a regulatory framework for access to port services and the financial transparency of ports, in order to contribute to a more transparent, efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of the trans-European transport network (RTE-T). Key purposes are the modernization of port services and operations, as well as the creation of investment attractiveness conditions, to counteract the reduced competitive pressure and possible market abuse in this segment. Overall, I consider this proposal to be quite positive and I largely endorse the suggestions put forward by the rapporteur in order to contribute to more efficient, transparent and more involved port management and, therefore, to give greater legal certainty in the smooth functioning of the TEN-T network.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted to approve an agreement for a regulation establishing a framework for market access for port services and the financial transparency of ports. The Regulation aims to increase the transparency of financial relations between the State, ports and port service operators. Finally, a high level of transparency of financial relations will make better use of public funds and the application of EU competition rules more fairly and effectively.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Despite the Commission's intention to use this legislative initiative to liberalise and privatize the European port sector, the negotiations between Parliament and the Member States have enabled the text to become, on the contrary, a mechanism for preserving working conditions in the sector and strengthening its rights to collective bargaining or in the event of transfer of the operator service. However, some of its provisions could be used to fragment the public management of the port system by accounting separately those segments that could be open to private competition. Considering the text as a whole, I chose to abstain.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the ports within the UK operate completely differently to the ports on mainland Europe in that the majority of them are privately operated and it would be for the UK Government to decide on the operating terms expected. This regulation is a further adoption from the EU of a one size fits all policy that will just not work.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to support this report. The Commission’s proposal for a new Port Services Regulation did not sufficiently recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU’s port sector. However, after negotiation and campaigning since 2013, the European Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements, including on respecting employment and trade union rights. The continuing success of the UK ports industry is vital to the country and there are major challenges ahead in the light of the Brexit vote. Labour MEPs will continue to work actively to support our ports and all who work in them.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I did not support this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not actually reflect the actual quality and quantity work, efficiency and most of all the success of advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. “I supported the legislative resolutions because I believe that the proposed measures can contribute to a more efficient, better connected and sustainable operation of the trans-European transport network (TEN-T), which connects Member States' land, sea and air routes into a single multimodal system. I also voted in favour of this proposal because the adoption of this framework will improve the performance of all ports, which ultimately can contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industries on world markets, while creating added value and new jobs in all coastal areas regions of the Union. As we continue to see complex administrative procedures for customs clearance causing delays in ports, which are a major obstacle to the competitiveness of coastal maritime transport and to the efficiency of Union ports, I agree that the steps set out in in the Communication from the Commission entitled Ports: a Growth Engine on Administrative Simplification. In order to avoid unfair competition between ports and to limit customs clearance formalities, I expect Member States and the Commission to monitor these procedures regularly and, if necessary, take appropriate measures to address unfair competition.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - Trade of the European Union with the rest of the world and within the single market depends heavily on ports. 74% of imported or exported goods go through ports and 37% of intra-Union trade. Supporters of the proposal, which is on the table, predict that it will bring better financial transparency to the operation of port services, but the effects of this will in fact be limited, as this could only apply to smaller ports in the southern Member States. The new rules will not bring change to existing structures in major and northern ports. Nor does the text contain sufficiently convincing content and the Commission only resolves its face, since two port packages have already fallen and simply cannot afford it any more. The whole sector agrees that it would be much more important to regulate the area of State aid for ports, which the Commission promised 12 years ago and never implemented. This bundle, unfortunately, doesn't govern that either. In the Greens/ESZ Group, we also worked to ensure that the regulations also include strong environmental criteria and a clear commitment to respect EU legislation in this area, which was rejected. For all of the reasons listed, I voted against.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: — This report on greater financial transparency in ports is misleading, given that it only concerns the smaller ports in the southern Member States. For the larger ports in the north, the new rules will not count and their structures will not change. Moreover, the report lacks convincing content and is mainly intended to save the Commission's face. He does not want to go away after two previous rejections of the port directive. The proposal we are voting on concerns the liberalisation of services in marginal and limited segments. The controversial freight and passenger handling is not included. What the sector needs — and there is agreement on this — is clarity on state aid. Something the Commission has promised for 12 years, but still has not put into rules. We also tried with the Greens to include environmental and working conditions measures in the text, but almost everything was voted out, including the question of clarity on state aid. The report is so weak that it will pass under the pretext 'it does not benefit, it does not harm', and in the meantime the Commission is leaving the sector alone. But I don't call that policy. I therefore did not support the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. — European ports are an important part of the global trading network. We must prepare them for the upcoming digitisation and automation of transport so that they remain competitive while meeting all the European Union's environmental and safety standards.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - Ports can contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industry in world markets, while increasing the added value and number of jobs in all coastal regions of the Union. The complexity of administrative procedures for customs authorisations, which causes a halt at ports, represents a major obstacle to the competitiveness of coastal navigation and the efficiency of Union ports. The Connecting Europe Facility allows ports in the trans-European transport network to benefit from Union subsidies during the current period from 2014 to 2020. Furthermore, the Commission intends to establish a revised framework for state support to ports and, since Directive 2014/23/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council also establishes a new legislative framework for concessions, which will also affect port services provided in accordance with the concession by agreement, strict rules on the transparency of financial flows must be introduced into that Regulation in order to prevent unfair competition between ports in the Union or dumping. I support this proposal to contribute to the modernisation of port services and operations with the aim of efficiency, better interconnectivity and sustainable functioning of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN-T).

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. I support amendments that underline, inter alia, that ports can contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industry on global markets, while increasing the added value and number of jobs in all coastal regions of the Union. In this light, it is therefore essential to simplify administrative procedures for customs clearance, reducing delays in ports, which are often an important obstacle to the competitiveness and efficiency of Union ports.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted against the report, as its main objective is the deregulation and liberalisation of port services. Many reforms are being promoted to reduce costs (with all this to the detriment of workers) and increase competitiveness to attract private investors. The proposals which promote many workers' rights are jeopardised.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The control of the economic and commercial activities of ports which the European Union wants to impose creates more problems in terms of security, workers' rights and the development of its Member States. The ports are managed by the Member States of Europe and they alone should control their exploitation and information about their activity, thus ensuring their economy and national security.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on access to the port services market and the establishment of a framework for financial transparency in ports. European ports make a major contribution to the long-term competitiveness of European industries. That is why I support, in agreement with the Commission's proposal, the creation of a more efficient, connected and sustainable TEN-T. In fact, it is essential to develop a framework that improves the operation of ports and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. It is to be welcomed that the material has played an important role to ensure fair competition between ports, one of which is a clear framework for State aid rules. Among the rapporteur's modifiers, I particularly agree with the additions to the social provisions governing the port labour law system, with which it stands for workers' rights, such as improved training and safety conditions.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation will provide stability and legal certainty for the whole sector for the next decades, ensuring growth and job creation. The new framework should boost the efficiency and strengthen competitiveness of maritime ports of the trans-European transport network, whilst taking into account the specific situation of ports located in outermost regions. The agreed text provides that social and labour rules would not be affected by the Regulation and that port workers should receive adequate information about their working conditions. It also invites the EU-level Sectoral Social Dialogue Committee for Ports to develop guidelines regarding training requirements to prevent accidents and ensure the highest level of safety and health for port workers. Furthermore, the report secures the right to strike, stating that industrial action does not constitute grounds for taking emergency measures  The Regulation also approved financial transparency provisions that would ensure fair competition and prevent price abuse, in particular when services are not subject to effective competition.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: I am in favour of the Commission's proposal in many respects, particularly with regard to financial transparency, but nevertheless wish to propose a number of amendments aimed at improving it. Only port services offered directly to the user should fall within the scope of the Regulation. Dredging is therefore excluded, since it is not a service offered directly to the user, but rather a maintenance task designed to maintain access to the port.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Regulation seeks to create a framework for the TEN-T ports to improve their performance and better cope with changes and transport and logistics requirements. The text is made up of two chapters, one setting up the rules for access to port services, and one to supervise the financial transparency. I particularly welcome the provisions relating to financial transparency, which, I believe, should aim to promote fair competition between European ports, although a certain flexibility is left to the national authorities concerning the rules on the market access of services.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this final agreement between Parliament and the Council. I congratulate the rapporteur, my Socialist colleague Knut Fleckenstein, for having succeeded in imposing the progressive red lines of the European Parliament. Minimum requirements will be imposed on port service providers. In this context, Member States will be able to raise the level of requirements such as that of the national flag for towing and lamanage service providers. This is a step forward, supported by trade unions, that avoids the threat of unbridled competition by providers operating under flags of convenience that undermine workers' rights. The possibility of limiting the number of port service providers on a number of grounds such as scarcity of the sea surface, the characteristics of port traffic and the environmental conditions of the port also represents a new protection. The possibility of imposing public service and personnel transfer obligations in the event of a change of service provider, the possibility of resorting to internal operators, and the possibility of excluding handling and pilotage services from the liberalization provisions are also victories. Finally, the text provides for financial transparency obligations, which represent a substantial step forward.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the “Motion for a resolution on access to port services market and financial transparency of ports”, as it contributes to better use of public funds and the appropriate application of competition rules, as well as modernization of port services and operations. In accordance with this Regulation, the activities listed in the Commission Communication entitled 'Ports: engine of growth' should also be implemented as ports increase the value and number of jobs in the coastal regions of the European Union. It is also necessary to simplify the administrative procedures for customs approvals in order to reduce downtime at ports. The aim is to remove restrictions on the freedom to provide services in the Union, which is one of the symbols of the community itself, as stated in Article 56. Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - I supported the Regulation creating a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports, which aims to contribute to the objective of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of the Trans-European Road Network. I believe that this proposal will modernise port services and operations and create framework conditions for attracting investment in ports. In particular, I support the part introducing the possibility of an exemption in order to avoid unnecessary administrative burdens on those seaports whose annual turnover does not justify the full application of this Regulation. This will avoid an approach according to which one rule fits all and thus ensures fair competition in the port services sector and a competitive market. In addition, I believe that automation and technological innovation will open up an opportunity to improve port efficiency and security.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. The Commission proposal aims to contribute to the overall objective of a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T network by creating a framework that improves the capacity of all ports and helps them cope with changing transport and logistics requirements. The desire is to update the ports and create conditions that will attract investment in them and increase their service.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am disappointed with the outcome of this compromise at the end of trilogue negotiations because in the end the status quo in the port system in my country, Catalonia, won’t change. In fact with this outcome, Spain like other Member States can and will maintain its centralised system of port management, avoiding therefore fair competition among ports in Spain. This absence of real change, real reform, will be to the detriment of competition: therefore no reduction of prices for consumers, the companies using the ports. The result is less efficiency in port management as there is no autonomy de facto.  The port of Barcelona would very much like to compete with other ports of the Mediterranean and of northern Europe on an equal footing. With the current regulations, it is impossible. The port of Barcelona is already connected and chosen as part of the core network in the TEN-T program. It could really become a gateway for the European single market but Spain will never allow it, it will never give it real autonomy. The centralised system in Spain is constructed with disguised State Aid to non-efficient ports.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — Once again, States are forced to liberalize their services. This proposal for a regulation is certainly only the first step towards an even wider liberalisation which will only benefit multinationals, certainly not to port and maritime workers, and European employees and consumers as a whole. I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission's proposal aims to contribute to a more efficient, connected and sustainable operation of the TEN-T by developing a framework that improves the operation of ports and helps them adapt to changed transport and logistical requirements. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on port services began with a liberalising proposal by the European Commission with which we are deeply against. However, during the negotiations, the proposal was reversed, the liberalization clauses were omitted and the rights of dockworkers were protected. This is a satisfactory result that we usually do not see in the reforms of European transport legislation. However, I have decided to abstain, because the final wording calls for the promotion of decentralized port management while, in an eminently maritime country such as ours, centralized management of the port network is one of the key elements of the system. Although in no case does this decentralisation take place compulsory, we wanted to be consistent with our position to defend the ability of each Member State to choose its own public management model, in accordance with its trajectory and its specificities.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report because although its supporters hail the proposal to bring financial transparency to port service provision, this is only true for some smaller ports in southern Member States. The new rules will not bring change to the existing structures in bigger and northern ports.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation aims to increase transparency in the financial relationship between the State, ports and their service operators. The text makes it possible for the organization of port services to be subject to minimum requirements for their provision, limitation on the number of suppliers, public service obligations and other restrictions relating to internal operators. With regard to the challenges faced by labour relations in ports, it is committed to jointly developing provisions that improve from workers' conditions to environmental health issues or the required professional qualifications. Its ultimate goal is, in general, to remove restrictions on the provision of port services and to increase transparency in port financing. Since the belief that this regulation will contribute to a better use of public funds and to a fairer and more effective application of the Union's competition rules in ports, I voted in the affirmative.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Despite the Commission's intention to use this legislative initiative to liberalise and privatize the European port sector, the negotiations between Parliament and the Member States have enabled the text to become, on the contrary, a mechanism for preserving working conditions in the sector and strengthening its rights to collective bargaining or in the event of transfer of the operator service. However, some of its provisions could be used to fragment the public management of the port system by accounting separately those segments that could be open to private competition. Considering the text as a whole, I chose to abstain.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this transparency regulation which introduces a legal framework allowing, but not requiring, Member States and port management bodies to impose certain minimum requirements, including insistence on compliance with social and labour law, as well as safety, security and environmental sustainability.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: I voted in favour because ports can contribute to the long-term competitiveness of European industry on the world market while creating jobs in all coastal regions of the Union.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Under the cover of a modernization of services and operations, the liberalization and privatization of another strategic sector of the economy is the port sector. Promises have already seen them in relation to other sectors: to capture investments, greater efficiency, better quality. We know well what they mean, denying that they are, without appeal or harm, by reality. This proposal falls far short of what was the European Commission's initial ambitions. A retreat forced by the struggle, by the resistance of the workers. However, the proposal does not fail to point a way. A negative and urgent path that must be fought.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The aim of the Commission's proposal is to contribute to a more efficient, more interconnected and sustainable functioning of the trans-European transport network by establishing a framework within which all ports can improve their performance and adapt to the changing requirements in transport and logistics ( TEN-V). The main objectives of the proposal include the modernisation of port services and port operations and the creation of an attractive framework for investment in ports. The Commission intends to use this Regulation to counteract weak competitive pressure and potential market abuse in order to increase the efficiency of port services. The social legislation on the labour regulations of ports has been substantially excluded from this Regulation and will be discussed by the Sectoral Social Dialogue Committee for Ports at EU level, which started its work on 19 June 2013. Nevertheless, the rapporteur considers it important to take a clear stand against irregular employment and for better training and better safety conditions. Compliance with national social standards has been added as a minimum criterion. In addition, Member States should ensure the rights of workers in the event of transfer of undertakings or establishments. For these reasons, I supported the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission's proposal for a new Port Services Regulation did not sufficiently recognise the complexity and diversity of the EU's port sector. However, after negotiation and campaigning since 2013, the European Parliament has managed to secure some limited improvements, including respecting employment and trade union rights. The continuing success of the UK ports industry is vital to the country and there are major challenges ahead in the light of the Brexit vote. Labour MEPs will continue to work actively to support our ports and all who work in them.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that ports are a very important contribution to the long-term competitiveness of European industries in world markets. Moreover, ports are great providers of jobs in all European coastal regions. I believe that delays at ports represent a major obstacle to the competitiveness and efficiency of short sea shipping at Union ports and this is often due to the complexity of administrative procedures for customs clearance. So a big economic advantage for ports could be achieved with a simplification of customs procedures. I support the use of a risk-based policy approach in order to avoid distortion of competition. I agree that a single system is not appropriate for the organisation of port services because this system is very diverse and includes many different models.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation establishing a framework for market access for port services and financial transparency of ports. This legislation was proposed in 2013 by the European Commission and will apply to all European ports within the TEN-T network. Although the negotiations on this regulation were not easy, and several trialogues were needed in order to reach the final text within the Dutch and Slovak Presidencies, I think that the agreed text will bring a number of benefits to port users. For me, the reason for voting in favour was also enhanced financial transparency.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the creation of a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. The proposed regulation seeks to adopt a clear framework for access to the port services market and common rules on financial transparency and compensation applicable to port service providers. There are more than 1200 seaports in Europe. Port activities represent up to 3 million (direct and indirect) jobs in 22 maritime Member States. 96% of all cargo and 93% of passengers pass through EU transit ports, and 319 ports are set out by the Commission's proposal for Trans-European Transport Network Guidelines (TEN-T). The aim of this Regulation is to contribute to a more efficient, interconnected and sustainable functioning of TEN-T by creating a framework that improves the performance of all ports and helps them cope with changes in transport and logistical requirements. In addition, the estimated application of these regulations will save €10 billion by 2030 and ensure the development of coastal navigation, reducing road thickening and job creation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for access to the port services market and financial transparency of ports. I support the purpose of the proposal for a regulation which is to increase the transparency of the financial relationship between the State, ports and port service providers. I believe this will contribute to better use of public funds and to more consistent compliance with EU competition law rules.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted against the proposed candidate because it is inadmissible that there is no real fight for an equal presence of men and women in the different European institutions. The present candidate for the Court of Auditors is once again a man, who, regardless of his qualifications and abilities, was part of a body almost entirely composed of men. The European institutions must set an example to society as a whole in order to combat the reality of glass ceilings, and that is why I have decided to vote against this candidate.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe all Members of the Court of Auditors should be both experts and politically neutral. The appointment of Juhan Parts is clearly a political appointment given his extremely pro-EU stance and work to bring Estonia into the EU. I have concerns over his ability to find and report errors and irregularities within EU finances so I therefore voted against.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of appointing Juhan Parts as a Member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: Juhan Parts is an experienced and probably competent man, but my policy has always been to abstain on such applications except in two types of cases: whether there is a proven conflict of interest or that the candidate is an expert recognized for his impartiality and not a political figure. In any event, Parliament's final vote does not necessarily have an impact on the appointment, since it is the will of the government of the candidate's country that prevails, in this case Estonia.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — Following the recommendation of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I approved the appointment of Mr Parts as a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ The Court of Auditors is an important European institution that plays the role of external and independent auditor of the Union's accounts. Founded in 1977, it became a full EU institution only in 1993 while continuing to provide support for the improvement of the management of the Community budget. It consists of one member for each state of the Union, each of them being appointed by the Council after consulting Parliament remaining in office for six years. On this occasion, Parliament was called to speak out on the appointment of Juhan Parts. Taking note of the contents of the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control and following the guidance of my political group, S&D, I voted a secret vote on the proposed name.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against given the candidate's conservative political orientation, his lack of vocational training for office, because a woman was not chosen — in a context of absence of gender balance — and the lack of neutrality she has shown in the various interviews, for a position where it is necessary to offer a profile of professional training, international experience and independence.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors, Mr Juhan Parts, who has shown his competence to qualify for office. Too bad there are no more women in the Court of Auditors.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I do not question the professional skills of this candidate, but I do not have sufficient assessment elements to give him full support. That's why I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - This morning the plenary of the European Parliament voted, by secret ballot, in which I participated, the proposal for the appointment of Juhan Parts as a member of the Court of Auditors following the assessment of the candidate's qualifications and the hearing held on 5 December last before the Control Committee Budgetary and the favourable opinion given.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which proposes that Juhan Parts be appointed as a Member of the Court of Auditors. The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control assessed the qualifications of the proposed candidate and during 5 December 2016. The meeting of the Committee on Budgetary Control was held by this candidate. Thus, Parliament gives a positive opinion on the Council's proposal to appoint Juhan Parts as a Member of the Court of Auditors. For his part, the candidate stressed that the standard of effectiveness of performance audits should be changes in the real environment, a real problem solution, and not a number of proposals adopted and applied in practice. It is in mind that the success of the auditor and the audited body is not assessed on the basis of the recommendations adopted and executed. So quickly comes to a situation where mutually comfortable offers are presented. In many cases, it is necessary to put an end to the executive routine properly and in such situations the understanding and support of the European Parliament is crucial. In order for operational audits to be effective, it is necessary to have a partner with an interest in addressing the problems raised by those audits. The Committee on Budgetary Control is the excellent partner of There can be no doubt that your committee is controlling all executive actions in the most literal sense. It is also necessary for the audited body (in this case the Commission) to be aware of the nature of the problems and to take substantive action to remedy the situation.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the appointment of a member of the Court of Auditors Juhan Parts.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: This candidacy for the post of member of the Court of Auditors comes from a rather conservative political figure opposed to Russia's influence in his own country. On the other hand, it is in favour of European integration. With regard to a personal candidacy supported by his own Government, I will take a certain reservation on this issue. So I abstained.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ We believe that Juhan Parts has all the qualities and skills necessary to fill the role to which it is designated, assuming the burdens and honours that such acceptance entails.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the appointment of former Estonian Minister Juhan Parts as a member of the Court of Auditors. In his career he gained a fair amount of professional experience in the field of public finance, budget planning, management control and audit. As Deputy Secretary-General to the Ministry of Justice (1992—1998) he was responsible for directing justice at civil service level. This responsibility included the creation of judicial institutions and the preparation, reporting and monitoring of related budgets. Later, as a member of the Estonian Court of Auditors (1998—2002) he was responsible for external audit duties in Estonia. The main task during that period was to transform the Court of Auditors into a modern and effective auditing organisation that complied with international auditing standards (for financial controls, compliance checks and management controls). That is why I voted in favour of his nomination.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this nomination on the grounds that Mr Parts was a member of the board of the Estonian Privatisation Agency and was responsible for the mass privatisation of industries and services in the early 1990s. He therefore has no adequate background or experience for being a member of the Court of Auditors.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against appointing Juhan Parts becoming a member of the Court of Auditors for Estonia. UKIP believes that Members of the Court of Auditors should be independent experts and not political appointments. Juhan Parts is a sitting MP in the Estonian Parliament and was formerly the Prime Minister of Estonia. As Prime Minister, he took Estonia into the EU, which shows this is a political appointment. He is a pro-EU politician whom we cannot trust to criticise, uncover and expose the fraud and waste in the EU budget.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Reviewing, once again, the lack of a certain “gender equality” in the candidates presented in 2016, all men, I voted against the nomination of the Estonian candidate who, moreover, presents a purely political curriculum. I strongly believe that the Member States and the Council should give a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and at all levels.
