name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the appointment of Juhan Parts as a member of the Court of Auditors because I believe that it meets the qualifications for this function. For the last 25 years, Mr Parts has worked continuously in various public offices, thus contributing to the establishment of the institutions of the modern Estonian state. Since 1992, he has served in the Ministry of Justice of Estonia as Deputy Secretary-General. He became Auditor General in 1998 and was Prime Minister during Estonia's accession to the EU. Subsequently, he became Minister of Economy and Communications, where he was responsible for managing public funds and reporting and auditing. During his time at the Ministry of Justice, he was also responsible for setting up judicial institutions, accounting and monitoring their budgets. As a member of the board of directors of the Estonian Privatisation Agency, he participated in the restructuring of virtually all state-owned enterprises. And during his time as State Auditor, he was responsible for external audit duties in Estonia. During this period, he also tried to cooperate with the European Court of Auditors, as, for the first time, Estonia was able to benefit from various funds provided by the European Union. In the light of the experience presented, I believe that Mr Parts will be a beneficial member of the Court of Auditors.

text: The Court of Auditors (ECA) acts as a collegiate body of 28 Members, one from each member state. Its members shall be appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament for a renewable term of six years. The post of Estonian auditor will expire soon, a candidate was proposed by the Estonian government and then by the Council. The appointment of the Estonian candidate was adopted with the votes against of GUE/NGL, some greens and EFDD. We are voting against because there is a gender imbalance in the ECA that needs to be addressed. In addition, the candidate is drawn from the ranks or conservative political parties in power, further biasing the political vision of this body. This candidate has proved to be an enthusiastic supporter of privatization of all public goods, which certainly jeopardizes his ability to be an objective fiscal in analysing the spending of public funds on public or public/private projects.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the appointment of Juhan Parts, former Estonian Prime Minister and Economics Minister, to the European Court of Auditors. Mr Parts has extensive experience and he gave a strong performance in his committee meeting.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ It was necessary to appoint a new member of the Court of Auditors. The procedure provides that members of the Court of Auditors are chosen from persons who are or have been a member, in their respective states, the institutions of external control or who have a qualification Specifies for this function and that they must offer all guarantees of independence. After consulting the non-binding European Parliament, the Council shall adopt the list of members, on a proposal submitted by each Member State. The Estonian candidate, currently Member of the Estonian Parliament, presents a purely political curriculum. That is why I saw fit to vote against it. There also remains a lack of a certain “gender equality” in candidates submitted in 2016. The Court of Auditors already has a rather marked imbalance and I believe that the Member States and the Council should give a signal to promote gender equality in all institutions and all the levels. It should also be remembered that Parliament's vote is not binding and this has created frictions between Parliament and the Council in the past. In fact, there is no real democratic control in the choice of the candidate and the nomination is also in purely “political” practice.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for Mr Parts to be a new Member of the European Court of Auditors because I consider him to be a person with substantial professional experience and a person of high integrity that will greatly contribute to his role as a supervisor of the transparency and regularity in the EU spending. In his career, Mr Parts has been Estonian Prime Minister, Auditor General and Minister of Economy and Communications, giving him a satisfactory knowledge in public finance and budgetary planning and implementation, and qualifying him for his new role as a Member of ECA. Mr Parts has committed to work closely with the European Parliament and I am looking forward to seeing his added value in his new role.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported the appointment of Mr Juhan Parts as a member of the Court of Auditors. Mr Parts was appointed by the Estonian Government and his work experience, as he served as the top auditor in Estonia, was prime minister, as well as minister for economics and communications and personal qualities, convinced MEPs even during the hearing on day 5. 12. 2016.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - Mr. Juhan Parts' previous experience speaks positively about his professional work and activities. That he was the country's prime minister when Estonia entered the European Union makes it clear he is a man who values and respects European values. Amid the security challenges facing the whole of Europe, it is important to point out that Mr Parts led Estonia and on his way to NATO. He is clearly designated as a person who is against any kind of fraud and corruption, which is necessary for someone who is pretending to be a member of such a distinguished court as the Court of Auditors. His international experience instills us with confidence that he will very easily cooperate in a collective with other members of the Court. All these facts speak about how it is a quality person who is ready to work honorably and devotedly on every task entrusted to him.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ After the liquidation of the former ECSC, a liquidation mechanism was established which is still in use now. The subject of the report is precisely the following mechanism, to which some changes are made. However, these are funds for research in the field of coal and steel, which are two very sensitive areas with regard to the environmental aspect. For example, for steel processing in Europe there are completely out of normal plants that should be dismantled. The same thing applies to coal, which also adds respect for European climate policies. These are the motivations that prompted me to cast a negative vote.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the FICA (Coal and Steel Research Fund) is an important programme for making the coal and steel industries cleaner and more efficient. The FICA programme allocates around EUR 50 million annually in funding for R&D and innovation for the coal and steel sectors. The new legal framework of 'Horizon 2020', the Union's research and innovation programme (2014-2020), requires a revision of the multiannual guidelines for the FICA. In this way, this FICA review of programme management rules harmonises the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020 in order to facilitate the participation of the same beneficiaries in both programmes (FICA and Horizon 2020). In addition, it has been intended that the programme can finance research activities in the field of bioindustry for the capture and management of C02 from coal, helping and supporting the sustainability of the sector and the economy of the regions living from the exploitation of these materials.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I decided to vote in favour of this report on the approval of the Research Programme of the Coal and Steel Research Fund, because this amendment is an improvement in its operating rules. This research fund is a fundamental tool for the long-term operation and viability of the coal and steel industries. The present report includes arrangements for assessing and continuing projects developed with funding from the fund. I believe that both industries are essential for industrial activity and the energy transition of our production model, and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFTF). The programme shall be financed from the remaining assets of the European Coal and Steel Community that are no longer operational. The RFTF brings together industry partners, top research centres and universities across the European Union to develop knowledge and innovation in this field. The funded research shall cover production processes, the use and conservation of resources, the improvement of the state of the environment and safety at work in the relevant sectors. I voted in favour, in support of the objective of this proposal, which is to amend its legal basis following a periodic evaluation of the rules for administering the programme in order to achieve the following objectives: (1) to facilitate access to funding by simplifying the rules and in proportion to the rules of Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research; (2) ensure that the Commission administers the Programme while guaranteeing transparency. The Commission is proposing amendments aimed at determining more precisely the status of experts appointed by the Commission as members of the advisory and technical groups established on the legal basis of the ERDF programme in order to avoid conflicts of interest.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: On 18 April 1951 the Treaty of Paris, which established the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), was signed. Entered into force on 23 July 1952 and scheduled for a period of 50 years, it expired on 23 July 2002. The remaining assets of the old ECSC were then transferred to a new Coal and Steel Research Fund (FRCA), which provides approximately EUR 50 million in research and development funding each year for the coal (27.2%) and steel (72.8%) sectors. While the European steel industry is in a particularly critical situation, the European Commission text believes that “the FRCA has achieved its objective of supporting competitiveness”. Obviously, under the pretext of 'facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries' ('simplification', 'transparency', 'harmonisation'), the text aims above all to give the EC full powers to finally “manage the FRCA programme alone”. For this reason, I voted against the Commission proposal and abstained on Parliament's motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation will hand over more powers to the EU and increase interference in an area that should be controlled by EU Member States. This report also comes with financial implications that will cost British taxpayers more money whilst we remain in the EU. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I have decided to speak for this report because I am in favour of further research in the fields of coal and steel. These two areas are of strategic and historical importance for the European Union, originally built from them. In fact, I am in favour of the adoption of the Coal and Steel Research Fund's research programme, which will facilitate access to financing, as well as the proportional harmonization of the rules with the general Horizon 2020 research programme.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal amending Decision 2008/376/EC concerning the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and the adoption of multiannual technical guidelines for that programme. The objective of the Commission proposal is to amend its legal basis following a periodic evaluation of the rules for administering the programme in order to achieve the following tasks: 1. to facilitate access to funding for beneficiaries by simplifying the rules and proportionately aligning them with the rules of the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research, with which stakeholders in the coal and steel sectors are familiar; 2. ensure that the Commission administers the programme by ensuring appropriate transparency and in accordance with the Commission's rules on expert groups. This includes updating the relevant provisions of the legal basis, in particular those relating to the committee procedure.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the Commission's proposal because, claiming 'facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries' of FRCA subsidies ('simplification', 'transparency', 'harmonisation'), it aims above all to give the Commission full powers to finally 'manage the programme alone. ' In other words, this text would give ever more responsibility to unelected bureaucrats who, by ideology (alliance of financial ultra-liberalism and the ayatollahs of ecology), failed to protect our coal and steel industries, even though China was automatically granted on 11 December 2016 the precious “status of economy” in accordance with Article 15 of the Protocols to its admission to the WTO 15 years earlier. However, I abstained on the more measured motion for a resolution, because France must protect its metallurgical industry, and therefore steel, but let us not forget that it is mainly Germany and Poland who have an interest in defending coal, not us.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I endorsed this report, which proposes approval of the research programme of the Coal and Steel Research Fund with amendments calling for preference also to be given to projects that address the impact of mining operations on the employment of workers and the local community and on health and safety workers and the local community.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to ensure that the Fund's legal basis is adequately changed, following the periodic evaluation of its management rules.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Parliament's amendments to the Commission proposal improve the initial text on transparency of consultative groups, SMEs access to the Fund and, above all, the working conditions of workers in the steel and coal sector. However, the purpose of the Fund is to ensure the long-term viability of a highly polluting sector, without proposing alternatives to the production model and, therefore, to propose labour alternatives for workers affected by the closure of their enterprises. That is why I abstain.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the Research Programme of the Coal and Steel Research Fund. I supported the evaluation of the completed projects, in particular with regard to subsequent support measures aimed at ensuring the continuity and long-term viability of steel production in the areas concerned.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on the proposal for a Council Decision amending Decision 2008/376/EC on the adoption of the research programme of the Coal and Steel Research Fund and the multiannual technical guidelines for that programme. Indeed, under the guise of “facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries” of the Coal and Steel Research Fund (FRCA), the text will give full powers to the European Commission, which will manage the FRCA programme alone. We must not give more power to the illegitimate eurocracy that has sold our coal and steel industries... while China was automatically granted on 11.12.2016 the precious “market economy status”, in accordance with Article 15 of the Protocols of its admission to the WTO on 11.12.2001... The European Union is a political powerlessness and economic.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The report being voted has unclear passages which could open to future issues, so I decided to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the FICA (Coal and Steel Research Fund) is an important programme for making the coal and steel industries cleaner and more efficient. The FICA programme allocates around EUR 50 million annually in funding for R&D and innovation for the coal and steel sectors. The new legal framework of 'Horizon 2020', the Union's research and innovation programme (2014-2020), requires a revision of the multiannual guidelines for the FICA. In this way, this FICA review of programme management rules harmonises the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020 in order to facilitate the participation of the same beneficiaries in both programmes (FICA and Horizon 2020). In addition, it has been intended that the programme can finance research activities in the field of bioindustry for the capture and management of C02 from coal, helping and supporting the sustainability of the sector and the economy of the regions living from the exploitation of these materials.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. The European Union has been supporting coal and steel research for more than 50 years. This started with the signing of the Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) in 1951. When this agreement expired in 2002, it was decided to transfer the ECSC assets (and related interest) to the Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFTF). The programme shall be financed by funds derived from the remaining (discontinued) assets of the ECSC. It shall be administered by the Commission. The APMTF complements Horizon 2020, but is not managed under this programme. Around 50 million are allocated to both coal and steel sectors. EUR (72.8% for the steel sector and 27.2% for the coal sector). It brings together industrial partners, SMEs, best research centres and universities across the European Union to develop knowledge and innovation. The funded research shall cover production processes, the use and conservation of resources, the improvement of the state of the environment and safety at work in the relevant sectors. The Commission proposes to facilitate access to funding for beneficiaries by simplifying the rules and proportionately aligning them with the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme, which are familiar with stakeholders in the coal and steel sectors.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community expired in 2012. Subsequently, the Member States decided to set up a research fund to promote innovation in the coal and steel industry to replace the treaty. The fund contributes around €50 billion a year to innovation, benefiting both industrial companies, small businesses and research institutions. Since the setting up of the fund, support priorities have not changed significantly, but the operation of the system has shown in practice the need for further fine-tuning. Horizon 2020 research and development programme, which was introduced later, also provides funding for innovators. The coordination of the two programmes is essential for efficient operation. Accordingly, the two main objectives of this proposal are to harmonise the operation of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and Horizon 2020 in terms of financing, control and management processes. In Hungary, both the coal and steel industries have significant traditions. Domestic lignite production remains one of the most important pillars of security of supply in the electricity market. It is important that knowledge accumulated in industries is not lost and, adapting to the changed economic and technological environment, be able to up-to-date support the country's economy and competitiveness.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the legislative resolution on the coal and steel research fund because the proposal for a decision does not open any room towards a different use of that fund, than the context current industrial makes it more and more necessary. The coal and steel research fund should today help solve the industrial problems that the EU has been dragging on for decades. The 5 Star Movement calls for a rethink of the general approach: the 2002 scenario, of the ECSC liquidation, no longer holds, it cannot be continued with “business as usual”. Even within the current legal constraints on fund management, we believe research should send a clear signal for these industries. For steel, the social and environmental impact, both on workers and local communities: totally out of normal plants must no longer be subject to official aid in Europe, much less for research; their only rational horizon is dismantling. For coal, there is added respect for climate policy goals to these concerns. The M5S would have wanted a more thorough discussion of the proceeds resulting from liquidation and calls for bold use of the same to ensure that they really contribute to solving problems by now old date.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report on the Research Fund for Coal and Steel Research Programme, which aims to facilitate access to funding, ensure transparency and alignment with Commission regulations on expert groups.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is to give the Commission full authority to manage the FRCA programme alone and to create more liberalism and environmental constraints. So far, these technocratic policies have not helped protect our coal and steel industries, while, at the same time, China was granted market economy status in the WTO, making them even more fragile. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, while voting against any aspects that would be detrimental to the environment.  The report makes improvements to the Commission's original proposal with amendments seeking a just transition for the social conditions for workers in closed-down steel/coal production facilities, a focus on technologies to improve emissions output and a higher level of transparency and increased inclusion of civil society groups in the Commission expert groups which decide technical issues that often have important climate impacts.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: On 9 May 1950 Robert Schuman gave the famous speech which would lead the following year to the creation of the ECSC (European Coal and Steel Community). Europe has since supported research in the field, resource sharing and knowledge exchange. The assets and related interests of the ECSC, which ended in 2002, were included in a specific research fund on the sector which produces funding of around EUR 50 million each year with a breakdown 72.8% for steel and 27.2% for coal. It brings together university, industrial, SMEs and public institutions partners. Today we need to find the most appropriate formula from a legal point of view to allow the fund's activities to continue, supporting research in the field and directing it fairly and effectively.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. — The Coal and Steel Research Fund finances €50 million for research and development programmes in the coal (27.2%) and steel (72.8%) sectors. The legal basis establishing the rules governing the management and operation of this fund was adopted by the Council in 2003 and provides for a systematic periodic reassessment. This report uses transparency and simplification in favour of beneficiaries as a pretext to transfer more powers to the European Commission in managing the fund. These same Brussels technocrats who have failed to protect our steel industry currently facing serious difficulties because of unfair competition in China, drifficulted which risk reaching their peak with the granting of market economy status to the Middle Empire. It is more than time to protect our industries from all the winds of wild globalization, including through intelligent protectionism and economic patriotism. However, I abstained on this text, which keeps the budget at a fund for research and development in the steel and coal sectors.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - For a longer period of time, the EU has provided support for research in coal and steel, which began with the signing of the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community, and after the Treaty expired, work has gone under a fund of research managed by the Commission. The research fund is complementary to but managed outside Horizon 2020, providing around €50 million annually for research, development and innovation funding, both in the steel and coal sectors, bringing together industrial partners, SMEs, major research centres and universities across the EU, aiming to develop knowledge and stimulate innovation in the sector. I voted in favour of the report on the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel because I believe that the development of research and innovation in these EU sectors is very beneficial.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the FICA (Coal and Steel Research Fund) is an important programme for making the coal and steel industries cleaner and more efficient. The FICA programme allocates around EUR 50 million annually in funding for R&D and innovation for the coal and steel sectors. The new legal framework of 'Horizon 2020', the Union's research and innovation programme (2014-2020), requires a revision of the multiannual guidelines for the FICA. In this way, this FICA review of programme management rules harmonises the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020 in order to facilitate the participation of the same beneficiaries in both programmes (FICA and Horizon 2020). In addition, it has been intended that the programme can finance research activities in the field of bioindustry for the capture and management of C02 from coal, helping and supporting the sustainability of the sector and the economy of the regions living from the exploitation of these materials.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report which aligns the rules of the 'coal and steel research fund' and those of Horizon 2020, changing the legal basis. The coal and steel research fund is complementary to the Horizon 2020 programme and is run independently of it. Each year it provides around EUR 50 million of funding in research and development and innovation in both the coal and steel sectors (with a breakdown of 72.8% for steel and 27.2% for the coal). The purpose of the change is to facilitate access to funding through simplified rules and proportionate alignment with the rules of the general research programme “Horizon 2020". In addition, this amendment will ensure that the programme is managed by the Commission with proper transparency and in line with Commission rules concerning expert groups.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the research fund for coal and steel. This report makes improvements to an original proposal with amendments seeking a just transition for the social conditions for workers in closed-down steel/coal production facilities, a focus on technologies to improve emissions output and a higher level of transparency. It also provides for increased inclusion of civil society groups in the Commission expert groups, which decide on technical issues, often having important impacts on the climate.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the legislative report on the adoption of the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. We are against the financial implication of this EU programme and we believe that research in this field can be efficiently achieved at a national level.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to amend the legal basis of the research programme dedicated to the coal and steel sectors after periodic assessment of its management rules, with a view to implementing a number of objectives in order to align with the Commission’s rules on expert groups. I believe that only the management rules need updating and that the general scope of the fund is not concerned.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The decision makes slight changes to the now conventional mechanism of use for research projects of the financial proceeds of the funds remaining since the liquidation of the former ECSC in 2002. The funds used annually are approximately EUR 50 million. We are for a rethink of the “business as usual” model, addressing “difficult truths” in these industries. In steel, the social and environmental impact, both on workers and local communities, as they remain in Europe totally out of normal plants and which must no longer be subject to aid official, much less for research. Their only reasonable horizon is dismantling. For coal, the same concerns add respect for climate policy targets. We want a deep discussion about the funds and proceeds from liquidation and courageous use of them so that they really help to solve these inherited problems. For these reasons, together with the M5S delegation, I voted against it.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report and call on the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly, in accordance with Article 293 (2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 106a of the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the adoption of the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for the programme. As I consider this to be a positive research and development effort, I voted in favour.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The report aims to change the legal basis of the coal and steel research fund in order to better comply with the Horizon 2020 programme. In this report, too, it is clear that the European Commission has full powers to manage the fund to the detriment of the Member States. Abstention vote.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Coal and steel are symbolic materials for the Union. It itself derives from what was in the beginning of the ECSC, and these materials have a key role for Europe's global industry. Where it is convinced that this objective is to be achieved and achieved, it is a priority to change the same legal basis as the research programme following the periodic evaluation of its rules of management, I therefore express my favour to this report. It pursues transparent management of the fund through a programme financed directly from the EU general budget and under the responsibility of the Commission, through a review of the relevant rules the skills and composition of advisory and technical groups. They want to inform those concerned about deliberations. Together with this, the changes are also aimed at facilitating access to funding especially for SMEs, through simplified requirements and alignments due to the rules of the research programme General “Horizon 2020". The latter aspect will ensure a deep social responsibility given the worn-out conditions faced by those working in the coal and steel sector.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: The Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS), funded by the remaining assets of the former European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC, whose founding Treaty - 1951 - expired in 2002), supports research and development in the steel (72.8%) and coal (27.2%) sectors at an annual figure of about 50 million euros. I therefore believe that this financial flow should promote innovation in the exploitation of these resources (production, use and conservation), in ensuring environmental sustainability and in the safety of workers. I agree with the concern about the harmonisation of rules, processes and terminologies with Horizon 2020. It is important that the policy of supporting research in the European Union should be coherent and that initiatives should be complementary. I share the intention to clarify the rules on expert groups in order to ensure the highest level of transparency in the management of the RFCS by the Commission. I would remind you that the Commission has already decided on the establishment and operation of expert groups (Decision of 30 May 2016) and that the European Parliament is preparing its position on the subject, and the regulation should therefore be consistent. I therefore support this report.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the legislative report on the adoption of the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. We are against the financial implication of this EU programme and we believe that research in this field can be efficiently achieved at a national level.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to amend the legal basis of the research programme dedicated to the coal and steel sectors after the evaluation periodic of its management rules. It is important to ensure transparent management of a programme financed by the general budget of the EU and under the responsibility of the Commission with the application of the Commission's rules on expert groups.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I have decided to vote in favour of this report on the proposal for the approval of the Research Programme of the Coal and Steel Research Fund, because this amendment is an improvement in its operating rules. This research fund is a fundamental tool for the long-term operation and viability of the coal and steel industries. The present report includes arrangements for assessing and continuing projects developed with funding from the fund. I believe that both industries are essential for industrial activity and the energy transition of our production model, and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Although our group has made numerous efforts to expand the scope of R&D activities and to prioritize research and technological development in this text, the report final features some lights and shadows. In particular, we have tried to push forward a number of measures on the impact on employment of workers and local communities on consumption and emission reduction policies. In addition our battles focused on introducing new support structures to manage job market transitions. Overall, I am voting in favour of this text because we have managed to get steps forward to facilitate access to funding, ensuring due transparency and alignment with the rules of Commission on expert groups.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - For more than 50 years, the EU has supported coal and steel research. This practice began with the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community, signed in 1951. Funded research covers production processes, resource use and conservation, environmental improvements and workplace security in relevant sectors. I voted for facilitating access to finance and for total transparency of the programme.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Community and the EU have been supporting research in the coal and steel industry since the signing of the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) for more than 50 years. At the expiry of the ECSC Treaty, it was decided that the assets of the ECSC should be received by a Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS) and the programme will be managed by the Commission. The RFCS, which complements Horizon 2020, provides EUR 50 million per year for R&D and innovation activities. Funded research shall cover production processes, resource utilisation, environmental improvements and occupational safety in the relevant sectors. The European Commission proposes amendments aimed at avoiding conflicts of interest and clarifying the tasks of experts appointed by the Commission. Parliament is currently preparing a resolution on the monitoring of the register and composition of Commission expert groups, bearing in mind the coherence between the two documents.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a motion to change the legal basis after a periodic assessment of the principles of management of the Coal and Steel Research Fund. The FBWiS programme is a continuation of the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) which expired in 2002. The programme is financed by proceeds from the sale of other assets of the now-defunct ECSC. The Fund provides approximately EUR 50 million annually to fund research and development and innovation in the coal and steel sectors (72.8% for the steel sector and 27.2% for the coal sector). Funded research includes manufacturing processes, resource disposal and protection, environmental improvement and job security in the sectors concerned. The importance of financing is very important in relation to the nature of the Polish raw material economy and the mining sector. This involves the possibility of developing knowledge and promoting innovation in a sector that is very important for Poland.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Research and Development are crucially important for any sector. Nonetheless, for the coal and steel industry I am in favour of a facilitated access to funding while ensuring transparency and alignment with the Commission’s rules on expert groups. The research funded covers very important aspects of this industry, such as production processes, utilisation and conservation of resources, environmental improvements and safety at work in the relevant sectors.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I want to ensure that the coal and steel industry continues to benefit from the funds available under these dedicated research programmes. The fund has seen positive results in bringing together industrial partners, SMEs, leading research centres and universities across the EU and is intended to compliment, not duplicate, Horizon 2020.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This non-legislative report proposes to amend the rules of the research program on the coal and steel sectors. In particular, the report proposes to facilitate access to funding for recipients through simplified rules and to increase transparency in the management of funds. Considering that coal and steel remain strategic sectors of importance for European industry, for which the development of new technologies through research and innovation is a real lever for competitiveness in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the legislative report on the adoption of the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. We are against the financial implication of this EU programme and we believe that research in this field can be efficiently achieved at a national level.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the report on the research program of the Coal and Steel Research Fund. Thus, we strengthen the clarity of the management of this fund and make it easier to access. Each year, the Steel and Coal Research Fund provides around €50 million to stimulate innovation in these two sectors. With this report, we are simplifying the rules on access to finance so that SMEs can benefit more from this fund. We also impose additional guarantees on the transparency of the choice of experts appointed to this fund by aligning the standards with those required for experts at the European Commission.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community expired in 2012. Subsequently, the Member States decided to set up a research fund to promote innovation in the coal and steel industry to replace the treaty. The fund contributes around €50 billion a year to innovation, benefiting both industrial companies, small businesses and research institutions. Since the setting up of the fund, support priorities have not changed significantly, but the operation of the system has shown in practice the need for further fine-tuning. Horizon 2020 research and development programme, which was introduced later, also provides funding for innovators. The coordination of the two programmes is essential for efficient operation. Accordingly, the two main objectives of this proposal are to harmonise the operation of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and Horizon 2020 in terms of financing, control and management processes. In Hungary, both the coal and steel industries have significant traditions. Domestic lignite production remains one of the most important pillars of security of supply in the electricity market. It is important that knowledge accumulated in industries is not lost and, adapting to the changed economic and technological environment, be able to up-to-date support the country's economy and competitiveness.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. The Treaty of Paris establishing the European Coal and Steel Community, which entered into force on 23 July 1952 and was scheduled for a period of 50 years, expired 23 July 2002. The remaining assets of the old ECSC were then transferred to a new Coal and Steel Research Fund (FRCA), in support of coal and steel R&D (EUR 50 million available annually). The FRCA was taken over by the Commission on new legal bases defined in 2003 and needs to be periodically evaluated. At a time when the European steel industry is experiencing a critical situation, particularly in the face of Chinese competition, it is ironic to read that the FRCA would have “achieved its objective of supporting competitiveness”. We cannot endorse this text, which, moreover, gives extended powers to the European Union to the detriment of the Member States.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported Mr Buzek's report on the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel, which proposes to change the regulatory basis of this fund, which was established in 1951 by the conclusion of the Treaty on the European Steel and Coal Community. But in 2002 The treaty expired and Member States decided to transfer the assets of the European Coal and Steel Community to the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. This fund is currently managed by the European Commission and has around €50 million for development and research in sectors related to steel and coal mining, environmental improvement and job safety, etc.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - This proposal was published only a few weeks ago, before the Commission published updated horizontal rules on this issue, which means that a new update will be needed, so this report to be put to the vote is already out of date. In addition, I would like to mention that facilitating the access of companies to the financing of two funds is not necessarily considered to be beneficial.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as the promotion of coal and other fossil fuels with EU funding is not in line with our priorities following the Paris Agreement. Climate change is the biggest threat facing us, and I have worked with Stop Climate Chaos Cymru and others to get stronger international action.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The report establishes the position of the European Parliament for the use of the next research phase of the Coal & Gas Fund. It is important that we continue to conduct essential research for how we can maximize resources and achieve good quality of research. Energy sources of a reasonably controversial kind also need judgment to be revised and examined. This in particular with regard to the Energy Union and the next Energy Package to be dealt with by both the European Parliament and the European Council.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - The EU has been supporting coal and steel research for more than 50 years. The Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS) is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed independently of Horizon 2020. It provides annual funding of approximately €50 million for R&D and innovation in both coal and steel sectors (with a distribution of 72.8% for steel and 27.2% for coal). It brings together industrial partners, SMEs, universities and cutting-edge research centres across the European Union to develop knowledge and promote innovation in the sector. Funded research covers production processes, resource use and conservation, environmental improvements and safety at work in the relevant sectors.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against: under the pretext of 'facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries', the text aims above all to give the EC full powers to direct management of the FRCA programme. In other words, more power has not been enough to protect our coal and steel industries... while China was automatically granted the precious “market economy status” on 11.12.2016.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: The Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was signed in 1951. When the Treaty expired in 2002, it was decided to make the ECSC assets available to a Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS). The Programme is financed from the revenues generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC and is managed by the European Commission. The RFCS is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed independently of Horizon 2020. In any case, the main beneficiaries are known. It provides annual funding of approximately €50 million for R&D and innovation in both coal and steel sectors (with a distribution of 72.8% for steel and 27.2% for coal). It brings together industrial partners, SMEs, universities and cutting-edge research centres (mainly from the main EU powers) to develop knowledge and promote innovation in the sector. Funded research covers production processes, resource use and conservation, environmental improvements and safety at work in the relevant sectors. The report proposes simplifying some rules and improvements in the transparency of RFCS management. Guidelines to which we generally do not oppose.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: ‒ I voted in favour of the following proposal because I agree with the need to change the legal basis for the management rules for the research fund for coal and steel. In fact, I think it is necessary to facilitate access to funding through simplified rules, ensure that the programme is managed by the Commission with due transparency and to facilitate alignment with Rules of the research program “Horizon 2020" with respect to which the research fund for coal and steel is complementary and independent.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The main objective of this proposal is technical changes linked to greater transparency, expertise, independence and funding for research bodies under the control of the European Commission. Despite the efforts of the Socialist and Democrat Group, the European Commission has not proceeded to extend the powers and the subject of examining the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain from the report, it could certainly be done better.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel, as I do not agree with the purpose of this proposal to amend the legal basis.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council Decision amending Decision 2008/376/EC on the adoption of the research programme the coal and steel research fund and the multiannual technical guidelines for that programme, because I am in favour of continuing this programme in support of research, but also of promoting innovative and development processes. I am very pleased with the ability of this program to create a network between small and medium-sized enterprises, research centres and universities, fundamental to production development and beyond. It is also of great importance to the good use and conservation of resources while respecting the field in total safety, especially with regard to the health and safety of workers in the sector. I fully agree with the Commission that it wants to change the legal basis in order to improve access to funding through simpler rules, so as to allow easier access to the program “Horizonte2020" and the research fund for steel and coal. I hope that we can continue to work in this direction to be able to develop new knowledge and promote innovation.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The proposal aims to facilitate access to finance through simplified rules and to align them with the rules of the Horizon 2020 general research programme.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the legislative report on the adoption of the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. I am against the financial implication of this EU programme and I believe that research in this field can be efficiently achieved at a national level.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Parliament's amendments to the Commission proposal improve the initial text on transparency of consultative groups, SMEs access to the Fund and, above all, the working conditions of workers in the steel and coal sector. However, the purpose of the Fund is to ensure the long-term viability of a highly polluting sector, without proposing alternatives to the production model and, therefore, to propose labour alternatives for workers affected by the closure of their enterprises. That is why I abstain.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report intends to simplify the application procedure rules for the Coal and Steel Research Fund by bringing them closer to Horizon 2020. This will encourage research and support SMEs in these sectors, which are severely affected by international competition. I therefore voted in favour of this text in order to be able to update, in good intelligence with Horizon 2020, research and development in two historical sectors that were at the origin of European integration and which must now be modernised.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because I believe that the FICA (Coal and Steel Research Fund) is an important programme for making the coal and steel industries cleaner and more efficient. The FICA programme allocates around EUR 50 million annually in funding for R&D and innovation for the coal and steel sectors. The new legal framework of 'Horizon 2020', the Union's research and innovation programme (2014-2020), requires a revision of the multiannual guidelines for the FICA. In this way, this FICA review of programme management rules harmonises the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020 in order to facilitate the participation of the same beneficiaries in both programmes (FICA and Horizon 2020). In addition, it has been intended that the programme can finance research activities in the field of bioindustry for the capture and management of C02 from coal, helping and supporting the sustainability of the sector and the economy of the regions living from the exploitation of these materials.

text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report as it gives an objective picture of the problems faced by the coal and steel industries, their environmental performance and the safety of workers in these industries. In addition, the planned fund is expected to support the coal and steel industries until more sustainable solutions are found.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported this approach by the Research Fund for Coal and Steel ('RFCS'), which is complementary to Horizon 2020 and which is managed by the Commission. It provides funding for research, development and innovation in both the coal and steel sectors (72.8% of the funds being allocated to the steel sector and 27.2% to the coal sector) with around €50 million annually. Steps have been taken to expand the scope of research and development activities by adding a study of the social impact of restructuring and closing of mines in the coal and metal industries.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted for the Report on the proposal for a Council decision amending Decision 2008/376/EC on the adoption of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for the programme, as the Commission plans to facilitate access to funding and to provide greater transparency, which is extremely important to how the sector would develop even more and encourage innovation. The Research Fund provides 50 million euros for research and development to the coal and steel sector annually. The report I voted for proposes amendments to the fund concerned, which focus on the management rules of the Coal and Steel Research Fund programme, and align it with the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020 in order to facilitate the participation of the same beneficiaries in both programmes.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — Since the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme and for the sake of harmonisation and simplification, the Commission has taken over and managed the Coal and Steel Research Fund. Moreover, it considers that the Fund has fulfilled its competitiveness objectives at a time when the steel industry is in a critical situation. I condemn this ever greater transfer of responsibility to technocrats who are responsible for the slump in our coal and steel industries. So I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Jerzy Buzek's report on the research programme of the Coal and Steel Research Fund. This programme grants financial aid to projects or actions promoting research and development programmes on coal and steel. This text is making changes to facilitate access to finance for SMEs and to enhance the transparency of the programme. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported Mr Buzek's report. The purpose of this proposal is to amend the legal basis following the periodic evaluation of its management rules in order to achieve the following objectives: To facilitate access to finance through simplified rules and proportionate alignment with the rules of the Horizon 2020 comprehensive research programme, with which actors in the coal and steel sectors are familiar. The proposed amendments to the LDCF focus on the management rules of the TECS programme (Chapter III) and align, as far as possible, the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020, so as to facilitate the participation of the same beneficiaries in both programmes (ACC and Horizon 2020). Ensure that the programme is managed by the Commission in due transparency and in accordance with the Commission's rules on expert groups. This includes updating the relevant provisions relating to the legal basis, in particular those relating to comitology.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. The RFCS fund provides significant support to annual R&D investments in the coal and steel sector with around €50 million. It supports activities that bring together partners from industry, SMEs, leading research centres and universities from across the European Union to build knowledge and boost innovation in the sector. The research projects financed include production processes, use and conservation of resources, improvements in environmental protection and safety at work in the sectors concerned. It also calls for greater transparency in line with Commission rules.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to amend the legal basis after the periodic assessment of its management rules, with a view to implementing the objectives of facilitating access to funding, ensuring due transparency and alignment with the Commission’s rules on expert groups.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Coal and steel were two commodities that stood at the birth of the Industrial Revolution in the 18th century. After dramatic exchanges in these two fields over the past 30 years, there has been a radical reduction in coal mining and steel production has seen major changes. For both commodities, a world market has formed, and the failed rather than successful privatisation of the whole sector puts new questions ahead of us. In any case, the use of new coal processing technologies and the introduction of new trends in steel mills is an important part of the future of the industry of the developed countries of the world. The EU certainly cannot be lacking in this area of R&D. In all activities related to mining and modifying both coal and steel production, there is always a social aspect. The effect on employment in some regions is absolutely key. The fundamental environmental impact cannot be doubted and the emissions associated with steel processing and coal utilization are significant in the context of EU environmental policies item. In addition to notorious chemical production, the use of CO2 in agriculture as well as various chemical and biochemical processes can be very interesting. It is important that the European Union, in this area of industrial activities, is minimally in contact with the head of the peloton of solvers.

name: Stelios Κοuloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since our amendments modified the Council decision as a useful way of addressing the challenges that the European steel and coal industries currently are facing. The report stresses the legacy of cooperation in the area of coal and steel which should inspire Member States to act in a spirit of solidarity so as to respond to the current crises.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing. - The Coal and Steel Research Programme has been a well-functioning area since ancient times, measured by EU standards, and its framework has been laid down and shaped for several decades to this day. The report contains amendments to the Council decision, which are largely acceptable because they are justified from environmental protection, safety or other aspects. I note that it would be timely to find the right proportions in environmental protection, putting considerably more weight on preserving and restoring forests in tropical and temperate zones, for example, than juggling with quota trading. Let us not forget that many jobs in the EU have been a victim of the blissful activities of the NGOs funded from the great overwater.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the proposal to adopt the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. The coal and steel sectors are important in the European integration process and play a key role for the entire Union industry. At the same time, working conditions in these sectors are severe and often lead to damage to the health of workers and citizens. Companies should therefore respect all legal requirements regarding social responsibility, propose solutions and minimise the social consequences of the transition or closure of installations.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS) gives funding of over €50 million every year to innovative projects to enhance the safety, efficiency and competitive edge of the EU coal and steel industries. It is important to note that RFCS is complementary to and managed outside the Horizon 2020 programme. RFCS brings together industrial partners, SMEs, leading research centres and universities from across the EU to develop knowledge and foster innovation in the sector with regard to production processes, utilisation and conservation of resources, environmental improvements and safety. However, I do not support the Commission’s proposal for a proportionate alignment of RFCS rules with those of Horizon 2020 because the beneficiaries are the same in both programmes (RFCS and H2020). Therefore there is no real need to amend the legal basis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — For more than 50 years now the EU has supported the coal and steel research fund. Managed by the European Commission, this fund is complementary to Horizon 2020 and provides around EUR 50 million in research, development and innovation funding every year. It is also responsible for grouping industrial partners, SMEs, research centres and universities with the aim of promoting innovation and knowledge in the European Union. The Commission today proposes to amend the legal basis of the research programme, following the periodic assessment of its management rules, and to implement a number of objectives, including that of facilitating access to funding by developing simplified rules and adapting rules to the Horizon 2020 programme; and to ensure transparent and smooth management of the programme by updating provisions in reference to the legal basis. In the light of what I am voting in favour of Mr Buzek's report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on the research program of the Coal and Steel Research Fund. While the European steel industry is in a particularly critical situation, the Commission text considers that “the FRCA has achieved its objective of supporting competitiveness”. Obviously, under the pretext of 'facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries', the text aims above all to give full powers to the European Commission to finally “manage the FRCA programme alone”. In other words, the unelected bureaucrats who, by ideology, have failed to protect our coal and steel industries... while China will be automatically granted on 11.12.2016 the precious “market economy status”, in accordance with Article 15 of the Protocols of its admission to the WTO on 11.12.2001. One more confirmation that, far from allowing the emergence of any Europe-Power, the EU has organised the collective helplessness of the nations of Europe.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because, within the framework of the Union's trade and internal liberalisation policies in the coal and steel sectors, it is necessary to ensure its modernisation and efficiency so that European production can be viable.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: at the expiry in 2002 of the Treaty which marked the beginning of European integration, the ECSC Treaty, its asset was transferred to a Coal and Steel Research Fund (FICA), which seeks to boost knowledge and innovation in the sector. This legislative proposal seeks to amend the legal basis in order to achieve two objectives: on the one hand, to facilitate access to financing with simplified rules and harmonisation of the Horizon 2020 programme and, on the other, to ensure that the programme is managed transparently by the Commission. I voted in favour as these objectives are reflected in this proposal. For example, the amendments to the FICA harmonize procedures for the Horizon 2020 programme so that the same beneficiaries can more easily access both programmes.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted against. I believe that the so-called The Coal and Steel Research Fund is an office that has no justification. The Czech Republic has already had to pay over one billion kroner into it. In my court, it would be best to abolish this EU office.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The EU has been supporting research on coal and steel for more than 50 years, and the expiry of the 2002 Treaty decided to make the assets of the ECSC available to the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. The programme shall be financed by revenue generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC, managed by the Commission. The Coal and Steel Research Fund is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed outside the framework of the programme. The Fund grants €50 million to the coal and steel sector for research and development and innovation, and through it brings together industry partners, SMEs, leading research centres and universities from across Europe. The purpose of this proposal is to amend the legal basis following a periodic assessment of management rules, in order to facilitate access to financing by means of simplified rules and proportionate alignment with the rules of the general research programme “Horizon 2020”. The proposed changes to the Coal and Steel Research Fund focus on the management rules of the Coal and Steel Research Fund programme and align it with the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020. As the objective of this proposal is to ensure the transparent management of the programme funded by the general budget of the EU, I supported this proposal.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament adopt the following amendments to the Commission proposal: research projects to which preference will be given include the following: projects on the impact on the employment of workers and the local community of operations for mining, the impact on the health and safety of workers and of the local community of operations for mining.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a Council decision amending Council Decision 2008/376/EC approving the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on technical guidelines multiannual duration for the programme because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the report on the adoption of the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel because, at this point, and given the context of the energy market, it is important to facilitate access to finance through simplified rules and to align proportional to the “Horizon 2020” rules. I stress the importance of the continuity of this fund based on the former Treaty of the European Coal and Steel Community, which provides around EUR 50 million per year for research and innovation in the coal and steel sectors. This financial instrument must be used to find solutions for modernising energy technologies in the coal and steel sectors and improving energy efficiency, especially in EU Member States with limited budgets and dependent on coal exploitation. Last but not least, I ask the Commission to manage this fund in accordance with the transparency rules on expert groups and to update the provisions on its legal basis as urgently as possible.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. This text concerns the Coal and Steel Research Fund (FRCA), which took over the remaining assets of the former European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC). Management is foreseen in a 2002 text, revised in 2008 and includes periodic and systematic reassessment of the relevance of the programme. However, while the European steel industry is in a particularly critical situation, the Commission text considers that 'the FRCA has achieved its objective of supporting competitiveness', which is why we cannot support this text.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for a Council Decision amending Decision 2008/376/EC on the adoption of the research programme for the coal and steel research fund and technical guidelines For this programme, it is part of the long path which sees the European Union to fund research in coal and steel. I welcomed the Commission's proposal, primarily aimed at facilitating access to available funding and making this research programme consistent with the objectives set out in the general research program “Horizon 2020".

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Today we addressed a report addressing the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. The EU has supported research in coal and steel for more than 50 years. At the very beginning stood the European Coal and Steel Community Treaty (ECSC) signed in 1951. In 2002, when this contract expired, it was decided that the ECSC assets (and related interest) would be released to the Coal and Steel Research Fund (RFSC). The program is funded by revenue generated by the remaining assets of the (defunct) ECSC. It is administered by the Commission. The Coal and Steel Research Fund complements the Horizon 2020 programme and is managed independently of this programme. It provides funding annually for research and development and innovation in the coal and steel sector amounting to about €50 million. The rapporteur has taken the view that, in order to reconcile the rules of the Coal and Steel Research Fund and the rules of Horizon 2020, it is not necessary to change the legal basis, which I completely agree with, so I upvoted the report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because, on the one hand, it calls for greater transparency and, on the other hand, it will give SMEs easier access to RFCS.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I supported the proposals to amend the Council decision on the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. The aim of this proposal is to facilitate access to funding for beneficiaries, to simplify the rules and to align them proportionately with the rules of the Framework Programme for Research.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: The Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was concluded in 1951. At the end of the Treaty in 2002, it was agreed to devote the ECSC assets (and related interest) to the establishment of a Coal and Steel Research Fund (FRCA). Funded research covers production processes, resource use and conservation, environmental improvements and workplace safety in the sectors concerned. The proposal before us aims to facilitate access to finance by simplifying the rules. It also ensures greater transparency between expert groups and relevant stakeholders. The rapporteur also calls for the social partners to be consulted on issues related to social responsibility. I am voting in favour of this text, regretting that environmental aspects are not being put forward further.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: This is a report on the proposal for a Council Decision amending Decision 2008/376/EC on the adoption of the Coal and Steel Research Fund programme and the multiannual technical guidelines. While the European steel industry is already in a dramatic situation, the text aims above all to give full powers to the European Commission to manage the programme alone and to boasts support for competitiveness. Managing this program by ideological technocrats who have failed to protect the coal and steel sectors risks, particularly with China, which was granted market economy status on December 11, 2016, to put its sectors of activity and research a little more at risk. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The FRCA programme provides around EUR 50 million annually for research and development and innovation for the coal and steel sectors. In order to fully play its role, it was essential to enhance transparency in its operations and to facilitate access to funding for beneficiaries. Research and development play a fundamental role in our society, not only from an economic point of view but also because they have a mission to shape the world of tomorrow.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report, which calls for amendment of the legal basis after the periodic assessment of the management rules, with a view to implementing the objectives of facilitating access to funding, ensuring due transparency and alignment with the Commission’s rules on expert groups.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. The Commission proposed to the Council the adoption of a decision adopting the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and amending Decision 2008/376/EC on multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. Before adopting this Decision, the Council should consult Parliament. In its report, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy proposes that Parliament approves the Commission's proposal with ten amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. — While the European steel industry is in a particularly critical situation, the EC text considers that “the FRCA has achieved its objective of supporting competitiveness”. Obviously, under the pretext of 'facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries' ('simplification', 'transparency', 'harmonisation'), the text aims above all to give the Commission full powers to finally manage the programme of the fund alone. In other words, the unelected bureaucrats who, by ideology (alliance of financial ultra-liberalism and ecology), have failed to protect our coal and steel industries... while China will one day be granted the precious “status of a market economy”, in accordance with Article 15 of the protocols of its admission at the WTO on 11.12.2001. One more confirmation that, far from allowing the emergence of any Europe-Power, the EU has organised the collective helplessness of the nations of Europe. Vote against.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. — Under the pretext of 'facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries' ('simplification', 'transparency', 'harmonisation'), this text aims above all to give the EC full powers to finally “manage the FRCA programme alone”. In other words, unelected bureaucrats who, by ideology (alliance of financial ultraliberalism and the ayatollahs of ecology), have failed to protect our coal and steel industries... while China will be automatically granted, on December 11, 2016, the precious “market economy status”, in accordance with Article 15 of the Protocols to its admission to the WTO on 11 December 2001. One more confirmation that, far from allowing the emergence of any Europe-Power, the European Union has organised the collective helplessness of the nations of Europe. This text merely deserves abstention on my part, as it does not address the real problems.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text on the Coal and Steel Research Fund. This fund was established after the expiry of the ECSC Treaty. Managed by the Commission separately and complementary to Horizon 2020, it is financed from the old ECSC assets. It supports R&D on coal (27.2%) and steel (72.8%) each year, amounting to €50 million. The aim was to modify its legal basis in order to facilitate access to its financing, especially for SMEs, as well as to strengthen its transparency.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Research Fund for Coal and Steel was created in 2002, offering funding of over €50 million per year to innovative projects that enhance the safety and efficiency of the EU coal and steel industries. I have voted for his report regarding the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and the multiannual technical guideline for this programme.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it is in favour of the Austrian steel industry, and small and medium-sized enterprises should have easier access to the Research Fund for Coal and Steel.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Amendments to the Regulation are aimed at simplifying funding opportunities under Horizon 2020 and more transparent management of the Research Fund's research programme.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Commission's Research Fund for Coal and Steel was established in 2002 to support the competitiveness of the European coal and steel sectors, based on the legacy left by the Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community. I voted in favour of the report proposing to amend the legal basis of the research programme following the periodic evaluation of the management rules in order to ensure transparent management of a programme financed from the general EU budget and under the responsibility of by applying the Commission's rules on expert groups and facilitating access to funding for beneficiaries, through simplified rules and proportionate alignment with the rules of the Horizon 2020 General Research Programme. It is also important that facilities and companies comply with all legal requirements regarding social responsibility, offer definitive solutions and minimise the social consequences of the transition or closure of facilities.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues proposal because I believe it is necessary to change the legal basis in order to facilitate access to funding by means of simplified rules, both to align with the rules of the research program “Horizon 2020". This research programme must be managed by the Commission with full transparency and in accordance with the Commission's rules on expert groups. These amendments are necessary to enable the Commission to clarify the positions of the experts appointed to participate in the advisory groups and technical groups set up in the light of the programme coal and steel research fund, in such a way as to avoid conflicts of interest. I therefore voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The purpose of this proposal is to amend the legal basis of the research programme dedicated to the coal and steel sectors after the periodic assessment of its management rules with a view to implementing certain objectives. I voted in favour because it will inter alia align the programme with the Commission’s rules on expert groups. I believe it will ensure transparent management of what is a programme funded from the EU general budget.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - Coal and steel sectors are important in the European integration process and play a key role in the overall industrial sector of the Union. In terms of social responsibility, plants and enterprises must respect high legal requirements regarding the health of workers and citizens, but also those social expectations associated with the transition or closure of the plant.
