In this regard, this very significant sector needs to be approached with due diligence and adequately assisted projects that ensure the future of the sector tailored to new needs and challenges. That is why it is necessary to emphasize that the Research Fund for Coal and Steel is complementary to Horizon 2020 and annually provides €50 million for research and development and innovation to sectors. Through it, industry partners, small and medium-sized enterprises, research centres and universities from across Europe are joining together to drive innovation in the sector. Research covers production processes, use and conservation of resources, environmental protection and occupational protection. Access to the financial resources of this fund is necessarily facilitated and simplified.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The Research Fund for Coal and Steel is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed outside the framework of the programme. The Fund grants €50 million annually to coal and steel sectors for research and development and innovation. Through it, industry partners, small and medium-sized enterprises, leading research centres and universities from across Europe join together to develop knowledge and encourage innovation in the sector. I accept the Commission's proposal. The Commission notes that the purpose of the proposal is to amend the legal basis following a periodic assessment of management rules, in order to facilitate access to financing through simplified rules and proportionate alignment with the rules of the general research programme 'Horizon 2020' with which the stakeholders referred to in take note of the coal and steel sectors and to ensure that the Commission manages the programme with appropriate transparency and in accordance with Commission rules on expert groups.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) The Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was signed in 1951. When the Treaty expired in 2002, it was decided to make the ECSC assets available to a Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS). The Programme is financed from the revenues generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC and is managed by the European Commission. The RFCS is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed independently of Horizon 2020. In any case, the main beneficiaries are known. It provides annual funding of approximately €50 million for R&D and innovation in both coal and steel sectors (with a distribution of 72.8% for steel and 27.2% for coal). It brings together industrial partners, SMEs, universities and cutting-edge research centres (mainly from the main EU powers) to develop knowledge and promote innovation in the sector. Funded research covers production processes, resource use and conservation, environmental improvements and safety at work in the relevant sectors. The report proposes simplifying some rules and improvements in the transparency of RFCS management. Guidelines to which we generally do not oppose.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. “According to the Commission, the aim of the proposal is to amend the legal basis after a periodic assessment of the management principles of the Coal and Steel Research Fund (the FBWiS Programme). The European Parliament must be consulted on this occasion. The rapporteur proposes to agree to change the legal basis. The EU supports coal and steel research starting with the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) signed in 1951. When the Treaty expired in 2002, it was decided to make the assets (and accrued interest) available for the purposes of the Coal and Steel Research Fund (the FBWiS Programme). The scheme shall be financed by proceeds from the sale of the remaining assets of the (expired) ECSC. It is managed by the Commission. The FBWiS program complements Horizon 2020 and is managed separately. It provides approximately EUR 50 million annually to fund research and development and innovation in the coal and steel sectors (72.8% for the steel sector and 27.2% for the coal sector). It brings together industrial partners, SMEs, leading research centres and universities from across the European Union around the goal of developing knowledge and promoting innovation in the sector. Funded research includes manufacturing processes, resource disposal and protection, environmental improvement and job security in the sectors concerned. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: The Coal and Steel Research Fund was established after the expiry of the ECSC Treaty. Managed by the Commission separately and complementary to Horizon 2020, it is financed from the old ECSC assets. It supports research, development and innovation on coal and steel each year. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with changing the legal basis of the Fund in order to facilitate access to finance for SMEs but also to increase its transparency. It is essential to encourage research and development in order to improve the competitiveness of European SMEs in the coal and steel industry, which is particularly affected by foreign competition.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: Coal and steel have played an important role on the European Union's agenda for more than six decades, referring to 1951, when the Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was signed. When the Treaty ceased to be in force in 2002, it was decided to make the ECSC assets available to a Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS). The Programme is financed from the revenue generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC and is managed by the Commission. The Commission is now proposing amendments aimed at clarifying the characteristics of experts appointed to participate in advisory groups and technical groups established in accordance with the legal basis of the RFCS Programme in order to avoid any conflicts of interest. This is a relevant step. I support this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the legislative report on the adoption of the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. We are against the financial implication of this EU programme and we believe that research in this field can be efficiently achieved at a national level.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — Having regard to Protocol No 37 on the financial consequences of the expiry of the ECSC Treaty and the Research Fund for Coal and Steel, annexed to the Treaty on European Union and to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and having regard to the report of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy of the European Parliament, I have voted in favour of the report, which called on the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly, in accordance with Article 293 (2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Article 106a of the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Unfortunately, Parliament adopted this very unbalanced text on the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and the multiannual technical guidelines for that programme. Unfortunately, we have not been able to remove hints of support for shale gas production from the text. It was also not possible to include provisions on technologically advanced methods of steel production or increased transparency in the activities of expert groups.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: The EU has been supporting coal and steel research for more than 50 years since the Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) signed in 1951. When the Treaty expired (2002), it was decided to make the ECSC assets available to a Research Fund for Coal and Steel, which was financed from the revenues generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC and managed by the European Commission (EC). The Research Fund is complementary to Horizon 2020 and ensures annual funding of approximately €50 million for innovation in the coal and steel sectors. The objective of this proposal is to amend the legal basis of the Programme after periodic evaluation of its management rules with a view to facilitating access to funding through simplified rules and harmonisation with the rules of the Horizon 2020 general research programme (with which the Parties stakeholders from the sectors are familiar), ensuring that the programme is managed by the EC with due transparency. As I agree and acknowledge the importance of harmonising and simplifying the rules inherent in this programme, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of changing the management rules for the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. The aim of the changes is to ensure transparent management of a programme financed from the general budget of the EU.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ The coal and steel research fund provides approximately EUR 50 million of funding for research and development in the coal and steel sectors each year, with a view to bring together industrial partners, SMEs, major research centres and universities throughout the European Union and to develop knowledge and promote innovation. The proposal amends the legal basis of the research programme with the aim of ensuring more transparent management and simplifying funding rules to facilitate small participation and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The new changes will also allow proportionate alignment to the rules of “Horizon 2020", leaving the objectives and scope of the program unchanged. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not wish to see the EU spend UK taxpayers’ money on research. This should be done by our own parliament.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this proposal, the purpose of which is to amend the legal base after the periodical assessment of its management rules, with a view to implementing the objectives of facilitating access to funding, ensuring due transparency and alignment with the Commission’s rules on expert groups.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour. I support research in the field of coal and steel and the transparent use of resources from the Research Fund for Coal and Steel (VFUO), which is financed from profits generated by proceeds from the remaining assets (already invalid) of the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC). I consider it necessary to ensure that the Commission manages the programme with due transparency and in accordance with the Commission's rules on expert groups. I welcome the fact that access to funds will be facilitated by simplifying the rules of the VFUO programme and the maximum alignment of the VFUO rules with those of Horizon 2020. This will facilitate the participation of the same beneficiaries in Horizon 2020 and the VFUO programmes.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I did not support this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not actually reflect the actual quality and quantity work, efficiency and most of all the success of advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Support for research in the field of coal and steel dates back to the founding of the European Coal and Steel Community in 1951. When the contract expired in 2002, it was decided that the assets of the European Coal and Steel Community would be released to the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. The programme is financed by profits generated through the proceeds of the remaining assets and managed by the Commission. This fund is in addition to Horizon 2020 and is managed outside of Horizon. It provides around €50 million for development and research and innovation in the coal and steel sector annually. It brings together industrial partners, SMEs, major research centres and universities across the European Union to develop knowledge and support innovation in the sector. Funded research focuses on production processes, resource use and conservation, environmental improvements and occupational safety in relevant sectors. The approved resolution aims to facilitate access to funds by simplifying the rules of the Programme and aligning them appropriately with the rules of the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE)
text: in writing. - The purpose of the proposal amending Council Decision 2008/376/EC approving the LECF research programme is to facilitate access to and administer it with due transparency. Given that the proposal was published a few weeks before the Commission adopted updated horizontal rules on the functioning of expert groups and while the European Parliament is preparing a resolution to be its position on the latest update , care has been taken to ensure that the amendments introduced are consistent with the forthcoming resolution and do not prejudge its outcome.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Coal and steel played an important role in the process of European integration. While the use of coal as fuel is on decline, steel is and will be an important component of industrial production and trade. Research in these areas should, in the future, focus mainly on innovation and efficiency of extraction, production and processing, which also relates to the need to protect the air and the environment in general.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The EU has been supporting research for coal and steel for over 50 years. It all began with the Treaty on European Union for Steel and Coal (ECSC, signed in 1951). When this Treaty expired in 2002, the Coal and Steel Research Fund (RFCS) was established, managed by the Commission. The Coal and Steel Research Fund brings together industry partners, SMEs, leading research centres and universities from across the European Union and encourages the development of knowledge and innovation in the sector. I support the proposal to amend and supplement the legal basis of the Coal and Steel Research Fund to facilitate access to funding and to align it with the rules of the Horizon 2020 General Research Program.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the proposal for a Council decision amending the Council Decision adopting the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. I support the proposed changes underlining the importance of the coal and steel sector in the European integration process and the role in the Union industry. I support companies to comply with legal requirements on social responsibility while finding definitive solutions to reduce the social consequences of transition or closed establishments. Working conditions in this sector are challenging and often harming the health of workers and citizens

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This research focuses on environmental performance, improvement of processes, conservation of resources and job safety in the coal and steel sectors. The coal and steel industries are facing serious problems at Union level, which clearly cannot be solved with this fund, but this will be a useful tool to support these sectors. In particular, we focus on the fact that this fund must be used to find sustainable solutions in order for these two sectors to maintain their activities, particularly taking into account their long-term viability. It is for these reasons that we have voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - This proposal is untimely in that it does not take into account important elements that have emerged and may have significant future implications.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community expired in 2012. Subsequently, the Member States decided to set up a research fund to promote innovation in the coal and steel industry to replace the treaty. The fund contributes around €50 billion a year to innovation, benefiting both industrial companies, small businesses and research institutions. Since the setting up of the fund, support priorities have not changed significantly, but the operation of the system has shown in practice the need for further fine-tuning. Horizon 2020 research and development programme, which was introduced later, also provides funding for innovators. The coordination of the two programmes is essential for efficient operation. Accordingly, the two main objectives of this proposal are to harmonise the operation of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and Horizon 2020 in terms of financing, control and management processes. In Hungary, both the coal and steel industries have significant traditions. Domestic lignite production remains one of the most important pillars of security of supply in the electricity market. It is important that knowledge accumulated in industries is not lost and, adapting to the changed economic and technological environment, be able to up-to-date support the country's economy and competitiveness.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was signed in 1951, since then the EU has been supporting research in the coal and steel industry for more than 50 years. This is because, after the expiry of the contract in 2002, the assets of the ECSC (and related interest) were received by a Research Fund for Coal and Steel ('RFCS'). The scheme is financed from the revenues generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC. The report describes that the RFCS complements Horizon 2020 and grants around EUR 50 million per year for research and development and innovation activities to the steel (72,8%) and coal industries (27,2%). It brings together EU industrial partners, small and medium-sized enterprises, leading research centres and universities and helps them develop their skills and innovate within the sector. The report responds to a proposal from the Commission, which would amend this legal basis with a view to facilitating access to finance by simplified rules, in particular by proportionate approximation to the rules of the General Framework Programme for Research Horizon 2020. The aim is to further ensure the Commission's management of the programme through the amendments, with due transparency and in accordance with the Commission's rules on expert groups. In view of the late publication of the Commission proposal and the EP resolution under construction, I voted in favour of the report and the amendments contained therein.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report, as I wish to support research. I voted against Amendment No 16D, as shale gases are good to be included in the study, even if they are not relevant in practice. In line with the ALDE, I voted minus on a number of amendments, which I believe do not fall within the scope of the programme.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the legislative resolution on the coal and steel research fund because the proposal for a decision does not open any room towards a different use of that fund, than the context current industrial makes it more and more necessary. The coal and steel research fund should today help solve the industrial problems that the EU has been dragging on for decades. The 5 Star Movement calls for a rethink of the general approach. The 2002 scenario, of the ECSC liquidation, is no longer holding, therefore it cannot continue with 'business as usual'. Even within the current legal constraints on fund management, we believe research should send a clear signal for these industries. For steel the social and environmental impact, both on workers and local communities. Absolutely out-of-normal installations must no longer be subject to official aid in Europe, much less for research, their only rational horizon is dismantling. For coal, there is added respect for climate policy goals to these concerns. The M5S would have wanted a more thorough discussion of the proceeds resulting from liquidation and calls for bold use of the same to ensure that they really contribute to solving problems by now old date.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The purpose of this proposal which I support is to amend the legal base after the periodical assessment of its management rules, with a view to implementing the objectives of facilitating access to funding, ensuring due transparency and alignment with the Commission’s rules on expert groups. This report raised important questions related to the social impact of restructuring and closing down of mines in the coal industry, as well as the evaluation of possible new support facilities to manage labour market transitions. I believe it is very important to assess the impact on employment of workers and local communities of emissions reduction and energy consumption. The debate should stay open on these issues.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the text written by the former President of the European Parliament. The European Union has been supporting coal and steel research for more than 50 years. It all began in 1951 with the signing of the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC). At the end of the Treaty in 2002, it was agreed to devote the ECSC assets (and related interest) to the establishment of a Coal and Steel Research Fund (FRCA). The FRCA programme, managed by the Commission, is financed from revenues generated by the ECSC assets in liquidation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS) was established after the expiry of the European Coal and Steel Community Treaty (ECSC) in 2012 and provides annually around 50 million euros, from the EU general budget, managed by the Commission for R&D and innovation funding to the coal and steel sectors (27.2% for coal and 72.8% for steel) in order to develop knowledge and foster innovation. The proposed revision of the RFCS legal basis is focused on the management rules for the programme and is in line with the procedures and concepts used for Horizon 2020, the EU programme for research and innovation, which will act as an outline for the rules for participation and dissemination in the RFCS programme. As a shadow rapporteur for this file I decided to focus mainly on issues of transparency and support for SMEs to be able to benefit more from this fund. All my amendments were endorsed by the EP. I did not support amendments which went beyond the framework of the programme or which would lead to a significant change to the basis for the programme, as that is not necessary in my opinion. In the final vote I supported the texts as proposed by the EP.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ An industry that is not renewed is an industry that is destined not to be able to adequately respond to challenges in the globalised world. As legislators we are tasked with providing our industries with the tools to be able to innovate. That is why I think it is important that there is a research programme to fund research to improve steel production processes. The aim is to enhance the quality of products and increase their productivity. In industrial and research, our priorities must always be actions such as reducing emissions, decreasing energy consumption and environmental impact, as well as better use of raw materials.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the “Motion for a Resolution on the Research Fund for Coal and Steel Research Programme”, as it is an area that the EU has been exploring and supporting for over 50 years. The first such treaty was signed in 1951, and with the expiry of the same year 2002 the assets are made available to the Coal and Steel Research Fund, which gives €50 million a year to coal and steel sectors for research and innovation. Coal and steel sectors are of utmost importance for the European integration process, but at the same time working conditions are demanding and harmful to workers. Simpler funding rules should be considered and allow the use of “unit costs” in favour of small and medium-sized enterprises involved in the scheme.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the report relating to the so-called coal and steel research programme because it is necessary to introduce better conditions, including guidelines. The coal and steel sectors are important for the European integration process and play a key role in the overall industrial structure of the Union. But at the same time, working conditions in those sectors are very difficult and often have a bad effect on the health of workers and citizens. Therefore, factories and enterprises should follow all conditions relating to civil responsibility, provide final decisions, reduce the consequences of public rearrangements or liquidate factories. Where possible, public partners should be consulted on issues related to global responsibility and job protection.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The EU has been supporting research on coal and steel for more than 50 years, and it all started with the Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), signed in 1951. When that Treaty expired in 2002, it was decided that the assets of the ECSC would be made available to the Coal and Steel Research Fund. The programme shall be financed by revenue generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC and managed by the Commission. The Coal and Steel Research Fund is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed outside the framework of the programme. The Fund gives 50 million euros annually to coal and steel sectors for research and development and innovation. It joins industry partners, small and medium-sized enterprises, leading research centres and universities from across Europe to develop knowledge and encourage innovation in the sector, which is of utmost importance for the development of the sector in all EU countries. The purpose of this proposal is to amend the legal basis to facilitate access to financing through simplified rules and to ensure that the Commission manages the programme with appropriate transparency and in accordance with Commission rules on expert groups. Given that I support the reasons for changing the legal basis, I voted positively on this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Council decision amending Council Decision 2008/376/EC adopting the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. The EU has been supporting coal and steel research for more than 50 years. It began with the Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community, signed in 1951. It ceased operations in 2002 and funds were made available to the Coal and Steel Research Fund (managed by the European Commission) - the Fund complements the Horizon 2020 programme. The Commission proposed to change the legal basis following a regular assessment of the management rules, in order to achieve the following objectives: to facilitate access to funding and ensure that the Commission manages the programme with all the necessary transparency and in accordance with its rules on expert groups. A slight concern for the consequences that updated rules for the Coal and Steel Research Fund might have.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: On 18 April 1951 the Treaty of Paris, which established the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), which expired on 23 July 2002, was signed. The remaining assets of the old ECSC were then transferred to a new Coal and Steel Research Fund (FRCA). While the European steel industry is in a particularly critical situation, the EC text considers that “the FRCA has achieved its objective of supporting competitiveness”. Obviously, under the pretext of 'facilitating access to financing for beneficiaries', the text aims above all to give full powers to the European Commission to finally “manage the FRCA programme alone”. In other words, it is a matter of giving ever more responsibility to the unelected bureaucrats who, by ideology (alliance of financial ultra-liberalism and the ayatollahs of ecology), have failed to protect our coal and steel industries from extra-Community competition. However, some investment provisions in these sectors have motivated my choice of abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The aim of the Commission proposal is to amend the legal basis following a periodic assessment of the management principles of the Coal and Steel Research Fund. The programme complements Horizon 2020 and is managed separately. It provides approximately EUR 50 million annually to fund research and development and innovation in the coal and steel sectors. It brings together industrial partners, leading research centres and universities from across the European Union around the goal of developing knowledge and promoting innovation in the sector. Funded research includes manufacturing processes, resource disposal and protection, environmental improvement and job security in the sectors concerned. I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — The EU has been supporting research in the coal and steel industry for more than 50 years. It all began with the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), which was signed in 1951. I supported the present proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Parliament's amendments to the Commission proposal improve the initial text on transparency of consultative groups, SMEs access to the Fund and, above all, the working conditions of workers in the steel and coal sector. However, the purpose of the Fund is to ensure the long-term viability of a highly polluting sector, without proposing alternatives to the production model and, therefore, to propose labour alternatives for workers affected by the closure of their enterprises. That is why I abstain.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel because, although the Commission proposal aims at increasing transparency and aligning procedures with the Horizon 2020 Research Programme, I believe that H2020 should not finance fossil fuel energy.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported Mr Buzek's report on making the Research Fund for Coal and Steel continue to exist, in addition to the Horizon 2020 programme, and to be managed independently by the European Commission. The Steel and Coal Fund has existed since the signing of the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community in 1951, which started the unification of the European continent. Today, the Fund provides EUR 50 million in funding annually for research and development and innovation in both the coal and steel sectors (with 72.8% allocation for steel and 27.2% for coal). The Research Fund brings together industrial enterprises, SMEs, leading research centres and universities across the European Union to both develop knowledge and stimulate innovation in the sector as well as research on production processes, use and conservation of resources, and the environment and the safety of the working environment in these sectors. I believe that the time has not yet come when we need to suspend research on steel and coal, in an attempt to shut down coal at all as an energy resource. It takes at least another decade of intensive research to establish whether those technologies that can offer the use of coal in a clean way will be found.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report carries out an amendment to the legal basis of the research programme on the coal and steel sectors aimed at improving programme management, facilitating access to funds by simplifying rules and updating provisions relating to the legal bases of comitology. We are therefore talking about a report aimed at updating this Fund in order to improve it, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of it.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I have decided to vote in favour of this report on the proposal for the approval of the Research Programme of the Coal and Steel Research Fund, because this amendment is an improvement in its operating rules. This research fund is a fundamental tool for the long-term operation and viability of the coal and steel industries. The present report includes arrangements for assessing and continuing projects developed with funding from the fund. I believe that both industries are essential for industrial activity and the energy transition of our production model, and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it is appropriate to promote the participation of SMEs in the RFCS programme by, inter alia, simplifying the rules for the participation of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the RFCS programme and allowing the use of unit costs in the calculation of the eligible personnel costs for SME owners and other natural persons who do not receive a salary.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: The Treaty on the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) was signed another 50 years ago in 1951. When the Treaty expired in 2002, it was decided to make the ECSC assets available to a Research Fund for Coal and Steel (RFCS). The Programme is financed from the revenue generated by the remaining assets of the former ECSC and is managed by the Commission. The RFCS is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed independently of Horizon 2020. The proposed amendments aim to facilitate access to funding through simplified rules and proportionate harmonisation with the rules of the Horizon 2020 general research programme, and to ensure that the programme is managed by the Commission with due transparency and in accordance with the rules of Commission on expert groups. We vote in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it calls for greater transparency and, on the other hand, it will give SMEs easier access to RFCS.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal amending the legal basis of the research programme dedicated to the Coal and Steel sectors with a view to implementing the following objectives: ensuring transparent management of the programme; facilitating access to funding for beneficiaries with simplified rules and updating the provisions referred to in the legal basis concerning, in particular, comitology. The S&D group also pushed for the inclusion of an analysis of the impact of mining operations on employment of workers and on local communities.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that coal and steel sectors are very important for the process of European integration. However, working conditions in those sectors are still resulting in harm to the health of workers and citizens. I agree with the call for installations and companies to respect all legal requirements and minimise possible harm caused by the transition or closure of installations. The coal and steel sectors are meant to provide positive outcomes, and continuing to perform research in this area will help those sectors to do so.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted on the report on the Council proposal on the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. According to the rapporteur, for more than 50 years, the EU has supported research into coal and steel, starting with the Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC, signed in 1951). According to the Commission, the purpose of this proposal is to amend the legal basis after regular evaluation of its management rules in order to achieve the following objectives: facilitating access to finance by means of simplified rules; ensuring that the programme is managed by the Commission with the necessary transparency, respecting the Commission's rules on expert groups. I welcome the rapporteur's critical spirit, who mentions the fact that he is not fully convinced that aligning the rules of the RFCS with those of Horizon 2020 requires a change in the legal basis. According to him, this proposal was published just weeks before the Commission published updated horizontal rules on this issue, with the rapporteur concerned about the future implications that updating the rules could have on this issue. proposals relating to the RFCS.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Treaty establishing the European Coal and Steel Community was signed in 1951. Research in this area is financed by the Research Fund for Coal and Steel (VFUO). The annual amount of money for development, research and innovation in this sector amounts to €50 million. This fund is also a complement to Horizon 2020. It is unique because it brings together industrial partners, small and medium-sized enterprises, major research centres and universities across the European Union in order to develop knowledge and promote innovation in the sector. Funded research focuses on production processes, resource use and conservation, environmental improvements and occupational safety in relevant sectors. The Commission proposal, which I supported, should facilitate access to funds by simplifying the rules of the Programme and aligning them appropriately with the rules of the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme. It should also ensure that the Commission manages the programme with due transparency and in accordance with the rules on expert groups.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF)
text: ‒ The PVV voted against the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel. The reason for the creation of the fund is outdated. The fund should be lifted.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a Council decision amending the decision on the adoption of the research programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. The purpose of the Commission's proposal was to amend the legal basis of the programme after its regular evaluation. The European Union has supported research in the field of coal and steel since 1951. However, since the original Coal and Steel Community treaty expired, it was necessary to find another way to support this research and therefore a new research fund was established. I think that this is a traditional sector that is widespread throughout the European Union, and therefore I support the simplification of the legal framework as well as the rules on the financing of this fund. On the other hand, however, I also welcomed the amendments that called for a slow change of orientation, from maintaining the continuity of coal mining in Europe at all costs to finding alternatives, recultivating the environment and creating other jobs, coal and steel.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the Buzek report which facilitates access to funding through simplified rules of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel Research Programme with the rules of the Horizon 2020 general research programme. I would like to highlight the proposals to ensure that the programme is managed with due transparency and in accordance with the rules in force on expert groups. I only regret the rejection by the Committee on Industry of some amendments by the Socialist Group of Europe which would have strengthened the role of the Fund in actions relevant to coal and steel research.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a Council decision amending Decision 2008/376/EC on the adoption of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel Research Programme. The Coal and Steel Research Fund is complementary to Horizon 2020 and is managed outside the framework of the programme. The Fund gives €50 million annually to coal and steel sectors for research and development and innovation (72.8% of funding goes to the steel sector and 27.2% to the coal sector). Through it, industry partners, small and medium-sized enterprises, leading research centres and universities from across Europe join together to develop knowledge and encourage innovation in the sector. The purpose of the proposal is to amend the legal basis following a periodic assessment of the management rules, thus achieving the objectives of accession to funding aligned with the rules of the general research programme 'Horizon 2020' and will ensure that the Commission manages the Programme with appropriate transparency and in accordance with the Commission rules on expert groups, this concerns, in particular, the provisions relating to comitology.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a Council decision amending Council Decision 2008/376/EC adopting the Research Programme of the Research Fund for Coal and Steel and on the multiannual technical guidelines for this programme. The coal and steel sector is important in the European integration process and plays an essential role in the Union industry. The purpose of this proposal is to amend the legal basis following a regular assessment of the management rules to facilitate, inter alia, access to financing through simplified rules and thus enable beneficiaries to participate in both research programmes (the Coal and Steel Research Fund; and Horizon 2020 programme). Funded research programmes deal with production processes, resource exploitation and conservation, environmental improvements and safety at work in these sectors.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I consider the subject of human rights and democracy to be a very important agenda of the European Union. It's also a number of points where we're addressing the state of human rights and democracy in individual states in the world. I agree with most of that message. However, in the end, I did not support it and I abstained, because there are also points in the report which are, in short, very shaky politically, on which we do not have a uniform here on the floor of the European Parliament opinion. It's kind of a shame that there are things in this recapitulating report that may have led me to believe that in the end I couldn't support the report, even though I agree with an absolute majority. It's things like trying to push through a unified asylum system or accelerate resolution of relocations and so on. We know well that this is a subject that divides the House here, but also European politicians. So I note that this is why I did not ultimately support the report, although I agree with the principles of monitoring human rights and democracy in the world.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: — I consider it right that this Parliament assesses the situation in the world every year from the point of view of respect for human rights and the state of democracy. I am all the more regret that some Members will always take this opportunity to push into the text demands which have very little in common with human rights. The universal human right to abortion does not exist. Nevertheless, this request found itself in the report submitted. Similarly, the European Court of Human Rights has repeatedly confirmed that it is not the human right of two same-sex people to marry. Nevertheless, the report requires Member States to recognise these volumes, thereby also interfering with the competence of the Member States. I therefore had to reject such a distorted notion of human rights, despite the fact that I appreciate the many activities of my colleague Weidenholzer.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in line with the EPP, I voted in favour of this report in its final version, given the report’s balanced consideration of the state of human rights and democracy in the EU and beyond. Having said that, my colleagues and I from Ireland did abstain or vote against some of the amendments. I remain alarmed by continuing incidents of violence and persecution, intolerance, and discrimination towards minorities, and ongoing trends of migration and displacement. However, the advancement of democracy, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms and the rule of law continue to define our policy in this field. Thus we may hope that the shared challenges which we face in this year may be handled in the spirit of bilateral engagement and cooperation as we continue to advance towards the improvement of human rights. I must say that, hopefully, those who continuously criticise the European Union and the European Parliament might give us credit for the ongoing work we are doing continuously, day in day out, in promoting human rights right across the globe.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Every year the European Parliament is responsible for drawing up an explanatory report on its human rights position. The following refers to the year 2015. In addition to the elements that are usually considered in the presentation of the report, some points have been introduced this year which can be described as innovative and extremely interesting. For example, I consider paragraphs concerning freedom of expression online and offline and through audiovisual and other media very positive, the paragraph concerning migrants, refugees and those seeking asylum and the connection between democracy and human rights. I have long dealt with this last issue in relation to other reports and I therefore very much appreciate a separate section dealing with the subject has been included in the dossier. For these reasons I have decided to vote for it.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because, in the face of an increasingly critical global situation in respect of human rights, Parliament sends a strong message that the Union remains firm in its promotion and defence, through all its external policies. Especially in times of insecurity and crisis, the Union must be faithful to the fundamental values that inspire it. In this regard, we Socialists have managed to introduce into the text a clear request for the effective protection of the rights of refugees and asylum-seekers — because we believe that Europe has not lived up to its commitments in managing the arrival of hundreds of thousands of people entitled to protection — and consistent solutions and long - term effects on migration in line with respect for human rights. In this report we also show serious concern at the continued reduction of civil society space that can be seen in multiple countries — with a serious deterioration of fundamental freedoms of association and expression — often under the excuse of the fight against terrorism, and we also call for improvements in protection mechanisms of activists and human rights defenders.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted against because the annual report on human rights calls for greater European military integration and to improve the preparation and flexibility of the European armed forces, 'in order to enable them to respond to threats and cases of serious human rights violation', which is a total contradiction; to say, it intends to increase security and defense guarantees of fundamental rights. An excuse to justify the increase in military capabilities.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area. As the report rightly states, there is a risk that human rights and democratic values will not be respected and promoted throughout the world. Some countries, including those governed by authoritarian regimes and terrorist groups, are increasingly and more stubbornly challenging the universality of human rights. Efforts to reduce the space allocated to civil society and human rights defenders are becoming increasingly active, freedom of assembly and freedom of expression are more restricted. I support the call to condemn such abuses and infringements. No legislation should in any way reduce the space in which civil society groups can operate. The report calls on the EU institutions and Member States to act in accordance with their commitments to promote democracy and the rule of law, to defend and enforce human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is also welcome to call on the EU Member States to set an example and to take a common position in support of indivisibility of human rights. Finally, the EU's commitment to human rights and democratic values throughout the world is recalled. Rapid and adequate response to human rights violations must be ensured even in the early stages of human rights violations.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - This is the annual report on human rights, an assessment of the EU's action in this area. This text aims to strengthen the EU's diplomatic role by using human rights as a lever for encroachment on state action. It also assumes a desire to interfere in the affairs of third States in the name of the defence of humanitarian aid. In line with the other human rights reports, I obviously opposed this law and politically correct text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it talks about further EU integration in areas such as defence, which is not an issue which should come up in a human rights report (or even at all, since the defence of the realm is the very definition of a sovereign matter). I note that the proposed solution to any crisis continues to be ‘more European Union’ even when that it patently inappropriate or flies in the face of previous evidence of EU failure. However, I did support text which highlighted the dangers to persecuted Christian minorities across the world, and specifically which noted the dangers to ancient communities in the Middle East and North Africa, and I voted accordingly on paragraph 148 of this report.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I have decided to endorse this report on human rights and democracy in the world and the policy of the European Union in this field. I am concerned that the promotion and protection of human rights is threatened by totalitarian regimes and terrorist groups in some parts of the world. It is more necessary than ever to recall that the European Union focuses its foreign policy on the promotion of democracy and the rule of law. Finally, I would like to add that the Union, if it is to be a credible player in this area, must ensure greater coherence between its internal and external policies

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2015 and the European Union's policy in this area. In view of the deteriorating situation on human rights and democracy in the world and on the diversity of conflicts, I agree that the EU must pay more attention to people's rights, because the EU has many instruments of action to do so.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — The report aims to strengthen the diplomatic role of the European Union by using human rights as a pretext to influence the action of States. It also assumes a willingness to interfere in the affairs of third States in the name of the defence of humanitarian associations. I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which calls on all actors concerned to take full responsibility for their role in respect for human rights and democratic values, as these rights are increasingly under threat throughout the world. In the face of this alarming situation, it is essential that the European institutions and Member States place human rights at the centre of the Union's external policies by promoting and defending them firmly. In this context, Parliament welcomed the adoption of the EU's Second Plan on Human Rights and Democracy (2015-2019) and encouraged Member States to implement the actions outlined. Other measures are also encouraged in the report to achieve this end, including the strengthening of human rights dialogue with third countries. These rights must be respected equally among the entire world population, whether women, children, the elderly, persons with disabilities or those belonging to a minority. Nevertheless, the issue is particularly worrying about migrants, refugees and asylum-seekers who are victims of human trafficking networks and who have their human rights violated while fleeing war.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour as this is a very balanced and comprehensive report.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The international community has been unable to curb war conflicts and massacres beyond its borders, and to support democratic processes that have been able to prevent the displacement of thousands of refugees and the death of thousands of people during the annual reporting period. The European guidelines on human rights seem to us insufficient and with its policies the Union has been complicit in the most important humanitarian crisis of recent decades. I have not found a defence of social rights in this report and articles that use the defence of human rights as a strategy for trade penetration in third countries. Voluntary principles for the control of multinationals are not sufficient. I am obviously against further European military integration. If we really want to work to maintain consistency with the defence of human rights, as advocated in this report, we must firmly face xenophobic reactions, rethink our trade policies, and not allow people without rights into our territory. For the defence of the rights of all and our obligation to defend them, I voted abstention on this report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and EU policy on this matter. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work. I also supported the amendment calling for the fundamental rights of the people of Western Sahara to be respected and calls for the release of all Saharawi political prisoners, and that Members of Parliament, independent observers, NGOs and the press be allowed access to the territories. It also called for a just and lasting solution to the conflict based on the Saharawi people in accordance with the relevant United Nations resolutions.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — This text concerns the 2015 Annual Report on World Human Rights and Democracy and the European Union's policy on human rights and democracy and takes stock of EU action in this field. The report actually aims to strengthen the EU's diplomatic role by using human rights as a lever for encroachment on state action (paras. 19-25). It also clearly wishes to interfere in the affairs of third States in the name of the defence of humanitarian workers. Therefore, for these simple reasons, I voted against the report.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Regarding the report on economic rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in the area of 2015 (Weidenholzer), I have abstained. The report comprehensively and covers most of human rights issues. It has many positive points such as the need for safe and legal escape routes to the EU, the rights of LGBT people, markings against racism and xenophobia, etc. But the report also contains a lot of negative points, mainly in the area of security. For example, the report calls for “further integration in Europe to promote the readiness and flexibility of the European forces.” The report also favourably favourages military operations such as “Eunavfor WITH Sophia,” which has been an immensely criticised operation from an MRI perspective. There are also problematic writing in the field of migration, where deportations are seen as an important part of the common European asylum system. This is not something I can support, and not something that should take place in a report on human rights. These, and more points, made me decide to put my vote down.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because, in the face of an increasingly critical global situation in respect of human rights, Parliament is sending a strong message that the Union remains firm in its promotion and defence, through all its external policies. Especially in times of insecurity and crisis, the Union must be faithful to the fundamental values that inspire it. In this regard, we Socialists have managed to introduce into the text a clear request for the effective protection of the rights of refugees and asylum-seekers — because we believe that Europe has not lived up to its commitments in managing the arrival of hundreds of thousands of people entitled to protection — and consistent solutions and long - term effects on migration in line with respect for human rights. In this report we also show serious concern at the continued reduction of civil society space that can be seen in multiple countries — with a serious deterioration of fundamental freedoms of association and expression — often under the excuse of the fight against terrorism, and we also call for improvements in protection mechanisms of activists and human rights defenders.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which discusses the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area. The European Parliament expresses its deep concern that there is a risk of failure to respect and promotion of human rights and democratic values throughout the world. Parliament strongly underlines that the EU is committed to developing the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and all other external EU policies based on the universality and indivisible of democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect the promotion of human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity and of the principles laid down in the Charter of the United Nations and in international human rights and humanitarian law. These principles are also inseparable from external actions not covered by the CFSP, and, inter alia, from development and humanitarian policy instruments. Parliament also expresses its deep concern at the current numerous attacks on human rights defenders, and calls on the EU, and above all the High Representative and Vice-President of the Commission, to adopt a policy that would systematically and unequivocally condemn human murders of rights defenders and any attempt to commit, persecute, threaten, harass, imprisonment or arbitrary arrest, take measures to disappear, and condemn those who commit or tolerate such atrocities.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — In its report on the situation of human rights and democracy in the world and the EU's policy in this regard, the European Parliament expresses grave concern that the protection of human rights worldwide is subject to serious threats. The document underlines the Union's long-term commitment to promoting human rights, including religious freedom, freedom of expression and minority rights. However, I regret to note that the report unilaterally addresses the issue of migration affecting Europe as a human rights issue, ignoring other important aspects of it, such as the protection of the EU's external borders or the legitimacy of border crossing requirement. Although it is worth mentioning that the report distinguishes between migrants and refugees, I abstained from voting.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this self-initiative Report, which is based on principles of decency and equality that do not accept any form of discrimination against any of our citizens. I support condemnation of all forms of discrimination against LGBTI people, as well as condemnation of the lack of humanity displayed at European borders, who, instead of compassion, offered walls and barbed wire to those fleeing war and persecution.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: This annual report on human rights is only an additional opportunity to give the EU more power in international affairs, which I condemn. He even suggested a willingness to interfere in third States in the name of the defence of human rights, which is a great deal. For these reasons I am voting against this report.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Despite some positive aspects, I voted against the Weidenholzer report. I welcome and fully endorse the report’s references to the protection of LGBTI citizens, the acknowledgement of climate refugees, strong language on women’s rights and gender equality and its annex, which reiterates the European Parliament’s support for the release of Irish prisoner of conscience Ibrahim Halawa. However, some aspects of the report were unacceptable to me. The calls for the development of a common security and defence policy, the strengthening of European military integration, the creation of a common EU asylum policy, the creation of harsh readmission agreements, the selective use of the principle of non-refoulement and more made it impossible to support.  Sinn Féin completely opposes the militarisation of the EU. It is an unnecessary and expensive venture that makes a mockery of the neutrality of some of its Member States. We will continue to diligently oppose any further militarisation of the EU and continue to defend Irish military neutrality.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union must act in a coordinated and consistent manner in its development policies, whether they are addressed to territories internal to the Union or to external territories. Coherence of policies supposes agreement on values and principles to conform to and on which to converge. Multilevel governance and coordination on different scales is therefore essential to promote dialogue and to foster agreement and the political commitment of each institution in transforming its policies, integrate, apply and monitor them as expected in a constant review and renewal process. There is no risk of promoting values of democracy, respect for human rights, combating poverty and then implementing policies or trade agreements with third countries in some areas which, indirectly, create the conditions for which the undertakings made are violated or disregarded. In particular, for the next few years, attention should be paid to partnership and cooperation agreements with non-democratic developing countries where, without an appropriate reporting procedure of the aid provided, we risk unintentionally strengthening the darkest parts of those same countries that we would like to help.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This annual report focuses on the state of human rights and democracy in the world, as well as the progress made by the European Union in this regard. This text uses the current regression of fundamental rights in many States as a pretext to strengthen the diplomatic role of the European Union when it has no legitimacy to intervene in this area of competence. Furthermore, we believe that the European Union and its Member States do not have to interfere in the internal affairs of third countries in order to impose their vision of democracy. Finally, it is surprising that the European Union is concerned about respect for human rights in third countries when it imposes on European peoples free trade treaties and quotas for illegal migrants to which they strongly oppose. For all these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union is committed to a common foreign and security policy, oriented by the principles that led to the creation of the Union and which it must pursue and promote worldwide, such as democracy, the rule of law, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity, indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, and respect for the principles of the United Nations Charter and international law. The relations of the European Union with the rest of the international communities also lead to the affirmation and promotion of values and interests, but also contribute to the protection of citizens, peace, security and sustainable development of the planet, lead to solidarity and respect between peoples, free trade and fair, the elimination of poverty and human protection, but in particular the protection of the rights of the child and the development of international law. I voted in favour of the report on human rights and democracy in the world and the policy of the European Union in this regard because I believe that, in order to maintain peace in the world and well-being between peoples, it is necessary to respect human rights and to have an easy democracy for all the parties directly involved.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because, in the face of an increasingly critical global situation in respect of human rights, Parliament sends a strong message that the Union remains firm in its promotion and defence, through all its external policies. Especially in times of insecurity and crisis, the Union must be faithful to the fundamental values that inspire it. In this regard, we Socialists have managed to introduce into the text a clear request for the effective protection of the rights of refugees and asylum-seekers — because we believe that Europe has not lived up to its commitments in managing the arrival of hundreds of thousands of people entitled to protection — and consistent solutions and long - term effects on migration in line with respect for human rights. In this report we also show serious concern at the continued reduction of civil society space that can be seen in multiple countries — with a serious deterioration of fundamental freedoms of association and expression — often under the excuse of the fight against terrorism, and we also call for improvements in protection mechanisms of activists and human rights defenders.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the 2015 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy on this issue, because even in 2015 on human rights. In many countries an increasingly restricted area has been reserved for civil society, restrictions were recorded on non-governmental organizations, serious violations of human rights against activists and attacks on journalists and bloggers. Much more needs to be done to ensure fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, principles of equality and solidarity. Today, more than ever, the construction of a European area of rights that is genuinely inclusive in its complexity, and not only a geographical border, is an element that should represent a priority on the agenda of the Community institutions and the Member States.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. There were some good aspects to the report, including the fact that it proposes incorporating human rights standards into trade agreements, is strong on LGBTI rights, acknowledges climate refugees and generally addresses gender issues in a positive way. There was also an annex which reiterated the resolution passed by the European Parliament last year on the continued detention without trial of Ibrahim Halawa.  However, the report also made statements about the development of a Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP), including strengthening European military integration and making more use of readmission agreements. As Sinn Féin does not support these elements, I was forced to reject the text as a whole.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. Whilst we fully support efforts to improve human rights and democracy, we cannot support EU activity in this or any other area. The vote on Article 148(2) regarding Christianity was un-whipped and each MEP voted according to their own conscience.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am concerned by continued violence and persecution, intolerance and discrimination against religious and belief minorities around the world. I believe that we should launch interreligious dialogues and ensure that minorities are protected, including in the Middle East, where Yazidi, Christian and Muslim minorities are being persecuted by Da’esh and other terrorist groups, affecting, in particular, women, children, people with disabilities, and elderly people. In its holistic approach to find sustainable, long-term and coherent solutions, based on international human rights standards, it highlights the importance of differentiating between refuges and migrants. Trade and human rights must go hand in hand; and I therefore welcome the adoption of the Commission’s new strategy “Trade for All”, which calls for appropriate actions stipulated in human rights clauses. Due to a reference to abortion I was unable to vote in favour of the whole report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report is the one with which, every year, the European Parliament expresses its position, its assessment and wishes on human rights, taking into account Considering the factual, political and regulatory events that took place the previous year, in this case therefore refers to 2015. I very much appreciated the great work done by both the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs who have produced, on the whole, an extremely good text. My vote was positive.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The text under consideration prepared annually by the Human Rights Subcommittee and approved by the Foreign Affairs Committee gives a partial review of the human rights situation in the world. The reports drawn up start with a laudable intent on the part of Parliament, to report abuse and condemn situations beyond control and tolerability. Alongside hateful discrimination against religious minorities and unjustifiable violence against the weakest, many references in favour of abortion are punctually juxtapozed. The text on the plenary examination equates, among the rights proclaimed by the European Union of individual and religious freedom, that with the right to abortion which has nothing to do with universal human rights. That is why I thought it appropriate not to support a report which moves from very high principles but fails to carry out an analysis without ideologies.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it touches upon what I consider absolutely central to any external action of the European Union: protection and promotion of human rights in all the regions of the world. The EU has the reputation of being a union of states which share a very high level of human rights for their citizens. We should emphasise that also in our cooperation with third countries beyond EU borders. That is one of the key aspects of the EU’s added value in the international field.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As national budgets for overseas development and humanitarian aid keep shrinking, due to austerity policies, the European Parliament takes account of the human rights challenges in many parts of the world and the EU’s commitment to ensure coherence between its policies, inside and outside the EU, with regard to human rights. I commend my colleague Joseph Weidenholzer for his strong commitment to protect LGBTI rights, to demand respect for human rights standards in trade agreements.  I thank all the colleagues who helped with the inclusion of the annex reiterating the resolution passed by the European Parliament last year on the unlawful detention without trial of Irish citizen Ibrahim Halawa.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — The report by Mr Weidenholzer is an extremely useful tool to shed light on where and how human rights and democratic values are threatened in the world. If in fact authoritarian regimes and terrorist groups such as ISIS seriously jeopardize the universality of human rights in many parts of the world, it is our moral responsibility to take a clear position and strong to defend them. In addition, the report has the merit of again spotlighting the worrying situation of refugee minors and unaccompanied minors, missing or separated from families. Member States must give this tragic situation the top priority. I voted in favour of the report with the hope that the European Commission will present a concrete strategy as soon as possible so that unaccompanied minors will be genuinely and effectively protected from all kinds of violence, exploitation and abuse.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report and express deep concern that the promotion and protection of human rights and democratic values are under threat throughout the world and that the universality of human rights is seriously questioned in many parts of the world, including by totalitarian regimes, but also by terrorist organizations such as the so-called Islamic State.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this field in 2015. Although the general objective of the report is positive and in the interests of the citizens, I believe that there are references to issues of security and restriction of citizens' rights which are wrong, so I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The world is crying, but we cannot afford to do the same. One must aspire to an awareness of one's evils by taking on the appropriate strategies to erode them and that is what I intend to do by expressing favour of the report. To date, it is no longer sufficient to find out the constant violence and persecution that must be perpetrated especially in the Middle East and by ISIS and its followers. Complaining, similarly, forms of intolerance and discrimination dictated by a different religious belief serves very little if interfaith dialogues and forms of integration are not undertaken by investing in opportunities that the future and its generations can confer. The report shows how certain strides have been made on this issue and how they should be increased through, for example, strengthening the role and powers of the EU Special Representative to implement the promotion of human rights and the decisive European role. There are also attempts to reduce the gap between civil society and freedom of assembly and expression. Therefore, my full support for special dialogues on human rights as effective tools for undertaking bilateral commitments and cooperation between institutions and organisations.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union’s policy on the matter in 2015. I supported the issues regarding LGBTI people. I did not support the provision regarding European military integration due to Ireland’s position of neutrality.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: Fundamental Rights play an essential role not only within the internal sphere, but also in European external relations. In this area too, the European Parliament is calling for the Union to be a beacon of hope for the world. With the right distinctions, just like what happened on the European continent, in the rest of the world, 2015 was hard for respect for human rights and democracy. Among the many problems still in the world, I must highlight - for its significance and impact - the persecution, violence and intolerance to which Daesh is subjecting Yazidis, Christians and Muslim minorities. The need for a long-term solution, however, should not jeopardise more immediate support. That is why, as the rapporteur rightly points out, it has never been more essential than today to distinguish migrants and refugees.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. Whilst we fully support efforts to improve human rights and democracy, we cannot support EU activity in this or any other area. The vote on Article 148(2) regarding Christianity was un-whipped and each MEP voted according to their own conscience.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure underlining the continued persecution and discrimination against religious minorities in the world. The report urges the initiation of interfaith dialogues and ensuring that minorities are protected, including those present in the Middle East, where minorities of Yazidis, Christian and Muslim are persecuted by Daesh and other terrorist groups. The report also pays special attention to women, children, people with disabilities and older people and EU human rights policies by highlighting how conflicts, wars and failures of government are the main causes of migration.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against because the annual report on human rights calls for greater European military integration and to improve the preparation and flexibility of the European armed forces, 'to enable them to respond to threats and cases of serious human rights violation', which is a total contradiction; to say, it intends to increase security and defense guarantees of fundamental rights. An excuse to justify the increase in military capabilities. This biased and reductionist view of the concept of protecting the human rights of the population does not know the impact and importance of economic and political measures for the safeguarding of citizens' social and economic rights. On the other hand, it is interventionist and seeks to emulate the US interventionist policing policy of the world, as it underlines the need to consolidate in international law the concept of “responsibility to protect” and to give the Union the opportunity to “lead meaningful initiatives and actions to protect civilians, even when they are under the threat of their own State”.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Currently the universality of human rights is seriously endangered in many parts of the world. Just think of the constant violations of freedom of association and expression in Russia, China and Turkey. I voted in favour of this resolution because I share the need for the EU to ensure consistency between its internal and external policies regarding respect for human rights. I believe that the EU should make full use of the instruments it has to promote and protect human rights.
