In particular, public diplomacy through EU declarations, political initiatives and dialogues, human rights guidelines and national strategies on this subject, periodic dialogues on human rights and financial cooperation projects, including support for civil society. The EU must not abandon its commitment to incorporating human rights and gender aspects into its missions and, more generally, to conduct the common defence and security policy in line with values fundamentals of civil society and the principles of democracy contained in the treaties and the Charter of the United Nations.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I have abstained from voting on the annual EU report on human rights and democracy in the world and European Union policy in this regard for 2015. I believe that the report, although it raises very important issues related to the protection of human rights, in its matter contains problematic parts arising a number of questions. I firmly believe that development and human rights are interdependent and that respect and protection of human rights is a necessary condition for reducing inequality and achieving sustainable development goals for all people. Unfortunately, the existing discrepancies and the discussion issues present in the report have made me decide to abstain from voting on the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which underlines that the universality of human rights is being challenged in many parts of the world. The European Union should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights. I also agree with the rapporteur that when it comes to migration, we need long-term and coherent solutions based on human rights, keeping in mind the growing number of human rights abuses against refugees, irregular migrants and asylum seekers on their route to Europe. In this report, I voted against any references to abortion.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - Gender equality is at the heart of European values and is enshrined in the EU's legal and political framework, and is at the heart of the UN Agenda 2030. In this context, I consider essential the EU's commitment to integrating human rights and gender issues into common security and defence policy missions on women, peace and security, as women are seen as a central component of all efforts to tackle challenges World. To this end, the European Union must support at international level the recognition of the added value of women's participation in conflict prevention and resolution, as well as in peacekeeping operations, humanitarian assistance and post-conflict reconstruction.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This own-initiative report highlights attempts to reduce the space of civil society, limit freedom of assembly and freedom of expression and expresses concerns about the persistence of violence and persecution, intolerance and discrimination against religious minorities worldwide. The report calls for strengthening interreligious dialogues and strengthening the protection of minorities, particularly in the Middle East, where Yazidi, Christian and Muslim minorities are being persecuted by the Islamic State group and other terrorist groups. Considering that human rights are fundamental values of the Union, I supported this report, which denounces these shortcomings.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. Whilst we fully support efforts to improve human rights and democracy, we cannot support EU activity in this or any other area. The vote on Article 148(2) regarding Christianity was un-whipped and each MEP voted according to their own conscience.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which makes recommendations in relation to the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world, and the policy of the European Union for 2015. This report reports on the situation of respect for human rights in third countries of the European Union. Some of its recommendations must be promptly taken into account in order to combat non-respect for fundamental rights. For example, the Commission should conduct an in-depth assessment of the implementation of the human rights guidelines by EU delegations and diplomatic representations of Member States in all third countries. Moreover, while we are facing an unprecedented migration crisis, the fight against trafficking in human beings must be one of the priorities of the European Union in its external policies.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — In its report on the situation of human rights and democracy in the world and the EU's policy in this regard, the European Parliament expresses grave concern that the protection of human rights worldwide is subject to serious threats. The document underlines the Union's long-term commitment to promoting human rights, including freedom of religion, freedom of expression and minority rights. However, I regret to note that the report unilaterally addresses the issue of migration affecting Europe as a human rights issue, ignoring other important aspects of it, such as the protection of the EU's external borders or the legitimacy of border crossing requirement. It is well known that Hungary's position on migration differs from the EU's official policy in several respects. Although it is worth mentioning that the report distinguishes between migrants and refugees in line with the views of the European People's Party, I nevertheless abstained with my fellow Members from Fidesz.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This is the annual report on human rights, which is an assessment of EU action in this area. The report aims to strengthen the diplomatic role of the European Union through the use of human rights, which indicates a willingness to interfere in the affairs of third States.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I abstained on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area (2015) because it has many opinions with which I disagree, such as the sharp criticism of the EU and the Member States for not complying with the European legislation in the field of migration. We cannot require Member States to implement and comply with the legislation imposed by the European institutions, which does not work in their favour, but, on the contrary, aims at weakening Member States and destroying European traditions and culture.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The report attempts legislative intervention in the safeguarding of the rights of illegal immigrants with adverse effects both on the internal balance of the host countries and on the possibility of using their refoulement mechanism, which is now trying to eliminate.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the EU policy on this issue because the text reports with accuracy and organicity the main ones events and assessments and positions that the EU has expressed for the protection of human rights during 2015. In particular, the report emphasises the issue of migrants and asylum seekers, one of the biggest challenges facing the EU. The part relating to trade, business and human rights largely takes up Mr Corrao's report on corporate liability, which calls for greater attention to the policies adopted by multinationals on respect for human rights.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The report is an important step for the European Parliament to have a coherent, united voice against a lack of human rights activities. It is regrettable that some writing in the report tends to be misleading, particularly in regards to religiously persecuted groups - there I distance myself to the “actual” claims that only risk polarizing the debate more superficially.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Respect, promotion and protection of indivisibility and universality of human rights are among the main objectives of the EU foreign and security policy. Human rights and democracy policy should be integrated into all EU policies with an external dimension, such as development, migration, security, counter-terrorism, enlargement and trade policy, in particular through the application of the conditions linked to respect for human rights. I express my concern that the promotion and protection of human rights and democratic values are threatened throughout the world and that the universality of human rights is being seriously undermined must fulfil their respective commitments to promote democracy and Law, protect and make human rights and fundamental freedoms a reality.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Vote against: this report aims to strengthen the EU's diplomatic role by using the pretext of human rights as a lever. The report also assumes a willingness to interfere in the affairs of third States.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2015 and on the European Union policy on this issue is distinguished by its organic plant and less concentrated on analysis of individual country-cases-. The European Parliament's strong commitment to the protection of fundamental rights, including outside the Union, is confirmed. With reference to the report for 2015, the title dedicated to freedom of expression deserves particular appreciation. The assessment on the report is for this, and other reasons, very positive.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This annual report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World (2015) and the EU's policy on this subject takes stock of the EU's work in defending and promoting human rights. The usual exercise of hypocrisy, systematic use of double standards, depending on the geopolitical interests of the EU and its powers. The usual restrictive and instrumental conception of democracy and human rights. In 2015, human rights were once again used by the EU to justify interference and interference in sovereign countries. In 2015, the EU properly closed its eyes to blatant human rights violations occurring within its borders, some of which it actively promoted, inseparable from its policies. There is no shortage of words to link trade/market with human rights, defending the 'Trade for all' policy as capable of bringing human rights to the world, when it is known that there are many European companies that do precisely the opposite in different parts of the world. Execrable. The report highlights the EU's aggressive attitude, militarism, shaped by the Common Security and Defence Policy, and praises it as a promoter and advocate of human rights and democracy in third countries. It is the development of the “responsibility to protect” theory. We obviously voted against it.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes because I agree.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - Human rights represent one of the fundamental values on which the European Union is built. It must therefore actively speak out against any violations of them. It's true both inward and externally. Therefore, the European diplomatic service needs to be even more strongly involved in these activities in the future. Cases of human rights violations should also be taken into account more strongly when building economic and trade relations between the European Union and its Member States with third countries. Their protection is particularly important from the point of view of the various vulnerable groups of the population. Whether it's women, children, minorities, seniors, but, for example, handicapped people, who are unfortunately often forgotten. Each of them is specific in terms of their rights and needs in this area. In ensuring them, various organisations play an irreplaceable role within a functioning civil society. These should therefore not be questioned, which we are unfortunately witnessing today also on the domestic political scene. On the contrary, they need to be helped and work to strengthen their independence.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I vote against the relationship which, among other things, supports the recognition of same-sex marriages and civil unions as well as adoption by the same.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this field in 2015, as it attempts legislative intervention in safeguarding the rights of illegal immigrants with adverse effects both in the internal the balance of the host countries and the possibility of using their refoulement mechanism, which is now being attempted to eliminate.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which addresses fundamental issues and strongly condemns the lack of humanity shown on European borders. Social inclusion and integration of migrants and refugees and the granting of international protection in the host society is part of a dynamic and multi-dimensional process, in which the respect for European values must be a priority. I support the call on Member States to apply integration policies as swiftly as possible and with adequate dedicated resources, and to develop them in cooperation with national institutions, local governments, schools, NGOs, as well as migrants and refugee communities. It is important to consider that that access to education is one of the foundations for the integration of refugees. We will continue fighting for the principles of decency and equality, and will not accept any form of discrimination in Europe.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. — During our December plenary sessions, we always pay special attention to the human rights situation around the world. Unfortunately, the picture is only deteriorating: not only individuals, but entire groups of people are at risk every day. The very existence of certain religious minorities, including Christians in the Middle East, is at risk. Crowds are forced to leave their homes, saving their lives. They are the real refugees, to whom the EU must provide all the assistance to protect their lives and to facilitate their return to their homeland. To do this, however, it is not enough to talk about the issue, but to take concrete action: it is up to our financial assistance and global cooperation that allows refugees to return to their homes. Rebuilding their homes, schools and churches is at stake. These Christian communities need humanitarian attention and help more than ever. The final text of the report also pays particular attention to the issue of national minorities. Ensuring equality in practice between national minorities and the majority nation is essential. This is true for all aspects of life — social, economic, political or cultural life. Particular attention should be paid to ensuring the protection of national and linguistic minorities during the accession process, as experience has shown that minority rights can be adequately ensured during the accession process.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. — In its report on the situation of human rights and democracy in the world and the EU's policy in this regard, the European Parliament expresses grave concern that the protection of human rights worldwide is subject to serious threats. The document underlines the Union's long-term commitment to promoting human rights, including freedom of religion, freedom of expression and minority rights. However, I regret to note that the report unilaterally addresses the issue of migration affecting Europe as a human rights issue, ignoring other important aspects of it, such as the protection of the EU's external borders or the legitimacy of border crossing requirement. It is well known that Hungary's position on migration differs from the EU's official policy in several respects. Although it is worth mentioning that the report distinguishes between migrants and refugees in line with the views of the European People's Party, I abstained with my fellow Members from Fidesz.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - Human rights are one of the key foundations of the EU, along with democracy and the rule of law. An important element is the strengthening of civil society, which is committed to the effective protection of human rights.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. Whilst we fully support efforts to improve human rights and democracy, we cannot support EU activity in this or any other area. The vote on Article 148(2) regarding Christianity was un-whipped and each MEP voted according to their own conscience.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which has been adopted in response to the EU annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2015, approved by the European Council on 20 June 2016. It underlines the fact that the universality of human rights is being seriously challenged in many parts of the world and that the EU should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. — The report on human rights and democracy in the world is, like the Nagy report voted yesterday, a compulsory exercise of this Parliament. It is also an opportunity, this year, to add to the situation in the European Union as regards migrants, Roma, LGBTI people, prisons, etc. It is strange that European democracies find themselves in the same general basket as Zimbabwe, Saudi Arabia, China or the “Islamic State” group... The aim of this report, in addition to the litany of good feelings, is above all to give meaning, an object and even an appearance of existence to a common external action of the European Union at the expense of national diplomacy. But even this minimal base, which is intended to be consensual, is not credible. The number, nature and extent of sanctions, where they exist, are derisory in terms of the alleged violations and the intensity of your indignations. The list of countries that are subject to it is strangely lacunar. And the inconsistent results. The diplomacy of influence, the famous “soft power”, which won the European Union's Nobel Peace Prize, is a model that never really worked.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The international community has been unable to curb war conflicts and massacres beyond its borders, and to support democratic processes that have been able to prevent the displacement of thousands of refugees and the deaths of thousands during the annual reporting period. The European guidelines on human rights seem to us insufficient and with its policies the Union has been complicit in the most important humanitarian crisis of recent decades. I have not found a defence of social rights in this report and articles that use the defence of human rights as a strategy for trade penetration in third countries. Voluntary principles for the control of multinationals are not sufficient. I am obviously against further European military integration. If we really want to work to maintain consistency with the defence of human rights, as advocated in this report, we must firmly face xenophobic reactions, rethink our trade policies, and not allow people without rights into our territory. For the defence of the rights of all and our obligation to defend them, I voted abstention on this report.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because, in the face of an increasingly critical global situation in respect of human rights, Parliament sends a strong message that the Union remains firm in its promotion and defence, through all its external policies. Especially in times of insecurity and crisis, the Union must be faithful to the fundamental values that inspire it. In this regard, we Socialists have managed to introduce into the text a clear request for the effective protection of the rights of refugees and asylum-seekers — because we believe that Europe has not lived up to its commitments in managing the arrival of hundreds of thousands of people entitled to protection — and consistent solutions and long - term effects on migration in line with respect for human rights. In this report we also show serious concern at the continued reduction of civil society space that can be seen in multiple countries — with a serious deterioration of fundamental freedoms of association and expression — often under the excuse of the fight against terrorism, and we also call for improvements in protection mechanisms of activists and human rights defenders.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with human rights and democracy in the world and the EU's policy in this area. The report contains too many elements. We stress that we are in no way against human rights, but we are their first ambassadors. However, the report actually promotes further all the mechanisms that it currently has in operation, many of which we have criticisms from time to time. It supports the CFSP, the European army, the Sophia mechanism, the EU's immigration policy and so on, policies which we believe are contrary to the objective of defending human rights. For all these reasons we abstained on this report.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the policies of the European Union in this regard for 2015. A few days ago we celebrated an international day of human rights, so today's discussion on the state of compliance with them in the year 2015 fits perfectly into the time of reflection on this subject. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights has been in place for nearly 70 years, however, I have the feeling that, in the face of violent conflicts and the rising tide of violence in the world, the common struggle to uphold these laws has not been so important and needed. Issues such as the right to life and personal security, freedom of religion, assembly or prohibition of torture guarantee people a peaceful and dignified existence in their countries of residence, and reduce the need for often dangerous and uncertain migration. I therefore believe that the European Union must fight with full vigour and determination to respect universal human rights in the world. In this context, the effective implementation of the Human Rights and Democracy Action Plan 2015-2019 is particularly important.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report to protect human rights all over the world, to assess how they are affected by counter-terrorism, trade or development measures. This topic is becoming sensitive in the context of migration, which is why urgent long-term measures and coherent human rights solutions are required. This is the aim of preventing human rights violations, especially in the current context of refugees, illegal migrants and asylum seekers. The report insists that human rights clauses should be systematically introduced into all international agreements and that the business community must play an important role in promoting human rights and democracy in the world.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted for the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and European Union policy in this area (2016/2219 (INI)), which expresses serious concern about the fact that the promotion and protection of human rights and democratic values are being threatened across of the world. There is a problem of freedom of expression, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and freedom of assembly and association. There is an increasing number of repressive laws affecting civil society, which are being passed around the world under the pretext of fighting terrorism. The report underlines that the European Union is committed to foreign and security policies based on the promotion of democracy, the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity. It welcomes the adoption of the second EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy (2015-2019) and encourages the EU and its Member States to implement the actions envisaged in the plan in full, consistently, transparently and in a timely manner, and to reinforce support for democracy. It underlines the need for the EU to push for UN reforms aimed at strengthening the influence and strength of the rules-based multilateral system and ensuring more effective protection of human rights and advancing international law.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — The European Union's aim is to strengthen its diplomatic grip and interference capacities to the detriment of State sovereignty by the European Union. I voted against it.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because, in the face of an increasingly critical global situation in respect of human rights, Parliament sends a strong message that the Union remains firm in its promotion and defence, through all its external policies. Especially in times of insecurity and crisis, the Union must be faithful to the fundamental values that inspire it. In this regard, we Socialists have managed to introduce into the text a clear request for the effective protection of the rights of refugees and asylum-seekers — because we believe that Europe has not lived up to its commitments in managing the arrival of hundreds of thousands of people entitled to protection — and consistent solutions and long - term effects on migration in line with respect for human rights. In this report we also show serious concern at the continued reduction of civil society space that can be seen in multiple countries — with a serious deterioration of fundamental freedoms of association and expression — often under the excuse of the fight against terrorism, and we also call for improvements in protection mechanisms of activists and human rights defenders.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Josef Weidenholzer's report on human rights and democracy in the world. The report calls on Member States to place themselves as defenders of human rights in their state relations and in their relations with their fellow citizens. It also reverts to the urgency of protecting religious minorities persecuted by the Islamic State group, especially Eastern Christians.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report. It calls for the adoption of an EU asylum plan and for further military integration of European armed forces. I reject this.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which has been adopted in response to the EU annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2015. However, we have so much more to do, and the EU should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights. With so many human rights violations still existing in the world, we need to redouble our efforts to aid those who need it most, and the perpetrators of those violations must be held to account in every possible forum.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - As last year, the “Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World” is too comprehensive and goes beyond the necessary focus. There is overlap with the competences of other committees, particularly with regard to asylum or family reunification. As Liberal-Conservative Reformers, we have made a constructive contribution and are pleased that the rapporteur has included our points, such as the explicit mention of China, Russia and Turkey as countries that suppress their civil societies through repressive laws and practices. As a result, despite some criticisms, I have decided to support the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I was sorry, but I could not support the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area. I believe that important and burning themes opened up in it, but this message, which was supposed to be independent and impartial, all too often slid to political declarations, which I could not accept.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it devotes a whole chapter to the situation of people with disabilities. My motion has been included in the text for a more thorough examination of the effectiveness of projects relating to persons with disabilities and the involvement of local NGOs representing people with disabilities in the implementation of such projects with the words 'nothing about us, without us! ' principle. I am convinced that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities must be respected and that more projects are needed worldwide to promote the social integration of people with disabilities in their homes. We do not need to talk, but to act, not to export democracy, but to strengthen local communities. Local organisations need to be involved because they know exactly what is needed locally and they can also help to get the support really to the people for whom it is intended.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: in writing. — The comprehensive report on human rights and democracy in the world (2016/2219 (INI)) deserves appreciation and support. The report highlights the importance of international agreements and institutions to ensure compliance with human rights, annual reports and reports prepared at European Union level, as well as the inclusion of demands on the observance of human rights and the principles of democracy in the negotiations carried out within the foreign policy of the EU Member States and the Union itself. The report notes the victims of war conflicts and refugees, and the importance of cooperation with countries of origin and transit, which enables more efficiently to implement migration policies, manage migration flows and protect the most disadvantaged. It calls for the EU to encourage third countries to sign the Palermo Protocol against the smuggling of illegal immigrants and recalls the Valletta summit arrangements. The report addresses the situations of children whose number among refugees is rising, also children who arrive unaccompanied, also children who are missing or separated from their parents and calls for adequate health, social and educational care to be provided and protected from violence. I support most of the comments and demands in the report and the call for Member States to implement the EU Human Rights Action Plan 2015-2019.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Union is constantly committed to the implementation of common policies for security and foreign affairs, based on principles of democracy, the rule of law, the universality of human rights and fundamental freedoms. Parliament's report expresses concern about violence, persecution and discrimination against religious minorities around the world and proposes recommendations to ensure that the rights of religious minorities are respected. It is therefore called for interfaith dialogues to be undertaken with the certainty that minorities are protected and paying more attention in the Middle East, where religious groups are the subject of persecution by terrorist groups. The report also points out that conflicts, wars and hostile governments are the main causes of migration and reiterates the need for distinguishing between refugees and migrants, always keeping in mind international human rights standards and with the intention of finding consistent, sustainable and long-term solutions. Confident that these initiatives can contribute to improving the situation of minorities, I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on human rights and democracy in the world and the policy of the European Union on this matter. In fact, this report, as every year, intends to strengthen the diplomatic role of the European Union by using human rights as a lever for encroachment on State action. The report also assumes a willingness to interfere in the affairs of third States in the name of defending humanitarian ideas.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because it only launderes the Union's foreign policy, which is only motivated by geostrategic and economic interests, with the mantle of human rights.

name: Sabine Lösing (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted today against the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this field (2016/2219 (INI)) because, on the one hand, in paragraph 35, “more extensive military integration, with the willingness and flexibility of [the] European armed forces to be able to and so that the military concept of R2P is strongly supported. In addition, paragraph 36 of the report clearly advocates 'CSDP operations such as the Sophia military operation of the European Union naval forces in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED) ', which 'serve to effectively combat the smuggling of migrants' and 'calls on the EU to continue and extend such operations'. These are two demands that I firmly reject, which is why I rejected the report in its entirety.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: in writing. - As last year, the “Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World” is too comprehensive and goes beyond the necessary focus. There is overlap with the competences of other committees, particularly with regard to asylum or family reunification. As Liberal-Conservative Reformers, we have made a constructive contribution and are pleased that the rapporteur has included our points, such as the explicit mention of China, Russia and Turkey as countries that suppress their civil societies through repressive laws and practices. As a result, despite some criticisms, I have decided to support the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted against. I do not agree with the call for Member States to provide migrants with access to education, housing and health, free of charge. I disagree with the call for the establishment of a single EU asylum system. On the contrary, I think the Czech Republic should retain its functional system of asylum proceedings and not be subject to any common European one.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The European Union stands for a common foreign and security policy and all other policies with an external dimension based on the advancement of democracy, the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The report highlights concerns about various forms of violent action, persecution, threats, harassment, disappearing or incarceration. I did not support this report since it, in addition to protecting minorities, proposes the protection of LGBT communities, and a strategy to promote and protect the rights of LGBTI persons, which I do not support.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament has expressed serious concern that the protection of human rights and democratic values are under threat worldwide. Parliament has called on all the EU institutions and Member States to act on their commitments to promote democracy and the rule of law, protect human rights and fundamental freedoms, including the right to development by all peaceful means, and to place human rights at the centre of the EU’s relations with all third countries.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. - Respect and rigorous promotion of human rights and democracy must be a permanent part of the Union's internal and external policies. The Commission and the Member States must be committed to maximizing these values both in the EU and around the world. This role is particularly important at the moment when the world is swept away in war conflicts, migration, terrorism, organised crime, corruption and deepening the disparities between the poor and the rich.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy Around the World and the European Union's policy on this issue, for the reasons I explained in detail at the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/12/2016, as and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important response to the European Council’s annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and highlights several global and regional challenges we face, particularly the rights of women, children, migrants, refugees, the LGBTI community and indigenous peoples across the world. It is crucial that greater political be invested in creating long-term, comprehensive and coherent solutions to these dilemmas based on respected international human rights norms.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The text is an annual report on human rights and aims to strengthen the diplomatic role of the European Union. In fact, under the guise of a better defence of human rights, it wishes to encroach on the action of States (paragraphs 19 to 25) or to interfere in the affairs of third countries (paragraphs 42 to 48), which we oppose.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Today we discussed the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and on EU policy in this field. The report contains a number of alarming messages such as the fact that every 200th child in the world is a child refugee, and the number of child refugees doubled between 2005 and 2015, alarming as well as figures on internally resettled persons from Iraq and Syria, as well as Ukraine, with a combined total of 1.4 million in 2015. I agree with some core ideas, such as the need to address the global problem of poverty and malnutrition-related diseases as much as the lack of access to pharmaceuticals. Because I am not a supporter of the concept of migration policy as modified in the report, and I am no longer sure that the Union itself can serve as a model for someone who fully adheres to human rights and can lead by example, when voting on the report as a whole I abstained.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report deals with the situation of human rights and democracy in the world and the policy adopted in the EU in this area, calling for a more objective and accessible approach to the general public. The report sets out positive measures, particularly with regard to the rights of migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, the fight against trafficking networks in human beings, women's rights, universal repulsion of the death penalty, etc. other measures, which are in no way positive either for the Member States or for third countries, such as the development of a common foreign and security policy, based on the idea of militarisation of the European Union. I abstained.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The rapporteur calls for, among other things, legal migration, extensive rights for LGBTI, full access to education and health for migrants, and also an interventionist policy on the part of the EU, I voted against this report.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I approved the annual report on human rights and democracy, which raises the issue of human rights violations across the world. As a member of the European Parliament’s Subcommittee on Human Rights, I believe we should take a clear stand to defend our universal human rights worldwide, including for women and children, migrants, refugees, the LGBTI community and indigenous peoples.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the situation of human rights in the world in 2015. Pnaesh discusses the problems of a social, legal, political and economic nature that migrants, women, people with disabilities, communities of religious and ethnic minorities in the world.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This year's general report on human rights in the world contains support for some of the usual taboos. He advocated a universal moratorium on the death penalty while stressing that the United States still practised it. He called for the closure of the Guantanamo base. But it is also persevering in the endless path of a European army outside democratic control. It “calls for enhanced European military integration in order to deal with threats and to respond to serious human rights violations, genocide or ethnic cleansing”. This logic of global human rights policing would make sense only within the framework of the United Nations, while respecting the sovereignty of States. Finally, the report includes a list of prisoners of conscience who are not allowed to amend. Russia, China, are still in a good position. But we never talk about US prisoners, like Mumia Abu Jamal, a journalist and political activist, who has been behind bars for more than 30 years. I am voting against not to endorse these convictions with variable geometry.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — This annual report on human rights and the action of the European Union in this field is in fact a strengthening of the EU's diplomatic role on the pretext of human rights to interfere in the actions of States. Moreover, this interference in the sovereignty of States is fully assumed in the name of the defence of humanitarian workers. I opposed this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — (NL) Despite the fact that the annual report on human rights in the world has become a classic in the EP, we remain extremely concerned about the increasing violations of human rights. It is the EU's job to show leadership and act where human rights are under attack. This year, the report rightly focuses on the instruments that the EU uses to promote the idea of freedom, the advancement of democracy and the rule of law. That is why the EU's human rights policy must be integrated into all policy areas with a foreign dimension. This also means that political conclusions must be drawn if human rights dialogues do not produce the desired result. Particular attention this year also to the many thousands of people fleeing war and armed conflict. These flows of refugees are a challenge for Europe, not only because of the need to find effective solutions, but also because in Europe universal values are put to the test so much that they threaten to divide our society. Finally, my concern goes to those countries where execution is still being carried out. The report rightly calls for an ongoing EU fight against the death penalty.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which underlines the fact that the universality of human rights is being seriously challenged in many parts of the world and that the EU should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights, which is very important. However, I have never supported any references to abortion and women’s sexual and reproductive health and rights, which, in my opinion, are strictly a competence of the Member States.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — On 20 June 2016, the Council adopted a document entitled “The EU Annual Report 2015 on Human Rights and Democracy in the World”. The Committee on Foreign Affairs proposes its opinion on this report in its motion for a resolution by Parliament. The motion is undoubtedly thorough and detailed, but, in my view, it does not have the necessary balance. That is why I abstained in the final vote on its adoption.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — We are voting against this report, which aims to strengthen the EU's diplomatic role by using human rights as a means of encroachment on state action. The report also assumes a willingness to interfere in the affairs of third States in the name of the defence of humanitarian aid, a will already present in many other reports.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: This report aims to strengthen the diplomatic role of the European Union by using human rights as a means of encroachment on State action (points 19 to 25). The report also assumes a willingness to interfere in the affairs of third States in the name of the defence of humanitarian workers (items 42 to 28). I am therefore voting against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it takes stock of the human rights of women and children, migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, LGBTI persons and indigenous people, and assesses how they are affected by counter-terrorism, trade or development measures. On migration, the urgent need for long-term and coherent solutions based on human rights is stressed, given the growing number of human rights abuses against refugees, irregular migrants and asylum seekers on their route to Europe. On business and human rights, the rapporteur insists that human rights clauses should systematically be introduced in all international agreements, observing that these go hand in hand and that the business community has an important role to play in promoting human rights and democracy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. — As every year, the European Parliament votes on a report on human rights and democracy in the world and the policy of the European Union in this field. The 2015 report contained several terms hostile to Russia, which remains an ally of the European Union. That is why I abstained on the final vote.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the 2015 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the EU’s policy on this matter. The report reveals concerns regarding the promotion and protection of human rights and democratic values.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report because I consider it a complete and realistic document on the most important human rights developments in the world and in the EU. Unfortunately, the day-to-day reality, but also the content of this report, does not give me the impression that the overall situation is improving. In fact, we are seeing a clear deterioration in the situation regarding respect for universal human rights in many parts of the world. More than ever, the European Union must be coherent in its external actions, and this means much more consistency between the Member States, the EEAS and the Council. At the same time, as I have said repeatedly, in order to be respected by our external partners, we need to show tolerance and openness in our dialogues and relationships with the various cultures and civilizations of this world, and in certain situations, to listen to all the arguments put forward before cataloging.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the 2015 report on human rights and democracy in the world and on the policy of the European Union in this field, which includes, inter alia, the fight against all forms of discrimination, human trafficking, interconnection of trade, business and human rights, persons with disabilities, rights of women and children, rights of indigenous people and members of minorities, international humanitarian law, freedom of thought, conscience and religion or belief, freedom of expression online and off-line and through audiovisual and other media sources, combating terrorism or capital punishment. In this context, I believe that the EU should maintain an ambitious policy on the global abolition of capital punishment in accordance with the EU's general principles on capital punishment, which were revised in 2013, and continue to oppose the death penalty. In the context of combating illegal migration, I fully support the launched operation of the European Union Naval Forces in the Mediterranean (EU NAVFOR MED), which is an effective way to combat smuggling migrants, which is why the EU should continue operations of this kind and intensify them.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I opposed this report because the report calls for full access to education, health and much more for migrants.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The report focuses on the situation of human rights and democracy in 2015, covering all areas including migration, human trafficking, women's rights, children, LGTB and freedom of expression.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - In an environment marked by instability and conflicts in the Middle East and regions of Asia and Africa, the resulting migration crisis and repeated terrorist attacks against civilians, 2015 was a year of particular challenges for the European Union and the international community in general. Islamic State has extended its action to regions of Syria and Iraq, committing mass atrocities and human rights violations, particularly against minority groups. There has also been a worrying tendency to intimidate and attacks against activists and members of civil society. There is a strong concern about the numerous, ever-increasing attempts to reduce the margins of civil society and human rights defenders, and the increase in the number of repressive laws adopted around the world, under the guise of fight against terrorism (through the introduction of counter-terrorism laws). I voted in favour of the report as the current complex crises and the widespread violations and abuses of human rights and fundamental freedoms require ever more determined efforts by the EU. The EU must respond to the challenges through targeted actions, through systematic and coordinated use of the instruments at its disposal and an improved impact of its policies and tools on the ground.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. — The intensification of EU intervention 'wherever land' for the interests of the European business groups it serves - which it even calls provocatively a 'protection responsibility' - on the pretext of human rights and democracy is expressed in the report voted against by the European Parliamentary Group of the Greek Communist Party. The report reveals the so-called sensitivity of the EU: on the one hand, it calls for the promotion of European military integration in order to improve the readiness and flexibility of the European armed forces', in other words the bloodshed of the peoples, which brings shelter, poverty and misery, and on the other hand, it reserves for refugees and migrants uprooted from politics its own and other imperialist forces an intensification of repression by “deploying CSDP missions such as the EU naval force in the Mediterranean, Operation Sophia (EURONAVFOR MED)”, etc. At the same time, claiming that it seeks “inclusive and sustainable development that allows for a fair redistribution of the wealth produced”, it consciously conceals that the capitalist barbarism it serves sacrificed labor grassroots rights for the profitability of business groups. Their rights will only be guaranteed by the people when they take power and become owners of the wealth they produce, released by the EU and every imperialist alliance.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleague's motion for a resolution because I believe that, despite dealing with a complex and delicate subject, we are articles in a coherent and thoughtful text, the result of a Accurate work. During 2016, the fiftieth anniversary of the adoption of the two international pacts of the United Nations (on civil and political rights and economic, social and cultural rights) human rights has been strained by the rampage of strong waves of violence on a global scale. The European Union, as a community of values and principles, before as an economic community, represents a bulwark for the defence of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, highlighting the vocation to protect the weakest categories and victims of abuses. This vocation is also seen in relations with third countries and over the past year, cooperation with them has played a fundamental role in the fight against terrorism, which by definition attacks the essence of human rights, annihilating the right to life. I agree with the objective of strengthening justice and combating impunity and the desire to develop a more comprehensive approach to democratisation processes. Therefore, I voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is committed to a Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and all other policies with an external dimension founded on the advancement of democracy, rule of law, the universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of it as it pays particular attention to women, children, people with disabilities, elderly people and EU human rights policy in this regard. The report further underlines the fact that conflicts, wars and failures of governance constitute key causes of migration and displacement. In its holistic approach to finding sustainable, long-term and coherent solutions, based on international human rights standards, it highlights the importance of differentiating between refugees and migrants.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - In today's world, human rights are systematically violated on a daily basis. War, violence and persecution escalate. In Syria and Iraq ISIS has committed genocide against Christians and Ygues, Boko Haram is doing the same in Nigeria. The rules of war are not respected, so access to humanitarian aid is prevented, innocent civilians are killed, hospitals, schools, churches are bombed... Freedom of thought, conscience and religion in many countries of the world has been completely abolished. We live in a world where most people are in everyday fear for a naked life. We live in a world where children don't know anything other than war. That's the reality. It is therefore unacceptable to me that in the 2015 annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and European Union policy in this area we deal with trivial matters and ideologically coloured policies. The EU has a responsibility in its common foreign and security policy to care primarily about the indivisibility of human rights and respect for human dignity and fundamental freedoms. The right to live in peace without persecution, without fear for tomorrow must be the focus of the EU, not the different quasi rights being put to the forefront.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I supported this report because it accurately analyzes the situation of human rights and democracy in the world in 2015 and how they are threatened by xenophobic sentiments, discriminatory laws and nationalist and extremist movements. The universality of human rights is denied in too many areas of the world. Women and children, migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, LGBTI people, indigenous people and human rights activists are the most at risk categories. 2015 was a critical year for the European Union. The arrival of so many refugees has tested European solidarity as ever before. But especially during times of economic crisis and generalized insecurity, it is important that Europe remains true to its core values: democracy, the rule of law and human rights. And that must be true so much for his internal and external policies. All international agreements on migration, development and trade should include clauses that provide for respect for democracy and human rights, which are complementary and not alternative to the economic well-being of any society.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — Article 21 The TEU commits the European Union to a common foreign and security policy guided by the principles that inspired its creation and which the Union seeks to improve worldwide: the principles of democracy, the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, the principles of equality and solidarity and respect for the principles of the United Nations Charter and international law. This report underlines that respect for fundamental human rights has been seriously questioned in many parts of the world and that the EU needs to ensure coherence between its internal and foreign policy in respect of human rights. S&D has asked that particular emphasis be placed on the human rights of women and children, migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, and LGBTI people. On migration, long-term and coherent solutions based on human rights are urgently needed in view of the increasing number of human rights violations of refugees, migrants and asylum seekers on their way to Europe. With respect to business and human rights, we have reiterated a strong call for the systematic introduction of human rights clauses into all international agreements, including trade and investment agreements, that are concluded or are yet to be concluded between the EU and third countries.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report does not differ from those of previous years. It is characterised, in essence, by a manipulative and reductive vision of human rights - political, social, economic and cultural - using them as a justification for interference and political pressure on third countries. There is a mild or omission stance with countries aligned with EU policies and strategy as opposed to the approach to hard-criticised countries. Criticism which, for the most part, is due not to their practices, but rather to be submissive to US imperialism and the EU. The omission of the grotesque and systematic violations of human rights that have been added throughout 2015 in various Member States in response to the humanitarian refugee crisis, either by the own decision of each government or through the implementation of the criminal migration policies that the EU has imposed, that feed and promote racism and xenophobia. The omission of extremely serious situations such as Western Sahara and Palestine persists, passing a rag on the aggression of Morocco and Israel on those peoples. Not a word about the consequences of austerity policies, and the deterioration of living conditions and violations of human rights which also ensue: poverty, social exclusion, hunger, housing loss. We voted against it.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to United Nations statistics, 65.3 million people were forcibly displaced during 2015. Another 21.3 million have been officially designated as refugees. While this fact is regrettable, I believe these figures have sufficient telling value on their own. I voted in favour of the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world last year, because I fully agree with its call aimed at the European Union and the Member States. The situation on the field of respect for human rights and democracy deteriorated in a few places in 2015. There is therefore a need for the European Union's Second Action Plan for Human Rights and Democracy to be held more responsibly. This is true even in the context of the refugee crisis. We must find effective and sustainable solutions that will not lead to the internal implosion of our whole. The European Commission, as well as the whole Union, still has the advantage of a stronger position in the negotiation of European accession terms. It is therefore necessary to take advantage of this opportunity to try to improve as much as possible respect for rights and democratic principles in candidate countries or countries identified as potential candidate countries. Likewise, it needs to project these elements into other external policies, as consistently as possible.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to introduce Parliament’s human rights annual report as a response to the EU annual report on human rights and democracy in the world in 2015. The importance of the report is that it underlines the fact that the universality of human rights is being challenged in many parts of the world. I must stress that the EU should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights. I fully support the S&D rapporteur, who diligently included the accounts of the human rights of women and children, migrants, refugees, asylum seekers, LGBTI persons and indigenous people, and assessed how they are affected by counter—terrorism, trade or development measures. On migration, I emphasise the urgent need for long-term and coherent solutions based on human rights, given the growing number of human rights abuses against refugees, irregular migrants and asylum seekers on their route to Europe. On business and human rights, I insist that human rights clauses should systematically be introduced in all international agreements. We must move forward to continue improving human rights, outlined in this report, in the face of the migrant crisis and big business.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The report positively addresses assistance for internally displaced persons in Ukraine and the protection of human rights defenders and journalists around the world. However, there are also many aspects that are troubleshooting. Unfortunately, the subject matter of the report is also devoted to asylum and migration, and instructs Member States about connecting families and opening legal migration routes. Among other things, the report put forward a proposal for free and high-quality education, healthcare and accommodation for refugees, as well as their access to the labour market. In the section on women's rights, she is calling for the right to access safe and legal abortion. In light of the comparable number of positive and negative aspects of the report, I abstained from the vote.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the situation of human rights and democracy in the world and the policy of the European Union in this regard. We are particularly concerned by the increase in acts of violence, persecution, intolerance, discrimination against all minorities and the persistence of armed conflicts around the world. Europe is a symbol of humanity and must remain a model. That is why the policy of supporting human rights and democracy must be at the heart of all the Union's external policies, such as development, migration, security, the fight against terrorism, neighbourhood policy, enlargement or trade, through the establishment of human rights requirements. We are more than ever committed to promoting human rights worldwide and we are very proud to have presented the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Mind this year to Nadia Murad Bassi Taha and Lamiya Aji Bashar, two Yazidi young Yazidi, survivors of the barbarism of the Islamic State group.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. Whilst we fully support efforts to improve human rights and democracy, we cannot support EU activity in this or any other area. The vote on Article 148(2) regarding Christianity was un-whipped and each MEP voted according to their own conscience.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution, which addresses the main challenges related to fundamental rights within the European Union, including migration and child protection. The vote on this text was not only an opportunity to deplore the increasing level of hate speech in certain institutions, political parties and media: the European Union must set a good example. And in this case, Member States have a role to play. For example, they should intensify their efforts to promote European values, tolerance and community, avoiding stigma. But also in terms of migration. For 2015, 10,000 unaccompanied refugee and migrant children have been reported missing in the European Union. Thus, vulnerable groups, including unaccompanied children, should be able to be identified as soon as possible. The resolution therefore calls on Member States to strengthen guardianship systems for unaccompanied children and encourages them to keep families together. There is still a long way to go.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I endorsed the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union's policy in this area. The document shows the important role played by the European Union in this area and, unfortunately, how few can be done.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: in writing. — The 2015 report on human rights and democracy in the world rightly highlights the increase in violence and discrimination against women and girls in recent years. It also refers to the violence, prosecution and discrimination suffered by LGBTI people in many parts of the world. Based on this worrying observation, this report calls for several measures. With regard to women, the report suggests extending measures to address gender-based violence in the digital environment. It also encourages Member States, the Commission and the EEAS to promote the economic and political empowerment of women in developing countries. With regard to LGBTI people, the report recommends that EU institutions and Member States contribute more to reflecting on the recognition of same-sex marriage as a political and social issue related to civil and human rights. I therefore supported this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: The European Union (EU) is committed to the implementation of its common foreign and security policy, as well as to all other external policies relating to respect for the principles of democracy, the rule of law, universality and defence of human rights (HR) and fundamental freedoms. This report reports on the various forms of violation (and/or attempted violation) of human rights worldwide. We are mainly talking about violations of the rule of law and the exercise of fundamental freedoms, such as restrictions on freedom of expression, persecution, intolerance, discrimination on the basis of beliefs, among other types of atrocities that deserve special attention when adopting preventive measures of this kind of crimes. Migration flows have captured the EU's attention for their causes, multiple implications and involving human beings whose dignity must, above all, be respected. The Dialogues dedicated to HR are an effective tool for bilateral engagement and cooperation, as reflected in the Action Plan for HR and Democracy 2015-2019, as well as other defense measures based on international standards. As I agree with the need to enforce and respect the universal principles for the preservation of HR, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights, Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area. The reason for this is that the report identifies the points on which the European Union is committed, for a common foreign and security policy and all other policies based on the progress of democracy, the rule of law, universality and the indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The report also provides an impetus for finding sustainable and long-term solutions to current problems, such as violence and persecution, based on international human rights standards.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against because the annual report on human rights calls for greater European military integration and to improve the preparation and flexibility of the European armed forces, 'to enable them to respond to threats and cases of serious human rights violation', which is a total contradiction; to say, it intends to increase security and defense guarantees of fundamental rights. An excuse to justify the increase in military capabilities. This biased and reductionist view of the concept of protecting the human rights of the population does not know the impact and importance of economic and political measures for the safeguarding of citizens' social and economic rights. On the other hand, it is interventionist and seeks to emulate the US interventionist policing policy of the world, as it underlines the need to consolidate in international law the concept of “responsibility to protect” and to give the Union the opportunity to “lead meaningful initiatives and actions to protect civilians, even when they are under the threat of their own State”.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, however there are certain elements of it that I agree with.  Christians are being persecuted in the Middle East, especially by ISIS, and all nations should recognise this.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, which underlines that the universality of human rights is seriously being challenged in many parts of the world and that the EU should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Another liberal so—called ‘progressive’ report claiming to solve violence against women by ensuring they have the power to kill their children! Or tackling poverty by reducing the size of the population. No state can thrive when its population is in fatal decline. Europe should solve its own demographic winter before exporting its ideology to the world.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the draft EP resolution on the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area. In the resolution, we expressed our deep concern that the promotion and protection of human rights and democratic values is threatened globally and that the universality of human rights is being seriously challenged in many parts of the world, including under authoritarian regimes as well as terrorist groups. Today, many human rights defenders are victims of attacks, so we must systematically and unequivocally condemn the murder of human rights defenders, persecution, endangerment, harassment, disappearance, imprisonment or arbitrary arrests. In the motion for a resolution, we also condemned all forms of discrimination, including discrimination based on race, colour, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, language, culture, religion or belief, social origin, gender, age or any circumstance. Human rights enshrined in UN conventions are universal, interrelated and interconnected, and their respect must be enforced in the event of violations.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — Unfortunately, human rights abuses are a daily reality in many places in the world and, for example, these days, we are seeing an even greater escalation of the conflict in Syria by the President Assad or the recent bombing of humanitarian convoys. I welcome this report to defend religious freedoms, especially Christians in the Middle East. Nevertheless, I could not support this report because of reservation of conscience, because some parts of it are in direct conflict with the protection of the unborn life.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and European Union Policy in this area expresses serious concern about the threat of protection of human rights and democratic values worldwide and undermining the universality of human rights in many parts of the world, including in authoritarian regimes and through the functioning of terrorist groups such as Daiš. It calls on all EU institutions and Member States to pursue their commitments to promote democracy and the rule of law, protect and exercise human rights and fundamental freedoms. The conviction of attacks on journalists, judges, prosecutors, as well as environmental activists and human rights defenders around the world is also important, which we unfortunately still witness very often. The report also takes a clear view that the European Union must place human rights a central place in its relationship with all third countries, including strategic partners, while it is important that the same commitment is reflected in both internal and foreign policy. I am also pleased that the report is progressive enough and includes strong pieces on areas such as LGBTI rights, combating all forms of discrimination, human trafficking, migration, sexual and reproductive rights, environmental migration, freedom of expression online, supporting advocates human rights, etc. Due to all of the above, I also supported the report.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: . — (NL) The European Parliament wishes to use the Council's annual report on European activities in the field of democracy and human rights in third world countries to bring about a necessary debate on the overall European human rights policy. The report adopted has become a difficult to read and thick piece of work. But fortunately it is seasoned with a strong progressive touch due to the many green points that have been recorded. The report is therefore much more ambitious than previous years. The Greens want to demonstrate with their recommendations that we must awaken from the illusion that human rights are respected worldwide. Unfortunately, the rise in violence and intimidation against human rights defenders is just one example of this. It is crucial that the EP calls on Mrs Mogherini, Vice-President/High Representative Foreign Policy, to impose an EU arms embargo on countries accused of human rights violations. It is also very innovative in the report that, for the very first time, a chapter on the rights of older people has been included. This is a very good report. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - As last year, the “Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World” is too comprehensive and goes beyond the necessary focus. There is overlap with the competences of other committees, particularly with regard to asylum or family reunification. As Liberal-Conservative Reformers, we have made a constructive contribution and are pleased that the rapporteur has included our points, such as the explicit mention of China, Russia and Turkey as countries that suppress their civil societies through repressive laws and practices. As a result, despite some criticisms, I have decided to support the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union has long advocated respect for human and civil rights in the world. 2015 was particularly tragic as conflicts escalated in several parts of the world, including Iraq, Syria and Ukraine. In future, the European Union should not only state human rights violations, but should act actively, for example, through its economic diplomacy, in order to enforce improvements and punishment of the culprits.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The European Union has committed itself to the Common Foreign and Security Policy/Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), which rests on democracy, the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, respect for human dignity, principles of equality and solidarity, and respect for the principles of the United Nations Charter and international law. Promoting and preserving the indivisibility and universality of human rights are among the key objectives of EU foreign and security policy. The EU believes that cooperation with civil society and human rights defenders in third countries should be one of the top priorities in promoting human rights and combating human rights violations. Also, the EU is committed to promoting human rights in all areas of external relations “without exception”. I support this report because I believe that human rights must be respected, in accordance with the fundamental principles of freedom, democracy, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law, and that every individual is entitled to the same without exception.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and European Union Policy in this area. We must not allow the action of terrorist groups such as ISIS in many parts of the world jeopardises the protection of fundamental human rights and democratic values. I support the call from the Annual Report for all EU institutions and Member States to pursue their commitments to promote democracy and the rule of law, to protect and enforce human rights and fundamental freedoms, including the right to develop through peaceful means, and to give human They give rights a central place in the EU's relations with all third countries, including strategic partners, and at all levels.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the 2015 Annual Report on Democracy in the World and EU Policy in this area, because it is based on the fact that the European Union and its common foreign and security policies are based on promoting democracy, rule of law and universality of fundamental human rights. The report highlights continued violence and discrimination against religious minorities variously in the world and calls for the protection of these minorities. In the context of the migration crisis, it cautions that conflicts, wars and dysfunctional governments are the main cause of migration — while distinguishing migrants and refugees — and promotes a comprehensive long-term approach towards the creation of functioning societies through development assistance and investment. But it also stresses that trade and human rights must go hand in hand.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We are in every way defending respect for and strengthening human rights. However, the report promotes all the mechanisms that the EU has which operate in the opposite direction. It supports the CFSP, promotes the strengthening of the European army, the Sophia mechanisms, the further militarisation of the Union and the strengthening of its intervention in the internal affairs of other States under the pretext of protecting democracy and human rights. For these reasons, we abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The report attempts legislative intervention in the safeguarding of the rights of illegal immigrants with adverse effects both on the internal balance of the host countries and on the possibility of using their refoulement mechanism, which is now trying to eliminate.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
