text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the adoption of the annual report, mainly because it reflects the fact that the European Union still does not wish to succumb to its ambition to remain the flagbearer of human rights and democracy in the world. In particular, I agree with the statement that this, faced with the latest international challenges, particularly the refugee crisis, requires more than ever the coherence and credibility of the Union's external and internal policies, which has recently been disrupted internally by the governments of some EU Member States in the inhuman, degrading, discriminatory treatment of refugees. In this respect, too, the report confronts us with dramatic facts, but avoids the designation of specific Member States, but as a Hungarian politician and democrat, I had to bear in mind that, unfortunately, the Orbán Government today provides the most obvious European example. This is part of the overall picture of the current global situation of human rights, and it is also a serious internal challenge for the EU as a democratic community of values, which is hopefully driven by this year's EP report.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. “The protection of human rights and the promotion of democracy in the world are priorities not only for the European Parliament, but also for the European Union as a whole. There are many confessions in this regard, and without increased efforts by Member States and the Community, it will not be possible to effectively place human rights and democratic values at the heart of their relationship with foreign partners. In order to ensure that human rights are further integrated into the external aspects of EU policy, special emphasis must be placed on those areas that require renewal of policy commitments and additional efforts to support local actors. Countering and correcting human rights violations during military conflicts and crises is also crucial. There needs to be greater consistency in the response of the European Union in relation to such strategic policy areas as migration, trade and counter-terrorism, or deepening the effectiveness and improvement of the performance of EU human rights tools. The challenges of human rights in key areas such as freedom of speech, countering discrimination, gender equality or promoting economic, social and cultural rights are enormous. In support of the report, I am looking forward to a firmer effort from the European Union at the same time.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s human rights annual report is an assessment of the situation on human rights and democracy in the world in 2015 that I support. After having analysed the report, one can say that the universality of human rights is seriously being challenged in many parts of the world and that the EU should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights. There are more and more human rights breaches and violations every day. We need a common approach and concrete implementation in practice by utilising all instruments available for human right protection. I also support taking stock regularly of the human rights of women and children, migrants, ethnic minorities, refugees etc., and starting to take action on these so as to prevent gross abuse and stop the wide violation of human rights around the world.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the text of my colleague, whose concerns I share. I am deeply concerned that the promotion and protection of human rights and democratic values are being threatened throughout the world and that the universality of human rights is being strongly challenged in many parts of the world, including under certain totalitarian regimes and by terrorist groups such as ISIS . We are also concerned about increasing efforts to reduce the space for civil society and human rights defenders, the increasing limitation of freedom of assembly and expression, and the increasing number of repressive laws adopted around the world that have an impact on civil society. We need a clear condemnation!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy promotes the centrality of human rights in EU external policies. The report laments the state of human rights and democracy in 2015, which has come increasingly under threat. Further, the report called on the EU institutions and Member States to promote democracy and the rule of law and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms. I voted in favour of the report as it places human rights at the centre of the EU’s relations with all third countries, reinforcing the EU’s commitments to the protection of European values worldwide.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: in writing. — In its report on the situation of human rights and democracy in the world and the EU's policy in this regard, the European Parliament expresses grave concern that the protection of human rights worldwide is subject to serious threats. The document underlines the Union's long-term commitment to promoting human rights, including freedom of religion, freedom of expression and minority rights. However, I regret to note that the report unilaterally addresses the issue of migration affecting Europe as a human rights issue, ignoring other important aspects of it, such as the protection of the EU's external borders or the legitimacy of border crossing requirement. It is well known that Hungary's position on migration differs from the EU's official policy in several respects. Although it is worth mentioning that the report distinguishes between migrants and refugees in line with the views of the European People's Party, I nevertheless abstained with my fellow Members from Fidesz.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the “Motion for a Resolution on the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and European Union Policy in this area”. I agree with most of the text of this motion for a resolution. I consider the correct call for further military integration of the European Union with the aim of strengthening the flexibility of the EU's armed forces and to respond more effectively to cases of human rights violations and infringements of international humanitarian law. In particular, I would like to recall the European Parliament's resolution calling on the UN Security Council to ask the International Criminal Court to investigate the human rights violations of Christians committed by ISIL in Iraq and Syria and urge the need for the institutional protection that Christians in this area need. In particular, the cases of smuggling of migrants which are essential to trafficking in human beings should be taken into account and develop a unified approach within the Member States of the European Union to address this problem.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — As in previous years, the World Human Rights Report covers a wide range of topics such as religious freedoms, recognition of positive contributions of the business sector to human rights, protection of the journalistic profession, assistance to internally displaced persons and many others. I believe that respect for fundamental human rights must be an unquestionable and uncompromising civilizational achievement and, accordingly, I support most of the calls that this report contains. But I cannot agree that the right to abortion is a fundamental human right. I have already emphasized many times my firm view that the right of one being ceases at the moment when the right of another begins. So I voted abstentions.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and European Union Policy in this field for 2015. The European Union advocates for a common foreign policy and a policy of external dimension based on democracy, the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms. There are still attempts to shrin space to civil society, to limit freedom of expression and assembly. It is necessary to support a dedicated dialogue on human rights as a successful and effective tool for bilateral cooperation. We may still be concerned about continued violence and persecution and largely intolerance and discrimination against religious beliefs and minorities around the world. We should start interfaith dialogue and provide minorities with protection even to those in the Middle East (Yazidis, Christians, Muslim minorities - which are persecuted by various terrorist groups). In the field of human rights, special attention should be paid to women, children, people with disabilities and the elderly. Conflicts and wars are the main causes of migration and displacement. With a comprehensive approach, sustainable, long-term and coordinated solutions based on international human rights standards (differentiate between refugees and migrants) could be found. Trade and human rights must go hand in hand.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained with this report because the EU has been a de facto union of democratic double standards in recent years: very active with Hungary and Poland but completely absent with violations in Spain for example.  I take the opportunity to remember that last September, with 77% participation, Catalan pro-independentist parties achieved an absolute majority in the Catalan Parliament. 2 million voters voted for independence. Carme Forcadell was elected President of the Catalan Parliament and she allowed a debate on Catalan independence in September. On Friday Carme Forcadell has to appear in front of the Spanish court to make a statement, which follows orders from the Spanish Government. She could be banned from public office because she allowed Catalan MPs to debate on independence! Commissioner Jourová, dear colleagues, don’t be indifferent to the actions of the Spanish State against Catalan democratic politicians. Don’t let Spain undermine with total impunity our fundamental rights as Europeans.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — The report aims to strengthen the EU's diplomatic role by using human rights as a lever of pressure on state action. The report also assumes a willingness to interfere in the affairs of third States in the name of the defence of humanitarian workers. This text is in line with other human rights reports.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The report positively addresses assistance for internally displaced persons in Ukraine and the protection of human rights defenders and journalists around the world. Unfortunately, the subject matter of the report is very much in line with the themes of the work of the LIBE committee, in large part on asylum and migration. The report also instructs EU Member States on family reunification and opening legal migration routes. I abstained.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. − The European Union is one of the greatest achievements of European history and that thanks to the transforming power of the EU, its citizens and neighbouring countries, many of which have become EU Member States, can live in peace, stability and prosperity.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The international community has been unable to curb war conflicts and massacres beyond its borders, and to support democratic processes that have been able to prevent the displacement of thousands of refugees and the death of thousands of people during the annual reporting period. The European guidelines on human rights seem to us insufficient and with its policies the Union has been complicit in the most important humanitarian crisis of recent decades. I have not found a defence of social rights in this report and articles that use the defence of human rights as a strategy for trade penetration in third countries. Voluntary principles for the control of multinationals are not sufficient. I am obviously against further European military integration. If we really want to work to maintain consistency with the defence of human rights, as advocated in this report, we must firmly face xenophobic reactions, rethink our trade policies, and not allow people without rights into our territory. For the defence of the rights of all and our obligation to defend them, I voted abstention on this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it presents a sobering picture of the current situation regarding human rights: promotion and protection of human rights is under threat worldwide and the universality of rights is being challenged; civil society space is shrinking globally, and human rights defenders, notably on indigenous peoples’ rights and environmental rights, are increasingly subjected to violence and harassment.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn all attacks, intimidations, arrests, killings, harassment or repression against prosecutors, judges, scientists and journalists or any other profession whose independence and professional freedom are necessary to strengthen democratic society.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which underlines the fact that the universality of human rights is being seriously challenged in many parts of the world and that the EU should ensure coherence between its internal and external policies with regard to respect for human rights. The report is balanced and takes stock of the human rights of women and children, migrants, refugees and asylum seekers, LGBTI persons and indigenous people, and assesses how they are affected by counter-terrorism, trade and development measures.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Through this text, the European Parliament takes action on the thematic issues contained in the 2015 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World, submitted by the Council on 20 June. This report describes the Union's efforts over the past year to promote the universality of human rights. It emphasizes, for example, the adoption and progress made in the implementation of the new Plan of Action on Human Rights and Democracy 2015-2019, which underlines Community priorities at five years. The report indicates that the Union's foreign policy over the past year focused on promoting priorities such as the empowerment of human rights defenders and civil society, freedom of expression and association, the rights of women and children, the fight against torture and the abolition of the death penalty, discrimination and the promotion of accountability for human rights violations. It also explains how progress has been made in relations with third countries in this area, with Morocco, Azerbaijan and Cuba. I therefore supported this document with my vote.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour because internal and external cohesion in the field of human rights is essential to the credibility of EU human rights policy abroad.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of adopting the report on the annual report on human rights and democracy in the world 2015. For the most part, I considered the report to be a good albeit broad one. I deviated from my group's position, in particular in the paragraphs of the European Common Asylum System. I believe that decision-making on immigration should remain in the Member States. Coordination between Member States should be continued and increased.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - What moral does the European Union have when this report does not engage in self-criticism of human rights which are constantly violated within the borders of its Member States. It talks about the situation of refugees but says nothing about its causes and about the disastrous balance of European refugee policy. Of course, there are positive aspects in the report, for example the reference to the requirement for the closure of Guantanamo and some issues relating to the rights of women, people with disabilities, children and issues relating to the death penalty. However, this cannot in any way make us agree with the hypocrisy of the EU and the subjective and overarching way in which it looks at human rights.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The rapporteur calls for, among other things, legal migration, extensive rights for LGBTI, full access to education and health for migrants, and also an interventionist policy on the part of the EU, I voted against this report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: in writing. - The report is about no less than the role of the EU as a future world policeman who wants to impoke his opinion militarily, if necessary. This EU-Europe is not entitled to list global human rights violations as long as the human rights of EU states are violated, and once again the Gulf states and Israel are missing here. We should be careful not to the choice of words used here, which leads directly to armed conflicts with other regions of the world and to tensions with existing partners. There was a mandatory refusal here.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that the situation of human rights in the world today is dire – as we voted on this report, the Assad regime was destroying what was left of besieged Aleppo, reportedly massacring thousands of civilians. My thoughts and actions are with those innocent people caught up in the conflict and suffering through no fault of their own. We must also stand up and fight for the release of human rights defenders and political prisoners around the world. The human rights defender Nabeel Rajab is still in prison whilst the Bahraini government reviews his tweets. The European Union, the Higher Representative, must demand his immediate release. In Iran, UK—Iranian citizen Nazanin Zagari-Ratcliffe has been imprisoned for unknown charges, separated from her baby daughter and her husband Richard. The UK Government and EU diplomats must do more to secure her release. Together with my colleagues, I will continue to do what I can to ensure she comes home safely.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe in the fundamental importance of human rights. As a liberal, I stand behind the battle against violence and discrimination against LGBTI people. Moreover, I believe that in the modern society, same sex marriages cannot be discriminated against any more and I believe that to make the Union stronger, we have to take better care of minorities. Also, religion discrimination cannot be allowed. I agree with the importance of engaging in human rights-specific dialogues with countries that are having serious human rights problems. I also agree with the fact that human rights discussions should never be subordinated to other interests in high-level political discussions.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. “The issue of human rights is one of the EU's priorities, so the annual review of EU policy in this regard is important and much needed. As President of the EP Delegation for relations with Belarus, I give special attention to the situation of human rights in Belarus. Unfortunately, it is not good. Belarus is the last country in Europe to use the death penalty. More executions were carried out in November. I am pleased that the situation in Belarus has not eluded attention in this report as well. The European Parliament will consistently call on the Belarusian authorities to adopt a moratorium on the execution of the death penalty, which is the first step in the process of abolishing it altogether. The actions of EU Special Representative for Human Rights Stawros Lambrinidis are also very important in this context. I am counting on our fruitful cooperation in this regard.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support the motion for a resolution evaluating the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area 2015. As usual, this resolution contained a large number of topics covering areas ranging from the protection of women's and children's rights to rights in the digital world and the issue of antimicrobial resistance. The resolution addressed virtually all problematic areas, including the right of refugees and asylum seekers, the fight against violence against women and the protection of the rights of people with disabilities and Roma inclusion. On the other hand, however, it contained challenges and stresses that I could not support. In the context of the migration and refugee crisis, it referred to the system of compulsory quotas, in the context of combating violence against women, called for ratification of the legally unenforceable and zideologized Istanbul Convention, and called for the recognition of registered persons with regard to the rights of LGBTI marriages or partnerships. And although, with the fact that the human rights situation needs to be monitored closely and continuously, I strongly agree, I think that the resolution could have taken a more subtle stance on many controversial issues.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the Weidenholzer report because I agree with the conclusions and proposals put forward in the field of human rights and democracy in the world and the EU's policy in this area. I would stress that on migration, there is an urgent need for coherent and lasting solutions based on human rights, given the increasing number of human rights violations against refugees, irregular migrants and asylum seekers on their journey to Europe. I would also like to highlight my support for the systematic introduction of human rights clauses in all international agreements concluded and to be concluded between the EU and third countries, particularly in trade and investment agreements.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - In the direction of the speech on human rights, it is very important to emphasize that extremely important prerequisites for their achievement are the elimination of poverty and underdevelopment. The exercise of human rights is also related to the problem of migration, i.e. the refugee crisis, which needs to be solved in the most painless way. Migrants must be guaranteed full respect for human rights so that they can solve the entire refugee crisis as easily as possible. It is necessary to ensure that the funds allocated for development reach the necessary ones and provide a framework for action at national and international level. It is necessary to promote the social, economic and political inclusion of everyone, regardless of age, gender, sexual orientation, race, ethnicity or religion, including a fair approach to strengthen the national health system. The EU institutions need to advocate even more to tackle caste discrimination on a par with other causes of discrimination. The EU stands out in supporting vulnerable and marginalised groups, including people with disabilities. The danger of terrorism underscores the need for better cooperation between foreign security policies. It is important to provide permanent assistance for vulnerable areas.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the 2015 Report on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and European Union Policy in this area. I supported the report, in my view, highlighting key areas of difficulty in the realisation of human rights, especially in the most vulnerable groups such as children, the elderly, people with disabilities and members of minorities. The report also highlights the importance of implementing and protecting international human rights standards in current war conflicts and in countries with unstable political and economic conditions.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: — Madam President, I did not support this report. I simply have reservations about these very ambitious reports trying to solve all global problems when the European Union is failing in practical implementation. I'll just give three examples. We have failed in Syria. What's unfolding over the last few days is basically a defeat for the West, it's a defeat for the European Union as well. We have allowed Iran to win de facto and to take the next step on the road to regional hegemony, which is certainly not in our interest. Another example, we are not clear on policy towards Turkey. Something else says the European Parliament, something else is doing by the European Commission, something else is doing by the European Council, so here we should also get this straight. We seem confused, even as to the future of transatlantic relations. So far, I haven't seen anyone from the European Union trying to establish relations with the emerging Trump administration. So, let's please solve practical problems and not deal with ambitious news.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Mr President, the Union faces unprecedented situations, including interstate conflicts, cyber insecurity and interputer wars. We're dealing with a more hostile Russia than ever before. Russian propaganda seeks to undermine unity in the European Union, trust in the European Union, in the form of disinformation campaigns and by supporting extremist groups. Regarding the disinformation campaign, I would like to remind you that, for two years now, the Russian Federation has been buying television, radio licenses in the former communist states and will transmit — in some it already does — in the language of that country, just as, during communism, the BBC and Radio Europe Free were transmitting in the language of our countries precisely to keep us informed. So now basically the Russian Federation wants to replace the good brought by the BBC and Free Europe, but this time with evil. The Union's external action must be founded on three pillars — defence, development and diplomacy — and I agree with the creation of a permanent civilian and military command and a defence fund, but not to the detriment of NATO in parallel.

name: Tatjana Ždanoka (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I voted against this report which advocates a policy giving the EU a negative role regarding the current conflicts in its neighbourhood. Moreover, this report also provokes such conflicts, in particular within its own territory. How can they understand the following words in paragraph 36, and I quote: ‘cooperation with Russia over the recent Iran nuclear deal holds out hope for improved relations in other areas, including with NATO, in order to defuse tensions such as those in the Baltic, Syria and Ukraine’.  Putting the Baltics, an EU region, into the same line with Syria and Ukraine, states where civil war is taking place, is playing with fire. Moreover, it is an attempt to start a fire and therefore it is completely unacceptable.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Brok’s report represents an important and essential evaluation of foreign and security policy within the European Union. In line with Mr Brok’s views, I would consider the safeguarding of EU interests and values to be an important concern in light of the extent and nature of the existing challenges which we face in international affairs. Against a backdrop of growing security challenges, the debate regarding the future of European defence cooperation is increasingly pertinent.  In fact, 66% of Irish citizens would like to see greater EU engagement in matters of security and defence policy, according to a new Eurobarometer survey of the European Parliament on perceptions and expectations. Nevertheless, military expenditure was 0.4% of Ireland’s GDP in 2015. I share and appreciate the goal of ensuring greater safety for EU citizens and reiterate that, during the evolution of the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy, our EU counterparts have always fully respected Ireland’s sovereignty, independence and neutrality. Because of that neutrality, we did not support all the amendments and abstained in the final vote.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I voted against this report. I am from the Republic of Ireland, as the last speaker is. The reason I voted against it is because Ireland is a neutral country. There is another reason why I voted against it, and that is because many EU Member States are hypocrites when it comes to talking about peace.  All you need to do is a quick search on the internet to see the masses of weapons that are sold by countries from within this Union. Reuters reported in January that the German Government has approved several arms export deals with countries in the Middle East, including delivery of 23 Airbus helicopters to Saudi Arabia, 660 machine guns, 600 additional gun barrels and 550 submachine guns. Now can someone tell me what is Saudi Arabia going to do with that? Are they going to cuddle people; are going to make life better for people? No, they are going to terrorise people; they are going to cause mayhem; and they are going to make my life less safe. If Europe was serious about doing something about war, they would stop selling the tools of mayhem and stop being bloody hypocrites.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The following report is presented annually as it sets out the general guidelines of the European Union on common foreign and security policy. Specifically, I find the rapporteur's positions on these issues very far from my ideas, sometimes almost unlikely. Some examples of this are the extremely aggressive attitude towards Russia, seen as a threat to the West, and strengthening defence and security, which would involve spending greater in the Member States. For these reasons I decided to vote against it.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Spanish Socialists have voted in favour of this annual report because it addresses the most relevant issues and developments related to the CFSP over the past year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the Union operates. It emphasizes the need for strengthened Union integration, including steps towards a 'defence union' and the need for Union institutions and Member States to revive this aspiration. The report also calls for the CFSP to play a more visible and effective role in conflict resolution, particularly in Syria, taking advantage of the Union's influence on all key regional actors, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. By our S&D amendments, it also offers a possibility for more constructive relations with Russia and outlines areas of common interest. In addition, we Socialists have included the importance of controlling Union arms exports, that is to say, refrain from selling arms to countries that do not meet the criteria for eligibility under the Union Common Position on the arms trade.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it is based on a securitarian and militaristic perspective which also draws conclusions without really analysing the causes of the current conflict situation. It raises the increase in arms spending and the increase of all military capabilities, but not to seek a non-aggressive deterrence, nor an independent Union, but on the contrary, it assumes positions in which it remains subordinate to the interests of the United States. In addition, the text celebrates the Warsaw Summit, and therefore the role of a global NATO that seems to compete with the UN and which assumes increasingly aggressive actions and positions with our East neighbourhood, generating greater tensions and conflict as we continue to bet on unilateral sanctions. This vision of the common foreign and security policy leads to further conflict, reveals to a Union that still does not understand geopolitical changes, and proposes to increase military expenditure by ignoring the severe economic and social crisis which seriously affects the European population. We reject the budget being devoted to military financing and we advocate a Union that will stop contributing to military escalation in and around the region.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy. The resolution states that the EU is one of the greatest achievements in European history and that the EU's ability to change has ensured peace, stability and prosperity for its citizens and neighbouring countries, many of which have become EU Member States. The EU continues to have the greatest economic power, is the largest donor and leader of humanitarian aid and development aid in addressing global multilateral diplomacy, such as climate change, international justice, non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and human rights. I agree with the provisions set out in the report that the EU must take responsibility for our security: to prevent, defend, to deter, to react. The EU must strengthen its security and defence capabilities, because it can only benefit from its full potential as a global player if it combines its' soft 'power with' hard 'power. The resolution calls on Member States to increase investment in defence costs, including defence research. I believe that it is rightly emphasised that one of Europe's most important priorities at the moment must be to ensure peace and stability on our continent, neighbouring countries and Africa, because in the absence of security, no sustainable development, such as stability, social justice and democracy cannot be ensured Condition.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: This report aims to strengthen the common foreign and security policy to the detriment of States by taking advantage of Brexit and the withdrawal of England, the main opponent of the project. This text is in itself a major attack on national sovereignty. Its provisions are not innovative: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of the States, and the unification of defence companies (under German rule). So I opposed it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report aims to take further powers from EU Member States and uses terms such as ‘diplomatic superpower’ to describe the EU on the world stage. This report is clearly a threat to the parliamentary sovereignty of the United Kingdom and I therefore voted against. I further note that paragraph 20 of this report calls for a European Union military headquarters, and question how those who tell the UK at domestic level that there are no plans for an EU Army can possibly simultaneously support such a resolution when it comes before the European Parliament.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text because I share the view that the European Union has brought peace and prosperity to many countries which subsequently became members. I also believe that the current crisis, both internal and external, should be an opportunity for the Union to affirm more ambitious external policies in line with other European policies. As such, it is more than imperative to assume responsibility for our security at European level, to invest in a comprehensive approach and to strengthen European diplomacy. From a strictly budgetary point of view, I can regret that the small budget of around €320 million was underimplemented by EUR 96 million in 2015.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the current turbulent times in and around the European Union, there is a great need for all its institutions and Member States to cooperate in the field of its security. The CFSP is one of the most important steps in order to bolster Europe’s resilience to threats to its security. Member States have to start shifting their security perspective from one of individual national priorities to one of a wider scale, spanning all of Europe. The CFSP reaches not only to Europe’s borders, but beyond them as well, trying to subdue threats coming from neighbouring regions as well. As a whole, the CFSP is a major key for Europe to be able to stand together and united in one of the most important aspects – its security.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposal for the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The draft resolution proposes to establish a new, more realistic strategy for EU relations with Russia, and to develop a common EU foreign policy through three pillars — diplomacy, development cooperation and defence.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: I voted against this text, which aims to strengthen the common foreign and security policy to the detriment of the Member States, taking advantage of Brexit and the withdrawal of England, the main opponent of the draft. The text would in itself be a blow to national sovereignty. Moreover, its provisions are nothing new: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of the States, the unification of defence companies under German rule, etc.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which recalls the unprecedented internal and external challenges facing the European Union. MEPs emphasise the importance for Member States to show sufficient unity, political will and mutual trust to be able to use the available foreign and security policy means in a concerted manner. The report invites Federica Mogherini, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs to develop a security and defence implementation plan in order to achieve the first results in 2017. It also asks the State to implement the instruments provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular permanent structured cooperation and some recent proposals such as the creation of a permanent civilian and military headquarters or the strengthening of the Union's rapid reaction instruments. Finally, the report deplores the limited budget for foreign and security policy.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it is in line with my European position. I believe that, in the current context, a common, ambitious and coordinated foreign and security policy is still more necessary. This policy must be useful in meeting the important challenges that await us. In an increasingly globalised world and in which power is increasingly shared among the various world powers, the Union must remain united and adopt a common position on foreign policy and defence, with the aim of being an influential actor capable of defending European values on the international stage.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report on the Union's common foreign and security policy, as it calls for a strengthening of the Union's military structures, which would require an increase in Member States' contributions. Among other things, the report is good at the policy of cooperation with Turkey in the management of the flow of asylum seekers.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on this report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The road map and commitments of the Bratislava Summit are welcomed and a concrete commitment from Member States to its implementation is expected.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy (Article 36 of the EU Treaty) should make it possible to strengthen the CFSP to the detriment of the states by taking advantage of Brexit and the withdrawal of the United Kingdom. This text itself is a major attack on states' sovereignty and its provisions are nothing innovative: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of the States, and unification of defence companies (under German rule). So, of course, I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I do not agree with the report by Mr Brok, I therefore spoke out against this text.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have voted against the report. The report calls for, inter alia, strong military rearmament, joint permanent military headquarters, special EU combat groups, more effective decisions on military operations and EU-funded military research. I oppose all this and believe that such a policy only leads to increased tension in the world and increased risk of war. If the EU intends to push for peace, disarmament, detente and focus on peaceful, political and diplomatic solutions of conflict are required.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Spanish Socialists have voted in favour of this annual report because it addresses the most relevant issues and developments related to the CFSP over the past year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the Union operates. It emphasizes the need for strengthened Union integration, including steps towards a 'defence union' and the need for Union institutions and Member States to revive this aspiration. The report also calls for the CFSP to play a more visible and effective role in conflict resolution, particularly in Syria, taking advantage of the Union's influence on all key regional actors, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. By our S&D amendments, it also offers a possibility for more constructive relations with Russia and outlines areas of common interest. In addition, we Socialists have included the importance of controlling Union arms exports, that is to say, refrain from selling arms to countries that do not meet the criteria for eligibility under the Union Common Position on the arms trade.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The European Parliament recalls that the European Union is one of the greatest achievements in European history and that the EU's ability to make change has ensured peace, stability and prosperity for its citizens and neighbouring countries, many of which have become EU Member States. The EP also stresses that the EU continues to have the greatest economic power, is the largest donor of humanitarian aid and development aid and the leader in global multilateral diplomacy, such as climate change, international justice, weapons of mass destruction non-proliferation and human rights. Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to strengthen their capacity to combat disinformation and propaganda campaigns targeted at the EU's population and its neighbours. It also calls on the EU institutions and the Member States to recognise that the ongoing information war is not only an external but also an internal problem of the EU. In addition, the EP regrets that the EU is not able to inform the European public properly about the actions, merits and achievements in the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. He therefore calls on the Council, the Commission and the Member States to close this gap and to make the EU's external action more visible and clarified. Parliament recalls the EU's commitment to the common foreign and security policy in accordance with the principles of democracy, the rule of law, the universality and indivisible of human rights and fundamental freedoms, and in accordance with the UN Charter and international law.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the implementation of the European Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy emphasises that the Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges. It recalls the EU's commitment to contribute to the strengthening of democracy, the rule of law and human rights and international order through its foreign and security policy. Although I agree with a significant part of the report, it contains a number of statements which have led me to abstain from voting in the end.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: ‒ The EU, as a key player in international dynamics, faces new challenges that closely affect its security and defence. With increasing interdependence between internal and external security and the profound instability affecting the Union's neighbourhood, strengthening its capabilities in this area becomes one of the priorities in scope of Community policies. I therefore support this report which underlines the importance of establishing Community mechanisms that exploit the potential already present in the Treaty of Lisbon, such as structured permanent cooperation. In order to promote self-sufficiency in the field of security and defence, the Union needs coordination first and foremost. In addition, with an already underfunded budget, joint operations under the CFSP require funding and additional cooperation from Member States. The report also underlines how the Union's external policies should be consistent not only with each other, avoiding duplication both in terms of operations and financing, but also with pillars fundamentals on which the European Union is based, such as fundamental rights, the rule of law and democracy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —I support this Report. In an era of huge geopolitical challenges in the EU, deeper integration, including defending the bloc building and maximising the diplomatic weight of the bloc and strengthening resilience through a range of available political, economic, military and humanitarian tools, is key to the EU's survival as an influential international “player ”.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is to take advantage of the UK's withdrawal following BREXIT to push an additional corner on the transfer of sovereignty from Member States to the EU over foreign and defence policy. This is unacceptable to me. I therefore vote against it.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report for a number of reasons. The report is further evidence of the unrelenting push for the militarisation of the EU at all levels, from coordinated security and defence policy through to an EU army. The calls in the report for the EU to align soft power with hard power are extreme and militaristic. The increased militarisation of Europe will not make our citizens safer. Only intelligent investment in our police services and cooperation between Member States on intelligence relating to crime and criminals will make EU Member States safer. Calls within the EU for reduced social payments on one hand and increased military spending on the other are not what the people of the EU deserve. Furthermore, the report was further evidence of the contempt for neutral Member States. It is for these reasons, and many more, that I voted against this report.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Union has a great historical responsibility, facing internal and external challenges including conflict between states, collapse of states, terrorism, threats Hybrids, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change. We must realise that the EU will only be able to provide an effective response to the new challenges if its structures and its Member States work together as part of a joint and truly coordinated action in the framework of the ESSC/CSDP, a framework which, in the long term, can only lead to the foundation of a federal nucleus, the ultimate aim of the birth of the European Union. Only a European government leading a European federal state will have the military, economic, strategic and intelligence resources necessary to effectively protect its citizens and be promoter of stability in the bordering regions of the world. Today we are lacking our historical task and only partially fulfill our role in the world. We fail because our 28 national policies are piecemeal, limited and divergent. But with a single guidance and one foreign policy we could easily bring stability and security to all areas overlooking the Mediterranean basin.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This report uses current geopolitical instability as a pretext to propose strengthening the common foreign and security policy. The text calls for the adoption of a single foreign policy, to increase the financial contribution of the Member States and to proceed with the unification of defence companies. We are firmly opposed to any common foreign and security policy. On the one hand, the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy and credibility. The European management of conflicts in Syria and Libya, as well as tense relations with Russia, demonstrate this. On the other hand, this report seriously undermines the sovereignty of the Member States in so far as foreign policy falls exclusively within their competence. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The EU faces unprecedented internal and external challenges, even interstate conflicts, country collapses, hybrid threats, terrorism, climate change, organised crime, energy and cyber insecurity, increasing challenges where the EU will be able to respond effectively new challenges only if its structures and Member States cooperate in a joint and truly coordinated effort in the context of CFSP/CSDP. Currently, the EU is surrounded by an arc of instability due to the large parts of the Middle East and North Africa that are covered by ethno-religious conflicts and the emergence of wars through interputations, ISIS terrorist groups and the Jabhat Fateh al-Sham Front, proliferate throughout region, and the security vacuum in the Middle East and North Africa is widely used by Al-Qaeda terrorist groups. I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy (Article 36 TEU) because there is a need to strengthen the security of the European Union, as well as its neighbouring states, to combat and avoid terrorist attacks, and at the same time time to combat this stability of terrorist groups.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We welcome and support large parts of Mr Brok’s report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy and thank him for closely cooperating with our group on compromise language prior to the vote in committee. Europe’s neighbourhood is characterised by a growing number of armed conflicts and instability and we therefore very much support the call for a strengthened common foreign and security policy. However, we would like to clearly express our opposition regarding some of the proposals made in the report’s chapter on defence: we reject the Commission proposal on the financing of the European Defence Fund based on national contributions to be treated as one-offs under the Stability and Growth Pact. Member States should not further run into debt for defence and weaken the euro; we also reject the idea of using a number of existing civilian funds and diverting financial resources to the defence industry such as the European Investment Bank, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, the European Structural and Investment Funds and the European Regional Development Fund. Instead, Member States should significantly strengthen military capabilities by pooling research, development, procurement and maintenance of capabilities.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Spanish Socialists have voted in favour of this annual report because it addresses the most relevant issues and developments related to the CFSP over the past year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the Union operates. It emphasizes the need for strengthened Union integration, including steps towards a 'defence union' and the need for Union institutions and Member States to revive this aspiration. The report also calls for the CFSP to play a more visible and effective role in conflict resolution, particularly in Syria, taking advantage of the Union's influence on all key regional actors, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. By our S&D amendments, it also offers a possibility for more constructive relations with Russia and outlines areas of common interest. In addition, we Socialists have included the importance of controlling Union arms exports, that is to say, refrain from selling arms to countries that do not meet the criteria for eligibility under the Union Common Position on the arms trade.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this own-initiative report, which provides an overview of the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. This is a good report, which calls for more defence resources and synergy and greater defence cooperation with the United Kingdom. It also welcomes the launch of the new European Border Guard and Coast Guard Agency and calls for strengthening the partnership with the countries of the South in managing migration flows. However, I voted against certain paragraphs concerning Russia. Indeed, I believe that Russia is an indispensable partner on the international stage. A necessary dialogue must therefore be maintained. Moreover, I do not believe in the effectiveness of sanctions against Russia. On the contrary, we see that Russia's reaction to a food embargo on certain European products continues to have very negative effects on the European economy and more particularly on our farmers.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the report in question, which takes stock of the state of implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The European Union faces internal and external challenges, including conflict between states, collapse of states, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy insecurity, crime organized and climate change. These conflicts have direct and serious consequences for the security and well-being of EU citizens, as they are increasingly pouring into the EU both in the form of terrorism and as massive flows of refugees, both with disinformation campaigns that aim to divide our societies. The report emphasises the need on the part of the European Union to strengthen its security and defence capabilities, underlines EU commitment to an international order based on law and effective multilateralism under the guidance of the United Nations and considers it of fundamental importance to make operational the instruments provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO).

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected this report which, like the majority of reports coming from the Committee on Foreign Affairs this year, focused on security issues. It calls for strengthening the EU’s security and defence capabilities and stepping up defence cooperation. To this end Member States should provide additional funding. Moreover, the report supports efforts to establish an integrated defence market and the consolidation of the European defence industry. The report advocates stronger cooperation with NATO and says that the strategic partnership with the US and Canada should be transformed into an effective foreign affairs instrument as a matter of priority.  This report offered nothing constructive and is basically just another push for the EU to become a hard military power. For these reasons, I rejected the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. In particular, we rejected the self-congratulatory language referring to the EU as being one of the greatest achievements in European history and as a diplomatic superpower. We are concerned by proposed changes to the financial structures governing the CFSP and proposals for budgetary increases as this could affect the UK before we leave the EU.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The EU is surrounded by serious conflicts and the challenges the EU is facing are multifaceted, from terrorism, cyber security, misinformation, human trafficking or radicalisation. The external and internal threats are intertwined more and more. In order to effectively safeguard our interests, protect our citizens and promote values worldwide, EU action requires a full engagement of the Member States and the coherent use the policies within the external policy toolbox. I agree that the EU external action needs to be based on three pillars, defined as the ‘three Ds’: Defence, Development and Diplomacy.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The annual report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy is, in my view, highly problematic, first of all with regard to the talk of sanctions on Russia. The report states that sanctions have proved to be the most effective means of deterring Russian aggression in Ukraine and insists that the EU should reserve the possibility of impose additional gradual sanctions. I don't share those positions. Another sensitive step in my view is one in which Member States are asked once again to meet the 2% target in defence expenditure as required by NATO. While I am in favour of greater harmonisation and better coordination of forces, I believe that at a historic moment of strong economic crisis like the current one should limit increases in expenses. Another critical node is the proposal to establish a permanent civil-military headquarters, with a military planning and conduct capability and a civilian capacity for peer planning and conduct importance. My vote was against it.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because it gives a very good and realistic perspective on the Union’s Common Foreign and Security Policy. It is one of the policies which should strengthen the EU’s position at the international level and make the EU more visible. I may have some criticism of the work of the EU delegation abroad, but overall I think the EEAS and its services are on the right track. Finally, better integrating defence and security matters into the CFSP and the EU’s external actives is a way forward, especially when the tackling security challenges of these days.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report and stress that the European Union faces internal and external challenges, including transnational conflicts, state collapse, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber-insecurity and energy insecurity, organised crime and its change climate. We underline that the EU will be able to tackle the new challenges effectively only if its structures and Member States work together in a joint and genuinely coordinated effort within the framework of the CFSP/CSDP.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy fails to provide answers to important issues concerning civil liberties and cooperation between the Member States of the European Union, which is why I voted against it.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Negative vote. The report emphasizes how badly security in Europe has been damaged by Russia's military intervention in Crimea and eastern Ukraine. More engagement and dialogue with Russian civil society is also suggested on the one hand, while diplomatic, political and economic pressure is to be maintained on the Russian government on the other. More defence spending, collective funds for EU missions and funding are also required to have rapid military responses at European level.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Terrorism scares us but it cannot bring us down, even cyber and energy insecurity hinder our progress, yet they will not be able to stop it. Only by implementing full security of the Union and using footy foreign policy instruments could we reaffirm ourselves as a source of peace, stability and prosperity as we have historically become, so I vote to favour that the Union's external policies are consistent with each other and with others with an external scope. Resilience is our main objective and is actionable through a security and defence implementation plan containing level of ambition, tasks, requirements and priorities in terms capacity for European defence. Such an overall strategy requires commitment, ownership, political will and leadership from all Member States. We must not forget how development, which our EU is also affected by the economic and employment crisis, can only be there if there is security, and vice versa. All this is a thunderous reminder of a strengthening of diplomacy in its forms of prevention and mediation, not only external, but internal.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy. I voted against strengthening military and defence capabilities as well as for providing for additional defence spending due to Ireland’s position of neutrality.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: The challenges facing the European Union in defence (terrorism, hybrid threats, cybersecurity, organised crime or energy security) require an operational and effective Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). I note the presentation of the annual report on the CFSP and the progressive increase in the political will for greater integration in defence matters, which are contained in documents such as the Comprehensive CFSP Strategy. I share the understanding of External Action based on three pillars: diplomacy, development and defense. I am in favour of exploiting all the instruments of the Treaty of Lisbon, namely Permanent Structured Cooperation, as a dynamo of greater integration. I believe that Member States should invest more in defence at the political level (with the creation of a permanent civil and military headquarters) and financial (with increasing investment in defence, according to the 2% of GDP target, under NATO). Conducting a “Defense” training in the Council of Ministers or the creation of a Defense Semester should correspond to concrete actions and avoid the complexion of decision-making processes. I share a comprehensive CSDP approach, in line with the Neighbourhood Policy, cooperation or development support. I therefore support this report.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report because we need a more closely coordinated and effective interlinked European foreign and security policy. Most people in the EU want a common foreign, security and defence policy. I therefore support the call for two percent of the respective gross domestic product to be used for defence and to establish multinational forces.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. In particular, we rejected the self-congratulatory language referring to the EU as being one of the greatest achievements in European history and as a diplomatic superpower. We are concerned by proposed changes to the financial structures governing the CFSP and proposals for budgetary increases as this could affect the UK before we leave the EU.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the text highlights the need for all policies within 'foreign policy instruments' to be implemented, constantly and in a manner consistent, for the benefit of safeguarding EU interests and values around the world. The report recognises the multiple challenges facing the EU abroad, from terrorism to cybersecurity, from misinformation to the fight against trafficking in human beings. I agree with the report that the European Union's foreign action should be based on three pillars: diplomacy, development and defence.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it is based on a securitarian and militaristic perspective which also draws conclusions without really analysing the causes of the current conflict situation. It raises the increase in arms spending and the increase of all military capabilities, but not to seek a non-aggressive deterrence, nor an independent Union, but on the contrary, it assumes positions in which it remains subordinate to the interests of the United States. In addition, the text celebrates the Warsaw Summit, and therefore the role of a global NATO that seems to compete with the UN and which assumes increasingly aggressive actions and positions with our East neighbourhood, generating greater tensions and conflict as we continue to bet on unilateral sanctions. This vision of the common foreign and security policy leads to further conflict, reveals to a Union that still does not understand geopolitical changes, and proposes to increase military expenditure by ignoring the severe economic and social crisis which seriously affects the European population. We reject the budget being devoted to military financing and we advocate a Union that will stop contributing to military escalation in and around the region.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: ‒ The EU is in a deteriorating environment in terms of stability and security, due to hybrid threats, conflicts in neighbourhood countries and Russia's aggressive action in Crimea and Ukraine. In such an interconnected and complex context, Member States need to use the instruments made available by the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular permanent structured cooperation, and ensure consistency between civil and military actions abroad, in line with the objectives of diplomacy, development and defence. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution which recalls the areas in which the EU can and should continue to commit to developing a common foreign and security policy inspired by the principles of democracy, of the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for the Charter of the United Nations and international law. I consider the strengthening of the European potential in the management of its security, through a combination of soft and hard power aimed at preventing and reacting to the challenges of particular importance in terms of common security.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges and will only be able to respond effectively to them if its structures, as well as those of the Member States, cooperate in a joint and truly coordinated effort. These conflicts have direct and serious consequences for the safety and well-being of European citizens. The European Union must strengthen its security and defence capabilities, as it cannot use its full potential as a world power unless it combines its undeniable uncoercive power with coercive power. The EU must play a more active role in the areas of disarmament, non-proliferation and arms control. I voted to strengthen the role of the national parliament in the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The EU has brought peace, stability and prosperity to its citizens and neighbouring countries, and this must continue.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report emphasises that the EU remains the largest economic power, the most generous donor in the areas of humanitarian aid and development aid, as well as taking a leading role in global multilateral diplomacy in areas such as climate change, national justice, non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and human rights. The EU can only be a strong global actor and an equal partner of other major powers if all Member States speak with one voice and act together within the framework of a strong EU foreign and security policy. Member States need a change of approach, as the approach to foreign policy and security from national perspectives has now become invalid. It stresses the necessity of globalisation and multipolarity for integration processes. The proposal highlights greater compatibility and integrity of the armed forces of the Member States. Strengthen the common security and defence policy, leading to greater efficiency, unity and effectiveness. The proposal also underlines the need for the Union to be stronger, more effective and more value-oriented. The proposal advocates, inter alia, the creation of a permanent civil-military headquarters, with military planning and execution capabilities and a Civilian Planning and Execution Service that would strengthen strategic and operational planning and which would further enhance civil-military cooperation and improve the EU's ability to respond quickly to crises.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — Due to the protection of the sovereignty of the Member States and the inviolability of their foreign and security policy powers, I abstained from voting on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The Treaty of Lisbon sought to increase cohesion and better expose the common foreign and security policy. The development of the Common Security and Defence Policy, the creation of the European External Action Service and the establishment of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy are a continuation of this strategy aimed at strengthening the EU's role on the world stage. Taking into account the current volatile situation of the terrorist threat and the real risk of war in Europe, I believe that EU foreign and security policy can be an important tool for the implementation of multilateral shared interests. However, I also believe that it cannot replace the possibility of Member States pursuing such a decision, their own independent policies in these areas.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on security and defence. As an MEP from Malta, neutrality is entrenched in our Constitution, so in all my voting I reflected the need to have an opt-out and recognition of national cases of neutrality.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While the EU's foreign and security policy can be an important means for advancing multilateral, shared concerns, I also believe that it must never replace a Member State’s ability to conduct its own independent policies in these areas whenever it chooses to. I therefore abstained on this.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ It is before everyone's eyes how the historical period in which we live is extremely complicated from both political and social terms. The complexity of the interests at stake, the multiplicity of actors — often “non-state” — on the scene, the dramatic demagogic and extremist trends growing in many countries determine the need for to conceive international relations in an unprecedented way. Compared to the decades before us, we can no longer think that the threats coming from outside our continent can be adequately addressed by individual Member States. Today, as never before, there is the need for greater integration between the foreign policies of the Member States in order to summarise them into a single and effective foreign policy of the European Union. The annual report on the state of the common foreign and security policy that we have approved addresses the main problems inherent in the CFSP and sets its priorities for the future. In particular, the report addresses the changed geopolitical environment in which the EU must operate and its challenges — such as Brexit, the Mediterranean and the Middle East crisis — stressing the need for a enhanced European integration.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This own-initiative report analyses the current state and challenges of international affairs, and stresses the need to deploy in a coherent manner the aspects of foreign policy in order to safeguard the interests and values of the Union around the world. The report recognises the multiple challenges facing the Union in the external field, such as terrorism, cybersecurity, combating trafficking in human beings or radicalisation. Considering that the deepening of the implementation of the common foreign and security policy should strengthen the role of the Union on the international stage in conflict management and the promotion of peace and stability, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. In particular, we rejected the self-congratulatory language referring to the EU as being one of the greatest achievements in European history and as a diplomatic superpower. We are concerned by proposed changes to the financial structures governing CFSP and proposals for budgetary increases as this could affect the UK before we leave the EU.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. It is our duty to take our security and invest more in our defence, which is too limited. However, NATO remains a major player in our collective security. The time is for concrete actions. I therefore call for an effective implementation of the EU's overall strategy presented by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, in June 2016. In addition, we need to build resilience and address the root causes of instability and irregular and forced migration, such as armed conflict, poverty or climate change.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the implementation of the European Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy emphasises that the Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges. It recalls the EU's commitment to contribute to the strengthening of democracy, the rule of law and human rights and international order through its foreign and security policy. Although the report also calls for a revision of the strategy for relations between the EU and Russia, I regret to note that I abstained from the vote, as the position of the Hungarian Government on this issue differs in several points from the official EU policy. Since sanctions against Russia have caused enormous economic damage to Hungary and several other Member States, and since, in my opinion, they do not achieve their objective in the long term, I could not support the points that would envisage the imposition of more serious sanctions.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I believe that the latest events, including terrorist attacks and conflict between states, have reduced security within the EU. In fact, the EU finds itself surrounded by conflict-riddled countries that pose a growing threat to EU internal security. I therefore urge the EU to invest more in defence and closer cooperation with NATO, continuing its commitment to peace and the fight against extremism and radicalisation.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Security is a concern for many European citizens. 66% of Europeans want Europe to take more action on defence and security, according to a poll conducted by the European Parliament. In France, 72% of respondents are in favour of increased EU action. It is time for the Union to develop its own resources so that it can guarantee stronger defence and security within it. Member States must cooperate more systematically by promoting the pooling and sharing of military capabilities.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This text aims to strengthen the single foreign policy in the wake of Brexit: increasing the budgetary contribution of the States, unification of defence companies (under German rule), etc. This text goes against the sovereignty of the states, and so on.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - For another year, Mr Elmar Brok's report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy (Article 36 TEU) calls for the 'narrow-minded national view' and the conduct of a common EU foreign policy, as well as for the creation of a common European army. The Lisbon Treaty has already achieved a major step forward in this respect and, in my view, every next step will be a step towards centralisation in Brussels, federalisation of the EU and the forwarding of national sovereignty. Certainly, the common approach gives the European Union more weight to pursue foreign policy and achieve its objectives, but the EU's objectives are not always aligned with the interests of individual Member States. This is precisely why the European foreign security and defence policy must not replace and should not limit Member States' ability to pursue their own foreign policy to achieve their foreign policy objectives.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The report promotes stronger cooperation between the EU and NATO, the merger of internal and external security, calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be extended beyond parliamentary control and advocates EU-funded permanent structured cooperation. The threats facing the EU are not so strong as to justify an excessive increase in its military capabilities.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the implementation of the common foreign and security policy as I am opposed to the militarisation of the European Union. I believe the EU could play an invaluable role on the world stage in conflict prevention. I am engaged in the campaign to establish a Peace Institute in Wales which will help promote peace in our society and in our everyday lives. The EU should have its own Peace Institute to help develop a policy that would bring people real security.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Strengthening security and defence cooperation is necessary in the position we are in now. That is why it is important that in Europe we can move forward and forward in this area also in deepening cooperation with other actors, such as NATO. For me, the report goes a little far in terms of the request for budgetary resources, as this must be done primarily as part of budgetary work. Moreover, I believe that the report goes too far in some parts in terms of ambitions to create an EU army. These positions have been reflected in how I voted for this report.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: - The European Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges, including interstate conflicts, state collapses, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyberinsecurity and energy insecurity, organised crime and climate change, and only the EU can respond effectively to new challenges. The European Union is currently surrounded by an arc of instability and these conflicts have serious and direct consequences for the well-being and safety of European citizens. Therefore, the current internal and external crisis represents an opportunity for the Union, provided that it is used to improve its functioning and cooperation. A reform is urgently needed to make the EU better, more democratic and capable of meeting citizens' expectations.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Vote against: this text is in itself a major attack on national sovereignty. Its provisions are not innovative: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of States, and the unification of defence companies.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
