text: in writing. - Another report that does not differ from previous ones, pursuing the militarist, security and external interference policy that characterizes the EU's action. Without news, the justification for this security drift focuses on the alleged threats facing the EU, to the east by the Russian Federation and to the south by terrorism and Islamic radicalism. The EU's responsibilities for escalating tensions to the east and promoting so-called 'Islamic radicalism', which has justified actions of aggression and interference in the Middle East and North Africa are completely omitted. Cynically presenting the EU as a project of success and prosperity, it carries on the federalist approach to militarism, further undermining the sovereignty of the Member States. The report highlights the anti-democratic nature of the EU; advocates strengthening the defence budgets of the Member States and the EU; the role of the EU as the European military pillar of NATO; the reform of the UN Security Council, seeking to ensure that it becomes an instrument at the service of the EU and imperialism. It promotes the policy of war, aggression, domination over third countries and oppression. Values that can never be reconciled with policies of disarmament and peace. We advocate another policy, based on solidarity, cooperation and mutual respect between States, as a guarantor of peace.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - Despite the many challenges it is currently facing, the European Union is still one of the most successful cooperation projects in European history. Over the past decades, it has also been possible to ensure peace, bring stability and prosperity to individual countries. Nor does it change the rise of populism, nationalism and demagoguery. These would only be able to delay the solution or make it completely impossible. On the contrary, the European Union's cumbersome in dealing with some issues is also due to the lack of national coordination, the promotion of partial interests and the inability of some national leaders to agree. However, the resolution of its crises can emerge from both the EU and its individual members. It could fulfill its potential for a true global actor. Currently, the EU is the strongest economic bloc, the most important provider of humanitarian and development aid, as well as a leader in several technological areas or in the fight against climate change. There is also a need for more intensive defence cooperation. It will be able to participate more actively in preventing and resolving conflict situations in its immediate surroundings. To help ensure peace and stability. This is also important for dealing with the refugee crisis, for example. At the same time, the effectiveness of currently still underused European diplomacy would be increased.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: ‒ Vote against, the usual anti-Russia report is unrealistic.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (Article 36 TEU), as the report promotes stronger cooperation between the EU and NATO, the merger of internal and external security, calls for the ATHENA mechanism to be extended beyond parliamentary control and advocates EU-funded permanent structured cooperation.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that in the report we managed to avoid unnecessary duplication of condemnations, while preserving the strong message of deep concern about Russia's aggressive policies and supporting measures the EU takes in strengthening its resilience in the face of this challenge. On transatlantic relations, a necessity for values-based cooperation with the US is emphasised. Moreover, I welcome the focus on the importance of respecting the EU arms exports controls, for example by refraining from selling arms to countries that do not fulfil criteria to be eligible under the EU Common Position on arms trade. At a time of unprecedented geopolitical challenges to the EU, a deeper integration, including building a defence union and maximising the Union's diplomatic clout, and strengthening resilience through an array of available political, economic, military and humanitarian tools, is a key to the EU's survival as an influential international actor.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy because in the light of the changing geopolitical contexts in which the EU is working it is essential to make decisive choices for a joint action plan, capable of providing adequate funds and playing a more visible and effective role in the resolution of conflicts. I am very convinced that finally making operational the instruments provided for in the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular permanent structured cooperation between Member States, could represent a important step forward in the construction of a real “defence union”, which securely European citizens and areas affected by wars. I think it is essential to establish an effective dialogue and establish a more constructive relationship with countries such as Russia which at this historic moment have a fundamental weight in the current clashes in the countries Middle Eastern. I am sure that greater cooperation between Member States and a more significant understanding between the Member States are the necessary bases from which to meet the expectations of stability and prosperity of all citizens, maximising the EU's diplomatic weight and asserting their influence internationally.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We welcome and support large parts of Mr Brok’s report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy and thank him for closely cooperating with our group on compromise language prior to the vote in committee. Europe’s neighbourhood is characterized by a growing number of armed conflicts and instability and we therefore very much support the call for a strengthened common foreign and security policy.  However, we would like to clearly express our opposition regarding some of the proposals made in the report’s chapter on defence: we reject the Commission proposal on the financing of the European Defence Fund based on national contributions to be treated as one-offs under the Stability and Growth Pact. Member States should not further run into debt for defence and weaken the euro. We also reject the idea to use a number of existing civilian funds and divert financial resources to the defence industry, such as the European Investment Bank, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, European Structural and Investment Funds, and the European Regional Development Fund. Instead, Member States should significantly strengthen military capabilities by pooling research, development, procurement and maintenance of capabilities.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - Ensuring peace and stability in Europe and our neighbouring countries is one of the key priorities of European policy. The EU can only effectively address the current challenges if its structures and members cooperate in a coordinated manner within the framework of the Common Foreign and Security Policy.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. In particular, I rejected the self-congratulatory language referring to the EU as being one of the greatest achievements in European history and as a diplomatic superpower. I am concerned by proposed changes to the financial structures governing the CFSP and proposals for budgetary increases, as this could affect the UK before we leave the EU.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual report on Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), which addresses the most salient issues and developments pertaining to the CFSP over the last year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the EU operates: the prospect of Brexit, Trump’s election as the US president, growing challenges along the EU’s eastern and southern borders prompted by an aggressive Russia. The report addresses these challenges by emphasising the need for a reinvigorated EU coordination. It also stresses the need for the EU to play a more active role in conflict resolution by using the leverage the EU has over all key regional players, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. Last but not least, it underscores the importance of strengthening ties with strategic partners in Asia.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, considering the role of the CFSP extraordinarily important for the projection and European identity not only for our partners, but also directly on our Member States. In this sense, it is important to follow up the proposal for an annual reflection on the progress of the implementation of the strategy involving Parliament, in order to increase the perception of the citizens European action, also in conjunction with the electoral deadlines of the institutions. I think that the latest steps taken to promote a defence Europe and the new global strategy very well embody the principles on which to base EU external action: diplomacy, development and defence. And this must encourage us to be even more ambitious, bearing in mind the increasingly important function of cultural diplomacy for EU external relations and the EU development agenda .

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to support this report, which addresses the most salient issues and developments pertaining to the CFSP over the last year. It also sets priorities for the future and reflects on the changing geopolitical context in which the EU operates.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report on the Union's common foreign and security policy, as it calls for a strengthening of the Union's military structures, which would require an increase in Member States' contributions. Among other things, the report is good at the policy of cooperation with Turkey in the management of the flow of asylum seekers.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: in writing. — We Swedish Social Democrats think it is important that the EU strengthens its ability, with the resources of the Member States, to help preserve peace, prevent conflict and strengthen international security. We are in favour of cooperation in the framework of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and wish to emphasise its importance to the EU as an actionable foreign policy operator. Given the more volatile security policy situation in our world, cooperation within the CFSP is becoming increasingly important. However, we would like to emphasise that we do not support the report's call for increased defence expenditure for Member States or its calls towards permanent common defence, but we believe that defence policy should be national competence. We specifically oppose the elements of starting to take steps towards a “European defence union” and therefore appreciate that the report makes clear that any possible decision to move towards a defence union must be based on unanimity among Member States. We also emphasise that we are aware that the OECD's Criteria for Public Development Assistance (ODA) are respected in decisions on how to finance military action. Furthermore, it is important that GSDP measures under the CFSP continue to be used only to preserve peace and prevent conflicts outside the Union.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Spanish Socialists have voted in favour of this annual report because it addresses the most relevant issues and developments related to the CFSP over the past year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the Union operates. It emphasizes the need for strengthened Union integration, including steps towards a 'defence union' and the need for Union institutions and Member States to revive this aspiration. The report also calls for the CFSP to play a more visible and effective role in conflict resolution, particularly in Syria, taking advantage of the Union's influence on all key regional actors, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. By our S&D amendments, it also offers a possibility for more constructive relations with Russia and outlines areas of common interest. In addition, we Socialists have included the importance of controlling Union arms exports, that is to say, refrain from selling arms to countries that do not meet the criteria for eligibility under the Union Common Position on the arms trade.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report deals with the implementation of the Union's common foreign and security policy. The report is annual and unfortunately, like the previous ones, it forms part of the general philosophy of the need for the EU to become a strong international player. The need to align the foreign policy of the Member States and to express it through a single voice is highlighted in several places. We understand that this serves the EU's sovereign circles aimed at fully identifying with the US and NATO. The report itself reaffirms our position that the further militarisation of foreign policy is now being promoted. As a group, we have tabled a minority opinion by expressing its views on the report. We fundamentally disagree with the militarisation of the foreign policy that is being promoted and we call for, among other things, no funding for military missions from the EU budget and a clear separation of the EU from NATO. We are calling for the EU to become a pillar of peace, not of war. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Maria Heubuch (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We welcome and support large parts of Mr Brok’s report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy and thank him for closely cooperating with our group on compromise language prior to the vote in committee. Europe’s neighbourhood is characterised by a growing number of armed conflicts and instability and we therefore very much support the call for a strengthened common foreign and security policy. However, we would like to clearly express our opposition regarding some of the proposals made in the report’s chapter on defence: we reject the Commission proposal on the financing of the European Defence Fund based on national contributions to be treated as one-offs under the Stability and Growth Pact. Member States should not further run into debt for defence and weaken the euro. We also reject the idea to use a number of existing civilian funds and divert financial resources to the defence industry such as the European Investment Bank, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, European Structural and Investment Funds, and the European Regional Development Fund. Instead, Member States should significantly strengthen military capabilities by pooling research, development, procurement and maintenance of capabilities.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the implementation of the European Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy emphasises that the Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges. It recalls the EU's commitment to contribute to the strengthening of democracy, the rule of law and human rights and international order through its foreign and security policy. Although the report also calls for a revision of the strategy for relations between the EU and Russia, I regret to note that I abstained from the vote, as the position of the Hungarian Government on this issue differs in several points from the official EU policy. Since sanctions against Russia have caused enormous economic damage to Hungary and several other Member States, and since, in my opinion, they do not achieve their objective in the long term, I could not support the points that would envisage the imposition of more serious sanctions.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which advocates for deeper integration, for building a diplomatic Defence Union, and for strengthening resilience through a range of available political, economic, military and humanitarian instruments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Report on Implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (2016/2036 (INI)), given that in recent years the security situation in Europe and its neighbourhood has deteriorated significantly and created new challenges. It is necessary that the Union's foreign policies are in conjunction with each other, but also with other policies that have an external dimension. The EU is committed to developing a common foreign and security policy inspired by the principles of democracy, the rule of law, universality and indivisibility of human rights and fundamental freedoms, and respecting the Charter of the United Nations and international law. I particularly support that the Report outlines enlargement policy as one of the most successful EU policies and which has contributed to ensuring stability, democracy and prosperity on the European continent, and reiterates strong support for the enlargement process. There is a problem of United Nations restrictions and calls on the EU and its member states to seek reform of the Security Council. The EU must strengthen its security and defence capacities to better use its full potential of the world power. The creation of a European Defence Union must be enacted unanimously among EU member states. It supports deepening cooperation between NATO and the EU in the areas of cybersecurity, migration, strategic communication. It is important to find ways to calm current tensions and establish constructive dialogue with Russia to identify measures aimed at reducing the risk of misunderstanding and miscalculations.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. - On many occasions, and this rule does not fail, such reports are solely intended to undermine national sovereignty by a combination of harmonizing and unitary remarks. Here, England's withdrawal from the European Union seems to reinforce the common foreign security policy. I voted against it.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. — Spanish Socialists have voted in favour of this annual report because it addresses the most relevant issues and developments related to the CFSP over the past year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the Union operates. It emphasizes the need for strengthened Union integration, including steps towards a 'defence union' and the need for Union institutions and Member States to revive this aspiration. The report also calls for the CFSP to play a more visible and effective role in conflict resolution, particularly in Syria, taking advantage of the Union's influence on all key regional actors, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. By our S&D amendments, it also offers a possibility for more constructive relations with Russia and outlines areas of common interest. In addition, we Socialists have included the importance of control over Union arms exports, that is to say, refrain from selling arms to countries that do not meet the criteria for eligibility under the Union Common Position on the arms trade.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Elmar Brok's report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. This report is an opportunity for the European Parliament to highlight European priorities in the field of security and foreign policy. Ethno-religious conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa have consequences for the security of European citizens. Therefore, the text calls on the High Representative to draw up a plan for the implementation of the EU's overall strategy based on defence, diplomacy and development.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it can lead to conflicts of interest from the point of view of a neutral Member State. The report deals with the effective implementation of a common security and foreign policy and deals with the various departments dealing with this issue. On a positive note, however, the rapporteur calls on the Member States to abide by the Lisbon Treaties, which provide for an efficient CSDP. The report also deals with the creation of an EU army, the financial increase of the EEAS, the extension of the ATHENA mechanism and the creation of a European Defence Fund, as well as closer cooperation with NATO.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We Greens welcome and support large parts of Mr Brok’s report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy and thank him for closely cooperating with our group on compromise language prior to the vote in committee. Europe’s neighbourhood is characterized by a growing number of armed conflicts and instability and we therefore very much support the call for a strengthened common foreign and security policy. However, we would like to clearly express our opposition regarding some of the proposals made in the report’s chapter on defence: we reject the Commission proposal on the financing of the European Defence Fund based on national contributions to be treated as one-offs under the Stability and Growth Pact. Member States should not further run into debt for defence and weaken the euro. We also reject the idea to use a number of existing civilian funds and divert financial resources to the defence industry such as the European Investment Bank, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, European Structural and Investment Funds, and the European Regional Development Fund. Instead, Member States should significantly strengthen military capabilities by pooling research, development, procurement and maintenance of capabilities.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this annual report, which addresses the most salient issues and developments pertaining to the CFSP over the last year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the EU operates: Brexit, Trump’s election as the US president, growing challenges along the EU’s eastern and southern borders prompted by an aggressive Russia. The report addresses these challenges by emphasising the need for a reinvigorated EU coordination, including decisive steps towards strengthening cooperation on defence. The report also stresses the need for the EU to play a more active role in conflict resolution by using the leverage the EU has over all key regional players, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The Brok report calls for a comprehensive extension of the European Common Foreign and Security Policy. The report calls for Member States to pool their national foreign policy interests into a common interest. I believe that this is an irreviable task, because the foreign policy interests of individual Member States sometimes diverge considerably. In addition, according to the EU treaties, foreign policy is and should remain the sovereignty of the nation states. Despite some common security interests, the call for a common EU security policy creates double structures with NATO. The dual structures, such as a separate military headquarters of the EU, would cost European taxpayers billions without providing any discernible added value. Instead, EU countries, which are also members of NATO, should honour their commitments in the Transatlantic Alliance. For these reasons, I have rejected the report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I could not support the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. This paper relied on EU and NATO cooperation, appreciated President Juncker's proposal to create a European Defence Fund to promote research and innovation, and promoted the emergence of a European military connected to NATO. I am truly convinced that the proposals do not reflect the demands of Europeans at all and represent unthoughtful steps that will not lead to an increase in security in the EU.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the implementation of the European Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy emphasises that the Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges. It recalls the EU's commitment to contribute to the strengthening of democracy, the rule of law and human rights and international order through its foreign and security policy. Although the report also calls for a revision of the strategy for relations between the EU and Russia, I regret to note that I abstained from the vote, as the position of the Hungarian Government on this issue differs in several points from the official EU policy. Since sanctions against Russia have caused enormous economic damage to Hungary and several other Member States, and since, in my opinion, they do not achieve their objective in the long term, I could not support the points that would envisage the imposition of more serious sanctions.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing. — Packaging is not bad, even attractive in some places, so you could sell the goods. However, according to the report, the EU has allegedly brought peace, stability and prosperity to its citizens and neighbouring countries, but for some reason the opinion of Syria, Libya, Egypt and the citizens of all countries that have been chaos with colorful revolutions and civil wars is different. The rapporteur also modestly conceals the fact that the EU is one of the world's largest arms exporters. The report unacceptable encourages further militarisation of the EU and closer EU-NATO cooperation and supports the consolidation of internal and external security to the detriment of Member States' sovereignty.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - With my voice, I supported the adoption of a resolution on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy, as I believe that the European Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges, including interstate conflicts, disintegration of states, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy insecurity, organised crime and climate change. The Community will only be able to respond effectively to these challenges if its structures and its Member States work together on a common and genuinely coordinated effort. The European Union is one of the greatest achievements in European history, aiming at achieving peace, stability and prosperity. It continues to be the most significant economic power, the most generous donor of humanitarian aid and development aid, as well as a leader in global diplomacy on issues such as climate change, international justice, non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and human rights. I believe that the EU must strengthen its security and defence capabilities. A strengthened and common civilian and military capacity is a key element for the Union to provide a comprehensive response to crises, build the resilience of its partners and protect Europe from the challenges.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — I am voting in favour of the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy which highlights the countless challenges facing the EU in the context of its external borders, terrorism, in the field of cybersecurity, disinformation, radicalisation and the fight against trafficking in human beings. Countering the uncertainties between internal and external security will only and exclusively be possible with strong commitment, responsibility, political will and leadership on the part of the Member States. In this regard, the report recommends that the Union's actions in relation to foreign affairs should be based on its three fundamental pillars: defence, development and diplomacy. It is called for the EU to fortify its security and defence capabilities and ensure peace and stability in neighbouring countries, and finally, it is considered essential that more attention should be put in preventing of conflicts, considering, above all, the Union's immense potential as a diplomatic player and guarantor of the protection of human rights and democracy.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The aim is to strengthen the common foreign and security policy to the detriment of the states, taking advantage of Brexit and the withdrawal of England, the main opponent of the project. This text is in itself a major attack on national sovereignty. Its provisions are not innovative: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of the States, and the unification of defence companies (under German rule).

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because it omits any criticism of the Union's economic and political imperialism in the exercise of the CFSP, when the Union's motives in its foreign policy are none other than ensuring the dominant relations between European capitals and governments over the countries in its neighbourhood.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: in writing. - The Brok report calls for a comprehensive extension of the European Common Foreign and Security Policy. The report calls for Member States to pool their national foreign policy interests into a common interest. I believe that this is an irreviable task, because the foreign policy interests of individual Member States sometimes diverge considerably. In addition, according to the EU treaties, foreign policy is and should remain the sovereignty of the nation states. Despite some common security interests, the call for a common EU security policy creates double structures with NATO. The dual structures, such as a separate military headquarters of the EU, would cost European taxpayers billions without providing any discernible added value. Instead, EU countries, which are also members of NATO, should honour their commitments in the Transatlantic Alliance. For these reasons, I have rejected the report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted against. At the beginning, the report notes nonsensically that “the EU is one of the greatest achievements in the history of Europe.” Then he calls for the emergence of an EU army, including a “permanent military headquarters,” a “military planning unit” and a “Defence Affairs Council.” Countries that want to cooperate militarily have NATO, and creating an EU army with parallel command is meaningless. Seeing how the Czech Republic upvoted on quotas, I don't want to wait for a downvote on military action. By warning us, be military action by France and its allies in Libya in 2011, which led to chaos, civil war, power grab by Islamic State and a giant migration wave that is a threat to the entire European civilization and the security of our citizens.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Today, the EU is facing numerous challenges, such as terrorism, cyber security, disinformation, human trafficking or radicalisation. Therefore, the Union's external action must be based on diplomacy, development and defence. This report outlines the current situation and challenges of international policy and underlines the need to bring together all instruments to safeguard the interests of the EU and its values. In the field of defence, it is necessary for the EU to strengthen security and defence capacities, and Member States must step up synergy in action by increasing defence cooperation. A key priority is ensuring peace and stability in the Union environment, as sustainable development is impossible without security. To this end, it is crucial to address the causes of instability, terrorism, radicalisation, forced migration and poverty in neighbouring countries. The report calls on the Union to show stronger leadership and take a stronger role in conflict prevention and economic diplomacy. These tools can help strengthen EU policies in these areas, so I have supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. — Europeans and politicians still believe that Europe is the centre of the world, which can dictate its rules to other countries and regions of the world. This is no longer the case, and practitioners who encounter foreign affairs every day can approve of it. The number of instruments of influence for European foreign policy is very limited. We still have strengths — technologies, education, a capacious internal market, influence in international organisations, opportunity to finance development projects. But with every step here, too, Europe is losing its influence. How quickly Europe will lose its position to other superpowers, and where the new balance point will ultimately be, will depend on how European countries can overcome disagreements and create a common, realistically working European foreign policy. This is the main question we have to ask ourselves in this report as well. Other issues, I think, are secondary.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The current political and security situation in the world requires the Union to ensure effective and effective protection of its citizens and their interests. The Union and the Member States must have the highest interest in conflict prevention. If they are created, they must be addressed with priority through diplomatic and peaceful channels. At the same time, the EU and the Member States must not resign for the necessary and proper defence and must therefore be prepared in advance for possible threats. The role and importance of building a common security policy and defence are, in particular, indisputable in this period. I therefore supported the resolution by which the EP calls on the Commission and the Member States to fulfil their tasks and commitments in the field of the common foreign and security policy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy for the reasons I explained in detail at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/12/2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the changing geopolitical landscape the EU will now face in 2017 and beyond, an analysis of developments and priorities was crucial. I agree with the report’s emphasis on reinvigorated policy coordination among Member States and the call for the EU to use its leverage with key regional actors, especially in the Middle East, to play a greater role in conflict resolution.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This report aims to strengthen the common foreign and security policy by taking advantage of the fact that England, which still opposed it, is considering its exit from the European Union. We do not accept that the role of the Member States should be further diminished in favour of the Community institutions. This report is therefore a major infringement on the national sovereignty of France and the other European states.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (Article 36 TEU). The European Union and its citizens are undergoing a period of instability and insecurity resulting from the impact of proliferation of terrorist groups, hybrid threats, cyber and energy insecurity, organised crime and interstate conflicts. Therefore, the Member States need our support, which will enable them to respond effectively to the new challenges that are having serious consequences on the well-being of citizens. Only by increasing cooperation and implementing stronger measures will the EU be able to continue fomenting peace, stability, and prosperity to its citizens and remain the largest economic power, the most generous donor of humanitarian and development assistance and a model in global diplomacy.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Today we addressed a report discussing the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. I would rate the report as militant, talking about the need to strengthen financial resources as well as personnel for the European Defence Agency, as well as alluding to the idea of building a common European the military, which I disagree with. A comprehensive passage is also devoted to denigrate Russia from aggressiveness, causing conflict and threatening Europe's security and cyber security, and the need to continue and preferably deepen sanctions against Russia. The highlight of NATO's role is also the content of this report. Because most of the ideas contained go against my beliefs, I voted against this report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The report deals with the effective implementation of a common security and foreign policy and deals with the various departments dealing with this issue. Among other things, there is talk of the need for Member States to abide by the Lisbon Treaties, which provide for an efficient CSDP. The rapporteur also calls for this to be visible in general foreign policy. It also addresses climate change, cybersecurity, the situation in Syria, the situation in other potentially vulnerable states and the situation with Russia. The report also deals with the creation of an EU army, the financial increase of the EEAS, the extension of the ATHENA mechanism and the creation of a European Defence Fund, as well as closer cooperation with NATO. As this report is contrary to Austria's neutrality, I voted against this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy. The report calls for more funds in this area, for compliance with commitments to allocate 2% of GDP for defence, for strengthening defence cooperation, and for the sanctions imposed on Russia.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: It has been several months since this Parliament has been working to promote a European army. The European project is out of breath. They believe that the fight against terrorism can revive the machine and ignore its contempt for the peoples. And for that, we would have to sell the tools of our French diplomacy and defence in Brussels. To promote peace? No, to strengthen the alliance with NATO. Because the UN has “limits”. Apart from the next European Council on Thursday, Parliament is making its recommendations here. He warns: we need to go further than a European command district. There is a need for a common defence market and binding regulations on States. Those who contribute will be able to obtain leniency on the golden rules of the European Semester. Trade policy must serve these interests. Regardless of Trump's election, CETA and TTIP must allow for deepening relations with these countries. All of them, including Greens, have embarked on this hysterical and warmongist race. Some by the appeal of endless communitarization, the others in their crazy race to tension with Russia. I vote against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: This text aims to strengthen the common foreign and security policy of the European Union, to the detriment of the sovereignty of the Member States. The European Union is taking advantage of Brexit for this implementation, since England was the main opponent. The text provides for a single foreign policy, an increase in the contribution of States and a unification of defence. I therefore voted against this text considering that this is a major attack on the sovereignty of nations.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: in writing. — (NL) The current crises in the world and in Europe's neighbourhood are also threatening the EU. Because these threats also effectively spread to the EU, in the form of terrorist attacks and refugee flows, this has implications for the security and well-being of our citizens. That is why, however, these crises are also a wake up call for the EU and an opportunity to set up an effective foreign and security policy that will ensure peace, stability and prosperity in Europe and beyond. I voted in favour of this report because it offers ambitious, balanced and realistic responses to the security challenges. A mature European foreign policy rests on three pillars: diplomacy, development and defence. Our own defence capacity with a permanent European military headquarters, as the citizens of Europe demand, will enable us to combine our soft approach with, if necessary, a tough approach. Moreover, with a European capacity for defence and deterrence, we are also better prepared to act swiftly, once all peaceful means have been exhausted and in cooperation with international partners, to prevent serious violations of human rights.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Council presented to the European Parliament its annual report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy. The Committee on Foreign Affairs proposes Parliament to adopt a resolution on this report. The proposal suggests that the EU is a success story that has brought peace, stability and prosperity to its citizens and neighbouring countries. The draft highlights the importance of the EU's responsibility for its own security, calls for closer cooperation between the EU and NATO, enhancing the EU's defence capabilities, strengthening the common security and defence policy, and the development of permanent structured cooperation. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The provisions of this text are nothing new in relation to what the European Parliament has used to ask for in the field of common foreign and security policy: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of the Member States, and the unification of defence companies, currently under German rule . With Brexit, and therefore the future withdrawal of England, the main opponent of this project, the European institutions are taking advantage of this opportunity to try to strengthen it to the detriment of national sovereignty. Of course, we are opposed to this text.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: This text is in itself a major infringement of national sovereignty. Its provisions are not innovative: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of the States, and the unification of defence companies (under German rule). I am obviously voting against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which addresses the most salient issues and developments pertaining to the CFSP over the last year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the EU operates: Brexit, Trump’s election as the US president, growing challenges along the EU’s eastern and southern borders prompted by an aggressive Russia. The report addresses these challenges by emphasising the need for a reinvigorated EU coordination, including decisive steps towards strengthening cooperation on defence. The report also stresses the need for the EU to play a more active role in conflict resolution by using the leverage the EU has over all key regional players, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP). The text sets out the priorities for meeting the challenges facing Europe, through the European Union's external action. These include the defence and security of the continent, development and diplomacy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ EU Member States have committed themselves to the Common Foreign Security Policy, which represents the organised and agreed foreign policy of the EU for security and defence actions and diplomacy.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy because I believe that it is increasingly necessary for the EU to respond in a coherent manner to all current security changes and threats. To this end, the EU must apply a common foreign and coordination policy strategy. With regard to security policy, together with foreign policy, it must be an integrated one, adapted to new challenges and enabling Member States to protect their citizens from personal security threats, but at the same time possess and the adaptability necessary for future possible changes on the international scene.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the non-legislative report calling, inter alia, for the EU to finally start using the instruments laid down in the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular a permanent structured cooperation in the field of defence (PESCO), and to accede to the deepening of the CSDP, in particular in the form of a permanent civilian and military headquarters, strengthening civil-military cooperation; and improving the ability of the EU to respond quickly to crises, strengthening the EU's rapid response tools in particular by increasing the applicability of combat groupings and strengthening the Eurocorps to make more use of in CSDP missions and operations.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — From Austria's point of view, this report must be strictly rejected as it is contrary to neutrality. In addition, this report is very hostile to Russia. I therefore opposed the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Good EU-US allied relations are the result of decades of work. Cooperation at several world pain points is important, with the US and EU vision of different crises and approaches to them similar both in Syria, in the fight against terrorism and in Ukraine. Such a good relationship must continue with the advent of a new administration, too. At the same time, it is important that the EU itself develops its defence capabilities in order to be prepared to defend its own security if necessary.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. Surrounded by an arc of instability ranging from aggressive Russia to proxy wars in the Middle East and North Africa, 70% of Europeans think there should be more Europe in terms of foreign and security policy. It was with these elements in mind that I supported this resolution on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. While power relations once again dominate international relations, we have recalled that defence military capabilities are essential for weighing in diplomatic negotiations. We therefore called for increased defence spending, pooled funds for European Union missions and measures to improve the possibilities for the use of EU rapid reaction forces (battle groups) and joint procurement of defence equipment.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of my colleagues proposal because I believe that in today's situation the European Union faces both internal and external challenges. In fact, EU Member States are surrounded by a wide arc of instability, for example much of the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) is a stage for continuous ethnic-religious conflicts. So implementing a common foreign security policy on the one hand will protect the EU from threats from other nations and, on the other hand, present an opportunity to improve its operation and its cooperation. I therefore voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I supported this report, which acknowledges the multifaceted challenges the EU is facing in the external domain, from terrorism, cyber security and misinformation to the fight against human trafficking or radicalisation. Effectively countering the ever-blurred nexus of external and internal security challenges will be possible with strong commitment, ownership, political will and leadership from the Member States. Furthermore, the report underlines that EU external action needs to be based on three pillars (the ‘three Ds’): diplomacy, development and defence.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. — Today, the EU faces unprecedented internal and external challenges, including conflicts between states, country breakdowns, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy uncertainty and organised crime. Europe is at risk of terrorism in its territory and there is to highlight thousands of returnees from the wars in Syria and Iraq in the EU who are members of terrorist groups. I especially express concern about the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and in which Islam as we have known it in BIH is becoming radical, especially in rural areas. While the number of fighters leaving Europe on battlefields to Syria and Iraq is reportedly decreasing, probably due to tighter controls, it should be taken into account that ISIL is now applying a strategy of instructing its like-minded people in Europe and the US not to travel to battlefields, but to forge and execute bloodthirsty plans in their own lands. These are alarming circumstances, and I am of the view that civilian and military capacities are key elements for the EU to fully respond to today's challenges and protect its citizens, and I support this report which encourages the strengthening of the Union's security and defence capacities.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The EU faces old and new challenges. To the instability and crisis in neighbouring countries, east and south, there are uncertainties about the new international context following the Brexit referendum and the election of Trump as president of the US. All in an economic situation that seems to be improving, but which is still far from rosy. For this reason, there is a need more than ever for a strong and united Europe, which can speak with one voice and that makes all its political, economic, moral and diplomatic weight felt in conflict resolution, in confrontation with an increasingly aggressive Russia and in the fight against terrorist groups. The report therefore reiterates the need to strengthen European integration, in particular by taking concrete steps towards a common defence and allowing the High Representative to play a greater role visible and actual. With regard to Russia, it will be necessary to support sanctions with a strategy aimed at finding areas of common interest and creating more constructive relations, while in the case of conflicts in Syria and Yemen, the EU must play a more active role, leveraging key regional players such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran, to achieve a peaceful solution.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The European Union is currently facing a number of internal and external challenges. This year's report reflects the environment in which the EU is currently operating which includes the issue of Brexit, relations with the US after the presidential election, growing challenges at its eastern and southern borders, and particularly instability in the south due to extreme Islamist groups. Therefore, I welcome President Juncker's proposal to create a European Defence Fund to encourage research and innovation. Member States should allocate adequate human and financial resources to implement the EU's global strategy, especially in the key areas of conflict prevention, security and defence. It is also time to set out a more realistic strategy for the EU's relationship with Russia. Sanctions were needed in response to Russian aggression in Ukraine and the EU should leave open the possibility of further gradual sanctions, but new relations should also be based on dialogue in areas of common interest, such as counterterrorism, non-proliferation of weapons and trade. Furthermore, the EU needs to play a more active and effective role in preventing conflict and peacebuilding, this particularly concerns the importance of finding a sustainable solution to the conflict in Syria. The EU needs to use its influence over key actors such as Iran, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Qatar and Russia to take a constructive stance and refrain from contributing to further escalation of the situation.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Another report that does not differ from previous ones, pursuing the militarist, security and external interference policy that characterizes the EU's action. The justification of this security drift is uneventably focused on the alleged threats facing the EU, to the east by the Russian Federation and to the south by terrorism and Islamic radicalism. The EU's responsibilities for escalating tensions to the east and promoting so-called 'Islamic radicalism' which has justified actions of aggression and interference in the Middle East and North Africa are completely omitted. Cynically presenting the EU as a project of success and prosperity, it carries on the federalist approach to militarism, further undermining the sovereignty of the Member States. It promotes the anti-democratic nature of the EU; advocates strengthening the defence budgets of MS and the EU; the role of the EU as the European military pillar of NATO; the reform of the UN Security Council seeking to ensure that it becomes an instrument at the service of the EU and imperialism. It promotes the policy of war, aggression, domination over third countries and oppression. Values that can never be reconciled with policies of disarmament and peace. We advocate another policy based on solidarity, cooperation and mutual respect between states, as a guarantor of peace. We voted against it.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. — I consider the European Union one of the greatest achievements in the history of Europe. The EU has brought peace, stability and prosperity to its citizens and neighbouring countries, many of which are now EU member states. I believe that the current political situation in the world is so unstable that the EU, as a guarantor of peace, must face it, otherwise it may be torn down into conflicts caused by by extreme Islamism or Russian expansionism. I believe that creating a so-called defence union and deepening EU integration, primarily for defence, is one of the best ways to preserve peace in Europe. I also believe that the EU should focus more on tackling the war in Syria, because the best help we can give refugees who immigrate to Europe en masse is precisely securing safe home.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. “The report outlines the CFSP in the context of current emergencies in the vicinity of the EU and further regions and assesses current and future risks to European security and aspirations. The rapporteur approves of the EU as a global power and precursor to international diplomacy, and urges member states to stop looking at foreign policy and security issues from a “limited domestic perspective.” The rapporteur calls for the strengthening of the CFSP on the basis of three pillars — defence, deterrence and response — while calling for analogous strengthening of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). The report made a number of other recommendations, including drafting a defence white paper, increased parliamentary control over the CFSP, strengthening the diplomatic arm of the EU-EEAS, as well as a review of EU relations with Russia. I believe that EU foreign and security policy can be an important tool for the implementation of multilateral, common interests. However, we also believe that it must never replace the capacity of a Member State to conduct, whenever the State concerned takes such a decision, its own independent policy in these areas. I hereby abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the foreign policy of the European Union. I am indeed in support of a strong and united Europe around foreign and security policy issues. European citizens suffer from the consequences of external conflicts, our duty is to protect them! The EU's external action must therefore be based on three pillars: diplomacy, development and defence. Our defence and deterrence capabilities must be increased so that the EU can weigh in diplomatic talks. We must also be less conciliatory with neighbouring countries that run counter to our democratic principles and human rights.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union is, by definition, a project of peace of stability, aiming for prosperity among its citizens and among the citizens of its neighbouring countries, notably through the donation of humanitarian assistance and development aid. However, the Union today faces unprecedented internal and external challenges, including new conflicts in the polymorphic international community, energy insecurity, terrorism, cyberinsecurity, organised crime and climate change. The Union will only be able to respond adequately to the new challenges if its structures and Member States jointly commit themselves to a joint and truly coordinated effort. The guarantee of peace and stability on our continent, in our neighbourhood and in Africa must be an axis of Europe's action. Therefore, and recalling the important role of parliamentary diplomacy in strengthening political cooperation with EU partners, I support this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. In particular, we rejected the self-congratulatory language referring to the EU as being one of the greatest achievements in European history and as a diplomatic superpower. We are concerned by proposed changes to the financial structures governing the CFSP and proposals for budgetary increases, as this could affect the UK before we leave the EU.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We welcome and support large parts of Mr Brok’s report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy and thank him for closely cooperating with our group on compromise language prior to the vote in committee. Europe’s neighbourhood is characterised by a growing number of armed conflicts and instability and we therefore very much support the call for a strengthened common foreign and security policy. However, we would like to clearly express our opposition regarding some of the proposals made in the report’s chapter on defence: we reject the Commission proposal on the financing of the European Defence Fund based on national contributions to be treated as one-offs under the Stability and Growth Pact. Member States should not further run into debt for defence and weaken the euro. We also reject the idea to use a number of existing civilian funds and divert financial resources to the defence industry such as the European Investment Bank, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, European Structural and Investment Funds, and the European Regional Development Fund. Instead, Member States should significantly strengthen military capabilities by pooling research, development, procurement and maintenance of capabilities.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - This report refers to the developments concerning the Common Foreign Security Policy that have emerged most in the past year and sets priorities for the future, taking into account developments in the geopolitical context, particularly in view of Brexit, the election of Trump, the challenges that arise in the East/South border against an aggressive Russia or extremist Islamic movements. Parliament believes that these challenges are nothing more than emphasising the need for enhanced EU integration, including decisive steps towards a 'defence union' and the need for EU institutions and Member States to commit to this goal, including providing funds appropriate.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In this flagship report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy, which was adopted by 433 votes in favour (including my own), 174 against and 93 abstentions, the European Parliament believes that European cooperation on foreign and security policy could bring 'the greatest added value'. Parliament stressed that Europe's action should henceforth be guided by the desire to ensure peace and stability on its continent, its neighbourhood and in Africa, and that the Union's external action should be based on three pillars: diplomacy, development and defence (the three D). Parliament emphasised defence, stating that since 'power relations are once again dominating international relations', 'defence and deterrence capabilities are essential for us to weigh in diplomatic talks. '

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. : The implementation of the CFSP last year clearly shows that the EU has faced not only an internal crisis but also an external crisis. The growing tensions and a sense of insecurity are just some of the signs of the failure of this policy, the crises, which are inaudible in the EU's voice, which do not bring more results to neighbours in European spaces. I supported this report, first of all because officials in charge of external relations can focus on their core work rather than rewriting the report, but it is clear that as current trends continue, the EU will also lose the remaining opportunities to act as a global player.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This report examines the current state and challenges inherent in international policy, as well as the consequent role that the European Union (EU) plays through its Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP). The rapporteur recognises and identifies the various challenges facing the EU in the external field, such as terrorism, cybersecurity, the fight against trafficking in human beings and radicalisation. In order to tackle today's internal and external security challenges effectively, the EU and its member states need strong commitment, political will and leadership of Member States. I therefore agree with the idea that the EU's External Action should be based on three basic pillars that support its union, integrity and security: diplomacy, development and defence. Ensuring peace and stability in Europe is a key priority for sustainable development and tackling the root causes of instability, terrorism, radicalisation and forced and irregular migration in the neighbourhood is crucial, and therefore the new partnerships on migration and the External investment is of enormous importance in this area. As I agree with the content of the report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which emphasises that diplomacy, development and defence should be the pillars of the European Union's foreign policy. In order to achieve our foreign policy objectives, the European Union must be united and speak with one voice; in this sense, it is important for Member States to show unity and trust. Current international conflicts have serious consequences for the security and well-being of European citizens. European cooperation in the field of foreign and security policy could thus bring greater added value. In this report, we also call for increased defence spending, as well as mutual funds for EU missions. Finally, it is important for the European Union to be active and expanding its cooperation on cybersecurity, migration, strategic communication and response to hybrid threats.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy. The report provides a comprehensive analysis of the current situation and the challenges of international affairs. It reflects the role of the EU in this context through its Common Foreign and Security Policy.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it is based on a securitarian and militaristic perspective which also draws conclusions without really analysing the causes of the current conflict situation. It raises the increase in arms spending and the increase of all military capabilities, but not to seek a non-aggressive deterrence, nor an independent Union, but on the contrary, it assumes positions in which it remains subordinate to the interests of the United States. In addition, the text celebrates the Warsaw Summit, and therefore the role of a global NATO that seems to compete with the UN and which assumes increasingly aggressive actions and positions with our East neighbourhood, generating greater tensions and conflict as we continue to bet on unilateral sanctions. This vision of the common foreign and security policy leads to further conflict, reveals to a Union that still does not understand geopolitical changes, and proposes to increase military expenditure by ignoring the severe economic and social crisis which seriously affects the European population. We reject the budget being devoted to military financing and we advocate a Union that will stop contributing to military escalation in and around the region.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it calls for an EU Army.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to support this report, which addresses the most salient issues and developments pertaining to the CFSP over the last year. It also sets priorities for the future and reflects on the changing geopolitical context in which the EU operates.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality of and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - The EU is currently facing internal and external challenges, including interstate conflicts, state failures, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy insecurity, organised crime and climate change. The EU will only be able to respond to all these challenges if its structures and Member States work together and co-ordinate their efforts in the area of the common foreign and security policy. In addition, the EU is currently surrounded by instability, as vast parts of the Middle East and North Africa are swept away in ethnic-religious conflicts and wars. These conflicts have direct and serious consequences for the security and welfare of EU citizens, as they are gradually expanding into the EU, whether in the form of terrorism or a massive influx of refugees. For this reason, the EU and its Member States must develop an effective foreign, security and defence policy that respects national interests while at the same time seeking to cooperate with international partners, the UN, NGOs, human rights defenders in order to promote peace, prosperity and stability all over the world.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy of the EU, whose main author is the long-time chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs from our PPE Elmar faction Brok. The resolution appropriately points to the increased need for coordination of military issues within the EU and better military readiness to any threats. I also agree that it is a good reminder of the commitments the Member States have to NATO, in particular concerning defence expenditure amounting to 2% of GDP that many countries, including the Czech Republic, should begin to comply. Nor does the text forget other possibilities for influencing the CFSP, in particular through development aid and diplomatic channels. Here I would like to draw attention to the great possibilities of a positive influence of European culture in the world, for example through the involvement of third countries in EU programmes to promote culture, education, research. On key foreign-policy issues, the resolution is delineated in the right direction. He reciprocally criticizes Russia for its aggressive policy toward Ukraine and calls on China to maintain peaceful relations in the region, including Taiwan.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — The European Union has faced unprecedented internal and external challenges in recent years, including interstate conflicts, country collapse, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy uncertainty, organised crime and climate change. However, the EU will only be able to respond effectively to all these new challenges if its structures and Member States participate in joint and truly coordinated efforts under the Common Foreign and Security Policy, which must be clearly outlined if it wishes to be successful. Although I welcome the report's view that none of the Member States alone can overcome the current challenges and that Member States must demonstrate a sufficient level of unity, political will and mutual trust, I am critical that the wording of the resolution is unfortunately still under-elaborated . The Common Foreign and Security Policy strategy reflected through the resolution is not clear enough, as does the resolution include several controversial and flawed parts. Among other things, it calls on Member States to increase their defence expenditure in order to meet NATO's capabilities targets that require at least two percent of GDP to be allocated to defence, which would naturally have an impact on Member States' public finances. Because there are simply more questions than answers in the text of the resolution, I did not support the resolution.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE)
text: in writing. - The EU's external action is based on three pillars: diplomacy, development and defence. This motion for a resolution launches a reform that will make the EU more able to offer its citizens a higher level of security. The EU, as a diplomatic superpower and at the same time as a soft force, must work to ensure world peace and stability in cooperation with its international partners, the United Nations and the NGOs. In this context, it should encourage the launching of further negotiations for the reunification of Cyprus. A significant increase in the financial resources allocated to the EU's external action is also necessary.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - The Brok report calls for a comprehensive extension of the European Common Foreign and Security Policy. The report calls for Member States to pool their national foreign policy interests into a common interest. I believe that this is an irreviable task, because the foreign policy interests of individual Member States sometimes diverge considerably. In addition, according to the EU treaties, foreign policy is and should remain the sovereignty of the nation states. Despite some common security interests, the call for a common EU security policy creates double structures with NATO. The dual structures, such as a separate military headquarters of the EU, would cost European taxpayers billions without providing any discernible added value. Instead, EU countries, which are also members of NATO, should honour their commitments in the Transatlantic Alliance. For these reasons, I have rejected the report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - European foreign and security policy must stand on three pillars, diplomacy, development and defence. Diplomacy must prevent potential conflicts in our immediate neighbourhood, effective development aid must stabilise the troubled countries, and effective defence must defend Europe against threats, including those brought by hybrid war and terrorism.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The European Union faces a number of challenges including interstate conflicts, terrorism, hybrid and cyber threats, organised crime and climate change. The EU will only be able to respond effectively to new challenges if EU structures and its members cooperate in joint and coordinated efforts under the CFSP/CSDP. The safety and wellbeing of EU citizens has seriously undermined the refugee problem and terrorism. The current internal and external crisis represents an opportunity for the EU and its members to better co-operate in the area of an effective common foreign and security policy as a priority area of action of the Union. The EU must work on cooperation with the Eastern Partnership countries with the aim of strengthening democratisation and good governance and to become full members of the CSDP mission for the purpose of security and stability of the region. I support this report because in the current internal and external crisis, the European Union must offer its citizens adequate solutions that will ensure peace, stability and prosperity of citizens and neighbouring countries.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for a report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy. As we accepted in the opinion of the Budget Committee, we can all be concerned that less than a third of all available funds were spent in 2015 in the area of the Common Foreign and Security Policy, which is unusual given the scale of international conflicts that also threaten the European Union. I also support the opinion of the Budget Committee, which calls on Member States to meet the criteria on spending 2% of GDP on national defence, such as Slovenia, but also need to invest more carefully in their defence capabilities to improve their capabilities in NATO and the EU .

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy because it underlines the need for common action by Member States in enforcement and defending the interests of the European Union in the world. It also highlights an increasingly interconnecting issue of external and internal security, which must also be responded to together, even given the worldwide nature of threats such as terrorism, disinformation campaigns or internet crime. The report further notes that foreign policy must be based on defence, development and diplomacy. The European Union has the potential to be a diplomatic superpower, but it must also be able to use its hard power for this soft power. That is, to increase its defense capabilities.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - As every year, the report forms part of the general philosophy of the need for the EU to become a strong international player. In addition to aligning the foreign policy of the Member States and expressing it through a single voice, the report highlights the Commission's new plans for a common defence and military policy. This certainly serves the EU's sovereign circles aimed at fully identifying with the US and NATO. We have voted against the report and our group has tabled a minority opinion in disagreeing with the militarisation of the foreign policy being promoted and calling for the immediate removal of the funding of military missions from the EU budget. Finally, it calls for the full separation of the EU from NATO.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of the adoption of a comprehensive and detailed report, from which I expect the European Parliament's political instruments to contribute, at last, to the EU's breakthrough in the implementation of a genuine, global, proactive and effective common foreign and security policy. This summary also reflects the fact that the greater and more direct external challenges now requires, and can, in fact, contribute to an improvement in the Union's response capacity, a defence union and a strengthening of the role of the Common External Action Service. It has reason to applaud the efforts of the High Representative and, on my part, it is important that the EP confirms that the European Parliament can continue to be its main ally in developing the unity and political will for the further development of the CSDP. Although the report refers to it, experience shows that not all Member States can now be expected to strengthen the EU's independent foreign policy image. As a Hungarian opposition representative, I am particularly concerned that today it is the Orbán Government that, on the basis of political calculations or corruption interests, is ready to serve Moscow's increasingly aggressive expansive aspirations, in which, more recently, by deploying the tools of hybrid war, It is also trying to undermine the EU's achievements and future through domestic political forces, elections, and actions and propaganda aimed at influencing public opinion in general, which we will have to pay more attention to in the framework of the CSDP in future.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. “The European Union today faces internal and external challenges that include interstate conflicts, the collapse of countries, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy uncertainty, organised crime. Unfortunately, these conflicts have direct and serious consequences for the safety and well-being of European citizens as they increasingly embrace the EU, whether in the form of terrorism, mass movement of refugees or disinformation campaigns aimed at bringing about divisions in our societies. However, this situation is also an opportunity to improve the functioning of the EU and enhance cooperation between Member States. Without firm commitment, co-responsibility, political will and leadership roles of individual countries, it is impossible to effectively implement the EU's common foreign, security and defence policy. Of course, there is no doubt that NATO is the foundation of collective security in Europe. But he enjoys the declaration of cooperation between NATO and the EU adopted at the Warsaw summit. I fully support the deepened cooperation between NATO and the EU on security, as a stronger NATO and stronger EU are mutually strengthening and complementing each other.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union is a significant international actor, aiming to have a major positive impact on the development of events in various parts of the world. In this respect, the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) is the instrument by which the Union seeks to achieve its objectives externally. Events have taken place lately, which constitute a challenge to the CFSP and the EU's response capacity. These include Brexit, the election of Donald Trump as President of the United States, threats at the Union's southern and eastern borders, Russia's aggressive action in the EU's neighbourhood, and the actions of Islamic extremist groups. In order to be able to counter these threats, the EU needs to step up the process of European integration, including by creating a 'Defence Union' and by supporting the position of the High Representative by the Member States.
