Regarding Russia, the current economic sanctions are the result of its aggressive and revisionist action in eastern Ukraine on the annexation of Crimea, but this must not be a hindrance to further dialogue in the bilateral relationship. The EU can also play an important role in resolving conflicts in Syria and Yemen. I support the adoption of this important report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the text proposed to the vote. The European Union is one of the greatest successes in European history, and the Union's ability to bring about change has brought peace, stability and prosperity to its citizens and neighbouring countries, many of whom have become EU Member States. It should be stressed that the Union remains the largest economic power, the most generous provider of humanitarian and development aid and a tenor of global multilateral diplomacy on issues such as climate change, international justice, the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and human rights. The visibility of the Union's action in these areas needs to be strengthened. The current internal and external crisis can also give the Union an opportunity to improve its functioning and cooperation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Common Foreign Security Policy aims to strengthen the EU’s ability to act externally through the development of military capabilities in conflict prevention and crisis management. The report on the implementation of the Common Foreign Security Policy assesses the role of the CFSP in the context of current and future risks facing the EU. More importantly, the report calls for a stronger external policy with the aim of safeguarding Europe’s interests and values, at home and abroad. I voted in favour of the report because I share the same vision of a stronger global and external engagement strategy as key priority for the stability and security of Europe.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The positive vote for Mr Brok's report is part of a strong support for the Union's action to address security and defence issues. Common civilian and military capabilities are key elements in enabling the European Union to respond fully to crises, develop partner resilience and protect Europe from internal threats and External. The common security and defence policy must be strengthened in order to increase its effectiveness, including by promoting investment in advanced technologies. Finally, I agree with the view that any decision to move towards a desirable European Defence Union must be adopted unanimously by the Member States.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: in writing. The report on the implementation of the European Union's Common Foreign and Security Policy emphasises that the Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges. It recalls the EU's commitment to contribute to the strengthening of democracy, the rule of law and human rights and international order through its foreign and security policy. Although the report also calls for a revision of the strategy for relations between the EU and Russia, I regret to note that I abstained from the vote, as the position of the Hungarian Government on this issue differs in several points from the official EU policy. Since sanctions against Russia have caused enormous economic damage to Hungary and several other Member States, and since, in my opinion, they do not achieve their objective in the long term, I could not support the points that would envisage the imposition of more serious sanctions.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the “Motion for a Resolution on Implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy”. First of all, I believe that the European Union must develop a common security policy so that it can readily respond to the security threats and challenges that lie ahead. First of all, it is necessary to find an adequate solution to the migrant crisis, which has demonstrated a number of weaknesses in the functioning of the European Union, especially when taking into account the unevenness of Member States' approach in addressing the issue. Boundary permeability proved to be the area for which it is most important to find an adequate solution. The European Union must not allow any country or alliance to directly determine the throughput of the European Union's external borders. This issue is not just a question of security, but generally the credibility of the institutions of the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. - The Treaty of Lisbon sought to make the Common Foreign and Security Policy of the European Union more coherent and tangible. In this regard, the European External Action Service and the High Commissioner for Foreign and Security Policy of the European Union have been established. While I agree that joint action of the European Union in the foreign and security policy segment is not only a desirable but sometimes necessary and very useful tool for multilateral cooperation and solving common problems, I still believe that the above should never and in no way diminish the right individual, national Member States of the Union to implement independent policies in all those segments of foreign and security policy which they deem necessary. So I voted abstentions.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The European Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges involving interstate conflicts, country collapse, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy uncertainty, organised crime and climate change. He encounters terrorist threats even on its own territory. Europe will only be able to respond effectively if its structures and Member States work uniformly. It is smart intent on drawing up a security and defense implementation plan. We are surrounded by unstable hotspots (Middle East, Africa, Russia) which has direct implications on the welfare and security of EU citizens. This is now an opportunity for the EU to improve its functioning and cooperation (single foreign policy, disinformation struggle, defence strengthening...). The EU needs to strengthen its security and defence capabilities, as it will only be able to use its full potential of a global force if it has no rivals to escort its soft power with hard power as part of the EU's comprehensive approach. Apart from defence and diplomacy, sustainable development is one of the three pillars on which EU foreign policy must work and it is difficult to strengthen the market without security and stability. As soon as possible, it is necessary to find a solution to the conflict in Syria, including with the help of Turkey as a partner.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report has been particularly unbalanced and contradictory: especially on the issue of propaganda, the wording in the report did not always reflect the reality. The intentions for foreign policy are unclear, as references are often made to building bridges and at the same time burning them down. I feel that in order to strengthen the position of the European Union in the world, the approach of the European Union should be different than the one described in the report. In the current political climate, the European Union has to have a clear and stable approach to foreign and security policy. Only then can we send the right message.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: in writing. - The Brok report calls for a comprehensive extension of the European Common Foreign and Security Policy. The report calls for Member States to pool their national foreign policy interests into a common interest. I believe that this is an irreviable task, because the foreign policy interests of individual Member States sometimes diverge considerably. In addition, according to the EU treaties, foreign policy is and should remain the sovereignty of the nation states. Despite some common security interests, the call for a common EU security policy creates double structures with NATO. The dual structures, such as a separate military headquarters of the EU, would cost European taxpayers billions without providing any discernible added value. Instead, EU countries, which are also members of NATO, should honour their commitments in the Transatlantic Alliance. For these reasons, I have rejected the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: The aim is to strengthen the common foreign and security policy to the detriment of States by taking advantage of the withdrawal of England, the main opponent of the project. This text is in itself an attack on national sovereignty. Its provisions are not innovative: a single foreign policy, an increase in the budgetary contribution of the States, and the unification of defence companies (under German rule). I voted against it.

name: Helga Trüpel (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – We welcome and support large parts of Mr Brok’s report on the Common Foreign and Security Policy and thank him for closely cooperating with our group on compromise language prior to the vote in committee. Europe’s neighbourhood is characterised by a growing number of armed conflicts and instability, and we therefore very much support the call for a strengthened common foreign and security policy. However, we would like to clearly express our opposition regarding some of the proposals made in the report’s chapter on defence: we reject the Commission proposal on the financing of the European Defence Fund based on national contributions to be treated as one-offs under the Stability and Growth Pact. Member States should not further run into debt for defence and weaken the euro. We also reject the idea to use a number of existing civilian funds and divert financial resources to the defence industry such as the European Investment Bank, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises, European Structural and Investment Funds, and the European Regional Development Fund. Instead, Member States should significantly strengthen military capabilities by pooling research, development, procurement and maintenance of capabilities.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The report outlines the CFSP in the context of current emergencies in the vicinity of the EU and further regions and assesses current and future risks to European security and aspirations. E. Brok expresses approvingly about the EU as a global power and precursor to international diplomacy, and urges member states to stop looking at foreign policy and security issues from a “limited domestic perspective.” I believe that EU foreign and security policy can be an important tool for the implementation of multilateral, common interests. But it cannot replace a member state's ability to pursue its own foreign and security policy. I abstained.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. − The European Union is one of the greatest achievements of European history and that thanks to the transforming power of the EU, its citizens and neighbouring countries, many of which have become EU Member States, can live in peace, stability and prosperity. I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report on the Union's common foreign and security policy, as it calls for a strengthening of the Union's military structures, which would require an increase in Member States' contributions. Among other things, the report is good at the policy of cooperation with Turkey in the management of the flow of asylum seekers.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report because I am not in favour of increasing the EU Member States’ military spending, and because the text has some language on migration that I cannot support.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the proposal to consider the state of implementation of the strategy every year. I believe that this debate should take place during the annual debate in Parliament and should be based on the implementation report prepared by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: in writing. — Today Europe faces unprecedented external and internal challenges, including transnational conflicts, terrorism, hybrid threats, lack of cybersecurity and energy security, organised crime and climate change. The citizens of the European Union (EU) are under threat of terrorism, massive refugee flows and disinformation campaigns designed to split society. All this directly affects the well-being of citizens, and therefore requires a foreign policy that can defend our interests and values. I support the resolution, which, among other things, calls on EU Member States to increase their mutual trust and ability to speak with one voice in response to developments in foreign policy. The EU can only be a strong global partner equivalent to other superpowers if all Member States express a common position and act jointly in pursuit of a strong EU foreign and security policy. In Latvia, we feel that Russia continues to disregard the sovereignty of neighbouring countries and openly challenges the order of peace and security in Europe and the world. The Kremlin's official propaganda portrays the West as an adversary and actively seeks to undermine unity in Europe. I believe that sanctions have been and are an effective tool for foreign policy, so they must be maintained as long as Russia continues to violate international law. Support the position that EU foreign policy should be based on three pillars: diplomacy, development and certainly defence. It should be stated uniformly and unequivocally to the Russian government that its actions in Ukraine and air manoeuvres in the Baltic States will not be left unattended.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report assesses the priorities for the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) presented by the High Representative. The geographical priorities of external action include relations with Russia, the United States, Canada and Latin America, and the importance of the Eastern Partnership, Turkey, Syria and, in general, the Middle East and North Africa areas. It emphasizes the need to further deepen the Implementation Plan, as well as the narrowing of EU-NATO relations. It explains the importance of the three “D” (Defence, Development and Diplomacy) when designing community strategies in these areas. It values the transatlantic relationship to meet common challenges, mentioning the importance of increasing parliamentary diplomacy and the CFSP budget. In general, it argues that foreign policy tools must be developed consistently and consistently to protect European values and interests. In this regard, he recalls that strong commitment and political will are needed to effectively address current challenges — from terrorism to cybersecurity, radicalization or human trafficking. I therefore supported this text with my vote.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it is based on a securitarian and militaristic perspective which also draws conclusions without really analysing the causes of the current conflict situation. It raises the increase in arms spending and the increase of all military capabilities, but not to seek a non-aggressive deterrence, nor an independent Union, but on the contrary, it assumes positions in which it remains subordinate to the interests of the United States. In addition, the text celebrates the Warsaw Summit, and therefore the role of a global NATO that seems to compete with the UN and which assumes increasingly aggressive actions and positions with our East neighbourhood, generating greater tensions and conflict as we continue to bet on unilateral sanctions. This vision of the common foreign and security policy leads to further conflict, reveals to a Union that still does not understand geopolitical changes, and proposes to increase military expenditure by ignoring the severe economic and social crisis which seriously affects the European population. We reject the budget being devoted to military financing and we advocate a Union that will stop contributing to military escalation in and around the region.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it addresses the most salient issues and developments pertaining to the Common Foreign Security Policy over the last year and sets priorities for the future. It reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the EU operates and addresses these challenges by emphasising the need for a reinvigorated EU coordination.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour because the European Union faces unprecedented internal and external challenges, including conflict between states, the collapse of states, terrorism, hybrid threats, uncertainty about cyber and energy security, organised crime and climate change.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Today the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy, which I voted against. The report sets out guidelines for changing the EU in the direction of the military alliance. This is the kind of development I can't help but support. I have stated on several occasions that I am in favour of greater rational military cooperation. This includes, inter alia, cooperation with regard to the procurements of war materials. Instead, a development towards a military alliance or even a military superpower I cannot support.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — A European army in the future through a European defence strategy and action plan: this is the answer to Brexit to “reassure” the European peoples proposed by the French government in particular. Fears are fuelled with the usual recourse to the necessary fight against insecurity and terrorism to justify an increase in military spending, strengthen joint research and the need to increase... 'European defence market'. The “Europe of peace” is preparing to accompany its most belligerent states in their militarist follies. And we're going to get even closer to NATO as a bonus. Conversely, we attack the United Nations and its limits, which are certainly real, but the blame on whom? Rather, it is on this side that we should look at before it is too late, for the United Nations to regain its original ambitions and to ensure that the decisions taken by the General Assembly, inter alia, cease to face the blockages of the so-called great Powers, whatever they may be. It is peace that we need and men and women who are fighting for it. Of course I voted against this report.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The report deals with the effective implementation of a common security and foreign policy and deals with the various departments dealing with this issue. Among other things, there is talk of the need for Member States to abide by the Lisbon Treaties, which provide for an efficient CSDP. The rapporteur also calls for this to be visible in general foreign policy. It also addresses climate change, cybersecurity, the situation in Syria, the situation in other potentially vulnerable states and the situation with Russia. The report also deals with the creation of an EU army, the financial increase of the EEAS, the extension of the ATHENA mechanism and the creation of a European Defence Fund, as well as closer cooperation with NATO. As this report is contrary to Austria's neutrality, I voted against this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the common foreign and security policy (Article 36 TEU). I think it is good to continue the success story of transforming the European Union through action. We need to take responsibility for our security by strengthening our capabilities in terms of security and defence. We need to develop resilience and invest in a genuine global approach through development, support and enhancement projects. The role of parliamentary diplomacy should be highlighted in order to strengthen political cooperation with EU partners.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: in writing. — A propagandistic threat backdrop of an allegedly aggressive Russia is intended to work towards the formation of an EU army that is no longer to be controlled by the nation states. Formulations such as “using full potential as a world power” and the EU-wide increase in the military budget clearly show where the journey is headed: more wars, more interventions, more attempts at blackmail against other peoples. In the interests of peace, this report must be rejected.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which reflects the changing geopolitical context in which the EU operates: Brexit, Trump’s election as the US president, growing challenges along the EU’s eastern and southern borders prompted by an aggressive Russia and more. The report addresses these challenges by emphasising the need for a reinvigorated EU coordination process, including decisive steps towards strengthening cooperation on defence. The report also stresses the need for the EU to play a more active role in conflict resolution by using the leverage the EU has over all key regional players, such as Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Iran. However, the EU must remain above all a project of peace. In our common security and defence policy we must emphasise the need to refrain from selling arms to regimes which violate human rights and commit war crimes. The EU must always stand for human rights, democracy and the rule of law, and nothing in our CSDP should ever compromise those commitments. Also, Labour MEPs abstained or voted against recommendations on the Defence Union that offer ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted on the own-initiative report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The rapporteur stresses that the EU must strengthen its security and defence capabilities, as it can only use its full potential as a world power if it combines its undeniable uncoercive power with coercive power in its approach comprehensive. The report recalls that strengthening common civilian and military capacities is essential for the EU to respond fully to crises, to build partners' resilience and to protect Europe. It is noted that since force relations once again dominate international relations, defence and deterrence capabilities are fundamental to exercising our influence in diplomatic negotiations. In this respect, the rapporteur reaffirms that the common security and defence policy needs to be strengthened and intensified, because the only realistic way to strengthen our military capabilities during this period of budgetary constraints is to increase synergies by intensifying cooperation in the field of defence, based on the needs of all Member States, and by focusing on investment.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - This report analyses the state of play and the challenges on the international scene that the EU has to face. I particularly highlight the efforts to formulate the need for a common coherent foreign and security policy. The EU faces many challenges, from terrorism to cyberattacks, disinformation to radicalisation problems. From the right, it stresses that the EU's external action must be based on three pillars: diplomacy, development and defence. The European Union must strengthen its security and defence capabilities by combining soft and hard power. At the same time, the EU has the potential to become a diplomatic superpower, which is currently unable to fully exploit. The EU needs to focus its diplomacy more on preventing and preventing conflicts, but also mediating them. I support this report because it is extremely important for the EU to be united nowadays, especially externally.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the report presented and believe that the EU's common security and defence policy should be clearly strengthened. The SBZP has the potential to perform a unique and complementary role in the field of global security, but I feel that Member States are not aware of this. Indeed, the current problem is without question the willingness of states to contribute to their own defense and the general failure to deal with defense at the collective level. Personally, I think it is not essential enough at this time whether security will be ensured through the cooperation of the armed services of the States or thanks to the joint European forces. It is important that the European Union can respond quickly and efficiently to current security threats and problems. European Union states should therefore now seek to maintain defence spending levels of 2% of GDP and improve cooperation between national armed forces.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Elmar Brok Report is an important document because it allows you to look at Community foreign policy in a holistic way. The analysis of the situation contained in it is reliable, in-depth, but also critical in many places. It is essential that the Union institutions are able to exercise an objective assessment of their own actions, including those not entirely successful. I am pleased to point out the problem of disinformation carried out by third countries and to point out the need to counter this phenomenon. There is also the issue of the threat of cyber attacks. Here, too, we need to do more to protect data and ensure sustainable and secure access to the network. As a positive, I take the strong declaration of support for the EU enlargement process and close cooperation with the countries of the Eastern Partnership and the Balkans. Strong defence is listed as one of the three pillars of EU external action. Presented in November, the so-called defensive package is a step in the right direction. I hope it doesn't end with once again creating and adopting a good description of reality with which community policy strategists will do little.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I did not support the report on the implementation of the common foreign and security policy. The report focused on the analysis of the common foreign and security policy in the light of the current crises in the European neighbourhood and sought to identify possible future security risks. It has assessed the European Union as a global superpower and leader of international diplomacy. The report questioned traditional approaches to foreign and security policy and proposed a change in the mindset of Member States in this area. I think that the report rightly pointed out that the current threats facing not only the European Union are unprecedented and enhanced cooperation with NATO as well as additional funding will be required to cope with them. However, I do not agree with the calls for reform of the UN Security Council or with proposals for permanent structured cooperation at EU level. Although these challenges were conceived in a very mild language in the report, I believe they do not coincide with the Member States' competences in this area, which is why I finally decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the Brok report because I agree that at a time of unprecedented geopolitical challenges for the EU, deeper integration is needed, which involves building a defence union and maximising the Union's diplomatic influence. I would remind you that the European Union is one of the greatest successes in European history and that its transformative power has brought peace, stability and prosperity to its citizens as well as to its neighbouring countries, many of which have become EU Member States. I also stress that the Union remains the largest economic power and the largest donor of humanitarian assistance and development aid, as well as a pioneer in global diplomacy in areas such as climate change, international justice, non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and rights Humans. I therefore believe that the current internal and external crisis also represents an opportunity for the Union, provided that it is used to improve its functioning and cooperation to make the EU better, more democratic and capable of meeting citizens' expectations.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on Implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy. The EU is now surrounded by a series of hotspots of instability, with much of the Middle East and North Africa being covered by ethnic and religious conflicts and wars in which major forces are indirectly involved, and terrorist groups spread across the region. The report I supported analyses a comprehensive analysis of the current situation and challenges of international affairs and the role of the EU. Internal and external security challenges are complex. An effective security policy is possible only through the cooperation and political will of all Member States.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: Madam President, I wanted to explain my positive vote on this report on price volatility in agricultural markets. It is perhaps one of the problems that concern our European agriculture most and needs to be addressed. Very interesting measures are taken here, for example, that there is a European regulation covering all farmers and prohibiting unfair trade practices in the food chain, and thus solving this serious problem for our farmers. The second point I would like to highlight and for which I supported the report is that the objectives of the common agricultural policy must prevail over competition rules. Thirdly, it is absolutely amazing that as a European Union we do not protect our agricultural model. While we diminish our strategic support in the budget, our competitors, such as the US, China or Brazil, do the opposite. I want a better future for European farmers and agriculture. That is why I voted yes on this report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as an Irish MEP, the representation of agricultural interests is one which lies at the forefront of my agenda. Thus I chose to vote in favour of this report given the rapporteur’s efforts to identify tools which will help to lessen price volatility in this sector. In the light of economic, political and natural factors which often prove to be outside our control, I welcome renewed efforts to regulate said volatility in this domain. In doing so we may take a positive step towards the modernisation of existing CAP tools.  I also welcome this report’s appraisal of the often significant gap between supply and demand in the agricultural market. I would therefore hope that the recommendations of this report will continue to place rural development as a priority on our agenda, thus promoting greater stability in this sphere. Having met, in recent weeks, many farmers in my constituency who have suffered unbelievably due to volatility in tillage, dairy and beef, any measures that can reduce volatility and give them certainty as regards income will be most welcome and they will welcome it too.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Madam President, European producers are exposed to a number of difficulties. While authorities in the United States, Brazil and other countries competitive in agricultural production adopt and maintain measures to protect their producers through financial means to develop risk-related policy models, Europe is still failing to keep up. Evidence of this is the crisis in a number of agricultural sectors across the continent. Geopolitical decisions, climate change and equipment price growth are just some of the factors affecting the volatility of the sector in Europe. In the framework of Regulation No 1305/2013, Member States were proposed to provide for a 'risk management' measure within the framework of the second pillar of the CAP. The Bulgarian government, led by Boyko Borissov, which appeals almost daily for the implementation and absorption of the Common Agricultural Policy in Bulgaria, has not yet proposed a mechanism for this measure. Should we wait for other forms of embargoes or crises for a mechanism to be proposed to protect the Bulgarian farmer? It is time for a qualitative change in this strategically important sector for Bulgaria and GERB proved that they cannot do it.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The agricultural market has always been characterised by substantial price volatility, but in recent times this situation has worsened especially due to the volatility of the demand and supply of agricultural products. To resolve this situation we need to act in a concrete way, proposing and applying measures and policies aimed at reducing price variability. Unfortunately, although it contains some positive elements, this report merely exposes the situation without really proposing something to deal with the problem. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because, although we agree that price volatility is a very serious problem for the agricultural sector, it does not identify the real causes of this volatility, linked to the current agricultural model driven by the Union, the liberalisation of this market, excess production and export promotion and new markets. The solutions proposed in this report are based on risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, as well as public-private partnerships within the CAP's crisis management tools. But these do not represent a long-term solution, they are not effective and are created almost exclusively to benefit the larger farms, thus reversing for the benefit of the agro-industrial model.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) measures to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets. As a result of the dependence of farming on biological processes, uncertainty prevails in the related markets. The globalisation of agricultural trade also poses health risks (disease spread) and risks of supply or demand jumps. They are determined by external causes related to the EU's external policy in the fields of trade, diplomacy or development cooperation, and therefore there is even greater uncertainty and greater economic risk in the future. Therefore, risk management measures in agriculture receive increasing attention. The increasing interest in this subject is evidenced by the gradual spread of these measures in agricultural policy. The price volatility of agricultural products is already one of the main factors of the dramatic current situation of many European farmers, and the current risk management measures of the CAP are clearly not adapted to limit the impact of price volatility on farmers' incomes. As part of the CAP, the EU must find solutions to eliminate this phenomenon. In order to send a clear message to all citizens and farmers in particular, the resolution seeks to confine itself to combating price volatility and to clearly identify the three main steps needed to do so: strengthening the structure of supply chains and activating the conclusion of contracts, better protection increase the transparency of markets by setting up price monitoring centres, by introducing appropriate measures to manage price volatility risk.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: This own-initiative report has been subject to many debates and amendments since its preparation. As some Members have pointed out, Mrs Delahaye's report contains a basic cyclical error: it aims to combat price volatility in agricultural markets, when these prices are no longer volatile but desperately low, for two years. The current question is therefore rather low price stagnation. This own-initiative report is difficult to understand. The analysis of the causes of volatility and difficulties faced by agriculture is fragmented and poorly hierarchical. In the absence of a coherent framework (Mrs Delahaye has repeatedly warned MEPs against this risk, without changing anything herself), this text is a tote, in which common sense measures (notably public interventionism in the markets, or improved contractualisation) and others, much more dangerous, which reinforce the financialisation of agriculture or the administrative burden of the CAP. That is why, together with my colleagues from the National Front, we voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report demonstrates the lack of understanding the EU has on agricultural matters and continues to push for further EU interference that in my opinion is not needed and should be decided at a national level. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the proposals made in this text. Anxiety and despair are unfortunately the feelings that dominate today in the peasant world. The constant obsession has led to the abolition of quotas, which now forces our milk and meat producers to sell at a loss. It is now more than urgent to equip ourselves with instruments of protection to prevent and resolve crises. Indeed, I think it is appropriate to establish European mechanisms for balancing supply and demand and to involve producer associations and PDOs in fixing the volumes delivered according to price level. It is time for Europe to reconcile producers and consumers.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: ‒ The VVD supports the development of new and existing (financial) risk management instruments - within the framework of the common agricultural policy - which can make farmers more resilient to price fluctuations. The VVD believes that binding European rules on unfair commercial practices are not the right instrument and is also awaiting the impact assessment of the European Commission in this respect. The VVD wants more attention to voluntary and self-regulatory initiatives initiated by the sector. Nor is the VVD in favour of the idea that CAP objectives should prevail over competition rules and that the crisis reserve should be placed outside the EU budget.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on CAP measures to reduce price fluctuations on agricultural markets. The CAP has been characterized by strong market regulation. The aim of the CAP was to guarantee prices. By regulating prices, farmers were guaranteed minimum prices for their products in the event of a crisis. However, over time, the CAP has been cyclically reformed, leading to a significant change in price regulation. Following the 2013 reform, the second pillar of the CAP (rural development) provides for a new set of risk management measures. Therefore, the current risk management measures in the second pillar of the CAP are clearly not adapted to limit the impact of price volatility on farmers' incomes. In this context, I support Parliament's recommendation to strengthen the measures of the current second pillar in order to increase the competitiveness of European agriculture and to involve producer organisations more closely in the implementation process.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The report examines options for reducing price fluctuations in agricultural markets. It provides a good historical overview of the CAP's proposals, which are changing from time to time from the beginning of the 1990s, thus embedded in their context. The report may also be seen as a necessary and timely precursor of the review and adjustment directions of the CAP 2014-2020 financial cycle, at least in the three areas it has undertaken. These areas are: 1) the need to create and strengthen producer organisations; 2) strengthen and promote risk management tools in the second pillar; 3) improve market transparency by setting up price monitoring centres. The special merit of the work is thorough detail, with which it seeks to identify the causes of price fluctuations which are unfavourable to both farmers and consumers. In doing so, it points out appropriate criticism of the negative effects of free trade rules, the consequences of weather exposure, rising inputs and decreasing profitability, as a result of which millions of economies are disappearing from the EU economy over a cycle. I supported the report on its up-to-date and objective findings.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. — Mrs Delahaye's report is based on a gross mistake: it aims to combat price volatility in agricultural markets, when these prices are no longer volatile but desperately low, for two years. The current question is therefore rather the stagnation, at a low level, in prices. The result is many inconsistencies, with several incompatible projects: regulation of supply, setting up countercyclical aids, mutual funds or the use of insurance on courses - as the Americans do. This text is a tote, with good ideas and some much worse, which would reinforce, for example, the financialisation of agriculture or the administrative burden of the CAP, and that is why I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — Price volatility on agricultural markets severely penalizes agricultural activity. I therefore endorsed this report, which calls for a more incisive and coherent policy implementing targeted instruments at both national and EU level to ensure sustainable and multifunctional agricultural production throughout the EU and fair and remunerative prices, including reducing the impact of the negative effects on the players most exposed to price volatility.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. I believe that the problem of price volatility in the agricultural market is not reduced to a problem of balance between supply and demand, as the report insists. Price volatility can affect global food security and it is a problem that we must put an end to a blatant way. I think this report is not strong enough. The report is looking for solutions in the wrong place in my opinion. Price volatility is also related to many other macroeconomic variables in addition to political will, environmental legislation and speculation with agricultural products and food. The problem dealt with in the report is a structural problem given the agricultural market model that exists in the Union, presenting more risk management tools does not solve the problem in the long run, it only conceals it.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on the CAP instruments to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets. I also supported asking the European Commission to create a European legislative framework prohibiting unfair trade practices in the food supply chain which could lead to price volatility in agricultural markets.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets aims to combat price volatility in agricultural markets, when these prices are no longer volatile but desperately low, for two years. The current question is therefore rather low price stagnation. On the other hand, the proposed tools here are only too partial or overestimated. Indeed, the improvement of the price observatory and contractualisation is illusory if we do not reform the competition law which penalizes our producers. Moreover, the combined addition of supply regulation projects, counter-cyclical aid, mutual funds or the use of insurance on prices (see USA) is inconsistent. The framework is not coherent and this text is more like a tote in which common sense measures coexist (notably public interventionism in markets...) but other more dangerous (financialisation of agriculture, administrative weight of the CAP...). So I voted against to protect our farmers.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Although the text is generally shareable, I decided for a vote of abstention because of the little incisiveness and the poor value of the contribution brought by this report at the beginning of a phase very important future review of the CAP.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — As this report points out, which I supported with my vote, price volatility and volatility due to shocks in demand, supply and prices have in recent years become a structural element of agriculture, both at European and global level. Unfortunately, the European Union does not have a real safety net to curb market volatility, which is a strong disincentive to the maintenance of agricultural activity on the territory of the Union. In view of this reality, this report calls for strengthening the organisation of sectors and contractualization, as well as the bargaining power of farmers. It also urges the promotion of risk management tools adapted to price volatility and provided with sufficient resources, requesting new instruments from the European Commission. Finally, it calls for greater transparency of markets through the creation of a European price observatory covering the entire chain and all sectors.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which deals with the common agricultural policy (CAP) measures to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets. Farming depends on biological processes and is therefore strongly influenced by climatic conditions and diseases of plants and animals. These natural factors are not under the control of farmers. Thus, it is much more difficult to define the evolution of farm performance than undertakings in other economic sectors. Income uncertainty is particularly detrimental to investment and innovation and can therefore threaten the economic viability of farms. Moreover, due to the seasonality of agricultural production, agricultural product markets are characterised by an internal trend of volatility. It is widely recognised that excessive volatility is unhelpful either for producers (distorts market signals and therefore revenues depend on randomness) or for consumers (changes in food choices). Variability is a complex phenomenon whose origins are diverse, and sometimes contradictory. After a sharp rise in the prices of agricultural products on world markets, they began to fluctuate heavily between 2007 and 2008. This phenomenon has entered the agenda of international policy and is due to its possible impact on global food security. Therefore, in 2011. The G-20 adopted an Action Plan to reduce volatility in food prices and agriculture, and on the basis of which an information system for agricultural products was created to improve the transparency of agricultural markets. In the future, the markets are likely to face even greater uncertainty and greater economic and climatic risks.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —I support this Report. I think we need effective measures in the EU to protect farmers as well as consumers from the practice of unfair trading. Farmers are the weakest link of the food chain, and they are also the most important link.

name: Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, because despite there being a strong need for updated tools to cope with volatility in agricultural markets, this report falls on the wrong side. It places an over—reliance on competitiveness, reliance on third markets, liberalisation, mutual funds and insurance tools – while ignoring that it is the market orientation of CAP that has caused this problem. It denies where the problems are coming from and places private institutions at the heart of the solution. Finally, it talks about strengthening the position of producers in the food supply chain, despite the problem being that it has been farmers who have been the shock—absorbers in all of this.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. — Agricultural activity depends on biological processes, such as climatic conditions and animal and plant diseases, thus factors beyond the farmer's control. Uncertainty about income primarily hurts investment and innovation. Moreover, variations in agricultural production generate an inherent tendency of agricultural markets to be volatile. Originally, the CAP was characterized by strong regulation of markets. At the heart of it were guaranteed prices. With them farmers got a minimum price for their produce in the event of a crisis. Over time the CAP has been reformed and now proposes a series of new risk management measures under the second pillar. In this context, Member States may or may not include them in their rural development programmes. However, it is considered that the CAP's risk management tools are unfit to limit the effects of price volatility on farmers' income. The EU should provide solutions to the phenomenon, through the CAP, focusing on three key points: strengthening the organisation of supply chains and contracting, improving income protection farmers through risk management tools adapted to price volatility and strengthen market transparency.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This report, which aims to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets, has a fundamental economic error. The difficulties encountered by farms are mainly due to the stagnation of commodity prices at extremely low levels and not from the volatility of these values. Beyond this fault, this text proposes measures that deserve to be studied, such as the introduction of counter-cyclical aid and mutual funds or improving contractualisation. On the other hand, this report will help to strengthen the financialisation of agriculture and the administrative burden of the common agricultural policy. The viability and sustainability of our farms depends mainly on the immediate cessation of any new tariff concessions granted under a free trade agreement and the lifting of the Russian embargo. In the absence of this common sense policy, any other subject will be superficial. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: This own-initiative report by my colleague Angélique Delahaye provides a basis for reflection on the forthcoming reform of the common agricultural policy (CAP). This report proposes a series of tools that will effectively address price volatility in agricultural markets. This report proposes to strengthen contractualisation between the various players in the food chain, to direct the CAP towards a policy of support to farmers through an insurance system in case of price volatility and to create price observatories to make markets more transparent. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report which offers the Commission good suggestions for strengthening the negotiating power of producers in the food supply chain and hopes for introduction of countercyclical aid to support farmers' income when unfavourable vintages squeeze their income. Volatility in prices for agricultural products is one of the main factors of the dramatic situation in which many European farmers are currently in. A more incisive policy should be adopted, with instruments targeted at national and European level, aimed at tackling the negative effects of volatility and ensuring fair prices and remuneration for farmers . The resolution, in the drafting of which I participated, identifies possible areas of intervention in written contracts, support for risk management, increased market transparency and actions at the level European against unfair trade practices that harm not only European farmers but also consumers, who may find themselves unfairly faced with inflated prices.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because despite there being a strong need for updated tools to cope with volatility in agricultural markets, this report falls on the wrong side. It places an over—reliance on competitiveness, reliance on third markets, liberalisation, mutual funds and insurance tools – while ignoring that it is the market orientation of CAP that has caused this problem. It denies where the problems are coming from and places private institutions at the heart of the solution.  Finally, it talks about strengthening the position of producers in the food supply chain, despite the problem being that it has been farmers who have been the shock—absorbers in all of this.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose this because the authors clearly do not know either what a market is or how one properly operates.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It labels the current CAP risk management toolbox as inadequate in a time of growing market volatility. The report recommends facilitating the introduction of contractual relations by adapting competition law, further developing crisis and risk management tools and monitoring instruments for greater market transparency. A major objective for the future CAP must be the tackling of price volatility in order to ensure a fair income for farmers, stabilise agricultural markets and guarantee viable food production.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report recalls concepts that are certainly shareable, such as the importance and need for strengthening of primary producers, strengthening the negotiating power of producers, protection farmers, supply chain contracts, but unfortunately a correct analysis does not follow a proposal up to par with regard to investment and concrete policies. I therefore opted for an abstention.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. — Price volatility on agricultural markets has grown in recent years due to multiple factors, including extreme weather phenomena and the impact of climate change on activities human. Such events also had serious effects on food security and farmers' income. I believe it is the task of the European institutions to mitigate the causes of this volatility by reforming their common agricultural policy. In particular, I believe that the negotiating power of small producers should be strengthened by means of collectively negotiated standard contracts. Such instruments could allow farmers to defend themselves against business practices that could harm them or otherwise reduce their ability to invest and innovate. I welcome that the report, for which I voted in favour, recommends the creation of appropriate European agricultural price observers to analyse the entire production chain, from cost to production at the final sale price. In this regard, it would be appropriate to ensure greater transparency of agricultural markets so that price information is accessible in real time to all interested parties, including consumers. However, I am convinced that price crises must be prevented through counter-cyclical measures such as the provision of direct aid to farmers which can offset large price cuts.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report and stress that agricultural activity depends on biological processes. It is therefore heavily dependent on climatic conditions and is influenced by plant and animal diseases — natural factors that are out of farmers' control. The variation in the performance of agricultural holdings is therefore much more uncertain than that of other sectors of the economy. Income uncertainty affects mainly investments and innovations and is capable of undermining the economic viability of farms. Moreover, fluctuations in production mean that agricultural markets have an intrinsic tendency to be volatile. It is widely accepted that excessive instability does not benefit producers (affecting market signals and rendering incomes uncertain) or consumers (influencing their food choice).

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the instruments of the common agricultural policy to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets. I believe that this report fails to provide solutions, as it does not highlight the wrong structure of the current agricultural policy model, which, together with the exclusive targeting of economic profits, does not bring profits to small producers, but is a burden on their position. I therefore voted against.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Abstention vote. The report is unimpactful and does not give European policies the right responsibility for the volatility of the prices of agricultural products. The fundamental theme of recognizing the “value” of productions is not addressed.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The mere reflection we are preparing to take in the face of a year coming to an end includes the many environmental disasters that have characterised Europe. In fact, from floods onwards, natural impacts are only one of the many external variables affecting agricultural production and related markets. In the face of this axiom, I share this report with the full understanding that the instruments of the common agricultural policy adopted so far have been inefficient or poor in the face of the rampant product price volatility. Limiting changes is difficult, thinking that you can govern them completely is impossible, but it is possible to resort to certain measures to prevent or avoid their pernicious effects. Among them, two contextual measures are proposed. The first opts for a profound strengthening of the organisation of supply chains and contractualisation in order to ensure revenue for farmers. To complete it, it becomes necessary to introduce contractual relations through an adaptation of competition legislation. However, the latter must be guaranteed in full and therefore functional tools will be adopted for its monitoring. Since the agricultural sector, by its very nature, does not enjoy immediate adaptation, tools for risk and crisis management are needed.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We oppose this because the authors clearly do not know either what a market is or how one properly operates.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which aims to strengthen the organisation of supply chains and contractualisation, the better protection of farmers' income through the preparation of specific risk management instruments adapted to price volatility and strengthening market transparency by establishing price observers.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because, although I agree that price volatility is a very serious problem in the agricultural sector, it does not identify the real causes of this volatility, linked to the current agricultural model driven by the Union, the liberalisation of this market, excess production and export promotion and new markets. The solutions proposed in this report are based on risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, as well as public-private partnerships within the CAP's crisis management tools. But these do not represent a long-term solution, they are not effective and are created almost exclusively to benefit the larger farms, thus reversing for the benefit of the agro-industrial model.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Volatility in prices for agricultural products is one of the main factors of the dramatic situation in which many European farmers are currently in. On the one hand, income uncertainty, due to the difficulty of predicting production, mainly harms investment and innovation and may call into question the economic viability of companies agricultural. On the other, variations in agricultural production imply that farmers markets have an inherent tendency to be volatile. The current CAP, while proposing the different instruments for income stabilization, failed to address high price volatility on agricultural markets and instead placed an excessive burden on the manufacturer. Therefore, I think it is necessary that with the forthcoming CAP reform, new ways to combat price volatility and stabilise farmers' income in reacting to market imbalances.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - Agricultural activity depends on biological processes. Thus, it is highly dependent on climatic conditions and affected by plant and animal diseases, phenomena that cannot be controlled by farmers. Volatility is a complex phenomenon with multiple and sometimes controversial origins. The growing globalisation of agricultural trade entails health risks and risks of exogenous supply and demand shocks linked to the European Union's external policies in the field of trade, diplomatic and development cooperation. I voted for better transparency provided to markets and better protection for farmers' incomes, so that they can offer products that do not endanger human health.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. - Due to the imperfection and globalised nature of agricultural markets, the variability of supply influenced by weather and the precarious balance of food supply, European farmers are constantly exposed to price volatility and are increasingly dependent on stable markets and prices, as well as adequate public funding and measures to ensure the competitiveness of agricultural holdings and family farms. It is appropriate to develop a multifunctional and sustainable agricultural production. Proposals to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets include strengthening inter-branch organisations and contracting systems, better protection of the farmer's income through the creation of appropriate means to manage the risk of price fluctuations, and strengthen market transparency through the establishment of price monitoring centres. According to the report, it is necessary to maintain decoupled direct payments and the single area payment scheme, which is essential to secure the income of farmers, while providing them with a certain level of financial stability.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on the report on the instruments of the Common Agricultural Policy to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets due to the failure to take into account the amendment submitted to the report by the Polish delegation to the ECR. Amendments which emphasised that direct payments should remain a CAP instrument after 2020. The rejection of the amendment while recognising the potential of long-term contracts and the possibility of locking for a set period of time prices reflecting production to neutralise the impact of volatility has weighed on my decision on this matter.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report, which focuses on strengthening the organisation of agricultural sectors while protecting farmers’ income and market transparency. The future CAP needs to introduce ways and means on how to combat price volatility and stabilise farmers’ income. We need effective EU measures that will protect the farmers as well as the consumers against unfair trade practices.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Farming is central to the economy, yet further EU intervention in agricultural markets does nothing to ensure the sector is competitive, particularly as there are many measures available to Member States under CAP rules. This threatens to undermine recent CAP reforms and to move us away from a cost effective subsidy system that encourages innovation and makes Europe’s farmers globally competitive.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The CAP has been largely insufficient to counter the effects of price volatility in relation to farmers' income. The international context, globalisation, finitiarization of the real economy have hit the primary sector hard: 2.4 million farms disappeared in the five years 2005-2010 alone. Extreme climate phenomena have brought various European regions to their knees. Moreover, the dominant and unopposed position of the processing industry and the large distribution industry imposed hunger prices on farmers, and forced to face the growth of energy and production costs. The EU's political choice with the embargo on Russia and the consequent retaliation on the agricultural side contributed to price volatility and income instability. The answer cannot be in the use of higher-risk financial instruments or even more expensive insurance products. Just as it cannot continue the destruction of local markets with subsidies from the dumping of surpluses. Instead, we need an intelligent use of the Structural Funds, together with the CAP review, which supports quality and sustainable production and to enable the strengthening of small companies and production of excellence, while ensuring food sovereignty. Consequently I will abstain.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - Over time, the CAP has undergone important reforms in successive cycles that have profoundly altered its functioning. These reforms have progressively oriented the CAP towards markets. This is the context in which the first reflections on the potential role of risk management tools have emerged in order to combat volatility and stabilise revenue. Agricultural price volatility is one of the main factors behind the catastrophic situation that European farmers are currently facing. This unsafe environment for farmers poses a long-term threat to European food independence. The European Commission should study how to prevent and combat price volatility crises through countercyclical aid instruments, which can protect farmers' incomes much more effectively, but also through greater transparency of markets, by creating price observers.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: The purpose of this own-initiative report is to identify CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets. This report, carried out by my colleague Angélique Delahaye, has been the subject of a great deal of work in the Committee on Agriculture to propose ways of thinking to protect farmers from the harmful effects of the very high price volatility observed since 2007-2008 on world and European markets. The rapporteur makes interesting proposals on market transparency, contracting and risk management. It also rightly points out that tools exist in the current CAP, in particular in the regulation establishing a common organisation of the markets, but are too little used. I have worked particularly to ensure that the issue of crisis prevention and management is also raised, as this is a central issue. Considering that this report is an excellent basis for work to improve the current CAP and prepare for the next CAP, I voted in favour of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We oppose this because the authors clearly do not know either what a market is or how one properly operates.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Angélique Delahaye on the tools of the common agricultural policy (CAP) to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets. The current situation - strong fluctuations in agricultural prices - is untenable. It penalizes producers, depriving them of stable incomes, and reduces consumer choice. If we are concerned with European agriculture, we must propose solutions to enable our farmers to operate without fear of bankruptcy on a daily basis. It is precisely the purpose of this report which proposes solutions to redesign the contractual relations between farmers and mass retailers, as well as new tools to better manage and predict risks and crises in agricultural markets.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: I welcome the adoption of my report by a large majority of MEPs. The whole work done on this report was first of all an opportunity to take stock of the current situation and to target the concrete and urgent needs of European farmers. This assessment has enabled us to formulate measured and realistic proposals for improving European agriculture, through a series of tools that can help combat price volatility: strengthening contractualisation between the various players in the food chain, setting up insurance systems to support European agriculture. farmers, and to improve market transparency through the establishment of a price observatory. The adoption of this report entails several very positive consequences. First of all the work done will be useful for future reflections on the 2020 CAP reform. But also this vote in favour is a strong sign of the European Parliament's commitment to agricultural issues and its involvement with the Commission on these sensitive issues. Finally, this adoption coincides with an alignment of planets. Indeed, the Commission and the Committee of the Regions have just adopted texts in similar colours.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The objective of this report is to combat price volatility in agricultural markets. Thus, this report has three objectives: 1. the introduction of tools to limit volatility, whereas, in our view, it would be appropriate to limit wild competition in this sector; 2. reform of crisis management mechanisms; and 3. reform of the method of allocation of aid under the first pillar. These diverse solutions are contradictory with each other without addressing the substantive problems. In addition, some measures tend to strengthen the financialisation of agriculture and the administrative burden of the CAP.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. This report calls on the Commission to come up with new proposals to reduce the negative effects of price volatility by facilitating the introduction of contractual relations by adapting competition law, by further developing risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, and through the application of the European Agricultural Prices Observatory for the different sectors of agriculture. As the proposal should continue to be paid under the Operational Programme for Agriculture after the end of the period 2014-2020, I abstained from the end of the period 2014-2020.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - The volatility of agricultural prices is one of the main factors leading to the dramatic situation that many European farmers are experiencing today. We are in favour of the National Agricultural Policy and we are voting against this report because it considers that the conditions are fair and the conditions of competition in the EU's single market and excludes the prospect of renationalisation of the CAP.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report on common agricultural policy tools to reduce price volatility. Agriculture is a vital sector in Wales and I want to ensure funding to develop rural areas is directed at rural areas.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a report which correctly points out that farmers are a vulnerable group, especially when prices on the world market fluctuate as they do. However, it is a report that goes too far in terms of the importance of new EU regulations in the field of contract law, and it propagates for financial and budgetary systems that do not go in the direction that I think is necessary to reverse the development of Europe's farmers. I see a risk with some of the suggestions highlighted in the report that they may cement the situation rather than facilitate it. That's why I chose to abstain on the final vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. - Agricultural activity depends on biological processes and is therefore strongly subordinated to climatic conditions and plant and animal diseases. These natural factors are beyond the control of farmers. The development of farm performance is more uncertain than that of enterprises in other economic sectors. Income uncertainty is particularly detrimental to investment and innovation and may jeopardise the economic viability of farms. There is likely to be an increase in market uncertainty as well as economic and climate risks in the coming years. I agree that the volatility of agricultural prices is one of the main factors in the dramatic situation currently experienced by many European farmers, and it is part of the role of the European Union to find solutions to this phenomenon, particularly through the CAP.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Vote against: for lack of a coherent framework, this text is a catchall, in which common sense measures and others, much more dangerous, coexist, which reinforce the financialisation of agriculture or the administrative burden of the CAP.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The instability of prices in agriculture is inseparable from capitalist globalisation from the trade in agricultural products. It is due to market factors (supply and demand), political decisions (trade agreements in the global market), financial investments and speculation (financial investments in agricultural products) and climate factors. The report aims to strengthen the organisation of different agricultural sectors and contractual systems; addresses inequality in the food chain between large retailers and primary producers and solutions to protect farmers' incomes more effectively through the use of risk management tools, income stabilization instruments, individual provision mechanisms and mutual funds. The report also emphasises that there is a lack of effective response tools in the current CAP. However, it does not give clear answers, looking for solutions in the wrong places, not identifying the true cause of the volatility problem. On the contrary, it supports a market and competitiveness-oriented model of agriculture. Price volatility is a structural problem, to which liberalisation of trade in agricultural products contributes. The proposed risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, as well as experiences with public-private partnerships within the CAP crisis management tools, are not a solution.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. — Over the past few years, we have seen increasing volatility and price volatility, both at European and global level. This phenomenon has been caused by a number of factors, but in particular the rapid sequence and changes in supply and demand, and fluctuating prices. Unfortunately, under the current setting, the common agricultural policy is unable to address and adequately respond to high price fluctuations in agricultural markets, which is an excessive burden on producers, while the rest of the food chain remains without consequences. The report in question, after a thorough analysis, provides several solutions and identifies the main problems. In the future, we should focus on increased support for individual sectors and producer organisations, improving the contractual system and increasing transparency. The report also points out that risk management tools may be more appropriately used to protect farmers' incomes. We need effective measures at European level to ensure the necessary protection for farmers as well as consumers from unfair trade practices. Farmers are the weakest link in the food chain, with many forgetting that they are the most important link. The future common agricultural policy must look for new ways to combat price fluctuations and try to stabilise farmers' incomes.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain for the little incisiveness and the poor value of the contribution brought at the beginning of a very important phase of future review of the CAP.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - The volatility of agricultural prices is one of the main factors leading to the dramatic situation that many European farmers are experiencing today. I am in favour of the National Agricultural Policy and I am voting against this report because it considers that the conditions are fair and the conditions of competition in the EU Single Market and excludes the prospect of renationalisation of the CAP.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We need effective EU measures that will protect farmers as well as consumers against unfair trade practices. The farmers are the weakest link of the food chain while being the most important one. The future CAP should look at new ways to combat price volatility and stabilise farmers’ income; the current system doesn’t work or is too slow to react to market imbalances such as the Russian embargo or international low demand of agricultural products. This report, together with the Andrieu report on the CAP capacity of generating and maintain rural jobs, are the first steps toward the next CAP.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the adoption of this report because it contains concrete ideas for reforming the risk management instruments under the second pillar of this CAP in order to limit the effects of price volatility on farmers' incomes. The report proposes firstly to strengthen the organisation of the sector and the negotiation. Next, the call for the Commission to develop additional public and private instruments, as well as a binding early warning mechanism to counter market crises more effectively is important. I also support the proposal to set up European observatories to provide a constant analysis of agricultural market prices to improve transparency and limit vicious practices such as price speculators. As an extremely positive element of the report, I take the emphasis on the key role of young farmers in the future of European agriculture. The EU's food security, as well as developing a competitive and sustainable agricultural sector that meets the needs of European citizens, should be a strategic objective that cannot be achieved unless stable incomes of farmers are guaranteed.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on CAP instruments to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets because I believe that instability and volatility the prices of agricultural commodities and, as a reflection, of agricultural products in general, which have been heightened by the economic and financial crisis, have always characterised agricultural markets and that in the last years have become a structural element of agriculture globally, due to the rapid succession of demand, supply and price shocks. Price volatility will be set to increase for a variety of causes such as instability and imperfection of agricultural markets, globalisation and sophistication of agricultural markets, the growing Variability of supply due to climate instability, increased health risks and the fragile balance of the food supply chain. Therefore, agriculture intended as an activity, albeit as a vital economic sector for the EU, has in front of it very important challenges in terms of innovation and streamlining processes.
