It will be necessary, at once, to consider new risk and crisis management instruments and a strengthening of the existing measures of the second pillar in order to enhance the competitiveness of European agriculture actively involving producer organisations in the implementation process.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - Price volatility in the agricultural sector is a major problem for farmers and is one of the main reasons for the tense situation in which many European farmers are currently experiencing. It is important to ensure better income protection for farmers through the use of risk management instruments. In addition, the establishment of price observatories can increase market transparency. The position of farmers in the food chain also needs to be strengthened.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose this because the authors clearly do not know either what a market is or how one properly operates.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report, which responds to the rising challenge of price volatility in agricultural markets which undermines the livelihoods of many farmers, particularly tenants and smallholders, and can potentially threaten food security in the EU and beyond. The report offers a balanced view, critically assessing low effectiveness of traditional CAP market intervention tools, while instead advocating stronger emphasis on improvement of farmers’ terms of trade, their position in the food supply chain, contractual relations with retailers and availability of risk management tools.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: in writing. — Mrs Delahaye, elected LR, is the author of an own-initiative report by the European Parliament on agricultural price volatility. It thus makes it the alpha and the omega of multiple and successive agricultural crises that have put farms in trouble. The report therefore does not indicate that the real cause of the distress of our farmers is, on the contrary, stabilization of prices at the lowest, incompatible with profitability on farms and pushing our farmers into bankruptcy or even suicide. This report also makes a mistake on productivity and agricultural policy. The main orientations of the CAP have led our country to specialize in sectors that are under fierce global competition and our farmers face crises of overproduction. They owe them in particular to the European Union and its geopolitical choices which do not serve our interests in any way, as was the case with Russia, whose embargo decision on our agricultural products has revealed the fragility of our positions. In the absence of a reliable basis, this report cannot therefore make serious proposals to improve the situation of our farmers. I, of course, voted against this own-initiative report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. I believe that the problem of price volatility in the agricultural market is not reduced to a problem of balance between supply and demand, as the report insists. Price volatility can affect global food security and it is a problem that we must put an end to a blatant way. I think this report is not strong enough. The report is looking for solutions in the wrong place in my opinion. Price volatility is also related to many other macroeconomic variables in addition to political will, environmental legislation and speculation with agricultural products and food. The problem dealt with in the report is a structural problem given the agricultural market model that exists in the Union, presenting more risk management tools does not solve the problem in the long run, it only conceals it.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the adoption of the report by my colleague Angélique Delahaye on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets. It is a strong signal sent to farmers who have been going through a crisis of extreme severity for more than a year that has led many of them to sell their farms or worse, to end their lives. This report is the result of a one-year reflection to propose an agricultural policy that reflects the reality of agriculture in the Member States and proposes a future for this today's disentrenched profession, which is a pillar of our economy and which is essential to our food sovereignty. Thus, this report proposes concrete tools to preserve European agriculture and make it competitive in a world where competition is often unfair and fierce: strengthening contractualisation between the various actors in the food chain, orientation of the CAP towards a policy of support to farmers via systems insurantials to guarantee income against price volatility and the creation of price observatories for more transparent markets.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE)
text: ‒ The VVD supports the development of new and existing (financial) risk management instruments - within the framework of the common agricultural policy - which can make farmers more resilient to price fluctuations. The VVD believes that binding European rules on unfair commercial practices are not the right instrument and is also awaiting the impact assessment of the European Commission in this respect. The VVD wants more attention to voluntary and self-regulatory initiatives initiated by the sector. Nor is the VVD in favour of the idea that CAP objectives should prevail over competition rules and that the crisis reserve should be placed outside the EU budget.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report where farmers will be protected by effective EU measures, as well as consumers, from unfair commercial practices. This report seeks new ways to combat price volatility and aims to stabilise farmers' incomes. Farmers are the weakest link in the food chain, while also having the utmost importance. The current system is not working or is too slow to react to market imbalances, such as the Russian embargo or reduced international demand for agricultural products.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for a proposal for a resolution by the European Parliament on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets, because this is a broad-spectrum problem which, excessively, is not favourable to producers or consumers. This Report presents four key ways to improve the volatile situation of agricultural markets, namely to push for better sector organisation, develop risk management tools, continue to implement price observations and improve crisis management measures. Europe must find an adequate response to such challenges and additional measures to help the development of its agriculture. Concrete measures need to be adopted at national and European level, but also at regional and local authorities level, and therefore I support this Report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report fights against price volatility in agricultural markets when it should focus on the stagnation of prices at a very low level and the plural crisis facing agriculture. Positive in appearance, really for some, for example, on public interventionism in the markets, the rapporteur's intentions are lost in dubious meanders and contradicts, hence an inconsistency which prevents my support. I voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The report presents 4 main proposals on how to mitigate the impact of fluctuations on the agricultural market. These are improving crisis management and organisation of sectors, continuing to use price monitoring centres and further developing risk management tools. The development of the market in the agricultural sector is less predictable than in other areas due to its dependence on climate influences, so I supported the adoption of measures that are the main objective to correct the volatile situation on the agricultural market.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Angélique Delahaye's report on price volatility in agricultural markets. The measures proposed to combat price instability and volatility revolve around three areas: strengthening contractualisation between the various players in the food chain, making markets more transparent and improving the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) to guarantee income for farmers in the face of price volatility. Finally, the report looks at the crisis management mechanisms that Europe must make faster and more efficient. This text is timely as reflections on the future of the CAP are accelerating. I welcome this initiative, which sends a strong signal to the agricultural world and makes concrete proposals to improve the situation of farmers in Europe.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. European farmers are increasingly exposed to risks and uncertainties (plant and animal diseases, climates, pest infestations, etc.). Fluctuations in agricultural products lead to price fluctuations which do not benefit producers or consumers. In order to counter this uncertainty, more attention will be paid to the instruments (e.g. CAP) of risk management in agriculture.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing. - Eligible report based on extensive analysis, compiled in fair detail, which really seeks to identify the causes of agricultural price fluctuations. It rightly criticises the negative effects of free trade legislation, which, overall, create an unfavourable situation for both producers and consumers. It is incompatible with the legitimate need for sustainable development and the commitment to high-quality food that hundreds of thousands of small farms go bankrupt every year in the EU due to regulatory deficiencies and the advancement of multinational companies.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on CAP instruments to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets, as this is one of the main reasons for the disadvantage that many farmers are in the EU. I believe that the EU should help to resolve this problem. The recommendations provided in the report provide an appropriate set of measures to make this happen. I support the proposal to facilitate the introduction of contractual relations by adapting competition law and the development of risk management tools, as well as monitoring instruments for greater market transparency.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. — As we well know agricultural activities depend heavily on natural factors, including climatic conditions and plant and animal diseases, factors, unfortunately, beyond the control of the farmer. These factors only increase the volatility of food prices, characterizing the agricultural sector with uncertainties compared to others. Uncertainties that cause damage to investment and innovations and put the economic viability of farms at risk. Following the increase in agricultural prices between 2007 and 2008 and the consequences presented on world food security, this problem has received international attention. This interest in risk management is reflected on agricultural policies and in particular in the 2014-2020 CAP. Parliament's report, which I supported in this House, focuses on three main issues in order to ensure efficient food production. It is therefore called for strengthening the organisation of supply chains and contractualisation, to improve the protection of farmers' income by setting up appropriate risk management tools for price volatility and to strengthen market transparency, fielding measures aimed at countering unfair trade practices along the supply chain.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this own-initiative report on the worrying subject of agricultural commodity price volatility. In fact, these can be subjected to frantic speculation with the consequences that are known not only for farmers, who are victims of these speculative games, but also for the purchasing power of French and European consumers: the price of a whole series of foodstuffs, like that of bread baguette, can be greatly increased. To combat this volatility, my colleague Angélique Delahaye made a number of recommendations around three strong ideas: the strengthening of contractualisation between the various players in the food chain, the orientation of the CAP towards a policy of support to farmers via insurance systems to guarantee revenue, and better transparency of markets through the creation of price observatories, as well as strengthening existing ones. Agricultural raw materials cannot be regarded as raw materials like any other; there is a need for a minimum of regulation and guarantee arrangements in the interests of producers and consumers.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — With the end of the framework for production and prices, only private storage aid and public intervention on the markets are left to try to stabilize agricultural prices. Unfortunately, these tools have not been able to stop the latest agricultural crises. Based on the fair observation that the current tools are not enough this report proposes to develop new ones: much more ambitious countercyclical measures with more budgetary means; rebalancing the relations between farmers and agri-food industry through contractualisation and a stronger legislative framework against practices unfair. These are steps in the right direction. But the pressure on farmers demand much more if we want to keep a peasant agriculture. Increasing competition, particularly with the proliferation of trade agreements, further reinforces the dangerous trend towards concentration of farms: ever larger and fewer. That is why we also urgently need mechanisms guaranteeing fixed prices for farmers on production volumes. Otherwise, the latter have no guarantee to produce and will continue to put the key under the door ever more.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report entitled 'CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets'. This report has a basic mistake: it aims to combat price volatility in agricultural markets, when these prices are no longer volatile but desperately low, for the last two years. The current question is therefore rather low price stagnation. In the absence of a coherent framework, this text is a catch-all in which common sense measures (notably public interventionism in markets, or improved contractualisation) and others, much more dangerous, which reinforce the financialisation of agriculture or the administrative burden of the CAP.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. In the absence of a coherent framework, this text is a catch-all in which common sense measures (notably public interventionism in agricultural markets, or improved contractualisation) and others, much more dangerous, which reinforce the financialisation of agriculture or the administrative burden of the CAP. An already overwhelming weight for our farmers. Finally, the main problem today is not price volatility but the stagnation, at a very low level, in prices.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because, although I agree that price volatility is a very serious problem in the agricultural sector, it does not identify the real causes of this volatility, linked to the current agricultural model driven by the Union, the liberalisation of this market, excess production and export promotion and new markets. The solutions proposed in this report are based on risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, as well as public-private partnerships within the CAP's crisis management tools. But these do not represent a long-term solution, they are not effective and are created almost exclusively to benefit the larger farms, thus reversing for the benefit of the agro-industrial model.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted against. Resolution calls for a more “vigorous” EU policy to be linked to “fairer and profitable prices” — in other words, the report calls for stronger regulation, for stronger influence on market prices in agriculture. European agriculture, on the other hand, needs fewer regulations and fewer subsidies to bring about a market straightening and more stable prices.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — Agricultural activity is strongly dependent on climatic conditions and plant or animal diseases, which are natural factors beyond farmer's control. Therefore, the performance of agricultural holdings is much more uncertain than in other economic sectors. Revenue uncertainty harms investment and innovation and can challenge economic sustainability, and excessive volatility does not benefit either producers or consumers. Due to the growing global agricultural exchange, tools for managing risks in agriculture are once again in the spotlight of the new CAP for 2014-2020. The report points out that risk management tools from the second tier of the current CAP are inappropriate to limit the consequences that price volatility has on farmers' incomes. Since the volatility of prices for agricultural products is one of the main causes of unpredictable business conditions for European farmers, the EU should contribute to addressing this problem under the CAP. Ideas for improvement are strengthening the organisation of various parts of the agricultural sector and the contract contract system, better protection of agricultural revenues by establishing tools to manage risks of appropriate price volatility and greater market transparency by introducing a price monitoring observatory. Since I believe that in order to send a clear message to citizens and farmers, it is necessary to adopt a practical approach to the problem through the adoption of tools to combat price instability, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union does not currently have a genuine safety net to curb market volatility. Noting that farmers will be increasingly exposed to price volatility, the European Parliament deemed it necessary to adopt a more incisive and coherent policy, with targeted instruments at EU and national level. The European Parliament has underlined the importance of maintaining decoupled direct aids under the current CAP, together with the single area payment scheme, which constitute compensation for public services and a vital component in securing the income of farmers and providing them with a degree of financial stability.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The safety and stability of the agricultural sector are essential for food security and sufficiency. Globalisation of trade in agricultural products, climate change, animal and plant health affect the availability, price and quality of agricultural and food products. This has, in addition to economic risks, implications for the health and lives of the population. Therefore, through risk management tools, the common agricultural policy must respond flexibly to all factors affecting agricultural production, so that agriculture is a stable economic area capable of ensuring affordable and quality agricultural products .

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. This own-initiative report aims to combat price volatility in agricultural markets, even though these prices have not been volatile for the past two years. The report therefore contains a basic cyclical error which we cannot ignore. Furthermore, the rapporteur's analysis of the difficulties encountered in the field of agriculture is fragmented and poorly hierarchical. There is a lack of coherence in the solutions envisaged. Some measures are common sense, notably public interventionism in markets, but others remain very dangerous for French agriculture. Given this lack of coherence and the willingness to impose additional administrative measures on the CAP, we remain against this report.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed in favour of the report on CAP instruments to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets, recognising the great importance of this sector, not only provides for the supply of food products but also contributes significantly to the development of rural areas. The delicate balance that characterises the food supply chain today is put at risk by the instability of agricultural markets, on which globalization processes and changes are also important. climate. On the basis of these prerequisites, coordinated action at national and European level can be effective in order to ensure productivity in the agricultural sector but also to protect agricultural operators more exposed to price volatility.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Agricultural activity depends on natural factors, such as biological processes and climatic conditions, which are beyond the control of farmers, resulting in a significant degree of uncertainty in the yield of agricultural farms. This is also added to the volatility of agricultural prices, which is one of the factors responsible for the dramatic situation facing many European farmers today. I therefore support the definition within the framework of the forthcoming CAP reform of instruments to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets by strengthening the organisation of sectors and contracting. I believe that there is also a need for better protection of farmers' income through the introduction of risk management tools tailored to price volatility and strengthening market transparency through the creation of price observatories.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. — The main agricultural crises of recent years (milk crisis; livestock crises) have been partly caused by high price volatility in markets. It is true that agricultural markets are inherently unstable, owing to the difficulty of adjusting production to demand, which itself depends on consumers' eating habits. Above all, this extreme price volatility is the direct result of the double logic advocated by the European Commission: deregulation and liberalisation. Deregulation, as the CAP does not have the means to prevent sharp price drops. Liberalisation, as European agriculture is increasingly exposed - as a result of major international trade negotiations - to competition from third country agro-industries. The Delahaye report - considerably redirected by the European Socialists - has the virtue of putting forward concrete solutions for improvement. While the right has placed greater emphasis on private instruments (better collective organisation of producers, price observatories, etc.), the Socialists rightly recalled the importance of a proactive public policy, which, for example, does not forbid itself to mobilize tools for moderating production. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Agricultural activity depends on biological processes. It is therefore heavily dependent on climatic conditions and is influenced by plant and animal diseases — natural factors that are out of control by farmers. The variation in the performance of agricultural holdings is therefore much more uncertain than that of other sectors of the economy. Income uncertainty affects mainly investments and innovations and is capable of undermining the economic viability of farms. Moreover, fluctuations in production mean that agricultural markets have an intrinsic tendency to be volatile. It is generally accepted that excessive instability does not benefit producers (affecting market signals and rendering incomes uncertain) or consumers (influencing their food choice). For the above reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - European farmers are increasingly exposed to risks and uncertainties (plant and animal diseases, climatic conditions, pest infestations). Fluctuations in agricultural products lead to price fluctuations which do not benefit producers or consumers. In order to counter this uncertainty, more attention will be paid to the instruments (e.g. CAP) of risk management in agriculture. CAP objectives 2014-2020: Increased competitiveness, improved sustainability, greater efficiency = tackling volatility and stabilising incomes. The instruments of the current CAP have been used by a total of 12 Member States. A total of €2.7 billion of public funding was used (€1.7 billion from rural development funds). According to the rapporteur, the risk management instrument of the second pillar of the current CAP is completely inappropriate to limit the impact of price volatility on farmers' incomes, which calls for a revision of the current CAP. As the demands include strengthening the agricultural sectors and better protection of farmers' incomes (risk management instruments), I supported this report.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report responds to the price volatility in agricultural markets that can threaten the financial security of smallholder farmers. I supported the report where it critically assessed current CAP intervention methods and I support improving the terms of trade for farmers, for example, when they are dealing with the big supermarkets that buy their products. However, I voted against the parts of the report which seek to increase CAP spending.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on CAP measures to reduce price fluctuations on agricultural markets. I hope they will help to ensure price stability, food security and the competitive position of European farmers on the world market.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report due to the high level of price volatility facing agriculture in the EU.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur believes that volatility in agricultural prices is one of the main factors in the dramatic situation that many European farmers are currently experiencing. It's true! But, while sweetening, the report only agrees to imagine “that the financialization of the world economy and the speculative game that accompanies it has potentially effects on agricultural markets”. And with fatalism, it states that “farmers' exposure to price volatility, (...) will increase”, while stating that “it is the role of the European Union to provide solutions to this phenomenon, particularly through the CAP”. A way to justify in advance the inaction and inefficiency of the EU? To remedy this, far from any idea of production quota and price regulation, it merely offers farmers “training courses on risk management”. I am voting against this text which recognizes the disappearance of European agriculture.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: This report, which has already been discussed at length, has not been the subject of prior consensus. Its objective is to combat price volatility in agricultural markets when these same prices are not volatile but dramatically low. This text is a catch-all, without a coherent framework, it accumulates common sense proposals but also dangerous measures that reinforce the financialisation of agriculture and the administrative burden of the Common Agricultural Policy. Considering that the objectives of this text are outside the reality of the situation and that the resulting proposals are inconsistent, I therefore voted against it.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this report on price volatility on agricultural markets and the tools of the CAP that can reduce this volatility. Price volatility has an impact on agricultural activity, farmers' income and food security. The European Union, within the framework of the CAP, needs to address this issue in order to combat the uncertainty generated by price volatility and its impact on investment and innovation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report because we need effective EU measures that will protect the farmers as well as consumers against unfair trade practices. The farmers are the weakest link of the food chain, while being the most important one. The future CAP should look at new ways to combat price volatility and stabilise farmers’ income; the current system doesn’t work or is too slow to react to market imbalances such as the Russian embargo or international low demand for agricultural products.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to the draft resolution of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, the main risk to the situation of European farmers is fluctuations in the price of agricultural products, and the risk management tools provided by the CAP are not able to mitigate this risk. According to the draft, it is for the European Union to find a solution to this situation, through the instruments to be developed within the framework of the CAP to enable the effective fight against price volatility. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: This report, which is subject to many debates in the AGRI commission, is a serious economic error. It addresses the issue of price volatility, whereas the major problem facing producers today is the low stagnation of these prices. Moreover, this text is a catch-all where a large number of sometimes very good measures are mixed, such as increasing public interventionism in the markets or improving contractualisation, but sometimes very dangerous because reinforcing the financialisation of agriculture and the administrative burden of the CAP. In the face of a text that is inconsistent, we will continue to oppose it.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report has a basic cyclical error: it aims to combat price volatility in agricultural markets, when these prices are no longer volatile but desperately low, for two years. The current question is therefore rather low price stagnation. In the absence of a coherent framework, this text is a catch-all, in which common sense measures (notably public interventionism in markets, or improved contractualisation) and others, much more dangerous, which reinforce the financialisation of agriculture or the administrative burden of the CAP. I am therefore voting against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it responds to a rising challenge of price volatility in agricultural markets which undermines the livelihoods of many farmers, particularly tenants and smallholders, and can potentially threaten food security in the EU and beyond. The report offers a balanced view, critically assessing low effectiveness of traditional CAP market intervention tools, while instead advocating stronger emphasis on improvement of farmers’ terms of trade, their position in the food supply chain, contractual relations with retailers and availability of risk management tools.  However, I rejected three paragraphs explicitly advocating an increase in CAP spending in areas related to market intervention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this French own-initiative report on CAP tools to limit price volatility on agricultural markets. Adopted by a large majority, the text proposes to improve the structuring of the sectors thanks to three major ideas: strengthening contractualisation between the different actors, the orientation of the CAP towards a policy of support to farmers via insurance systems, transparency with the creation of price observatories and strengthening of existing observatories.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The common agricultural policy represents the agricultural policy of the EU implementing a system of agricultural subsidies and other programmes. I have voted for this report regarding CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report, given that the common agricultural policy is one of the most tangible and concrete policies of the EU, for the operation of which substantial amounts of the EU budget are invested annually, and the creation of instruments to balance spending in this area is extremely necessary, both for farmers-producers and consumers. As more and more European farmers face major economic problems in recent years caused by climatic conditions or various animal diseases, I believe the EU can implement a number of instruments to reduce volatility prices on agricultural markets. The document adopted today proposes a better predictability of the costs required for agricultural production, so as to take into account the provision of a fair income with labour for producers, as well as an affordable price for consumers, and one of the solutions proposed in the report is the creation of price observers.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — In the context of the report adopted, I fully share the recommendation to further develop climate, health and economic risk management tools in the market-oriented CAP, in particular various types of insurance against risks in agricultural production, income stabilisation instruments, mechanisms for individually provided services and mutual funds, in order to limit the effects of fluctuation prices and encourage the management of farms focused on the future. The Commission should promote the exchange of best practices between Member States and develop new instruments to prevent and effectively manage the risks associated with price volatility, and thus lay down basics for discussion of future CAP reforms.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE)
text: ‒ The VVD supports the development of new and existing (financial) risk management instruments - within the framework of the common agricultural policy - which can make farmers more resilient to price fluctuations. The VVD believes that binding European rules on unfair commercial practices are not the right instrument and is also awaiting the impact assessment of the European Commission in this respect. The VVD wants more attention to voluntary and self-regulatory initiatives initiated by the sector. Nor is the VVD in favour of the idea that CAP objectives should prevail over competition rules and that the crisis reserve should be placed outside the EU budget.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report because I believe that it is necessary to adapt the instruments to the current situation in order to combat price volatility.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Farmers are suffering from constant price swings and the market is unstable. Member States can, as appropriate, integrate CAP solutions, including risk management measures such as harvest, animal and plant security and ways to stabilise income, such as financial participation in the joint fund.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Price volatility and volatility have always characterised the agricultural market, and in recent years have become, due to the rapid succession of demand, supply and price shocks, a structural feature of agriculture, both at European and global level. Unfortunately, the current CAP has failed to cope with high price volatility on agricultural markets and puts an excessive burden on the producer. The report, which I voted for, after analysing the current situation and identifying the main problems, proposes various improvements in view of the forthcoming reform of the CAP, such as strengthened sectoral organisation and contractual arrangements, better protection of farmers' incomes by creating risk management tools tailored to price volatility, greater transparency of markets through the creation of price observatories.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: in writing. — The CAP is a tool for destroying and wiping out small and medium-sized farmers who have managed to survive so many years of its implementation because of competition for the profitability of the monopoly groups operating in the sector. This is the reason for low producer prices below cost and high prices for the working class and the popular layers that consume the products. Certain well-founded findings in the report, such as the reference to point (I) page 4/22 of the disappearance of 2.4 million agricultural holdings, become hypocrisy, since these do not lead to measures to address the cause; on the contrary, any measures are proposed, except that they are ' aspirins” (setting up price observatories, crisis management prevention, mutual funds, etc.), are also measures to reinforce the tendency of concentration and centralisation capitalism serving both the EU and the CFP. Primary production is objectively subordinated to merchants and banks, as the report acknowledges, referring to them as “a weak link in the food chain due to the growing concentration of the sector and large enterprises”. Finally, the proposal for joint inter-branch organisations of producers and companies as a 'solution' is like putting the wolf to guard the sheep.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report. Although in its original version it was a very liberal approach, it was subsequently rebalanced thanks to extensive work of amendments by Socialist Members. Beyond market mechanisms and in the face of the systemic problem of price volatility in the agricultural sector, it is important to act on the balance between supply and demand by also adopting public policy tools and rules. It is important to have capacity to respond to agricultural crises (such as in the milk sector) and market dysfunction by controlling production or adopting anti-cyclical measures.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Dear colleagues and colleagues, I voted in favour of my fellow Members proposal because I believe that excessive price volatility on the agricultural market would harm producers and farmers consumers. I therefore voted positive.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Agriculture is confronted with higher levels of price volatility than other economic sectors due to a variety of economic, natural and political factors. I voted in favour of this report as it recommends facilitating the introduction of contractual relations by adapting competition law, further developing crisis and risk management tools and monitoring instruments for greater market transparency. A major objective for the future CAP must be the tackling of price volatility in order to ensure a fair income for farmers, stabilise agricultural markets and guarantee viable food production.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support the European Parliament's resolution on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets, which adopts a more decisive and coherent policy with relevant instruments at EU and national level, in order to ensure multifunctional and sustainable agricultural production throughout the Union. I emphasize that agricultural activity depends on biological processes and therefore strongly depends on climatic conditions and plant or animal diseases, and natural factors are beyond farmer's control. Farm performance is therefore much more uncertain than when it comes to businesses in other economic sectors, so direct payments continue to be a kind of stability for farmers. Greater synergy between the CAP and other EU policies is needed, particularly in the areas of energy, water supply, land use, biodiversity and ecosystems and development of both rural and island areas. The negotiating power of producers in the food supply chain must be strengthened by standard, transparent, balanced and collectively agreed contracts so that farmers are able to respond to unfair trade practices, be more competitive, be able to increase the stability of their incomes, create added value and invest in innovation or to be drivers of employment. I believe that long-term agricultural policy objectives must ensure fair living standards for agricultural communities or primary producers, strive to stabilize the market and guarantee sustainable food production.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Farmers are the most important, but also weakest, link in the production chain of food and are the most affected by high price volatility. The EU needs to draw up effective measures to protect them and consumers from unfair trading practices. The current system responds too slowly to market shocks and imbalances, as in the case of the Russian embargo or weak international demand for agricultural products, and is incapable of combating Unfair trade practices, excessive price volatility and stabilize the income of farmers. This report is a good starting point for addressing these issues. It proposes several improvements to the common agricultural policy, such as the inclusion of new instruments for the prevention and management of crises in the short term and the provision of counter-cyclical measures on the long term. Equally important will be the strengthening of the bargaining power of farmers, thanks to the introduction of standard, transparent, balanced contracts and collectively negotiated contracts. Price volatility and market imbalances are a threat not only to farmers and consumers, but put the same EU food independence at risk over the long run. It is therefore necessary and urgent to intervene and that is why I supported this resolution.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — Volatility and price fluctuations have become a structural feature of agriculture both at European and global level due to a series of rapid successive shocks in terms of demand, supply and price fluctuations. Occurrences resulting from climate change such as droughts and floods also contribute to price volatility. Price volatility harms the agri-food sector, which is detrimental to investment and the ability to create new jobs. The European Union does not have the right safety net to limit market volatility. Effective EU action is needed to protect farmers as well as consumers against unfair trade practices. The future CAP needs to look for new ways to combat price volatility as well as to stabilize farmers' incomes. The current system has not proved successful in responding to market imbalances like the Russian embargo or to declining demand for agricultural products internationally. After analysing the situation and identifying the main problems, the report proposes several improvements to the CAP: increased support for sectoral organisation and manufacturers, better contractual system and increased transparency. This report may be seen as a first step towards a new Common Agricultural Policy.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — (PT) The instability of prices in agriculture is inseparable from the capitalist globalisation of trade in agricultural products. It is due to market factors (supply and demand), political decisions (trade agreements in the global market), financial investments and speculation (financial investments in agricultural products) and climate factors. The report aims to strengthen the organisation of different agricultural sectors and contractual systems; addresses inequality in the food chain between large retailers and primary producers and solutions to protect farmers' incomes more effectively through the use of risk management tools, income stabilization instruments, individual provision mechanisms and mutual funds. The report also emphasises that there is a lack of effective response tools in the current CAP. However, it does not give clear answers, looking for solutions in the wrong places, not identifying the true cause of the volatility problem. On the contrary, it supports a market and competitiveness-oriented model of agriculture. Price volatility is a structural problem, to which liberalisation of trade in agricultural products contributes. The proposed risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, as well as experiences with public-private partnerships within the CAP crisis management tools, are not a solution.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The concept of price volatility in agriculture implies significant changes in the prices of agricultural products in a given year. Farmers often face significant price changes they receive for selling their agricultural products. This creates financial uncertainty about farmers” incomes and may pose risks to them, as their incomes are less predictable and may be subject to a sudden fall in prices. Besides, this phenomenon reduces opportunities for long-term investment, especially by young farmers. Agriculture is exposed to price volatility also due to climate and weather factors and changes in global trade, especially with Russia and China, and the resulting surplus of commodities in the European market. The PiS delegation submitted an amendment which emphasised that direct payments should remain a CAP instrument after 2020, but the rapporteur declared it incompatible with the report and the amendment was rejected. I hereby abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Angélique Delahaye, which proposes the establishment of tools within the common agricultural policy to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets. Indeed, agriculture is facing higher levels of price volatility due to exchange rates, fluctuations in oil prices, adverse weather conditions and animal or plant diseases. It is therefore necessary to strengthen the organisation of the chains, create a compulsory precautionary saving system, better protect the income of our farmers and to strengthen market transparency through the establishment of price observatories. A Europe that acts and wins is also a Europe that provides concrete solutions to economic actors in sectors in difficulty.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. - Agricultural activity is exposed to various risks, because it depends on biological processes and is therefore strongly subordinated to climatic conditions and plant and animal diseases, factors which, to some extent, are outside the control of farmers. Thus, agriculture is faced with higher levels of volatility than other economic sectors. Income uncertainty is particularly detrimental to investment and innovation and may jeopardise the economic viability of farms. The report argues that CAP does not today have sufficient risk management tools for the needs of the sector, in a guise of increasing volatility in the markets. I support this report because I believe that the main objectives of the CAP should be to combat price volatility in order to ensure fair incomes for farmers, stabilise agricultural markets and ensure viability of food production.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - We need effective measures in the European Union to protect farmers, as well as consumers, from unfair commercial practices. Farmers are the weakest link in the food chain, although they are one of the most important. The future Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) must seek new ways to combat price volatility and stabilise farmer's incomes. The current system does not work or is too slow to react to market imbalances such as the Russian embargo or low international demand for agricultural products. This report also states that the ability to generate and maintain rural jobs is the first steps towards the next CAP.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. — As this report points out, which I supported with my vote, price volatility and volatility due to shocks in demand, supply and prices, have in recent years become a structural element of agriculture, both at European and global level. Unfortunately, the Union does not have a real safety net to curb market volatility, which is a strong disincentive to the maintenance of agricultural activity on the territory of the Union. In view of this reality, this report calls for strengthening the organisation of sectors and contractualization, as well as the bargaining power of farmers. It also urges the promotion of risk management tools adapted to price volatility and provided with sufficient resources, requesting new instruments from the European Commission. Finally, it calls for greater market transparency through the creation of a European price observatory covering the entire chain and across all sectors.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which believes that the historical tools of the CAP in crisis management are no longer effective enough to cope with the challenges of a globalised economy. The adopted text therefore calls on the Commission to put in place tools belonging to the public and private registry, which can be combined or complemented by each other and providing for a binding early warning mechanism adapted to the needs, to ensure proper functioning and counter market crises. The text of the report also calls for the establishment of a crisis reserve outside the CAP budget, which can be used to finance crisis management tools.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I supported this document. The EU has done a great deal of work in ensuring measures that have helped to increase the stability of agricultural prices. Of course, the work has not yet been completed and it will have to be continued, especially in the preparation of the new CAP after 2020.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: The volatility of agricultural material prices threatens the sustainability of European agriculture and exposes farmers to unacceptable precariousness. This report proposes to adapt the CAP in order to better regulate the market, control price developments and protect farmers. It advocates strengthening the bargaining power of farmers in the food production chain, based in particular on standard, transparent, balanced and collectively negotiated contracts. The report also suggests the creation of effective climate, health and economic risk management tools, such as sectoral mutual funds and insurance mechanisms. In addition, it proposes the creation of European agricultural price observatories to produce a dynamic analysis of agricultural markets and make recommendations. Finally, this report calls for the development of a medium-term system of counter-cyclical intervention, in order to enable the Union to act on agricultural markets to avoid price falls. In so far as it makes proposals for better protection of farmers and the preservation of rurality, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Agricultural activity obviously depends on biological processes and is therefore subordinated to natural factors outside the control of farmers (exogenous), thus rendering the performance of farms uncertain and jeopardizing their economic viability. Initially, the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) was characterised by strong regulation of agricultural markets through guaranteed prices, which provided farmers with a minimum value for their products in the event of a crisis. With the successive reforms, its functioning has changed. The latest reform in 2013, which defined the CAP for the period 2014-2020, was based on two pillars and the direct payments system has been reformulated (more targeted, fairer and greener). However, the risk management tools provided for in the second pillar of the CAP are insufficient to circumvent farmers' income price volatility - one of the main factors of the instability currently experienced by many European farmers. Strengthening the organisation of the sectors and contractualization, improving the protection of farmers' income through risk-management tools adapted to price volatility and strengthening market transparency are some of the measures proposed by the rapporteur, whom I endorse and, for that reason, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the own-initiative report by my colleague Angélique Delahaye on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets. This text represents the first step in a reflection on the preparation of the next CAP. Thus, a series of tools are proposed to combat price volatility. Three main ideas are present in this report: the strengthening of contractualisation between the various players in the food chain, the orientation of the CAP towards a policy of support to farmers through insurance systems to guarantee income in the face of price volatility, and making markets more transparent to the market. through the creation of price observatories and strengthening existing ones. Finally, the report is also reflecting and developing avenues for crisis management, as the mechanisms are not currently fast and effective enough.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the introduction of instruments of the CAP (Common Agricultural Policy) to reduce price volatility on the agricultural market. Agriculture is faced with higher price volatility than other sectors. The main objective of the future CAP must therefore be to combat fluctuating food prices in order to ensure fair income for farmers, stabilise agricultural markets and ensure viable food production. For this reason, the report recommends encouraging the introduction and development of crisis and risk management tools, as well as the monitoring of existing instruments.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported the report by rapporteur A. Delahay on common agricultural policy instruments designed to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets. The adopted resolution effectively describes the current situation in agricultural markets and proposes a number of active solutions to mitigate agricultural price fluctuations. I consider the provision that asks the Commission to create an EU legislative framework prohibiting unfair trade practices in the food chain. Following the June resolution on unfair trade practices by rapporteur E. Cezsak of the IMCO Committee, on which I participated as shadow rapporteur, this is another of the specific challenges of the European Parliament towards the Commission, this time from the AGRI Committee, to finally begin addressing the existing imbalance of forces between individual actors in the food chain.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because, although I agree that price volatility is a very serious problem in the agricultural sector, it does not identify the real causes of this volatility, linked to the current agricultural model driven by the Union, the liberalisation of this market, excess production and export promotion and new markets. The solutions proposed in this report are based on risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, as well as public-private partnerships within the CAP's crisis management tools. But these do not represent a long-term solution, they are not effective and are created almost exclusively to benefit the larger farms, thus reversing for the benefit of the agro-industrial model.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as the EU should not be involved in UK agriculture.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I have voted to support this report, which responds to the rising challenge of price volatility in agricultural markets, which undermines livelihoods of many farmers, particularly tenants and smallholders, and can potentially threaten food security in the EU and beyond. The report critically assesses the low effectiveness of traditional CAP market intervention tools while instead advocating stronger emphasis on improvement of farmers’ terms of trade, their position in the food supply chain, contractual relations with retailers as well as availability of risk management tools.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. — I have decided to be abstained by this Report, and this rationale of voting arises as a critique of the existing system of evaluating the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not actually reflect the actual the quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the representative activity.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because the recent waves of extreme fluctuations in the world's agricultural markets have forced us to think more seriously about the growing threats that threaten world food security, weaken investment and modernisation, discourage new entrants and hamper recovery generations in the agricultural sector. I regret that the traditional instruments of the common agricultural policy (CAP) for crisis management are not effective enough in a globalised economy. Unfortunately, price fluctuations, despite the measures taken so far, continue to harm agriculture and the agri-food sector, so I consider it necessary to adopt instruments at Union level that will ensure multifunctional and sustainable agricultural production throughout the Union, as well as fair and bargain prices. Although the current measures have increased the consumption of public expenditure compared to the old CAP, this still represents only 0.4% of CAP expenditure, which is not right. I therefore expect that, in order to reduce the negative effects of price fluctuations and to remedy market distortions, the Union will implement the instruments of the Single CMO more quickly and operatively.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the own-initiative report on instruments designed to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets. Farmers are often exposed to price fluctuations due to many factors, whether they are natural factors or economic factors, such as exchange rates or fertilizer and energy prices. The danger of price volatility not only can lead to insecurity among farmers in terms of securing further livelihoods and incomes, but can also discourage many young beginner farmers from business. Therefore, the price fluctuations in agriculture need to be built, the causes of the problem and the appropriate solutions to be sought. The report presents certain ideas that can be supported and further elaborated. These proposals are, for example, to take appropriate measures to promote agriculture in disadvantaged regions, and in particular to strengthen the negotiating position of producers by creating standard and balanced collectively negotiated contracts that, in the outcome, can guarantee a defense against unfair commercial practices by sales chains. I also welcome the consideration of the possibility of more frequent use of so-called derivatives, i.e. contracts where the price for a certain quantity of a commodity is fixed, better information on financing programmes by the EIB and the creation of a European centre for monitoring the prices of agricultural products from the producer to the final selling prices.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: — I do not agree with this report where price volatility in agricultural markets seems inevitable. Of course, weather conditions and changing harvests are responsible for price fluctuations. But we would better regulate the markets to reduce the risk of heavy losses. For example, we could ban speculation on food. Or try to better match supply and demand and produce fewer surpluses. The current aggressive export strategy of the European agricultural sector and the extreme dependence on markets outside the Union create the known problems. The fruit and vegetable sector, but also dairy and pork do not find a market - partly because of the Russian boycott - or see their prices plummeted. Describing this as a 'natural phenomenon' is lame. The risk management instruments already included in the CAP (second pillar) are, according to the rapporteur, inadequate and need to be strengthened. Since the reform of the CAP, the Greens have been opposed to instruments of this kind. They 'eat the money' from the funds intended for rural development. The fact that agricultural products are traded on a global market, and therefore involve financial risks, cannot be compensated by means of this kind of funds. Moreover, I think the solution that is being proposed to combat symptoms, but it is absolutely inadequate to meet the challenge we face.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - Our aim is to protect primary and small farmers from market fluctuations and to ensure a fair position in the supply-supply chain. However, these measures must be followed by an overall reform of the common agricultural policy, which, as it stands, discriminates against farmers from the countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - Farmers are increasingly exposed to price volatility, and the European Union is downgrading its strategic assistance to agriculture and based it on production unrelated support. It is therefore necessary to adopt a more decisive and coherent policy with appropriate instruments at EU and national level to ensure multifunctional and sustainable agricultural production and fair and cost-effective prices. The report recommends strengthening current measures under the Second Pillar to increase the competitiveness of European agriculture and calls on the Commission to conduct a thorough analysis of the reasons for the poor use of the tools available under Pillar 2 of the CAP and take urgent measures to provide assistance agricultural sector. Independence on food and food safety in the EU, as well as the development of a competitive and sustainable agricultural sector across the Union to meet the needs of citizens must remain the strategic objectives of the future CAP and urgently ensure an adequate standard of living for farmers. I express my support for this Report because I believe that this will limit the impact of price volatility, strengthen agricultural education and vocational training programmes and encourage future-facing agricultural management.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of a report on the instruments of the Common Agricultural Policy to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets. I support the initiatives of the Budget Committee, which in its opinion calls, inter alia, for better synergy between the Common Agricultural Policy and other EU policies, in particular on energy, water supply, land use, biodiversity and ecosystems, as well as the development of remote and mountain areas, while at the same time also to improve the transparency of agricultural markets to make price information available to all stakeholders, including consumers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The volatility of agricultural prices is one of the main factors leading to the dramatic situation that many European farmers are experiencing today. The common agricultural policy must not create market distortions and must take account of the specificities of each Member State, with the ultimate aim of assisting countries based on the rural economy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — We need concrete instruments to combat price volatility in agricultural markets, which are mostly affected by farmers and often do not reach other players in the food chain. The exception is consumers who are frequent victims of unfair commercial practices. I agree that, given the instability and imperfection of agricultural markets, the globalised nature and complexity of agricultural markets, the weather-dependent variability of supply, increased health risks and the precarious balance of food supply, the agricultural producers will be even more exposed to price fluctuations. The instruments formulated by the report, such as support for producers and their organisations, a better and more transparent system for concluding contracts and a better agricultural market and price monitoring system, will reduce price fluctuations if they are directed to real producers, or go to their organizations. These instruments and subsidies are not a waste of resources, because one of the most important objectives of the Common Agricultural Policy is the creation of food safety. Another important fact is that, besides competition, the sector is increasingly exposed to the adverse effects of climate change, so it needs to be developed. For this reason, we are developing a more profound and coherent policy with targeted tools at EU and Member State level to ensure multifunctional and sustainable agricultural production and fair prices. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — Agricultural activity depends on biological processes and is therefore highly dependent on climatic conditions and plant and animal diseases. Of course, these natural factors remain beyond the control of farmers. However, price volatility is increasingly affected by issues such as the instability and imperfection of agricultural markets, greater supply volatility due to climate instability or fragile balance in food supply. The change in profitability for farms is therefore more difficult to predict than for companies in other sectors of the economy. It is therefore necessary to adopt a more articulate and coherent policy strategy, together with targeted instruments at Union and national level, in order to guarantee multifunctional sustainable agricultural production across the Union. It is necessary, first of all, to further develop risk management instruments in the field of climate, health and economy, in particular different types of agricultural production insurance or mechanisms for the individual creation of reserves and mutual funds in order to reduce the effects of price volatility and the support of forward-looking management of farms. It is equally important to take action to increase awareness of farmers and agricultural organisations of modernisation opportunities and to increase the competitiveness of farms.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - Agricultural markets bear successive shocks in the two components of the market (supply and demand), the structural elements of agriculture and the price of agricultural products, with agricultural supply under the impact of climate change and its phenomena (drought, flood), pest effects, structural factors, environmental and animal protection policies, trade policies, etc. As such, farmers face an increase in production costs, coupled with an increase in their indebtedness, resulting in a decrease in agricultural production and jobs in rural areas. Moreover, the global population growth, largely undernourished, contributes to increasing the phenomenon of price volatility in agriculture. Moreover, agricultural markets, the place of meeting demand and supply, are by nature unstable, making it all the more difficult the EU's mission to ensure food security and to help ensure a competitive position for farmers and vegetable producers Europeans on the world market. However, the EU has at its disposal not only the risk management tools within the CAP, but also the possibility of establishing a coherent agricultural policy with specific strategic instruments at European and national level.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union's Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) was designed as an effective tool to support this sector so much needed to provide food for European consumers. Unfortunately, the agricultural market has been characterised, in recent years, by increasing instability and increased price volatility due to a rapid succession of changes in demand, supply and prices. The current CAP, although it includes a number of provisions aimed at stabilising agricultural incomes, fails to manage the current situation and producers are increasingly vulnerable, while the rest of the production chain is not affected. In these circumstances, a recast of the CAP is needed, by introducing increased support for producers and organisations in the field, greater transparency of contracts and by improving instruments for monitoring the market and agricultural prices. In order to protect farmers' incomes, risk management, crisis prevention and management tools are also needed to be included in the countercyclical measures. European farmers need to be protected, to the same extent as consumers, against unfair commercial practices. It is an important report for European agriculture and I express my support for its adoption.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — Financial markets have gone crazy. Speculators even go so far as to attacking agricultural markets, investing and disinvesting in food, causing extreme price fluctuations and economic shocks that create hunger in parts of the world and put many farmers on their knees. It is for this reason that today we will vote on a text that aims to put in place risk management tools to combat this volatility and stabilize the incomes of European farmers. The latest economic, financial or food crises in the world have thrown our farmers into endless turmoil. We produce too much and our farmers sell at a loss. European agriculture is in danger. The great gods of the market, for whom no offering is sufficient, are killing an entire sector, destroying our producers and threatening the quality of our food. Blind ultraliberalism must be put in place and effective regulatory tools must be put in place.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The constant rise in agricultural prices on the world markets since the financial crisis in 2007 have resulted in price volatility in agricultural markets everywhere. As a result, price volatility has become a high priority on the international political agenda. The EU’s common agricultural policy (CAP) is a set of mechanisms that were developed to help curb volatility. However, the CAP tools have proven to be inefficient and therefore little used by Member States. I voted in favour of the report, which asks that the CAP tools be looked at and scrutinised, and additional solutions be proposed in order to render effective CAP, with the aim of helping to curb volatility in agricultural markets.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the “Proposal for a resolution on CAP tools to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets”. Agriculture is the most sensitive economic area due to various economic, natural and political factors affecting prices and quality of agricultural products. Contractual relations should adapt to competition and targeted policy decisions should encourage transparency. It is necessary to look up to the US, which, by introducing a law called the Farm Bill in 2014, developed special insurance policies for agricultural sectors and contracts provided prices and payment deadlines for supplied agricultural products. The fact is that traditional CAP crisis management tools are not sufficiently effective in the globalised economy system and need to find adequate mechanisms that can address a number of market challenges.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: written. — The concept of price instability in agriculture contains significant variations in prices of agricultural products in a given year. Farmers often face major changes in the price they receive from their agricultural products, resulting in financial uncertainty about their incomes and creates a major risk for farmers whose incomes are wholly unpredictable and threatened by a sharp drop in prices. Major additional risk factors are weather conditions and changes in world trade flows, especially with Russia and China. The problem that arises as a result of the above is the reduction of capacity for long-term investments, especially young farmers. The aim of this report is to invite the Commission to draft a new draft law that will mitigate the negative effects of price volatility in agriculture by creating contractual relations through the adoption of competition laws and through further management of risk assessment instruments and implementation of the Observatory for European Agricultural Prices for various agricultural sectors. Since the 2014-2020 CAP is primarily focused on compensating for the negative effects of price volatility and unpredictability in revenue, and given the exceptional expansion of the scope of global trade that carries with it global food insecurity, I voted in favour.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the instruments of the common agricultural policy to reduce price volatility on agricultural markets. European farmers are increasingly exposed to different risks as they depend on biological processes, climate change and various impacts of plant and animal diseases (natural processes over which there is no influence). A big problem for farmers is the volatility of prices in the market. The original instrument contained price regularity or that farmers would receive a guaranteed minimum price despite the crisis. The third cycle began in agriculture with a reform in 2013, which defined the Common Agricultural Policy for the period 2014-2020 (Cycle I. started 1992 Agenda 2000, Cycle II started in 2003 Fischler Reform). These reforms have made the Common Agricultural Policy progressively oriented towards markets. Volatility in agricultural products prices is one of the main reasons for the catastrophic situation that many European farmers currently face.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Price volatility generates insecurity and instability, which complicates the working life of farmers, since it puts in danger investments in the business and therefore the creation of stable workplaces in this sector. I support this proposal with a view to putting in place measures to help improve this situation, especially in order to secure the future of European agriculture by facilitating the role of young farmers.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report has a basic cyclical error: it aims to combat price volatility in agricultural markets when these prices are no longer volatile but desperately low, for the last two years. The current question is therefore rather low price stagnation. The analysis of the causes of volatility and difficulties encountered by agriculture is described in a parcel and poorly hierarchical manner. In the absence of a coherent framework, this text is a catch-all, in which common sense measures and others, much more dangerous, coexist, which reinforce the financialisation of agriculture or the administrative burden of the CAP. I voted against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — Direct payments should remain an instrument of the Common Agricultural Policy after 2020. The rapporteur unfortunately found this matter incompatible with the report. Accordingly, I abstained.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — Agricultural activity depends on biological processes. Therefore, it largely depends on climatic conditions and diseases of plants and animals. The natural factors cannot be influenced by farmers. The performance of agricultural holdings is therefore much more uncertain than those of enterprises operating in other sectors of the economy. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report. I believe that the problem of price volatility in the agricultural market is not reduced to a problem of balance between supply and demand, as the report insists. Price volatility can affect global food security and it is a problem that we must put an end to a blatant way. I think this report is not strong enough. The report is looking for solutions in the wrong place in my opinion. Price volatility is also related to many other macroeconomic variables in addition to political will, environmental legislation and speculation with agricultural products and food. The problem dealt with in the report is a structural problem given the agricultural market model that exists in the Union, presenting more risk management tools does not solve the problem in the long run, it only conceals it.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I voted against, because I oppose the risk management instruments eating up the rural development funds and diverting funds from farmers to bankers.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. Dear colleagues, degraded climate, droughts, floods, pests and whatnot have an adverse impact on crop levels and stability of production prices. Farmers face increased production costs and debt growth, while sustainable agriculture as a source of livelihood can only be guaranteed if buying-in prices cover all costs of production. The CAP is designed to ensure a decent standard of living for farmers and to ensure safe supply at affordable prices for consumers. The maintenance of direct aid in the CAP, together with the single area payment scheme, is therefore a public service compensation and is vital to ensuring farmers' income. Risk management tools, insurance, individual securing mechanisms and mutual funds need to be further developed in the CAP in order to limit the effects of price volatility. The Commission should promote the exchange of best practices between Member States and develop new instruments that are acceptable and accessible to farmers, including providing better information and encouraging farming organisations. It is extremely urgent to activate safeguards to support agriculture in the outermost, mountainous and less developed regions, where costs and risks are much higher.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the fact that additional market monitoring measures have also been introduced to other sectors.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Prices in agriculture suffer from higher levels of volatility than in other sectors. While supply cannot be quickly adapted to changes by the very nature of agricultural production, external factors such as oil prices, adverse weather conditions or pests have a substantial influence on food prices. In a context of increasing market volatility, this document considers that the tools that the CAP provides for risk management are inadequate. It therefore recommends further the development of such tools, the adaptation of competition laws and the inclusion of price observatories. Since the ultimate objective of this report is to provide solutions to the harsh situation many of our farmers are experiencing as a result of the volatility of agricultural prices, and to shape ideas that will stimulate reflection for the forthcoming reform of the CAP — one of whose challenges will be to end the price volatility in order to ensure the future of farmers, stabilize markets and ensure viable production — I strongly supported with my vote for its approval.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
