text: in writing. - I voted against this report because, although I agree that price volatility is a very serious problem in the agricultural sector, it does not identify the real causes of this volatility, linked to the current agricultural model driven by the Union, the liberalisation of this market, excess production and export promotion and new markets. The solutions proposed in this report are based on risk management tools, in particular the various types of insurance and mutual funds, as well as public-private partnerships within the CAP's crisis management tools. But these do not represent a long-term solution, they are not effective and are created almost exclusively to benefit the larger farms, thus reversing for the benefit of the agro-industrial model.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it responds to a rising challenge of price volatility in agricultural markets which undermines the livelihoods of many farmers, particularly tenants and smallholders, and can potentially threaten food security in the EU and beyond. The report offers a balanced view, critically assessing low effectiveness of traditional CAP market intervention tools, while instead advocating stronger emphasis on improvement of farmers’ terms of trade, their position in the food supply chain, contractual relations with retailers and availability of risk management tools.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour because the price fluctuations in agricultural products could be strengthened by political decisions, such as the introduction of a trade embargo.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - As is rightly said, volatility is a complex process with many causes. However, we should not mix these causes because otherwise we are not applying the appropriate instruments to this volatility. The fever can be caused by a virus or a bacterium. Treatment, to be efficient, always implies a correct diagnosis. In this particular case, I fear that climate randomness is being deliberately mixed with financial speculation and price manipulation by large multinationals and large distribution. To seek to impute climate change the biggest cause of increasing price volatility is to seek to impose or accentuate an increasingly market-oriented reform of the CAP and further exacerbate the consequences of this instability. It is not, of course, about the stability of farmers. What is at stake here is the definitive abandonment of a logic of direct income support, which is stable, by means of a logic of income insurance, copying the American model. Price volatility is combated with public regulatory instruments rather than financial instruments.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - European farmers are increasingly exposed to risks and uncertainties (plant and animal diseases, climatic conditions, pest infestations). Fluctuations in agricultural products lead to price fluctuations which do not benefit producers or consumers. In order to counter this uncertainty, more attention will be paid to the instruments (e.g. CAP) of risk management in agriculture. CAP objectives 2014-2020: Increased competitiveness, improved sustainability, greater efficiency = tackling volatility and stabilising incomes. The instruments of the current CAP have been used by a total of 12 Member States. A total of €2.7 billion of public funding was used (€1.7 billion from rural development funds). According to the rapporteur, the risk management instrument of the second pillar of the current CAP is completely inappropriate to limit the impact of price volatility on farmers' incomes, which calls for a revision of the current CAP. As the demands include strengthening the agricultural sectors and better protection of farmers' incomes (risk management instruments), I supported this report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament also apparently realised that the globalisation madness is destroying agriculture. The report to be adopted here does not tackle the causal problems of the primary sector, but at least creates some mitigating resources and puts farmers in a better position compared to trade, and therefore agrees.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report adopted responds to a rising challenge of price volatility in agricultural markets which undermines the livelihoods of many farmers, particularly tenants and smallholders, and can potentially threaten food security in the EU and beyond. The report offers a balanced view, critically assessing low effectiveness of traditional CAP market intervention tools, while instead advocating stronger emphasis on improvement of farmers’ terms of trade, their position in the food supply chain, contractual relations with retailers and availability of risk management tools. For this broad and inclusive policy view, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. “I supported the report on common agricultural policy instruments to limit price fluctuations in agricultural markets. This report rightly pointed out that price fluctuations affecting farmers bring them great financial uncertainty, unpredictable incomes, thus preventing them from long-term planning or investment. Moreover, in addition to price fluctuations, climatic factors are currently at risk for farmers. And all these problems, without a proper and unequivocal answer, are harmful and demotivating agricultural policy, which may in future jeopardise the ability of the European Union to provide food for its inhabitants. That is why we have called for more effective policy and targeted action against price fluctuations. At the same time, we underlined that measures must be tailored to each sector and that one size fits all cannot be accessed and preventive risk management tools are more important than subsequent compensatory mechanisms.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the report of my colleague Angélique Delahaya and agree that it is necessary to adopt a more decisive and coherent policy in order to reduce the negative consequences from price volatility. Implementing policies not only at European Union level but also at national level will ensure sustainable and multifunctional agriculture. As we are aware of how the world's leading competitors are allocating more and more funds for the development of agriculture, risk management models and instruments to protect against price instability need to implement more decisive policies and maximally protect farmers. To date, addressing the problem of instability of the agricultural market has not been adequate and urgent measures are needed to help the agricultural sector. Some of these measures are certainly better informing farmers, encouraging young and new farmers, the ability to join together and increase market transparency.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — This document seems to be on the assumption that price volatility in agricultural markets is a fatality. I am convinced that as a result of intense weather fluctuations, increased with climate change, and the variability in the supply of agricultural products the market is and will always be exposed to the risk of volatility. However, there are many actions that we can field to regulate and contain excessive exposure. I am referring in particular to measures that limit speculation on food and real supply and supply management, even by making them coincide. The current approach which insists on over-reliance on third markets has caused major problems, such as the dairy sector and fruit and vegetable sectors. The text also expresses shareable concepts, but it is an exposition of the situation rather than the proposal for concrete measures or policies. Price instability and volatility are now seen as a structural feature of both European and world agriculture, but that is not the case. We must do more, much more, to protect a sector as important as agriculture and in the light of these considerations I voted abstention from this report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on Common Agricultural Policy instruments to reduce price volatility in agricultural markets. The agricultural sector is increasingly exposed to price volatility, due to various causes such as instability and imperfection of agricultural markets, increasing globalisation and development of agricultural markets, increased variability of supply due to climate unpredictability, increased health risks and unreliable balance of food supply. The report I supported therefore advocates for a more robust and coordinated policy with targeted instruments at EU and national level to ensure multifunctional, sustainable agricultural production across the Union at fair and profitable prices.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on labour market reforms and labour relations in Greece (2016/3032 (RSP)).

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, you have added the topic of labour market reforms and labour relations in Greece on the agenda of this session, but I have to be very open and honest with you, I have just a few words to say on the process.  Firstly, the Council does not intervene in adjustment programmes and I can hence confirm that it has not discussed the issue at hand, either in December or in earlier meetings. Secondly, the Eurogroup is regularly informed of the state of play of the adjustment programme by the institutions and the authorities, and on occasion the Eurogroup provides political guidance on open issues; but I understand that this has not been the case as far as the ongoing discussions on labour market reforms are concerned.  That is why I believe the Commissioner is much better placed to provide you with further information on the subject, and you will understand, honourable Members, that for the reasons that I have outlined and for procedural reasons, I cannot further elaborate on this issue on behalf of the Council.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission is well aware of the difficult employment and social situation in Greece and is putting great emphasis on measures to tackle it. The social costs of an eight-year-long economic crisis are evident and have revealed deep—seated structural problems in Greece that existed before the crisis. The new programme for Greece has been designed to address these challenges, paving the way for sustainable economic growth and job creation. We are seeing a gradual improvement in employment, although unemployment remains at worrying levels. We hope that these positive trends will continue in 2017 as the economic situation improves and growth takes hold. If the new programme is fully implemented, Greece will have come a long way in securing sustainable growth and job creation. The first review of the third programme has been completed successfully, and the last related disbursements were made at the end of October. The second review is ongoing. All sides are working towards a positive conclusion. As you will recall, in the summer of 2015, we negotiated– on behalf of the European Stability Mechanism – the new Memorandum of Understanding for a Stability Programme. The Commission insisted that social and fairness considerations were explicitly and seriously taken into account in the design of the adjustment programme. We conducted an ex—ante social impact assessment to this effect. Furthermore, this has most importantly translated into a number of policy choices and measures to strengthen social safety nets. One such critical example is the roll-out of a guaranteed minimum income scheme, or ‘social solidarity income’, to improve the effectiveness, sustainability and fairness of the Greek social protection system. We are also working with the authorities on vocational education and training measures to support employment and job creation to the benefit of the Greek people. In addition, measures to curb tax evasion, fight informality, introduce social and generational equity, strengthen decent employment, and reduce undeclared work can be found at the heart of this stability support programme. I would also like to recall the substantial support of the European Structural and Investment Funds for improving the labour market and social situation. More than EUR 4 billion is available to Greece from the European Social Fund for the period 2014-2020 to finance measures promoting job creation, social inclusion, institutional capacity-building and investment in education. Youth employment is supported by an additional EUR 170 million from the EU Youth Employment Initiative. Overall, the reform promoted through the economic adjustment programmes have aimed to help Greece to build a more solid basis for growth and job creation founded on sustainable public finances, a stable financial system and a more competitive and dynamic economy. Achieving these objectives required many changes, including in the sphere of labour market legislation, in order to facilitate the adjustment of the economy. This has sought to promote labour reallocation, reduce the extent of job destruction and contribute to restoring competitiveness. Under the memorandum of understanding agreed in August 2015, Greece agreed to bring collective bargaining, collective dismissal and industrial action frameworks into line with best practices. To facilitate this task, the memorandum provides for a broad consultation process involving a group of international experts. The expert group submitted a report in September 2016 after consultation with major stakeholders, including social partners. The Commission considers the report an important input into the ongoing discussions between the Greek Government and the representatives of the Institutions on how to improve collective bargaining and other labour frameworks. The goal is to establish a strong and more sustainable social partnership, striking an optimal balance between protection and flexibility, providing certainty to companies and adequate safeguards to workers. The gains in competitiveness of recent years must be secured, ensuring a pathway to sustainable growth and job creation. Regarding the framework for collective bargaining, the experts were not unanimous in their recommendations, but they also did not recommend reducing the scope of collective labour agreements. We believe in the importance of social dialogue and constructive industrial relations. This is about respecting workers’ rights and the autonomy of social partners in collective bargaining. The Commission has always tried to engage in a constructive dialogue with the social partners, both at EU and country level to discuss the economic developments and labour market reforms under preparation. Apart from the formal consultation process with the social partners on the existing labour market frameworks, the Commission held dedicated bilateral meetings with both sides of industry to exchange views on labour market reforms.  We welcome the steps that have been taken so far to improve the process of social dialogue in Greece. However, more effort is needed. The Commission encourages the process of establishing a framework for a more constructive social partnership as a medium—term goal. For that, respect, ownership and representativeness are key.

name: Burkhard Balz
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. I thank the Council and the Commission for coming and, above all, for the statements on labour market reforms and industrial relations in Greece. I would like to take up our debate today in October, in which I referred to the lack of reforms in relation to a key area of structural reform, namely the labour market. Where are we, or should I say where is Greece today? Progress is encouraging, even though there has been no agreement between Greece and lenders on labour market reforms. Flexible labour markets with flexible collective bargaining rules and also redundancies are important elements for reducing unemployment and to ensure that Greek companies can and want to afford to recruit and employ Greeks again. A return to an outdated system of centralised collective bargaining and redundancies is certainly not a solution. This is also important in view of the lack of a well-functioning social security system. Pensions cannot be equated with or ultimately replace social security. The progress made over the last few weeks must not be compromised, but must be an incentive for further efforts to move forward at last. A serious reform of the labour market, pension and social systems is, in my view, essential.

name: Agnes Jongerius
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, my Group, the S&D Group, recently pleaded in a letter for restoration of collective bargaining in Greece. Labour market reforms have made collective bargaining practically non-existent, and the Troika said not to worry because reforms would strengthen collective bargaining at firm level instead. But that didn’t happen, and the situation of Greek workers is dire. Mr Juncker’s letter in response to us stated that the Commission acts in full compliance with the EU Treaties, but that the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights doesn’t apply as such to Greek measures. This is a flagrant contradiction.  The situation in Greece is neither in compliance with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, nor with the core ILO Conventions. It is not because the Memorandum of Understanding is not EU law that we can now exclude Greece from the European social model. I will not stand for that. The Memorandum cannot be a legal no-man’s land, and besides, the recommendations of the already-mentioned expert group are crystal clear. The Commission writes that the Troika is discussing which recommendations to consider. Let me remind the Commission that the experts were endorsed by all Memorandum partners and that cherry picking from them is unacceptable. It’s time to bring collective bargaining in Greece back in line with good practice and with EU law.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President, after the Eurogroup and the Troika turned Greece into an immense social cemetery cutting salaries and pensions since 2010, after the Troika filled the country with armies of unemployed and broke up labour relations by putting collective collective conventions in history, now the Council is washing its hands as Pontius Pilate and the European Commission is pretending to be aware of labour in Greece. The same applies to the Syriza-ANEL Memorandum Government, which, continuing the New Democracy and PASOK memorandum choices, is now pouring crocodile tears for the workers who have sentenced them to hunger wages; a government that cuts up supplementary pensions, the EKA and divestitures public property instead of a lentil plate; a government that has not dared to proceed with the recapitalisation of the insurance system and the inclusion of German compensation in the state budget; a government that begs lenders having sounded a Spanish retreat. Enough hypocrisy and bilingualism! The Greek people no longer tolerate mockery and will soon send a hard message to the Troika and its submissives.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Madam President, before I even heard the previous speaker, I thought that I felt that these issues should be dealt with a little while ceasing to be forced to choose one side. Either we are on the Greek side or we are on the side of Europe. For my part, I have the impression that Greece is one of the Member States, that a number of efforts have been made, that when financial assistance reaches 330 billion, the Greeks cannot say that nothing has been done for them and that the fact that Greece is still a member of the euro area clearly shows the common will to keep that country in the euro area, moreover, in accordance with the will of its people. The solidarity we have shown is solidarity with a Member State that was experiencing imbalances — my own knows about them too, so I am not coming to get the little beast — I am simply saying that we must have a good chronological approach. It was not the European Union that precipitated Greece into difficulties: there were difficulties which the European Union has more or less well solved, but which cannot be fully attributed to the European Union. I would also like to speak a bit as chairman of the Intergroup Against Poverty. I agree with the idea that the social situation is very serious; that when there are so many children who suffer from poverty — about 23% living in difficult conditions — this is not good for the future of the country; that when youth unemployment is too high, it is not good for the future of the country; that equality before tax is not good for the future of the country; not always totally what one might want — i remember, when i was rapporteur for the two-pack, we tried to do a lot so that there were as many actions on the expenditure side as on the revenue side to rebalance a budget. I believe that the key question is whether the European Commission and Member States in the Council agree to focus on reforms that bring investment and employment. We must get a little out of this role play in which we reject responsibility to infinite and think effectively of the Greek people and the peoples of the other Member States who have contributed through their taxes to try to get Greece out of where it is. I think we need a balanced approach, which I do not find in all the speeches heard, particularly just before me.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, I find it inconceivable, gentlemen of the Commission and the Council, that Greece should be exempted from what the European acquis provides for collective bargaining. Greek and Greek women are European citizens equal to other European citizens and not second-class citizens and, since everyone, like Mr Balz, admits that progress is being made in Greece, there is no justification for any delay in completing the second evaluation. nor to restore collective bargaining, as required by European legitimacy. Seventy-seven out of the eighty prior actions, out of the eighty prerequisites, have already been closed. One of the three remaining is the restoration of collective bargaining. I would like to ask you, gentlemen of the Commission and of the Council: the International Monetary Fund, which is not a Europe, is asking, especially for Greece, that the European acquis should not be applied. What's your position? How long will you give in to the demands of the International Monetary Fund, violating European legitimacy and hurting Greece, its economy, the Greek people and the eurozone, because if the eurozone and the European Union cannot prove that it solves problems, then the propaganda of the anti-European populist extreme right will be strengthened. We must therefore run, move forward, and you are obliged by law, gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, to implement European legitimacy. It is inconceivable in a euro area Member State to refuse to restore collective bargaining. The European Union asks Bangladesh to establish collective bargaining in order to sign a trade agreement. What you ask of the Bangladeshi people do you deny it to the Greek women and the Greeks? By what right?

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in July 2014 President Juncker said here that if there were to be new structural adjustment plans — something he did not believe — they should be subjected to a social impact study. A year later, a new structural adjustment plan was imposed on Greece, and the social impact, which has never been studied, has become quite visible in the meantime: one million jobs lost since 2008, one third of the Greek population exposed to poverty and exclusion, one in six workers — one in six workers! — exposed to poverty, while millions of Greeks no longer have access to health care. Meanwhile, Member States and the IMF are coalising to impose on Greece a new package of measures, retargeting the labour market, with the annihilation of collective bargaining and the total liberalisation of redundancies. So, in fact, there is no obligation on the Juncker Commission to carry out social impact assessments. On the other hand, the Commission has a legal obligation to be guardian of the Treaties, to enforce the law of the European Union, including the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Everyone knows that the measures advocated by creditors, in this plan and in the previous ones, are a lighter violation of European law. If the European Union really wants to help Greece, it will be able to focus on four points. First, to alleviate the burden of Greek debt that is not repayable as it is. Secondly, to help Greece establish an effective tax administration to combat fraud and evasion, an area in which successive Greek governments have not really illustrated themselves. Thirdly, stop returning refugees to Greece and, on the contrary, relieve Greece — the front-line country — of the burden of receiving refugees. This is probably the country of the Union which has the least resources to do so. And finally, mobilize investment. You're gonna tell me, “There's the Juncker plan.” Congratulations! There is the Juncker plan: 3% of the investment in the Junker plan goes to Greece and, at the same time, 10% to Germany, a country that no longer knows what to do with its savings. Everyone will understand that it is no longer a question of helping Greece, it is a matter of teaching the lesson that there is no alternative to neoliberal globalization. Madam President, I would like to conclude by saying that they should begin to understand that 'which sows neoliberal globalisation harvests national-populism'. When will they understand?

name: Laura Agea
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 5 December, at the Eurogroup meeting in Brussels, the French Finance Minister announced with confidence and determination that the Greek government had made great strides to implement the reforms demanded by the Troika. Tears, blood, social carnage but the tasks had been carried out. Certainly the deal was upon us and would have been closed before Christmas. It was time, the minister said, to reward Greece's efforts with a lowering of debt, because Greece kept its word, it's time for Europe to keep its own. But here again the German government thought about closing the taps, to prevent Greece from receiving what little breathing space Europe was willing to offer. Germany, the same one that has been violating surplus rules for years, the same one that hurts the whole euro area by not investing, when it should. For German minister Schäuble nothing is ever enough, Greece has not done enough, it takes more austerity, new structural reforms have to be implemented. What pulpit do these sermons come from? The German minister should explain to us what structural reforms are put in place by Germany to avoid a new diesel gate or to increase the wages of minijobs. Rather, will it not be the elections in Germany, scheduled for next year, that make the minister so rigid and unyielding? An election campaign lived on the hunger of those parents who can no longer feed their children, on the skin of those mothers who give themselves to prostitution to be able to buy their breakfast children. Prostitution in Greece increased by 150 percent, HIV cases by 200 percent. Voters are not heard but only suggestive, voters were not heard in Greece with the referendum wanted by Alexis Tsipras, voters are not heard in Italy. They said no to constitutional reform, no to Renzi and the government of banks, the fact that they find themselves, after a few days, a premier remote-controlled by Renzi himself. And as if that were not enough, Athens has recently approved the budget for 2017, which includes cuts of one billion euros and provides new taxes of an additional billion euros. Colleagues, this Union consists of twenty-eight Member States, and I invite you to choose the words mentioned before. Greece has kept its word, Europe now keeps its own. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Burkhard Balz (PPE)
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — (DE) Madam President, Mrs Agen. Well, I'm a little surprised. I mean, everyone has been insulted now, not just Germany — I can handle this by now, although of course I do not share your assessment. My question is this: you said Germany would break the rules. I would be very interested to know where the German Federal Government, which is composed of Social Democrats and Christian Democrats, is breaking the rules in concrete terms.

name: Laura Agea (EFDD)
text: answer to a question 'blue card'. — Mr Balz, the surplus that your country has been doing for years and for which it has not been sanctioned for years is not a novelty that I have disbanded today, it is not even an offence, it is not even an offence, it is exactly the situation as it is. What has his country done? Your country must be sanctioned for the surplus it has been doing for years, for the damage it does to other states. This is a fact, it is not an insult. Take your responsibility, pay the fines you are owed for the surplus and then come and tell me that the policy that applies to Greece is not okay.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). — Madam President, the memoranda has been imposed on Greece in order to destroy the Greek economy and to impoverish the Greeks. I will not dwell in detail on the issues already known to you, namely the excessively high rate of youth unemployment, the unacceptably low levels of wages and pensions, the arbitrariness of employers and the prevalence of a Middle Ages working in violation of the human rights of Greeks. I would point out that the Greeks have been chosen as a guinea pig, so that these harsh measures can be applied to them and, if they succeed, they can also be applied to the other countries of Europe. And now I will answer you honestly to the legitimate question “why is all this happening?”. Ladies and gentlemen, Greece is a rich country. In its subsoil and underwater space it has oil, natural gas, precious stones and precious metals. All these international loan sharks, spearheaded by each German government, want to seize them from Greece, and that is why they want to impoverish the Greeks. Recently, the German Finance Minister, Mr Scheible, said that we Greeks live above our potential, as if we did not live decently from antiquity. I believe that his positions will be remembered by his Greek voters in the next... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (
text: PPE). — Madam President, where the free market does not work, a black labour market is created. And how can we not create a black labour market in Greece, when we have, based on the latest data, 24.5% unemployment — 49.5% among young people — when we have flexible forms of work 60%, that is, from the 700 euro generation, which the Greek government was once accused of, we have gone down in the generation of EUR 300, when we have a wage balance for November reduced by 37 000, 2% of unemployment per year, how can we not create a black labour market? Madam President, of course we say 'yes' to the social model, we say 'yes' to what should apply to Greece, as they apply to the principles and values of the European Union for all European countries. The Greek government must pursue its policy to create growth and prosperity for the people and the European Union to be completed so that it has funds to cover the weaker social groups. Today the European Union must help Greece, which is the weakest link in the European Union.

name: Γιώργος Γραμματικάκης (
text: S& D). — Madam President, as I understand it, the dimensions of the Greek crisis can hardly be conceived by a European citizen, but I am also afraid of some officials of the European Union. That is why it is very fair that the Greek Government is passionately calling for the application of the acquis communautaire to work. Greece cannot be an exception to this maximum issue. If the world of workers — and this is true for the whole of the European Union — is left to its own fate, the cries of populism and xenophobia simply increase — remember that —. Respect for collective bargaining is therefore self-evident, but the acquis communautaire does not stop here. I will not repeat the nightmarish figures on youth unemployment. The concept of work in Greece is deteriorating and the social fabric of the country is being destroyed, I fear, at a steady rate. The Greek Government is right to claim not only the acquis but also the closure of the evaluation. The myth of Sisyfos is an ancient Greek myth and it is a tragedy to live in modern Greece.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL). — (GR) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are now witnessing a tasteless theatrical performance between the lenders and the Tsipras government. In the name of the Greek programme, in the name of the country's stay in the eurozone, in the name of competitiveness, all Greek governments have accepted the complete deregulation of the Greek labour market. Now the Syriza government will implement a Middle Ages working in Greece in the name of an honest compromise, the Greek Finance Minister said. The Commission did not see, did not know, did not understand what the memoranda meant over the years, it acts as a brutal lender, closing its eyes to the violation of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. But in this theatrical performance, ladies and gentlemen, the protagonists are those political groups in the European Parliament which, in their words, condemn the violation of the acquis communautaire in Greece, but did not agree to a resolution from today's debate stating that they did not there may be a country, such as Greece, that does not apply collective agreements. Ladies and gentlemen, this is the script of the play. Hypocritical statements of sympathy, “alliances” for supposedly defending the workers, a pro-popular person in memorandum policies for possible pre-election developments in Greece.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to make it clear once again that fundamental rights cannot be selected in the way that seems opportless. I would also like to refer to Mr Balz once again. This exchange here on the subject of Greece is already a tradition. Fundamental rights apply in principle, you can't just leave them aside if you fit your own reform agenda. The reform of collective agreements and the collective bargaining system in Greece is unlawful. The Socialist Group has made this very clear, and this must also apply in Greece. Greece has flexible labour markets, and where there are problems, these problems must be solved in such a way that we do not violate the rights to collective agreements that are part of European and international law. We have to tell the Commission: dear Commission, you must not take part in brethren of fundamental rights in Europe, you must comply with European law, and you must work to ensure that your partners, such as the International Monetary Fund, also comply with them. Incidentally, the IMF is right when it comes to primary surplus figures. Therefore, I cannot understand the Greek Government. By calling for the IMF to be excluded from the programme, they simultaneously catapult the Bundestag into opposition to the continuation of Greek programmes. And that really can't be our goal. Hence: the IMF's criticism of the reform programmes is justified, but this response from the IMF does not help us at all, but makes things worse. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Laura Agea (EFDD)
text: Question 'blue card'. — Mr Giegold was in a hurry to leave, but on this surplus we try a moment to establish the order of things. Does Germany need to be sanctioned? Is it going against the rules? Then instead of saying we want to wage a political war start abiding by the rules, because it is the normalcy of democracy to respect the rules. You are violating a rule, as a state, and therefore you can't teach any kind of lesson to other countries. Put things right and then come and give us the lessons.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. — Germany has been achieving export surpluses above the thresholds for many years. The European Commission has carried out an investigation on this. This study has the same result as our policy of the Greens in Germany: we need higher investments and higher wages in Germany so that these surpluses no longer drive our partner countries into debt. We are criticising the grand coalition in Germany. But you really need to leave the church in the village with the tone you show to the people you act. Germany is not a criminal country and should not be criticized in this way by the so-called five-star movement by the Italian public. The tone you put on in part is unacceptable.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, Minister. A few days ago, the Greek Parliament adopted the 2017 budget by a narrow majority. With an expenditure volume of €56 billion, this expects growth of 2.7%. That's pretty good. We have only 1.5% in the eurozone. The draft budget also foresees tax increases of 1 billion and leads to cuts of 5.7 billion. Since yesterday, the Greek Government has been renegotiating with donors to disburse another tranche of the third aid package of EUR 2.8 billion, and we have already heard today: the sticking point is again the implementation of structural reforms in the labour market, pensions and taxes. A sideline is the discussion on Greece's debt sustainability and also on the level of primary surplus. The Eurogroup, in particular the IMF, is now calling on Greece to impose massive restrictions on labour law on the right to strike, dismissals, minimum wage and, in particular, on the autonomy of trade unions. Prime Minister Tsipras opposes this and is supported by the Commission of Experts, which justifies him in its report, in which it says that trade union rights must be restored. One can only hope that a compromise can be found here for the benefit of Greece, but also for the good of Greece... (The President withdraws the speaker from the speaker.)

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). — (EL) Madam President, conflicting statements by the European Commission, the IMF, the Syriza government on debt and surpluses, with the latter playing heroic negotiation, just before the third memorandum, its mockery as well as in here, now, about the evil IMF and good European Union with European acquis of mini jobs, zero hours contracts, etc. hide the agreement of all of them in a finding for the deterioration of the work jungle, the abolition of collective agreements according to the interests of companies, the establishment of the disgrace of the subminimum wage of 150-200 euros, operational individual contracts and wage subordination to profitability, collective redundancies and lockouts, pension open for new reductions after fifteen previous ones, with one-off mockery aid, new measures and after 2018 for blood-stained surpluses already agreed by the government, and this blow of the strike right. The working class should not wait for its slaughter, for she is the only one they fear. The December 8 strike escalated with a strengthening of the organisation, a pan-working uprising against the employers, the European Union and their parties, aimed at overthrowing their power.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). — Madam President, in recent months we have had worrying developments in Greece in the labour market. In August we saw a decline in jobs, although it is a tourist month, during which employment has traditionally increased. In September, October and November we saw a sharp decline in full-time jobs, with a tendency to replace full-time jobs with part-time jobs, most of which provide a meager income for workers and do not contribute adequately to the financing of the social security system. The Tsipras government is constantly increasing the tax burden for large businesses, small and medium-sized enterprises, micro family businesses, while in the state budget of 2017 there are new tax measures worth 3 billion euros, without any substantial reduction in public expenditure, most of which will make it even more difficult for marginal companies to continue operating. More insurance burdens, more tax burdens, more bureaucracy, more energy costs, expensive money, which is not always available; this is the recipe for failure with regard to the labour market in Greece. That's what we need to fix. Obviously we are in favour of the implementation of the European acquis, but above all we need to change the government's economic policy, because otherwise the European acquis will have no practical significance.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: Madam President, we have seen in recent years how aggressive debtor countries were imposed — under the logic of the power of the creditor countries — on aggressive labour reforms which they have left behind are poorer, more unequal, less protected and more precarious societies. And to do all that, it has been essential to weaken collective bargaining. The extreme case has undoubtedly been Greece, that we have seen how in a few years it went from having agreement coverage of 83% to 42% and a 24% reduction in gross wages during these years of crisis. And now we have to see how the President of the European Commission not only recognizes that we suspend part of democracy when we impose these reforms, but also suspend the Charter of Fundamental Rights in the countries where we apply memorandums because, of course, they are outside European law. This is absolutely intolerable and, moreover, hides a huge economic and political failure whose consequences we are seeing election after election on this continent. Inclusive growth that thinks about people is the only way out for this continent.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I really wonder if you are aware of what this Parliament is involved in. We are talking about respect for the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and at the same time you are voting against amendments that defend them. We are talking about the European acquis and you are maiming it in the name of the omnipotence of the laws of the market. We see Nazism and extreme nationalism harvested, and you continue to support and maintain the causes that give birth to them. Poverty, unemployment, energy in the middle ages. Do you really believe that today's debate is about and is limited only to Greece? Do you really believe that there is room for further rebates on what we still call the European acquis? Ladies and gentlemen, we are consciously involved in the gradual dismantling of the United Europe. You know, Commissioner, that some people earn a lot from it and find both willing and obedient. So do you think you can convince us, both you and the Council, that Greece of millions of unemployed, millions of poor and excluded is your successful experiment, as you told us earlier? Of course not, Commissioner. Plan you serve and you are indifferent to both the consequences and the results.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, the attacks on labour rights in Greece obviously come from the 2010 memorandum. Two extremely negative things were done. First, the ability to set the minimum wage for social partners to transfer it to the Executive was withdrawn, and creditors could enforce an effective reduction in the minimum wage. Secondly, individual enterprise agreements were allowed to prevail over sectoral agreements, which obviously led to the fall in collective bargaining from almost 80 per cent to a coverage rate of currently 40%. This is not tolerable. Moreover, I would like to address the Commission in particular, because collective bargaining is something recognized in European law (Article 156 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Article 28 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, Article 6 of the European Social Charter). What cannot be done is that, in certain countries, because they are under a financial intervention programme, European law is suspended. Look, no. The fact that there is a programme in Greece does not mean that European law can be suspended. It applies the same as in any other country and, therefore, when the Greek Government has been trying to restore rights that have been abolished for some years, what it is saying is — just as the current memorandum, which does not speak of taking further labour measures — what it is saying is: 'I want to restore European law in my country'. And that, ladies of the Commission, is something that you should be supporting, because you are the guardians of the Treaties and it is you who have to ensure the application of European law throughout the continent.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Greek economy has been in crisis for eight years, being unable to return to sustainable growth. A lot of blame for this unprecedented failure is routinely put on the European institutions and the so-called austerity measures, but the truth is that the necessary structural reforms in Greece have never been fully implemented. They have been incomplete, partial and delayed, and the damage has been further exacerbated by unrealistic promises made by populist politicians. If economic growth is to be restored, more flexibility is needed in the labour market. The EU should stand ready to help Greece with the European Youth Initiatives and programmes aimed at increasing mobility and employability, but the responsibility for implementing reforms is entirely on the Greek Government. Let me repeat once again that there is no obligation for Greece to accept financial assistance from outside. But if Greece wants to use other countries’, other Member States’ taxpayers’ money, it has to reform in order to guarantee that this money is repaid back on time. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – You are always talking about reforms that have not been implemented in Greece. According to every statement and review, even of the European Commission, Commissioner Moscovici said the day before: Greece has made more changes than any other country in the European Union. What are you talking about?  Then the second question is a very simple question: do you accept that Greece is following the same rules as the other European countries or not? It is very simple: yes or no?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, thank you for your question. Of course   I am of the opinion that Greece should be subject to the same rules as other countries. That includes also the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, which are the rules, by the way, that Greece has violated for a number of years. Now, on the other hand, as far as the reforms are concerned, as I said, they have been implemented late and slowly, and this is the reason for the lack of result. If you want to have, indeed, conditions conducive for investment, as you are interested in, and more job creation, we have to be consistent in implementing those reforms.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S& D). — Madam President, what we have just heard, I am sure, does not reflect the Europe we all dream of, because we have a political and legal issue ahead of us. Is it ever possible in a Member State of the European Union — and that is the fundamental question — that the acquis communautaire on collective agreements is not applied on the grounds that this country is under a memorandum? That is the question before us. And yet it is possible because the International Monetary Fund disagrees with us and because Mr Scheible disagrees with us. In which Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union is allowed to have second-class citizens in the European Union? No one! Despite all the difficult budgetary objectives, despite the management of refugee flows, despite Erdogan's threats, even though Greece safeguards the external borders of the European Union with the backlog of the Greek people, instead of being rewarded it is punished. That is the essence before us.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (
text: GUE/NGL). — Madam President, we are calling for a return to legitimacy and a return to collective labour agreements. From 2010 to 2012 you enforced five laws that caused the dissolution of industrial relations, a ban on collective bargaining on the minimum wage. Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission and of the Council, do not hide behind the IMF! Get clean at last! Are you committed or not to the restoration of collective agreements in Greece? That is what workers and employers in my country are calling for. Are you with the IMF or with the European acquis? Close the assessment with the Greek government now, unless you want us to return to slavery status.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: — There are probably strong reasons for Greece to find itself in such a situation as it is today. I believe that she has also been pushed into such a position by irresponsible politicians and today people suffer the consequences of these decisions. I am pleased that the statistics show that nevertheless in recent years Greece is doing better, that the necessary reforms have been made. However, despite all these reforms, people are still living worse. It will be necessary to do probably a little more. It will be necessary to realize that the country will never succeed in bringing a good life closer to people if it does reforms for the sake of others. The country needs to do reforms for itself and responsible policy is doing them to make their citizens and citizens better off. Greece should also do that. The Speaker replied to the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL), blue-card question. — Mrs Tomc, you rightly pointed out the responsibilities of those who ruled the country and caused the large deficits and debts and bankruptcy. Do you remember which party was in the government when these deficits and debts were recorded? Was it the New Democracy party with which you belong to the same political group? Why don't you tell them?

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: The answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — Because I think the answer is never so easy that we can only point a finger at one man or one government. The situation that Greece is in today is the result of unscrupulous conduct that goes back far into the past. And I think that if Greece wants to find a solution, we should be well aware of this. It is not necessary to look to the past, it is necessary to look to the future.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: — Madam President, I will focus solely on the issue of social dialogue, because I believe that our European model is based on this social dialogue. Commissioner, you have expressed your willingness to work with the social partners and yet, at present, the Greek social partners no longer have the freedom to define the appropriate level of their consultations with, as a direct result, a drastic weakening of the protection of Greek workers. So, Commissioner, this is a serious infringement of European fundamental rights. However, Commissioner, you are in charge of upholding these fundamental rights and not of violating them. It is therefore your duty to re-establish European law in Greece and to give back the social partners the right to negotiate collective agreements at the level they consider appropriate.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President! Strong trade unions and a functioning social partnership are key to success in Europe's leading economies. This means that this applies to Germany, Sweden, Austria and so on. This must also be a good thing for Greece that we do not set two standards here. One third of the Greek population is affected by poverty, and this is already calculated generously. Every second teenager has no work. People are definitely suffering from the reforms. You've heard that more or less from everyone here now. Now it's time to action: the right to strike, relaxation of dismissal protection and the curtailment of trade union rights. These are now demands that are put on the table that do not make any sense in the economy and, accordingly, of course, are not good for the population. The group of experts set up also recommends strengthening and improving the collective and individual rights of workers. That is to say, please leave the trade union rights and also the right to strike alone. This is something that should not be applied by double standards in Europe — whether it is now in Sweden, Austria or Greece.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we recently sent a letter to the three Presidents, Mr Juncker, Dijsselbloem and Mr Draghi, with our colleagues in the Socialists and Democrats Group, on the issue of collective bargaining in Greece, following the implementation of the memorandum. An utterly unpleasant situation, which effectively forced the Greek government to decentralize by emptying the system of collective bargaining in the country of value. The Commission's response leaves us puzzled. On the one hand we recognise the seriousness of the employment and wage situation and the growing poverty, the Commission accepts the utmost attention on the part of the Commission to respect for fundamental and social rights, but, at the same time, it is noted that the memorandum acts outside European rights and therefore, technically, those rights do not apply to the implementation of the measures imposed, I would like to emphasize, one more time, imposed on Greece. On the other hand, I believe that the European Commission, this Parliament and all the institutions must always fight for the rights of the Union to be applied at all times. The Commission is the guardian of the Treaties, so I was taught.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, President Juncker always talks about the 'triple social a', and here tonight you talked about social justice at the heart of the European Union's priorities. Frankly, I say to you, I was nevertheless very shocked that, in his reply to my colleagues on the employment committee who asked him about the suspension of collective or branch agreements at the national level, President Juncker indicated that the Charter of Fundamental Rights should not apply with regard to the programme of employment. budgetary conciliation of Greece. There cannot be double standards, and if Greece is to be exemplary in accordance with the budgetary rule, it will have to be given the means to be exemplary in respect of social democracy, otherwise there will be no return to the climate of confidence. This climate of trust awaits even stronger signs of debt for investment to resume in that country. This country is suffering at the forefront in the name of European solidarity for the reception of refugees, that country has been engaged for many years now in structural reforms that it is implementing with determination, with a democratically elected government, and it is time for it to cover all the tools of social democracy. Remember that at the beginning of the European Commission's intervention, in the case of the troika, from the very beginning, the ILO and the Council of Europe denounced these crossings that prevented Greece from having these essential tools. Commissioner, tell the President of the Commission that it is time to allow Greece to recover all these tools that recreate this climate of trust and investment, which Greece and ourselves need so much.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to express, first of all, my solidarity with the Greek authorities and people and their efforts towards recovery, human dignity and social justice. The situation in Greece shows that the policy of austerity is at a dead end. The EU acquis labour issues should also be applied in Greece, and it must be ensured that Greece will not be the exception as regards labour rights. The collective labour contracts are a very important acquis which must also be applied for Greece. I hope that Athens, despite the International Monetary Fund’s protest, will be able to restore collective bargaining following its elimination on the terms of the second bailout programme in 2012. There is no need to tighten rules on strikes or to allow lockouts, which are a way for employers to ban workers during strikes.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Madam President, in recent weeks we have become unintentional spectators of an absurd theatre starring the Commission and the International Monetary Fund, because both institutions had agreed with the Greek Government to set up a committee of high-profile experts and common acceptance, which would give an opinion on issues related to industrial relations in Greece. This committee gave its opinion and gave its opinion that collective bargaining should be maintained, or rather reinstated, in accordance with EU law, and that it would do no good to fully liberalise collective redundancies, which would lead to in a country where unemployment accounts for 23% of the working population. Both the Commission and the International Monetary Fund are therefore called upon to honour their signature effectively by accepting the findings of the Committee of Experts. Pacta sunt servanda.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Commission, the IMF, dear ECB, dear members of the Eurogroup and, above all, Mr Schäuble! Over and over time, Greece has been accused of not sticking to agreements in recent years, especially in the Member State from which I come — Germany. Greece has been accused of unreliability, laziness, even a crooked mentality, because the Treaties are supposedly so sacred. A rule that no longer seems to apply correctly today. For now, Greece is to be forced, against international law and against the EU treaties, that is to say treaties, to restrict, among other things, the right to collective bargaining and the right to strike. If the treaties are so sacred to you, stop it! Stop this double standards and put forward a plan to relieve the debt burden for Greece without breaking international law.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). — (EL) Madam President, despite the bloody sacrifices made by the Greek people over the last seven years, despite the unprecedented recession that Greece has not seen in the Second World War, despite the continuing failures of the measures imposed by the Union, we are again witnesses of the attempted blackmail by Greece into accepting a new package of measures which, apart from deepening the crisis, will have no other effect. In particular, it is very easy to propose the circumvention of labour acquired and rights, with the sole aim of serving capital and large companies. You do not really care if Greece turns into a special economic zone and workers become serfs. But do not think that my country is a colony, and such practices will have no chance. Even if they are signed, for us it is the product of blackmail, so there will be no commitment to their implementation when the people choose to have a national government. The economic war and the attempt to impose the absurd German demands on the whole continent, our continent, will not only encounter resistance but will be crushed by the healthy national forces that are awakening throughout Europe.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Madam President, today more strongly than ever the mock of the institutions (the Commission, the Council and the IMF) towards the peoples and especially the Greek people. The IMF and EU institutions are blaming each other for who is imposing harsh measures on peoples and workers. At the same time they are promoting a flagrant violation of workers' rights to collective bargaining and collective agreements in countries that have been imposed on them by memorandum. It is the European Union together with the International Monetary Fund that forced the dismantling of the institution of collective bargaining in Greece in 2010 and led to a reduction in the coverage of employees by collective agreement from 80 to 40% within six years. They did the same in Portugal, Cyprus, Italy and Spain. As the Left, we express our solidarity with the workers of Greece and believe that the only way is to fight the memorandum and we will not stop fighting both inside and outside Parliament to assert workers' rights, to assert the decent work and social coverage.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to say a few words after the debate. First, thank you all for the very open and expressive debate.  The Commission does not agree that there has been any violation of European Union or international law and standards. International labour standards are universal instruments adopted by the international community and reflect common values and principles on work—related issues. They are common to us all. The European Court of Justice has not found that measures adopted in the framework of the economic adjustment programme are in non—compliance with the European Union Charter. That is also clear.  The suspension of the legal extensions of sectoral agreements and the favourability principle does not mean that collective bargaining has disappeared from Greece. The workers’ and employers’ organisations are free to negotiate and sign all forms of collective labour agreements at national, general, sectorial and company level. It would therefore be misleading to say that in Greece the freedom of collective bargaining has been abolished and needs to be restored. As I mentioned, at the end of September, a group of independent experts delivered a report with recommendations following a thorough assessment of the Greek labour market. We all need to see such a thorough assessment of the Greek labour market today. The experts made 12 recommendations relating to collective bargaining, collective dismissals, industrial action and the setting of a minimum wage. Four of these 12 recommendations were split, reflecting the lack of consensus within the group. These related to the setting of a minimum wage and collective bargaining, extension and favourability of principles. The Commission considers the report an important input to the ongoing discussions on possible labour market reforms in Greece. In principle, this could entail a revision of some measures which have already been implemented measures. However, simply returning to the pre—crisis status quo is not an option. The Greek labour market was already in poor shape before the crisis erupted, not least due to policies and the quality of social partnerships that were dysfunctional and not delivering. The objective of the review is to promote a more responsible social partnership today and ensure sufficient margins for flexibility to allow Greek firms still faced with the need to restructure to do so. This process represents a unique opportunity for Greece to develop a stable setting that is supportive of social dialogue. We all need such a social dialogue, of course, including job creation and competitiveness, ensuring the right balance between flexibility and fairness and taking into account the very high unemployment and the need to pursue sustainable and inclusive growth and social justice. We have carefully considered the group’s recommendations and discussions with the Greek authorities on how to reflect them are still ongoing. Therefore I will not speculate on what might or might not be. However, the Commission recognises the scope to improve collective bargaining in Greece with the goal of establishing a strong and more sustainable social partnership today. For example, extensions would need to be based on reliable mechanisms to measure the level of representativeness for collective agreements, which is something which the experts also recommended. Proper consideration should also be given to the design of all functioning systems of possible derogations. As in the past, we will do our utmost to ensure the success of the stability support programme for Greece and thus a return to economic, financial and social stability. We are convinced that the structural reforms foreseen, including those in the labour market, are necessary to enable Greece to modernise and secure the competitiveness gains of recent years. The goal is to regain the path of sustainable growth and job creation by strengthening the role of effective social dialogue and collective bargaining.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — Labour reforms carried out in Greece under the auspices of the Troika have deteriorated the collective bargaining system, leaving millions of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion. This situation is absolutely intolerable because it violates both the Union Charter of Fundamental Rights, ILO Conventions and the European Social Charter. The fact that memorandums of understanding are not specifically considered European law cannot serve to deteriorate the European Social Model in Greece. We call on the Commission and the Troika, as we did in the Cercas report on 'the labour and social aspects of the role and activities of the Troika (ECB, Commission and IMF) in relation to euro area countries subject to the adjustment programme' and by letter last week, to listen to the ILO, to listen to the European Committee on Rights social and to take good note of the report of the Committee of Experts which she herself commissioned. This ignominy must be put to an end by reinstating collective bargaining in Greece and by taking measures for a just economic recovery, focused on people's well-being.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. — Labour reforms carried out in Greece under the auspices of the Troika have deteriorated the collective bargaining system: marginalization of sectoral agreements without the promised increase in enterprise agreements, a 40% reduction in wages leaving millions at risk of poverty and exclusion social. This situation is absolutely intolerable because it violates both the Union Charter of Fundamental Rights, the ILO Conventions and the European Social Charter. The fact that memorandums of understanding are not specifically considered European law cannot serve to deteriorate the European Social Model in Greece.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: in writing. — Ladies! The labour market situation in Greece is the worst in the whole Union. Despite some progress, still more than 23% of the citizens of this state are unemployed and close to 17% remain out of work for more than a year. What is most worrying, however, is that close to half of young Greeks do not have permanent employment. It is therefore good that in the last week an agreement has been reached to extend the deadline for repayment of loans by Athens and some of the interest has been forgone. It has long been known that without a debt restructuring, Greece will not be able to return to growth. However, a condition for the entry into force of this agreement is for Athens to implement reforms in the labour market, which could further increase unemployment in the short term. I understand the concerns of the public of this State, which, after years of renunciation, still has no apparent prospect of improving the situation. However, I am from a country that, during the economic transition, had to make radical, immense unemployment, changes in the labour market. Before Greece, as before Poland in the early 1990s, there is no other path and certain decisions must be made. It is essential to support the government in Athens with a decision to restructure its debt. Without it, as even the International Monetary Fund already points out, it will not be possible to heal the situation in this country.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The reforms that the Troika negotiated with the former Greek governments — the dismantling of collective bargaining and facilitating dismissal — are the same as the PSOE and the PP imposed in Spain. Imposing enterprise agreements on top of the rest and allowing ad hoc commissions is nothing other than giving employers carte blanche to unilaterally impose working conditions, especially when the business fabric in Greece, as in Spain, is essentially made up of SMEs. Facilitating dismissal is nothing more than permanent blackmail for workers, who know they will have to compromise with any taxation or go to the streets. The results of these reforms are visible in Spain as in Greece: a quarter of the unemployment population and one-third of the workers below the SMI, under increasingly precarious conditions. That is why, more than ever, our solidarity with the people and Government of Greece in the face of the new impositions of the IMF and the EU.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: in writing. — I condemn the austerity measures imposed by the troika on the Greek people. These measures, already applied in the past, have demonstrated their inefficiency. Yet this year there has been a steady increase in the number of austere reforms: on 9 May, two reforms (pensions and income taxes) had been implemented, which led to the discontent of the Hellenic people; at the end of May, an increase in VAT and the creation of new taxes (residency, for example) were on the order of day; at the end of September, these reforms concerned the reorganization of the energy market and new privatization; today, wages, social benefits and increases in taxes are taking the Greek people out into the streets. When will the European Union stop deliberately organizing the impoverishment of whole countries? But these measures are not only economic nonsense, they are also an affront to sovereignty: the Greek people rejected this policy by voting massively “no” in the referendum in July 2015, as the French voted “no” in the referendum on the European Constitution, finally imposed by the government. Two different countries, one and the same shameful way of proceeding within the European Union.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. — Greece has come a worthy chunk of winding road since the start of the crisis in 2009. So far, he is pulling with him a reminder in the form of national debt accounting for up to 177.4 percent of gross domestic product and unemployment of 23 percent. These figures do not just remind him of the fact that providing distorted statistics can have a very unnice or catastrophic game for many, but also to what end blind neoliberal economic policy leads. I am very happy that Greece is still a member of the European Union and its smaller euro area monetary association. However, I would like to point out in this context that meeting the requirements imposed by the International Monetary Fund and the European Commission is one thing. The second thing, but still inseparable, is to ensure acceptable living and working conditions for employed and unemployed residents. They also belong to European citizens. So we really want to allow a withdrawal in a developed country belonging to one of the largest economic blocs, which has been serving Europe for months as a so-called buffer in the migration wave. of a fundamental right, such as the right to collective bargaining? Do we really see fit to replace classic work commitments with short-term and unstable ones? Not only do we violate the fundamental elements of social Europe, but we also violate the provisions of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which we ourselves adopted in 2000 and 2007.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the rule of law and democracy in Poland (2016/3030 (RSP)).

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament for putting the situation in Poland on the agenda of its plenary meeting today. Last time we discussed this issue in plenary was on 13 September. The resolution which the plenary adopted later that day provided a strong support for the Commission, and I would like to thank Parliament for this support. Today, I would like to explain what has happened since and how we see the situation since the adoption of our recommendation. As you know, the Commission raised three main issues of concern in its rule of law recommendation of 27 July. The composition of the Constitutional Tribunal, the publication of its judgments, and the effectiveness of the functioning of the Tribunal. The Commission asked the Polish authorities to address these concerns within three months. Regrettably, since the adoption of the recommendation, the situation has not improved. On 14 October, the Venice Commission issued an opinion on the rule of law in Poland which fully supports the concerns expressed by the Commission. Regrettably, the Polish Government has not accepted, but strongly criticised this opinion. Let me remind you, the Polish Government asked for the Venice Commission to give its opinion. On 27 October, the Commission received a reply from the Polish Government. However, this reply did not announce any new actions on the part of the Polish authorities to address the concerns identified by the Commission. It rather explained why the Polish Government disagreed with the positions of the Commission expressed in the recommendation. In particular, the Polish Government denied that the judgments of the Polish Constitutional Tribunal of the 3 and 9 December 2015 had any legal relevance for the composition of the tribunal.  Furthermore, three new laws regarding the Constitutional Tribunal are at the final stage of the legislative process; they were voted on last night in the Sejm. While these laws would address some of the issues raised in the recommendation of 27 July, they also introduce new provisions, raising concern in particular regarding the President of the Constitutional Tribunal.  The President of the Republic would be given the right to appoint an ‘Acting President’ of the Tribunal, which is in clear disregard of the provisions of the Polish Constitution concerning the election of the President and the Vice-President of the Tribunal. In addition, the functioning of the Tribunal is significantly impeded as three judges of the Constitutional Tribunal, elected by the previous Sejm, have still not been sworn in. Three judges appointed by the new majority are currently not participating in the Tribunal’s work. This leaves the Constitutional Tribunal unable to decide cases in composition of a full bench, which requires the participation of 11 judges. I am deeply concerned by these new developments, which threaten to deepen the rule of law crisis in Poland. I therefore urgently call on the Polish authorities not to put into force the new laws before the Constitutional Tribunal has had the occasion to examine their constitutionality, which is the role the tribunal has in the Polish Constitution. I also call on the President of Poland to urgently swear in the three judges elected by the previous Sejm, and I call on the Poland Government to publish, and fully respect, all the previous judgments of the Constitutional Tribunal. You do not get to pick and choose which judgments you like and then only publish the judgments you like; that is in violation of the separation of powers. The College is following the situation closely and will discuss the situation in Poland soon, in order to consider the situation and determine the best way of addressing this situation. Let me underline, once again, that this is not a political question; it is about our fundamental values. It is crucial that, whatever a government’s programme entails, it is done in full accordance with the constitution and the law itself. That is why the effective functioning of the Constitutional Tribunal is so important. This is also crucial for the implementation of all Union policies, including the Internal Market, and is the basis for the mutual trust between Member States. The separation of powers is essential for the functioning of our internal market, because the Court of Justice in Luxembourg has to be sure that, in its direct relationship with courts at the national level, there is no interference of the other branches of power. Judicial independence is of the essence for the whole system to be able to function, including the functioning of the internal market. To conclude, I would like to thank the European Parliament for its continuous efforts to uphold the rule of law in the EU and for supporting the Commission’s actions concerning the situation in Poland. As I said at our last debate, upholding the rule of law is the shared responsibility of all EU institutions, and it has never been as necessary as it is today. That is why, Parliament, your support is crucial; that is why, let me say this again, this is a dispute the Commission has with the Government of Poland, not with the Republic of Poland – certainly not with the people of Poland – but with the Government of Poland.  (Applause)

name: Janusz Lewandowski
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Madam President! 35 years ago, on December 13th, under the cover of night, the communist power declared war on its own society. It was a dark card of Polish history. I, together with students, organized resistance at the University of Gdańsk. It was a naive barricade, in full sense of defencelessness at the sight of tanks, but also with a full sense of meaning for this protest and the hope that it would bear fruit. And we have come to a free Poland in a united Europe. This is a good opportunity to thank all those for whom the fate of Poland was not indifferent, who helped us on the path to freedom. Yesterday, which is 35 years after martial law was introduced and 27 years after independence was regained, tens of thousands of people took to the streets to voice their opposition to abuses of current power. That power came from a democratic mandate, but the mandate of less than 20% of those eligible to vote does not justify a progressive coup on the institutions of the rule of law, civil society, a healthy economy. He doesn't justify ruining Poland's position in the world. The list of these abuses is lengthening. Yesterday was a sad day for Poland, as a new assembly law stifles freedom of assembly — a fundamental right that Solidarity fought for. The list is lengthening, and you can point out the next objectives of this hearing with the public: local government, unhinged judiciary... This is all perfectly visible to the democratic world on both sides of the Atlantic. No longer can the new Iron Curtain be drained. The brainwashing mission, carried out by some public media in Poland, does not reach Strasbourg and Brussels.
