Anyone here who lies in the image of Polish reality loses credibility, also in this forum. It has already been referred to Poland five times in the European Parliament, so we are the sick link of this Community. The price is paid by all Poland. It is a wonderful collective work of millions of Poles that is Poland a quarter century does not deserve to be paid so great prices for abuses of power. That's why we'll be testifying to the truth. We will be the voice of millions of people who know that the principles in treaties and in our constitution are in order to protect civil liberties, a healthy economy, a healthy public and social order. We will be the voice of millions of people who feel good in the European Union, feel at home, and understand the European Union as a guarantee of our security and our chances for development.

name: Birgit Sippel
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. The 30th anniversary of the Polish Constitutional Court should be a cause for joy, a symbol of Poland's commitment to freedom and democracy. But little of that can be felt. The ultra-conservative PiS government continues to amputate the Supreme Court, and in addition, reports of restrictions on the right of assembly or curtailment of women's rights are causing concern. No democratic majority in the world entitles a government to destroy democracy. That is why it was right that the Commission launched the rule of law mechanism for Poland. But the Polish government has no insight. I am tired of our calls for respect for fundamental rights, for the safeguarding of freedom and democracy bounce again and again on a wall of resistance that Mr Orbán and Mrs Szydło are building higher every day. Let's finally give a clear signal! Poland is on the Council's agenda, and only a four-fifths majority is needed to formally recognise the existence of a systemic threat to the rule of law in Poland. That would, after all, be a signal, even if there are no concrete sanctions. This also shows that the existing instruments to safeguard democracy and the rule of law are not enough. However, the Commission is not as helpless as President Juncker said in an interview. Mr. Timmermans! We urge you to present a proposal for an independent annual report on the state of the rule of law in all EU countries. Democratic fundamental rights are obviously not a matter of course. Like many places in Europe, the people of Poland have had to fight hard for this. Obtaining them now, however, is the responsibility of all Europeans.

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Well, unfortunately, you're doing an Orwellian spectacle again. I hope that the last, though knowing this chamber, you never know anything. As before, this whole decision to debate Poland is senseless, unfair, extremely biased and unsupported. I don't know how, in such a short time, I'm supposed to disperse all these untruths that have been told. There is, please, no problem with the Assembly Act. It doesn't. Am I making myself clear? No, there are no restrictions on anyone's right to demonstrate in Poland — neither individuals, nor groups, or organizations. He doesn't! So why are you bothering people? How can you size so extremely with facts? Shame on yourselves! You must not do such things! Some comments here were on women's rights in Poland and on the Istanbul Convention. Please, if it comes to violence against women, Poland is in last place in Europe in this inglorious ranking. In last place in Europe! Your homeland, Mr Timmermans, is very high in this hierarchy. So why don't we take care of countries like the Netherlands, like Belgium, and stop talking about Poland. Come to Poland, maybe you can learn how to take care of women's rights. Apparently, it's never too late for science. This principle perhaps does not apply to the European elites, but I hope that something will change on this one. You, Mr Timmermans, are pulling the Constitutional Court case incomprehensible to me, demanding — well, because that's really what it comes down to — that this Court be dominated by nominees of one political party. This procedure was done in a way — to put it mildly — not entirely lawful at the end of your previous term during the previous government and you didn't react at the time. Why didn't you react? Why didn't the Commission respond? I'll tell you why. Because it was your site. I because I understand why you think that institutions, also Polish, should be dominated by one side of the political dispute. There has been one political constellation in the European Union since time immemorial and you have already become so accustomed to the fact that if there is a differentiation somewhere, they treat it as an anomaly. Mr President, believe me: if there are disputes in the Constitutional Court, then maybe well. If the lawyers differ, then maybe good, isn't it? Do you think that, in that case, one chorus of nominees of one party should govern, exercise control over the constitution in Poland? However, a similar attitude is characterised by — I say this with regret — the Venice Commission, which came to Poland for the first time in February of this year and did not even deal to meet the judges of the Constitutional Court who have a different opinion. She just didn't fend, and they threw their written opinion in the trash. How am I supposed to — sorry — believe in the credibility of the Venice Commission? What are these mores anyway? And don't tell me here that you're all about freedom and rights, because you're not the least about it. You mean — I repeat again — about preserving one side's monopoly. If you don't know how long they've been talking about European values here, the truth is that you have less and less to do with these values. You don't follow treaties. Mr President, you do not obey the treaties! All this procedure that you and your colleagues have initiated against Poland is out-of-war. You sir are completely ignoring it. You don't respect the principle of subsidiarity, you don't respect views other than yours, you don't recognize the principles of rational discussion, you don't recognize the Roman principle that one has to listen to the other side's rations. You don't follow another Roman rule that no one can be a judge in their own case. This alienation of European elites from European culture, which we have been seeing for a long time, is a deeply saddening fact and is fateful. More recently with my my colleague, Mr Tomasz Poręba, I wrote you an extensive letter pointing out gross errors — I repeat: gross errors — in your position and the European Commission and it is not about interpretation. It is about factual errors concerning the Polish constitution and Polish law. You, by your custom and custom, have completely ignored this. Either you didn't understand them, or you pretend you don't get it. This is the old method — pretending there isn't something. Just as the Venice Commission pretended there were no other judges to speak to. True, how does it all straight then look, if you don't have to answer arguments, no need to argue? Right? No need to look for some compromises, just you can sing the same aria at the clapping audience all the time. But this is not a political conversation, this is not a debate, this is not any way of settling a dispute. This is all unfortunately — I'm afraid — a fragment of a larger whole. The European Union, instead of stabilising itself, is increasingly swayed and you have a fair share of responsibility for this. You are antagonizing societies, deepening divisions, not only in Poland. Look at how it cooks in most European countries. Instead of unifying your allies, seeking support, you are producing new enemies at an ever-faster pace. Enemies — I say — not reformers like myself or my colleagues in my group who want the Union to reform. But it can't go on forever. Well, how long is this process supposed to go on, the process of generating a generation of new enemies who want the European Union to break up from the inside? What is your answer to this? More of the same, yes? More of the same. It could all be fatally over. Then, at the end, what can I do? I can appeal to some authority. I dedicate to you, Mr. President, and to you the famous phrase from the Old Testament, from the Book of Proverbs: “haughtiness treads before failure, and the spirit delicious before fall.” Just to make myself understood: 'Pride goeth before destruction, and an haughty spirit before a fall'. (Applause from some quarters, murmurs of dissent from others) (The speaker agreed to take four blue-card questions under Rule 162 (8))

text: question (“blue card”). — Madam President! Thank you very much. I would like to ask you a concrete question there. text: the question asked by raising the blue card. — Mr President! If you were to seriously take what you just said, you should get the impression that there is some kind of powerful conspiracy across Europe against the government in Warsaw, which seems to be untrue. Will you admit — and these are my questions — that this hated and ugly Europe, which wants to dig our homeland so badly, enjoys the greatest support among all European countries in Poland, among Polish citizens? And the second question — will you still argue that the three judges chosen correctly by the previous term's Sejm are judges who are supposed to form some mythical majority (not known whose) because they're properly elected judges?

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. “It is true that in Poland we have very much support for the European Union, but if the Commission, including Mr Timmermans, continues to do what it does, over time this support will surely fall. text: — I ask you, Madam President, because since you have asked Professor Legutka to answer three questions, and after the first question you interrupted him, I would like to ask you as President, however, to allow you to answer questions about which you also solicits as leading these deliberations.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Congressman! Maybe the translation was not correct, maybe he was not paying attention, he has the perfect opportunity to answer all the questions, in line, in a row. You first answered Madame Post's question, now you have answered Congressman Zwiefka's question, and there are two more. Two questions, two blue cards, one question by Mrs Björk and the other by Mr Hadjigeorgiu. That's it, and he's going to answer in a row. 30 seconds questions, 30 seconds answers, that's order. Here you go, Congresswoman Björk.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: blue-card question. – There is structural under-reporting of violence against women in all our Member States, and I think that is definitely the case in Poland also. Would you not agree that under the Istanbul Convention it is a fundamental right of women to live a life free from violence? Why should your government withdraw from that? For me, it is a question of the fundamental rights of women, and they are under attack in Poland. Why is that so?

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by picking up the blue card. — Well, I don't know how many times I have to say the same thing. We are in the lowest place in Europe. The Istanbul Convention has nothing to do with it. If she had anything to do, then there should be this violence reduced in your countries, and it's very high. As for the Constitutional Court, Mr President Timmermans, also no Constitutional Court judgment said anything about the three judges who were elected. The Constitutional Court is talking about laws, not choice. The three-judge issue came up in the justification for the judgment. The rationale for the sentence is not part of the law. I know this may be new information for you, Mr President, but I am engaged to you that it is.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), blue-card question. — Dear Mr Legutko, you have had eight minutes to argue and, with all your appreciation, your argument shows you that you think that everyone here has been misled, not to say that your whole argument seems to think that Maybe we're out of our minds. What do you think is the root cause of this attitude? What's wrong with us?

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by picking up the blue card. — I can repeat what I've already said. We have two basic enemies: one is ignorance, the other is prejudice. It's very hard to fight.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I always think you are funny, Mr Legutko. For somebody who says that this debate should not take place, you have got a lot of speaking time from your Group. Having this debate, this is a very personal remark.  In this debate today, my thoughts go to my former colleague, Bronisław Geremek, who sat next to me for a number of years. He was always a big hero of mine when I was still a student, and I was ever so proud that he was my colleague. Today, I stand, my Group stands, this House stands with the Polish people – just as the European Parliament stood with the Polish people in 2012, when we debated and condemned the website by Geert Wilders’ party from the Netherlands against the Polish people; as the European Parliament also stood by the Polish people this summer, when we mourned a Polish citizen who was the victim of xenophobic hate crime in the UK.  We stood by the Polish people then. We also stand by the Polish people today; we stand by the thousands who took to the streets yesterday at a protest organised by the Committee for the Defence of Democracy, which I commend for their actions. We also stand by our own sister party ‘Nowoczesna’ and other parties like the EPP colleagues who are present. They are protesting against the erosion of their rights, because like all EU citizens, Polish citizens are entitled to an independent judiciary. Polish women, like other women, are entitled to protection against domestic violence. Polish women, like other women, are entitled to free choice into decide over their own bodies. Polish people have a right to freedom of assembly, freedom of speech and freedom of thought, Mr Legutko.  Now the Polish Government is robbing the Polish people of their rights and freedoms. I wonder if this is what the Polish people voted for when they went to the ballot stations a year ago. Did they vote for the restriction of their freedoms? I do not think so, Mr Legutko. They voted for a good life, to get a job, education for their children, housing and infrastructure. That is what they voted for, Mr Legutko. They did not vote for restrictions on the freedom of the press or the independence of the judiciary. Finally, a question to Mr. Timmermans: you have been criticising the Polish Government, but I would like to know what you are going to do? Because, in your letter of July 27 – I am coming to conclusion, Madam President – you described the situation in Poland as ‘a systemic threat to the rule of law’. Now, if that does not call for action by the European Commission, then what does? Even if you know that the Council will never vote for an Article 7.1 procedure, the Commission should take its responsibility and vote on that. We should put it on the agenda.

name: Malin Björk
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, Colleagues! Two months ago, the Polish government wanted to criminalize and imprison women and those who helped them carry out an abortion. It was a draconian bill and so it was perhaps not so unexpected that hundreds of thousands of women and men in Poland and in solidarity demonstrations around Europe took to the streets. The Polish government was allowed to back down. It was a victory for all of us who see women as full citizens. Now the Polish government is coming back and continuing its assault on women. The government's responsible minister has declared that the country wants to withdraw from the Istanbul Convention. I'll say it one more time: pull out of the Istanbul Convention. Where are we anywhere? This is an international legal fundamental instrument to combat all gender-based violence. It is a human rights issue, of the rule of law, of fundamental principles. It is as important as respect for human rights. Clearly, one is worried about the protests of the people, because furthermore proposals are proceeding, and it has been voted on, to curtail freedom of demonstration. For us, the attack on democratic institutions and rights and the attack on women's rights are interrelated. It is democracy and fundamental rights that are being attacked. I want to see the Commission fight for the basic instruments represented by the Istanbul Convention. You can't let it go. It should not be on the map that a member country can abandon the Istanbul Convention. Thank you! (The speaker declined to answer a question (“blue card”) from Jadwiga Wisniewska)

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, every child in Europe learns in their history classes about the peaceful revolution that took place in Poland and other countries of the European Union some 30 years ago. They learn about the strikes, the protests and the demonstrations that brave Polish citizens organised in order to struggle for democracy and the rule of law. My own image of Poland is strongly shaped by these images. If young people ask me today why they should go out on the streets and get politically engaged, I very often refer to precisely these protests. In the last month, however, we have again seen mass protests and demonstrations in Polish cities and villages against restricting the right to free media, against limiting the rights of an independent jurisdiction, against depriving women of the right to their own bodies. All of these rights are fundamental rights and thus the European Union has to be concerned about them. We stand in solidarity with these movements and we support their struggles. Mr Legutko, if you are saying that we should not have this debate, I must honestly say that I would like not to have this debate and for these problems not to exist, but should I just shy away and close my ears to the concerns of thousands of Polish people who are asking me to speak up for them? Or should I shut my ears to the Venice Commission, an independent expert commission, that is saying that there are problems with the rule of law in Poland, and trust you? I don’t think so. I think democracy is about listening to different voices. This is why we are having this debate and this is why it is so important to exchange our views. I think that the European Parliament will continue to stand with these people, whether in fighting against the restriction of freedom of assembly or the withdrawal from the Istanbul Convention, which has actually been announced by some in the Polish Government. But the real question – and I think you will have to give an answer to this today, Mr Timmermans – is, given that you have you have said that you are concerned and the Commission is concerned about the developments, what exactly will you do? Will you stand up? Will you take decisive steps in order to give a strong signal from both Parliament and the Commission that what has been happening in Poland is not only of concern but in fact needs action at European level?  (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: question asked by raising a blue card. — Dear Madam! Mr Janusz Lewandowski said today that the European Parliament was looking at Aleppo. He should be looking at the streets of Warsaw. Is such an opinion a credible opinion for you? Is she building credibility? Don't all these untruths that fall here about Poland ridicule this House? The commissioner says he is in conflict with Poland's democratically elected government. This is a really perfidious, creeping assassination. An attempted creeping assassination attempt on Poland's democratically elected government.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Well, there wasn’t really a question posed, but I will take this opportunity again to salute all of those people who yesterday and last month in many Polish cities and in many Polish villages were standing up for their rights. I think there are many colleagues in this Chamber who are very proud to stand in solidarity with them, not only the Polish women of the black protest movement, but also those who are fighting for democracy and rule of law. Thanks again to all of them. I think that they really deserve all the credit from the Members of this Parliament.

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Mr President! Soldiers armed to the teeth patrolling the streets of cities, armored transporters, reinforced police forces, checks at stations and airports, an atmosphere of fear and uncertainty, a protracted state of emergency. You'd think it was Poland from thirty-five years ago, but no: it's today's France and Belgium. I look around and see people being murdered on city streets, I see terrorists shooting passers-by, perpetrating rapes on women, driving a truck into the crowd. Is it Poland? No, it's Sweden, France, Germany. I look around further and see a repeat election due to mass irregularities, I see how the government is disregarding democracy and ignoring the results of the referendum. Is it Poland? No, it's Austria, the UK. Aren't these problems that we really should be debating and addressing them? Dear ladies! Let's be honest, Poland does not need your remarks, your false concern, your advice taken from the ceiling. Take care of the mess in your states, on your streets and in your societies. Poland needs no more of your hypocritical democracy. What, on the other hand, does Poland need? Freedoms. Poland needs freedom and Poland must stand on the side of freedom. We need freedom from EU laws, we need freedom from the supervision of EU officials, we need freedom from the comments of EU MPs — some people are Poles — we need freedom from the comments of EU commissioners. In a word: Poland needs freedom from this whole European Union. Poland needs freedom to work peacefully, to run the company peacefully, to live safely according to its own tradition and history. You who invade Poland are on the side of oppression, I am on the side of freedom. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Barbara Spinelli (GUE/NGL)
text: 'blue card' question. — The question, Mr Iwaszkiewicz, what does everything you said have to do with the speeches we are making in this Parliament? And again, what are we doing in this Parliament and in this European Union, since we are in this Parliament with Commissioner Timmermans to discuss among ourselves on how to defend common values and principles? What are you doing here?

name: Robert Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz (EFDD)
text: answer to the question posed by picking up the blue card. — Dear lady! I defend freedom. First, European values, not EU values. Roman laws, Greek ethics, Latin civilization, Christian culture, not still-changing laws imposing enslavement on normal, ordinary, law-abiding citizens. I'm defending that, ma'am.

name: Michał Marusik
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Mr President! Critical comments on Poland's internal affairs are unacceptable because they break the principle of state sovereignty and worse, they also break the principle of self-determination of nations. That is why trends to come out of the European Union are becoming more clear. Nations want to decide for themselves. Dear compatriots! Faith does wonders. You didn't believe it was possible to get out of the eastern pressure. We're out. Today you don't believe you can get out of the pressures and pressures of the West. We're going to go out, just need to believe it, and we're really out We will be a free country and a free nation. And finally I call you, Poland, my homeland. Get up off your knees! We will be free, we will host in our own home and we will officiate this house our own way. Just get up off your knees. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: question of “blue card”. — Dear colleague, I love Poland. I love the Poland of resistance and overcoming. I love Solidarity Poland. I love Poland of art, free expression, reconquered democracy, innovation, culture. I love Poland of science and progress. What do you think Marie Curie — Maria Skłodowska — would say, European, if, a century after winning two Nobel Prize laureates in science, she found that your country's government wants to bring him back to the Middle Ages?

name: Michał Marusik (ENF)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — Absolutely from the way of progress Poland does not turn back. Poland is just looking to enter this path of progress. She is looking for a way that she can decide for herself, and that we Poles can in our own home arrange the order we want, and grow so and so live, through culture, tradition and custom as we want to have, and there is nothing wrong with that. If Mrs. Poland loved, you would also love our will to live in your own country.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: — What can be said in a minute, as you know nothing about Poland. For example, women have much more say in politics in Poland than in any country in Europe. Do you, for example, know (You are a Democrat — I say to you in't Veldt — and I am not a Democrat) that there is a slight advantage in Poland of men who are in favor of abortion, and there are definitely more opponents of abortion than among men? It's women who are opponents of abortion, not men. In Poland, I can call Afropolak the word proper in this country, and if I use the word here, I will be punished with three thousand euros. It is in Poland that there is freedom of speech, and there is none here. In Poland, the people who ruled in communism are protected legitimately by this tribunal, and indeed the current power is breaking the rules because it wants to introduce a little different order. The Court has lost the moral support of the country.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also share the concern of the Polish people at the drift away from democracy and the rule of law in their country. The Constitutional Tribunal has disregarded since March – you said it so well, First Vice—President – the proposal to limit the right of assembly, thus undermining civil society. Does that mean that Polish women demonstrating for their rights will not be able to take to the streets anymore and attend the protests that I wholeheartedly supported? Would that be banned? There was another statement from the Minister of Social Affairs that Poland intends to withdraw from the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women.  Today, as co-rapporteur for the Convention, I want to reach out to you, colleagues, and to the Polish Government, to engage in an open and constructive dialogue on their reservations. I call on you, First Vice-President, to initiate this dialogue together with the Council of Europe. Let’s do it based on facts, not ideology. And what is the definition of gender-based violence in the Convention? It is clear: it is violence done to women just because they are women. We are talking about domestic violence, sexual abuse, rape, child marriage, honour killings. To consider the Convention to be against our tradition and culture is a false interpretation, even according to the Council of Europe. How could punishing criminals and protecting girls be considered against Christian values? I therefore ask the Polish Government to reconsider their intention to withdraw from the Convention. I am sure we share these common values on zero tolerance against violence. I want to conclude by saying that we in the PPE continue to stand by the people of Poland demonstrating for their rights.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: — Today's debate is not a debate against Poland, but for Poland — in order to correct its direction and again become a country for all its inhabitants. I support the action of the European Commission. Vice President Timmermans, will he sway? I will never be quiet when governments like Poland are going to crudely but without consequences violate many rights to their citizens. Poland is increasingly moving away from democratic values, increasingly evident violations of rights to women and the christening of the role of a woman in society. Increasingly dire is the situation in media becoming manipulative, and increasingly noticeable is the rise of far-right and hate crime. All the worse is the role of the rule of law. Colleagues, today's debate is not against the Poles, but against the current Polish government, and is a debate that demands attention at the Council of the European Union tomorrow. (the speaker said last sentence in English)

name: Syed Kamall (ECR).
text: – Mr President, here we are again. Yet another session, and yet another opportunity for this Parliament to lecture Poland, its people and its government on how to run a democracy. But when you try to lecture a government, especially one which won a democratic election with a large majority, you lecture not just the governing party, but also the people who voted for that governing party.  No wonder people feel more detached than ever from Brussels. The Polish Government needs no lecture from you guys on how to run a democracy; but the Left, they like to give lectures on democracy while the hypocrisy blinds them to the authoritarian regimes that they have supported in the past. Many on the left of this House kept silent or even supported Soviet socialism. While members of the Polish Government and governing party fought for years to throw off the shackles of communism and oppression, and on the week of the 35th anniversary of invoking martial law in Poland, this is fresh in our minds. It is very clear that whatever everyone's role is in this situation, it is outlined in the Treaties. This House has no real role in this; it should be for the Commission. The tone here, where we were supposed to be having a debate, seems to be undermining dialogue – it is just polarising. So often, Members in this House refer to the Treaties and call upon the Commission to act in a fair and impartial way; yet so many are happy to throw that rule book out the window if it means cheap political points can be scored here in the Parliament. Add to that, the Polish opposition parties that, having lost democratic elections at home, seek to attack their government in Brussels and Strasbourg – forgetting the fact that they packed the Constitutional Court when they were in power and did not follow international standards on media regulation, never missing the opportunity to play judge, jury and executioner. Some here will argue that they are defending democracy and offering a helping hand, but that helping hand is starting to feel like a controlling fist. The tone of this debate and the ones before it is why some Member States now feel less equal than others. That is why when it comes to this issue, many brave Poles who fought against martial law are beginning to feel that in Brussels it has a master rather than a partner.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. –  My initial question was going to be whether after this intervention, you can still look yourself in the mirror in the morning, because I do not think you believe what you just said, Syed. Very disappointed. My more political question is going to be – and I think your allegation, that I, as apparently all of a sudden a part of the left, was a support of communism, is really hysterically funny, you know it is not true – but I wonder: if you say Poland is being singled out, you seem to have forgotten that I have been criticizing Hungary, Lithuania, the Netherlands, many other countries. My question to you is: why then did you do not support the report that was voted in this House on the pact for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights that covers all the Member States and treats all the Member States equally? I would have expected your support.

name: Syed Kamall (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Because what I see from you, Sophie, is actually selective in your debate. Many people here have talked about the Istanbul Convention and criticised Poland for thinking of withdrawing from it – and I understand those concerns. But look at the Istanbul Convention. Do you know, when you count the numbers, there are 14 Members of the EU that have not ratified it? And yet you are hypocritical. You yourself, from your own country, are hypocritical, condemning the Poles who have ratified it. You are the biggest hypocrite I have seen.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: - Mr President! What is missing from this debate is the words of the master, the conductor of what is now happening in Poland. Jarosław Kaczynski said, quote, about refugees: “There are already symptoms of the appearance of diseases very dangerous and long unseen in Europe: cholera in the Greek islands, disinteria in Vienna, all sorts of parasites and protozoa, which are not threatening in the organisms of these people, and they can here be menacing.” On the judgments of the Constitutional Court: “These are acts of a private nature which may under no circumstances acquire legal force by publication.” About the opposition's actions: “Oh well, these are the fumes of absurdity — something between disease, you know what, and some burlesque. Otherwise, it can't be determined.” And about the prescription for the opposition: “On our part, there will be attempts to sort out the actions of the opposition. We will put forward proposals to ensure that the political dispute in democracy runs as it should proceed.” We already know this from history. Isn't that threatening?

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr President! Mr Vice-President Timmermans! Concern for the state of law, democracy and human rights should always accompany us and concern each state, regardless of what government is in that state. I am a Polish MP and I know that three quarters of Poles support the Union — a peaceful, open, solidarity community. I know that Poles do not deserve to be doubted in their faith and hopes placed in the community. And it is not true that Poles are turning away from the Union, as Mr Kamal said; he is wrong. Poles, on the other hand, have the right to live in a democratic state, observing civil liberties, maintaining continuity. They are entitled to enjoy a sense of pride in history. They have the right to live in a state where collective responsibility does not apply, in which the law does not work backwards, in which independent courts and social organizations operate. Consideration, moderation, dialogue and responsibility are our duty. And the governing, and the opposition.

name: Anders Primdahl Vistisen (ECR).
text: - Mr President! Time and again we need to have the debate here, in this chamber, around Poland, around Hungary and around other countries. Every time the majority in this house is overruled in nation states, in elections where you choose a more EU-critical, more EU-realistic position, then you think you need to make yourself chief judges of how a country's democratic government should act and act in the country where it has won an election. It's shameful! And it is even more shameful when it is so evident that the only thing driving the majority of this house in the witch-hunt taking place against Poland is that you are politically disagreeing with the government that was democratically elected by the Polish people a small year ago. And it's so evident when e.g. The ALDE Group has just held congress in Warsaw, at the subsequent meeting here by President Guy Verhofstadt decides to propose again taking such a round of Poland-bashing on the House agenda, which is quite clearly in the context of the fact that you are trying to take yet a Polish opposition party into your own group. Or when Commissioner Timmermans chooses — instead of engaging in a dialogue with the Polish Government, which has responded again and again once the Commission has approached — to bypass the government, to bypass the official channels and address the Polish people directly in a hateful tone towards their own government in a newspaper; instead of, as any responsible Commission should do, to take the dialogue with the government now once elected and represents Poland in the Council. And that is why I have to say to the Commission: once again you have proved that you are acting politically! You're not capable officials! You are not defenders of the Treaty! You are political tools for your own political agenda against a democratically elected government, and that is not acceptable — either against Poland or against any other country in the EU!

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President! Poland is a great country and without Poland, Europe would be a torso. That is why developments in this country are of European importance, particularly as regards the rule of law. Our discussion is not interfering with national sovereignty. Poland finally agreed to the Copenhagen criteria upon its accession. We are concerned that the constitutional crisis has still not been resolved, indeed that the situation is becoming more dramatic from week to week. Poland does not need legal anarchy. Poland needs an independent constitutional court. This is important in these turbulent times in the country. It is a worrying development how the whole thing draws into a spiral. There is still time for the Polish Government to move towards the opposition and take the recommendations of the Venice Commission seriously. A divided Poland is not only detriing Europe, but a divided Poland is particularly damaging Poland itself. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE)
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. — Mr. Weidenholzer, I know that you are very interested in what is happening in Poland, and you are following this, and you are probably seeing that the government, through the so-called national media, is notoriously insulting those who are fighting for the right and for freedom in Poland. I would like to ask you: If you could directly address those who were on the streets yesterday to defend the rule of law, what would you say to them?

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — I would like to say to these people that we are very grateful to them for feeling Europeans, that we live in a common house of Europe and that we want to shape this common house according to democratic principles of the rule of law.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne Kaufmann (S&D).
text: Mr President, Vice-President Timmermanns. The German-Polish Neighbourhood Treaty has turned 25 this year. A reason to celebrate, because our two countries have never been so closely connected. I am particularly pleased that so many Germans and Poles are committed to bring this treaty to life. For this very reason, however, I am deeply concerned about the action of the Polish Government with regard to the rule of law and democracy. What is also worrying is how the restructuring of the country is being driven by the replacement of offices and positions in the media, culture or administration. These most worrying events have recently reached my hometown of Berlin. There people are stunned by the surprising dismissal of the meritorious director of the Polish Cultural Institute, and on the outrageous justification that she has dealt excessively with Polish-Jewish issues. There is rightly a lot of protest against this. It is to be hoped that the Polish Government will no longer close itself to criticism of its governance, including in the interests of Poland's future role in Europe.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President, this is an absolutely necessary debate and that is why it is sad and revealing that you have had at times grotesque moments: when arguments ranging from the defence of freedom or sovereignty are invoked to cover up the inability to understand that being a Member State of the European Union entails obligations and that, therefore, it concerns this European Parliament to worry about the 40 million Poles, including the 34% who voted on the Government currently in power when it unilaterally restricts pluralism; when it shrinkens the area of democracy; when it unilaterally reforms the Constitutional Court; when it changes the rules of the game without subject them to consensus; when the basic understanding that this is a club of rules, obligations, which also concern Poland as a Member State. That is why this is not an attack on Poland, it is a claim that this is the house of freedom, fundamental rights, defence of the rule of law, and that goes to you too, gentlemen of the Polish right.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr President! I have the privilege to represent a party that had nothing to do with, or when you were in charge, last June, a dispute over the Constitutional Court from your illegal actions, or then the escalation of this dispute, but I know one thing: this is not about the Court, neither for treaties nor least for human rights. For if this were about human rights, Mr Timmermans would have been reacting for days to come to the public with what we hear from France about a law that is to close our mouths to portals in defence of the lives of the unborn. If this was about the Constitutional Court and Constitutional Democracy in Poland, President Timmermans would remind all these abortion enthusiasts that in Poland, the protection of life from conception is part of the constitutional order established by the Constitutional Court by the 1997 ruling year, confirmed by the 2003 ruling, confirmed by last year's ruling by the Court, whose composition no one disputed. If it were about the Constitutional Court. But this is just about attacking my country.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr. President! Honourable Members, I am a Hungarian Member, and in our history it was that Poland and Hungary went hand in hand and followed each other. Where first something happened in Poland, then later in Hungary, first in Hungary and later in Poland. The Hungarian and Polish people are in good friendship. However, I must see that everything that we have seen or seen in Poland has unfortunately happened much earlier in Hungary. The fact that the government, the Hungarian government, has been inciting on billboards for a year, literally inciting refugees, and at all, if I confine myself to the subject of the Istanbul Convention, I must say that Hungary also seems to be flanking out of the Istanbul Convention. Ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to raise the responsibility of those who, in particular, think of the People's Party, are sitting in their ranks because FIDÉSZ — the Hungarian government party — have tolerated what now unfortunately seems to be sweeping across the continent for many months.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: — Mr. President, I will not talk about the Constitutional Court, I will not talk about the Istanbul Convention, nor will I talk about the right to gather. I will only tell you, dear friends, that as a young man in '81 I took a train from Croatia to Warsaw, I went to Gdansk to look for you, look for your friends from Solidarnośći. I sang in the cathedral in Gdansk your songs because I believed you, because I believed because Poland was in my heart and in Croatia we sang Poland in my heart and our heart was full. But my heart today, dear friends, is empty and sad. When I watch you laugh at us here, you remind me of those worst communists who laughed and believed they would be eternal. There are none, and I believe your politics will disappear as well.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: - Mr President! I will quote Mr Legutka's statements because he perfectly illustrated the behaviour of the current Government of Law and Justice. You do not listen to other rations, you do not listen to another side, you do not allow others to speak, you antagonize society, you produce enemies at a rapid pace, I will add from yourself — and in Poland, and abroad. You have two enemies: ignorance and prejudice — hubris always steps before falling. True, and I hope there will be the collapse of the PiS government. Your democracy is about defending the prosecutor of martial law, not defending those who fought for that freedom and served time in prisons. To Mr. Kamall: actually PiS won in a democratic way, but the Poles did not give a democratic mandate to violate the constitution and restrict freedoms. And to Poles: dear, I have not heard anyone criticizing Poland and Poles in this House. It is always proudly spoken of our achievements — there is criticism of the Law and Justice government!

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: — Mr President, on 1 October thousands of Polish women were on the streets, not to support the Kaczyński Government, but to say that they had doubts about the protection of their physical integrity, because this Government wanted to take steps to withdraw protection from their physical integrity within the framework of the new abortion laws. It is our duty, as European elected representatives, to defend these Polish women who demand that they be defended in their physical integrity. That is what we are doing today, you are not the ones who defend Polish women, we are the ones who defend Polish women. I also ask the Commission to be able to integrate this gender issue when we talk about fundamental rights, because even if you are women, we also have the right to European fundamental rights.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to this debate. Please let me make a few points.  First of all, after the painful experiences of the first half of the last century, the free part of Europe – those of us who were lucky enough to end up on the right side of the Iron Curtain – immediately understood, inspired by Winston Churchill – and I am saddened by the fact that Mr Kamall, who made such horrible allegations, has left so I can’t answer him personally – what Churchill brought to the table, which was this: we have seen that it is possible to use democracy against the rule of law simply by saying, ‘I have a majority, therefore I dictate what the rule of law is’. That is why the Council of Europe, which was created before this institution, always said that, in a democracy, you accept the limits on democratic action which are set by the rule of law, which is controlled by a completely independent judiciary. That is the very foundation of democracy in Europe after very, very painful experiences in our common history. As soon as the Iron Curtain fell and the Polish people had fought for their liberty and obtained their liberty, they immediately subscribed to that principle and wanted to join the Council of Europe as soon as possible and, as a follow-up to that, also the European Union.  The fundamental principle is that you respect the rule of law, you respect human rights and you respect democracy, but you don’t use one against the other. There is a balance between the three that is essential for the European Union – for Europe – to remain free. I cannot understand that some people would use the word ‘freedom’ to fight the very concept of the rule of law on the basis of a democratic majority. The strength of democracy is based on the fact that those who have the majority respect the limits that the rule of law places upon them. This is the context within which we work and I am saddened by the fact that, with all the propositions we have made from our side for a dialogue with the Polish Government, we see exactly the same thing again here today in this Chamber. Mr Legutko took eight minutes not to go into the three points that we have put on the table with the Polish Government. What did he say about not publishing the rulings of the Constitutional Tribunal? Nothing.  If you respect the division of powers and if you respect the independence of the judiciary, you cannot as a government pick and choose which rulings of a Constitutional Tribunal you like and only publish those you like. You cannot do that. That is in violation of the Polish Constitution. You cannot ignore the vote in a parliament to elect judges to the Constitutional Tribunal simply because you do not like the composition of that previous parliament. When judges are lawfully elected, they should be sworn in by the President of the Republic. That is in line with the Constitution. You cannot introduce ways of operating the Tribunal that are clearly in violation of the Constitution. The arbitrator there is the Constitutional Tribunal, so the least you should do is submit these draft laws or laws to the Constitutional Tribunal and then accept the judgment of that Constitutional Tribunal. That’s the whole point of respecting the rule of law.  Also in political terms, I have already said something about some people here using freedom against this very principle. This is not the Commission of others looking at Poland. I am also a Polish Commissioner. I feel a responsibility for the Polish people. I feel a responsibility for the rule of law, all across the European Union. I can tell you, on a personal note, that I might not even been alive had my family, my father not been liberated in 1944 by Polish soldiers who offered their lives for our collective freedom. So I feel a huge debt of gratitude towards the Polish people, a personal debt of gratitude which compels me to insist on these points and to continue on these points. These men who freed us never saw freedom themselves, but their children and grandchildren are living in a free, strong and independent Poland. Poland has never been as independent as it is today as a full-fledged member of NATO and the European Union. This is something I cherish. This is one of the greatest achievements of European history. So please be aware. It is not only in Poland. I see it in many countries: nationalists and ultranationalists attacking judges everywhere in a personal way, attacking the judiciary, and ignoring the rulings of judges. This should be a warning to all of us, not just in Poland. We see it all across the European Union in some states: personal attacks discrediting the so—called elites. Who are these elites attacking the freedom of the press? I am not saying it is happening in Poland, but I am saying that it is a European phenomenon we should be aware of. Freedom is what so many people fought for. The European Union, based on the rule of law, democracy and respect for human rights is the concrete expression of the will of freedom, of 500 million Europeans. That is why I believe that these institutions – the European Parliament and the Commission – have a responsibility, where we can, to help 500 million Europeans in the expression of their freedom. For that, we need an independent judiciary in every single Member State, we need full respect of the separation of powers, which is an essential element of our freedom, and we need the possibility to debate and discuss. Because another element I warn about is portraying your adversaries as enemies. We are political opponents sometimes and we have a political debate. With your adversary you have a debate; your enemy you want to destroy or ignore. In a democracy there are no enemies, there are adversaries. That is how this Parliament operates, that is how the Commission wants to operate, and that is what we need to defend for our children and grandchildren and for our collective future: a Europe whole and free, based on democracy, the rule of law and human rights.  (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the Commission's approach. The principle of the separation of powers must not be circumvented. It is the cornerstone of European democracy. I hope that the Polish Government will soon be given a refuge, so we do not have to have a fifth debate here in this House!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission recommendation on the implementation of the EU-Turkey statement and on the reintroduction of transfers under the Dublin Regulation (2016/3036 (RSP)).

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for scheduling this debate today on two key elements in our European Agenda on migration: the implementation of the EU-Turkish statement, and our last recommendation to gradually apply the Dublin rules in Greece. Let me first point out that, while these are two important elements in our comprehensive migration approach, they are not the only ones. Secondly, all our policies are interconnected, and the progress we have achieved so far – and all our reports from last week demonstrate this – is precisely because we have made progress on many fronts, not just one. From relocation and resettlement to returns, to improving reception conditions, to fighting smuggling, and indeed to cooperating with all important partner countries. All of these matter. This is why it is so important to sustain and deepen the progress that we have made so far.  We are not where we were one year ago, but the situation remains fragile. Now is not the moment to become complacent. Let me therefore start by emphasising that the EU-Turkey Statement continues to work and bear results. Fewer people are crossing the Aegean Sea – around 90 persons per day – and fewer people have lost their lives trying to do so. In parallel, more than 2 600 Syria refugees have been resettled from Turkey to the European Union since the entry into force of the Statement, and this pace continues to pick up. The main challenge is that the number of returns since September continues to be low, even if the Greek asylum service has doubled the number of experts working on the islands. Additional experts are expected to be recruited by the end of this year. Indeed, since the previous report at end of September 2016, 170 persons who went to Greece through Turkey have been returned to Turkey in the framework of the EU-Turkish Statement, including 42 Syrians. This brings the total number of migrants returned to Turkey since the EU-Turkey Statement to 777. In total, 1 960 irregular migrants were returned from Greece to Turkey in the course of 2016 under the EU-Turkish Statement or the Greek-Turkey Bilateral Readmission Protocol, and 95 of those were Syrians.  Further efforts and support are needed, in particular additional Member State experts through the European Asylum Support Office. The processing of asylum applications needs to speed up, and the number of returns of those who have no right to stay needs to increase. But there are more elements to the EU-Turkey Statement, and you know that. Both parties are fully committed to implementing and delivering on all.  The Commission has accelerated the implementation of funding through the Facility for Refugees in Turkey for humanitarian and for non-humanitarian purposes, with a view to addressing the most critical needs of Syrian refugees and host communities in Turkey. These funds are now starting to have a direct impact on the ground. On visa liberalisation, the Commission and Turkey are continuously engaged in committed dialogue to find solutions to all outstanding benchmarks. To conclude, the implementation of the EU-Turkey Statement continues to deliver results, despite challenging circumstances. The Commission will continue to drive this work forward and will present its fifth report on the progress made in early March 2017.  On the recommendation of the resumption of Dublin transfers to Greece, let me begin by repeating once again – and I want to be very clear on this – that no single Member State should bear the burden of the refugee crisis alone. No Member State in the future should be left alone to endure an unsustainable burden. Significant progress has been achieved in Greece to put in place a fully functioning asylum system over the last months and years under very pressing and difficult circumstances. We should all praise and commend Greece for this, and we should continue to support Greece. Greece is also facing huge challenges in implementing the EU-Turkish Statement. The number of asylum applications has multiplied by four during the course of this year. This why we have recommended a gradual resumption of Dublin transfers of asylum seekers, starting as of 15 March 2017, in order to reach a balance between the burden the country still has to face and returning Greece back to the Dublin system. But let me be clear on this: the Commission did not decide to send refugees or migrants back to Greece. What we recommended to Member States is a gradual return to the application of the rules. Greece’s progress, despite the exceptional situation, has been recognised by the fact that we proposed a gradual resumption as of mid-March 2017 meaning for migrants that will enter Europe through Greece after that date only and might try to move irregularly towards other Member States. But even then, it will concern only certain categories and it will presuppose individual guarantees for the transfer of its migrants which Greece should be in a position to provide.  We recommend that every time a Member State wants to execute a Dublin transfer, they should only do so after having received individual assurances from the Greek authorities that its particular applicant will be received in the conditions mandated by European law. Sending the message that rules have started to apply will encourage relocation efforts by showing Member States that Greece is respecting its legal obligations to take back asylum seekers who have absconded.  Relocation will only work if other Member States do their part in picking up the pace of relocation and deploying national experts. In addition to that, asylum seekers need to know that they cannot relocate themselves, and that if they do so, they will be sent back and cannot benefit from relocation. It goes without saying that the Commission will constantly monitor the situation and update its recommendation if necessary. The ultimate responsibility for resuming transfers lies, of course, with the Member States, and their national courts.  Returning to a fully functioning Dublin system is a key element in restoring the normal functioning of the Schengen area. As you know, secondary movements of asylum seekers from Greece have been one of the reasons for the reintroduction of internal border controls. The resumption of transfers, coupled with the fact that Greece has reinforced the control at its northern border, is important to move in this direction.  In parallel, we pursued together with you the priority of finalising the negotiations of the reform of the Dublin system based on a fairness mechanism which also relies on the effective carrying out of Dublin transfers.  As I said at the beginning, all these elements go hand in hand. This is also why the Commission called last week on Member States to sustain the good progress in terms of relocation and to ensure at least 2 000 relocations per month from Greece and 1 000 from Italy from this month onwards. And the Commission is doing everything to support all Member States to the maximum – and in particular the frontline Member States – to effectively address not only the immediate, but also the long-term challenges of migration, and to turn them into opportunities. But for all elements to go hand in hand, we need many hands. It is absolutely critical that all actors and stakeholders, all Member States, EU agencies, civil society organisations as well as you, honourable Members, take up their fair share of their responsibility. Our work is not over yet.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the EU-Turkey declaration agreement significantly reduced the flow of refugees and migrants from the coast of Turkey. However, lately we have on average arrivals of about a hundred people every day. It should be noted that in the islands of the North-East Aegean, sixteen and a half thousand people are currently hosted in places of capacity less than half, living in difficult conditions, while throughout the country there are more than sixty-five thousand, with enormous responsibilities, I stress, of today's government of Greece, which goes without a plan, creating deadlocks. It goes without saying that tensions and incidents are causing, which test the strength of Greek society. The relocation of refugees to the Member States is working, but slowly, as are the returns of irregular migrants to Turkey. The agreement is being respected but with problems, so that Greece is unable to accept more foreigners and provide them with decent living conditions, bearing in mind that hundreds of thousands of my fellow citizens are already living below the poverty line, due to the recession in which the country is for the seventh consecutive year. Given these facts, if, if, by God, asylum seekers are now returned to Greece under Dublin, they are certain that they will create complete suffocation and an explosive situation that will not be manageable. The clarifications you have given today, Commissioner, were very important. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), blue-card question. — Mrs Wozeberg, you spoke of the responsibility of the Greek Government. It is the responsibility of the Greek Government that the relocations of supposedly two thousand people per month are actually carried out in a multiplicity number or is it the responsibility of the Greek Government that, while the other Member States have promised one hundred experts and one hundred interpreters from the European Asylum Service, in fact 36 are currently in Greece.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (
text: PPE), answer to a question with a blue card. — Thank you for the question. Mr President, there is no doubt that the responsibilities of the European Union for the malfunction that you have pointed out have been pointed out by us, but it is the responsibility of the Greek Government that in October 2015 it accepted that our country has the capacity to accommodate 50,000 people, 20,000 of them with rent subsidy, while there were no infrastructure then, as they do not yet exist, under the sole responsibility of the government that governs the country.

name: Sylvie Guillaume
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, we have debated this famous EU-Turkey statement on many occasions, but what is the opinion of Parliament and what is the outcome of this declaration? The European Union is sending Syrians back to Turkey, where the human rights situation is deteriorating from day to day. Of course, migration pressure on Greece had to be lowered. But was there, sincerely, no alternative but to return these refugees to a country plagued by such a situation? To be clear, I am not against cooperation with third States, which is an essential instrument of a comprehensive and effective European migration policy, but that cannot mean the outsourcing of that same policy. It is clear that agreements continue to be reached in this direction, as with Afghanistan, Pakistan and Mali. We must tackle the root causes of migration. This is probably the most important thing and it must be done through our external action, with full respect for the values of the Union. It would be totally harmful if this approach was conditional, between humanitarian action and border protection. Finally, I would like to express my complete misunderstanding of the desire to re-establish transfers of asylum seekers under the Dublin Regulation, when, for example, the ECHR had already condemned Belgium a few years ago. I think that is not the right track and that the situation really needs to be improved considerably before these transfers can be resumed.

name: Jussi Halla-aho
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, migrants arrive in Greece and Italy not because they want to stay there but because via those countries they can easily move to Western and Northern Europe. As long as this is the case, more people will come. Therefore, it is vitally important to make it clear to irregular migrants that if you come to Greece or Italy, that is as far as you will get. If you go elsewhere, you will be returned. This is the only way to discourage irregular migration and this is why we need the Dublin system and Dublin transfers.  Irregular arrivals in the Eastern Mediterranean have come down by 70% from last year’s figures, mainly thank to the closing of the Balkan road and the EU-Turkey statement. Nevertheless, I find it deeply irresponsible that we outsource the dirty work to a country like Turkey. We must have the courage and the will to protect our own external borders. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL), blue card question. — Correctly point out the need to assume our responsibilities. Can you comment on the extremely slow implementation of the refugee relocation programme within the European Union? It is found, according to the Guardian, at a total of 5%. Hungary and Poland have not accepted a single refugee, Slovakia 9 and the Czech Republic 12. Do you think it fair that these countries receive European funds for their farmers and their infrastructure and deny their European obligations in the refugee case?

name: Jussi Halla-aho (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. If you are referring to relocation plans, I do not believe that relocation is the solution to our problem. It is my opinion that we must drastically reduce the absolute number of people, irregular economic migrants, who are arriving in Europe. And one way to discourage such movement, as I said, is to make it clear to the irregular migrants that if they come to Greece or Italy, that is as far as they will get.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as we are discussing here in the plenary today, desperate calls for help from people in Aleppo are reaching us. Men, women and children are being slaughtered by the barbarous forces of the Syrian dictator Assad and his Russian and Iranian henchmen. The lack of response from Europe is a failure as such, and I am convinced that the judgment on all of us will be harsh in the future.  On the issue of migration, I am afraid we are not performing much better. The so called EU-Turkey statement was entered into bilaterally between Member States and Turkey, explicitly designed to circumvent this Parliament’s legal rights to consent, or not, to international agreements. Basically, the agreement is to hand over EUR 6 billion of taxpayers’ money to the autocratic ruler Erdoğan, not on the basis of international law or any formal agreement, but on a joint press release.  Recently, I have heard different Member States suggesting concluding similar agreements with countries like Libya, Tunisia, and even exploring (like Australia, by the way) absurd ideas such as external processing centres in these countries. I wonder, Commissioner, if the Commission today can put an end to such ideas once and for all, and instead focus on the challenges that we are facing together. In other words, concluding the legislation that lies before us on the common European asylum system that must be resilient and stand the test wherever pressure is met in Europe. Because it is in the absence of a functioning EU policy that this Union has outsourced its own responsibility to the autocratic Erdoğan regime. I will come back to the Greece situation later. Greece is something very close to my heart and I will discuss that with you on a different occasion.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, your recommendations have something disconcerting to me. Yourself, not just Amnesty International, say that reception in the Aegean islands and mainland does not work, that unaccompanied minors and vulnerable people are still detained, but recommended the return to Greece of refugees from March 2017, given the many progress. You admit that the islands are overcrowded and ask to crowd them more. Please mention the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights against such transfers, even gradual ones, and forget them on the street. No less puzzling is the action plan on the European Union and Turkey. It is established by now that Turkey is not a safe country. Even so, you want more returns, family reunifications managed in Turkey and feel free to recommend deportations of the most vulnerable. The Greek government is even asking to rewrite laws banning such returns. I ask the Commission what drives it to be strong when it is proving that only in power is it entirely incapable of relocating refugees as promised, ignores the economic misery imposed on Greece, unless he wants to fake himself strong like that, eradicating human rights.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, yesterday in this Parliament we heard from the two amazing Sakharov Prize winners, the young Yazidi women who had escaped Daesh. They described the situation of the first refugee camp they came to in Iraqi Kurdistan: overcrowded, unsanitary, lacking privacy, cold and insecure, and lacking medical care. They could have been describing many of the camps or reception centres, especially on the islands in Greece. They said: we look up to Europe as a symbol of humanity. Well, we are really failing at the moment. If it were not for local people in many of these places, themselves often in dire need, the situation would be even worse.  So how soon do we really believe that we are going to have adequate facilities in Greece on the islands? Should we not be immediately transferring asylum seekers, particularly those who are vulnerable, to mainland Greece, ensuring they are adequately protected and also stepping up the relocation process?  As others have said: the lack of will from some Member States is pitiful. We should not be congratulating ourselves on the EU-Turkey deal. We have no wish to see it as a stable and sustainable pillar of EU policy in its current state. When we are looking at questions about returns, we should also remember that 87% of those deemed irregular migrants actually come from the top ten refugee-producing countries of the world. So please, let us think about the solidarity and humanity.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Vice-President Timmermans recently said - and I quote: 'Our comprehensive approach to migration is bearing fruit'. That's right. The EU approach is bearing fruit, but it is very wrisome: rapes, assaults, robberies and murders by illegal immigrants. And you look away from all these horrors. Because if things are going so well, why should 21 100 officers and security officers be deployed in Cologne to prevent another wave of sexual assault by young illegal immigrants during New Year's Eve? Then why are soldiers walking through the streets of European cities in the fight against Islamic terrorists who have entered Europe through the asylum stream you facilitated? Stop looking away. Let's do what people at home ask for. Let the Member States themselves go beyond their own borders in order to protect their country, to put things in order. We do not need Brussels and Mr Timmermans to do that. For Mr Timmermans and his companions can order champagne in fourteen languages; they do not understand the will of the ordinary man in any language.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). — Mr President, the Commission, through the Commissioner responsible, proposes the return of refugees to Greece. The proposal concerns refugees who will be found illegally in another Member State and not the huge number of illegal immigrants. Until now we have known about illegal immigrants; we have now learned of the existence of illegal refugees. With the memorandum, institutions and Greek governments made Greece a country discredited, deserted and impoverished economically, socially and labor. Now they're going to turn it into a country where illegal refugees and illegal immigrants will be crowded, to borrow a popular Greek expression. After that, I wonder if there's a hint of shame, integrity, dignity. Will the Commissioner responsible resign? Will there be a confession from the President of the Commission and the leaders of the countries that the agreement with Erdogan was a huge mistake? I am a realist and I do not expect such a demonstration of self-criticism and self-assessment from politicians who congratulate and applaud each other when their only achievement is the impoverishment and dechristianisation of peoples. All I expect is that the peoples of Europe will finally come out of their slumber and choose by nationalist criteria those who represent them in the European institutions.

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: A functioning Dublin is essential for a functioning Schengen, and I fully agree with the Commissioner on that. And if the situation in Greece allows, it is also very desirable to resume the Dublin rules on return to Greece. On the other hand, I strongly wonder whether the wish here is not the father of the thought. I read in the recommendation of the European Commission itself, among other things: 'There are 16 000 refugees on the islands, while there is only room for 8 000, and there is a waiting list of 1 200 unaccompanied minors in the area of adequate care. Many of the reception facilities in Greece are substandard. The hotspots are short in terms of sanitation and hygiene.” For example, I can continue for a while with the findings from the European Commission's communication. The question is therefore to the European Commission: how realistic is it that in three months' time we will have a situation in Greece where we can actually send people back to Greece? A second point that the Commission has rightly pointed out here: the redistribution of refugees from Greece to other Member States is still going very slowly. Tens of thousands of refugees are waiting on mainland Greece. Solidarity is also an essential prerequisite for maintaining a functioning Dublin system in Europe in the current circumstances. My question to the European Commission is: would it be possible at all for us to apply the resumption of Dublin rules on return to Greece only to those countries that have already fulfilled a significant part of their quota for redistributing refugees?

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the decision to resume Dublin transfers to Greece is a countersense when relocations are at 5%. In April, Commissioner, you said that the old Dublin system was dead. Vice President Timmermans even discomfort Game of Thrones, saying he was as dead as John Snow. I wonder if he's part of the scriptwriters and knew the old Dublin would immediately be resurrected. In Greece there are still 16 000 people on the islands in inadequate conditions. What is the success of the EU-Turkey deal? To have moved the suffering of asylum seekers farther from our borders? The images of Aleppo recount that the reasons for escaping are more alive than ever before. It would be time to implement infringement procedures towards those who are not doing the promised relocation and instead calls on Greece to increase returns, including of minors and vulnerable people. Parliament called for overcoming Dublin, exceeding the criterion of the first access country, towards equitable sharing of responsibilities between Member States and the Council instead of debating the already weak Commission proposal discusses imaginative proposals on flexible solidarity to avoid all obligations. That is not the way, Commissioner.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: Mr President! The Commission has discussed the first successes of an alleged comprehensive European approach to migration. I think that, to put it cautiously, is very daring, because for a comprehensive approach we would first have to define what the EU really wants. Do we want unlimited access? Do we want access with a ceiling? How many migrants will be taken in then? And what concrete are we supposed to do at the EU's external borders? What, for example, would we do if ten thousand people showed up at the external borders tomorrow, where will they be taken? All these questions are not asked and certainly not answered. Against this background, I think it is a mockery to praise as a great success, for example, the relocation of a total of 1 187 people from Greece to Turkey, which has been returned there. In my opinion, this is nothing more and no less than a loss of reality. The EU has no control over this situation.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, nine months have passed since the European Union signed the agreement with Turkey. I think this is a good time to take stock. Number of people killed in the Mediterranean this year: 4,700, about 1,000 more than last year; and closing the Aegean route means that they are forced to take more deadly routes, such as that of the central Mediterranean. Resettled from Turkey: 2 600 Commissioner, more people killed than resettled. At the same time, in Turkey the massacre of the Kurdish people is increasing and repression is increasing: 120 journalists are imprisoned, 4,000 political prisoners in Turkish prisons. If the aim of the agreement was to have a contract with Turkey to act as an agency for the deportation of immigrant refugees and Europe, in return, to keep up against human rights violations, I think that the balance is very positive. Congratulations, Commissioner, you have achieved the objective.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I think the recommendation of the Commission to start sending people back to Greece is wrong. We really should not do that. I think it does not make sense to send the relocation refugees one way, and then the other way you send other refugees back to Greece. We should really do relocation first.  I know we can count on your support there, Commissioner, and the Member States have to finally understand that they really need to do that. But we need to do that first, and also we need first to improve the situation in the camps in Greece, because currently it is horrendous. Improvements are happening, but they have been too slow and, let us say, not exactly at a very high level.  We should not send people back into destitution. We need to have that European solidarity that many colleagues have been mentioning. I really hope the Council will say something about that, because it is the problem of the Member States. We are talking to you here, Commissioner, but it is actually the Member States who are the main problem in this issue.
