You will have the support of Parliament to address that issue, but at the same time I am asking the Commission not to recommend sending people back to Greece.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President! The alleged stroke of genius to solve the refugee crisis envisages bringing rejected refugees from Greece to Turkey and recognised asylum seekers to Greece. But this is not a solution, but only a problem shift. I do not know of any sovereign country that has passed here and authorised another country to decide who is eligible for asylum. The Union is obviously doing so because we do not want to control and protect borders on its own. Assignment of border management to Turkey is, of course, also an escape from responsibility: EUR 3 billion and visa exemption for it, and all this with a ridiculous return rate. You yourself, Commissioner, have mentioned the example: some 578 returns since June, which is ridiculous just under 4% of those who are being brought to Greece. Ultimately, the deal has only two reasons: on the one hand, to cover up the catastrophic welcome culture and on the other hand, Mrs Merkel's political survival.

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: — The migrant crisis facing Europe requires a show of solidarity with the countries most affected by the migration influx, such as Bulgaria and Greece, and new measures to address it. Such a new measure is the EU-Turkey agreement. It has managed to reduce the refugee flow to Europe, but in order for it to be truly successful, all parties must respect it and cooperate. At the same time, European asylum legislation requires radical change because it does not work as it stands. The gradual resumption of the return of applicants for international protection to Greece can be considered an apparent sign of a functioning European asylum system, but in no case should countries such as Bulgaria and Greece become large refugee centres under periphery of the European Union. This will only be done by removing the principle that the primary responsibility for migrants falls on the countries of first entry. It is time for the principle of genuine European solidarity to be enshrined in European legislation!

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S& D). — Mr President, Commissioner, are we talking about returns to Greece due to Dublin? Immigrants who fall under Turkey's agreement and will therefore be transferred there? I couldn't agree more. Agreements must be respected in full. So what does the Council and the Commission promise? Four hundred EAS officials should go to the Greek islands to speed up asylum applications. Right now we have 46! Then 63 000 refugees to relocate to the other Member States. At the moment, 6,300 have been relocated! Once these two steps have been completed, Member States will have kept their promises and Greece will have the conditions imposed by the law to be consistent with Dublin and will do so. Finally, they must maintain in every way the agreement with Turkey, which reduced the flow to deaths and provides better living conditions for Syrians in Turkey. To this end, I would suggest that the Council, which is meeting tomorrow, reject Parliament's proposal to freeze negotiations and keep all channels open. Let's not kill the deal!

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the news that Dublin transfers to Greece will resume from March and that there has been a reduction in attempts to cross the Aegean Sea. This sends a positive signal that the system can work, under the rules will be adhered to fairly. Every effort should be made to save lives, create stability in conflict regions, and assist Member States overwhelmed by the challenges they face. But many in this Parliament still believe that the solution lies in more forms of legal migration and binding quotas. I cannot support any relocation scheme that forces Member States to take an allotted number of persons. Any discussion of sanctions against Member States can only weaken European cooperation and spread resentment. Instead, Member States need to continue to commit more resources and aid to countries in the Middle East. We need efficient asylum processing and expedient returns. The one-for-one approach of the EU-Turkey deal is neither a sustainable nor fair solution. Instead, we need to work towards effective and fair cooperation with third countries.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I do not want to talk about Turkey or Greece, but about Niger. Today, the European Commission proudly presented figures showing that the number of people, migrants moving through Niger and going to Europe, has fallen dramatically. The figures used by the Commission come from Aeon. But they themselves say that they have doubts about their figures, that refugees have probably chosen different routes, and that prices for smugglers are apparently rising. That reflects badly on the refugees. The European Commissioner says that everything is connected with everything. That's right: everything is connected to everything. More border guards paid and trained across Europe, higher prices for smugglers, more difficult and dangerous routes for refugees and, on top of that, more people drowned in the Mediterranean last November because we do not have legal routes. Congratulations!

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I believe that the Commission's path is the only realistic one. Many wishes can be expressed here, but we have over 70 million refugees, and we have many of them to people who are migrants. That is, believing that you can solve the problem by opening doors on your own simply does not make sense. This means that we need a strategy together with states such as Turkey, we also need a strategy together with Egypt, Libya, Tunisia and also with states within the African continent, in order to find solutions for more people who are not only to come to us through traffickers and a lot of money. Ultimately, the humanitarian criteria must be decisive, and we must try to eliminate the causes of flight or to find solutions on the ground so that not so many people have to flee. We must be realistic here and not encourage visions and dreams that end up causing fears among our own people.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: According to Commissioner Avramopoulos, European countries can return refugees to Greece in the short term. I think this is a bizarre statement because a lot of people have been stuck in terrible circumstances for months now. On the mainland, housing is far from being in order and the situation on the islands is even more harrowing. Refugees are even at risk in the reception camps. For example, in hotspot Moria, a mother with her children was recently killed by the use of dangerous gas cylinders that are in circulation there. In addition, refugees are at risk due to the increased tensions between different groups of asylum seekers. Therefore, I think it is important that we remove the most vulnerable refugees from Greece and provide them with shelter in one of the other European Member States. It is not realistic to say that the Greek asylum system is working well enough to send refugees back there. The EU must stop making promises that it cannot deliver. Ultimately, that only helps the populists in hand and not the refugees.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — (EL) Mr President, Mr Avramopoulos, you know that Greece cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants. What measures will you take to relieve the congestion of the Aegean islands, where more than 16,500 refugees have been trapped? Are the government's announcements that the Commission is not allowing them to be transported to mainland Greece, because this is prohibited, as the government says, by the EU-Turkey agreement? Returns to Greece under Dublin III will not be accepted by the Greek people. We point out, as you know, that the return procedure is a matter for the Member States. That is why I ask you: Is Germany committed to non-return on the basis of Dublin of refugees who have passed through Greece in 2015 and 2016? Because that's not what the German Minister of the Interior, Mr de Maizier, says. What is needed is not returns through Dublin either now or in the future, but they need relocations, since only 5 700 refugees have been relocated from Greece to other European Union states of the 66,400.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Mr President, Commissioner, I have just one question: Mrs Mogherini recently before the Committee on Foreign Affairs said that the Commission and its Office are working on alternatives to the question of the European Union's agreement with Turkey, stating that she referred to possible new agreements with other states in the region, which will be financed, to draw refugees either from Turkey or if there is hope a new wave of refugees. My question is whether there are specific such studies and with which countries and with what funding?

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). — Mr President, your own decisions state this clearly: the secondary movement of refugees is prohibited. That is why the European Union and the Greek Government are holding thousands of appeals in the middle of winter in the wretched hot spots on the Greek islands, bound by the unacceptable agreement between the European Union and Turkey. You are now calling for an improvement in the conditions for hosting refugees in Greece and reactivating the reactionary Dublin by returning refugees from other Member States to Greece. Not only that; at the request of the Syriza-ANEL government, you are sending reinforced Euroborder guard forces to Greece's borders with FYROM and Albania, so that the Balkan corridor will remain closed to the uprooted victims of your own imperialist wars. The European Union and the government are accountable, because the results of their policy feed the poisonous propaganda of the fascists, who are starring in provocations aimed at turning islanders against the victims of the imperialist wars and choices of the European Union. Now to evacuate refugees from the Greek islands! Human hospitality conditions! Direct transport to the countries they have chosen!

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Mr President, the number of refugees arriving in Greece may have decreased, but arrivals in Italy have increased and the list of refugees drowning in the sea is growing. Then the refugees you are sending back on the basis of the unacceptable agreement made with Turkey not only do not receive any support but become victims for the second time. Turkey sends them to Syria, brings them back to the sea or tolerates them, without even securing their basic needs for housing and food. That is the tragic reality. These are the results of an unacceptable agreement you have made with Turkey. Rather than abolish Dublin, bring it back more strongly, so that states such as Greece that are receiving the biggest waves of refugees are more burdened. Despite promises to relocate 160,000 refugees, only 8,000 refugees have been relocated from Greece and Italy. Commissioner, unless all states show concrete solidarity immediately, the refugee crisis will continue to increase and innocent lives will continue to be lost at the responsibility of the European Union.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). — (GR) Mr President, Commissioner, the problem is the implementation of your own decisions. Only in this way can the European deficit of solidarity towards the people of Greece and the people of Italy be tackled. Implementation of the relocation programme is limited to 5%, according to official data, and for Greece out of 63,000 were relocated just over 6,000. Instead of 400 specialists who will serve asylum procedures, you have sent about 40. And at the same time there is this accusation against Greece and Italy that they do not do enough. By who? From Hungary and Poland, who have not taken a single one, from Slovakia, who already presides and has only got nine, from the Czech Republic who has taken twelve! These countries want a Europe 'la karte'; to give them funds for their farmers, for infrastructure projects, but to refuse to take on the commitments. And I ask you: Your proposals to penalise these countries, or at least to contribute financially to these costs, why have they disappeared?

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, I will speak first in English, then in Greek, so that you can practice your Greek. Honourable Members of Parliament, let me start by thanking you for your interventions. They contribution to a very lively debate. The Commission is very aware of your concerns. When we are dealing with a refugee crisis of this scale we can not afford to be ideological only, we have to be pragmatic. On Turkey, let me reiterate once again that this is an equal and mutually benefical partnership. The European Union Needs Turkey, but Turkey Needs the European Union as well. If anything has come clear this last year it is that the migratory challenges are not national or even European alone, they are global. You all Remember how this unprecedented phenomenon started. Everyone believed that it was a problem of the southern European countries, then it became a European one and now it has taken on global dimensions. And the EU-Turkey statement has started production tangible results. I spoke about it in the beginning, but our partnership can not be at all cost, it has to answer all the fundational and human rights and it continue to do so, and all elements and benchmarks must be fully filled. We are very clear on that. The European Union does not lower its principles. On Dublin now, I know some of you think we are not coming fast and other think we go too fast. Again I repeat what I said before, all our elements go hand in hand. But they also have to go hand in hand in an approximate and timely manner: no migrant will be sent back today, this week or next. What we recommend is that certain specific categories of migrants enterting Greece after 15 March, and who continue onwards to the north, can be sent back to Greece, if Greece is in a position to take them and provides individual guarantees about their reception. but from now until then further and intensified progress is needed in Greece, and we are supporting the Greek Government to better organise the reception centres and whatever is necessiary. And this is precisely where Additional Support is needed from Member States, Mr Papadimoulis is right on that. We can not accept that one or a handful of Member States shoulders this enormous responsibility of the refugee crisis. If we are a true European Union then one of the fundamental values on which this Union is built is solidarity, and solidarity, yes, does not come in pieces or à la carte. Our objective is to return to overall stability in the European Union. Relocation, Dublin, Schengen, it is all interconnected. And we can not have one without the other. Members of Parliament, we Need your support to continue delivery and moving forward on all such issues. And now, I accept your request, I turn to Greek. I should like to say a few words in Greek, since most of the last questions were addressed by distinguished Members of Parliament, who are Greeks: Mr Kyrkos, Mr Hadjigeorgiou, Mr Marias and Mrs Wozeberg. I wonder why there is a pervasive misinterpretation of the Commission's recommendation on Dublin. I have said it from the very first day I have repeated it today and I keep repeating it until it is understood. As I have already pointed out, no, Dublin returns to Greece are not starting. Clearly, it can't be said. The recommendation proposes a gradual and not complete recovery and, above all, it is clear that immigrants who are or will be in other Member States having entered through Greece before 15 March 2017 will not be sent back to Greece. Clearer positioning I think there can be no more understandable. It will actually only concern a small number of people, because controls at Greece's borders with Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia have been strengthened and what we call secondary movements are no longer being carried out. In addition, the Greece has called for the development of the European border guard in the region, which is also under way. This means that already, and certainly long before 15 March, no immigrants will be able to leave irregularly. The recommendation is therefore positive for Greece. Greece since 2011 — and this is worth reminding you — has been out of law with regard to asylum legislation, for reasons related to human rights violations at the time. You understand that. It could not continue and would not facilitate discussions, negotiations for a fairer and more effective Dublin mechanism, which is currently being revised on our proposal. In other words, with this proposal Greece is returning to European legitimacy. Is there anyone who wouldn't want this in Greece? The Recommendation recognises the significant progress — and we should note this — that has been made in Greece despite what is being heard and written. In order for the asylum system to work better and more effectively, under conditions of unprecedented pressure in extremely adverse conditions and, of course, with the substantial substantial assistance of the Commission, the European agencies and the Member States, it has become undeniable progress. Therefore, the recommendation — I repeat — does not apply immediately, but since 15 March. Excludes outstanding refunds and no immediate refunds are foreseen. However, even after 15 March it will concern certain categories of the few that will manage to bypass the checks and under conditions and with guarantees that Greece should be able to provide for each individual request for return, so with the cooperation of Greece. Because we have to compare with the way things were a year and a half ago, where there was no control and there was a great deal of the entry of irregular immigrants and mainly refugees through the Aegean into our country. These I say, so that the picture is clear in the face of a proper and objective evaluation of what the Commission has proposed. If circumstances change, the Commission will obviously revise its recommendation and may I add: All the other progress reports it presented on the same day are directly linked to this composition, i.e. the need to continue to implement the EU-Turkey declaration successfully, i.e. a reduction in arrivals, increased returns, stabilisation of satisfactory rates of relocations from Greece and Italy, the need to send experts immediately to speed up procedures in the context of both the declaration and relocation. Mr. Hadjigeorgiou asked a question. Alternative agreements are not considered. The declaration of the European Union-Turkey works and we are committed to implementing it. I do not know, to be honest, what statement by Mrs Mogherini Mr Hadjigeorgiou referred to, but it obviously concerns something else. Mr Papadimoulis, I said this before: You are right. We agree. I told you, and I want to see fixed relocation numbers. I do not hide — I say so in public — that I am disappointed. I would have expected a much more consistent response from all the Member States, because, as you rightly said, solidarity is not a go-ahead, and solidarity is not just in the face of the good that the European Union does, but also in the difficult times that the Member States are going through. And this solidarity, along with responsibility, are the two basic principles that today also test the very existence of Europe. I have said many times that, after all, it is not the economic crisis that is bringing Europe to its knees. It is the refugee crisis, because it is it that calls into question the basic principles we have spoken about today. I would like to believe that with our constant efforts in the end we will be able to take down the last obstacles in order to fully implement what I told you about a year ago and get to the numbers that we have set as target. This is not going to be an easy path and I will need the support of the European Parliament, as in the last two years, to which I would like to take this opportunity to express my public gratitude, because all that we have achieved is due to the fact that I have had from the first the full support of the democratic and progressive forces of this area.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 December 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. — The Commission's recommendations on the EU-Turkey Agreement and resuming transfers of asylum seekers to Greece are contradictory and inconsistent. There goes on to talk about implementing the EU-Turkey agreement as being of paramount importance for the European Union, but Turkey currently cannot see itself as a safe country and the European Parliament voted to freeze accession negotiations. It is admitted that the Greek islands are still overcrowded, that the Greek asylum system remains lacking due to the reception conditions, the treatment of vulnerable subjects and the timing with which the Greek asylum system remains lacking asylum applications are examined. Despite this, from March 2017, it is expected that Member States will again be able to reject asylum seekers who arrived in Europe from the Dublin system in Greece, under the rules of the Dublin system. Out of 160 000 migrants, only just over 6 000 people were relocated from Greece and not even 2 000 from Italy. The announcement to send migrants back to Greece portends an implicit invitation to behave equally with Italy, another member state victim of a common European asylum system made up of bankruptcy rules penalise first-arrival Member States.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Regulation ( EC) No 539/2001 listing the third countries whose nationals must be in possession of visas when crossing the external borders and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from that obligation (revision of the suspension mechanism) COM (2016) 0290 - C8-0176/2016 - 2016/0142 ( CODE).

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, the first thing I want to do is to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for the good work of all the shadow rapporteurs who, regardless of their final vote, have cooperated loyally and demonstrated their great European spirit. All the groups have been up to what they were asked, and we have been able to see the implications that this report had on the Union's foreign policy, general visa policy and, above all, on future liberalisation processes. Ukrainians and Georgians were following our debates and called for protection from Parliament from the Council's attitude, which linked the adoption of this report without legal basis to the negotiation of those other dossiers. I sincerely hope that, now that we are going to approve the reformed suspension mechanism, the Council will cooperate with Parliament on the rapid visa waiver for Georgia and Ukraine, countries which have long met the requirements. It has been six months of intense and hard debates in Parliament. We are thoroughly employed to reform this mechanism and make it more effective, operational and agile. Throughout this time we have tabled up to four different compromise proposals that sought to accommodate the positions of all parties. Unfortunately, we saw how all these proposals were rejected by the Council without any legal grounds. I hope that once all the related dossiers are completed, we will be able to know the intrahistory of the position of some Member States, especially those that blocked the agreement until late Thursday night. I know it's not the ideal text. That's not what we would have wished. We have all made great concessions, but without forgetting our positions: defending fundamental rights and preserving Parliament's role. And if we have done this, you were aware that with our commitment we strengthened the European project. The mechanism had to be more flexible, agile and operational, since the circumstances which gave rise to the originator's approval in September 2013 have been overwhelmed in recent years. Today we can guarantee the future of the Schengen area, avoiding possible abuses that could result from visa liberalisation processes. In addition, we can activate this mechanism in the event that some of the following situations occur in relation to a third country which is exempted from the visa requirement for access to the Union: an increase in the number of nationals refused access or for whom they are found to remain in the territory of the Member State irregularly; sudden increase in asylum applications in an unjustified manner; risks or imminent threat to the public order or internal security of States; or a decrease in cooperation on readmission. And at the same time, in line with our foreign policy, we ensure that the criteria that gave rise to visa liberalisation with third States are still respected in the future. We are talking about all the criteria contained in Article -1 of the Regulation: regional coherence, economic benefits, security, among others, but especially the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms, both in our territory and in that of origin. This is something we achieved through the introduction of a new monitoring mechanism by the Commission, for a period of seven years after the liberalisation of the visa requirement, or subsequently if there are indications of violation of any of these criteria. And we do this in turn improving and ensuring Parliament's role in decision-making on future temporary reintroductions of the visa requirement. For us, the issue of delegated acts is an emblematic issue. It is a fundamental question, as I always have defended. Visa policy is a shared matter. Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 is amended, as in this case, through the ordinary legislative procedure and therefore any substantial amendment to the basic act must be made through a delegated act, rather than implementing. This has always been our position, it was in 2013 and we kept it before the Court in 2015, which gave us the right in its judgment of 16 July of the same year. Finally, to conclude this part of my speech, I would like to point out that the Commission is also taking a new role, adding to what already has the activation of the mechanism as a power within the competence of the Commission, the Member State concerned and the simple majority of the Member States. And the Commission also gains powers by activating the review and evaluation mechanism.”

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the Parliament, the last-minute addition of this point in the plenary agenda was a very welcome one to me. The agreement on the reinforced suspension mechanism goes beyond the importance of the mechanism itself. Let me start by expressing my thanks to our rapporteur, Mr Agustín Díaz de Mera, for his excellent work. I know it was not an easy job. You did it. Without his commitment it would not have been possible to reach an agreement before the end of the year. I also want to express my thanks to the Council Presidency, which brokered the deal in the Council. Both institutions made decisive steps towards each other at the last minute, which made the agreement possible. The Commission also made some concessions for the sake of an overall agreement – for example, by accepting some elements of automaticity introduced by the Council. We also committed to taking into consideration the categories proposed by the Member States and to ensuring that these categories are sufficiently large to address in a proportionate way the circumstances. The Commission has made declarations in that respect to COREPER. Overall we have jointly succeeded in making the suspension mechanism a more effective instrument for our common visa policy. It will enable the European Union to react quickly in situations of strong migratory pressures or high security risks by suspending the visa exemption for certain third-country nationals. The final outcome allows for a flexible approach and a proportionate reaction to the circumstances encountered. Very importantly, it also allows for a dialogue with the third country concerned to remedy the situation that led to the suspension. By adopting this strengthened suspension mechanism we will be able to pursue our visa liberalisation strategy based on stronger safeguards. I am pleased to know that the trilogue on visa liberalisation for Georgia has been successful, and I am looking forward to the same outcome for Ukraine. These two countries have concluded a series of reforms to implement their so-called visa liberalisation road map, and it is now for us to deliver and grant to their citizens visa-free travel to Europe. Our common priority now is to accelerate the procedures for the entry into force of the suspension mechanism as well as for the adoption of the visa liberalisation proposals for Georgia and Ukraine. We have delivered on the commitments made to our partners. The correct implementation of visa-free travel for Georgia and Ukraine will only be beneficial mutually, enhancing the cultural and economic exchanges and strengthening mobility between these countries and the European Member States. It is an important and symbolic achievement, bringing people and nations closer. I hope that it will become a reality early in spring thanks to the agreement on the suspension mechanism that we are discussing today.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, first of all, thank you and congratulations to the rapporteur for his remarkable work. The European Parliament is co-legislator for this visa policy and we must continue to enforce our prerogatives. I would like to make three remarks. First, the review of the suspension mechanism is part of the holistic approach to intelligent and controlled management of migration and mobility. More security thanks to more flexibility to trigger the mechanism; this is a first success. However, we must recall the fundamental principles that will guide our decisions if the mechanism were to be triggered: a case-by-case review, on specific criteria, with the interest of citizens as a guideline. Second point, and I must again congratulate the rapporteur, because, thanks to the introduction of the possibility of suspending exemption for certain categories of persons, we retain the potential of visa policy as a tool for foreign policy and political dialogue. Finally, I also insist on visa liberalisation with Georgia and Ukraine. The Commission had decided to link the review of the mechanism to these two other files. Agreement has been reached on the mechanism and I will no longer accept any unnecessary delays. I count on the Maltese Presidency to start the trilogues on Ukraine in January.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Thank the Chairman, thank you first of all to the rapporteur De Meri for the outstanding negotiations that have secured the interests of the European Parliament and all European citizens. And also opened the door to Georgians and Ukrainians for imminent visa-free trips. Colleagues, the Union's visa policy is one of the most tangible and concrete instruments of European foreign policy. At least such has been in the past. I remember the extraordinary emotions of the people from the Western Balkans when we managed to abolish their visas. Today, this same visa policy is losing its appeal due to constant tightening. On the one hand, due to additional, including political, visa waiver criteria and new measures such as the introduction of smart borders or ETIAS. On the other, because of the constant threat after the reintroduction of visas, which allows the newly adopted mechanism on suspension. Dear Commissioner! The European visa policy has another key side, that is, reciprocity. The European Union must also have the courage to act when it comes to the issue of reciprocity. Today, the Commission still authorises second-rate citizens as many as five members of the Union and knowingly violates its own rules. We will closely monitor the implementation of the new rules in Parliament and will take decisive action in the event of abuses.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, I also congratulate our colleague Augustin Diaz de Mera, who amended the regulation very well and under pressure, with negotiations late in the night - I participated in them as rapporteur for my group. The mechanism for suspending the visa waiver is currently inappropriate, and that is why we have practically amended the regulation with regard to the suspension process, and that is what we will vote on tomorrow. It is very important to understand that the credibility of the European Union is also at stake, which grants visa waiver to some states, and then, obviously, expects those States to continue the progress and the criteria they met at the time of the visa waiver. If they take backward steps, it is not normal for them to continue to benefit from the visa waiver. Also, our credibility to European citizens, who see that we have exempted citizens of some states from visas, but then see that they violate public order, see that they do not come with good and clean intentions across the Union and create problems. That's why it's very good for credibility. What we are changing, very briefly, is: the deadlines for the visa waiver application have also been shortened, the reasons for applying for the suspension of the visa exemption have been increased, and one of them is new, namely the failure to comply with the readmission obligation of migrants where such agreements. A new mechanism was also introduced to verify the criteria that existed when a given State was exempted from visas, if these criteria still persist and no setback has occurred. Everyone will be more responsible, and the Member States, and the Union.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, visa liberalisation is a valuable political tool for the European Union which also offers significant advantages for the citizens of the third countries concerned. At the same time, for the security of EU citizens, we need an efficient suspension mechanism to avoid any abuse. This upgraded mechanism makes it easier to alert the Commission to  irregularities and emergencies that could justify a reintroduction of visa requirements.  It was not easy to reach an agreement. Both institutions had strong views on how this mechanism should be activated. Both Parliament and Council had to make concessions, resulting in a two-step approach which I believe in the end does not affect the main objective of this proposal; but we lost time due to the interinstitutional in-fighting.  The Council made this agreement a prerequisite for approving new liberalisation agreements such as those with Georgia and Ukraine. Even though we reached an agreement on the mechanism, it seems Member States are still delaying those liberalisation agreements. Ukraine and Georgia made enormous efforts to reform and fulfil our criteria. It is up to us now to deliver and be a reliable partner. The European Parliament is more than ready, and I call on the Member States not to delay the visa liberalisation any more.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, first of all I would like to thank our rapporteur and his tenacity in fulfilling our mandate. In vain! This text is meaningful of what I would call the migration obsession of the Member States. In the early 2000s, when the text on visa requirements and its exemptions was implemented, we were in a completely different landscape and the Union's desire was to open its borders to nationals of countries with which it intended to have good relations. The liberalisation agreements were implemented even before the European Parliament approved them. Over the last few months, total change of course. The new agreements are trampling pending the adoption of this suspension mechanism. The European Parliament has been subjected to real blackmail and, instead of improving the text, Council and Commission have only had the will to tighten it, with the States concerned being judged to be able to be the good gendarmes of the European Union, particularly in the light of readmission agreements, regardless of whether fundamental rights are violated. When we know which actors concerned by the blockade, Georgia and Ukraine, have fulfilled their obligations, but also Kosovo and Turkey, it is no surprise. The GUE/NGL will not follow you on this field.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, once, President Poroshenko of Ukraine said at the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga: ‘I was born visa free’, referring to some demonstrators outside the house who were calling for visa freedom for Ukrainians. And it has been very disappointing to see how long their justified wishes have had to wait for realisation.  Unfortunately, I must say that the most disappointing of all was that the Council wanted to link the visa waiver of Georgia and Ukraine with this suspension clause. We are not happy about it; it gives too many possibilities for EU Member States to restrict the visa waiver on grounds that may lead to human rights violations, for instance when returning illegally-entered migrants to the EU. I believe that the European Parliament has rightly insisted that we need to have more of a say in how the Commission will actually induce this suspension clause, so that it is not arbitrary.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this legislation is supposedly intended to ensure that visa liberalisation is not abused. It is supposed to ease the concerns of Member States, those concerns being that visa-free access for Ukraine and Georgia will lead to another influx of migrants. This is quite reasonable, given that Ukraine and Georgia have a combined population of 45 million people, while the average income in Georgia is GBP 320 per month and the average income in Ukraine is GBP 160 per month. If visa-free access is agreed, many hundreds of thousands, or even perhaps millions of people, will come to Europe and very many – visa or no visa – will not leave. These measures are in fact a pathway for the EU to conclude visa-free agreements with those countries. While the UK is not bound by this legislation, the UKIP MEPs will oppose it.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, Schengen is a sick person in an outdated coma, but the European Union is still trying to save him. This time, it is a matter of reassuring public opinion by strengthening the European visa suspension mechanism. The aim is to be able to temporarily re-establish the visa requirement for entry into the Union in the event of a sudden spike in irregular immigration. It will not work, but the Union does not laugh, because its real objective is elsewhere. It wants to give illusory guarantees to pass visa cancellation for the 45 million Ukrainians. While we should protect ourselves from the wave of migration by restoring controls at our national borders, the Union is doing the opposite, opening up its borders even further. The Union continues to dream of a world without borders, while states all over the world are re-establishing their borders. His dream is a nightmare that the people of Europe reject wherever they are dared to question them in a referendum. In the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Hungary, Italy and tomorrow in France.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, first of all let me thank and congratulate Mr Díaz de Mera for the great work he has done on this material. I'm a little surprised at the reaction of my colleague Batten and others who have responded here so that people from Ukraine or Georgia will really come to us. It's normal nonsense, my colleague. You haunt the public again a few months after the Brexit referendum. I think a lot of the mechanisms here in the European Union have not worked in the context of the migrant crisis. And here is precisely the effort to re-establish this mechanism and implement it in effective ways, under predetermined conditions. At the moment, the suspension is actually very slow, as we do not have sufficient flexibility. This tool that has been negotiated now gives us that flexibility. That's why I support this proposal and support what has been negotiated.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you and colleagues have said what I wanted to concentrate on, which is that the rapporteur, Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, and colleagues worked on this file as best they could. The LIBE Committee was locked into six months of very difficult debate with the other institutions. We maintained a position and we ended with the mechanism which speaks not only to dry procedure in relation to visas, but speaks to the hard work of this Parliament in relating to countries. You can see Georgians and Ukrainians here in this Parliament who are waiting to hear about the suspension mechanism, about the work that has been done in securing for them good news about the European Union. I agree with what the Commissioner has said and indeed other Members of this House. The conclusions of these negotiations between the Parliament and Council have been one of the key priorities for our committee. I want to thank everyone who has been involved in this bid for visa-free travel and colleagues. Sorry, President, I thought I had two minutes. No? Just one minute. Let me just thank the rapporteur again. Thank you very much Mr Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra. I conclude. (Applause)

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: - Mr President! Yes, I would like to clearly also tune into the choir singing the praises of the colleague Díaz de Mera for his tireless and outstanding work on this complicated issue. Despite some stiff opposition in the Council and sometimes even quite counterproductive interventions, we have now reached the objectives of this repeal mechanism. And that's good news! It is important that we have reached consensus because visa freedom for Georgia and Ukraine has depended on whether the EU could demonstrate that we can deliver. Now we have done so, and we can rejoice in future contacts and exchanges between the EU, Georgia and Ukraine. At a time where it seems that more and more people want to build walls, it is important that we now manage to lower thresholds and also build bridges between people. And that we can show that trust and trust is possible. So this is good news for the EU and for anyone who will be affected by this. Thank you, Mr President!

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I also congratulate my colleague, Mr Díaz de Mera, on the excellent work he has done, as is the custom. European visa policy, in particular visa-free, is an essential element of the Union's external relations, enabling better cooperation with third States. Cooperation that is particularly important with neighbouring countries. Visa liberalisation with Georgia and Ukraine - which this Parliament has already approved - is a paradigmatic example. The approval of this suspension mechanism will contribute to greater security, allowing the exemption to be suspended in the event of a substantial increase in irregular stays. It will also be possible in the event of non-respect for human rights in the third State. Equally important is the greater flexibility of the mechanism, giving greater and faster reaction capacity. Finally, thanks to the determined position of Dias de Mera, the involvement of this Parliament in more serious situations involving longer suspension has been ensured. Having arrived here, it is time for the Council to unblock visa liberalisation with Georgia and Ukraine. Not only are the requirements met, but clearly their importance for foreign policy.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mr Díaz de Mera for his work, certainly not easy. I firmly believe that visa liberalisation represents an opportunity in terms of the development of tourism, trade and international dialogue. I understand, however, that policies within the Schengen area must be made more flexible today to be adapted to the challenges of our age. This is the introduction of the possibility of suspending the visa exemption if there are elements that prove a possible threat to the internal security of the Member States. But of course it is important to maintain the Schengen system, so I think it is necessary for the Commission to assess the human rights situation in the third country before activating the suspension mechanism. subject to the suspensive procedure, in order to verify that the reintroduction of the visa requirement, where necessary, does not have negative impacts on citizens fleeing dramatic conflicts and persecution and there are no forms of abuse. It is important, also in this regard, that Parliament actively vigilates the process of suspending visas.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Commissioner, the European Parliament will decide tomorrow on the suspension mechanism for the issuance of short-term visas. It is a necessary condition for visa liberalization for Ukraine and Georgia. I believe that the European Parliament will approve this mechanism, and citizens of these countries will be able to travel on short stays without visas from next year. Both Ukraine and Georgia have fulfilled all contractual obligations set out in the action plans, including investment in border guards or biometric passports. I am a great supporter of the closest possible ties between the European Union and Eastern Partnership countries, especially Ukraine. Visa liberalisation is a tangible benefit for citizens and entrepreneurs and will improve the perception of the European Union in the areas concerned. We can reassure our citizens that the mechanism under discussion is precisely there to protect against increased migration flows and abuse of the system for longer-term illegal stays.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: Mr President, I congratulate Parliament's rapporteur, Agustín Díaz de Mera, on the ability to agree on an important issue for building a genuine European Union visa policy. The new rules allow flexibility and a rapid activation of the suspension mechanism in the event of a substantial increase in the number of nationals of the country concerned, or irregular entry into the territory of the European Union, a substantial increase in unfounded asylum applications, lack of cooperation on readmission and threats to public order, or internal security, relating to third-country nationals. This agreement with the Council will hopefully allow some of the Member States to calm down and, consequently, quickly finalise the approval of the proposals for a visa liberalisation agreement with Georgia and Ukraine. It remains to be hoped that these rules will not be used for perverse political games. Parliament will be vigilant.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I also congratulate the rapporteur on his performance. Clear rules for visa-free travel and its possible suspension and suspension, respectively, because visa-free travel for Ukraine and Georgia is, in my opinion, extremely significant even from a geopolitical standpoint. We must clearly open our arms to these countries and offer them cooperation so that these countries have a clear vision for the future, because the situation in these countries as we know is very difficult and they are under by huge pressure from Russia. I consider it extremely important from a geopolitical point of view — as an MP for the Czech Republic, which was unfortunately in the second half of the twentieth century, within Czechoslovakia, under the influence of The Soviet Union — cooperate with the countries of the former Soviet Union, offer them open arms, and for that we need these rules, which the rapporteur negotiated. I welcome this very much, and I quench the rules.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President. Well, rapporteur Díaz de Mera, for this work on a visa code which requires a regulation of visa-waiver conditions for third countries and which comes at a time that has been described as not easy and which is certainly difficult and negative for the fulfilment of the objectives of the area of freedom, justice and security, such as provided for the Treaty of Lisbon. Because the Treaty of Lisbon wants a common European visa policy, and the fact is that Member States are increasing the conditions imposed unilaterally, or unilaterally assessed — which may make it difficult to obtain such visas — and want to enhance the situations in which they can assess and decide on the exemption visa and the removal of visas. We are therefore in a really difficult situation that connects with other dossiers which have been blocked by the Council, as is unfortunately the Visa Code. But I care to stress the importance of both the Commission and Parliament exercising their power to assess the monitoring of these dossiers and to examine the conditions for the suspension of visas.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Mr President, I also join in congratulating the rapporteur, because this work is truly respectable. I would only like to point out that it is important to me that this proposal really brings flexibility, and the fact that it is a proposal that allows prerequisites for the removal of visa duties. I would like to say only on the edge of what is said precisely in relation to Ukraine and Georgia that they will already be exempt from that visa requirement — this draft only sets a certain mechanism, as may be exempt from this visa requirement, but it does not mean that there is now an exemption. We won't vote on such a proposal until February, if I'm not mistaken. At the same time, I would like to stress that this form of assistance to these two countries is absolutely necessary and should not be further postponed on our part. I think we owe it to these countries.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Council’s idea to link the free visa regime between the EU and Georgia and Ukraine with a suspension mechanism was a bad idea, as a result of which there has been an unpredictable delay of the visa-free regime with these countries. Georgia and Ukraine fulfilled all the conditions and are waiting for you to fulfil your commitments.  However, while some EU countries have publicly declared that they are glad to see these Eastern European countries on the way to EU integration, at the same time they have put their feet on the brakes and started to blackmail the European Parliament. In this way they are trying to solve their internal political problems. In politics, as in business, a society’s reputation as a reliable partner is a very valuable thing. So the EU’s reputation was seriously damaged in this case. We will not see the negative result immediately, but in connection with other cases of arrogance and neglect, our attitude towards our partners will return to us like a boomerang in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: (ECR). — (EL) Madam President, Mr Avramopoulos, there is no possibility of an appeal in this Parliament. I will make use of you being here and I will continue what I said earlier, because the Commission communication is as you said, that after 15 March there will be repromotions. But if there are no re-promotions, there are two things that have to happen: either the legislation in relation to Dublin III is changed and it prohibits Germany from doing so, or Germany and other countries are committing themselves not to do so. I therefore accept the Commission's commitment to its intentions, but that does not prevent Germany from proceeding with these procedures, and that must be clear. And secondly, does the Commission finally prohibit the Greek Government from taking a decision and transferring some of the 16,000 enclaved refugees to the Aegean islands? We want an unambiguous answer to this.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Mr President, as someone rather unusually decorated by both Ukraine and Georgia for my services to those countries and their Euro-Atlantic aspirations, I of course warmly welcome the agreement for visa liberalisation to allow their citizens, for tourism and business purposes, to visit the European Union Schengen zone. Both countries have waited for years and have made sacrifices by unilaterally lifting visa restrictions and fees on EU visitors with no reciprocity until now. Of course there must be safeguards, including suspension mechanisms if the numbers are excessive or overstay abuses are evident. Both European neighbouring countries deserve our warmest welcome, and in Ukraine we must remember that many of their citizens have died for the freedoms that we take for granted here in the European Union.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear colleagues, thanks again for this fruitful exchange. The new suspension mechanism will protect the European Union by making it easier for Member States to flag irregularities that justify a reintroduction of the visa requirement. The Commission will also have the right of initiative to launch the process leading to the reintroduction of the visa requirement, and it will monitor the continuous fulfilment of the benchmarks required for achieving visa liberalisation. The agreement has also made it possible to proceed with the discussions on the visa liberalisation proposals for Georgia and Ukraine. Having seen the wide support of the relevant parliamentary committee, I am confident that the plenary will approve this important agreement tomorrow. Thank you again for this fruitful discussion.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, very brief words, as I announced earlier. I just want to underline the vitality of the House when faced with genuine legislative bills. There have been twenty-one interventions. And I appreciate and thank all those who had a component of recognition of the task of the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs, but I also want to say that I appreciate those others who did not agree with us. The vitality of the House, the vitality of Parliament, is unequivocally demonstrated by the solidarity shown in the face of a project of this size.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 15 December 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The procedure for suspending the visa waiver needs to be revised to make it quicker and more flexible. This will enable the EU to respond operatively if there is a situation that threatens, for example, EU security, or there is a sudden increase in the number of third country nationals living illegally in EU territory. The review of this regime will also remove obstacles to the introduction of visa-free regime in Ukraine and Georgia. This is important because both countries have met the necessary criteria for some time ago, and a decision to grant them visa-free will have to be taken quickly.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. — I supported today in the European Parliament the revision of the visa suspension mechanism for citizens of non-Member States of the European Union to make it more efficient and flexible, especially in the context of the political situation and the migration phenomenon confront the European Union. Visa policy is an important topic for the European Union, with repercussions both internally and externally. Successive visa liberalisation procedures have made it necessary to revise the suspension mechanism for visa-free countries, the novelty being that the European Parliament will have the right to take part in these types of decisions. This review starts from the need to have tools to enable the European Union to respond to unforeseen circumstances, such as an increase in the number of citizens from non-EU countries staying illegally or threats to security across Europe. At the same time, I reiterated that this flexibility must be accompanied by a set of measures guaranteeing the protection of fundamental human rights, building on the statistics received from European agencies or competent security bodies. Only in this way will they be able to strike a balance between the safety of EU citizens and respect for the rights of those coming from outside the EU.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on Council and Commission Declarations on Europol data breach related to terrorist investigation files (2016/3031 (RSP)).

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, I very much appreciate the opportunity to discuss this topic with you today. It is important to clarify what has happened and address concerns. I would like to touch upon the facts regarding the incident and, finally, to draw some conclusions. But first of all, we have to have all the facts straight. On 22 September, a former staff member of Europol informed Europol that she had been contacted by a journalist earlier that day in relation to Europol operational data. The journalist had obtained access to those data via a private storage device belonging to the former staff member. As soon as Europol was informed about this possible compromise of data, a security investigation was launched, in coordination with the national authorities of the Member State of the former staff member in order to identify the nature of the compromised data. The national authorities also initiated a judicial investigation. In parallel, the Member States directly affected were informed by Europol in order to establish any possible impact. The Security Committee of Europol, where all Member States are represented, received a classified report on the matter. The Europol Data Protection Officer was also briefed.  Later on, the information about the incident became public on 30 November, when a TV programme was announced and then broadcast on Dutch television. It was in that context that the Europol data compromise was mentioned. Immediately, Europol circulated a background note about the incident to the relevant stakeholders - the Europol Management Board, the European Commission, the Europol Data Protection Officer, the Joint Supervisory Body, the EU Counter Terrorism Coordinator, the Council Secretariat as well as the Chairperson of the LIBE Committee. The Europol Security Committee was updated as well. Last week, the European Data Protection Supervisor, which will become Europol’s data protection oversight body on 1 May next year, was also informed. As regards the content of the compromised data, it is worth noting that we are talking about historical data which are mostly more than 10 years old. According to the assessment of the Member States concerned and Europol, the data do not jeopardise on-going investigations. Let me also make some additional remarks. As unfortunate as this incident might be, the case reported in the media is not a data leak – Europol’s information systems and its operational environment were not ‘hacked’ or intruded upon. In fact, Europol adheres to the highest standards of data security, including continuous security awareness briefings provided to its staff members. Europol operates state-of-the-art databases and secure communication capabilities for processing and analysing operational and classified information. Unfortunately, as with any law enforcement agency, the design of a robust system cannot completely eliminate human error. The former staff member clearly did not comply with Europol’s security rules, which explicitly forbid the use of private equipment to produce, store, process or transmit Europol operational or other sensitive information. This is the first identified case of this kind since Europol was established.  As far as the Parliament is concerned, I would also recall that the new Europol Regulation, which comes into application on the 1 May 2017, foresees a mechanism to allow enhanced parliamentary oversight. A Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group will be established by the national parliaments and the competent committee of the European Parliament. I therefore sincerely hope that this incident will not undermine our efforts to increase the exchange of information. We all share an interest in this. Exchange of information, not least in the framework of Europol, is vital in order to address today’s security challenges.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you. Members of the Parliament, thank you for the invitation to this session. Before sharing with you all the information I have on this security breach, let me stress four key points. 1. It is my firm belief that we need more cooperation on security and effective data exchange. But I am equally clear that this presupposes a high level of data protection and state-of-the-art security rules. 2. This incident could not have happened today, thanks to the technical security improvements that are finally in place. Nobody can plug in USB drives and download data from Europol computers. 3. It neither affected the private life of European citizens nor any on-going security investigations. 4. With you we have adopted new rules for Europol that will impose a different handling of the case today from May 1st 2017. Let’s look at facts first. This data breach is a case of human error by a former staff member who broke Europol’s security rules. There is no indication that the security breach by the former staff member was ill-intended. Still, it is of course unacceptable. Our data security rules should prevent human errors from happening. The data compromised involves a limited number of Member States. Europol received written assurances from the journalist that the data will not be disclosed and that they are stored safely as journalistic evidence for the television programme. I am confident on the basis of information we were given that Europol respected all its current security and confidentiality rules. A security investigation was launched with the Member State of the former Europol employee and to which the employee returned at the end of February 2016. National authorities also initiated a formal judicial investigation into the matter. In parallel, the Member States directly affected were updated by Europol to establish any possible impact. All Member States through the Security Committee of Europol received a classified report for their attention. The Europol Data Protection Officer was also briefed at an early stage of the process. It was verified that no current investigation in Member States has been jeopardised, because the breach concerns historical data which are around 10 years old. When the case was reported in the media on 30 November, Europol provided external stakeholders with a background brief on the facts: namely, an update to the Europol Security Committee, which includes all Member States; the Europol Management Board, which includes the Commission; separately, the Commission, the Europol Data Protection Officer, the Joint Supervisory Body, the EU Counter-terrorism Coordinator, the Council Secretariat, and the Chairperson of the LIBE Committee. Last week also the future data protection oversight body of Europol, the EDPS, was briefed with a report. Internally, staff were also updated when the incident was reported in the media on 30 November. Prior to that, all staff received continuous security awareness briefings. Staff members, and in particular staff working in the operational environment, are continuously trained about the expected handling of operational and sensitive information. Staff have also been briefed about the implications of the security incident. Another security awareness seminar for all staff is scheduled to take place this Friday. Honourable Members of the Parliament, as far as I am aware, this is the first real security breach of this kind involving Europol data since the establishment of the Agency in 1999. The Member States concerned confirmed that the compromised data does not jeopardise any on-going investigations. Only two people accessed the data. There are no indications that data have been further shared or the lives of private citizens affected. A judicial investigation in relation to a potential criminal offence committed by these two people is ongoing. Europol today is a different organisation than the one back in 2009 when the human error occurred. Since then, Europol has introduced numerous technical measures preventing copying of data, such as prohibiting the connection of external drives I mentioned earlier. Staff are constantly trained and informed about security requirements. The case reported in the media is not a data leak. ICT systems or the operational environment of Europol were not hacked or intruded. Handling security breaches is always the primary responsibility of the organisation when data have been compromised. That organisation, Europol, is obliged to inform the entities that provide the data, the internal data security bodies and its external data protection supervisor. Having said that, we should learn lessons from this case and improve our handling for the future. The Europol Regulation that enters into application on 1 May 2017 lays down specific rules on handling data security breaches. These rules set high standards on data security. They oblige Europol to notify the personal data breaches without delay to the European Data Protection Supervisor and the competent authorities of the Member States concerned, as well as the data provider. They oblige Europol to inform in certain cases persons whose data have been breached, and they oblige the Europol Data Protection Officer to keep a register of data breaches. Under the new Europol Regulation, a new set of security and confidentiality rules is being established. In light of his experience, we look more closely whether any changes are needed there. Finally, I would encourage Europol in the – hopefully unlikely – event of a future security breach, to share proactively information with the Commission and the Joint Parliamentary scrutiny within the limits of the security rules.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is no secret that I trust Europol. I affirmed at the recent interparliamentary meeting and reiterate now that Europol is an essential tool for the safety of Europeans, so my commitment is unequivocal. We are in the presence of an isolated case triggered by a former Europol official, which occurred in 2009 and caused confidential information on terrorist investigations ranging between 2003 and 2006, in breach of all Europol security standards. Europol's prestige should not be affected by this fact, nor should the Member States' confidence be affected. That is why it is important that Europol now raise at least these three questions: have sufficient measures been taken to prevent such incidents? Secondly, how should Europol guide this fact so that it does not undermine its credibility in the face of Member States or third States with which it has cooperation agreements? Thirdly, can it have implications for the security of the Member States? Although we know and affirm that Tuesday's Governing Body was very positive. On the other hand, through my own efforts, I have been able to know that a significant number of measures have already been improved. Network security accreditation has been increased, and since December 1, all USB ports on the secure network have been blocked. In addition, as is common domain, from May 2017 the new Regulation — of which I was rapporteur in the European Parliament — will enter into force, which will strengthen the data protection system. The European Supervisor, as Mr Avramopoulos said, will, as last responsible, monitor the correct use of them. Finally, there will be a greater and better system of democratic control of the Agency through the joint parliamentary control group formed by the European Parliament and the national parliaments. This debate is necessary because it is justified, but it must be proportionate and balanced, and help strengthen and revise Europol's security protocols.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Mr President, the breach of security that has led to the online disclosure of suspicious names and telephone numbers in Europol terrorist investigations cannot be minimised or seen as an isolated case. It is not possible to disregard this security breach, with the excuse of individual error and that no investigation has been compromised. An agency such as Europol must be equipped with procedures and controls so that the negligence of an official is not enough for sensitive information to appear suddenly on the net. Especially when the powers of this essential agency were extended later this year, and the role of democratic control to be exercised by the European Parliament in association with the national parliaments has been strengthened. It is not acceptable that the Europol Directorate, perhaps under pressure from the Commission and some Member States, chose not to inform this House when it attended the meeting of our Libya committee at the end of last month, and it is already in possession of this information. Ironically, the subject of this meeting of the Libya committee was precisely the scrutiny of this agency. Despite all the warnings and evidence that we are living in a hybrid war environment, it is intolerable that the Commission and the Member States, which have recently been everted to use the security argument to justify sprains to human rights and the rule of law, as is the case, for example, in the reception of migrants and refugees, are not really taking cybersecurity and the devastating potential of attacks on critical infrastructure and networks seriously. It is intolerable that the Commission is not fulfilling its role as a watchman when it is attacked itself, as was the case a few days ago. It is crucial to conduct an in-depth investigation and act urgently to ensure that all Member States, institutions and agencies effectively coordinate, exchange information and are equipped with the necessary security and defence tools, which implies adequate financial investment in technological resources and human resources, including human intelligence. Frightening reports also come from other parts of the world: Russian interference will have occurred to influence, and perhaps even pervert democratic expression in the United States elections, but when, here among us, in the agency responsible for coordinating efforts to combat crime in the digital age, it is enough to Negligence to show that the king goes naked, how can we say we're safe?

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President, seven years ago, two Europol workers inserted a flash drive into a computer and left there with confidential information from the institution. Europol is dealing with the fight against organised crime and, lately, very strongly, with the fight against terrorism. This did not affect any pending judicial investigation, any kind of investigation in general and had no other consequences. It wasn't a leak, it wasn't a cyber attack on IT systems. But this incident existed, which is regrettable and unacceptable. Today, however, it would no longer be possible. Today, no one could put a flash drive into a computer from Europol and leave with information home because Europol operates with databases that are confidential and has very high security capabilities, higher than in many Member States; analysis and processing of classified information. Europol's security standards are today, I repeat, very high and cannot happen again. However, this case is being investigated, but I want to finish by saying: I believe in Europol and never repeat it again.

name: Sophia in 't Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, you leave me with more questions than I came with actually, because I am beginning to wonder more and more, if you say this is not a data leak – a bit like ‘Ceci n’est pas une pipe’ – what a data leak looks like. To me this sounds as though 700 pages of confidential information have been publicly available. When you say that it is only historical data and that it does not jeopardise any current investigations, that does not correspond exactly to the media reports saying that there may have been an impact on ongoing investigations. So I think this is extremely worrying. If the procedures apparently do not ensure that people do not make such mistakes, we have a very serious problem. We have been asked, under great pressure, to pass a series of measures like, for example, my favourite – EU PNR – which has decentralised the storage of data. If we cannot even secure the data stored by Europol, how can we be sure that the data which Member States are now obliged to store are safe? I’m getting extremely worried here. But actually my main concern here is that we have all been talking about security, security, security, security – OK? – and we have all agreed that one of the big gaps in the security system is information sharing. This will have a devastating impact on the trust between Member States. How are you now going to convince Member States to share information? A majority of this House, as well as the Commission and the Council, fiercely opposed compulsory information sharing. I am not really sure what to think any more. You are trying to reassure us here by saying, ‘Keep moving folks, there is nothing to see here’. Well, I am not reassured. I would also like to know when exactly all these people – the Council, the JSB, the secretariat and everybody – when have they been informed? Was that before or after the media report? That is a question that I would like to get an answer to. I would also like to know when the Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs was informed, and under what conditions. Was he informed with the freedom to address these issues publicly, or is there a confidentiality clause?

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. It's odd how a Europol employee comes up with the idea of taking home 700 pages of confidential, unencrypted data — perhaps because she got bored or wanted to check who was with the bombers in Madrid. Europol — and this is the problem — did not have the duty to inform the European Parliament without delay, but stated after the publication of the data that it was merely historical data. Do you really know, and this is my question to you, where did the data go? Are you sure it just stayed there? You're playing down the incident, and I wonder how stupid do you think Parliament is? Also in view of the fact that the Europol data monster will gain even more skills in 2017, more public authorities will be involved in it, and even more data systems will be networked. Europol is only an uncontrollable black box, and it will remain so with the new regulation, including with the control body, which is toothless. This place is not safe either. That's the message. I wonder how many data leaks can we actually prevent and what about the hackers? It is not just about trust in an authority that almost no one already has, but about ensuring the safety of citizens, and I have not heard of that.

name: Jan Philipp Albrecht
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Commissioner that this example shows how important it is that we concentrate our systems and our storage on the information which is really necessary for the investigation – information linked to suspicion and risk. The more data we gather, the greater the risk of data being lost. It is true that this example is not the rule, and maybe today we have better standards to protect us against those losses, but there may be other occasions when data are lost and there may be other breaches of security. No system is 100% secure. There will never be any system which is 100% secure. That makes it even more important that we look for the data which are necessary, concentrate on that and do not build up a huge storage of data just because we can do it technically. We should rather have a better and quicker exchange of information built on common standards which are high on security and data protection. This should not only apply to the Member States with the Data Protection Directive, but should also apply to all EU data systems and agencies. That is not the case today. Every agency and every system has different standards. We need to harmonise these, and the upcoming regulation reform for EU agencies is a good opportunity to get these standards right in these agencies as well.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it is unfortunate that Europol mislaid some highly sensitive data on terrorism through human error. We’ve had similar experiences in Britain with highly sensitive government information being left on trains and in the back of taxis. If only obtaining information from Europol was always so easy. In October, I requested a copy of the joint Interpol-Europol report on migrant smuggling networks from Europol and I was told I could not have it. My constituents in London might be surprised that I, as their MEP and a member of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs Committee, cannot see this important report – not even a redacted version with sensitive and investigation-specific information withheld. My constituents would quite rightly expect me to be able to see this report. I hope that Europol will reconsider its decision and give me a copy of the report, rather than me having to hope that one turns up in the back of a taxi.

name: Marcus Pretzell
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the European Union. One of Europol's most urgent tasks is the fight against terrorism, and this does indeed require cooperation between different states, because terrorists are proving to operate across national borders, especially now that these borders between states are demolished and unguarded. However, there are good reasons why the police and the fight against terrorism should remain national affairs. Different states have different ways of combating terrorism, and the more diverse the paths, the more likely success. A single large authority runs the risk of monopolizing a defective structure. In January, Europol founded a European Counter Terrorism Centre. The nation states are encouraged to provide their data to this centre. A police officer has taken home 54 investigative files, 700 pages. It ended up in public, and you can not be one hundred percent sure that no one else used the material. But one thing is completely certain: if centrally collected data becomes public, the damage to the entire structure is immense.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
