text: Mr President, Commissioner, dear presidency of the Council, ladies and gentlemen. I think it's very worrying to use a data leak — as unfortunate as it may be and difficult such an operation — right now to fall back into old accusations. Firstly, I hope and hope — and here I support all the Members who are asking for this — that we will also receive detailed information in the European Parliament, in the LIBE Committee. Because non-enlightenment means sowing distrust. We want to have confidence in Europol, and we also trust Europol officials because they are doing an excellent job. It is simply nonkind to believe that the fight against terrorism would be better if each nation state worked on its own. This is almost counterproductive at a time when it is known that both organized criminals are moving across all borders, operate internationally, and are facilitating and supporting each other. That is why we need information exchange, which is why we need cooperation, which is why we also need data security and we need intensive data exchange, which will make it possible to combat criminals optimally. We need the various centres that deal with the new information technologies and the strategies that criminals use. We need a terrorist centre that promotes, supports and coordinates cooperation among the Member States. If we do this together, then we must now ensure that confidence is maintained in this case too and that we in Parliament will also receive optimised information on this matter in this case.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President, I am addressing the Presidency of the Council and Commissioner Avramopoulos, because someone who has no direct responsibility for the safety of Europeans could simply say that nothing less than in the European Union Agency for Police Cooperation, Europol, there has been a leak and an online exhibition of no less than seven hundred pages affecting the whopping fifty-four different investigations — all of which are very sensitive in nature — of operations against transnational organized crime, and particularly against terrorism. It produces stupor, but the fact is that we have been told that it did not occur maliciously. Well out! We could get there! That there would have been no less malicious leak by senior officials who are obliged to ensure cross-border European security against organised crime, a leak of all this extremely sensitive material. We therefore need an explanation, yes, but urgent, because the new Europol Regulation will enter into force in May 2017, which strengthens its capabilities on security penetration into the automated processing of personal data and the privacy of Europeans. So we need to be given absolute assurance that such security does not interfere with data protection rules and that protocols relating to that sensitive information are strengthened. If we also add that there is widespread unrest in the European Union with regard to the commitment to transparency on the part of the Commission and the Council, we have the right to know when that leak occurred, how this leak occurred, when this European Parliament was officially informed through the Committee on Freedoms Civil, Justice and Home Affairs, and how is it going to ensure that sensitive data leaks never again of personal security through a gross flash drive.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen (ALDE).
text: Mr President! Europol is at the heart of our everyone's defence against serious cross-border crime and increasingly in dealing with new terrorist threats and extremism. We have helped at ALDE to modernise and strengthen Europol in the new regulation, which will enter into force next May. We are delighted with many of the improvements we have helped to adopt. Improvements, which, among other things, ensure better data protection and should mean genuine scrutiny from both the European and national parliaments. But for me to see, that data breach in Holland is a problem that we might have avoided if we had had these new control tools. But it all requires, of course, for Europol to inform the European Parliament if there may be a breach of data. If it is to make sense of parliamentary control — what myself and ALDE are supporters of — then it requires Europol to inform, well to label before, that the media had to pick up stories and bring them on. And there I think there are still some answers that we have in terms of when that has been informed and on what basis has been informed. The threats of the future require cooperation between the police authorities and Europol. The exchange of data is a crucial prerequisite for this. That is why we must be able to trust institutions such as Europol to circumvent data securely. At ALDE, we are even ready to go even further and strengthen the exchange of data between the police of the member countries and even intelligence agencies, but this requires parliamentary scrutiny to work. It is parliamentary control that gives Europol democratic legitimacy, and there we must insist on the part of the European Parliament that Europol respect the playing field.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: — Mr President, I am surprised at this debate, biased by “human rights” speeches waving the presumption of innocence. Also surprised that you refused our group's request to discuss the situation in Aleppo, which, you will agree, is otherwise more crucial. It has not escaped me: Mrs in't Veld and the European Association for Human Rights are very shocked by the data leak at Europol. Obviously, the massive collection of data on citizens who have not committed any crime is a violation of freedoms. It is for this reason that my group has always regretted that no Member State of the European Union agrees to grant political asylum to Snowden. But what are we talking about here? Data on people linked to terrorist cases, including the terrible Islamist attacks in Madrid — 191 dead. Data protection is indispensable and such an incident is unfortunate from this point of view, but it is exaggerated to have as its main concern the respect for the fundamental rights of people involved in terrorist cases. It reminds me of your speeches defending the rights of the illegal, even if they are rapists, assassins or terrorists.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner. I wonder why we are actually having this debate at this time, because we are not achieving any added value with this debate. That's where human error happened. Yes, this must not happen, and yes, that is not right either, and yes, we must also follow the appropriate procedures. But at the moment we can't say anything more than: yes, data breaches are stupid, yes, and most likely the content of this data is not intended for everyone. Nevertheless, we have to take a procedural approach to this matter and say: yes, there is an investigation. The Commission has initiated this. It will also report to us accordingly on the effects of such an infringement. And we must actually insist that the institutions of the European Union will then also adapt to the General Data Protection Regulation or the Directive accordingly and to comply with the high standards of data protection established there. But the added value of this debate, just to ecauffeate itself that it's kind of bad with data and “if anything happens there” is no use. We'll need the results later.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, my concern about the episode involving Europol is not only linked to the type of information spread on the net, but also to the possible consequences as to the confidence of the States in the action to connect the Agency and the consequent willingness of the competent authorities to communicate data and information. But the seriousness of the episode must not make us lose sight of what, with commitment and not without difficulty, we are building in terms of cooperation in criminal law. From the most recent terrorist attacks we have learned that the exchange of information is a central element in the conduct of investigations to give a common and united response in the fight against terrorism and to organized crime. From the information leaked by the press, however, it emerges that the computer system was not violated, but it was human negligence, which is and remains serious. I therefore believe it is essential, also in relation to the extension of Europol's functions, that its director should report to the relevant parliamentary committee in order to better understand the events and to know the measures already taken to prevent such episodes from being repeated in the future.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, it is indisputable, everyone admits that there has been a serious problem in Europol, and the fact that it is old does not change the case. Of course, I admit, the fault is first of all individual. But this cannot overshadow the fact that there has been a real flaw in security control procedures, because finally, it is perfectly technically possible to prevent secure data from being copied by operators who have access to it. Europol must justify itself before the democratic bodies, that is to say, before the European Parliament, and explain the measures it has taken. Having said that, we need Europol, and I do not want some to take advantage of this incident to question the usefulness and credibility of Europol. It is not when thousands of jihadists are coming back to European territory, it is not when Europol's counter-terrorism centre becomes really operational that mines must be laid in order to undermine their credibility. Strengthen the rigour of management and security procedures, yes. Protect personal data, yes. Discredit Europol, no, radically no!

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: As has already been said by a number of colleagues today, Europe's greatest priority in the field of security is the better sharing of information by the Member States. In order to encourage better sharing, there must be confidence that that shared data will be handled in a good way. That trust got a strong dent two weeks ago. Call it a leak, call it a human error. The fact is, 700 pages of classified material were publicly insightful. I would have liked to have expected a somewhat sharper response from Europol and the European Commission. It is good that a security awareness seminar will be organised next Friday for Europol staff, but I would like to hear how to remove the weakest link from the system. The system is as strong as the weakest link. How are we going to ensure that it becomes technically impossible for this kind of human error to occur in the future in an organisation such as Europol? This is crucial to keeping Europol in the lead in fighting for better security in Europe.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in May of next year, a regulation will come into force granting Europol new powers to fight terrorism and cybercrime. However, this recent data leak represents a serious error, albeit an accidental one. We appear to have been fortunate this time, in that the leaked data was historical data. However, next time we might not be so fortunate. But even leaks of historical data can be of use to extremists. So could you please explain why it took two months for this Parliament to find out about the leak? What steps have been taken in terms of Europol policy to ensure that the risk of human error is as low as possible? I welcome greater cooperation between Member States in fighting international criminal threats, but we need to play our part and ensure that these sorts of errors are avoided.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, combating terrorism and combating cybercrime, which is carried out with complex investigations and sophisticated software. Data transmission and storage remains a moment of vulnerability. While waiting for the blockchain, methodical launched by Bitcoin, is also tested in the ordinary transmission of data, I have repeatedly expressed myself on cyber crime, which has offensive potential even in devices of yield. With my question of 15 December exactly two years ago, I questioned the Commission about three hundred life-saving devices at risk of cyber attack. It is yesterday's news that Google has launched Android Things, the new operating system dedicated to the Internet of things and I wonder how this can be protected from cyber crime. I therefore do not struggle to consider a sensitive sector such as Europol data completely vulnerable, precisely because of the important contribution made against the most serious forms of crime, such as trafficking narcotics, pedophilia, human trafficking, terrorism, fraud and bank cards. Much higher production standards need to be adopted.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, a few days ago it became known that more than seven hundred classified pages of Europol were leaked to the Internet including names and telephone numbers of natural persons. Despite the constant increase in Europol's budget, especially in the area of combating terrorism, we see that the results are disappointing. In addition to the failure to prevent terrorist attacks in France and Belgium, Europol is now suffering from internal leaks of classified files. Of course, more emphasis must be placed on the fight against terrorism, but Europol needs to be more effective and, above all, the privacy of the citizens of the Union must always be respected. That is why there must be increased parliamentary control over Europol itself and also control by the European independent data protection authority. The fact that it took too long to inform Parliament of this issue shows that there is even more rigorous parliamentary control over Europol's activities.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: –  Mr President, I congratulate the management of Europol, under its excellent British director Rob Wainwright, in the conduct of the untoward incident investigation into the breach of historic terrorist data security by a journalist and a rule-breaking former staff member. Europol has proven the integrity and reputation of the organisation, and appropriate measures to remedy the breaches are now in place for the future. I wish to take this opportunity to congratulate my country, the United Kingdom – in spite of the Brexit referendum – to wisely recently re-join Europol, and ways must now be found post-Brexit for a strategic UK-Europol partnership to ensure continuing access by my country to SIS, the Prüm Database, the PNR and the EAW. Otherwise the United Kingdom will be in a serious and unnecessarily dangerous situation for the security of its citizens in the future.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as the new Europol regulation will come into force in May 2017, its competences will be expanded and Europol will handle even more sensitive information and personal data, it is absolutely crucial that the data processing is done according to strict adherence to the data protection rules and data security requirements. The breach poses larger questions about the data protection standards of this agency. Leaked information may also strain relations with other EU states who may be reluctant to share data if it is not properly secured. The Commission and the Council must explain how the data breach was possible. Why did Europol first deny the leak and then admit it? How is the downloading of information even possible from the Europol database to an external device? Commissioner, this is a very important and serious matter.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as always, I have listened carefully to your interventions and I fully share your concerns. This incident should never have happened in the agency in charge of so much data at the very epicentre of our counter—terrorist work. I understand that trust may be shaken, but let us look at the facts once again. It was a human error which in practice would have been prevented today. Judicial investigations have been launched. No current investigation in the Member States has been jeopardised. The lives of private citizens were not affected. Security procedures have been updated and will be further strengthened with the new Europol regulation from 1 May. Data protection supervision is also being stepped up. The professionalism of the staff is ensured by continuous training to prevent such incidents from recurring. Let us be clear. Europol is a very different organisation today from 2009 when this incident occurred. As I said in my opening remarks, enhanced security goes hand in hand with enhanced data protection and security rules. Mr Díaz de Mera García was quite correct when he said that this was an unfortunate, but isolated, incident. It cannot – and will not – happen again. Mr Albrecht is also absolutely right: data protection and data security standards should be stepped up. Mrs in 't Veld, Europol’s systems were not hacked or intruded into. There was, as I said before, human error with an external hard drive. This cannot happen again. Europol has informed us that ongoing investigations have not been compromised, and the Member States concerned have confirmed that. Europol informed us – and you – and all the other parties concerned after the press reports. In its current rules, we are external parties. In future, with the new Europol regulation, the EU will scrutinise Europol’s activities through the Joint Parliamentary Scrutiny Group. This group will be briefed about key Europol operational aspects. We will examine whether Europol should, as a general obligation, inform the Commission and the parliamentary group on security breaches in order to allow them to exercise their oversight responsibilities. Let us draw lessons from this experience and make sure that the margin for human error of this type disappears.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, on the first question, why did Europol not inform the European Parliament, Council, the Commission or other public stakeholders before 30 November? You would understand that it is not for me, representing the Presidency, to answer in the place of Europol. That’s not for me. (But you’re in charge.) I am not in charge of Europol, I am in charge of the Presidency. But I can say that Europol has explained that it could not release information about an ongoing security and judicial investigation at national level, including sensitive classified information, to the general public or other stakeholders not directly affected. As a mitigating measure, when the case was reported on 30 November 2016, Europol immediately provided background information to its external stakeholders, in order to clarify the certain elements which were subject of the reporting in the media. Secondly, the future Europol regulation provides strong security guarantees and a robust data protection regime, and this will I am sure contribute to increasing our trust in Europol. Finally – important for this House – this new regulation sets out a new and better mechanism to brief the European Parliament about operation-sensitive matters. It provides for working arrangements to be concluded between Europol and the Parliament in line with the EU rules on handling classified information. Mr President, honourable Members, I too would like to use this opportunity for thanking you all for good cooperation during the Slovak Presidency.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: (addressed to Mrs in T'veld who asks for the floor) I am sorry, Mrs in T'veld, but the list of speakers is also closed. I can't give you the floor. If you wish, you can make a comment.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE).
text: –  Mr President, I don’t know the rules by heart, but we have a debate here about something very serious. I’d like to remind colleagues that in any Member State such an incident would have led to the resignation of the politically responsible, and here it’s treated as a technical incident. I have asked very precise questions and I do not get an answer. Three questions: when were people informed? The list of people I understand from you – after the media revelations – but I’d like to get a ‘yes or no’ confirmation. Two, when was the LIBE Chair informed, and under what conditions? Was there a confidentiality clause? And three, how are you (well that is more the Commission, but you are actually responsible as Council for Europol) going to secure data stored in decentralised systems like PNR and others? Can I have an answer to those questions?

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Mrs in't Veld, it was not exactly a point of order, but if the President of the Slovak Presidency wishes, he can answer.

name: Ivan Korčok
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – I think Madam in ˈt Veld, I have shared with you what is in my competence as a representative of the Council Presidency. I reiterate once again, if your are having questions to Europol, I am not representing Europol. I have present a position of the Council, and if you ask me about when the president of LIBE was informed, he is here.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE).
text: –  (inaudible)... unacceptable. I would like that to be in the minutes.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: What Mrs in t'Veld and the response of the Council representative have been recorded. The discussion is over. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — We constantly reiterate here the need to increase Europol's powers more and more. And I fully agree with that. But more powers must go in hand with strengthening the organization's internal structure, its internal rules and staff discipline. Otherwise, I fear that there may be a breach of trust not only in Europol itself, but above all the trust between the Member States on which this whole cooperation in criminal matters is based; and without which even the EU itself cannot function. We all need to be vigilant about how we handle the information and data we have access to and we work with. It has to be commonplace for us. At Europol, however, this is particularly sensitive data that, in the extreme case, may threaten the entire EU. Data covering individual cases of crime, organised crime or even terrorism. I strongly believe that the leadership of Europol, headed by Rob Wainwright, will ensure that a similar situation never happens again, has no negative effects, and above all, does not affect cooperation between Member States which have so far been on an excellent path to achieving the best possible results.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item is the debate on the question with a request for oral reply to the Commission on visa reciprocity obligations by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs ( 000142/2016 - B8-1820/2016) (2016/2986 (RSP)).

name: Claude Moraes
text: author. – Mr President, thank you for the invitation to answer questions in a previous debate. It was very kind of you to do so. What I will do on the Europol data leak debate, for which I was given no speaking time by my political group, is to answer Mrs in 't Veld in detail in the committee. I was informed in due course by Europol and, through full transparency, I will inform Mrs in 't Veld and the whole committee of how I was informed. Thank you for that opportunity. It is much welcomed. We now come to the important oral question, which many colleagues have been waiting for, on the very important, compelling and urgent issue of visa reciprocity. As colleagues will know, this is an ongoing issue of urgency, not just for those five countries and the citizens of those five countries – Poland, Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia and Cyprus – but indeed a matter of principle for the whole House on questions of symmetry and equality in our relationship with the United States.  In 2013, Parliament and the Council adopted a regulation modifying, amongst other elements, the so-called reciprocity mechanism. It entered into force in January 2014. Under EU law and according to this mechanism, if a third country does not lift visa requirements 24 months after notification of a situation of non—reciprocity, the Commission is obliged to suspend the visa waiver for citizens of that country for 12 months, via a delegated act to which Parliament and the Council could object.  Notifications of five Member States – and I have named them – were published by the Commission on 12 April 2014. There were at times cases of non—reciprocity also affecting Australia, Japan and Brunei and all of them have now been solved. After 24 months had elapsed, on 12 April 2016, the Commission, instead of presenting the delegated act as we required, decided to publish a communication asking the Council and Parliament for their views. This communication was followed by another communication on 13 July updating the situation and again failing to fulfil the Commission’s obligations.  As Chair of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, it is my view that the reciprocity mechanism sets out a procedure with precise time frames and actions not subject to discretionality by the Commission. Therefore, the Commission is under an obligation to adopt a delegated act pursuant to Article 1(4)(f) of Regulation 539/2001.  As the Commissioner knows, on 7 June 2016, I sent a letter reminding you, Commissioner, of the legal obligations of the Commission here. On 12 October, during the exchange we had with you in the Civil Liberties Committee, the Commission was again urged to act and all the Members who took the floor made it clear that the Commission does have some more room for manoeuvre. This was our view.  In this context, and with an overwhelming majority, we have in the Civil Liberties Committee adopted the following oral question for answer today: do you share the legal assessment according to which the Commission is obliged to adopt a delegated act – temporarily suspending the exemption from the visa requirement for nationals of third countries which have not lifted the visa requirement for citizens of certain EU Member States – within a period of 24 months from the date of publication of the notifications in this regard, which ended on 12 April 2016? In the event that the Commission agrees with the assessment that it is obliged to adopt a delegated act, by when will the Commission present this delegated act? And finally, if the Commission does not agree, what are the reasons for not agreeing with that assessment? This issue, as I said at the beginning of my presentation of this oral question, is not just about the deep and very understandable concerns of our colleagues from Poland, Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia and Cyprus; it is about the idea that we in the EU have the right to expect symmetry and equality with the United States in our relationship. We are right to expect fairness. The right to expect fairness is something that we have transmitted directly to our United States partners and to the State Department in Washington, and we did so respectfully and forcefully. I believe now is the time that we need to find answers from the Commission on this very important issue. It is a troubling issue which is now persistent and this oral question comes at a time when I do believe my colleagues from these particular countries – but I do insist, well beyond those countries, and within the Civil Liberties Committee – want to find answers. So Commissioner, please try to answer these, I know, very difficult questions on visa reciprocity but which go to the heart of our relationship on visa fairness.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the Parliament, let me start by telling you that I welcome the opportunity to discuss this very important matter, being already fully aware of your expectations. In October I discussed this with the members of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). You will remember that, Mr Moraes. It should be clear that we all share the same objective. Full visa reciprocity is the central principle of our visa policy framework. With the United States and Canada it is a challenging and sensitive issue, and we all hope for tangible progress.  Before responding to the questions, let me start with the good news concerning Canada. As I told you in the past, I used the window of opportunity offered to us, the EU-Canada summit. A series of meetings and discussions were held ahead in order to reach a mutually satisfactory agreement. I took the plane myself to meet in person the Canadian Immigration Minister John McCallum, in order to address the real situation at political and not at technocratic level. We had a very constructive discussion with the minister and we agreed to engage in a political process to address each other’s concerns and make the lifting of visa obligations for Romania and Bulgaria possible. Indeed, and as I had hinted in my meeting with LIBE, Canada took a positive decision in line with the commitment of McCallum in July. At the summit Canada announced its decision to lift in late 2017 the visa requirements for all Bulgarian and Romanian citizens. Moreover, certain categories of Bulgarian and Romanian travellers who visited Canada in the past 10 years, or who currently possess a valid visa issued by the United States, will already become visa-free from 1 May 2017. We all welcome very much this outcome. It is a strong indication that diplomatic channels and engagement can achieve positive results. On this point, I would like to thank Members of Parliament for their constructive contribution too. We worked in close coordination with Bulgaria and Romania and they played a central role in addressing Canadian concerns. We have to continue this path to ensure that full visa waiver is achieved. The Commission will continue to do its part, in full cooperation with both Member States. Now the situation with the United States is different. While I continue discussions with our US partners, most recently at the EU-US JHA Ministerial Meeting on 5 December in Washington, there is no progress to report. But I want to assure you that I will keep this issue high on the agenda with the new administration and Congress. I will personally immediately engage in conference with my new counterparts. I call on all of you to give a chance for the political discussion to take place and to explain the mutual obligations, reservations, goals and work to find a solution.  It is very important to understand that the role of Congress is crucial. The visa waiver programme cannot be expanded without Congress, particularly if Member States do not meet the thresholds of US legislation. It seems certain that temporarily suspending the visa waiver for US citizens would immediately lead to a visa requirement imposed on all EU citizens. We are aiming for the opposite, not a reciprocal visa requirement but a reciprocal visa waiver. Let me be very clear. The Commission would not hesitate to adopt the respective acts if that would improve the situation of EU citizens, and lead to the visa waiver for all. At the same time, the Commission has a responsibility to inform you, the co-legislators, about negative consequences on the EU and its citizens from the implementation of our rules.  And this leads me to your questions. There is a regulation that says ‘the Commission shall adopt a delegated act’. But there are also other requirements and obligations to be followed which are difficult to reconcile with this obligation, and which are equally important. The same regulation says that: ‘the Commission shall take into account the consequences of the suspension of the exemption from the visa requirements for the external relations of the Union and its Member States with the third country in question’. The approach we put forward back in April outlined these adverse consequences. We still consider that the negative impacts we identified, which were not questioned by other institutions and stakeholders, should be taken fully into account. If a visa requirement is reintroduced, it will be difficult to explain to millions of EU citizens travelling to the United States every year that the EU serves their interests and that the EU action was appropriate in this case. Would legal arguments be convincing for thousands of EU citizens that would likely lose their jobs due to the expected decrease of US visitors? I very much doubt it.  A recent study for the World Travel and Tourism Council suggests that suspending the visa waiver would annually lead to a 22% drop in visitors to the European Union, or 5.5 million fewer visitors from the United States and Canada. This will be equal to a loss of EUR 6.8 billion annually, risking the loss of 140 000 jobs in the tourism industry. The most affected Member States will be Italy, Spain, France, Germany, the Netherlands and Poland. I am asking the question: can we really afford that loss? Dear Members of Parliament, we are in a very unpleasant situation, but determined to work to achieve visa-free travel for all EU citizens to the United States, as we managed to do with Canada. Let us work together in this effort.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, in full agreement with what Mr Moraes said. But I would like to make it clear that today we are discussing a procedural issue, not a matter of substance. I am very sincerely grateful for the Commission's efforts with Canada, but I must likewise say that I regret that the Commission is not complying with Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 which, in Article 1 (4) (f), clearly states that, if within 24 months after the date of publication of the notification, the third country concerned has not abolished the visa obligation, the Commission shall adopt a delegated act amending Annex II and suspending the visa exemption for nationals of the third country concerned — the United States — for a period of 12 months. Its room for manoeuvre is void and confirmed by the Court of Justice of the Union in its judgment of 16 July 2015. It is never said there that the Commission will present a communication or two, or that we will ask an oral question in plenary. What the Commission is doing with this attitude is simply in failure to comply with the Regulation. We are then facing a clear interinstitutional problem, and the Commission must act as the real guarantor of the Treaties. In view of this situation, I call for the Regulation to be respected and that the delegated act be presented. It will then be us, the co-legislators, who will debate the adequacy and the political, economic and other consequences. What needs to be done is to launch the delegated act because it is more important that the visa be removed from Poland, Romania, Bulgaria, Cyprus and Croatia. There is no progress, Commissioner, as you say, so launch the delegated act.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President. Commissioner Avramopoulos, I am speaking to reinforce the alarm, which was clearly expressed on behalf of the entire Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs by its chairman, our colleague Claude Moraes. And also to underline the arguments of Popular Party spokesman Agustín Díaz de Mera. This is not just a matter of substance, which is the lack of reciprocity — inadmissible on a matter such as visas — on the part of the United States. After the successful completion of the procedure with Brunei, Canada and Japan, it has not been successfully completed with the United States, which continue to deny the common visa policy that corresponds to the European Union as a whole at least five countries: Romania, Poland, Bulgaria, Croatia and Cyprus. That is the bottom issue, a lack of reciprocity that has no view of improving with the new Trump administration in the White House. Quite the opposite. We have to say it clearly. The question is therefore to bear in mind that substantive scenario, but also to require that the Commission comply with the procedure laid down in the Basic Visa Regulation, which is the issuance of a delegated act deducting the consequences of this absence of reciprocity in the relationship with the United States, in accordance with various judgments of the Court of Justice. Because — it is not forgotten — the soul of this European Parliament is not just an oral question before the Commission. It is also the Commission's absence of reply to the Court of Justice. And that lack of response has to be satisfied as soon as possible. A delegated act which will deduce the political and legal consequences of this situation, which is politically intolerable, but which legally and legally binds and competes the Commission and Commissioner Avramopoulos. It is therefore not only about honoring that demand — which has often been stressed by the vast majority of this House — that Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia and Cyprus, in addition to Poland, should be treated exactly the same as the rest of the European Union countries, but that the Commission should talk about you to the United States about you.

name: Филиз Хюсменова
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — Mr President, Commissioner, the lack of visa reciprocity with the United States of America affects millions of European citizens in Bulgaria, Romania, Croatia, Cyprus and Poland. As a citizen of a directly affected country and as shadow rapporteur for ALDE on this subject, I am strongly and unreservedly committed to achieving real visa reciprocity for Europeans. Until now, it has repeatedly been pointed out by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs that the European Commission is obliged to take action to address the lack of visa reciprocity, by a delegated act temporarily suspending visa-free regime for US citizens. I take into account the diplomatic sensitivity and the need to find the right time and means to achieve maximum results in relations with the US, but I believe that it is high time for the Commission to take a decisive stance and show that the different treatment of European citizens is inadmissible. This is the opinion shared by the majority of my colleagues on the LIBE committee of the European Parliament. I use the moment again in this debate to point out that the inaction of the European Commission creates the feeling of a double standard, of a two-speed Europe and for different classes of Europeans. It certainly undermines the credibility of the institutions of European citizens from the countries concerned, but it also predetermines how a united Europe looks to the outside world. I therefore call on the Commission to fulfil its role as guardian of treaties in protecting the interests of all European citizens by unequivocally showing the administrative will to fulfil its obligations and political power to open up a worthy place for the European Union on the world stage.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened very carefully to your presentation. I set out three important things in it. First of all, visa reciprocity is a fundamental principle of the European Union's common visa policy. I am glad that, just as this issue is a priority for my country Bulgaria, it is also for the European Commission. The concrete results with the negotiated phase-out of visas for Bulgarians and Romanians are proof that only with coordinated action between the Commission and the Member States — but here it is time to take into account the European Parliament as well — we can make progress. That is why I am also paying attention to the second aspect, so that we continue to speak with one voice on the international stage. We must take very seriously into account that the current situation creates a feeling of a different category of countries and citizens of the European Union. This negative trend can have very long-term consequences. Finally, thank you, Commissioner, for your efforts so far. An overtaking action is the clear highlighting of the negative consequences of certain actions. But also because of this, I call for a strong stand with all the instruments of diplomacy so that, while defending the authority of the European Union, we can meet the expectations of all European citizens. (The speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162 (8))).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – In fact, I am Romanian and she is Bulgarian. We should ask the Commission together – and this is the question to you – why does the Commission not approach all the EU Member States in a non—discriminatory way? At the same time, why does it not apply the important values of solidarity and equality? I would also like also to hear from you if you asked the Commission why it did not comply with the obligation to adopt a delegated act, temporarily suspending, for 12 months, the visa waiver for nationals of a third country in those cases of non-respect of the visa reciprocity principle?

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card. — I would like to thank my Romanian colleague. I think he was very clear. We are asking general questions here today, we want equal treatment for all EU member states, and we want and hear carefully what the consequences of decision-making are. I therefore rather join his call — that we should very clearly assert our principle that all citizens of the Union are so and for the European Union to have sufficient rigidity and, on the international stage, to continue to do so, while upholding, I say again, our principles. Our legitimacy as the European Union towards our citizens depends on this.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, since 13 April 2016, the European Commission has clearly shown that it prefers to violate its own legislation rather than impose visas for the United States. This country discriminates against the citizens of Bulgaria, Romania, Poland, Cyprus and Croatia. The European Commission has shown no solidarity with those over 70 million Europeans. On the contrary, she chose to break the law even after a ruling by the European Court of Justice. It is shameful that Boyko Borissov's Bulgarian government has been dutifully silent and continues to remain silent on the issue. On the contrary, it gives consent against the discrimination of its own fellow citizens. If the Bulgarian government does not have the courage to defend Bulgaria's interest, I will seek all legal channels for the European Commission to be judged for its inaction. In a month, this same Commission will not be late to criticise Bulgaria through the proven ineffective mechanism for cooperation and verification for non-compliance with the law. Does she do it herself? The law applies to everyone, not just the strong of the day.

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner. I can already understand the criticism of my fellow Members. Of course, it is nice that we also have a common visa law within the EU, and if anything applies to Canadian and US citizens, it must be the other way around. I can understand that. Equal treatment is actually something that must and should be demanded and which we should also stick to. But I would also like to say that the transatlantic relationship is not exactly in the best place now and that there is no need to break down things here that may have been built up with difficulty and hardship. So this means that once again demanding a visa requirement for Canadian or US citizens is not right either. I think it is disproportionate to require a visa requirement for the United States or Canada, while at the same time we have visa-free travel for Georgia and Ukraine.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union is strong when it speaks with one voice. Therefore, the visa reciprocity mechanism requires a collective and solidarity response when discriminatory visa restrictions apply to European citizens. Why, Commissioner, do we have this legislation, if we do not comply with it? I believe that it is unacceptable for the European Commission to continue to delay the implementation of the delegated act proposing a temporary suspension of the visa-free regime for US citizens. I also believe that this prevents not only direct business contacts and partnership, cultural and tourist exchanges between us, but also undermines our strategic links and partnership relations. For Bulgaria, achieving full visa reciprocity is an absolute priority and I am delighted in the efforts of the Bulgarian government, which have been made, both in relation to Canada and the United States, at any meeting with representatives of the Congress, with representatives of the administration. We require them to happen as quickly as possible. Unfortunately, we see a reluctance on the part of both the US Congress and the current administration to make steps in that direction. I therefore call on the Commission to issue this delegated act.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, visa reciprocity is a fundamental element of the European Union's common visa policy. The aim of the common policy is to achieve full reciprocity, visa waiver for all Member States of the Union. So we see that the United States, Canada until a moment ago, and Brunei continue to impose visas on citizens of certain Member States of the European Union, despite the fact that their own citizens have a visa waiver. In particular, we have heard that this is Romania, Bulgaria, Poland, Croatia and Cyprus, i.e. the citizens of these countries are discriminated against from the United States. I consider what the Commissioner has said about Canada to be an important development. We should therefore, with one voice, support the European Union's efforts to ensure equal treatment for all citizens, so that such discrimination does not exist.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, Dear Lord Commissioner, who will respect European laws if not the Commission? Who will protect European law if not the European Commission? Who will protect European citizens if the European Commission will not do so? And here we are not talking about distrust in member states that still do not have the right to visa reciprocity, among other things, the country from which I come, Croatia, whose citizens in that case feel second-class citizens. This is about distrust in the institutions of the European Union. Not about distrust in member states, but in the institutions of the European Union. If we continue with this tactical policy, how much is it going to cost us? How much money are we gonna lose? Money, when it comes to principles, principles and respect for rights, must be in a different plan. I think we understand each other very well when we talk about it. We expect your directive, we expect your decision, as soon as possible, not to say immediately.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, inequalities between European citizens are unbearable. This non-reciprocity for the citizens of certain countries actually makes them, as has been said, second or even third-zone citizens, since Romanians and Bulgarians are double penalized, once by Canada and once by the United States. You are telling us that this is good for Canada, of which act. So much the better! It nevertheless took the blackmail of Romania and Bulgaria for non-signature of CETA in order for us to arrive at some results. But it is still good news. I will simply ask you why it is necessary to wait until the end of 2017 for this measure to be finally implemented. It is not the same with the United States. You're telling us that there is no breakthrough with this country. So, start the procedure! There is no solution. If the United States does not want to hear anything, we must implement the rules that exist. The negative impact would not only be for European citizens, it would also be for American citizens. Your catastrophic figures are not serious, Commissioner. These are assumptions and it is also a lack of confidence in the European institutions. Be sure of yourself and discuss equally with the United States. The Commission is the guardian of the Treaties, which has also been said. If itself does not respect the rules, it is true that the European Union is very badly in a position.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Mr President, I take the floor, not to say the obvious, that I too support the voices of colleagues in order to remove this injustice which is happening to many citizens of the European Union, namely that the American Government does not give what we are giving itself. I didn't take the floor just for the obvious. I would like to say that there is also a joint responsibility between the Member States enjoying this right and my fellow MEPs from the Member States enjoying this right, and I think that the Commissioner can make use of the Member States which have this right so that to exert more pressure, to put pressure not only on the countries concerned, but also on the other States. They have a responsibility to this issue.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, dear Members of the Parliament, I heard your interventions very carefully. I want to assure you again that we are on the same side. We share the same objective: that is, nothing less than full visa reciprocity for all our citizens. This is our goal. Our approach with Canada brought positive results. It was not the result of blackmailing. It was the result of frank and friendly negotiations, and I know that because I was behind it. We didn’t resort to unilateral suspensions there, we did not damage our bilateral relations. On the contrary, with patient engagement, diplomatic contacts and explanations from all sides, we managed to get a concrete roadmap to visa liberalisation. Your role, dear Members, was crucial in that respect. Mr Díaz de Mera, Mr López Aguilar, the Commission, you know that, is a law-abiding institution. We are aware and conscious of our legal obligations, but as I said, it is not just about adopting the delegated acts, it is also about taking into account the consequences. I was very clear and frank before, not hiding behind pretexts, as I always am here. Even adopting the act will most likely result in retaliations by the United States. As I said: yes, it is an unpleasant situation, but I have been, and I will keep on being, open and frank with you.  I call on you to show some patience while the political transition in the United States is completed. Once the new Administration is fully in place, we will make the point as strongly as we can. EU citizens in their vast majority do not constitute a threat. For those very few that could potentially do so, our security framework is in place and is getting stronger every day. We will continue to work hard in close cooperation with the Member States, with all Member States concerned, and of course with you to resolve the remaining cases, and will keep you fully informed. Next week as we committed last July, we will present the state of play in a second follow-up to our April communication. The road ahead will not be easy and we know it, but working together we can bring results in the case of the United States also.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Discussion is over. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. — Although Croatia is the closest of 5 Member States to meet the official criteria and join the Visa Waiver Programme, it is absolutely unacceptable that all EU citizens are not treated equally when the free movement of citizens is concerned. More so if the EU has ambitions of striking a trade deal with the US on the free exchange of goods and services. Free movement of people must be a prerequisite for the free exchange of goods and services. European rules are clear in this regard. I hope that this issue can be resolved soon and that the 5 remaining EU Member States will be included in the visa exemption scheme, which would avoid the introduction of visas for US citizens when travelling to the EU. A recent example of achieving visa reciprocity between the EU and Canada revoking visas for citizens of Bulgaria and Romania shows that it is possible. Unless we reach the same agreement with the US, I expect the Commission to comply with its legal obligations and present a Delegated Act opening up the possibility of suspending visa-free regime for US citizens when they travel to the EU.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. — On 1 January 2017 Bulgaria will mark the tenth anniversary of its EU membership - ten years in which we are constantly trying to prove that we are an equal partner in Europe and around the world. Unfortunately, this struggle continues and the fact that we from Bulgaria, along with five Member States, are the only ones who need visas to travel to the US is an example of double standards and unequal treatment of Bulgarian citizens. As a Bulgarian representative, I find such an attitude unacceptable, especially on the part of the European Commission. It is its duty to apply EU law to protect all European citizens and Member States. It is unacceptable to place the interests of our international partners above the rights of Europeans. I therefore urge the European Commission to respect its legal obligation and to come forward as quickly as possible with a delegated act in accordance with Regulation 1289/2013, so that it can be discussed by the European Parliament and the Council. It is also necessary for the Commission to hold active negotiations with the new US presidential administration in order to continue action to abolish US visas for citizens of the five member states. We already have such a positive example with Canada and I hope that we will see a solution to the US issue as soon as possible.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. – The stand—off on the signature of CETA between Romania and Bulgaria and Canada, which ended in an agreement to remove visa obligations for the two eastern European countries by the end of 2017, showed that the enforcement of the EU visa reciprocity mechanism is indeed possible for all European countries if enough pressure is applied from the European side. It is sad, however, that when presenting this agreement, the President of the European Commission mentioned that the citizens of the countries in question are entitled to these visa rights, but on the other hand made it clear that this visa liberalisation is still dependent on the adoption of the trade agreement. I believe that it is time that the Commission, instead of issuing communications, took concrete measures to ensure that third countries stop differentiating between EU Member States and between EU citizens.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item is Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the attack on the Coptic Cathedral in Cairo - Religious freedom and freedom of belief (2016/3037 (RSP))

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, last Sunday we were appalled when Coptic Christians were targeted as they were worshipping at St Peter’s Coptic Orthodox Church in Cairo. At least 25 people were killed and many more injured in the bombing. Our thoughts are with the victims and their families. The European Union expresses condolences to them as well as to all the people and the Government of Egypt.  An attack against Egypt’s Coptic community is an attack against all Egyptians and against their wish to live peacefully together. I visited Egypt recently because it is a key partner in the region for the European Union on many issues and we had a very fruitful discussion on all issues. I also met President el-Sisi and we also discussed security issues. They were aware that the situation is very difficult and attacks might occur at any moment.  These attacks endanger a multicultural society, which Egypt is and wishes to continue being. President el-Sisi is equally concerned about the destabilisation of his country as a result of the permanent terrorist threat. I assured him that we are partners against this common threat and Egypt has all our support.  Freedom of religion implies not only the freedom of belief, but also the freedom to worship, either individually or in a community, without fear or intimidation, discrimination, violence or attack. All people should be able to exercise their rights everywhere, based on the principles of equality, non—discrimination and universality. All states have an obligation to prevent violence based on religion or belief but, beyond this obligation, the prevention of this form of violence is also in the interest of every state because sectarian attacks make a society weaker, less cohesive and less resilient.  In the Middle East and North Africa in particular, an attack against any ethnic or religious group undermines the very fabric of society. Christianity belongs in the Middle East and in North Africa just as much as it belongs in Europe. Egypt’s Christian community is as ancient as Christianity itself. Obviously terrorist groups and individuals are afraid of the Middle East’s long history of diversity because it defies their weak narrative of a clash of civilizations. The Egyptian authorities must now work to ensure that the perpetrators of this attack are promptly brought to justice and that there will be no impunity for sectarian attacks. Overall, the number of terrorist attacks in Egypt has grown in recent weeks. Just two days before the attack on the church, there were two terrorist bombings in different parts of the country, killing security personnel. We stand on the side of the Egyptian people in the fight against terrorism. It is a shared challenge which we must tackle together. Terrorism, of course, needs to be addressed as a security issue. At the same time, measures to reinforce physical security will only be effective if police and judicial prevention and prosecution of terrorist acts is organised in a modern and effective manner. Countering radicalisation and violent extremism is also of fundamental importance.  We believe that a comprehensive approach is needed, including dialogue, education, the promotion of tolerance and pluralism, and adequate space for civil society. We are close to completing negotiations with Egypt on the priorities for our bilateral partnership and this terrible incident shows how essential it is becoming for us to work together with Egypt in this area, as in many others.  The importance the European Union attaches to freedom of religion and belief has also been reflected in the appointment by President Juncker of Mr Ján Figeľ as a Special Envoy for the promotion of freedom of religion or belief outside the European Union. The EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Mr Lambrinidis, has also been actively engaged in the promotion of freedom of religion and belief during official visits to partner countries and in multilateral fora. Our work to preserve religious diversity all around the world also has a financial dimension. For instance, the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights invests EUR 11 million in programmes focusing directly on freedom of religion and belief. Cooperation with our partners, both in governance and civil society will remain essential to all our efforts. From Egypt to Syria, the protection of diversity is – and will be -– a top priority in the years ahead. If there is one international actor that will always protect and defend the freedom of religion, it is us, the European Union. Let me therefore conclude by sending a strong message of support to Egypt. We are all standing by Egypt, united against the common threat of terrorism.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, a horrible crime was committed last Sunday in Cairo during a Coptic worship, and we know that it has caused many, many victims. Today is our opportunity to condemn this massacre, for which ISIS has taken responsibility, in the strongest possible terms and extend our solidarity to all victims of terror and violence.  It is true that the government has a primary responsibility to guarantee security and equality of all religions in Egypt. However, I think there are also some positive signals. The Coptic Pope Tawadros declared that the terror attack was conducted not only against the Coptic Church but against all of Egypt, and a leading Islamic university, Al-Azhar, qualified the attacks against houses of worship and killing innocents as criminal acts that violate Islamic principles. Egyptian President el-Sisi proclaimed a three-day national mourning and ordered state funerals. These demonstrations of shared solidarity are important. But now even more important is that the Egyptian people as a whole will recognise the ownership of such tragedies and victims. That supposes that also in everyday life, people will start to treat co-citizens from different religions as equals and start to respect them.

name: Javi López
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President. First of all, on behalf of my group and on my own behalf, we want to send a message of solidarity to the victims — especially after a terrorist attack like this, that of 10 December, in the Coptic Cathedral in Cairo, with more than twenty victims — and not only to the victims, but also to their families, to the Coptic community in its together and to the Egyptian people. We know the importance of the Coptic community, we know that it has been one of the minorities that has been systematically attacked by jihadists in recent years and has more than 85 million people and represents 8 per cent of Egypt's total population. At the same time, we would like to recognize on a day like today that President al-Sisi places security as one of his main concerns and that he has condemned the attack and helped the victims during these days. But it must be remembered — also very clearly — that terrorism is combated with security measures but, at the same time, terrorism is defeated by an effective fight, which means inclusive governance and means defending human rights and respecting religious freedom.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, life for the Coptic Christians of Egypt has considerably improved since President el-Sisi came to power. Honouring the victims by way of a state funeral and three days of national mourning is a powerful signal that this was not an attack on a minority community but an attack on all Egyptians. The attack on Saint Mark’s Cathedral is a stark reminder of the protection that this vulnerable community needs and the security threats that Egypt faces more generally on a daily basis.  Claimed today by ISIS, this atrocity is an early warning sign of the trend that we will see over the coming year as ISIS shifts its focus to North Africa and the Sahel, and Mosul and Raqqa are squeezed, and as their strongholds in Syria are weakened they will go to other places including, I am afraid, Europe.  In its statement today ISIS threatened to escalate its war on polytheism and to extend its attacks beyond the Sinai Peninsula. Egypt is a strategic partner of the European Union and is battling to contain the threats of high unemployment, a struggling economy, terrorism and the political transition following the fall of Mubarak. We in the European Union now need to support Egypt in these struggles and to better understand the threats that it faces.

name: Marisa Matias
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, we obviously condemn this attack, as we condemn all the horrific terrorist attacks that have taken place in recent times. But I think it's important to talk about this attack on the Coptic community to make a very clear message. It is not a war of religions that we are talking about, it is not a war of civilisations, and we in this Parliament cannot fall into that trap. All the victims count, whatever creed they are. We therefore have an obligation not to feed hatred, the same hatred from which the terrorism that causes these victims is fuelled. We can't be complicit in the washing that is done. There are no lives worth more than others. Our role is a role of acting on the causes, of understanding that this was an attack on the entire Egyptian people. The Egyptian people united, and united in three days of mourning. It is up to us to draw attention to each of these attacks and to have a solidarity response in relation to the humanitarian crisis we are experiencing, but, as I said, above all to act on the causes and not give more importance to some lives than others. They're all equally important.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this barbaric act was a shameless attack on an ancient centre of Christianity. Naturally I wish to express my sincere condolences to all those affected. This was not just an attack on a Coptic Christian community but on all Egyptians. I am encouraged how Egyptian society, which is of course made up of many different faiths, has widely condemned this atrocity, and moved swiftly to show their support for Egypt’s Coptic Christians. The presidential decision to give the victims state funerals and the announcement of three days’ national mourning must be acknowledged as a noble act of inclusiveness.  However, this tragedy again highlights the precarious position facing Christian communities across the Middle East and North Africa. Governments have a duty to protect their minorities, and we must do more to support those Christians fleeing persecution from Islamic fundamentalists.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, a death device exploded on Sunday 11 December in the church of St. Peter and St. Paul in Cairo. At least 25 people lost their lives and 49 others were injured, including a majority of them women and children. Christians living in Muslim countries are threatened in their flesh. In Iraq and Syria, ISIS monsters still have genocidal voices. Do not believe that only Christians of the East are threatened; the security of Christians is no longer assured in Europe. A priest was slaughtered in his church of Saint-Pierre-du-Rouvray by young French Islamists of paper, to whom our country had given everything. Churches are regularly the targets of anti-Christian acts of vandalism without it seems to be really moving anyone. It is time to protect Christians in the East and Europe from the revival of fighting Islam. At a time when the European Union seems to want to submit itself in full dhimmitude, let us sound the tocsin for the victims. Later it will be too late.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE).
text: - Mr. President! The Islamic State's assassination in Cairo targeted Egyptian Christians, but the Egyptians, Copts and Muslims seeking peaceful coexistence were jointly attacked. We offer our condolences to the young and elderly victims of the terrorist attack at the ceremony and to their grieving family members. Symbolic is the plot, the misdeed, that the members of the communities practising their Christian religion were murdered during the period of festive preparation. Their goal, Mr. President, was nothing less than to spread a culture of fear and death in the Middle East and throughout the world. What's the assignment? The security of Christians and other religious minorities must be guaranteed by an international community in the Middle East. Europe must help to secure the security of Christian and other religious minorities in their homeland, I would like to stress, in their homeland. Europe must do everything in its power to implement the measures adopted to combat jihadism. I am convinced that this is in the common interest of Europe and Egypt and the Middle East.

name: Mireille D’Ornano (ENF).
text: — Mr President, last Sunday's attack is the culmination of a sad litany of persecution. At least 42 churches in Egypt have been subjected to various desecrations since 2013, although President Sisi's efforts in favour of the Copts can be commended. By targeting the largest Christian minority in the Arab world, with its approximately eight million souls, it is the whole of Christianity that the Islamic State is bruising in its flesh. Our values of tolerance and humanism must not lead us to blindness; it is indeed the eradication of Christianity that is the ultimate goal of Islamists. At a time when Western interference has led to the deliquescence of formerly functional states, this objective is within reach in the Middle East. It is urgent that Europeans give concrete support to Christian minorities in the Arab world so as not to assume a historic responsibility for their disappearance.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, Commissioner. It is not my knowledge of how you come to say: it was an attack on all the Egyptians. Ten percent of the Egyptians are Christians. In a church, 23 Christians are murdered — the Islamic State is committed to this. Christians in the world are most persecuted by all religions. With 7 100 Christians murdered in 2016, this figure doubled compared to the previous year. I know it, and you know it too: it was an Islamist who murdered the 23 Christians in the Coptic Church in Cairo. It is Islamists who persecute, kill or force the Christians in Iraq and Syria to flee. It is Islamists who spread fear and terror among Christians to the many refugee camps in Germany and throughout Europe. A country like Hungary has reacted and established the post of Secretary of State to support persecuted Christians around the world. Where are our actions in the European Parliament to protect Christians?

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: - Mr President! I read earlier today about some of the casualties of the Cairo terror attack. About the little girl Maji. About Aida, an elderly woman and grandmother. About Nabil who had just become the father of a long-awaited son. In this House, we have today voted on a report on human rights and democracy. Among other things, we voted on a text that makes clear that Christians are the most persecuted religious group in the world. The paragraph was supported by a majority, but too many chose not to side with this fact. From my native Sweden, it is about colleagues in the Social Democrats, the Green Party, the Left Party and the Centre. Mr President! To not acknowledge the scale of the persecution that is happening today against Christians is to take on a great deal of responsibility. It's relativizing evil and crimes against humanity. It is letting Maji, Aida and Nabil down — the victims of global persecution and the genocide that is going on in this now.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: — Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Egypt, July this year — a Coptic family was attacked with knives, whereby one family member was killed. June — Coptic priest was shot in the head. March — four Bible translators were torturally killed in their office. November 2015 — A 26-year-old mother of two was killed by her uncle because she decided to move on to Christianity. August 2015 — A Coptic soldier is shot by soldiers. June 2015 — A Christian is found with two bullets in his chest after refusing to cross to Islam. May 2015 — A Coptic Christian is abducted and killed. April 2015 — A shooting on a church bus. March 2015 — A church built to commemorate murdered Coptic Christians is gunned down. February 2015 — A Coptic store owner is killed in his own store. March 2015 — A 50-year-old Coptic Christian is killed in his own home. The recent attack on the cathedral is just a continuation of the brutal persecution — 25 dead, six of them children. Let's stop the persecution of Christians. The responsibility is on us, too.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is a single violence that sows death and destruction. In those words Pope Francis commented on the terrorist attack targeting Cairo's Coptic community, which resulted in the deaths of 25 people, including many children, and the wounding of many civilians. A horrific crime, carried out at the moment of prayer at the Coptic cathedral of St. Mark in Abasiya, the oldest church in Africa and seat of the Pope in Alexandria. This is not the first time terrorism in Egypt has hit the Coptic Christian community, which accounts for about 10 percent of the population, in an overwhelmingly Muslim country. The massacre carried out in Egypt is particularly serious because men, women and children have been affected whose only fault was to profess a religion different from that professed by terrorists. The international community must react with determination and stand alongside Egypt in the fight against terrorism, but without failing to our values and without giving way to populism and religious fanaticism.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, first of all, I would like to express my deepest condolences to the families of the victims of the terrorist attack committed by Daesh on Sunday at St. Andrew's Cathedral in Cairo. Last week, the ECR team led by me was in Cairo and met with the Egyptian leadership and Mr. Sisi. Of course I could not imagine that today, speaking of these matters, only a few days have passed since we left Cairo. The terrorist attack, first of all, was an attack on all Egyptians. The fact that Egyptian newspapers were released under the title “We are all Copts” means a great deal. It means that there is, and is slowly, a unity within the Egyptian people. Everyone realizes that the act of terrorism against the church, which took place on the day of the celebration of Muhammad, was intended to create tension and conflict between Muslims and Christians. It is something that the citizens of Egypt themselves will not allow, namely to become victims in the context of terrorism and to collide with each other. So what Daesh was trying to cause is sure it's not going to happen.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: Who would not weep about the terrible terrorist attack on the Christian community in Egypt on Sunday when you see the pictures of the victims? I share the growing concerns of Egyptian Christians about a series of incidents between Muslims and Christians in villages, where, for example, an old Christian woman was dragged naked across the street. And I share the concerns about the lack of basic freedom to convert to Christianity as a Muslim. Egyptian Christians want a government that effectively protects their lives, assets and fundamental rights. To this end, the European Union must strongly call on President Sisi and give all its support.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I was a Member from the ECR Group of the same delegation that visited Cairo only last week. I left just one day before that terrorist attack, and after all meetings we had there with President el-Sisi and Grand Imam of al-Azhar and other dignitaries, I still have the feeling that we owe Egypt something. We owe Egypt clear support in its fight against terrorism, but also fair and balanced treatment. We have adopted many critical resolutions on Egypt here in the European Parliament, maybe too many, unlike in the case of some other countries. We also recognise the right of other countries to take very tough measures against terrorist threats, for instance in the case of Turkey. We should recognise the same right for Egypt, because Egypt is a key player in the region and its stability and security are crucial and vital, and also very important for Europe.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, we are all touched by this horrible and barbaric event in Egypt and we share the same feelings here tonight in this debate. I would like to thank you for your sensitivity in connection with the attack that occurred in Egypt.  The European Union is undertaking efforts to enhance stability in Egypt, as well as the freedom of religion in the whole region. The freedom of religion or belief is a universal human right. Its free exercise contributes to pluralism, democracy, development, rule of law, peace and stability. Its violation leads to intolerance, violence and despotism. The European Union will continue to use all its policy instruments to ensure all over the world a favourable environment for the exercise of the freedom of religion and belief. And this is what unites us all in this Chamber tonight.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Discussion is over. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing. — The attack on the Coptic cathedral of St. Mark in Cairo, with a tragic toll of 25 dead and 49 wounded, appears as a turning point in the terrorist strategy taking place in Egypt. For a long time there were no such serious episodes against places of Christian worship and the government proclaimed three days of national mourning. Some commentators speculate that this recrudescence is an attempt by groups linked to Islamic radicalism and Isis (mainly present in the Sinai area) to increase tension between Copts and President Al-Sisi. In fact, the Coptic community, which in 2013 had supported the current president against Mohamed Morsi, supported instead by the Muslim Brotherhood, strongly calls for greater commitment to the protection of its places of life and meeting. The international community and the EU have a duty to demonstrate with facts clear support for this community, the ancient guardian of Christianity of its origins, as well as the contrast to any attempt to further destabilization of the country, which today also experiences a difficult economic situation with the devaluation of the Egyptian pound and the scarcity of supplies of basic necessities. Our condolences to the Patriarch of the Egyptian Coptic Church Tawadros.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item is the debate on the question with an oral reply to the Commission on the recognition of the content of civil status certificates by Maddy Delvaux, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs (O-000145/2016 - B8-1819/2016) ( 2016/3000 (RSP)).

name: Mady Delvaux
text: author. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, on 6 June last we adopted here in Parliament the regulation aimed at promoting the free movement of citizens by simplifying the conditions for the presentation and acceptance of certain public documents within the Union. As rapporteur on this issue, I would like to recall that we have given our agreement to this text, with a little bitterness, after tough discussions with the Council, because, in our view, this regulation is too unambitious. But we considered that it was a step, a small step, of course, but still a step towards more Europe, because the acceptance by one Member State of a civil status document from another Member State brings a little more comfort to citizens moving within the European Union. I have regretted, and I still regret, the reluctance of the Member States which have not shown enthusiasm to reduce bureaucracy and to bring a small concrete solution towards more Union and more Europe. I would like to see some progress, though modest, and I believe that the reaction to the malwell-being of the European peoples cannot be a retreat on oneself.
