On the contrary, I believe that we must fight for a European Union that serves the citizens. I dare believe that the Commission can and wants to help move forward in this direction. At the time, when the Commission presented its proposal for a regulation on the acceptance of public documents, a second proposal was envisaged, which would provide for the recognition of the content of civil registration documents. This recognition should also concern registered partnerships. I would like to emphasize this, because I think this element is quite important, since it promotes equal treatment for all citizens, irrespective of their personality, marital status and choice of life. During the hearing that preceded his appointment as Commissioner, Mrs Jourová told us that she intended to propose such a regulation and that preparatory work had already begun within the Commission services, with the launch of a study to examine all the relevant issues. So my question is, when will the findings of the study or impact assessment be available? Does the Commission still intend to present a proposal on the recognition of the content of public documents, civil status documents? When can Parliament expect this presentation? Does the Commission still intend to include registered partnerships within the scope of the proposal? If not, why would she have changed her mind?

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for having raised the question of the important issue of the recognition, between Member States, of the civil status of EU citizens. People in the Union are increasingly mobile, and now more than ever, they live or raise a family in another Member State. 14 million citizens reside in a Member State other than their own, and 13% of all marriages in the Union are international. In order to facilitate the free movement of citizens, the Union has already adopted a number of legislative instruments. Several of these instruments are in the area of family law, and they enable citizens to have a judgment that is easily recognised in another Member State on such varied matters such as divorce, legal separation, child custody, children’s visiting rights, parental child abduction, maintenance obligations and succession.  Earlier this year, Parliament played a key role in making possible the swift adoption of provisions on the property regimes of marriages and registered partnerships, which will also facilitate recognition in another Member State of judgments on these matters. Parliament was also instrumental in reaching, last summer, a balanced compromise with the Council on a regulation to simplify the circulation of certain public documents within the Union. Under the Regulation, public documents on civil status issued in one Member State will be free of postal requirements when presented to authorities in another Member State, and the rules governing certified copies and translations of such public documents will be simpler and avoid language barriers. The Commission is aware that, despite existing instruments, citizens may encounter difficulties in having their civil status recognised when they travel or move to another Member State. Where recognition of civil status is governed by Member State law, the Union must ensure that citizens can enjoy their right to move freely within the Union. In this respect, the Court plays a very important role. With regard to a person’s name, the Court has already ruled that non-discrimination on grounds of nationality and proportionality must guide Member States in their decisions on whether or not to recognise a person’s name. As a result of the Court’s ruling, the Member States concerned have adopted their legislation or administrative practices on the recognition of names.  As for same-sex unions, an important development in the Court’s case law is expected. The Romanian Constitutional Court announced in November that it will seek clarification on whether a same-sex couple, a Romanian and a United States citizen married in Belgium, can be recognised as spouses under Romanian law, pursuant to the Union provisions on family reunification. The Commission, like the Court, must ensure that Member States apply correctly the Union provisions that facilitate the free movement of citizens.  In parallel to ensuring the correct application of existing law, the Commission has started a reflection process on how to address issues such as the expansion of the scope beyond what is currently covered by the Public Documents Regulation and on the recognition of civil status between Member States. In this reflection process, the Commission must consider the relevant case law developments in Member States’ frameworks and coherence with European Union policies. The Commission is also ready to continue the exchange with Parliament and engage in a dialogue with Member States and other relevant actors.  The Commission contracted in 2012 a study on the recognition of civil status in the Union. Since then, substantial legal developments have taken place in Member States regarding same-sex marriage and registered partnerships. Any eventual legislative action would need to be based on updated data and the Commission will look into ensuring the availability of the evidence base needed for eventual decisions. The Commission will keep Parliament and Member States informed on its reflection process and views gathered during it.

name: Емил Радев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, a few months ago we managed to make progress with the Member States on the adoption of the Regulation on the abolition of the apostille when presenting some official documents in the European Union. However, here we are discussing a completely different issue. In fact, different countries do not have the same vision of family law, especially in terms of marriage, adoption, registered partnerships. Family law represents relationships, not just facts. Their creation and existence is based on legal necessity, specific legal rules and arrangements. This means that the family relationship which exists under the legislation of one Member State may not exist within the law of another State. Recognition of the content of civil status documents would lead to a change in the substantive family law of the Member States. According to the Treaties, the EU does not have the competence to change the substantive law relating to civil status, especially as regards registered partnership or marriage. This falls within the competence of the Member States. If the European Commission incorporates registered partnerships in such a legislative text, this would be contrary to the treaties and would result in a kind of imposition of legislation that is not wanted by many Member States. We cannot oblige Member States to recognise legal instruments from other Member States, such as registered partnership, which are not known in their own national law.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you know how important it is for the future of Europe, just as it has been for the recent past, the possibility for people citizens to move freely. It was one of the fundamental achievements in the establishment of the European institutions. Today the delay the Commission has in launching the proposal we are urging it is likely to contribute to the slowdown of this mobility. The arguments you used to justify the delay, allow me to tell you with all frankness, are not convincing. Here, in this House, Commissioner Jourova told us before he took office that the technical work on the subject was already in advanced implementation. Another time has passed and the first measure never followed the second. I believe that reason is a political reason, but then it must be addressed like this. There are no technical difficulties, there is a resistance in some Member States to the issues relating to family relations becoming a subject which flows into a proposal concerning registered unions, because that's the theme. But a Europe that does not recognise this possibility, which does not recognise the legitimacy of family relations of this nature, is a Europe that starts on a path that inevitably leads it to decline. Here, we would like to avoid this decline.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, we citizens of the European Union are proud of the work that has been done for us to travel, move from one country to another, work and live freely. The fundamental idea of the EU has been to maintain and further develop this area of freedom, security and justice, where the free movement and rights of citizens are guaranteed. This is something we have stuck to very hard at least, and it is mentioned whenever the EU is talked about. It is therefore important to ensure that EU citizens have access to their rights. I have a right to marriage, family, name and identity. My name is provable across the EU. However, not everyone has this right. I wouldn't be a fair decision maker if I didn't demand the same rights for everyone.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, the regulation adopted last July was, as I had had the opportunity to say so, only a gadget, but a perverse gadget announcing the recognition of the contents of civil documents and the recognition, therefore, of a legal situation. Ms. Delvaux mentioned only the registered partnership, and this will certainly be the case for same-sex marriages and why not the filiation of children conceived by GPA. I would point out that civil law is the sovereignty of the Member States and that some of them have chosen not to recognise same-sex partnerships or marriages. This full recognition that you are preparing for us will undoubtedly result in a phenomenon of law shopping, that is, nationals of one Member State will go to another Member State in order to conclude their partnership or marriage. Ultimately, we see the perverse logic that drives you. To impose on all States the recognition of a given legal situation, regardless of whether they do not wish to recognize it, that is what you are preparing for us, a blow of legal force. We will oppose it with all our strength.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: — Sur President, hemm talba -enerali magthe mula mio - Xogto olna allura jrid dejjem isir aktar relevanti galihom. name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, like many and many Members when I was elected a couple of years ago, I had a dream, to try to improve in my small work the life of the European citizens. And so, like all my colleagues, I was thinking of a Europe with less finance and more economics, with less focus on austerity but more investment, with more work, with more social rights. We're working on that. Then however this dream hopelessly breaks, breaks, when you get to talk about civil rights and, in particular, the civil rights of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transsexual and intersex people of our continent. You see, Commissioner, we are perpetrating discrimination on our continent, because we continue to have families, because this is about, who cannot travel, who cannot turn around, whose documents are not recognized from one country to another. This is what we are talking about today. You told us just now that the Commission, which has also been mentioned by some other colleague, the Commission is studying, the Commission is deepening, it is analysing, it is making dialogues, the Commission is waiting for the Court's decisions as well. But, you see, I think it is wrong to continue to rely on the judiciary, here there is a need for politics, there is a need for courage, there is a need to make decisions. Not later than today, and yesterday, we voted on human rights reports on our continent and in the world, which also talked about these issues. Then to close, Commissioner, we often say that the citizens of Europe no longer like Europe. Unfortunately, I believe that this Europe is showing that it no longer loves European citizens. Either we go back to loving the citizens of Europe or we will hardly have a love for us.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I appreciate the European Commission's concerns about strengthening the most important value of the European Union, namely the free movement of persons, and simplifying the requirements for the presentation of certain official documents is part of this process. However, I believe that important steps must be taken further, so that the free movement of people has new valences. Recognition of the content of civil status acts is the next step that we consider necessary to be implemented by the European Commission. This allows European citizens to have better mobility within the European area, whether it is those looking for a better job, or students, or simply those who choose to reside in another Member State. In this context, I stress the need to identify effective mechanisms and procedures to ensure the suppleness of these rules for the benefit of citizens. However, I draw attention to the obligation to find necessary resources to ensure the safety and legal strength of civil status acts by preventing their falsification. With regard to civil partnerships, especially those concluded between same-sex persons, I call on the Commission to show particular concern and attention, bearing in mind that in some countries they are not recognised, as is also the case in Romania. I draw your attention, Commissioner, and also to all those who are concerned about this, that another approach from the Commission, namely to comply with national law, only violates the treaties, and this certainly could not be possible in The European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, more than 14 million European citizens live outside their country of origin. According to the Eurobarometer, 73% of Union citizens believe that measures should be taken to improve the circulation of public documents between EU countries. The abolition of the apostille stamp is now topical due to the increase in the flow of migratory flows among young people and is a positive thing that will strengthen the free movement of citizens, their establishment in another country and the search for work. In addition, however, the circle of public documents, particularly those relating to people with disabilities, Commissioner, needs to be extended. It is estimated that by abolishing these requirements, citizens and businesses in the European Union will save EUR three hundred and thirty million without counting on saving time and avoiding suffering.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, of course I see the complexity of the debates and many issues were raised which require all of us to move forward as quickly as possible. The Commission appreciates that recognition of civil status within the Union would further facilitate the free movement of citizens. No doubt. This is why, in addition to ensuring the correct application of existing law, it is reflecting on how to address this matter.  In its reflection, the Commission must assess what scope would be most appropriate for any possible initiative in this area. It is therefore too early at this stage to give concrete information on the results of the Commission’s reflection. We need to see our outcomes and then to present our results.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — We need to approach this topic with caution, as certain proposals on automatic recognition of civil status at EU level lead to very serious legal and ethical dilemmas. Family law, as well as the definition of marriage and registered partnership, are topics within the competence of the Member States and we must not question their sovereignty in this domain. Article 67, the first paragraph of the Treaty, in the functioning of the EU, states that “the Union represents an area of respect for fundamental rights and different legal systems and traditions of Member States”. Automatic recognition of civil status at the level of the European Union would certainly entail the impermissible imposition of legal solutions in the domain of family law, over which the EU has no jurisdiction. Two-thirds of Croatian citizens who went to the referendum in 2013 advocated the constitutional definition of marriage as a community of man and woman. Recognition of civil status at EU level would directly counter the Constitution of the Republic of Croatia and the will of Croatian citizens, which is entirely inadmissible. This would have further far-reaching implications and consequences in all Member States that have different family legislation and legal systems. We must preserve the values on which the EU rests by respecting the diversity of national legal systems and national constitutions.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on support for Thalidomide victims (2016/3029 (RSP)).

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I am pleased to have the opportunity to raise once more the issue of Thalidomide here in Parliament. I have met a few times people whose lives have been irreversibly damaged by Thalidomide and I know very well the extremely difficult day-to-day situations they are in and the problems they struggle with. It was actually this terrible tragedy which led to the creation of our European system for the safety of medicines.  Please let us inform the younger generation of the consequences Thalidomide had for survivors and their families, and let us collectively recognise that they need support more than ever before. They are rightly fighting for appropriate support and asking policymakers to help. They need more permanent national assistance and cooperation between Member States where patients suffered from this tragedy, and consideration from industry, which must be involved in the process.  Many Members of the European Parliament have written to me calling for support. We met and we also had the opportunity to discuss this issue in plenary already. Let me stress once again that I fully share your concern. I am keen to help within the limited competences of the Commission, taking into account the Member States separately and in cooperation with each other, to decide on how to support Thalidomide survivors and put a more patient-centred approach into practice in this case. Injury compensation schemes are currently not a matter of European Union competence and therefore the Commission is not in a position to take concrete legal action.  What the Commission can do is lend political support, and this is precisely what we have been doing. I have spoken with all the health ministers of the Member States involved and I am ready to do that once again. I have asked them to seriously consider additional support and I am willing to continue raising this issue. The key for finding a way forward lies with Member States, in particular the Member States concerned.  It is difficult to accept that the manufacturers and distributors of Thalidomide have shouldered only part of the cost of this tragedy and that society has to step in. It is also the obligation of the Member States and industry, through a more patient-centred approach, to restore trust and help people who have suffered from Thalidomide. We should not forget them, but rather remember the tragedy every year. I therefore repeat the call I made before you in March that you, as the Members of Parliament, relay back to your national governments and to industry the specific needs of Thalidomide survivors. I count on you to use your influence to support this course of action and raise awareness.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, thalidomide was an invention of the Nazis, experienced in concentration camps with prisoners. In 1954, the pharmacist Grünenthal created and put on sale this medicine as a compound for pregnant women. During the 1950s and 60s ten thousand children were born with congenital physical malformations caused by thalidomide. In early 1962, the drug was withdrawn in Germany, United Kingdom and Italy. However, in Spain it continued to sell for three more years and continued to appear in the Vademecum until 1975, causing more pain. Just a few months ago, this House was wondering why. Why, for fifty years, did governments around the world close their eyes to this tragedy? Why, fifty years later, are we still waiting for the company that put the drug on sale for forgiveness? Why, fifty years later, are we still not finding a solution? I, today, think we should ask ourselves until when. How long are we going to continue to regret our lack of compassion, without solving problems? How long are we going to allow victims to exist in Spain without official recognition and without enough help to live with dignity? Thalidomide victims have grown older crying. Probably five thousand have already died. To the problems they had at birth are added those that have arisen, which could not be expected, with age. Today we are not asking for any new fund to be created, because funds already exist. Today we are not asking for more resources, because resources already exist. Today we demand that bureaucracy be reduced and the requirements for victims, both German and non-German, to have access to the existing special health fund, created to meet the special needs of victims that have arisen over time. We're asking for less bureaucracy, no more money. The money is already there. We also demand that the Spanish Government reopen the process of recognition of victims, so that they can be eligible for the financial aid they are entitled. Because I am ashamed to admit that Spain, my country, is the only one that has not yet recognized its victims. Ladies and gentlemen, more is needed. Victim health deteriorates minute by minute while many of us do nothing but talk. If we wait longer, there will be no pain to be able to attend to. Let's do something right, let's do justice tonight.

name: Susanne Melior
text: Mr President, Commissioner Andriukatis, ladies and gentlemen. The Contergan scandal is one of the largest health scandals in Germany and has had an impact on many other countries in the European Union. I would like to recall here the numerous victims that are now mostly in the 1950s — just like myself, it is my vintage — and that is why it affects me very emotionally. Many of them were compensated after painstaking and years of struggle. Others have received little support to this day, and we must not forget these victims. There is no question that my own country, Germany, has played a not quite bodious role in dealing with the scandal and therefore also has a shared responsibility. But responsibility bears from my point of view — and so do my colleagues — especially the company Grünenthal itself, which produced the drug and exported it to other countries, even when it was already withdrawn from the market in Germany. Certainly, the Member States — Spain has just been mentioned — are also in the situation of having to provide concrete assistance to the victims who need to open up health systems to this end. However, I think that with the resolution we are quite rightly calling for the victims of the Contergan scandal to be recognised as such throughout the EU and for compensation and assistance.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Commissioner, the victims of thalidomide have received life - annuity pensions in Germany, Italy, the United Kingdom, Sweden and Ireland. In Sweden, in fact, even a specific centre for comprehensive care for victims was established more than twenty years ago. The Contergan Foundation, funded by pharmaceutical company Grünenthal and the German State, has paid these pensions of up to 6,000 euros to thousands of victims across Europe. Do you know how many Spaniards? Two. Is it because there are no more Spanish victims? Yeah, of course there are, about four hundred still live. But Contergan has demanded crazy requirements from them, such as presenting the original bottle of the drug their mothers bought. Thalidomide victims carry a life full of obstacles and suffering from the malformations caused by the Grünenthal drug. The Spanish victims have also suffered institutional abandonment, the incompetence of successive governments, Grünenthal's arrogant lack of scruples and media oblivion. I ask all my German colleagues to understand that this is not a Spanish problem. This is a 100% European case of discrimination. We are dealing with a company that avoids taking responsibility for the damage it committed. I ask you to take an interest in the proven discrimination I am denouncing, to contrast information and to fight in Germany so that the Contergan Foundation compensates Spanish victims, because they are their fellow European citizens. A week ago, a non-law proposal was approved in the Spanish Parliament to remedy this damage with concrete and useful measures for the victims. I ask that we join in this effort to end so many decades of injustice, because we must act now. And so that this case is not resolved by omission of relief with the slow death of the victims, I call for it to be resolved with dignity and justice so that we can settle the outstanding debt of more than sixty years than all we have with them.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, we want this reform of the law on compensation to not fall into a simple statement of intent, as is often the case. First of all, as has already been said, the person responsible is, of course, the pharmaceutical, who should be responsible for the damage, and also for the compensation. This is what those affected are currently asking, at least in Spain. The obligation of individual governments is not to cover the embarrassment of private companies such as pharmaceutical companies or those that bought thalidomide patents, but to demand that the rule of law be respected and that they pay the consequences of what they have done. Time is passing and they are no longer worth facelift. Recognition of all victims is already needed, regardless of the country to which they belonged. And fair and unconditional compensation is also needed. Mr Pons, you are Government — this is the second legislature, eight years. If you believe what you have just said, work on it, because you have a lot to say in our country's Government.

name: Jill Evans
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this may be a step forward in the long campaign to get justice for Thalidomide survivors. It should never have been necessary for those survivors to have to campaign to get justice, but campaign they did, and very effectively. So we see here cross-party backing for financial support for all of the survivors. We can play a role here, together with the Member States, in coordinating actions, and we urge the German Government to allow access to the health scheme which would enable survivors to deal with increasing health problems and independent living costs. The health needs are well documented. A UK study showed that Thalidomide survivors were amongst those with the poorest health-related quality of life in the population. That would include some of my constituents in Wales. We owe them justice. We owe their families justice. It has been over 50 years; it has been far too long. Let us put it right now.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I can remember the births of Thalidomide children when I was a boy and the appalling devastation this wreaked on those families. I have been hugely impressed with what those thalidomide victims who have not been so badly affected have been doing in this Parliament: going into every single MEP’s office, thrusting out their deformed limbs, shock-and-awe tactics that have really woken this place up. But actually, if the EU is to be any use at all it should have got hold of this subject years ago, because this must be the raison d’être of the EU. This is a problem that cuts across different countries. They could have lent on Germany to oblige the German Government to ask every German taxpayer to contribute 50 cents per year and that would have put this right; or they could have used their own funds rather than wasting them on projects like building administrative centres in Hungary for stray dogs, or funding studies in South America for flatulence in cattle. My point to German politicians is: if you change places with a  Thalidomide victim for 12 hours, you would change your tune. You know what to do – just to do it.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today we are writing a page that we all hope will be useful, a step forward, Commissioner, thank you once again for your sensitivity, but we really need concrete facts. I believe that all of us who are here must say thanks to these men and women who from England, Spain, Italy, from all the countries of Europe, have come with their associations to continue with strength, with great dignity, with great courage their battle, which they carried on in solitude, for many and too many years. That's why I want to read some words spoken by a lady who lived, took her license, had a family, children, without two arms, without a leg. She says “we did an experiment a few years ago, got in line, it was impressive for me, because I realized that if my mom had taken that tablet just eight hours earlier I would be born also without ears, in addition to injuries on the limbs.” Here, I believe that the suffering we perceive when we meet these people strongly demands that we give answers. It has been too long a history, of silences, lies, subterfuges, injustices, discrimination in discrimination, because in some countries there are compensation, in others there are fewer, in others still there are none, in Italy only since 2008 they receive compensation. Too little really. And we will never have asked them enough excuse for what they suffered and never told them even enough thanks, because thanks to them pharmacovigilance was born, because thanks to the drama they have lived they were not born other children with their own problems. So, Commissioner, I believe that today we must strongly demand that what has been asked for, less bureaucracy, compensation at hand, the money is there, no more justice should be denied, it must not be denied this justice, to be put an end to this discrimination which is one of the most ignoble we live in Europe. If we are that civil Europe we say we are, we must put an end to this page as soon as possible. Thank you all, but thanks mostly to these people who are not here, but are truly here with us. It is to them that we have to say thank you.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, fifty years are many years waiting for the victims of thalidomide to be recognized and rewarded for the greatest medical disaster of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. An exceptional situation with a response at least unfair. Tomorrow, finally, this House will give Europe a voice and recognize these victims and call all Member States to responsibility. Time has led not only the pharmaceutical company to be held responsible, but also the Member States, and we therefore call on Germany to open the road it closed in the 1970s, but that it does not, and we ask in the resolution, to exempt the Member States from their responsibility. In particular, we ask Spain to revise the Royal Decree which with good will launched in 2010, the first and only measure taken to recognize these victims, but which has proved to be insufficient. I do not want to end without expressing my thanks to the colleagues in Germany, for their sensitivity, who have made it possible for us to debate this resolution today, and especially to the victims, who really, through their awareness-raising work, have brought this issue to this House, as well as my solidarity above all to families who do not today they already have their victims.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: Mr President, promises, dreams and hopes truncated, to which social exclusion has been added, in many cases, is what the victims of thalidomide have experienced. They were beaten even before birth, when their pregnant mothers were prescribed thalidomide by their family doctor. They suffer, at this time, terrifying aging, with severe pains in muscles and joints. It has been a nightmare that has lasted more than fifty years, which gives us shame, blush and frightening. As for Spain — it has been said here — it is one of the countries that has not paid or recognized compensation to any of its victims, only to two. That still produces an added indignation. It is a full-fledged European social injustice. And that is why we are presenting a resolution today. Because, on the occasion of the amendment to the Law on the Foundation for Thalidomide Victims, we can make victims benefit from a German health fund. We therefore ask that they be compensated and recognized. That injustice be corrected. In the case of Spain, we should review the process that took place in 2010 so that they are identified and compensated without the need to present a jar fifty years ago, a recipe from fifty years ago that no longer exists. It is time to do justice and it is time for Europe to exhibit its values. It was in no case a disease, it was a crime. And I end with a few words from Jacques Delors: 'We do not believe in a Europe without soul, without conscience, without political will and without social dimension'. It's time for Europe not to forget its innocents. If it does, we will regain the prominence in the world.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after more than fifty years the thalidomide affair is still an open question and as the age progresses, victims are in increasing need of help in relation to problems related to aging. There are still categories of patients who have not been granted compensation and I mention the case of Italian victims born in 1957. Now that we have an updated framework in twenty-one countries of specific needs and assistance, allowances and entitlements insured to survivors, it is essential that the Commission intervenes for ensuring a European Guideline, fair treatment of all thalidomidics, overcoming the unjust disparities that still exist not only between Member States but also within the States, depending on, for example, of the year of birth. I therefore strongly support the request of my colleagues, we must be close to these fellow citizens and their families who pay the price for a serious scandal, from which the first was born European legislation on drug safety. Europe exists, it can not just be a market, but it must be a community that is attentive to the weakest, let us live the hope that things can change.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, as the penultimate on the list of speakers there is little left to add to the above, but I should like to make a reflection. Europe is staggering and staggering because it has not taken care of its soul. Tomorrow we will adopt a resolution that is sixty years late. Shortly after the Treaty of Rome, which gave rise to the Union we all know today, a pharmaceutical company, with name and surnames, caused damage that victims today continue to suffer. From Europe, this Europe that has been built, we must restore their souls. Place the person at the center of the policies and decisions we make and execute those decisions. We must say loud from this House, which represents the sovereignty of the European people, that we will not leave any victim or any person to be ignored. We must not forget that what affects only one of our citizens is all of us. It is our duty to demand compensation and liability from the company that caused the damage. It is our duty to demand that no European be discriminated against on account of his or her membership in one or another Member State. It is our duty, without any doubt, to apply the remedies necessary to return to Europe its humanist soul and to put the person back at the centre of public policies.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thalidomide is probably associated with the most serious collective disaster ever caused by a drug. Full recognition of the demands of thalidomide victims who have survived in Europe is necessary and to ensure their autonomy, access to medical care and an adequate quality of life. It is paradoxical that after more than fifty years survivors are still looking for justice and a compensation solution that allows them to support the costly care needed for their condition physics. I believe that we need a framework protocol at European level, in which all European citizens who suffer from thalidomide receive comparable compensation, regardless of the home Member State. This solution must be read as an opportunity also offered to the German government, because it remedies a historical error. The ultimate goal is to obtain an official recognition of the responsibility, even moral, for what has happened and the creation of a fund to assist the survivors of thalidomide. These people and their families can no longer be left alone and it is really unbearable to continue to register discrimination between thalidomide affections in different countries.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE).
text: — This is how we talk in the European Parliament in the evening about the serious issue of people affected by the use of Talidomid; it was sold on the market under the name Contergan. We know the various teratogenic effects it had on those fruits, those babies whose mothers used this medicine during pregnancy and didn't know it was something that would actually distort their baby. These people are adults today and need compensation. I also fully intercede as a doctor and as a Member, so that these people, regardless of which country these people are affected, are compensated, be compensated, and it is time for us not only to support these people morally, but also, in fact, in very practical steps, to recognise them financial support.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, thalidomide is responsible for the birth of more than ten thousand children with the syndrome of dysbiosis. The company deliberately concealed what it knew about the side effects of the drug, giving false information when experts started linking thalidomide to neurological disorders. Moreover, the pharmaceutical company never paid compensation to the families of children except a small pension and was not sufficiently convicted of the harm it caused. But there is also a great responsibility for the Member States which have hidden this very serious issue, especially the German Government, which has not checked this medicinal product even after the first complaints and side effects. We discussed the issue of thalidomide and the citizens' complaints in the Committee on Petitions and what we really heard was shocking. The European Union must, with many years too late, support and help victims and families by demanding that the German pharmaceutical company and the German state pay them an adequate amount of compensation.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, this is an issue that cuts across national, political and ideological divides. We all surely unite on this to agree that the Thalidomide victims get the justice and financial support that they so richly deserve. The German Government, and those responsible for making the drugs, should accept their responsibilities and provide adequate support for these brave people who have done so much to help themselves, especially now as they pass into their 60s and need help with the daily tasks that the rest of us take for granted.  It is good that we can all put aside our political differences and together call for the victims of the Thalidomide drug to be properly looked after, without any more undue delay.

name: Presidente. –
text: Now the Commissioner's reply, but I would like to make a note and join the great sensitivity that all my colleagues in all the political groups around this matter have expressed, because we all have met people who have suffered from these problems, and we certainly owe them justice, closeness, solidarity, we also owe it in memory of their families, all those families, mothers, fathers who they had no justice. We must have this act of moral recognition towards them.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I fully and absolutely agree that it is a moral obligation, and of course it is about social justice and the possibility of how to really help those people now, today. Of course we are very well aware that we must follow our legal obligations.  It is worth repeating that Member States are responsible and I tell you once again that I am ready to organise debates with Member States’ Ministers of Health, and to do as I did last year, namely to organise a round table on how to urge governments to understand how it is possible to cooperate, because the Member States have the right introduce the open method of coordination and to show solidarity, all together. It is not just Germany. No! We will see how we can invite all countries together to resolve this issue.  Of course industry must also pay the price. It was not enough just to say two decades ago ‘we will solve these problems’, and that’s it. No, because it is an ethical position, a moral obligation and relates to trust in science and industry. I am well aware of this but we all do it together by inviting all actors to solve these problems.  I have taken careful note of your comments and views and I appreciate Parliament’s decision to discuss those issues tonight. I will of course look at your document and we will do our best once again together. I can see that we must all be involved together in finding a solution to this issue. There is no doubt that we will address those questions.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have received two motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 15 December 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Thalidomide is a drug invented by the German pharmaceutical industry Chemie Grünenthal, which was marketed since 1957 as a sedative, anti-nausea and hypnotic, especially targeted way to pregnant women. It was withdrawn from the market as women treated with thalidomide gave birth to infants with severe congenital changes in limb development, namely amelia or varying degrees of phocomelia. At least 20 000 children suffering from severe physical malformations are estimated to have been born. I believe it is essential to fully recognise the demands of thalidomide victims who have survived in Europe, so as to ensure their autonomy, access to medical care and an adequate quality of life.

name: Mireille D’Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. — With some 20,000 children born malformed, thalidomide is one of the biggest health scandals known in Europe. Due to lack of vigilance, the German laboratory Chemie Grünenthal conceals, in the 1950s, the devastating side effects on the fetus of a drug (thalidomide) intended to relieve benign pathologies. Child victims of thalidomide suffering from serious malformations will also have to face denial of justice: for example, it is now established that the Federal Republic of Germany has interfered with legal proceedings initiated in the 1970s, preventing satisfactory compensation. As a result of decades of neglect, the social and health situation of victims continues to worsen: their entry into the elderly makes the question of their autonomy even more prevalent. It is therefore urgent to recognize their conditions and to ensure access to essential medical care. I therefore support the resolution tabled by the ENF Group, which, on the basis of the commitments made by Commissioner Andriukaitis on 9 March 2016, calls for a programme of assistance to victims of thalidomide in addition to the action of the Member States.

name: Presidente. –
text: The agenda is the debate on the question with an oral response to the Commission on medicinal products for paediatric use by Giovanni La Via, Françoise Grossetête, Elena Gentile, Bolesław G. Piecha, Frédérique Ries, Stefan Eck, Joëlle Mélin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000135/2016 - B8-1818/2016).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: author. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, with this oral question we ask a number of requests to the European Commission to improve the legislation on paediatric medicines, clearly for us representatives of the European people, but also for the citizens, very important. This is a duty that we must assume as politicians, legislators, but also parents for all the sick little ones in order to save as far as possible many young lives. The regulation had a significant impact on the development of medicines for pediatric use, acting as an engine for many pharmaceutical companies in product development and research projects, the whose number is greatly increased. But there are improvements and changes that are possible and which we Members of the European Parliament are asking strongly. We call on the Commission to submit a detailed report that fully identifies and analyses in detail the obstacles to innovation in the field of medicinal products for use today pediatric. We also ask to examine, on the basis of these findings, the possibility of making amendments, including through a legislative review, to the Regulation on paediatric medicinal products, which should be kept in the appropriate way Considering a number of important facts, such as pediatric development plans based on the mechanism of action and not just the type of disease, more timely and achievable pediatric survey plans, incentives research and strategies to avoid off-label use when there are licensed pediatric medicines. This will lead to a number of benefits in terms of lives saved in pediatric oncology, for example, as you know well. We also call for the Commission to consider amending the regulation so that promising trials are not stopped prematurely due to unsatisfactory results on adults and to support pediatric clinical research of elevated quality. We need to speed up the development of pediatric drugs, especially those drugs for neonatology and childhood cancers. I would like to thank the Commission from now on for its answers and we are sure that it will work to get to the bottom of this issue, which is a real necessity for all European citizens.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ensuring the health of children and maximising their life potential is our common goal. The Commission welcomes this debate. It confirms the shared interest of both our institutions to secure the best outcome for children. This debate comes at a timely moment; indeed the Commission is preparing a second report to the Council and Parliament on the Paediatric Medicines Regulation.  As honourable Members will know, the Regulation aims to ensure that we can provide children with quality medicines. This legislative stimulus was deemed necessary because pharmaceutical companies tend to focus mainly on adults. The Regulation succeeded in putting the spotlight on developing paediatric therapies. It was a game—changer; companies can no longer ignore paediatric development. It put an end to the dogma that children should be protected from clinical research. Instead, children merit the same evidence—based therapies as other age groups. It increased paediatric discharge also in the most vulnerable population of neonates. We now see an increasing number of new products for children entering the market. Indeed, more than 900 paediatric development programmes have been agreed under the Regulation, and more than 100 have been completed in recent years.  But there are also, of course, limitations to what the Regulation can achieve. As there is an obligation for it not to regard the development of adult medicines, the additional paediatric research may not address pressing paediatric needs, especially in diseases that occur only in children, such as many paediatric cancers. We are looking closely as this issue in the context of drawing up the second report. At the same time, we are analysing economic impacts with a particular focus on the rewards and incentives. Last month, the Commission launched a public consultation which will run until February 2017. This exercise is important as it gives everybody an opportunity for their voice to be heard before finalisation of the report. The Commission cannot therefore draw conclusions at this stage. We first needed to compare for you the data and gather experiences.  The Commission is committed to presenting, in the course of 2017, a detailed report on the Paediatric Regulation. It is our obligation, and on the basis of its findings we will be better placed to continue informed discussions on the best way forward. We are working on common discussions on those issues.

name: Françoise Grossetête
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, on 7 June 2010, at the age of 14, Margaux died of an aggressive brain tumor, unfortunately incurable. His mother wanted to continue fighting, through the association “Imagine for Margaux”. This is his fight, which I want to echo today. Like her, thousands of parents in Europe lose their children with serious illnesses every year due to lack of effective treatment. How can we continue to accept that children die from diseases that are known to be treated in adults? Despite the progress made by the 2006 Paediatric Regulations, for example, by requiring industry to conduct paediatric investigation plans, paediatric research remains too rare. Whereas the Commission is soon to proceed — as you said, Commissioner — to assess the current regulation, it is essential to make substantial improvements. Research is not yet sufficiently encouraged and too many exemptions are being granted to allow laboratories not to conduct or complete paediatric investigation plans. The first urgency is to use the flexibilities of the current legislation to base the obligation to conduct paediatric investigation plans on the mechanism of action of the molecule and to make them more realistic and feasible. The second urgency is to build a truly incentive system which, on the one hand, punishes those who do not play the game and, on the other hand, encourages laboratories to develop only paediatric indications and not necessarily modeled on adult products. A real reflection must be carried out in this regard. “Go ahead, fight and win”: these words, which we found in Margaux's notebooks, we are now the custodians of them. It is up to us to fight and win for sick children. Commissioner, I really count on you, you must absolutely help us not to waste time in this area.

name: Elena Gentile
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the figures are dramatically true. Every year in Europe six thousand patients of pediatric and adolescent age lose their lives. Many fortunately survive, returned to a normal life, but a considerable number will see their lives marked by complications that heavily affect quality of life. The European Network for Pediatric Oncohematology has set the need to promote a long-term sustainable strategic plan to make care more effective and thus improve the prognosis for those Patients against whom treatments currently available fail to focus on the goal of returning them a path of life free from complications. Few and insufficient resources available for research and experimentation. There is therefore a need to foster a new awareness of the European institutions in order to ensure that paediatric oncohematology is not considered residual on the European political agenda, but to play a role priority. Not only the researchers and critics of the sector, but the very many parental associations in the Member States who support the key points of this new strategy aimed at, in fact , to promote innovative treatments and research oriented towards a more timely knowledge of the biology of neoplasms connected to the mechanism of action of the drug. Support the European network of public research in connection with the diagnostic and care institutions, establishing a relationship with the system of the drug industry, simplifying procedures, speeding up Administrative steps: it seems to me, it seems to us to be a more than sustainable goal.

name: Stefan Eck
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Children need special care because they are our future. The bitter reality: only one out of ten children in the EU who have cancer is cured. The development of innovative therapies and special drugs for children suffering from cancer must be the focus of pharmaceutical companies. We owe it to these kids and their parents. I am therefore particularly pleased that this report is also suitable for promoting paediatric oncology. However, it is important to maintain the following principles: publicly available evaluation of development costs, full transparency of clinical costs and an assessment of how subsidies and public funds can be used efficiently. In conclusion, I want to wish you all happy holidays and a Happy New Year, but most of all health. That's why I took the liberation, dear colleagues, to put a vegan cookbook in your mailbox, because nutrition has a huge impact on health — adult health and children's health.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 10 years ago the Commission adopted the Regulation on medicinal products for paediatric use. We do not deny that this regulation has contributed to improving the overall situation and strengthening cooperation in the development of these medicinal products but, after ten years, a review is required critical of this text to eliminate the gaps so far found. Children, in fact, are the most vulnerable group of the population and there are substantial differences compared to adults on both physiological and psychological levels. That is why we are asking for the utmost attention on this issue which does not allow any time being made by the institutions. Let's talk about the small number of paediatric survey plans completed so far and the systematic deferment of pediatric surveys, for example. In the field of research, then, the problem is always the same. If the development of new molecules remains linked to the expectation that a product produces a certain profit we will never go anywhere. As already happens for antibiotic resistance, so it will happen and already happens for pediatric drugs. I also want to point out that in pediatric oncology scientific knowledge of cellular processes used to test drugs for adults has potential relevance also for the treatment of tumors Pediatric, but these drugs must be the subject of specific clinical trials for pediatric use. In addition, many of the cancers that affect young people are rare cancers and this is another factor why pharmaceutical industries have little interest in developing medicines in this area. We point out that even the current system of premiums and incentives can be misused or even abused by pharmaceutical companies. We don't say drug companies don't have to make money, but we can't continue to leave public health in hands of market logics. And that is why we renew the call to consider the establishment of a public and European pharmaceutical company. To close, I would like to remind you that a few days ago the Commission opened a public consultation on the experience gained so far. I call on everyone, pharmaceutical companies, doctors, scientists, patient groups and groups of parents with experience of difficulties behind them to send their contributions to the Commission by 20 February 2017.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE).
text: — I think that the question of paediatric medicines and their research and the availability of medicines for children for paediatric treatment is still very acute. I think we need to realise that, in fact, we need to move from discussion to action. The fact that the Commission... we will still be debating and perhaps in February will present something to us. To my taste, it is a slow reaction from the Commission, I would beg to speed up the whole process. The pharmaceutical industry is more devoted to research on medicines for adults, and only a very small proportion are medicines for children to be treated. We know that the most common cause after one year of life in children is actually child cancer, and only 10% of such children are successfully cured. Children aren't diminished adults. We can't use adult medicine on them just in some smaller can. Here we need original own research on such new drugs, new molecules, and when needed, molecules from generic medicines must also be released to help our children. It is our duty to do something specific and also put a lot more money into research on new pediatric drugs. I intercede to be far more practical and far more effective.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: Mr President, we have no doubt today that the behaviour of diseases and the response to treatments in children are clearly different from those of adults, so specific research and treatment are necessary. The Royal Decree of 2006 has produced significant progress, but I also believe there is almost consensus that we can improve and move forward. And I'd identify two main lines. One of these is the need for companies to comply with paediatric research plans in order to respond to this differentiation of diseases between adults and children. But more emphasis should also be placed on research into diseases that specifically affect children, especially in the field of oncology, where especially progress has been made. 80% of pediatric patients survive cancer today, but there is still a significant lack of knowledge about many of the diseases that affect them specifically. I think, Commissioner, that we need to revise this framework and provide assurance in this regard, both in the implementation of research plans and in the need to put in place fair incentives, aligned with priorities, transparent and, of course, giving rise to fair compensation. There is also a need for greater public funding, as well as a European network for research into the whole of these diseases.

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I am delivering this speech on behalf of my colleague, Dr Julia Reed. The Paediatric Regulation was adopted 10 years ago to ensure high-quality research into the development of medicines for children and appropriate authorisation of paediatric medicines. However, in 2013 several inadequacies were identified by the Progress Report adopted by the European Commission, especially with regard to paediatric oncology and neonatology. I appreciate that this motion for a resolution investigates this issue and that the development of a policy supporting paediatricians in improving children’s services is of major importance. I also agree with colleagues that children make up the most vulnerable part of the population and that research in the field of paediatric medicine should be given the same parity as adult health research.  We in UKIP are extremely concerned about the well-being and health of children. However, I firmly believe that this should and would be better done at national level. National parliaments should be the only entities entitled to legislate on this fundamental issue. Every Member State should shape policy and practices in order to provide high quality and sustainable healthcare services for all children in their own country.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Commissioner, the development, manufacture and use of medicinal products in general are a very professional sphere and also very sensitive, especially in relation to children's patients. The purpose of the 2006 Regulation is to promote the development of medicines for the children's population and to obtain new validated information on the properties of medicines intended for children and to obtain information on the use of of these drugs. The 2013 report on the implementation of this Regulation noted certain shortcomings and committed the Commission to adopt new measures. It turns out that so far the procedure is not fast enough. There is still a lack of information on the development of medicines, and also the development of these new medicines is not supported enough. I think the Commissioner has heard it repeatedly here. As my colleague, doctor Miroslav Mikulášik says, the child is not a diminished adult, therefore children need specific medicines adapted to their development and specific diseases. Commissioner, thank you for your response. But you hear from us repeatedly that we are not satisfied with the speed of the Commission's progress in this area. We ask you for greater deployment and support of research on pediatric medicines.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE).
text: — Mr President, the ambition of the regulation has been a real step forward, but without wanting to trivialise the progress that has been made, it must still be recognised that many, too many obstacles still persist. It is absolutely necessary to facilitate the accessibility of medicines to children, while at the same time providing adequate safeguards for safety verification. In some Member States, including my own, the reimbursement of a medicinal product for children is conditional on the statement in the package leaflet that it has been studied in the age groups concerned. It is therefore essential to encourage firms to study in children for the relevant molecules and indications. I insist that these should be relevant studies, as this should not lead to a blocking of the arrival of generic drugs, which also make it possible to alleviate budgets. Finally, pharmaceutical companies must, in a systematic manner, develop paediatric investigation plans. This is an essential condition for accelerating the development of treatments for children. We cannot despise this fundamental issue.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, there is a European indifference to paediatric medicines and paediatric research programmes, and there is an almost systematic postponement of paediatric studies. The European Union must ensure that medicines used to treat children meet the highest standards and undergo high-quality ethical research. In addition, the Union must ensure that all children have access to the necessary medication and vaccines they need. In Greece the deficiencies in paediatric medicines and vaccines are serious. The situation can have unforeseen consequences, as the shortages of children's vaccines, such as hepatitis B, in areas where there is a large number of refugees are particularly high. Especially in Lesvos there is a huge shortage, with pharmacists filing a complaint against the pharmaceutical company responsible for the distribution of medicines in Greece. So this is a serious issue and we must take steps to avoid risks to public health for citizens, especially children.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the regulation on paediatric medicines has helped to improve the overall situation by bringing tangible benefits for a number of childhood diseases, but many sectors reported no significant progress, particularly pediatric oncology and neonatology. Often, the legal requirement to pursue the development of medicines for pediatric use is not observed, as the drugs were developed under pathological conditions typical for adults, which do not Occurrence in children. There are therefore delays in starting clinical trials of cancer drugs for children because the drug is expected to show promise in adult cancer patients. We need a legislative review of this regulation which takes due consideration first of all the need to base paediatric development plans on a mechanism of action, not just the type of tumor, and secondly to ensure greater timeliness and achievability of pediatric survey plans. Lastly, special attention should be given to the system of incentives envisaged to stimulate research more effectively and respond more effectively to the needs of the pediatric population, ensuring that at the same time the transparency of the research and development process.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Mr La Via, I thank you because today we  have a good opportunity once again to discuss these very sensitive and very important issues. The health of our children is of vital importance. When they fall sick, we should aim to provide them with high-quality medicines. As you rightly said, Mr Mikolášik, children are without doubt not just small adults; they have their own specific needs. I appreciate Parliament’s initiative to raise this issue during the plenary session tonight. I have taken careful note of your comments and views, and I also think about Margot, whom you mentioned, Ms Grossetête. I also appreciate the Parliament’s comments to young people suffering from, for example, narcolepsy. Last Monday I met Members of the European Parliament, Mairead McGuinness and Jørn Dohrmann, together with patient representatives, to discuss this issue. Let me take this opportunity to express once again my sympathy towards all the patients and their families affected by this terrible condition. Remember, colleagues, we are in good time. Last year, in March, we launched European Reference Networks, and more than 300 hospitals voluntarily decided to create such a network. I disagree with those who argue that paediatric oncology is the competence of Member States. Can you imagine the possibility of treating rare diseases and rare paediatric cancers in the smallest countries where they do have enough medical expertise, clinical trials and possibilities to join with researchers? What can they do in Cyprus or in Lithuania, and so on? We need to understand that it is not possible to solve those questions at Member State level alone. No, we will push our resources, our clinical expertise and, of course, possibilities to properly manage the treatment of rare paediatric cancers, rare paediatric diseases and rare genetic diseases. There is no doubt. As Mr Mikolášik said, we must be very practical. I agree: we will do it this way. As you know, the Commission takes this issue very seriously and has taken a series of actions to ensure these possibilities and to do our best. Let me repeat: the Commission aims to provide this House and the Council in 2017 with a comprehensive report on the Paediatric Regulation which will serve as a solid basis for future discussions. Thank you once again for your interest.

name: Presidente. –
text: At the end of the debate I received a motion for a resolution in accordance with Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure. The vote will take place on Thursday 15 December 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – To watch an adult go through the pain and suffering of cancer is heart-breaking. However, to watch a child go through this pain is intolerable. 35 000 Children and young people are every year diagnosed with cancer in Europe. Every year in the European Union we lose 6 000 bright, young souls to this scourge. As Socialists and Democrats we are committed to continue working hard to help improve the quality of life of children with cancer and childhood cancer survivors.  This is why we firmly believe that it is extremely important for children with cancer to have access to new innovative therapies and drugs that can save their lives. The reality is that today there are limited innovative treatments because of the low profit margins in this area of research.  We call on the Commission to ensure there are enough funding provisions that support high-quality paediatric clinical research and on the Member States to concretely support research, development and the availability of medicinal products for paediatric use. This is our children’s lives that we are dealing with and we need to ensure that we do our utmost to provide them with the best possible therapies and medicines.
